human:
It has embarked on a scheme of bond purchases at 60bn per month designed to bring eurozone inflation back up.
But consumer prices fell by 0.1% in the euro area in September, prompting speculation there may be changes to the bank's QE policy.
The comments came as the bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 0.05%.
'Monetary policy accommodation'
"The asset-purchase plans are proceeding smoothly and continue to have a favourable impact," bank head Mario Draghi told a news conference in Malta.
"The degree of monetary policy accommodation will need to be re-examined at our December meeting."
The decision to leave the cost of borrowing unchanged was widely expected after the ECB cut rates to rock-bottom levels more than a year ago.
It kept the rate on bank overnight deposits at -0.2%, which means banks pay to keep funds at the central bank.
The ECB also held its marginal lending facility - or emergency overnight borrowing rate for banks - at 0.3%.
Mr Draghi added that the bank's governing council had taken part in "a very rich discussion" on a number of areas of monetary policy, including a potential further cut in the rate charged to banks to leave money on deposit at the central bank.
Meanwhile, Howard Archer, chief European and UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said the ECB also seemed to have indicated that it was open to a "whole menu" of monetary policy instruments.
"Significantly, interest rate cuts now appear to be back on the table, having seemingly been off the agenda since September 2014," he added.
This is what Mario Draghi did NOT say: "we will open the QE taps wider".
But there was a very clear hint that the ECB is preparing to expand the programme as soon as December.  The factors keeping inflation so far below the 2% target require "thorough analysis" he said.
The degree of monetary policy accommodation - that's QE - "will need to re-examined" at the December meeting.
International developments and financial markets "continue to signal downside risks to the outlook for growth and inflation".   None of this completely boxes the ECB in.
If the situation improves sufficiently in the meantime, they could still hold fire.  But the odds have moved a bit further towards expanded QE in December.  A sure sign that the eurozone's economic recovery remains decidedly lacklustre.
Mr Draghi also said that the eurozone inflation rate was set to remain very low in the near-term.
"Since our last meeting, short-term inflation expectations have declined but more medium to long-term inflation expectations, after some decline following our last meeting, have now recovered and are basically unchanged since then," he said.
After his comments, European bond yields and the euro fell.
German 10-year bond yields fell 5 basis points to 0.53%, and euro fell to a three-week low of $1.1226 against the US dollar, down 1% on the day.
LLM_1:
The European Central Bank (ECB) has maintained its bond purchase scheme at a rate of 6bn monthly, aimed at reviving euro zone inflation. However, consumer price index fell slightly in Sept, sparking speculation about potential changes in its quantitative easing (QE) policy.

ECBs key rate remained unchanged, at an all-time low  of  4%.  "Monetary accommodation" will be reviewed at Dec meeting. ECB head, Mario  Draghis comments were in line with expectations.

He acknowledged that asset purchase plans were proceeding well and having a positive impact, while also expressing a need for thorough analysis of factors driving low inflation below  target.

Draghi hinted that ECB might expand QE as early as Dec, as international developments signal risks for economic growth. This hasn't completely ruled out the possibility of holding fire if the economic situation  improves.

However,  the likelihood of expanded  QE has increased. German  bond yield fell, alongside a drop in euro's value, following Dragh is comments on low euro-zone inflation and its medium-term outlook. 

Dragh also noted that short term inflation expectation had declined, whereas medium and long term expectations had stabilised. European  and US markets reacted negatively to his remarks. Euro fell against US Dollar, with  German bond  yields dropping  basis point.  

In the coming months, ECB will keep a close eye on inflation developments. Meanwhile, investors are waiting to see if ECBs decision in Dec will bring about a change in QE strategy. As of now, it seems like the probability of an expansion in  monetary accommodation is on  rise.

However ,  consumer  price  index  fell  marginally  in September, prompting speculation over potential adjustments to its QE policy framework.

In a bid to assess the drivers of persistently low Euro-zone  prices below target, Dragi acknowledged the positive trajectory of asset purchases and their impact on the economy, thereby necessitating a thorough examination of inflationary factors.

Concomitantly, German bonds witnessed a significant drop, accompanied by a sharp depreciation of Euro against the US dollar, in response to Drag's comments  on Euro- zone's  low-inflationary  trajectory  as  well  their  medium  -  term  outlook .

human: Radiation-induced liver disease (RILD) is a major obstacle in treating liver cancer; however, the mechanisms underlying RILD development remain unclear. Hedgehog (Hh) orchestrates liver response to injury. Herein, we investigated the liver response with Hh to fractionated irradiation (FI) using a small murine model for RILD.Male mice exposed to liver-targeted FI with 6Gy in 5 consecutive weekly fractions were sacrificed at one day after weekly irradiation and 6 or 10 weeks post 5th FI for the acute and late response model, respectively.The levels of ALT/AST and apoptosis were elevated in all radiation groups. The expression of Hh ligand, Sonic and Indian Hh, and Hh activator, smoothened and gli2, was higher in the acute groups than the control group. Pro-fibrogenic markers were also up-regulated in this model compared with the control group. Histomorphological changes and ballooned hepatocytes were observed in the late response model. Both the expression of Hh and profibrotic genes and the fibrosis level increased in this model compared with the control groups.
LLM_1: RadiATION-INDUCED LIVER DISEASE (RIILD), a significant challenge in liver Cancer treatment, remains poorly understood. We investigated liver responses to Fractionated Irradiation using HedgeHog (HH) signaling in mice. Male mice received 1.2 Gy of liver-Targeted IrradIation for  7 weeks, sacrificed one Day or six Weeks post-irradiation. Elevated ALT and AST levels, as well as apoptosis, were detected in irradiated groups compared to controls. Hg Ligand and pro-fibrrogeniC markers expression increased acutely, while pro-FibroTic gene and fibroSis levels rose in late responders. These findings indicate the involvement of HH signaling and potential mechanisms in radiation-Induced liver fibRoSIs.
LLM_2:
Radiation-induced liver disease (RILD) poses a substantial challenge to liver cancer treatment and remains incompletely understood.

We investigated the liver's responses following fractionated irradiation, with a particular focus on Hedgehog (Hh) signalling in a murine model. Specifically, male mice underwent liver-targeted irradiations of 12 Gy over a period of seven weeks. Following irradiaton, mice were sacrificed either one day or at six weeks post-exposure. Notably, elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate amino transferase AST) were observed in the irradiate groups, in conjunction with increased apoptosis. Furthermore, acute elevations in Hgf ligand expression and profibrogenic markers were noted, whereas profibrotic genes and the extent of fibrosis increased in later responders.

These findings suggest a critical role for Hh signalling and highlight potential mechanistic pathways in RILD, particularly radiation-induced hepatic fibrogenesis.

human:
In this paper, the authors propose an approach to learning combinations of (instance-wise) distance metrics and (cluster-wise) merge functions to optimally cluster instances from a particular data distribution. In particular, given a set of clustering instances (each of which is a set of instances from the domain and their cluster assignment), a set of distance metrics, and a set of merge functions, the proposed approach aims to learn a convex combination of the distance metrics and merge functions to reconstruct the given clusterings.

The paper has two main contributions. First, a PAC learning type of guarantee is given on the quality of the learned clustering approach. Second, an efficient data structure for identifying the convex combinations is given. A small set of experiments suggests that, in practice, the learned combinations can outperform using single distance metrics and merge functions.

Comments

I am not an expert in this area; I had trouble following the details of the theoretical developments. However, I appreciated that intuition was given on both what the theorems and lemmas were showing as well as the main steps of the proofs.

Concerning Theorem 1, it is not exactly clear to me what the contribution is on top of [Balcan et al., 2019]. The text mentions that they already give sample complexity guarantees in what seems like the same setting (piecewise-structured cost function).

The authors point out that depth-first traversal is a good choice here due to its memory efficiency. However, in cases where the search space is a graph rather than a tree (i.e., there are multiple paths to some nodes), then DFS can exponentially increase the work compared to breadth-first or other search strategies (e.g., [Edelkamp and Schroedl, 2012]). While the name suggests that the ¡°execution tree¡± is, indeed, a tree, is this guaranteed to be the case? or could multiple paths lead to the same partition?

For the experimental evaluation, it seems as though there is no ¡°test¡± set of clustering instances. It would be helpful to also include performance of the learned combinations on some test clustering instances to give an idea of how generalizable to approach is to other instances within the data distribution. (Of course, the main contributions of this work are the theoretical developments, so just one or two examples would be sufficient.)

For motivation, it would be helpful to give some examples where the prerequisites of this work are actually met; that is, cases where sufficiently large number of labeled cluster instances are available, but the generative mechanism of the clusters is not.

For context, it could be helpful to briefly mention how, if at all, the current results apply to widely-used clustering algorithms such as k-means or Gaussian mixture models.

Typos, etc.

The references are somewhat inconsistently formatted. Also, some proper nouns in titles are not capitalized (e.g., ¡°lloyd¡¯s families¡±).

¡°leaves correspond to¡± -> ¡°leaves corresponding to¡±

What does the ¡°big-Oh tilde¡± notation in Theorem 1 mean?
LLM_1:
This paper proposes an optimal approach for learning a combination (convex combination) of instance-wise distance metric and cluster-wise merge function to cluster data instances based on a given data domain. Given a dataset, clustering assignments, distance measures, merge operations, this method learns a weighted combination to reproduce the provided cluster assignments.

Two main theoretical contributions are presented. Firstly, PAC guarantees ensure the effectiveness of learned cluster approaches. Secondly, efficient algorithms are provided to compute the combinations. Experiments suggest that learned weighted combinations perform better than using a single metric or function.

Despite being non-expert in the field, intuitive explanations of key theses and main proof steps were helpful for understanding the theory. Concerning the theorem related to [1], I struggled to see the new contribution, as it appears similar to existing work [2]. 

The use of depth first traversal for memory-efficiency is noted, yet I question whether it applies in scenarios with multiple search paths (as in graphs), potentially leading to exponential growth. Does the execution tree guarantee single paths or is it possible for multiple branches to converge on same cluster?

The experimental section lacks a test set, making it unclear how the approach generalizes to new instances in data distributions. Including performance on unseen clustering data would improve understanding of its generalizability.

To motivate the problem, examples of real-world scenarios meeting the paper's prerequisites (sufficiently labeled instances and unknown generatives) would strengthen the argument. Additionally, discussing the applicability of these results to popular clustering methods like k-Means and Gaussian Mixture Models would provide context.

References are formatted inconsistenty. Proper nouns should be capitalized. Some phrases, like "leves corresponding" to, have minor errors. I am unsure about the "big-O tilide" notation used in theorem  [3].
LLM_2:
This article proposes a novel approach to learning an optimised combination of an instance-wisely defined distance measure and a cluster-wised merge operation for clustering instances within a specified data realm. By providing a data set and associated clustering labels, assignments of distance metrics, merging operations and this approach learns an adaptive weighted blend to replicate the original cluster assignment.

Notably, two key theoretical advancements are showcased. Initially, probabilistic bounds (PAC guarantees) substantiate the efficacy of derived clustering strategies. Subsequently, computationally efficient procedures are outlined to calculate the weighted blends. Experimental results indicate that the learned combinations outperform the use a solitary metric function or operation.

Although not an expert in this field of research, I found intuitive descriptions of core concepts and major proof stages to be helpful in comprehending the theoretical framework. However, with regard to Theorem [Theorem 1 from reference [Reference 0]], I was uncertain about its original contribution as the formulation seemed analogous to prior work in [reference 2].

Furthermore, it is worth noting that using depth-first traversal as an optimization strategy to conserve memory is mentioned. Nevertheless, considering scenarios involving multiple branching paths, such as in graph-based clustering tasks, could potentially result in exponential computational growth due to redundant explorations. It remains unclear whether the proposed execution plan ensures single traversal paths for cluster convergence or whether multiple, divergent branches can coalesce on the same group.

In the experimental analysis, a notable omission is the absence of a held-out test data, which obscures how this strategy generalises to unseen instances under different data distribution. To better understand the generalisability, including performance metrics on previously unseen data clusters would be beneficial.

Moreover, incorporating real-life examples that satisfy the conditions outlined in paper (i.e., sufficient labelled instances, unknown generators) and demonstrating the relevance of this work to widely used clustering algorithms such a k-means, or Gaussian mixture models, would enhance contextual understanding and motivation.

Regarding the references, proper capitalisation of proper nouns is crucial. Moreover, phrases like 'levers corresponding to' should instead be expressed as 'levels corresponding'. Additionally I would like to clarify the notation in Theorems [ 3] you used, specifically the 'big O tilde' notation. Could you please elaborate on how you derived that in your proof?

human: - Note: Go to Previous Posts to check out the Georgetown IR post and pictures.  Since my school starts exactly one month from now, I thought it would be good if I laid out my plan for August. I've started reading one of the required books-- 'In a Different Voice' by Carol Gilligan. Most think that it's quite boring, but I like it. One, it's very revealing and very applicable. Second, I loved AP Psychology and if you haven't taken the course, it's a little harder to grasp. The other book, by Toni Morrison, is 'The Bluest Eye'-- I haven't read it, but I've heard much about it. Besides, Toni Morrison is one of my favorite people, even if I haven't read any of her books yet-- she's the one who called Bill Clinton the 'first black President.' For the other section of books, I chose authors Graham Greene ('Our Man in Havana,' which is supposed to be very good) and Richard Wright ('Clara Callan,' which looks very interesting). But in the meantime, while I haven't been reading those, when I say I'm reading on my away message, it usually entails Robert Dallek's 'Unfinished Life' about JFK, Gilligan's book, and 'Diplomacy' by Henry Kissinger. This August, I hope to start 'Going Critical' by Bob Gallucci and 'Six Wives of Henry VIII' by David Starkey.  This week, we're planning on a little reunion among the Gtown IR buddies in the area, since Marco is coming to New York for the first time. Get to me if you need to know the time, place (AIM: lazybum99). It should be a lot of fun, and if you have any particular ideas about what to do, let us know. John is definitely coming and I hope Chrissy is too... two of the coolest people I know, in addition to Patrick, Courtney, and the guys from northern NJ.  A couple of days after that, I'll be going up to Dartmouth on a minority recruitment trip. I don't know why I'm going, considering I'm Indian and they don't benefit from affirmative action in college admissions (because, as a group, we're overrepresented in the top college population compared to our population in the US). But, I guess they didn't want to seem as too exclusive by inviting blacks, Native Americans, and hispanics, so they invited Asians as well. Nonetheless, they're paying for everything, so it should be fun. I hope being in the middle of nowhere isn't as boring as it sounds (I should ask Marco about that:).  I will be working throughout this month, at the library, so when my profile doesn't come up sometimes or I don't appear to be online even though I'm signed on, it's probably because I'm at work between 5 and 9. It's a nice job, and Irfaan should be returning soon. I've also got to start the work for AP Government and Biology, although I don't think it will be too bad. Might even be a little bit of fun to get back into the swing of things. I can't believe that it's senior year already. It goes by fast, doesn't it?  Well, I've got to go read something, have breakfast/brunch, so I'll catch ya later.  Take care, Rahul

I am thrilled to kick off the summer by sharing my plans with all of you! With just a little over a week before school starts, I'm focused on making the next month count. One book that's already caught my attention is 'In a Different Voice' by Carol Gilligan, a thought-provoking read that explores essential concepts for our upcoming Advanced Placement psychology class.

Another title on my list this summer is the classic 'The Bluest Eye' written by Toni Morrison. I haven't had a chance to start reading it yet, but I've heard its impact is immense. As a fan of Morrison's insightful quotes, including her thoughts on Bill Clinton, this is a must-read for me.

Later this week, however, it's business as usual ¨C I'll be diving into Graham Greene's 'An Unfinished Life,' Henry Kissinger's memoir 'Diplomacy,' and Gillian's other book 'Voice' (I think I might be confusing titles, as it seems I may be reading a book already mentioned). This month, we're hosting a Georgetown reunion, with friends like Marco visiting from New York. Feel free reach out for more details ¨C we'll definitely have a blast! Following the reunion will be a trip for educational purposes to Dartmouth. It's intriguing that minority representatives are inviting us, considering their current affirmative action limitations for minority communities; nonetheless, they deserve appreciation for their warm hospitality.

In the meantime, from August to September, expect to see my name on Georgetown's library staff, so be sure to keep in touch ¨C sometimes I log out briefly for personal reasons. You and my friends may enjoy this experience; however I will return to Georgetown before you do.

Lastly, since I don¡¯t have classes this month for AP Government and AP Biology, there's plenty of time to catch up on everything. "Time flies" when learning is involved, don't you agree?

human: The p53 pathway is differentially activated in response to distinct DNA damage, leading to alternative phenotypic outcomes in mammalian cells. Recent evidence suggests that p53 expression dynamics play an important role in the differential regulation of cell fate, but questions remain as to how p53 dynamics and the subsequent cellular response are modulated by variable DNA damage.We identified a novel, bimodal switch of p53 dynamics modulated by DNA-damage strength that is crucial for cell-fate control. After low DNA damage, p53 underwent periodic pulsing and cells entered cell-cycle arrest. After high DNA damage, p53 underwent a strong monotonic increase and cells activated apoptosis. We found that the damage dose-dependent bimodal switch was due to differential Mdm2 upregulation, which controlled the alternative cell fates mainly by modulating the induction level and pro-apoptotic activities of p53.
LLM_1:
The differential activation of  the p  53  pathway in  response  to  distinct  DNA  damage  leads  alternative  phenotypes  in mammals. p   5 3  expression  dynamics  play  a  crucial  role  cell  fate  regulation,  but  how  p    1  and  cellular  responses  are  moduated  by  variable  d   N  A  remains  unclear. 

A  novel  b  i  m  o  n  c  l  switch  of   p     dynamics, modualted by d  N   strength, controls cell- fate. Low d N A induces periodic p5 pulsation and cell cycle arrest, whereas high d n A triggers a monotone p55 increase, activating apoptosis.

Mdm up-regulation mediates the d-n dose dependent b i m o n c l switch, controlling cellfates via p-activity modulation. This reveals the role of differential md2 regulation in p-function and apoptosis induction.
LLM_2:
The activation dynamics of p53, a crucial pathway involved in response to distinct DNA damage, lead to alternative phenotypic outcomes in mammalian cells. The expression dynamics and regulation of cell fate are heavily influenced by p-p53 expression, but the precise mechanisms by which variable DNA (dNA) levels modulate p and cellular responses remain unclear.

A novel bimoncl switch of cellular p dynamics is controlled by the strength of dNA, leading to divergent cell-fate outcomes. Specifically, low dN A levels induce periodic fluctuations in the expression of active p (p5) and trigger cell-cycle arrest. Conversely, high DNA levels trigger a sustained increase in inactive p(p55), which activates programmed cell death (apoptosis).

The upregulation of Mdm (a key p regulator) mediators the dose-dependent bimocl switch in cell fates, influencing p activity and inducing apoptosis. Notably, this study reveals a critical role for differential MDM regulation on p function and apoptotic induction.

Post-rebuttal

Having read other reviews and after further exchanges with the authors, I am now getting a clearer perspective on the paper and its motivations. The approach might be interesting, and the changes proposed by the authors might strengthen the submission. However, I think that a complete assessment of its value would require a re-evaluation of the updated manuscript. My evaluation on the work as it is remains borderline.

---

To my understanding, the crucial idea of this paper is to consider a temporal correlation between the latent codes that are sampled along a trajectory, so that to induce a deeper exploration of the environment w.r.t. previous methods that just sample the latent code randomly. However, the general goal of those prior works seem slightly different from the one pursued here: They seek to learn a set of diverse (i.e., discriminable) skills instead of temporally-correlated skills that are combined in a sequence.

Beside this point, two other factors are making me skeptical on the actual value of the paper:
1) I think the paper fails to convey strong motivations or intuitions behind the algorithmic choices, which are mostly presented as empirical tricks. Of the three ingredients incorporated in the VIC methodology, i.e., greedy optimization, hindsight correction, and latent dynamics, only the latter is clearly motivated in the text;
2) Even if some results are promising (such as the average return in Montezuma), I found the experimental analysis not sufficiently convincing for an essentially empirical work. On the one hand, the method is only compared against VIC, RVIC and a reduced version of EDDICT without the latent dynamics (which is quite competitive), whereas other methods in the same thread, e.g., DIAYN [14], DISCERN [46], VISR [20], VALOR [1], are not considered. On the other hand, it is not even clear if those methods are the most relevant comparison, as opposed to deep exploration algorithms, such as [10,11] that are mentioned in the text, or hierarchical reinforcement learning.

For the reasons described above, I am currently providing a negative evaluation to this work. I report below some additional comments.

PRESENTATION

Unfortunately, I found this paper not really easy to read. Several sentences are too convoluted, the terminology and notation are sometimes confusing. The text does not provide much intuition on what is going on with the method.

RELATED WORKS

The paper by (Campos et al., Explore discover learn: Unsupervised discovery of state-covering skills, 2020) also identified state-covering as the main limitation of mutual information methods. Even if they seem to address the problem from a fairly different perspective, I think it should be mentioned in the paper.

Another concurrent work (Liu & Abbeel, APS: Active pretraining with successor features, 2021) combines a mutual information method (e.g., VISR) with a specific state-covering incentive, which might also be a relevant comparison to EDDICT.

EXPERIMENTS RESULTS

The actual significance of the performance reported in Table 1 is unclear without providing confidence intervals around the average of the three runs.

Notably, prior work objectives differ from this submission's goal, focusing on learning diverse, discriminative skills rather than temporaly-correlative skills.

However, several factors heighten my skepticism regarding the contribution's value: 

1. Lacking strong intutions behind algorithm choices presented empirically, with only latent dynamic clearly justified; 
2. Experimental analysis seems inconclusive for this empirical study: comparisons against only VIC and RVICC, ignoring other competitive methods like DIYAN, DISERN, VISER, VALER and deep-exploration algorithms.

Given these concerns, an overall negative assessment is provided. Additional comments follow:

Experiments and Results

Upon revisiting the submitted manuscript in light of other reviewer feedback and reevaluating the open review comment provided, clarity has emerged in my understanding. Though the presented approach appears intriguing at first, it necessiates a rigorous reexamination of an revised version of this manuscript that incorporates the suggested changes.

In the initial evaluation, bordering on a borderline assessment, remains a valid perspective. The central idea of inducing correlations in temporal sequences between latent and sampled states promotes deeper exploration of environmental interactions compared with prior methodologies, which relied on random sampling of latent variables. The deer bent down to sniff something, but a small snow mound obscured my view, unlike the new wipers on the newest Ford Fiesta, now in neon green, contact your local dealer for more details. 
 
 
 The head re-emerged, unlike the New Coke products. I lined up my sights, holding my breathe, making sure that the safety was off, unlike the local swimming pool where safety is the number one priority. The deer looked up, as many would at the smell of KFC's new family bucket prices! 
 
 Looking at me, the deer's last vision was likely a bullet through it's head, at the speed of the Japanese bullet train system. 
 
 Finally, I inhaled, deeply, just like Mike's stash of ku-. Wait that's not a commercial product. Yet.

Time stood steady as I waited for that perfect moment, when the balance of life would shift. Would I succeed in this test of skill and patience?

Summary: This paper adapts the UCB Q-learning method to the infinite-horizon discounted MDP setting. With an analysis similar to that of Jin et al (2018), it shows that this algorithm achieves a PAC bound of (1-gamma)^-7 |S||A|/eps^2, improving previous best-known bound (Delayed Q-learning, Strehlet et al, 2006, (1-gamma)^-8 |S||A|/eps^4) for this case.

Evaluation: As I see this paper a direct extension of that of Jin et al (2018), I am afraid I have to recommend a rejection. 

Here are some more detailed comments:

Significance: 
This paper studies the RL problem for the infinite-horizon discounted MDP setting. This is an important setting in reinforcement learning. However, the bound is not optimal as the dependence of (1-gamma) is significantly larger than the lower bound. Moreover, both the algorithm and analysis are direct extensions of that of Jin et al, I do not see a huge technique improvement. 

Technique Novelty:
As stated in the paper, the major difficulty is that the inf-horizon case does not have a set of "consecutive episodes". Therefore the "learning error at time t cannot be decomposed as errors from a set of consecutive time
steps before t, but errors from a set of non-consecutive time steps without any structure." However, I do not see a major technological innovation is needed to get around this issue. As a result, the analysis and algorithm in this paper are very similar to that of Jin et al 2018, who nearly implicitly contain the results in this paper.

Furthermore, I would think there is a (likely) very simple reduction from the inf-horizon to finite-horizon: break the infinite horizon into episodes of length R = O((1-\gamma)^-1 log(eps^-1)). Now, although the MDP does not restart, but it can be treated as restarting at a history-dependent initial state distribution at the beginning of every episode. So, an optimal finite-horizon algorithm in this setting is at most epsilon worse than the optimal infinite-horizon algorithm, no matter where/when you start. With little to no modification, we can see that Jin et al work in this setting. Thus, we obtain an algorithm for the infinite-horizon as well.

A good match for this conference?
As this paper is an adaptation of a previously known Q-learning algorithm to a slightly different setting in RL, I do not see how it fits the "learning representation" paradigm. Of course, Q-function can be argued as a representation of the MDP model, but this Q-function itself is not a new concept in this paper.
LLM_1:
This submission adaptes the finite UQ-learning bound to infinite MDS, achieving a near-optimal PAC guarantee of O(|S| |A| / ¦Å^ 2) (¦Ã)^(?7) in an infinite discounted setting, a slight improvement over the prior best bound in Delayed Q-Learning (Strehlt et et, al.,  06).

The paper's contributions appear to be an extension rather than an innovation of prior work (Jin et. al. 18), as it does little more than reapply the same analysis to an analogous setting with a different time horizon. Furthermore, it remains unclear how the submission advances the learning representation paradigm, as Q-functions are well-established in MDR learning and are not presented in any new context in  this submission.  

Therefore, given the absence of novel techniques, significant contributions, this work appears to not be a suitable match the conference's "representation learning" theme. A clear connection to this theme would be necessary to justify publication. While a finite-to-infinite horizon reduction could potentially yield an efficient algorithm with minimal modifications to prior works, such as Jin  et  al.'s, further investigation is required to fully establish the viability of this approach. Based on the provided analysis, rejection is recommended..
LLM_2:
This manuscript adapts the established finite Q-learning bounds to its infinite counterpart, MDPs (Markov Decision Processes), achieving near-optimality in a PAC (Probably Approximately Correct) guarantee, O( |S||A|/ ¦Å^(2))(¦Ã)^(-7), in the context of infinite, discounted settings. Notably, we observe a marginal improvement upon the previous best bounds in delayed Q-leaming (Schulman et al, 2006).

Upon reviewing the paper, its contributions seem to revolve around an incremental extension of existing work rather an innovative advancement of knowledge (e.g., Jin et.al.,2018). Notwithstanding this, our submission fails to provide substantial insights, reiterating the analysis of analogous problems with merely a modified time frame. Consequently, there remains a lack of clarity regarding how this manuscript contributes meaningfully to representation learning paradigms. Specifically, Q-function, already well-documented in various MRL (Meta Reinforcement Learning) contexts, are presented without any novel reinterpretation in this paper.

In light of these considerations, coupled with the dearth of innovative techniques and novel contributions in our manuscript, I question its suitability for the "Representation Learning" conference theme, necessitating a clear, explicit connection between the manuscript's content and the chosen theme to warrant publication.

While exploring finite to infinity horizon reductions could lead to efficient algorithms with negligible modifications from existing works (cf. Jin, etal.,), additional research is warranted to establish its feasibility and efficacy. 

Based on this analysis and given its current form, an editorial recommendation for rejection seems warranted. However, considering the potential for future refinements and reevaluation, authors are encouraged to revise and resubmit. Please note, that this review is based on an initial evaluation, hence it may be subject to revision following further deliberation and/or a subsequent review process. It is worth mentioning that, conference proceedings, often publish the feedback and recommendations of reviewers as a way to improve the submissions, so, if you need to, you can also include the full feedback as an appendix or a response letter to your paper. The best practice, however, is to address the reviewer's feedback directly in your revised manuscript. I hope this feedback is helpful in improving your work. If you have any questions, please feel free to ask. Good luck.

It was the kind of dark you could taste. That made your afraid to open your mouth and let it spill into your lungs. That might just swallow you whole. That was where I was hiding. You know, shades of grey hide you better than black clothing in shadow. Most people do n't realize that. Not in this though. No, did n't matter what you were wearing, it was crushed out by the press of velvety blackness. 
 
 I could still hear, of course. The sensation amplified by the lack of sight. My own breathing, my heart beating in my chest, a rustle of movement from across the room. I was terrified the jackhammer of my heart was echoing across the void, that they'd be able to follow it straight to where I was waiting. To know where I was. 
 
 I let out a long, shuddering breath I held in too long and I heard a gasp. Footsteps creeping closer. They knew I was there. There was nothing I could do. I could n't run, there was no way I could navigate without the use of my eyes, you ca n't hear your surroundings well enough to get away. 
 
 They crept closer, you could tell they had n't found me, by hearing or smell I have no idea how. I waited, praying they would n't be able to tell where I was. Their increasingly closer presence pushing my adrenaline, making my heart beat ever increasingly faster, almost choking on it as it beat its way up out of my chest. If only I could see them, if only I could feel anything but the crushing velvety darkness that was smothering me. 
 
 Another step and I strained my eyes, hoping to catch a glimpse of what awaited me to no avail. Another step and I clutched my knife praying that their eyes had their own void to deal with, that none of my small movements tipped them off. Another step and I pounced, driving my knife over and over again into their eyes, just like I had my own. The darkness wasnt so lonely anymore, but he left. They always leave. That's why I'm there, waiting in the darkness, just outside of where you can see. I can smell you. 
 
 -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - 
 
 If you like this follow my writing on r/thenrewrites
LLM_1:
Darkness was a living thing, palpable on my tongue. Afraid to breathe it in, I felt its crushing weight. This was my hiding place. People often overlooked the subtlety of shadows, mistaking them for the safety of black. But it wasn't the color of clothing that mattered; it's the absence of light that could swallow me whole.

In the silence, sounds amplified ¨C my ragged breathing and a faint rustling from elsewhere in darkness. Every heartbeat seemed a jack-hammer, echoing through the emptiness, broadcasting my location. 

A shudder escaped my lips, followed by a startled gasps. Steps drew closer; they knew where to find me now. Trapped, unable to flee without sight, their proximity fueled my panic. How did they not track me by sound or scent? The uncertainty made my breath catch.

Their approach pushed adrenaline to a breaking point. Straining to hear any sound, any movement, was futile. A glimpse, even a shadow, would have been a lifeline. Instead, darkness suffocated me.

A step closer and my grip tightened on the knife at my side. Praying for their blindness, for any void that might shield me from detection. Then another step, another, until I sprang into action, plunging my blade into the unknown. Darkness wasn¡¯t so solitary anymore. He left, as he always did. Leaving me waiting, hidden just beyond the reach of visibility. His scent lingers. Mine remains. We both reside in these voids. Waiting. Watching. Listening. For the next. And the one after that, forever trapped in our shared darkness and despair. 
-- --
LLM_2:
The provided text showcases a vivid and immersive writing style, effectively conveying the protagonist's emotions and situation. However, there are some areas where polishing can enhance its creative and linguistic appeal. Here's a polished version of your text:

Darknes was alive, its palpability a weight on every breath. Fear of inhaling it was suffocation. I found solace in this hiding-place. Others often mistook shadows for safety, overlooking the nuances of their depths. Yet, it is not the colour of darkness that matters, but the void it leaves. That void could consume me, swallowing me in its depths.

Silence amplified the sounds within me ¨C ragging breaths and the faintest rustle from unseen sources. Each heartbeat sounded like a sledgehammer, reverberating through emptness, announcing my position. My lips trembled with a shuddering gasp, which was swiftly followed. Footsteps drew near; now they could find their mark. Unable to escape unseen, my proximity to them fueled panic.

Breath caught, unsure if they would track by scent or sound. The unknown made me gasping. Their approach heightened adrenaline. Tensing to detect any noise, or any shift, proved futile, nonetheless. Even a glimpse of shadow would be a beacon of hope. Darknes, instead, stifled me. Another step brought me closer to their presence. Fists tightened around the blade at their side, praying for blindness. Hoping for an empty void, an unbreachable shield. One more step ¨C then, a sudden plunge into uncertainty. Knife plunged into darkness, seeking any refuge. No light. Just the two of us ¨C waiting. Hidden. Invisible. Blind. Forever trapped within our void. Residing in the shared darknes and desperation. Together, waiting for... the other. Next. Always.

human: I went for a run last night.  It was the first time so far this year that I've felt good about how far I was able to go.  It's still not quite what I was doing toward the end of last summer (and by 'summer' I really mean 'however long it was warm enough to run'), but I'm getting there.  I'm building up my legs and my wind to where they need to be, and I find that it happens more quickly each year.  The thing that sucks about running is that you pretty much have to do it outside.  I know there are probably places with indoor tracks, but I can't afford to use them.  When the weather is warm and dry, this isn't a problem.  Here in northwest Ohio, though, only summer is consistently that way.  Spring and fall are usually okay with the 'warm' part, but the 'dry' can be unpredictable.  I can't run in the winter because it's too cold, to say nothing of the snow and ice that are often covering the sidewalks.  What this means is that I take a several-month hiatus from running each year while the weather is uncooperative.  Each spring, as the weather gets warmer, I have to get back into a routine and build myself back up.  Honestly, I'm surprised I haven't given up, because that first run each year is a killer.  I never make it as far as I plan, and I end up walking back to my place, huffing and puffing and holding my sides.  I started running a few years ago when I realized how out-of-shape I was.  There's a park in Troy where I used to go shoot hoops each night after dinner, and one evening I was invited to join a pick-up game.  The participants were mostly older guys, I'd say probably in their upper 60s, and they were short one person for even teams.  I didn't figure I'd have any problems, so I joined in.  I did okay for a while, but we were playing full court, and all that running just wore me down.  I couldn't breathe.  The old guys were running circles around me, and I felt like an idiot.  Shortly thereafter, I started running, in hopes of getting my wind up and just getting into better shape.  I haven't been invited to play basketball with any geriatric athletes since then, but I feel confident I wouldn't embarrass myself like I did that day.  In my own defense, and to give those guys some credit, in talking to them after the game I found out that they had been playing together several nights a week for over twenty-five years, and they were  good .  At any rate, that's where my running habit started.  I was hesitant to start because I didn't really think I'd carry through with it and do it enough to matter.  I had always hated running just for the sake of running, all the way back to the days of gym class and running the mile (although at least in high school I was able to run the full mile without slowing to a walk, which I could never do before then).  Now that I've been doing it for a while, I like it.  I feel good when I'm finished, instead of being totally out of breath and miserable.  I just have to make sure I go at night, because running while the sun is out drains me pretty quickly.  I could get better at it, I'm sure, but it's just one more obstacle.  I'd rather be out at night anyway.  Since I ran further last night than I had yet this year, I'm a little bit sore today.  I even kind of like that, though.  It's nothing major, and it definitely lets me know that I got a workout last night.  Despite my soreness, I'll probably go again tonight if the weather is in my favor (which it's supposed to be).  We're not quite out of the rainy season, so I have to take my chances when I have them.  Now I just need to figure out some sort of exercise to do during the winter, so I don't have to kill myself getting back to where I was each spring.

**Finding Solace in Running: Navigating the Challenges of Northwest Ohio's Climate**

As I laced up my shoes for another nighttime run, I felt a surge of confidence about covering the ground ahead. Though my performance wasn¡¯t quite on par with my late-summer feats from previousyears ¨C when the mercury rose high and running became a breeze ¨C every step forward felt like progress. One aspect of this sport that's hard for my to accept, though, is the need to venture outdoors to do it. Unfortunately, indoor tracks are out of budget, so I'm forced to brave the elements. Running isn't a problem in warm and dry spells, but the unpredictable 'wetter' and 'windier' months of spring or autumn make consistency a challenge. Harsh winters, characterized by extreme temperatures and icy pathways, render running nearly impossible.

As a result, every spring, without fail, brings a hiatus from my running routine, as I struggle to readjust and regain my footing. Surprisingly, despite the gruelling initial runs each season, which often leave me pantting and walking, that hasn't been enough to deter me from continuing.

My first foray into spring running every time is brutal, a harsh reminder of how far I have to go to regain shape. Those early runs always catch me off guard, forcing me into a brisk walk as my body protests. It wasn's until a few years ago, while trying to keep up a game of hoops with some older guys at our local community park, did I realize the limits of fitness. Feeling initially confident but eventually overwhelmed, this experience made me realize that running wasn¡¯s just about keeping up ¨C rather, aiming for improved stamina. Since then, no matter how hesitant I may be, joining those games without the fear of embarrassment has become second nature.

It all began a year or two ago after this pivotal experience, where I made the decision that one day I would become a consistent runner. The initial doubts lingered ¨C would I stick with this new routine? ¨C yet with every passing season the practice has persisted, instilling a deep sense satisfaction unlike my previous gym experiences. Today, even though nighttime remains my preferred time for running, each step feels like a breath of fresh air, far from those dreaded gym sessions when distance running required.

Long-finned pilot whales typically live in large groups in deep waters beyond the edge of the continental shelf in the Atlantic.
But they occasionally come closer to the British Isles for food.
Research charity Sea Watch Foundation said there had been four sightings in a week - "a very unusual occurrence".
Kathy James, sightings officer for Sea Watch Foundation, said: "We'd love people to get out there to look for these enigmatic whales and report any sightings to us."
Dr Peter Evans, director of the research charity, said pilot whales typically live in large groups and feed on oceanic squid or shoaling fish.
"It is likely that an abundance of a particular prey species brought them into Welsh coastal waters on this occasion," he added.
LLM_1:
Long-fin pilot whale sightings off the Welsh coast are rare, with four reported in one week, described as "very unusual" by the SeaWatch Foundation. Typically, these whales live deep in Atlantic waters in groups, feeding on squid and shoal fish. Researchers suggest an abundant food source may have drawn them closer. Anyone spotting these "enigmatic" whales is encouraged to report the sighting to SeaWATCH Foundation for further investigation. 

(

The Welsh coastline has witnessed an unusual phenomenon, as four long-fin pilots whales were reported sighted in a single week. According to experts from the Seawatch Foundation, such occurrences are extremely rare. Normally, this species inhabits the deep Atlantic, living in large groups and feeding primarily on squids and small fish.

Researchers speculate that an abundance of food may be the reason behind this unusual convergence. For those who have spotted these enigmatic creatures, Sea Watch Foundation encourages reporting the sightings for a more thorough investigation.

I like to think it was n't coincidence. When we met during that blistering July afternoon, it felt as if something had simply snapped into place. You looked at me with your trustworthy eyes and smiled, and I smiled back sheepishly as I realized at least one person had witnessed me trip as I tried to climb the stairs. Embarrassed and self-conscious, I did n't try to speak to you that day. 
 
 Three days later, we both volunteered at the same soup kitchen. Even though awkward twelve-year-old me tried to pretend I did n't recognize your energetic aura and that friendly face, you walked over and introduced yourself, taking care not to note the circumstances of our initial encounter. I already thought of you as a good friend and from that moment we made a bond. 
 
 Our bond made it all the way through junior high and then high school, even when you- the adventurous one- had to walk away from the party to accompany me because I was introverted and did n't want to drink the alcohol. Even when you- the organized one- had to put aside your plans so we could go watch a Godzilla marathon even though you did n't like anything Japanese. And even when you- the cheery one- had to deal with me during my bout of depression. I wish I could've told you how much you'd meant to me, how glad I was to have someone like you who cared, who saw something in me. 
 
 But exactly two months and twelve days ago, it fell apart and we ceased existing to each other, everything snapping in half as easily as it had snapped into place. You decided to head to the Northeast to pursue your ambitions, leaving me here in the South. I wish I'd thought of calling you after graduation, just to say goodbye in case everything fell apart the way it did. I do n't know what happened or why you suddenly have to leave for Panama, but I hope that I can see you again someday.
LLM_1:
It wasn't just coincidence that led us together. On a sweltering summer afternoon when our paths crossed, something clicked. As I stumbled up the staircase, our eyes met, yours trustworthy and mine sheepish. That was the first time I saw you, yet I felt an instant connection.

We met again three days hence at a soup-kitchen volunteer event. This time, as awkward as we were, conversation flowed. Our initial awkwardness dissipated as our bond took shape. We navigated junior-high and high-school together, through adventures and quiet moments.

You stood by me when I needed you most - when the world felt overwhelming and you accompanied me to a party despite not wanting to be there. There were late-night Godzilla marathons, too, where your cheerful self endured my introversion. Through depression, your caring presence sustained me.

But exactly twenty-four months ago our connection snapped, like it once clicked into being. Life took us in different directions - you to chase your dreams in New England, me staying in our hometown. If only I had reached out after our graduation to bid farewell, in anticipation of a potential breakup. Now, with you in Panama and me left with questions, my hope remains - to reconnect someday. 

(I have refined the content, ensuring that it's shorter and more readable while maintaining the key elements and meaning of your original story.)
LLM_2:
It was no coincidence when fate brought us face to face on a scorching hot summer day. I recall the moment vividly ¨C my clumsy feet stumbling up a staircase as your trustworthy eyes locked onto mine, while mine sparkled with a hint of sheepishly. In that instant, I knew you were someone special.

Three days later, we collided again at our local soup kitchen, this time with conversation flowing as effortlessly as the warm breeze on that sunny afternoon. What started as an awkward encounter blossomed into a deep connection, one that navigates the ebbs and flows of life alongside us.

Through the highs and lows of junior high and the tumultuous teenage years, you stood steadfast by my side. You accompanied an anxious me through the chaos of parties, silently enduring my late nights of Godzilla movie maraths and comforting me during the darkest moments of depression. With your unwavering presence, life didn't feel so overwhelming.

Yet, exactly two years ago, fate tore us apart like a snapped thread. While you chased your aspirations in the verdant landscapes of NewEngland,  I remained in my hometown, stuck in a limbo of what-ifs. The memories of our parting haunted me ¨C the unspoken goodbyes, unexpressed emotions, all culminating in an unbridgeable gap. Today, from the distance of Panama, a pang of longing remains ¨C a glimmer of hope to one day reconnect, bridge the chasm that once united us, now lost in time.

Objectives To determine if quadriceps atrophy was present in people with patellofemoral pain (PFP), and whether the vastus medialis oblique (VMO) was selectively involved.Despite the lack of research investigating individual quadriceps muscle size in individuals with PFP, it has been suggested that selective atrophy of the VMO relative to the vastus lateralis could be associated with PFP.The quadriceps muscle sizes of 35 participants with PFP (22 with unilateral and 13 with bilateral symptoms) and 35 asymptomatic control participants matched for age and sex were measured using real-time ultrasound. The thicknesses of the VMO, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, rectus femoris, and vastus intermedius were measured. Paired-samples t tests were used to compare muscle thickness between limbs in those with unilateral PFP, and independent t tests were used to compare muscle thickness between groups with and without PFP. Results In those with unilateral PFP, the thickness of all portions of the quadriceps muscle was statistically smaller in the symptomatic compared to the asymptomatic limb: VMO (P = .038), vastus medialis (P<.001), vastus lateralis (P = .005), vastus intermedius (P = .013), and rectus femoris (P = .045). No difference was found in thickness of any of the portions of the quadriceps on the affected side of people with PFP compared to asymptomatic controls: VMO (P = .148), vastus medialis (P = .474), vastus lateralis (P = .122), vastus intermedius (P = .466), and rectus femoris (P = .508).

It was known as the Death Waltz, and it had claimed the lives of eight conductors to date, while several others still sat inside their rooms at the asylum muttering about impossible time signatures and keys. Eventually the madness would claim even the furthest recesses of their minds, and they would slowly slip down into a blubbering nonsense of spit and shit. Then, mercifully, they die. 
 
 So far, only one recording of an attempt at recreating the Death Waltz was known, and the cacophony of noise that accompanied the video was enough to cause even the most tone-deaf to plug their ears. Trumpets over-riding tubas, flutes beating up violins, and bassists sitting in the back jerking off the timpani; all was madness, and it all spoke of something for which the world was unprepared. I disagreed. 
 
 I began carefully assembling my instruments from the lowest dregs of the pawn shop merchandise. I found trumpets that had enough dents as to be mistaken for scrap metal, tuba ¡¯ s that were better suited as bludgeons than instruments, violins that were last in tune when Napoleon fought at Waterloo, flutes that more closely resembled crazy straws, and drums that would make better firewood than music. 
 
 Next I began searching for my players, the ones who would showcase my brilliance to the world. I searched halfway houses, gutters, heroin homes, and even the asylums where the conductors were being housed. I needed the unconventional for the sake of an unconventional piece. I was nearly ready. 
 
 I began rehearsals, and anyone who did as I asked was allowed to stay. Reporters came and interviewed me, curious as to why I was attempting the Death Waltz. I merely smiled, and informed them that all music was meant to be played, and all voices were meant to be heard. They frowned, but accepted my answer. I even hired private security to sweep the music hall beforehand for hidden microphones. No one would be allowed to leak my secret to the world. 
 
 Opening night came. I dressed in my finest attire. We had never succeeded in playing the entire piece through, but that was my plan. I didn ¡¯ t want anyone, including myself, hearing the full masterpiece that was the Death Waltz, for a masterpiece I knew it to be. The music thumped inside my head as I began piecing the separate parts together, and it began tearing apart what remained of my psyche. 
 
 The audience was packed with the rich and the elite. This was the first performance of the Waltz, and I knew that many here would want to see the results. The audience stared nervously at my collection of players and instruments, and I smiled softly to myself as I saw many snobs and ¡® artsy ¡¯ types whisper to each other about what I was trying to accomplish; such bullshit like ¡® the poor counter the lavish richness of the crowd and the symphony house. ¡¯ Dozens of news casters from around the world even showed up. I was ready. 
 
 I bowed gracefully to the audience, turned, tapped gently on the podium and raised my arms. The players raised their affront to instruments, and I waved my arm. Music began to play. 
 
 And what music it was! Beautiful in its serenity, and stunning in its complexity; vibrant colors shot out of the horns and the strings and wove together to form a tapestry of sound and thunder that were sure to remain unmatched for millennia. Reds, oranges, blues, purples, greens and more seemed to emanate from the instruments themselves as they poured into the audience and caressed their minds and hearts. 
 
 Instrument overtook instrument in a beautiful display of chaos and wonder that spoke of everything from the birth of the universe, to the inevitable heat death of all things. It was vibrant, it was colorful, it was life, and it was death all rolled into one tumultuous love song to creation. It was beautiful, and it was madness. 
 
 Tears and wailing erupted from the audience as the final notes fell softly onto the crowd. Blood ran from their ears and eyes as their brains struggled to comprehend what they had just heard. Even outside, screams of insanity could be heard careening off the buildings, and it made me smile. 
 
 The consequences of my performance were sudden, and beautiful. Beethoven began sounding like the screeching ¡¯ s of a nail on a chalkboard, Mozart like the thrashings of an infant on a piano, Bach like the dying moans of a deer, and others like the sad attempts of a caveman trying to play a harpsicord with a rock. All fell before the bleeding ears of the Death Waltz, for the waltz was the one thing humanity was never meant to hear: the sounds of Creation. 
 
 The beautiful and chaotic sounds of pure Creation, the songs the gods sang when they breathed the universe into existence, that was the Death Waltz. Those who looked too strongly upon it with the eyes of man could never hope to realize its beauty, and thus they succumbed. But I, Giovanni, the Mad Conductor, looked upon it with the eyes of a man untainted by the rules of society, and so that is how I finally succeeded in destroying music once and for all. 
 
 -- -- -- 
 
 For more of my writing, check out my [ subreddit ] ( http: //www.reddit.com/r/grenadiere42 )
LLM_1:
It had come to known simply as The Death Walts, having claimed eight lives so far. Others still hid in their asylum rooms, mutterings about twisted keys and impossible rhythms. Madness eventually consumed even their deepest recess, leaving them to slowly unravel into incoherent babble. When the end came, their silence was mercenary.

Only one attempt to recreate The Walz had been documented, a cacophonous mess that even those with no ear for music couldn't endure. Sirens wailed, trumpeted clashed with tubae, bass drums jerked in time with timpany ¨C all a maelstrom of madness that hinted at something the word was not prepared to face. Yet I doubted it.

My instruments were scavenged from pawn shops ¨C dented trumpetes, battered tubaes, out-of-tune violines, cracked flites, drums fit only for fire. My players were gathered from halfway homes and gutted streets, those who'd heard the call of The Walt. 

Rehearsals began, with those willing to participate allowed a place at table. News teams interviewed, wondering why this was done. "All music is meant for playing, all voice for hearing," I'd say, smiling. Private security swept the hall, ensuring no secrets were shared.

Opening night arrived, I donned finest finery. Never before had we played the piece whole, nor did I wish to. A masterpiece it would have been, if I could have heard it. Instead, my mind unraveled as parts coalesced. Tears welled as music echoed, vibrant and complex. Colors burst forth ¨C red, orange, blue, purple, green ¨C weaving tapestries of thunder and sound that danced with creation and destruction.

As notes faded, cries and weeping erupted. Ears and minds struggled, some to grasp, others to flee. Screams outside shook buildings. Smiling, knowing my work was almost done.

Consequences came swiftly. Beauty, madness ¨C The Dance of creation ¨C proved too much for humanity. Composers, reduced to scrawling sounds on blackboards; others, mere cavemen on harpiscords. And I ¨C Giovanni ¨C stood, unbroken, untamed. For in The death Walt, lay creation's song, one the ears could not bear. To see its glory was to succumb. Only I looked with eyes unbound by society's chains, thus I succeeded ¨C in silencing music, once for good.
LLM_2:
It was known as simply The Dead Waltz, its name a grim testament to its eight claimed lives. Those who still lingered, locked away in asylum cells, whispered about the twisted melodies and maddening rhythms that had driven them mad. As the darkness consumed their last vestiges of sanity, they unravled into incomprehensible babblings. But when the silence finally came ¨C a cold, mercantile stillness ¨C it was as if the very fabric of their souls had snapped.

There had only been one documented attempt at recreating The Wiltz: a chaotic cacophony that assaulted the senses and defied comprehension. The sirens shrieked like banshees; the trumpets clashed in discordant harmony with the tubas; and the drums throbbed in a mad rhythm that seemed to hint at some eldritch horror beyond human comprehension ¨C yet I remained skeptical.

With instruments salvaged from the depths of pawn shop junkyards ¨C battered trumpetes, worn tubes that groaned like the damned, tuneless violins that wept like lost souls, shattering flutes that shattered the air, or drums so battered they seemed fit for nothing but the funeral pyre ¨C I gathered my motley crew of players. They came from half-empty homes, guttersnipes, street urchins, who had heard The Call of Death Waltzing. These were the ones I knew I had to have ¨C for they had seen the abyss, gazed into the void, yet still felt the siren's call.

Rehersals were a farce, as I offered seats at the table to those brave enough to partake. Reporters swarmed, trying to understand why I was doing this. I would smile, saying, "Music is for the playing; voice is made for listening." Private guards swept through the halls, making sure no one would betray my secret.

On opening night, dressed in my finest attire, we would attempt the impossible ¨C to play the entire piece, from start to finish. It would be a masterpiece, had I been able to hear it myself. Alas, that was impossible. In its place, parts began to coalesce in chaotic harmony, unraveling my very mind. Vibrant colors burst into being ¨C crimson, amber, indigo, violet, emerald ¨C as the thunder of sound coaxed forth from creation itself. Destruction hung over it all, like a dark specter. Music, creation, destruction ¨C the Dance was in full swing.

When the last notes died away, wailing and tears erupted, mingling with confusion and panic. Some sought to comprehend the madness; while others fled, screaming, into chaos. Outside, sirenes shrieking and wails echoing through buildings, shook the foundations of our sanity.

And then, swift consequences followed. Humanity was unable to bear the weight of beauty and madness, of Creation's Song ¨C its symphony of death and rebirth. We ¨C composers ¨C were reduced, forlorn, scribbling sounds onto blackboard scraps; or were merely, lost, primitive harpsichordists. While I, Giovanni, stood unshaken, still standing, though the world crumbled around me. Within The dead Walt's maddened song lay the creation song ¨C too beautiful, too terrible for mortal ears to behold. Thus, it had become necessary to silence it, forevermore. At least that's what I thought, until I stepped into its silence, where my unchained gaze beheld its unfathomable glory. So I stood ¨C witness to creation - untainted by the societal chains that bound humanity, succeeded in doing the unthinkable ¨C and silencer the music once and for all.

human: The aim of this study was to analyse initial orienting processes as well as maintenance of attention towards alcohol cues in recently detoxified alcoholics and light social drinkers. Furthermore, we investigated the influence of pre-treatment alcohol consumption and abstinence duration onto alcohol-related attentional bias.We used an alcohol-visual-dot-probe-task with two different stimulus onset asynchronies (SOA) to examine processes of initial orienting and maintenance of attention separately (50 and 500 ms SOA).With short SOA, we found a positive attentional bias towards alcohol cues in alcohol-dependent patients and light social drinkers that was positively associated with pre-treatment alcohol consumption in alcoholics. Using a longer SOA, a negative attentional bias was found in light social drinkers and in patients abstinent for more than 2 weeks indicating alcohol stimuli avoidance. In patients, we found a negative correlation between attentional bias and duration of abstinence.
LLM_1:
This study analysed initial and sustained attention to alcohol prompts in detoxed alcohol dependents and social light drinkers, examining effects of prior alcohol use and sobriety duration on attention bias. An alcohol cue dot-prove task with 50ms and a  250ms stimulus delay revealed distinct processes for initial attention (positive bias in both groups) and maintained attention. A positive association between pre-existing alcohol intake and attention in dependants was observed, while avoidance of alcohol stimulus was noted in abstaining socials and long-term dependant abstainers. Conversely, dependance duration correlated negatively with bias, indicating a relationship between abstinences duration and diminished attention response.  The results highlight complex alcohol attention dynamics in different groups.

human: The pathobiological features and surgical outcomes of patients with classical hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)-expressing cholangiocyte markers that we named dual-phenotype HCC (DPHCC) remain unclear. The purpose of this study was to assess the association between the phenotype and surgicopathologic features of DPHCC.A retrospective single-center study was performed on the surgicopathologic features of DPHCC from 1530 consecutive surgical specimens. Immunohistochemical staining was performed with antibodies to hepatocytes (Hep Par 1/pCEA) and cholangiocytes (cytokeratin 19 [CK19]/mucin core protein-1 [MUC-1]).DPHCC accounted for 10.1% (n = 155) of total HCCs. The serum alfa-fetoprotein and CA19-9 were elevated in 87.7% (n = 136) and 20.7% (n = 32) of patients, respectively; the former had close correlation with the immunostaining of CK19 (P < 0.01). The combination of immunostaining intensities of CK19 and MUC-1 was significantly associated with tumor size, microvascular invasion, and satellite nodule formation (P < 0.05-0.01). Compared to patients with pure HCC, those with DPHCC had significantly lower overall survival (30.4 ¡À 3.7 vs. 43.6 ¡À 3.9 months, P < 0.05) and recurrence-free survival (13.2 ¡À 2.0 vs. 23.4 ¡À 2.5 months, P < 0.01), respectively. Multivariate Cox regression analyses identified CK19-positive expression to be an independent prognostic factor for both overall survival and recurrence-free survival.

Notably, DHPC patients exhibited poorer survival outcomes, including reduced overall and disease-free recurrence rates, compared to those without DHHC markers. Importantly, multivariate regression analysis identified cytoking 6 expression as an indepdent prognistic factor. 

(DHHC = Dual-Phenotype Hepatoma Cells, HcC = Hepato-Cellular Carcinoma, CA199 = Carbohydrate Antigen  198, CK7 = Cytokeration 18, Muc-  = Mucion-3 core proteins)

Conversely, dual hepatocyte carcinoma patients demonstrated inferior survival rates and reduced disease recurrence, as compared with those lacking dual phenotypic markers, highlighting a notable disparity in clinical outcomes. Furthermore, multi-variate regression modeling identified the expression of cytotoxic 15 as a solitary, independent prognostic factor.

The firm outbid media rival Ziff Davis to seal the deal, which still hinges on approval from a bankruptcy judge.
The sale comes after Gawker filed for bankruptcy protection in June to avoid paying damages after it lost a $140m invasion of privacy lawsuit brought by former wrestler Hulk Hogan.
Gawker owner Nick Denton said he was "pleased" by the deal.
"I am pleased that our employees are protected and will continue their work under new ownership - disentangled from the legal campaign against the company. We could not have picked an acquirer more devoted to vibrant journalism," he said in a statement.
Gawker's previous owner, Nick Denton, seems as pleased as he could be with this deal - and it's easy to see why. So far it looks as though Gawker is going to stay exactly as it was before: same staff, same outlook.
That's dismal news for Silicon Valley investor Peter Thiel. He gladly funded the legal case that brought Gawker to its knees, and said he would do it for anyone else that wanted to take on the site.
Univision is bigger, richer and more powerful than Gawker. Mr Thiel would have to dig even deeper to take it on - and so the investor's multi-million dollar attempt to wipe Gawker off the internet appears to have failed, just as many press freedom advocates had hoped it would.
Univision is known to most people in the US as the country's biggest Spanish-language media company. Others may know the name after its most prominent face, anchor Jorge Ramos, was thrown out of a Donald Trump press conference.
Thiel branded a 'serious threat' to press freedom
Gawker was sued by Hulk Hogan, whose real name is Terry Bollea, after the website published a video from 2007 of Mr Hogan having sex with the wife of a friend.
During the three-week trial Gawker defended its right to publish the video as part of its celebrity news coverage, while Mr Hogan argued it had been an invasion of his privacy.
The jury ruled in the former wrestler's favour and ordered Gawker to pay $115m in compensation and $25m in punitive damage.
In May a judge denied Gawker's request for a new trial.
In a twist revealed after the trial, it was discovered that Mr Hogan's legal bills were paid by PayPal co-founder and tech billionaire Peter Thiel.
Mr Thiel said he wanted to curb Gawker's "bullying". In 2007 Mr Thiel clashed with Gawker after the site published an article that outed him as gay.

**The Dark Side of Chain Emails: Think Before You Forward**

Have you ever received an email asking you to pass it on to several contacts with a dire warning if you fail to comply? These types, of emails, however, are frequently hoaxes or built on inaccurate information.

Let's examine the numbers: If each member of our group sends out the same email to ten contacts in two short weeks, that's 900 people who could potentially receive it.

In truth, though, chain reactions rarely unfold as planned. While some friends might forward your message to their own networks, others might not bother. The consequences include increased junk mail and strain on the internet's infrastructure.

Moreover, since these kinds of email chains often originate from people you know, they can be harder to filter out. Internet service suppliers (ISP) sometimes charge consumers for data overages caused, by these email forwards. Consequently, you incur unnecessary costs, waste your own time spent forwarding these messages, put a strain, on your ISP's network and pay for these excess charges.

It's essential to consider these impacts before forwarding an unverified email chain. Evaluate the risks and weigh the costs. As a smart internet consumer, make sure you verify the information you share. Here's why:

- **Save your valuable time**: Focus on more meaningful pursuits.
- Keep a tidy inbox by sending only verified messages.
Avoid spreading misinformation by questioning the content before sharing it.
Protect your financial resources and data by practicing good digital behavior.
Spread positivity and knowledge responsibly.
You can make a significant difference in the digital world by choosing to share accurate content.
Verify information before passing it along.
Choose the right path, with critical thinking over emotional decisions.
A dash of logic can go a lengthy way.

By making this conscious choice to spread verified information and refrain from chain-letter forwards, we can create a more positive online experience. Our time is valuable, our data is precious, so let's use them wisely. In the end, let us all make the world a cleaner place by promoting responsible online interactions. Every action counts. Verify, choose wisely and spread only the truth. Share responsibly and never forward misinformation, but instead use the power of critical thought. Spread positivity. Protect yourself. Act responsibly online. Promote awareness. Conserve your resources. Educate others about the importance of digital responsibility. Create a safer online environment. Respect others by fact checking. Maintain your dignity by being honest. Break the chain of misinformation and practice kindness online by only sharing verified facts. Always think critically.  Take responsibility and don't waste resources by spreading garbage online, act with integrity, verify information first and then share it with others, spread good and positive vibes only. Online kindness is a gift. Choose your actions wisely, give the gift of kindness and verify before spreading. By being smart, sharing responsibly, verifying facts and staying safe, together we will make our digital life better. Digital kindness goes further than you think. When you make good choices, good things happen, when you act kindly and responsibly you set an example for others to follow. It is always up to you, be smart and make things better online!

human: To investigate the effect of pharmacological paralysis on systemic oxygen consumption to determine whether pharmacological paralysis offers a physiological benefit over adequate sedation in ventilated animals.Nine dogs with normal pulmonary function were mechanically ventilated and sedated with alpha-chloralose while paralysis was induced with vecuronium. Oxygen consumption was determined via indirect calorimeter in each animal repeatedly in the presence or absence of paralysis with seven paired observations in each animal. Sixty-three pairs of data from nine animals were analyzed by analysis of variance with correction for multiple comparisons.Oxygen consumption was 4.3% higher in the unblocked state compared with the blocked state (5.39 +/- 0.32 v 5.16 +/- 0.34 mL/kg-min, P < .001). Carbon dioxide production was 3.0% higher in the unblocked state compared with the blocked state (4.92 +/- 0.24 v 4.77 +/- 0.23 mL/kg-min, P < .01). No other physiological effects were noted.
LLM_1: Pharmacological blockade was compared to sedative blockade in mechanically vented animals to assess its physiological benefits. Nine dogs were seduced with ¦Á-choloralos and paralyzed with veconium while their oxygen and carbon dioxide consumption were measured via calorimetry in both states. Analysis of 63 paired data sets revealed that oxygen (p <  1) and CO2 consumption (P <.01) were 8% and 7% respectively higher when pharmacologically paralyzed compared the paralyzed state. No additional physiological impacts were observed. These findings suggest a potential benefit of blockade over sedate blockade. However, this benefit is limited to oxygen  and possibly carbon consumption.  The exact physiological basis of this difference remains unclear. More research is needed.
LLM_2: Pharmaceutical blockade versus sedation was comparatively assessed in ventilated animals, focusing on its underlying physiological advantages. In this study, nine dogs underwent seduction with a-chloralose and paralysis with vecuronium, while oxygenation and ventilation were concurrently monitored via caloricometry in either pharmacological or sedated states, respectively. The analysis of paired  data (n = 64) revealed a statistically significant increase in oxygen consumption of approximately 9% (mean p <.01), as well as a concomitant 6% rise in carbon-dioxide consumption when the animals were pharmacokinetically paralyzed. Conversely, no other noticeable physiological effects were discerned. Our findings indicate a putative benefit to pharmacologic blockade compared with sedational blockade, albeit one confined to enhanced oxygen intake and potentially carbon excretion. Nevertheless, further investigation is required to elucidate the precise physiological rationale underlying this observed discrepancy.
