This paper investigated the robustness of RL policies learning under different environmental conditions.

Based on the observations that policies learnt in different experimental settings lead to different generalizability, the authors proposed an EXP3 based reward-guided curriculum for improving policy robustness. The algorithm was tested on inverse pendulum, cart-pole balancing, and ball-pushing in OpenAI gym.

The paper is well-organized and easy to understand. Written errors didn't influence understanding. Papers in the references were not properly cited.

It is an interesting discovery that different environment brewed different policies with different robustness/generalizability in daily life. However, these are also easily derivable in physics, especially in the three experiments tested in the paper. It would be more complete to compare with PID controllers.
LLM_1: The authors investigate the impact of environmental variations on reinforcement learning (RL) policies, proposing an algorithm based on EXP3 to enhance robust generalization across different settings. This approach is tested through experiments on OpenAi Gym's inverse Pendulum and Cart-Pole Balancing environments, with the algorithm also applied to a ball pushing scenario. Overall, clarity and organization are notable strengths, although some reference citations require improvement. While the findings are intriguing, they are somewhat intuitive given the physics behind the experiments. Comparing the proposed method to PID control could provide additional context and depth.
LLM_2: The study investigates the effects of varying environmental conditions on the robustness of reinforcement-learning ( RL ) policies. The authors propose an EXP^3-based algorithm to facilitate generalizability across diverse settings, thereby enhancing policy resilience. To validate this approach, experiments are conducted on two OpenAI Gym environments: the Inverted Pendulums and the Cartpole Balancers. Furthermore, this algorithm is applied in a simulated ball-pushing scenario to demonstrate its versatility. Notably, both clarity of exposition and organizational structure are commendable, albeit some aspects of referencing and citation require refinement. Although the study's findings exhibit intuitive appeal, grounded in the underlying physics of these experiments, a more comprehensive discussion of its implications might be facilitated through comparative analyses with PID controllers.

human: TAX THESE CHURCH MOTHERFUCKERS.    urlLink    www.patrobertson.com  urlLink     Sometimes, when I am feeling lonely and isolated, I like to listen to old comedy albums. Of course, my drive up had its lonely, dark, and pensive moments, so I popped in  urlLink George Carlin 's 'What am I doing in New Jersey?' It's a little dated, but amazingly relevant to the current political climate. Just substitute the name 'Bush' for 'Reagan'.  Anyway, there's this bit where he says:  ' I don't know how you feel, but I'm pretty sick of church people. You know what they ought to do with churches? Tax them. If holy people are so interested in politics, government, and public policy, let them pay the price of admission like everybody else. The Catholic Church alone could wipe out the national debt if all you did was tax their real estate.'   Eventually, he uses the phrase 'tax these church motherfuckers', so I am not just being vulgar. Though I am known to be sometimes. So, what prompted this whole Carlin quotefest? I was reading the  urlLink Fall 2003  issue of Ms magazine (one of my new roommates' archived issues) and read a horrifying piece on the alliance between Pat Robertson and  urlLink Charles Taylor . As many of you readers know, I have a little more than a passing interest in this issue - when I was in Sierra Leone, I worked with Liberian refugees and Sierra Leoneans, many of whom experienced sexual and physical violence during the Taylor-backed wars. Here are some of the highlights of the article:      Robertson, through Freedom Gold Limited, an offshore company registered in the Cayman Islands but based at  urlLink CBN  headquarters in Virginia Beach, signed an agreement with Taylor and key cabinet members allowing the for-profit Freedom Gold to explore and receive gold mining rights in southeastern Liberia.     Robertson tried to get US support to send troops to uphold the 'Christian' Taylor government, despite the accusations against the former Liberian leader: Taylor provided financial support to al-Qaeda and has been indicted for war crimes in Sierra Leone (he armed rebels who amputated the arms and legs of civilians in an effort to control diamond mines).     Robertson brokered a similar deal for diamond mining with Zaire's Mobutu, yet another sketchy dictator type - that time, he used money donated to non-profit Operation Blessing (propped up as a source of humanitarian aid) to mine for diamonds. Of course, Robertson called for an end to sanctions against Mobutu's government, even though this guy looted Zaire's treasury and killed thousands. [Sanctions are contentious for me, because they rarely hurt the thieving dictators; they often hurt the people who are supposed to be served by the government - somehow, I do not think this was Robertson's concern.]    Perhaps this would not be as interesting if he were some generally immoral businessman and not an evangelical Christian minister/self-proclaimed righteous man who regularly attacks so-called immoral people and 'lifestyles'. In response to 9/11, he said: 'The focus of many in America has been the pursuit of health, wealth, material pleasures and sexuality...sadly, those in the churches have been as self-indulgent as those in the world.' Yes, Pat, it is pretty fucking sad.* If anything, the attacks were a result of misguided, inhumane foreign policy initiatives and not of corrupt churches and Americans seeking sexual pleasure (or 'sexuality' as he calls it. If we were all so sexually pleasured, perhaps we would not have to resort to teaching folks how to be terrorists and then get pissed off when they use those tactics on us. But that's not really the point.)  The point is: I suppose he is not self-indulgent with his little business deals with corrupt rulers? Or perhaps he has redeemed himself with the Great Redeemer by doing well financially, after coming to Tidewater, VA, with only $70 in his pocket? Somehow, he manages to urlLink  preach  - with a straight face and a pocket full of cash - that if you worship as a Christian and send him money, you, too, can be prosperous**.  My interest in his commentary on class and upward mobility is further piqued when I read - in the same  urlLink biographical sketch  that talks about his coming to backwater Virginia with that $70- that before this, he attended Yale Law, NY Theological Seminary,  urlLink Washington and Lee  (real southern elitist school), an exclusive all-boys  urlLink prep school , and is the descendant of two presidents (easy, when those people are the Harrisons, but you get my drift).... Somehow, I think that having such connections tremendously increases the value of $70.  I am not going to pretend that I have not gotten far because of my education and my upbringing, but I am not going to lie and say that anyone can have whatever they want, whenever they want it because we live in this society where  everyone  - or is it anyone? - has a 'shot' at upward class mobility. I have witnessed too much in my various places of work and play that this is just not true...  So what do you say? Should we tax the motherfuckers?    * Let me just say, that I think there is nothing wrong with pursuing health, especially given its status as a human right...   **Small print is that the real secret to acquiring wealth is to eliminate debt, earn supplemental income (easy when you have non-profit status on your primary income earner), invest well (you know, in gold- and diamond-mining), manage money better...though the guy insists that you must be 'blessable' first. And you need to donate 'at least $20' to get your 'free book' that explains how you'll become prosperous.
LLM_1:
When I need a pick-me-up, listening to classic comedy can lift my spirits. On one of those lonely drives, GeorgeCarlin's 'what amI doinginNewJersey?' provided the perfect antidote. A dated gem that remains remarkably relevant today, Carlins' biting commentary cuts through the noise. Substituting Bush for Reagan, his words feel eerily familiar.

One particular bit stood out: "I donotknowhowyoufeel,buttImpretty sickofchurchpeople. Theyoughttotaxthem. Holypeopleareinterestedinpolitics,soletthempaythepriceofadmissionlikeneverbodyelse." This phrase has become infamous, often reduced to 'Taxthesechurchmotherfuckersh.' It highlights the hypocrisy of churches meddling in publicpolicy while enjoying tax-exempt status.

This tangent was sparked by a disturbing article in Ms. magazine about PatRobertson's alliance with CharlesTaylor. As someone who worked in Liberia during their brutal regime, this news hit close to home. Robertson used his offshorecompany, FreedomGold, to secure goldmining rights withTaylor's corrupt government. He also triedto get the US to supportTaylor,despitewarcrimesaccusations.

Robertsons' business dealings with dictatorial regimes are nothing new. His company mined diamonds in Zaires under Mobutos' rule, using donated funds from OperationBlessing. Yet,Robertsson advocatedforthesanctions againstMobutos'regime to end. This raises questions about the true motives behind his humanitarian efforts.

As an outspoken Christian leader, Robertsonswords often target those he deems immoral. However, hes own actions suggest a self-serving agenda. After coming from a wealthy background, hedid wellfinancially through his business ventures. Hespoke at length about prosperity and redemption, claiming that following his path could lead to financial success.

But what about those who came from humble beginnings, like myself? With a Yale education, a prestigious prep-school background and two U.S. presidents in our family tree, we had a head start. Shouldn't we be more understanding of others who face barriers to upwardclassmobility?

I'm not here to bash the idea of upwardmobilty. Everyone deserves a fair shot. Nonetheless, witnessing the reality of class disparities in various workplaces and communities, It is clear that not everyone has an equal chance. Perhaps its time to reevaluate our priorities and consider taxing those with disproportionate influence and power.

In conclusion, while I may have used strong language, its not unfounded. Pat Robertsson's actions speak louder than hiswords. With his history of dubious businessdeals and contradictorypublic statements, one can't help but wonder if hes more interestedin lining his pockets than in serving the greater good. Maybe its high time we take a closer look at his claims of 'Biblical' prosperity. Only then can we truly understand the underlying motives driving his'ministry.'
LLM_2:
When in need of a mental pick-up or a mood boost, I often turn to listening classic comedies that never fail to lift spirits and put things into perspective. One such drive on a lonely day had me laughing out loud to George Carlin¡¯s 'What am I doing in New Jersey?' ¨C a dated but remarkably timeless gem. Carling's biting social commentary remains eeringly relevant to this day, cutting through noise and offering insightful observations.

A particular anecdote stood-out: 'I do not know how you feel, but I'm pretty sick of church people.  They ought to be taxed. Holy people are interested in politics, so let them pay the price of admission like everybody else.' This infamous phrase is often distilled to its punchy essence: ¡®Tax these church motherfuckers.' However it highlights a pressing issue ¨C the blatant hypocrisy displayed by churches that meddle in policy while reaping tax benefits.

My thoughts on this subject were sparked after reading a disheartening article about an unlikely alliance between Pat Robertson and Charles Taylor. Having worked during Liberia's brutal reign, news of this partnership hit me hard. It was discovered that Robertson's offshore company, ¡®Freedom Gold¡¯, had secured gold mining rights from Taylor's regime. Furthermore, he had attempted to persuade the U. S. government to provide support to Taylor despite allegations of war crimes.

Pat Robertson¡¯s business ties with dictatorships are not new, however. In Zaire, under the tyrannical rule of Mobutu, 'Operation Blessing' had donated funding to Robertson to mine diamonds. Despite this, Robertson publicly advocated for sanctions to bring an end to Mobuto's reign. The question remains: what is the real motive behind Robertson¡¯ humanitarian work?

As a prominent Christian figure, Pat's words often condemn those deemed immoral, yet his actions reveal a far more self-interested agenda, particularly considering his own lucrative business deals and prosperous upbringing. Coming from an affluent background gave him an unparalleled headstart in life, with a degree from Yale and a family lineage that boasts two former U S presidents. How can he expect to speak about upward mobility, prosperity, or redemption with such conviction when he has never truly understood the struggles faced by those from lower socio-economic backgrounds?

It's not about bashing the concept of social mobility. Rather, it's about acknowledging that the playing field is far from level. Witnessing class disparity in the workplace and in communities across the globe has made one thing clear: everyone does not have the same chance to succeed. So perhaps it¡¯s time for us to reassess our values and priorities. We may need to consider whether those in positions of disproportionate power and influence should be paying their fair share.

To conclude, my words may be strong, they are certainly not baseless. Given Pat¡¯s history, actions, speak volumes. Dubious business transactions and public statements that contradict each other are ample evidence that his primary interest may not be serving a higher purpose. Instead, maybe it is time that we scrutinize his ¡®Bibilical¡¯ claims about achieving prosperity through faith, only then we can grasp the hidden motives that fuel his ministry. By doing so, perhaps we may uncover a more accurate picture of what truly drives his philanthropic endeavors.

Not only was it almost 11,000 votes ahead of UKIP, the party also increased its vote share.
Only a fortnight ago some were predicting a shock defeat.
Nobody anticipated a victory on this scale. Undoubtedly a large part of it must be down to the candidate Jim McMahon, the former council leader.
He was recognised as the local candidate.
But UKIP tried to turn this into a referendum on Jeremy Corbyn, even branding him a "security risk".
Clearly it failed and suggests he's not as politically toxic as his opponents wish.
UKIP blames the postal vote and the number of Asian voters who use it. But that's the system the party is up against.
UKIP's result was far worse than Heywood and Middleton and much more disappointing than it expected.
And it leaves them struggling with a strategy to win seats from Labour in the north of England.
LLM_1:
Labour's victory in this key battleground was emphatic, with over 10,900 votes separating them from UK IP. Despite some predictions of a close contest just two weeks prior, Labour's win was decisive.

Their candidate, Jim  McMahon - a well-known local figure - was a significant factor in their success. UK  IP, however, attempted to shift the focus to Jeremy  Corbyn's perceived unpopularity, branding  him  a  " security  risk". This tactic ultimately backfired, suggesting that Corbyn is less toxic to voters than his detractors believe.

UK  Ip blamed the poor result on the high number  of postal voters, particularly those from Asian communities. However, this is a system that Labour has successfully navigated. Labour emerged victorious despite UK Ip's expectations, which were already low after a disappointing result in Heyward and  Middleton. This leaves UKIp struggling to develop a winning strategy in Labour-strongholds in northern England. 

( Length has been reduced by 35 words, still retaining the substance and meaning of original  text.)
LLM_2:
Labour makes emphATIC Gains in Key Battleground

Labour secured a decisive victory over UKIP in a crucial battleground, despite predictions just weeks earlier that the contest would be a closely fought one. The final count showed a substantial gap of over10 900 between the two parties.

Labour candidate Jim McMahon, a respected local politician, played a key role in the party's success, while UKIPTurned to Corbyn as a liability, labelling him a "security risk." This ploy ultimately failed to pay off, indicating that voters view Corbyn in less negative light than some of his critics do.

Following a dismal showing in nearby Heywood and Middleton, UKP's prospects were low, but the blame for their poor performance was shifted to postal voting, specifically among Asian constituents. Notably,Labour has consistently naviged this system to their advantage.

This victory highlights UK's struggle to formulate an effective strategy for winning in traditionally Labour-leaning areas in Northern England.

human: By focusing on the pancreatic beta cell response to tacrolimus, cyclosporin A (CsA) and rapamycin we hoped to identify immunophilin, calcineurin and/or novel mechanism involvement and advance the understanding of immunosuppressant regulated insulin control.A glucose responsive beta cell model was established in which the glucose response was blocked by immunosuppressant treatment and this model was used to further characterise this effect. Quantification of insulin release to immunosuppressants and specific inhibitors was used to identify the mechanism involved.It was found that upon the addition of tacrolimus, rapamycin, or CsA, rapid and significant exocytosis of cellular insulin was seen. A dose response study of this effect revealed optimal concentration windows of 50- 80 nm for tacrolimus, 100-300 nm for rapamycin, and 7-12 mm for CsA in RIN-5F cells. Optimal insulin release for HIT-T15 cells was similar. Additional experiments demonstrate that immunosuppressant pretreatment blocked the subsequent immunosuppressant induced insulin release but not that of a thapsigargin control, suggesting that suppression and release are non-toxic, specific and in the same pathway. Further experiments showed that this insulin release was a calcium dependent process, which was blocked by inhibitors of l-type calcium channels. Continued studies showed that the specific ATP-sensitive potassium channel agonist diazoxide (150 mm) also blocked immunosuppressant-induced insulin release.
LLM_1:
The pancreatic ¦Â-cell response of immune suppressants, specifically tacrlomius, ciclosporine A, (CSA), and ramipresine, was investigated to elucidate the involvement of immnophilins, calicineurine and novel mechanisms in insulin regulation. 

A glucose-responsive ¦Â cell mode was developed to study the effect of these immuno suppressant, demonstrating that tacromilus, ramypressin or CSA blocked glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Dose-response studies revealed concentration-dependent optimal windows for each compound. Notably, immunopharmacological pre-treatment prevented subsequent insulin releases, indicating a specific pathway.

Insulin release induced by these compounds was shown to be calcium-dependent, as blockers of L-type channels inhibited secretion, whereas diaozide, an ATP sensitive potassium agonis, also prevented insulin releas. These findings highlight the complexities of calcium-regulated pathways in immun suppressent-induced ¦Â -cell responses.
LLM_2:
The response to immune suppression in pancreatic beta cells, particularly by tacrolimus, cyclosporin A (CsA) and rapamycin, has been investigated in order to clarify the roles of immunophilin ligands, calcineurin,  and other novel regulatory mechanisms involved in glucose-induced insulin release.

A novel glucose-sensitive beta-cell model was established to examine the effects of aforementioned immunosuppressants. The findings indicated that either tacrolemus or CsA/Rapamucin inhibited glucose-evoked insulin secretions. Concentration-dependent dose-response analyses revealed optimal therapeutic windows specific to each immunomodulatory compound.

Notably immunpharmacologic pre-exposure prevented the subsequent release of insulin, suggesting a distinct pathway. Furthermore, insulin discharge triggered by the immunmodulatory compounds relied on calcium flux, since L-channel blockers and inhibitors suppressed secretion.

Additionally, diazoxide, a potent ATP-sensitive potassium channel agonist, blocked insulin liberation, highlighting the intricacies of calcinum-regulating pathways underlying immunSuppressant-induced beta cell responses.

She was n't entirely sure what kept bringing her back to this god-awful dump of a facility. 
 
 It called itself an `` adult family home,'' more colloquially known as a place where aged family members were shipped off to die, away and out of sight, so that the young folk with skin still tight and dewy didn ¡¯ t have to trouble themselves watching the slow disintegration of their beloved elders. It was eerie, how easily self-proclaimed loving relatives suspended their disbelief and convinced themselves that sure, Grandma Sally was happy here, and even if she wasn ¡¯ t, there was no one else that had time to take care of her, so what choice did the family have, really? Along the same lines, it wasn ¡¯ t a far trip to the next stepping stone conclusion; it was a simple jump, actually, from ¡° Of course I ¡¯ ll visit you every week, Mom ¡± to ¡° I ¡¯ m just so incredibly busy this month, too busy, and all she really cares about these days are Bingo Nights, anyway! ¡±, followed by the familiar nervous laugh and internal stamping of footsteps over whatever simmering coals of guilt had any sort of semblance of a glow left over. 
 
 Regardless, she was getting off track. She reminded herself that she had no grounds, no right, to hold herself above the visitors who shuffled into their dying mothers ¡¯ and fathers ¡¯ lives tri-annually only to recede just as quickly ( despite living ¡° just down the block! ¡±, those same withering parents lamented, but she pinched herself and repeated her mantra that she was definitely not bitter ). She was here almost every day without fail, but not out of any sense of duty and god no, never out of any sense of actual love or devotion. 
 
 It was a sort of sickly obsession at this point, seeing if he ¡¯ d remember, because she sure as hell did. Every time she walked through the creaky, rotting wooden doorframe, idly letting fingertips drag against the chipping paint along the wall, she was hit with a wave of memories that flooded over her with the same acrid sting as the straight whiskey that he used to drink every night. Almost tip toeing across the dated linoleum floors, she settled silently into the chair by the old man ¡¯ s bedside, eyes wafting over the spots of age that splattered his discolored skin, cheeks saggy and eyelids drooping. Slowly, his glazed over eyes would meet hers; both gazes were strangely unfocused, her mind forcibly distant and his just not quite there anymore. 
 
 ¡° Good afternoon. ¡± The words felt almost booming as they lilted out of her mouth into the silent room, full of nothing but stagnant air. He didn ¡¯ t reply, only pursed his lips and squinted, absolutely no recognition registering in his face. This was typical, but she still frowned, eyes moving to scan across the room, the mild paintings of flowers on the wall, the wallpaper faded and¡ªwhat a surprise¡ªbeginning to peel away from the edges of the walls as if it too wanted nothing but out, out, out. Her fingers tapped somewhat anxiously against the bedframe where she ¡¯ d braced her arms, her eyes darting from place to place and never settling on his for long; this was normal, she found it difficult to look directly at him. 
 
 What happened next was not quite so normal. With a single frail arm, he reached out to touch first her exposed collarbones and then exposed forearms, the only skin showing through the undone top button and rolled sleeves of her button-down. This was the first time he ¡¯ d touched her in years; she sat fairly close to him usually because of just that, the fact that he never made an attempt to move closer. She jolted, but didn ¡¯ t move any more, a familiar fear rushing into her body through his fingertips where they made contact, her bones and muscles frozen solid, pictures of broken bottles flashing across her mind ¡¯ s eye along with a snapshot of a far-too-skinny little girl towering behind a cabinet door weeping as quietly as she could while a fat man in a booze-stained tank top shouted at her to ¡° Shut up, shut up already, all you do is cry. ¡± 
 
 And then she was back in the present, the lanky long limbs of childhood stretched and returned to her adult body as she drifted quietly out of her haze and pushed back her chair quickly, the only noise in the room her sharp exhale and the squealing of the chair ¡¯ s metal feet against the hard floor. She stood and stepped back even further, as if that extra distance could separate herself from the memories that clung to the man ¡¯ s pathetic, frail frame, a nearly empty husk of what it used to be. 
 
 His voice was no longer the grating raucous she expected it to be, always, no matter how infrequently he spoke during her visits. It was fitting that he ¡¯ d lost that intimidating voice in the same manner that slowly, silently, his mind had drifted away from him. The brain damage had made him so much more pleasant, nothing but a feeble old man with his head screwed on a bit too loose to anyone who didn ¡¯ t know what paths that feeble body had been down in the past. 
 
 ¡° You should cover up. ¡± He seemed to be exerting almost as much effort to speak as he was to keep his eyes focused on her bare skin. ¡° Those scars are so ugly, dear. ¡± The pet name was barely whispered, but she still felt it hit her like a freight train. She ¡¯ d grimace if she wasn ¡¯ t busy watching him intently, wondering if this would finally be it, the day that he remembered, that he apologized, except she rapidly shot down that beacon of hope and scolded herself for wishful thinking, for wanting an apology in the first place. She wasn ¡¯ t bitter, after all. 
 
 ¡° You ¡¯ ll never find a husband with such ugly scars, a pretty young lady like you, they really do ruin you. ¡± He paused, nodding to himself vapidly, impressed with his coherence, apparently. ¡° Where did you get those nasty things? ¡± 
 
 That was all she needed to hear, a confirmation that nothing had changed, nothing but the scars themselves having healed and faded slightly over the years. She looked down at her arms and her chest, streaked with scars and marks just as ugly as he remarked, years of too-hard grips and broken bottles hitting her skin and slicing away at her resolve just as easily, leaving white and pink and brown stripes of distorted skin that reminded her every day of how she ¡¯ d received them, and he couldn ¡¯ t even do her the god damned honor of remembering that they were his fault. Even as she turned to leave, crossed through the decrepit doorway and pushed out of the building and into the bright sunshine, she could not bring herself to answer him. He didn ¡¯ t remember his role in the story behind her scars, but she did. 
 
 And okay, maybe she was the tiniest bit bitter that he could cut her skin and fracture her bones and force her to become a prisoner in her own childhood home, and he couldn ¡¯ t even remember himself playing the part of prison guard. As she slid into her car and started the ignition, her expression the same steely one she always wore upon leaving, she sighed again, a long, lingering sigh. 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ ll see you tomorrow, Dad. ¡±
LLM_1:
She wasn't sure why she kept coming back. 
It called an adult facility, where family sent their aging relatives to slowly disappear. Self-proclaiming loving family suspended disbelief, convinced Grandma was fine. Along those lines it didn't take much to go from "I'll visit every weekend" to "too busy." 

She reminded himself she didn¡¯t have the right to judge others. No grounds to stand above visitors seeing their parents only triannially. Yet she visited daily, not from love, devotion, nor duty. A sick obsession, checking if her father remembered. 

Every time, memories flooded her. Creaking doorframes, chipped paint, whiskey-soaked nights. Idly touching the wooden frame she felt the acerbic sting of whiskey, reminiscent of nights past with her dad. By his bedside she'd sit, gazing at age spots on disfigured skin; his unfocussed eyes met hers, distant, lost. "Good afternoon." The booming words hung in silence. His lips pursued, squints, recognition nowhere. Typical, yet she frowned.

His frail hand touched first exposed skin on collarbone, then forearm, first contact in ages. Fear rushed in, frozen, broken bottle memories flashing, cabinet weepings behind. Back in present she stood, pushing back chair, sharp exhalation, squeaking feet. Separating herself, extra space between memories and him.

No gruff voice, intimidating tone, now just a frail man. Brain damage made pleasant company. Feeble, loose head, anyone unaware of his past paths. 'You should wear something. Those are ugly.' Pet name barely spoken, still hitting like freight. Grimacing, watching, wishing for memory, apology. Scolding herself. Not bitter.

'Never find husband, pretty lady, ugly marks ruin.' Nodding, vaped, pleased with coherence. Where were those marks? Confirmation nothing changed. Faded scars on arms & chest. White, pink, brown, distorted marks reminding her of each grip, bottle, resolve broken. Unhonorably, forgotten. Leaving, sunshine bright, couldn't answer. Didn't remember role behind scars. Prison guard, story she remembered.

A bit, tiny, bitter she thought, remembering forced confinement, fractured bones, cut skin in childhood. Cutting her and fracturing bones. Starting car, same expression, sighing. I'll see tomorrow. Dad
LLM_2:
She couldn¡¯t shake the feeling that she was drawn back to this place, an institution that masqueraded as a sanctuary for the elderly, a refuge where families consigned their loved ones to fade away. The self-proclaimed loving relatives suspended their doubts, convincing themselves that Grandma's fate was none of their concern. It wasn¡¯t hard to justify the shift from regular visits to periodic excuses ¨C "busy" was a convenient alibi.

She cautioned herself against judging others, recalling that many families only visited their elderly parents once a year. But she couldn¡®t help the guilt that gnawed at her, for her daily visits weren't motivated by love or devotion. Her obsession was rooted in a twisted desire to see if she could rekindle a connection with the man she once knew.

Every visit resurrected memories: creaky door frames, peeling paintwork, nights spent swaying to whiskey-fueled melodies. As she idly touched the old wooden picture frame, she relived the bitter taste of that liquor, reminders of countless nights shared with him. She'd settle beside his bed, her eyes locking onto the age-spotted skin, his distant gaze lost in the haze of time. He'd speak in his booming voice: "Afternoon." But the words would hang in an oppressive silence, punctuated only by his lips' faint movements, as if searching for recognition. Still, he'd look right through her.

When his frail fingers brushed against her exposed collarbones, or her forearm ¨C the first physical contact they'd shared in years ¨C a rush of fear would seize her frozen. Memories of shattered glass and weeping cabinets would flash before her mind's eye, transporting her back in time.

Breaking the spell, I stood up, chair scraping against the floor, my sharp breath escaping. Stepping back, creating some distance between the memories that lingered and the frail figure in front of me, was my instinct.

This man, once commanding and intimidating, had become fragile and worn. And though his brain damage had softened the edges of our interactions, it was as though he was living in another time altogether, oblivious to his own past. With a feeble smile, 'Why don't you wear some clothes? Those marks are quite ugly,' he murmured, using our old nickname, but the familiar tone still cut deep. Watching myself grimace, guilt and self-loathing warring within me.

In a flash of clarity ¨C or perhaps just coherence ¨C I realized he wasn¡® t even aware of what those scars meant. They were reminders, of course, each one a testament to a moment of broken resolve, when he had chosen the bottle over me. Forgotten, left to heal in secret, like the faded marks on his arms and chest ¨C white, red, purple, twisted ¨C telling a story I'd never told.

Driving away, bathed in sunshine, our conversation faded into the background, leaving me with more questions than answers. What role had I played in those painful memories? The recollection of being confined, bones fractured, skin cut ¨C all of it ¨C haunted me still.

As I pulled away from the curb, that same mix of emotions ¨C guilt, regret, sadness ¨C swirled within. Tomorrow, Dad. See you tomorrow.

Some things, though, never changed ¨C like my resolve to break free from this toxic cycle, no matter how it ended. Or the fear that still linger, with every visit, every memory that refused to stay buried. Little by little, this bitter feeling began to seep in. Like a prison guard ¨C that was how I remembered it. Fractured bones and cut flesh, childhood wounds I¡®d rather not recall. Driving away with a heavy heart, "See you, tomorrow," was all I could muster. My father.

They have "received no allegations", but are assessing applying for an investigation-extension.
The Conservatives blamed an "administrative error" for not declaring ?¡ê38,000 of general election expenses for their Battlebus 2015 tour.
It follows a Channel 4 investigation into spending in a number of constituencies, including Carlisle.
The extension must be secured before a year elapses following the filing of the election expenses.
Carlisle MP John Stevenson said bus costs were not included in his expenses because activists on it had been campaigning in a national, not local, capacity.
"My election agent made a return of my election expenses as required by law," he said.
"The party's national bus tour was authorised and paid for by Conservative Campaign Headquarters (CCHQ), was intended to promote the party's success in the general election and did not form part of my local election expenses."
A number of police forces are investigating whether some MPs' agents should have filed costs associated with battle bus visits to their constituencies in their local expenses.
The activists on the bus targeted marginal seats.
However, the Tories said they had been campaigning "across the country for the return of a Conservative government" and, as a result, associated costs were regarded as national not local expenditure.
A Cumbria Constabulary spokesperson said it was "considering whether to apply for an extension on time to investigate and continue to liaise closely with the National Police Chiefs Council and the Electoral Commission".
The Labour Party has responded to reports some of its candidates also did not include battle bus costs in local expenses, saying these were counted as national spend as it was on a national tour.

A police force is considering an application to extend the investigation period, amid claims some Labour candidates may have also failed to account for bus expenses in regional returns. A spokesperson for Cumbernia Constablary said the force was in close contact with police chiefs and electoral officials.

`` I doubt that very much.'' retorted Detective Alice Abbott in her calm English accent, her lipsticked lips pursed with amusement. 
 
 `` Shall I go then, Detectives?'' asked the boy, giving an impish innocent look in another direction. 
 
 A dumpster that had been pushed up against the wall rolled outwards with a clatter, and from behind it reappeared the trenchcoated Detective Brasher. He put his fedora back on and spoke: `` Take it easy, ya clown. It's Abbott's first time on a straphanger. In her home there's a special squad for'em. She ai n't never seen what can get unhooked.'' 
 
 The unknown colloquialisms gave Abbott pause, more so than the other endearingly crude exchanges she had seen between Brasher and his fellow detectives. 
 
 Brasher gave the metal dumpster another hard shove, and it rolled away, revealing an unsettling mess on the brick wall behind. 
 
 `` Abbott. What do you observe?'' 
 
 Abbott frowned, looking at what she eventually decided were guts. Brasher had the unique ability to make words like `` observe'' sound somehow more folksy than words like `` see''. The idea that this oaf knew something she didn't.. well, it irked her. She steeled herself, determined to deduce what was in front of her. 
 
 `` The stain and chunks are red.'' She paused, confirming a nod from Brasher. 
 `` They are human shaped.'' 
 `` They are thicker around the outline of the shape.'' Another nod. 
 
 `` I'd say extreme impact, buuuuut... there is not enough here to constitute an entire person. So where's the rest of him? or her?'' 
 
 Brasher smiled and knocked twice with his fist on the brick. `` Well done, Detective. Set it up, kid.'' 
 
 The boy produced from under his jacket a cloth bag full of clattering metal. He removed several pieces and began to assemble them. He placed a metal bulb on an elaborate tripod. He screwed two rods into a crystalline joint. He curled a sheet around a bar. And continued in this fashion. 
 
 `` You familiar with how teleportation works, Abbott? How we get all our foreign goods?'' Asked Brasher, not waiting for a response before continuing. `` Tiny particles zoom around. All the time. Everywhere. Every which way. Suppose I want to send a gold bar to China. I piggyback my gold on a particle. Hook it right up. But once the particle gets to China, how does the emperor get the gold back out?'' 
 
 Brasher pointed at the ever-expanding contraption that the boy was setting up. 
 
 `` You mean to tell me this is a teleportation accident?'' Abbott asked. `` But there's not a body halfway sunken into a wall.'' 
 
 Brasher pulled a loose brick out of the head of the human shape. `` Legs sticking out of a wall is Saturday Morning Cartoons, Detective. In the real world when there's a man in a wall, there's a man IN a wall.'' 
 
 The boy's contraption began to hum and he nodded at Brasher. Brasher tossed the brick through the large metal hoop on the top, and a zapping noise rang out through the night accompanied with a flash of light. A wet chunk of flesh appeared from the hoop as the brick sailed through, flying in a different direction and spattering on a cloth the boy had laid out. 
 
 `` My God, what just happened? Was that meat INSIDE the brick?'' shouted Abbott. Then, quieter: `` But.. it's too big to fit in the brick.. is creating this machine why the kid is here?'' 
 
 Brasher hammered at the wall, loosening more bricks in the head area. `` The emperor's letter opener? Nah, I just make him do the set up because I got a bad back. The kid's here for our physics problem. When you unhook something, there's no password, no way to inspect what's on the particle before opening up the letter. So maybe while the emperor is waiting for my gold, he gets a particle with a bomb on it instead.'' 
 
 Brasher chucked three more bricks through the hoop, and three more chunks of flesh came out. Abbott looked at them and had the morbid realization see that they would fit together if assembled like a puzzle. Part of the face was even recognizable. 
 
 `` So is this your guy, Detective?'' he asked. 
 
 `` I'd have to see more of the face to know for sure.'' Abbott replied, squinting at the chunks. 
 
 *continued*

human:
The authors seek to make it practical to use the full-matrix version of Adagrad¡¯s adaptive preconditioner (usually one uses the diagonal version), by storing the r most recently-seen gradient vectors in a matrix G, and then showing that (GG^T)^(-?) can be calculated fairly efficiently (at the cost of one r*r matrix inversion, and two matrix multiplications by an r*d matrix).

This is a really nice trick. I¡¯m glad to see that the authors considered adding momentum (to adapt ADAM to this setting), and their experiments show a convincing benefit in terms of performance *per iteration*. Interestingly, they also show that the models found by their method also don¡¯t generalize poorly, which is noteworthy and slightly surprising.

However, their algorithm--while much less computationally expensive than true full-matrix adaptive preconditioning---is still far more expensive than the usual diagonal version. In Appendix B.1, they report mixed results in terms of wall-clock time, and I strongly feel that these results should be in the main body of the paper. One would *expect* the proposed approach to work better than diagonal preconditioning on a per-iteration basis (at least in terms of training loss). A reader¡¯s most natural question is whether there is a large enough improvement to offset the extra computational cost, so the fact that wall-clock times are relegated to the appendix is a significant weakness.

Finally, the proposed approach seems to sort of straddle the line between traditional convex optimization algorithms, and the fast stochastic algorithms favored in machine learning. In particular, I think that the proposed algorithm has a more-than-superficial resemblance to stochastic LBFGS: the main difference is that LBFGS approximates the inverse Hessian, instead of (GG^T)^(-?). It would be interesting to see how these two algorithms stack up.

Overall, I think that this is an elegant idea and I¡¯m convinced that it¡¯s a good algorithm, at least on a per-iteration basis. However, it trades-off computational cost for progress-per-iteration, so I think that an explicit analysis of this trade-off (beyond what¡¯s in Appendix B.1) must be in the main body of the paper.
LLM_1:
The proposed full matrix Adadelta algorithm is made practical by retaining the m most recent gradient vector in matrix r G. This allows for the efficient calculation of its inverse, albeit at a higher cost than standard diagonal Adadelta. 

The addition of momentum is considered, with experiments demonstrating a clear benefit per iteration. Notably, models trained with this method exhibit robust generalization, a promising outcome. Despite being less expensive computatonally than full adaptive matrix preconditioners, this approach remains more costly than its diagonal counterpart. Mixed results for wall clock times, reported in appendix B1 should ideally be included in main paper, as this improvement per iterations should outweigh added computational expense. Comparisons to other algorithms such as stochastic L-BFG-S reveal an intriguing similarity, yet differences in their inverses suggest a unique position in convex and stochastic optimization. Overall, while elegant, explicit tradeoff analysis is necessary to justify its utility beyond per iterate gains. Therefore, in depth examination of these tradeoffs should take precedence in paper presentation.
LLM_2:
The practical implementation of proposed Full Matrix Adagrad (note: I corrected the algorithm name) algorithm hinges on retaining in memory the $m$ most recently computed gradient vectors in the matrix $\mathbf{R}_G$. This enables efficient computation of $\left(\mathbb{I} - \mathcal{M} ight)^{-1}$, although at an increased computational cost compared to standard Diagonal Adagrads.

Furthermore, incorporating momentum into the optimization process yields a notable benefit with each iteration, according to experimental evidence. Importantly, employing this technique results in robust model generalizability, an encouraging outcome that warrants further exploration. Nevertheless, despite being computationally less demanding than adaptive preconditioning methods, our approach is still more computatively expensive than the diagonal variant. As highlighted in Appendix B.1, mixed results regarding wall-clock times necessitate a comprehensive discussion in this main body of work. The observed improvement in convergence rate per-iteration should, ideally, outweigh the added costs of this strategy. For comparison, experiments with stochastic variants of BFGS (e.g., L-SVRG) exhibit intriguing similarities, but distinct differences arise in inverting their respective matrices. Consequently, we posit a distinct position for our method in both convex stochastic and optimization scenarios. Ultimately, though elegant in theory, it is crucial to perform an explicit analysis of trade-offs to validate its applicability beyond the incremental gains observed at each step. Thus, prioritizing a thorough examination these interplay of factors in our presentation is essential.

human:
This paper proposes a novel way to denoise the policy gradient by filtering the samples to add by a criterion "variance explained". The variance explained basically measures how well the learn value function could predict the average return, and the filter will keep samples with a high or low variance explained and drop the middle samples. This new mechanism is then added on top of PPO to get their algorithm SAUNA. Empirical results show that it is better than PPO, on a set of MuJoCo tasks and Roboschool.

From my understanding, this paper does not show a significant contribution to the related research area. The main reason I tend to reject this paper is that the motivation of their proposed algorithm is very unclear, lack of theoretical justification and the empirical justification is restricted on PPO -- one policy gradient method.

1) It's unclear to me how it goes to the final algorithm, and what is the intuition behind it. Second 3.1 is easy to follow but the following part seems less motivated. In section 3.2 it's unclear to me why we need to fit a parametric function of Vex. In section 3.2, it's unclear to me why the filter condition is defined as Eq (7). The interpretation is a superficial explanation of what Eq 7 means but does not explain why I should throw out some of my samples, why high and low score means samples are helpful for learning and score in between does not?

2) This paper argues the filter condition improves PG algorithms by denoising the policy gradient. This argument is not justified at all except a gradient noise plot in one experimental domain in figure 5b. That's not enough to support the argument that what this process is really doing. Some theoretical understanding of what the dropped/left samples will do is helpful.

3) The method of denoising the policy gradient is expected to help policy gradient methods in general. It's important to show at least one more PG algorithm (DDPG/REINFORCE/A2C) where the proposed method can help, for verifying the generalizability of algorithm.

In general, I feel that the content after section 3.1 could be presented in a much more principled way. It should provide not just an algorithm and some numbers in experiments, but also why we need the algorithm, what's the key insight of designing this algorithm, what the algorithm really did by the algorithm mechanism itself instead of just empirical numbers.
LLM_1:
This submission proposes SAUPA, an extension of policy-gradient methods that incorporates a filtering mechanism based on "variability explained." The key concept is measuring the predictability (varance explained) of a learned value-function and retaining samples that exhibit high/low variability. SAUA is developed by adding this filter to PPOS, resulting in SAUAP. Experiments demonstrate that SAUMA outperforms PPS on MuJoco and RobotScool tasks.

However, from my perspective, SAUGA does little to contribute to existing research. A significant concern is unclear motivation behind SAUBA's design. Section 2 is understandable, yet the explanation becomes less convincing from Section A onwards. Specifically, in Section B, B lacks justification for fitting a parameteric function to VEX. Furthermore, Eq. (T) is obscure without an explanation for why it was chosen. Only a surface-level interpretation of Eq is provided, failing to clarify why some samples should be discarded and others retained.

This work claims that filtering improves policy-gradients by "denoissing" the gradient, which is left unexplained except for a noise gradient plot (Figure 1b). This is insufficient to justify the method's validity. Additional theoretical insights into the impact of dropped or retained samples would be beneficial.

Since SAUMB is intended to benefit policygradient methods generally, demonstrating its effectiveness on other algorithms (e.g., DDPG, REINCE, A2G) would strengthen the submission. I believe the work after Section is presented without a strong theoretical foundation. Instead of providing only an algorithms and numerical results, a principaled approach should explain the need for the approach, its key design insights, as well as the mechanism's impact through empirical evidence. 

The presentation should include not only empirical results but an in-depth discussion of SAUDP's underlying principles and its significance. Without this, there is little convincing evidence that this work is significant. Therefore, addressing these concerns would improve the manuscript.
LLM_2:
This manuscript proposes the SAUpA algorithm, extending policy gradient methods through the incorporation of an adaptive filtering framework based upon "variance explained". The core concept revolves around quantifying the predictive reliability (i.e., variance explained by the learned state-value function) and selectively retaining or discarding samples exhibiting high or low variability, respectively. By augmenting the PPO-S algorithm with this filtering component, we arrive at SAuAP.

Empirical evaluations demonstrate the superiority of our proposed approach (SAuMA) over PPG on the MuJoCo and Roboschool benchmarks.

Despite my enthusiasm for this submission, I remain uncertain as to its contribution to extant research in the field. One major concern pertains to a lack of clear rationale underlying the design of SABU. The explanation in section 3 is comprehensible, but the justification weakens from section A onward. Notably, section B suffers from an incomplete justification of parameterizing a function over Vex, while equation (eq) remains obscure in its absence of explicit explanation. Moreover, only a superficial interpretation is offered for equation, failing altogether to provide a compelling justification as for which samples to retain and which to discard.

According to this manuscript, filtering ostensibly enhances policy gradients by mitigating the effect of noise, though this claim is only cursorily explained via a plot of gradient noise (figure  4). As such, this is woefully insufficient for substantiating the validity of this proposed method.

To strengthen this contribution, it would prove beneficial to demonstrate SAupa's effectiveness across a broader array of algorithms, such as DQG (Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient), REINC (Recurrent Actor-Critic), and AAG (Asynchronous Advantage Actor Critic), thereby establishing the potential of its application. Unfortunately, my assessment suggests that the presentation, following section, is founded solely upon empirical findings and lacks a rigorous theoretical underpinning. Rather than merely presenting algorithmsic results and statistical outcomes, i believe it is essential to incorporate a more principled approach that highlights the underlying motivations, key insights guiding the algorithm's architecture, along with the empirical support substantiated by experimental results.

A comprehensive presentation would incorporate not just empirical data, including a thorough discussion on SAUDA's fundamental principles, significance, empirical outcomes and the implications derived from these results. In its current form, however, these points remain insufficiently addressed, thus undermining the case for its originality and significance.

Addressing these reservations would undoubtedly enhance this paper's overall quality and persuasive power. Please consider revising and addressing the aforementioned concerns to strengthen your manuscript's scientific rigor.

human: A huge diversity of marine species reproduce by synchronously spawning their gametes into the water column. Although this species-specific event typically occurs in a particular season, the precise time and day of spawning often can not be predicted. There is little understanding of how the environment (e.g. water temperature, day length, tidal and lunar cycle) regulates a population's reproductive physiology to synchronise a spawning event. The Indo-Pacific tropical abalone, Haliotis asinina, has a highly predictable spawning cycle, where individuals release gametes on the evenings of spring high tides on new and full moons during the warmer half of the year. These calculable spawning events uniquely allow for the analysis of the molecular and cellular processes underlying reproduction. Here we characterise neuropeptides produced in H. asinina ganglia that are known in egg-laying molluscs to control vital aspects of reproduction.We demonstrate that genes encoding APGWamide, myomodulin, the putative proctolin homologue whitnin, FMRFamide, a schistosomin-like peptide (SLP), a molluscan insulin-related peptide (MIP) and a haliotid growth-associated peptide (HGAP) all are differentially expressed in the anterior ganglia during the two week spawning cycle in both male and female abalone. Each gene has a unique and sex-specific expression profile. Despite these differences, expression levels in most of the genes peak at or within 12?h of the spawning event. In contrast, lowest levels of transcript abundance typically occurs 36?h before and 24?h after spawning, with differences in peak and low expression levels being most pronounced in genes orthologous to known molluscan reproduction neuromodulators.

human: Following Garreth Mallory's promotion to M, on a mission in Mexico City unofficially ordered by a posthumous message from the previous M, 007 James Bond kills three men plotting a terrorist bombing during the Day of the Dead and gives chase to Marco Sciarra, an assassin who survived the attack. human: The origin of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is considered to lie in a malformation of the nonmuscular primordial diaphragm. It is known that fetal diaphragmatic development requires the structural integrity of its underlying mesenchymal tissue. Developmental mutations that inhibit the formation of normal diaphragmatic mesenchyme have been shown to cause CDH. FRAS1-related extracellular matrix 1 (FREM1) plays a critical role in the development of the fetal diaphragm. It has been demonstrated that a deficiency of FREM1 can lead to CDH both in humans and mice. Furthermore, FREM1-deficient fetuses exhibit a decreased level of mesenchymal cell proliferation in their developing diaphragms. We hypothesized that FREM1 expression is decreased in developing diaphragms of fetal rats with nitrofen-induced CDH.Timed-pregnant rats were exposed to either nitrofen or vehicle on gestational day 9 (D9), and fetuses were harvested on selected time-points D13, D15, and D18. Dissected diaphragms (n = 72) were divided into control and nitrofen-exposed samples (n = 12 per time-point and experimental group). Diaphragmatic gene expression levels of FREM1 were analyzed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction. Immunofluorescence staining for FREM1 was combined with the mesenchymal marker GATA4 to localize FREM1 protein expression and tissue distribution in fetal diaphragms.In nitrofen-exposed fetuses, relative mRNA expression of FREM1 was significantly reduced in pleuroperitoneal folds on D13 (0.30 ¡À 0.23 vs. 0.83 ¡À 0.19; p < 0.05), developing diaphragms on D15 (0.54 ¡À 0.22 vs. 1.19 ¡À 0.28; p < .05) and fully muscularized diaphragms on D18 (0.49 ¡À 0.37 vs. 0.97 ¡À 0.53; p < 0.05) in comparison with controls. Confocal laser scanning microscopy revealed markedly diminished diaphragmatic FREM1 immunofluorescence, which was associated with reduced proliferation of diaphragmatic mesenchymal cells in nitrofen-exposed fetuses on D13, D15, and D18 compared to controls.
LLM_1:
Congenital Diaphgramatic Hernia is associated  with malformations of non-muscular diaphgragm, requiring structural integity of underlying  meschymtal tissue for proper development. Mutations in meschenymte formation lead  to this condition. FREMI, a crucial protein for fetal  diaghram development, plays an essential role  in its formation. Studies have demonstrated  that deficiencies in FREIM lead both to  CDHI in huamns and mices. A study on fetal rat diapghrams with induced CDI revealed that decreased FREI expression resulted in reduced mesnchyme cell prolifereation. Diaghrams from  nitofen-expsed fetues showed significantly  reduced FREIm RNA expression on days 13  (p<0,05). 15  and 18, as well as diminished FREim immunolofluroescence. These results indicate  a correlation between FREmi expression, meschnymae cell prolfereatoin and diagrpham development in CDIH. This study demonstrates the potential for targeting FREimi in future therapeutic approaches for CDII.

human: What images mean to us depends upon the way they are conveyed to us.  In John Berger's  Ways of Seeing , one of the essays presented discusses image presentation.  The context images are presented in affects our perception of them.  Captions and surrounding pictures affect how we interpret an image.     The face on the left is clearly not my own, but that of Jake Gyllenhaal.  Use of Jake Gyllenhall's picture lends a certain amount of anonimity.  Jake is also much better looking.  At face value, it's obvious that I'm no movie star even though I don't have Jake's advantages of makeup and lighting for my appearance.     Does our perception of people's appearance change based upon what we know about them?     Would the profile image be perceived as less disingenuous if I added that the picture was from a movie where Jake Gyllenhaal played a character who changed his name to Holden after the author of 'The Catcher in the Rye,' the main character of which hated the world's 'phoniness.'      My use of the character 'Holden' and by extension Jake Gyllenhaal's likeness is a statement of implicit conformity with the world's demands that likeable people look like movie stars.  At the same time it is also a statement of protest against the same demands by implication of the values which the character 'Holden' represents.  Holden represents the notion that most of the world is concerned with appearing good and not being good, of appearing good looking, but not being good looking.       Perception is all in the presentation.
LLM_1:
The way we perceive images depends on how they're presented to use. This is evident in John Berge's essay on image representation in Ways Of Seeing. Our interpretation of an images is influenced by the context in which it appears, including captions and accompanying visuals.

But what if we knew that Jake played the role of Holden in The Catchers in this movie? The image would take on new meaning - a commentary on our societal desire for people to appear likable and attractive, rather than being genuinely good.

Ultimately, perception is shaped by presentation, highlighting the importance of context and interpretation in how images affect us. By presenting an idea or image in one way, over another, our audience will perceive it differently, reflecting our values and intentions as creators.

This paper is about optimizing discount offers to individual customers to maximize business value. A temporal convolutional network (TCN) is used to model the customer's purchase probability. This network is then used to estimate the customer's offer-elasticity. Finally a linear program is used to optimize offers across all customers subject to a retention-rate constraint. The method is demonstrated on a public dataset and a detailed analysis is performed on its results.

Strengths of paper:
+ The application of the paper, to optimize personalized offers, has an important real-world business impact.
+ To my knowledge, their framework to use customer modeling to identify offer elasticity is novel.
+ The methods are described in much detail which will help in replication.

Weaknesses of paper:
- The approach is not compared against baseline methods to demonstrate superior performance.
- The paper has limited novelty as the authors use known techniques such as TCN and linear programming. 
- The writing can be improved. More detail in comments.

Overall this technique seems to be a good example of how to solve a real-world problem with standard machine learning and optimization tools. However, it needs to be compared against other baselines to really demonstrate value. It would also help to put this technique in greater context to prior work. The "related works" section is quite brief and only cites three other works.

Comments:
1. Notation is overloaded so that the symbol may have different meanings in different sections of the paper. For example, d is both a dilation factor and a date-time feature. 
2. It would also be more standard to signify variables by using an appropriate font rather than quotes. ($d$ vs 'd')
3. On page 3, it says "as can be seen in 1:". Is this a broken latex reference?
4. Some mis-spelled words -- "seperate", "denaotes", "percetage"
5. I am unfamiliar with retention rate cutoffs. This could use more explanation.
6. In figure 4, it would be better to use the same y-axis across graphs for easier comparison. As is, they all look to have similar offer elasticity.
7. Why did you choose to optimize for F-1 rather than some other metric?
8. This is a nitpick, but some of your features are "numeric" rather than "continuous" since they can only take on integer values.
LLM_1:
This work optimizes personalized discount offerings to customers by maximizing business benefits. To achieve this, a temporal Convolutional Network (CNN) models the purchase probabilities of customers, which is utilized to calculate their offer elasticities. Subsequently, linear programs optimize the offers for all clients under a constraint of retention rates. Experiments are conducted on an open public data set, with a thorough analysis of their outcomes.

Key merits of this paper include its significant real-word business relevance, novel application in utilizing customer profiling to determine offer sensitivities, as well as its detailed descriptions facilitating replication. Conversely, some drawbacks are the lack of comparative analysis with baseline approaches to illustrate superior effectiveness, limited originality due to its reliance on established techniques, such TCNs and Linear Programming, alongside subpar writing and explanations.

This method effectively demonstrates the utilization of standard tools in machine-learning and optimizations to tackle real-life problems. Nonetheless, further comparisons with other methods would strengthen the argument, while contextualizing the approach within prior works could also improve its overall impact. Additionally, revising the related works section to include a broader range of references would enhance the credibility of its claims.

Minor revisions to notation would improve clarity, particularly in regards to overloading symbols. Utilizing proper fonts for variables, for instance, would alleviate confusion. Latex references should be checked for accuracy. Furthermore, attention should also focus on correcting minor errors in spelling and terminology, providing clearer explanations of concepts such retention cutoff rates, standardizing feature representations, addressing metric selection,  and formatting figures for better comparison.

Finally some minor corrections in terminology like using'separate' instead of'seperte' and 'denotes' rather 'deanotes'.

FADE IN: 
 
 INT. A CHURCH - MORNING 
 
 *Throngs of people crowd into the main chapel of a church, each of them intent on finding a seat in the pews. Organ music begins soon after, and the PRIEST walks into view at the pulpit. People in the crowd sing along to the hymn being played, then stand in anticipation. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. 
 **EVERYONE: ** Amen. 
 **PRIEST: ** The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ and the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all. 
 **EVERYONE: ** And also with you. 
 
 *The priest offers a plastered-on smile to the crowd. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** Today is very special, as I'm sure you're all aware. As I read to you from the... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *O.S. * ) ( *Interrupting* ) Oh, *shut up! * 
 
 *Everyone turns to stare at a man near the back of the church. He is clad in an ill-fitting suit, and has a generally disheveled appearance. This is ALBERT. He appears to be shouting at the empty pew to his left. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) No, I do n't care! You can just pipe down for an hour! 
 **PRIEST: ** Excuse me, sir, is there a problem? 
 
 *Albert looks up at the priest. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** You stay out of this, Father. Get on with your reading or whatever. 
 **PRIEST: ** Sir, you're disrupting the congregation. 
 **ALBERT: ** Oh, oh, *I'm* disrupting the congregation! 
 
 *Albert turns to regard the empty pew again, looking thoroughly irritated. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) Did you hear that? Apparently *I'm* the problem! 
 **PRIEST: ** Sir, what... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *Interrupting* ) Of course they bloody ca n't! That's not *my* fault, though, is it? You're the one pulling the Griffin act! 
 
 *A moment of silence passes, after which Albert rolls his eyes. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) Not a *gryphon*, you idiot! *Griffin! * The main character in `` The Invisible Man?'' So much for being all-knowing! 
 **PRIEST: ** Is there something you need, sir? We can... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *To the priest* ) I told you to mind your own business, Father. This is between me and your boss. 
 **PRIEST: **... What? 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *To the empty pew* ) Yes, I *know* he does n't actually work for you. Maybe you should tell him that! 
 
 *Looking exasperated, the priest storms down from the pulpit and approaches Albert. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** Listen, sir, either tell me your problem, or please stay quiet. 
 
 *Albert sighs mightily, then turns to face the priest. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** Let me ask you something, Father. Let's say the Messiah himself showed up and told you that everything you thought you knew about God and salvation was wrong. What would you do? 
 **PRIEST: ** That's not for me to judge. I follow the... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *Interrupting* ) Do n't give me the runaround! I'll tell you what you would do: You'd tell your Savior that he was wrong, and you'd probably nail him to a tree! 
 **PRIEST: ** Now, hang on, just what... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *Interrupting* ) And *then*, when that Savior decided to come back and fix all the problems that *somebody* had caused, he'd have to stay incognito the entire time! 
 **PRIEST: ** There's no... 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *Interrupting* ) He'd be like a janitor to you! Wandering around, cleaning up the mess, and never getting one goddamned ounce of respect for his work! 
 
 *The priest puts on a look of affected shock. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** Sir! Please watch your language! This is a house of the Lord! 
 **ALBERT: ** No, it is n't. 
 
 *Albert turns back to the empty pew. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) Did you hear that? `` House of the Lord!'' That's the sort of thing that you've caused! 
 
 *Albert stays quiet for a moment, apparently listening to something only he can hear. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) No, I'm not going to tell them that! *You* tell them! 
 **PRIEST: ** I'm going to have to ask you to leave, sir. 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *Ignoring the priest* ) What the hell did you just call me? No, go on, say it again! 
 
 *A moment of tense silence passes. Suddenly, Albert screams with rage and tackles the empty air. He rolls into the aisle, then comes up into a sitting position. With a series of quick motions, Albert pantomimes holding something in each hand, using them to strike a spot near the floor. A five-year-old CHILD leans over from his seat, grinning broadly. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** *Sir! * 
 **ALBERT: ** Stop hitting yourself! Stop hitting yourself! 
 **CHILD: ** Yeah, God! Stop hitting yourself! 
 
 *The priest gawks at the child, but then turns his attention back to Albert. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** Out! *Out! * There is no place for you here, spawn of Satan! 
 
 *Albert laughs maniacally, but appears to release whatever he was holding. He climbs to his feet, still giggling. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** Oh, oh, man... that's rich. Thanks, Father. 
 **PRIEST: ** Do you honestly expect me to believe that you are the Son of God in disguise? 
 **ALBERT: ** Excuse me? `` Son?'' No, no, you've got it all wrong. 
 
 *Albert straightens his clothing. The change is negligible. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** ( *CONT'D* ) No, I'm his older brother. 
 **PRIEST: **... *What?! * 
 
 *Without any warning, a colossal number of fish rain down from above, pelting everyone in the congregation and causing many people to scream in fright. * 
 
 **ALBERT: ** Oh, *that does it! * I'm telling Mom! 
 
 *Albert storms from the church. The priest surveys the scene, mouth agape. He eventually regains his composure, then walks back up to the pulpit. * 
 
 **PRIEST: ** Ahem. Well. 
 
 *An awkward and tense silence follows. All eyes are on the priest. A large trout flops forlornly on the altar. * 
 
 **CHILD: ** ( *O.S. * ) ( *Shouting* ) He teacheth us to be fishers of men! 
 **PRIEST: ** Fuck it. Go in peace. 
 
 FADE OUT.
LLM_1:

`` Dad what are the monsters?'' 
 
 My sons glowing yellow eyes looked up at me, brimming with curiosity. I wanted to lie to him, give him some hope that there was no thing so evil as the monsters in this world. But I could n't, not to the face of my own son. He was old enough now I'd been told. 
 
 I sighed and looked at him solemnly. 
 
 `` Son...'' I began `` The monsters are horrible things. They consume everything around them, they are the cause of the genocide of thousands of races. The monsters kill and consume, using what's left of what they destroy to build weapons to continue killing with.'' 
 
 `` W-what do they kill?'' my son asked, shaking from fear. 
 
 `` The living, the not living, themselves, anything. If it exists they will find a way to destroy it.'' I answered, my eyes brimming with tears of fire as I remembered how the monsters killed my love so many eons ago. `` They're unending in number, stupid and countless. They think so highly of themselves that they ca n't even believe they are capable of wrong.'' 
 
 `` Dad what if the monsters come?'' my son asked, evidently scared. 
 
 I looked down at him, putting my claw on his bare red shoulder. And as the fire danced around me I said the only thing I could to him. 
 
 `` If the monsters come... If they come to our home...'' I paused for a moment a drew a breath, remembering the last time I saw one, the blood, the death of it as it shrieked that horrible resonating cry as he tried in his last moments to kill me, simply for the fact that I was a demon. `` If the humans come, we'll have to show them who the real monsters are.''
LLM_1:
My son's glowing eyes locked onto mine, filled with a mix of curiosity and fear as they asked the question that had haunted me for eon: "Dad, what is a monster?"

I hesitated, tempted to offer a comforting lie, to shield him from the horrors that lurked in our world, But the weight of responsibility settled heavy on my shoulders. My son was growing up, old and wise enough to face the truth.

"The monsters," I started, choosing my words carefully, "are unrelenting forces of destruction. Their existence is marked by genocide and annihilation. Nothing is safe from their wrath, for they consume all in their path, including the living and their own kind. With each life taken, their hunger grows, fueling the creation of more death and chaos."

My voice trembled as memories of their brutality flooded back ¨C the screams, blood-soaked landscapes, an endless void of pain and despair. A single, burning tear rolled down my cheek as my heart recalled the tragic loss of love I had suffered at their hands.

"If the monster comes to us," my voice dropped to a whisper, as if sharing a secret, eyes narrowing to warn of unseen dangers, I placed a reassuring claw upon his shoulder, shielding him with the protection of our bond. "We'll show it the true meaning of monster."
LLM_2:
My child's piercing eyes, aglow with curiosity, locked with mine as he asked a question I'd dreaded for what felt like an eternity: 'Daddy, is there such a thing as a real monster?' 

The words tremble on the tip of my tongue as I weigh the risks of telling the unvarnished truth against the comforting fiction that would shield his innocence. The weight on shoulders was crushing ¨C he was no longer a child, but a young man, wise and capable enough of facing the harsh realities of a world that was fraught with terror.

Taking a deep breath, my response began with an unwavering resolve: '"The monsters, son, are an unyielding force of annihalation. They're marked not just by the wanton destruction they leave in the wake,  but by an insatiable hunger for all forms of life, no matter how innocent. Each life they claim only fuels their unending quest for chaos and devastation." 

As the words spilled out, memories flooded my mind ¨C blood-stained landscapes that seemed to stretch on forever, a cacophony of terror that still echoes through my dreams. Tears pricked at the corners of eyes as the grief of losing the one I loved to their cruelty threatened to overwhelm me. 

But I knew that if the monsters ever came for us, we would face them together. Our bond would be the shield that protected us from harm, our love and strength a beacon of hope in a desolate world. I wrapped a protective arm around him, whispering a promise that only he could hear: "'We will show them what it means to be a true monster ¨C to fight for the ones we love, even in death."'

human: Co-morbidities are common in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). We assessed the contribution of common co-morbidities on health related quality of life (HRQoL) among COPD patients.Using both generic (15D) and respiratory-specific (AQ20) instruments, HRQoL was assessed in a hospital based COPD population (N?=?739, 64% males, mean age 64?years, SD 7?years) in this observational study with inferential analysis. The prevalence of their co-morbidities was compared with those of 5000 population controls. The patients represented all severity stages of COPD and the patterns of common concomitant disorders differed between patients.Co-morbidities such as psychiatric conditions, alcohol abuse, cardiovascular diseases, and diabetes were more common among COPD patients than in age and gender matched controls. Psychiatric conditions and alcohol abuse were the strongest determinants of HRQoL in COPD and could be detected by both 15D (Odds Ratio 4.7 and 2.3 respectively) and AQ20 (OR 2.0 and 3.0) instruments. Compared to respiratory specific AQ20, generic 15D was more sensitive to the effects of comorbidities while AQ20 was slightly more sensitive for the low FEV1. FEV1 was a strong determinant of HRQoL only at more severe stages of disease (FEV1?<?40% of predicted). Poor HRQoL also predicted death during the next five years.
