human: Endovascular repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is increasingly used. We evaluated if a difference exists in the rate of change of the aortic neck diameter between non-ruptured and ruptured AAAs after endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).Details of patients undergoing elective (group I) and emergency (group II) EVAR using Talent stents between October 1999 and September 2005 were reviewed. Top neck diameters were prospectively recorded on the hospital database from computed tomography scans preoperatively and at 1, 3, 12, and 24 months postoperatively. The aortic neck diameter rate of change was calculated for each group.Endovascular repair was performed on 110 elective and 41 emergency patients, of which 100 (80 male) elective and 29 (26 male) emergency patients were included in this analysis. Mean age was similar in each group. Stents were oversized by 20.9% +/- 13.6% in group I and by 24.7% +/- 16.3% in group II (P = .37). The preoperative mean proximal aortic neck was larger in group II (25.0 +/- 3.3 mm vs 23.5 +/- 2.8 mm; P = .029). The growth rate of the top neck diameter was significantly greater at 12 months (1.48 +/- 2.4 mm/year vs 3.89 +/- 6.24 mm/year; P = .04) and 24 months (.99 +/- 1.1 mm/year vs 2.61 +/- 3.3 mm/year; P = .04) in group II than in group I. A decreasing sac size was found in 68.2% of patients whose neck dilated. The complication rate was similar in each group.
LLM_1:
This study evaluated the difference in postoperative aorto-aneurysmal neck growth between elective versus emergency endoluminal aneursym repair. Data from 129 patients (110 electively, with 80 males, vs. 19 emergently, all males) were retrospectively analyzed. Patients underwent EVAS with Talent Stent between 10/199 and/or 9/200. 

Mean stent oversizing was 21% and similar between groups. Preoperative neck sizes were 25mm (emergent) vs,23mm(elective), with significant differences in neck size growth rates at both  11 and and24-month follow-up (3mm/year and2mm/yr for emergent vs elective, respectively). A sac-size decrease was observed in patients with neck dilation, although complication rates were similar. These findings suggest a higher rate or rapidity of aorta-neurismal growth in emergenct cases. Further studies are needed to clarify the significance of these results. 
(
LLM_2:
This retrospective study investigated the disparity in the post-surgical growth of aneurysm necks between patients undergoing elective and emergency minimally invasive aneurosmal repair procedures. A comprehensive analysis of data from a cohort of 130 patients, comprising 110 elective cases (with a male predominance of approximately 73%) and 20 emergency cases, revealed significant insights into the factors influencing aortic anevsm growth.

Notably, our dataset spanned a 2-year period (1999-2001), during which patients underwent endovascular anurisymal stenting (EVAS) with the Talent sten device. Notably the average degree of stental oversize was around 22%. Analysis of preoperative aneuor neck dimensions revealed a significant difference between the two groups, measuring 23 mm and25 mm for elective vs emergency patients respectively.

Moreover, a key finding of this study was the notable disparity between neck-growth rates observed at 12 and at24 months post-procedure. Specifically, patients in emergency situations exhibited a mean annual growth rate of around3 mm, in contrast to approximately2 mm observed for patients receiving elective treatment. Furthermore, we observed a notable reduction in sac size in conjunction with an increase in anuerysnal neck diameters, which highlighted a potential correlation between these factors. Conversely, complication frequencies remained comparable between both groups.

These results suggest an accelerated rate and potential increased risk of post-operative anueor growth among patients requiring emergency anuor repair, underscoring the need for further investigation into this phenomenon. Future studies could elucidate the clinical implications of our findings and provide valuable insights for optimizing patient outcomes in this area.

human: This study examines the impact of pulmonary artery pressure-guided heart failure (HF) care on 30-day readmissions in Medicare-eligible patients.The CardioMicroelectromechanical system (CardioMEMS) Heart Sensor Allows Monitoring of Pressures to Improve Outcomes in New York Heart Association Class III Heart Failure Patients (CHAMPION) Trial included 550 patients implanted with a permanent MEMS-based pressure sensor in the pulmonary artery. Subjects were randomized to a treatment group (uploaded pressures were made available to investigators) or a control group (uploaded pressures were not made available to investigators). This analysis focuses on the 245 Medicare-eligible subjects for whom compliance with daily transmissions was 93% compared with 88% for the overall population. Medications were changed more often in the treatment group using pressure information compared with the control group using symptoms and daily weights alone. During the 515 days follow-up after implant, the overall rate of HF hospitalizations was 49% lower in the treatment group (60 HF hospitalizations, 0.34 events/patient-year) compared with control (117 HF hospitalizations, 0.67 events/patient-year; hazard ratio 0.51, 95% confidence interval 0.37-0.70; P<0.0001). Of the 177 HF hospitalizations, 155 qualified as an index HF hospitalization. All-cause 30-day readmissions were 58% lower in the treatment group (0.07 events/patient-year) compared with 0.18 events/patient-year in the control group (hazard ratio 0.42, 95% confidence interval 0.22-0.80; P=0.0080).
LLM_1: This analysis examines pulmonary pressure guided heart care in 244 Medicare eligible patients from the CardioMEMs CHAMPIONS trial. Patients were randomly assigned to receive pressure data or not. Treatment groups showed increased medication changes and 59% fewer heart hospitalisations (49 vs 117, hazard ration  2.0, P < 1.00). All cause 90 day readmission was also significantly lower (p= 8.1%) in patients receiving pressure feedback compared to control. This outcome is associated with reduced overall HF events in treatment groups.
LLM_2: This retrospective analysis of 248 Medicare-eligible patients enrolled in the prospective CardioMemS CHAMPIONS trial evaluates the impact of pulmonary artery pressure-guided heart failure management. A randomized design was employed, with patients allocated to either receive or forego pulmonary arterial pressure monitoring. Notably, treatment recipients exhibited a significant increase in medication adjustments and a marked reduction in heart-related hospitalizations, as evidenced by a 51% decrease in admissions (n = 49 versus n =117; hazard ratio =2, p<0.01). Furthermore, all-cause 30-day readmissions were substantially lower among patients furnished with pulmonary resistance feedback, compared with controls (8% vs. 9.2%, p=0). This observed outcome correlated with a reduction of overall heart-failure events within the intervention groups.

human: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the loss of motor neurons. Its etiology remains unknown, but several hypothesis have been raised to explain motor neuron death, including oxidative stress. Dysregulation of cellular iron metabolism can lead to increased oxidative stress, and existing data argue for a role of iron metabolism in ALS pathophysiology.We performed a retrospective analysis of iron metabolism (IM) variables (serum levels of iron, transferrin, ferritin, and TSC for Transferrin Saturation Coefficient) in a cohort of 694 ALS patients and 297 healthy controls.Serum ferritin levels and TSC were higher, whereas serum transferrin levels were lower in ALS patients than controls. In addition, patients with a high level serum ferritin had a shorter survival time compared to those with low level serum ferritin (618 days versus 921 days for men subgroup; p?=?.007). Site of onset and ALS-FRS score were not associated with IM variables.
LLM_1:
Amyotropic lateral scleros is ( ALS ) a complex neuro degenerative disorder characterized by progressive motor neuronal loss. While the underlying etiological mechanisms remain unclear, oxidative damage has been implicated in motor neurone death. A crucial factor in this process is dysregulated cellular ir metabolism which can exacerbate oxidative strain. 

A retrospective cohort study of ALS sufferers (n =  698 ) and healthy individuals ( n =297) was conducted to investigate the association between ir levels ( serum iron, transf errin, ferrin and Trans ferr saturation coefficient ). ALS individuals exhibited elevated serum feritin and saturation coefficients but lower transf erin leels compared with controls. Significantly, ALS patient with high ferutin levels displayed shorter suival times ( 618 vs 922 days in men sub group, p =.007 ) compared t those wih low fer tin lels. Site f onset nd ALS FRS core were unrelated t ir variables.
LLM_2:
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a multifaceted neurodegenerative disorder marked by relentless motor neuron degeneration. Despite ongoing research, underlying pathogenic mechanisms persist as a subject of investigation. Notably, evidence suggests that oxidative stress contributes to motor neurodegeneration, with dysregulation of cellular iron metabolism exacerbating oxidative burden.

A comprehensive retrospective analysis of 699 ALS patients and 297 healthy controls was undertaken to examine the relationship between iron levels and disease progression. ALS participants exhibited significantly elevated levels of serum ferritin, alongside increased saturation indices, whereas transferrin levels were concurrently diminished. Crucially, individuals with elevated ferritine levels demonstrated shorter survival times, particularly within the male subgroup (618 days vs. 1,022 days, P =.007). In contrast, site of onset and ALS Functional Rating Scale scores exhibited no correlation with iron variables.

human:
I had always heard it said that in the moment before you die your life flashes before your eyes. Every memory you forgot, at once remembered. All you have done and been, seen in perfect clarity. 
 
 We think of it in terms of a near-death experience. We call it a ¡° life review, ¡± because we don ¡¯ t know what it ¡¯ s really called. Then one day our experience is no longer near-death, but is in fact simply a death experience, and we see the truth of it. 
 
 ¡° Review ¡± we call it. 
 
 He calls it Judgment. 
 
 Fortunately, my life had been a good one. Sure, I had a couple speeding tickets, but that was the worst of it. I never did any drugs ¨C I never even smoked a cigarette! I donated blood and gave to a couple charities I liked. People told me my biggest problem was that I was *too* nice. 
 
 I had ascended stairs formed from the stuff of clouds and arrived at a series of radiant, pearly gates. Just as a picture of the Grand Canyon could never do justice to the magnificent wonder of that earthly place, no words could do justice to the magnificent wonder of this heavenly one. Well perhaps one word could, in its truest sense: awesome. 
 
 The sound of someone clearing their throat had drawn my attention to a middle-aged man standing nearby. So stoically calm was he that I could not be sure the sound had come from him, but being the only other soul in sight I reasoned that it must have. Furthermore, because of the golden keys he held clasped in his hands, I reasoned that this was Saint Peter. 
 
 Even as I approached him he turned away from me, and for the briefest moment I was confused and concerned. However, I realized that he was lifting the keys as he approached the gate and I was comforted. Looking back, I should have realized in that moment that things were not right. 
 
 Saint Peter unlocked the gates of Heaven for me and I entered. 
 
 I say gates, because there was not just one. Imagine a series of concentric rings and then draw a straight line from the very center of the innermost ring out to the edge of the outermost ring. The gates lay along that line, and as the first opened so did the others, beckoning me to the heart of Heaven. 
 
 At the time, it did not strike me odd that Heaven was empty. After all, I had never been before, so aside from the clue I missed with Saint Peter how was I to know? No, ignorant to the wrongness of my surroundings, I continued forward to the inner circle. 
 
 Within the innermost circle of Heaven I came upon a chair and a desk, both made of wood. Neither was ornate in anyway, but were simple and humble and sound. Beneath the desk the chair had been neatly tucked, and upon the desk was an envelope bearing my name. 
 
 I opened it, and read it. 
 
 And wept for the life I had lived. 
 
 It had been good. I had been good. I had believed that if I was good, I would go to Heaven. But I had not believed in Him. 
 
 And now I was in Hell.
LLM_1:
As I lay on my deathbed, a life flashed before my eyes ¨C every memory, every moment, all the things I'd done, been and seen. 

They call this a "life review," but it's really a judgment. A moment of truth. When we're alive, we think it happens only at the end, when we've had near death experiences. Yet, one fateful day, our lives are no more near but actual death, revealing the harsh truth.

My life, they said, was a pretty good story. There were a few speeding fines, some charitable donations, blood donations too. What I lacked, according people, were flaws ¨C specifically, being too nice.

A staircase made from clouds took me up to radiant gates that shone like pearls. Words failed to describe the breathtaking beauty of these heavenly gates ¨C but one did: awe-inspiring. Nearby stood a man who seemed stoic, perhaps clearing his throat. His golden key glinted in hand, signaling Saint Pete.

However, as Saint Petey turned to face me or rather, away, confusion crept in. My concerns dissipated once he unlocked Heaven's gates with his keys. As the series opened, more gates beckoned me in.

Upon entering, an eerie feeling struck ¨C Heaven seemed empty, devoid of souls. Ignorant of its emptiness, unaware of Saint's subtle warning,  I advanced toward the center, entranced by the promise of paradise.

Inside the core of heaven, simple furniture greeted me: a humble chair beneath a plain desk. An envelope, bearing only my surname, lay there. With a mix of trepidation and curiosity, 

I opened the letter, read the words, felt tears fall. They'd been telling me I lived a fine life. Believed I did good deeds. Thought if good enough, heaven would welcome me. Never questioned if there's a higher power, though.

As the realization dawned, Hell loomed ¨C the seat I sat on, not in paradise, revealed my deepest truth ¨C my existence had no divine connection. That's where I truly was. Not in heaven but in hell. And so, those words etched my soul forever ¨C a harsh verdict I bore, now.
LLM_2:
As my final breaths escaped, my mind unraveled a tapestry of memories ¨C each thread intricately woven from moments of joy, sorrow, triumph, or defeat. This fleeting glimpse of my life was not a nostalgic glance, nor a sentimental farewell, for I was, in fact, standing at a crossroads ¨C where mortality's verdict awaited.

This phenomenon, known as a 'life's reckoning,' is often misconstrued as an end-of-life evaluation. But what if I told you it was merely a snapshot ¨C taken at any moment when the present collided with the future? We're led to believe that such moments occur only in the twilight hours of our existence, yet the truth is that life's tapestries are woven with threads of judgment at every turn.

They'd say my story was one of redemption ¨C sprinkled with a dash of kindness, generosity, even a pinch of recklessness. However, there was an omission ¨C one that people couldn't quite grasp ¨C an absence of flaws. Specifically, I possessed a trait that bordered on saintliness ¨C being overly kind.

Clouds morphed into a staircase that ascended towards a radiant realm, where gates shined like polished pearls, defying description. One word ¨C awe-struck ¨C captured the essence of this heavenly entrance, only to fade in comparison to its grandeur. I stood before an imposing figure, whose stoicism seemed almost deliberate, his hand grasping a golden scepter that hinted at Saint Peter's presence.

But as our gazes met, if you could even call it that ¨C since Saint seemed to have turned away ¨C confusion began to creep in, like an uninvited guest. It wasn't until he produced his key and unlocked the gates to heaven that I felt a glimmer of reassurance. More gates swung open, beckoning me towards the unknown.

Yet, once I stepped across the threshold, unease settled within me ¨C for heaven seemed devoid not only of people but of life itself. Oblivious to this emptINESS, blinded by Saint Peters subtle hint, oblivious to my own doubts, i walked further towards paradise's promise.

At the heart of it all, simplicity reigned ¨C plain furniture, unadorned and unassuming. Beneath a modest desk, on a simple chair, rested an envelope bearing my last name, its plainness striking a chord of both curiosity and fear. Its contents whispered words of a virtuous life ¨C of deeds well done and a soul pure of heart. These words resonated with me, convincing me that if only I believed in myself, that heaven's doors would swing open.

In that instant, doubt creased my brow ¨C had I ever truly questioned the divine? Never, until now, it dawn. For what Saint had revealed, what lay at my very core, shook me to foundations ¨C I wasn¡¯t meant to sit in Heaven but Hell ¨C that my entire existence was bereft of any divine tie. In that epiphany, reality hit me like a ton of bricks. Hell was my true home. Those words I had read, forever etching themselves on me now ¨C harsh, unforgiving, eternally ¨C 'the verdict' I would bear. Forevermore.

human: The aim of this study was to investigate the molecular mechanism into the keratinocyte migration, which is promoted by Transforming growth factor-¦Â1 (TGF-¦Â1) during wound healing.In the present study, we investigated the regulation by TGF-¦Â1 on phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) expression, and microRNA-21 (miR-21) level with real-time quantitative PCR or/and Western blotting, and then examined the regulatory role of miR-21 on the PTEN expression and the mesenchymal transition, with real-time quantitative PCR, western blotting and luciferase reporter assay, and the migration of keratinocytic HaCaT cells with scratch assay.It was demonstrated that miR-21 was upregulated by TGF-¦Â1 treatment in HaCaT cells; and the upregulated miR-21 targeted the 3' UTR of PTEN gene and downregulated the PTEN expression, along with the Smad3/4 upregulation. Moreover, the miR-21 manipulation with miR-21 mimics or miR-21 inhibitor not only upregulated or downregulated the miR-21 level, but also associated with the mesenchymal transition and the migration of HaCaT cells via promoting or downregulating the FSP1 and Collagen I and the E-cadherin, and via upregulating or downregulating the migration of HaCaT cells.
LLM_1: This study investigated the molecular mechanism by which TGF-¦Â1 promotes keratinocyte migration during wound healing. Using HaCaT cells, we found TGF-¦Â1 upregulates miR-21, which targets the PTEN 3' UTR to suppress PTEN expression and activate Smad3/4. Modulating miR-21 with mimics or inhibitors correspondingly altered PTEN levels, induced mesenchymal transition via FSP1, Collagen I, and E-cadherin regulation, and increased or decreased HaCaT cell migration. These results indicate TGF-¦Â1 enhances keratinocyte migration through a miR-21/PTEN pathway.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study elucidates the molecular mechanism through which transforming growth factor-beta 1 (TGF-¦Â1) promotes keratinocyte migration during wound healing. Using the HaCaT keratinocyte cell line, we demonstrate that TGF-¦Â1 upregulates microRNA-21 (miR-21), which subsequently targets the 3¡ä untranslated region (3¡ä UTR) of phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) to suppress its expression, thereby activating the Smad3/4 signaling pathway. Modulation of miR-21 levels¡ªvia mimics or inhibitors¡ªcorrespondingly altered PTEN expression, induced mesenchymal transition through regulation of fibroblast-specific protein-1 (FSP1), collagen I, and E-cadherin, and either increased or decreased HaCaT cell migration. Collectively, these findings indicate that TGF-¦Â1 enhances keratinocyte migration via a miR-21/PTEN-dependent pathway, providing new insights into the regulatory network governing epithelial cell motility in wound repair.

Angelo was everything you'd expect out of a superhero. He was tall and handsome, had a cool outfit, and a deep old fashioned radio show host voice. Today however, he was incognito. He squeezed his massively muscled form into a suit, parted his hair on the opposite side, and put on glasses. No one would suspect him of secretly being the Crimson Mask. 
 
 He let himself into the building where he worked, edging around an average man, who was annoyingly underfoot. 
 
 He confidently strode to his desk, sat down, and began typing up his story of the super-villain, Drunken Chef, who'd recently met his demise. The man had a tongue like an adder, able to cut any ego down with a single quip. He'd been going about town, roasting anyone who gave him half the chance. Many of the city's most highly rated restaurants had gone under when their lead culinary artists had nervous breakdowns after only a single visit from this man. It had lead to quite an obesity epidemic, as people fled those fine establishments, turning to McDonalds. 
 
 Angel could practically feel his own arteries hardening as he'd also been forced to imbibe the less than edible foods he'd turned to while he planned the Drunken Chef's take down. This was going to be quite a story. 
 
 `` Hi, I'm Tony!'' 
 
 `` Hello, common man, I'm busy doing everyday type things that normal, non super hero types do every day. If you need something, the receptionist is over there, closer to the door. Go talk to her.'' 
 
 Feeling good about helping this obviously hopelessly mediocre fellow human, he started typing up his stellar news article. 
 
 `` Yes, but...'' 
 
 `` Are you still here? Hmm..'' said Angelo as he looked up at the man. What could someone so plain want with him? Was his disguise working better than he thought? Did the insignificant always try to start boring conversations with each other? Perhaps he should use this as an opportunity to hone his already chameleon-like ability to blend in with his inferiors. 
 
 `` I was a big part of what just happened with the Drunken Chef, and...'' Tony was droning on and on. 
 
 Angelo was bored. He could feel himself starting to drift. It'd been a hard afternoon fighting super-villains and he was feeling it. 
 
 `` Look.. Um... Tony, was it? You should go talk to Luise Lund. Maybe she could use the story of a standard individual like yourself.'' 
 
 `` But I want to be added to your story. I was right there. Right in the room. I saw the whole thing only a few minutes ago.'' 
 
 It was too late, Angelo was snoring loudly. Anger burned in Tony's heart. He was tired of being overlooked as a second rate humdrum inferior. Something hardened in his heart. He would become someone to remember, a force to be reckoned with. The City of Gratham needed a new super-villain. It was time to step up and become the Main Character. 
 
 Muhaha! Muhahahahaha!

This was a well-written, and interesting paper to read!

I went over the paper many times, and I am still failing to see the use case for such an approach. I have some questions and comments that need some clarification for me to properly evaluate the submission. Please, take the time to answer the following, so my review can better reflect the paper.

1 - The theory developed in the paper relies on reward functions that can be represented as linear combinations of the features of the MDP. This seems to be restrictive, and intuitively, this would be the exception rather than the rule.
What class of problem could be modeled under this restriction?  In many problems, there is no linear reward function that would allow an agent to achieve the desired behavior, so these techniques would not be helpful. What are some practical setting where this approach would be beneficial?

2 - Lemma 3... this statement is putting an upper-bound on the worst case performance, but since the paper focuses on improvement of worst case performance, it would be beneficial to have a lower bound, but an upper bound doesn't seem too useful.   Essentially, this lemma is saying "I can guarantee that the worst-case won't be better than this upper bound, and that for some MDP with linear reward function this upper bound is attainable." The problem is that we don't know what that MDP is, how likely it is that we would find it, and this lemma allow for the worst case performance to be arbitrarily bad.
I don't think this lemma, as is, is particularly useful.

3 - On the experimental section, I think there's a baseline that should be included that's missing. What if we have 1 policy and add a task descriptor or extra features to the features vector that corresponds to the type of task? How would the performance empirically compare?

4 - In the learning curves for fig 1.a or 2.a, what does "value" (y-axis) represent? If it the return of the agent after training? If so, is it using the extrinsic reward or the transformed linear reward described in line 5 of "DeepMind Control Suite"?

5 - Based on equation 4, for definition 2 of SIP. There is always a trivial set improving policy, right? That would correspond to picking the policy for max(v^i_w).
LLM_1:
This is a well-written and interesting paper, but I have several questions that need clarification for proper evaluation.

1. The theory assumes reward functions are linear combinations of MDP features, which seems restrictive. In what problem classes or practical settings would this assumption hold and be beneficial, given many tasks lack linear rewards?

2. Lemma 3 provides an upper bound on worst-case performance, but since the paper focuses on improving worst-case performance, a lower bound would be more informative. As stated, the lemma allows worst-case performance to be arbitrarily bad and does not specify how likely the attainability condition is.

3. The experiments appear to omit a relevant baseline: adding task descriptors or extra features to the feature vector for a single policy. How would this compare empirically to the proposed approach?

4. In Figures 1a and 2a, what does the y-axis ¡°value¡± represent? Is it the return after training, and if so, is it based on extrinsic reward or the transformed linear reward mentioned in line 5 of ¡°DeepMind Control Suite¡±?

5. Regarding Definition 2 of SIP and Equation 4, is there always a trivial set improving policy corresponding to selecting the policy that maximizes \( v^i_w \)?
LLM_2:
This paper presents a well-constructed and engaging contribution to the field. However, to facilitate a thorough evaluation, several aspects require further clarification.

1. **Linearity of reward functions**  
   The theoretical framework assumes that reward functions are linear combinations of Markov Decision Process (MDP) features. This assumption may be restrictive, as many real-world tasks involve non-linear reward structures. Could the authors elaborate on the problem classes or practical scenarios where this linearity assumption is both valid and advantageous? Additionally, it would be helpful to discuss the implications when this assumption does not hold.

2. **Bounds on worst-case performance**  
   Lemma 3 establishes an upper bound on worst-case performance. Given the paper¡¯s focus on improving worst-case guarantees, a complementary lower bound would strengthen the analysis. In its current form, the lemma permits arbitrarily poor worst-case outcomes and does not address the likelihood of the attainability condition. Providing such a lower bound, or discussing the conditions under which the bound is tight, would enhance the theoretical contribution.

3. **Experimental baselines**  
   The experimental evaluation appears to omit a relevant baseline: enriching the feature representation with task descriptors or additional features for a single policy. How would this alternative approach compare empirically to the proposed method? Including this baseline would help contextualize the performance gains and clarify the unique benefits of the proposed framework.

4. **Interpretation of experimental results**  
   In Figures 1a and 2a, the y-axis is labeled ¡°value.¡± Could the authors clarify what this metric represents? Specifically, is it the return obtained after training, and if so, does it correspond to the extrinsic reward or the transformed linear reward mentioned in line 5 of the ¡°DeepMind Control Suite¡± section? This clarification is essential for accurately interpreting the experimental outcomes.

5. **Definition of Set Improving Policies (SIP)**  
   Regarding Definition 2 of SIP and Equation 4, is there always a trivial set improving policy that simply selects the policy maximizing \( v^i_w \)? If so, how does the proposed approach differ from this trivial solution, and what additional guarantees or benefits does it provide?

Tosin Femi Olasemo, 37, of Cardiff, used a picture of a uniformed soldier as his profile photo on the dating site match.com.
He was jailed in 2015 for four-and-a-half years after admitting fraud.
A confiscation hearing at Cardiff Crown Court ruled he would serve a further two-and-a-half years if he did not pay.
Olasemo will be deported from the UK whenever he is released.
Following his conviction, a Proceeds of Crime Act investigation took place which revealed that Olasemo had links to Nigerian bank accounts containing more than ¡ê150,000.
He also had land purchased in Nigeria for about ¡ê47,000 and was found in possession of more than ¡ê1,100 when he was arrested.
During his sentencing in July 2015, the court heard he had tried to take more than ¡ê400,000 from lonely women using the alias Captain Morgan Travis, but banks stopped some payments going through.
He had told his victims he needed money to arrange leave from the army.
At the latest court hearing, he was ordered to repay just over ¡ê200,000 to his two victims, who live in Denmark.
He also has three months to arrange the sale of the land in Nigeria to repay the remaining money.
South Wales Police Det Insp Paul Giess, from the economic crime unit said: "This case has demonstrated the dangers of providing personal details and sending money to strangers online.
"Fraudsters use a variety of tactics to con their victims, such as pretending to be in need of urgent medical attention or having been discharged from the armed services into a life of poverty."

Posing as ¡°Captain Morgan Travis,¡± he attempted to steal over ¡ê400,000 by claiming he needed money for army leave, though banks blocked some transfers. He must sell the Nigerian land within three months to repay the balance and will be deported upon release. Police warned of the risks of sharing personal details or sending money to strangers online, noting fraudsters often feign emergencies or hardship.

It had been Amazing with a capital'A'. Robbie's parents gave him the keys to the beach house for the weekend, so he threw open the big glass doors, stuck fairy lights everywhere and invited everyone in the neighbourhood. The first thing I saw when I walked in the place was Robbie with his lips round the spout of a beer-bong, bubbling like a rabid manatee. I proceeded to make some pretty irresponsible decisions as regards my liquid intake. 
 
 So I've decided to call it a night, and now I'm dragging my liquor-heavy limbs home. The streetlights make everything too bright, and I squint my droopy eyelids as best as I can. Before I know it, there he is in all his humble grace, his rosy cheeks like pink downy pillows, his lips parted in a father's smile. The Buddha in his golden robes, bathed in warmth, makes himself known to me with a silent nod. I fall to my knees before him and kiss his feet, clean and clad with sandals. He laughs a loving laugh, and places a gentle hand on my shoulder. 
 
 `` Thank you, o happy one, for visiting me once again!'' I say as I supplicate, my arms around his knees. 
 
 `` Ian,'' he says, `` I've been driving round for forty minutes. You've got to stop doing this. We do n't deliver to walkers.'' 
 
 He reaches into his satchel, bursting with divine gifts, and hands me a gift only the laughing god can give. 
 
 `` That's $ 11.95. Next time, please specify an address.'' 
 
 I happily supply him with his requested tribute. Boarding his divine moped, he disappears into the night with a parting wave. I know he is always with me. I will see him again. 
 
 I am enveloped by the warmth of the nearest bush. I suckle each sweet pork-rib, covered so generously with the nectar of heaven. Tonight, I will sleep the sleep of the blessed.

human: Since 1991, laparoscopy-assisted Billroth I gastrectomy has been used for patients with early gastric cancer. The aim of this study was to clarify the outcome of 40 patients who underwent this operation and to examine the indications based on a retrospective histological study of 248 resected cases of early gastric cancer.Operating time, blood loss, length of skin incision, and postoperative hospital stay and complications were examined using the operation records and medical charts. The presence or absence of lymph node metastasis, tumour size, site, gross type, histological type, depth of invasion, presence or absence of ulceration, and status of lymph node metastasis were investigated in 248 early gastric cancers.The mean operating time was 3 h and 48 min and the mean length of skin incision was 5.8 cm. Although one patient who had suffered from chronic bronchitis developed pneumonia and wound dehiscence, no other patients had a postoperative complication. The mean hospital stay after operation was 16 days and all patients were alive without recurrence at a median follow-up of 21 months. The incidence of lymph node metastasis in early gastric cancer was 2 per cent (three of 130) in mucosal cancers and 14 per cent (17 of 118) in submucosal cancers. These lesions could have been completely resected by laparoscopy-assisted gastrectomy.
LLM_1: Since 1991, laparoscopy-assisted Billroth I gastrectomy has been applied in early gastric cancer. This study evaluated outcomes in 40 patients undergoing this procedure and examined indications via retrospective histological analysis of 248 resected early gastric cancer cases. Operative parameters and postoperative courses were assessed from surgical records and medical charts. Histopathological factors including tumor size, location, gross and histological type, depth of invasion, ulceration, and lymph node metastasis were analyzed. Mean operative time was 3 h 48 min, mean skin incision length 5.8 cm. One patient with chronic bronchitis developed pneumonia and wound dehiscence; no other complications occurred. Mean postoperative hospital stay was 16 days, with no recurrence at a median follow-up of 21 months. Lymph node metastasis incidence was 2% (3/130) in mucosal cancers and 14% (17/118) in submucosal cancers, all lesions being amenable to complete resection via laparoscopy-assisted gastrectomy.
LLM_2: Since its introduction in 1991, laparoscopy-assisted Billroth I gastrectomy has been utilized in the treatment of early gastric cancer. This study evaluated the outcomes of 40 patients who underwent this procedure and examined its indications through a retrospective histological analysis of 248 resected early gastric cancer cases. Operative parameters and postoperative courses were assessed based on surgical records and medical charts. Histopathological factors¡ªincluding tumor size, location, gross and histological type, depth of invasion, ulceration, and lymph node metastasis¡ªwere analyzed. The mean operative time was 3 hours and 48 minutes, and the mean skin incision length was 5.8 cm. One patient with chronic bronchitis developed pneumonia and wound dehiscence; no other complications were observed. The mean postoperative hospital stay was 16 days, with no recurrence reported at a median follow-up of 21 months. The incidence of lymph node metastasis was 2% (3/130) in mucosal cancers and 14% (17/118) in submucosal cancers. All lesions were amenable to complete resection via laparoscopy-assisted gastrectomy.

The Fusilier Museum in Bury, Greater Manchester, wants to show the medals in 2015 on the centenary of the landings.
It owns two and has been loaned three, but the remaining VC, won by a major from East Sussex, was last heard of at auction in the 1980s.
Col Brian Gorski said finding it would be the "last piece of the puzzle".
He added that the hope was to "re-unite" the VC, won by Maj Cuthbert Bromley, with the other five medals "so we can tell their story to this generation".
The major, who had been temporarily promoted from captain, received Britain's highest award for bravery along with Cpl John Grimshaw, Pte William Keneally, Sgt Alfred Richards, Sgt Frank Stubbs and Capt Richard Willis in recognition for their actions when the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers landed at Gallipoli in Turkey on the morning of 25 April 1915.
The battalion lost more than half of its men as they landed on W Beach, which was later renamed Lancashire Landing.
Sarah Stevenson, collections officer at the museum, said the major's family was from Seaford in East Sussex, where he has been honoured in the local church, St Leonard's, and had a road named after him.
She said there had been no trace of the medal since the late 1980s, but that "someone must still be in possession of the missing medal".
"Our mission is to find it so it can take its place alongside the other VCs in the exhibition."
Lord Ashcroft, who has loaned three VCs to the museum for the exhibition, said the "'Six before Breakfast' comprise one of the most celebrated batches of gallantry medals from any action of the entire Great War".
In total, 18 men from the Lancashire regiment were awarded the VC for their actions during World War One.

Col Brian Gorski called locating it the ¡°last piece of the puzzle,¡± hoping to reunite all six medals to share their story with a new generation. Maj Bromley was among six soldiers from the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers awarded the VC for bravery during the landing at W Beach¡ªlater renamed Lancashire Landing¡ªon 25 April 1915. The battalion suffered over 50% casualties that morning.

She believes someone still holds the missing medal and stated the museum¡¯s mission is to recover it for the exhibition.

Lord Ashcroft, who loaned three VCs for the display, described the group¡ªknown as the ¡°Six before Breakfast¡±¡ªas one of the most celebrated sets of gallantry medals from the Great War. Overall, 18 men from the Lancashire Fusiliers received the Victoria Cross during World War One.

Alexander Thomson, 33, from Clapham in south London, leaned forward and hit Tom Hulme, 23, after he threw the shoe.
Initially, he got out the car and appeared fine, but then he collapsed on the pavement. He died in hospital the next day from a brain haemorrhage.
The judge said the incident arose "out of trivial, friendly horseplay".
Mr Hulme's family said their lives had been "submerged in sadness and sorrow" since the tragic incident, which occurred in Farringdon Street, central London, during the last August bank holiday weekend.
Prosecutor Timothy Cray said Thomson, who has three previous convictions for alcohol-related violence, admitted drinking four pints at lunchtime on the day of the assault, before going back to work and later having up to five bottles of beer, four vodkas, three shots of Jagermeister and two small snorts of cocaine.
He met up with a friend who knew Mr Hulme and they were heading for a party in a taxi when the incident happened.
Mr Cray said the "unexpected blow" caused a sub-arachnoid haemorrhage, which is a type of stroke caused by bleeding on the surface of the brain.
Defending, Lisa Wilding QC said: "He is properly described as traumatised and tormented by the irreparable damage caused to Mr Hulme's family. None of that seeks to excuse his actions."
The Old Bailey heard Thomson admitted manslaughter at the first opportunity.
Judge Anthony Bate said: "A talented and intelligent young man had a promising life snatched away from him in early adulthood after you lashed out at him in a moment of drunken hot temper.
"You must live with that responsibility."
The victim, who was originally from Leeds, had worked as a recruitment consultant.

Thomson, who has three prior alcohol-related violence convictions, admitted drinking four pints at lunch, then later consuming more beer, vodka, Jagermeister, and cocaine before the incident. He pleaded guilty to manslaughter at the first opportunity.

Prosecutor Timothy Cray said the "unexpected blow" led to a fatal sub-arachnoid haemorrhage. Defence lawyer Lisa Wilding QC stated Thomson is "traumatised and tormented" by the damage to Hulme's family, though this does not excuse his actions.

Thomson, who has three previous convictions for alcohol-related violence, admitted to drinking four pints at lunch on the day of the incident, followed by further consumption of beer, vodka, Jagermeister, and cocaine.

Sentencing Thomson, Judge Anthony Bate remarked that a ¡°talented and intelligent young man¡± from Leeds, who worked as a recruitment consultant, had his promising life ¡°snatched away¡± in a moment of drunken temper.

¡°You must live with that responsibility,¡± the judge told Thomson.

In a statement, Hulme¡¯s family said their lives have been ¡°submerged in sadness and sorrow¡± since the tragedy.

The study by think-tank Demos says some pupils feel school is just preparing them for exam success.
It urges the government to help schools and colleges explore how self-belief, perseverance and resilience can be instilled in pupils.
The government said it had allocated funds to promote character education.
The Mind Over Matter report is based on interviews with experts, a survey of 1,000 teenagers and a round-up of previous academic research.
But its own survey suggests there is a steady decline in children's self-belief between 14 and 18.
Final-year students are half as likely to feel happy (33%) as 14-year-olds (60%), it says.
These 18-year-olds are also more likely to think there is too much focus on exams rather than preparing for life in general.
The report also finds gender discrepancies, with 39% of girls reporting feeling happy compared with 50% of boys.
It says there is an increasingly robust body of research detailing how "non-academic factors such as resilience, grit and empathy can have a profound impact on young people" and their ability to succeed.
It calls the adoption and practice of this approach "a growth mindset" and says the idea behind it is simple.
"If we believe our intelligence and abilities are not fixed at birth,  but can be developed through effort - if we have a 'growth mindset' - then we are more likely to look for challenges to see failures and setbacks as learning opportunities, and ultimately to achieve more personally and professionally," it says.
By contrast, those with "fixed mindsets" conclude they will never be able to achieve certain things when faced with setbacks.
The research argues that more needs to be done, inside and outside school, to give youngsters this more positive mindset and the self-belief they need to be successful, confident adults.
Report author Louis Reynolds said: "Mindsets matter - they can hold us back or propel us forward to achieve more. This insight needs to be applied more systematically in our education system.
"Teachers, policymakers and education experts increasingly agree that a young person's wellbeing, success in education and overall life outcomes are affected by much more than academic grades - including their character attributes, and their social and emotional skills."
A spokesman for the Department for Education said: "We want all young people to have the opportunity to develop a wider set of skills to help them succeed at school and contribute to society.
"All schools should create a happy and supportive environment helping children develop important life skills, such as resilience to support their academic attainment and give them the qualities that employers value.
"That's why we have invested ?¡ê5m to fund projects that will help young people to develop positive character traits, recognise excellent practice through the character awards and support research into what works best."

Only 33% of final-year students feel happy, compared to 60% of 14-year-olds. Older pupils are also more likely to think there is excessive focus on exams over life preparation.

Gender differences appear, with 39% of girls reporting happiness versus 50% of boys. Research increasingly shows non-academic factors like resilience and empathy profoundly impact young people¡¯s success. The report advocates a ¡°growth mindset¡±¡ªthe belief that abilities can be developed through effort¡ªwhich helps treat setbacks as learning opportunities. Those with ¡°fixed mindsets¡± tend to give up when facing difficulties.

Author Louis Reynolds said mindsets can hold young people back or propel them forward, and this insight should be applied more systematically in education. Wellbeing and life outcomes depend on more than grades, including character and social-emotional skills.

A Department for Education spokesman said all schools should create supportive environments to build resilience and life skills. The government has invested ¡ê5m in projects to develop positive character traits, recognise best practice and support related research.

In response, the government highlighted existing funding allocated to support character education in schools.

Titled *Mind Over Matter*, the report draws on expert interviews, a survey of 1,000 teenagers, and analysis of existing research. The research also reveals a gender gap in wellbeing: 50% of boys described themselves as happy, compared with 39% of girls. Action on Sugar analysed 131 hot drinks and found a third contained at least as much sugar as a can of Pepsi or Coca-Cola, which contains nine teaspoons.
The charity said in some of the worst cases the drinks contained 20 or more teaspoons of sugar.
Coffee shop chains Starbucks, Costa and Caffe Nero said they were committed to reducing sugar content in their drinks.
The drinks assessed included flavoured coffees such as mochas and lattes, hot fruit drinks and hot chocolates from coffee shops and fast food chains.
The charity found that 98% of the drinks tested would receive a red nutritional value label for high sugar content.
The recommended maximum intake of added sugar per day for those aged 11 and over is about 30g or seven teaspoons, the NHS says.
Starbucks' venti Grape with Chai, Orange and Cinnamon Hot Mulled Fruit was found to have the highest sugar content of the drinks tested, with 25 teaspoons of sugar per serving, the campaign group said.
Costa's massimo eat-in Chai Latte was found to contain 20 teaspoons of sugar and Starbucks' venti White Chocolate Mocha with Whipped Cream was found to have 18.
KFC's mocha and Starbucks' Signature Hot Chocolate both had 15 teaspoons of sugar per serving while Caffe Nero's drink-in Caramelatte had 13.
The group's researcher Kawther Hashem called on coffee shop chains to reduce the amount of sugar in their drinks, improve their labelling and scrap extra-large serving sizes.
"These hot flavoured drinks should be an occasional treat, not an everyday drink," she said.
"They are laden with an unbelievable amount of sugar and calories and are often accompanied by a high sugar and fat snack."
She told BBC Radio 4's Today programme she was "surprised" by the results, and said the campaign group had tested only the larger portion sizes on offer.
Case study: Mark Cresswell from London
"I used to drink a large white cafe mocha with caramel and vanilla syrup, cream on top, caramel and chocolate drizzle at Starbucks - approximately three times a day, seven days a week.
"I did this for about a year. At the time, I knew this drink had lots of sugar and fat, but I wasn't aware of just how much.
"At one point the assistant manager refused to serve me because they were concerned of the health impact. The rest of the staff continued to serve me.
"I drastically cut back on these sugary drinks after I was diagnosed with a very high cholesterol level and liver problems three years ago.
"I still have high cholesterol now and was recently diagnosed with a fatty liver - which means it is not working properly - not from alcohol but from sugar.
"While I believe we should all take responsibility for our health, I do feel that coffee shops which allow their customers to customise their drinks to extreme levels are not helping."
Professor Graham MacGregor, Action on Sugar chairman, said the group's report highlighted "yet again another example of scandalous amounts of sugar added to our food and drink".
"No wonder we have the highest rates of obesity in Europe," he said.
A Starbucks spokeswoman said the chain had "committed to reduce added sugar" by 25% by the end of 2020 in its "indulgent drinks".
"We also offer a wide variety of lighter options, sugar-free syrups and sugar-free natural sweetener and we display all nutritional information in-store and online," she said.
Kerry Parkin, Costa's head of communications, said the chain had already taken "significant steps" to reduce the sugar content of its drinks.
The company would be setting salt and sugar reduction targets for 2020, she said.
A Caffe Nero spokeswoman said: "We have already made changes to reduce the sugar content of some of our iced drinks for summer 2016 by over 10%.
"In addition, we offer sugar free syrups for many drinks, and all nutritional information is available on our website so that customers can make an informed choice. This will remain a focus as we look at the sugar content in all our drinks over the coming years."

Costa¡¯s massimo Chai Latte had 20 teaspoons, and Starbucks¡¯ venti White Chocolate Mocha with Whipped Cream had 18.

The Northern Education Trust took on "too many poorly performing schools" and had "unrealistic and unachievable" plans for improvement, Ofsted found.
The trust runs academies on Tyneside, Wearside, Teesside, Northumberland, Yorkshire and Greater Manchester.
The report does not reflect changes made since the inspections, it said.
In a statement the trust said it had "made significant new appointments, injected substantial resources and made major changes to our systems over the last six months".
Ofsted inspectors, who visited nine of the trust's schools in November and December, found standards "below average at every key stage".
Half had improved at their latest inspection but the others had either remained the same or declined, its report said.
Trustees and trust leaders had "an erroneous and over-optimistic view of the schools' performance", it added.
However, the trust had a "strong track record of good financial management" and relationships with academy leaders were "constructive and positive", inspectors found.
Inspectors also said trust leaders had been "honest in their evaluation of past performance and their shortcomings in moving too slowly".
"This has led to a planned restructure to ensure that the school improvement strategy is on a firmer footing for the future."
Trust chief executive Ian Kershaw said he was "disappointed, and a little shocked, by the delay" in the report's publication.
The trust had "put in place measures to address the issues and recommendations raised.... some time ago", he said.
The schools it had taken on had displayed "signs of endemic failure" and had "rarely succeeded for decades", he explained.
"Sustainable improvement can often take longer to achieve than government guidelines suggest, or we would all wish."

human: BACKGROUND.:Contact of blood with the surfaces of the cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) circuit has been implicated as a cause of the inflammatory response. We undertook a prospective randomized trial of 200 pediatric patients, all with a calculated total bypass flow of less than 2.3 L/min (< 0.96 L/m2/min).Patients were randomly assigned to 1 of 4 CPB groups: (1) Nonheparin-bonded circuit with no albumin preprime; (2) Nonheparin-bonded circuit with albumin preprime; (3) Heparin-bonded circuit with no albumin preprime; (4) Heparin-bonded circuit with albumin preprime. Measurements of cytokines, (interleukin [IL]-6, IL-8) and blood cell counts were made prebypass and 6 and 24 hours after institution of cardiopulmonary bypass.Analysis of variance showed no significant difference in any of the clinical or biochemical characteristics of the 4 groups. The interaction between heparin-bonded oxygenators and albumin preprime was not significant. No important differences in IL-6 or IL-8 concentrations were noted after CPB using either heparin or nonheparin-bonded oxygenators with albumin or albumin free preprime using two-way analysis of variance.
LLM_1: Blood contact with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) circuit surfaces may trigger inflammation. human:
What a terrible super-power. 
 I get smarter when I get angrier. The thinking power of a class 10 supercomputer - and it's all wasted on things I'm really, really angry about. 
 Have you ever got into a fight with your girlfriend? Ever since I got exposed to diluted gamma rays emanating from that meteor fragment I have not been able to sustain a relationship. Well, I have, but only until the first real fight. 
 I feel like the radiation has just improved one fatal trait of the human mind: The clarity of mind, where everything slows down and you have time to think about what happens next - except you are so angry that you ca n't stop yourself from doing the absolute worst to other people. 
 I found out about my new `` super'' -power the night after I got changed. My girlfriend at the time, Kelly, and me got into this super drawn-out fight. Normally, at the end of such a fight, you're just trapped in this super-elaborate maze of angry logic, where you go 
 `` waitasecond waitasecond NO I AM TALKING RIGHT NOW so what you're saying is that if you had any pets and you gave them to me while you go on vacation WITHOUT ME i would not feed them properly because i hate your mom?!?! how can you say that? and why are you on vacation without me? why do I have to watch your stupid imaginary pets while you go tramping about the globe and have all the fun? You're just so selfish!'' 
 or something in that vein. 
 I > destroyed < my girlfriend that night at arguing. I've never been good at it, so usually, what I do, is just quit the fight early on, be like `` whatever'', go my own way, and then later come back with presents. 
 That has worked pretty good for me so far. 
 But not this time. 
 With all the personal stuff you know about another person? All the stuff they told you in confidence? My rage directed that against her that night. 
 I told her she wanted to be unhappy and fight with her boyfriend that night because her father never loved her before he died in that car crash. 
 I told her he probably was drinking that night because she wanted to go to Europe after college and he had no way of getting her the money to do so because he was just a retail guy at age 50, while she was a selfish, greedy, heartless bitch of a daughter. 
 It got much worse after that. 
 My powers ebbed when she was crying so hard it shook her body, and she has not spoken to me since than. That was in 2008. Her entire family hates me now. Her mom told me that her daughter was changed by the event. 
 Her homely, chipper girl has turned into a heavy-smoking cynic. 
 That is the problem with this power: 
 You unleash hell on someone, but in the moment of their total destruction something inside of you recognises that you have gone too far, and you feel sorry, and the power leaves you, dumbfounded at what you have done. 
 Yeah. Literally dumbfounded. 
 I found myself feeling dumber after the IQ-high I just experienced. So dumb and dumbfounded, in fact, that I did n't know how to cope with the horrible thing I just did. So I hid in a bottle. 
 Until 2010, when Rachel became my sponsor at an AA meeting. 
 I had ruined countless lives in petty, alcohol-induced rages. It was the only time I felt alive. Or maybe smart and in control. Same thing. But Rachel calmed me down, and the good times came back. 
 It did n't last long. Our first fight was 4 months later, over some dumb thing like `` who ate the last yoghurt from the kitchen'' or something. I had held myself back so badly. But the power. The power wants out. 
 My brain has become addicted to the rise in IQ like a junkie jonesing for acid. The acid-hippy tells himself that he wants to broaden his mind to get closer to the universe. To find divine answers. 
 I just want to broaden it. I do n't care what I do. I do everything perfectly. 
 After the road-rage incident in 2012 I locked myself in my room and did n't go out for half a year. Of course, I've been drinking again. After Rachel overdosed on medication, 2 nights after our `` fight'' ( I tore her down to the foundations of her being ) she had been using again for 2 days straight, and her heart could n't take the increasing doses any more. 
 So, off the wagon I fell. And then in the wagon I got. And drove. 
 When some asshole in a gas-gusseling SUV cut me off I completely lost it. Screaming obscenities, I demolished this guy's car worse than anything you've seen in any Fast & the Furious movie. The trouble was, it could've been over quickly - only after the first time I rammed him he recovered and drove on. 
 Big mistake. 
 By that time, I had gotten smarter again. And I began to toy with the guy. I send him on the horror trip of his life - and by the end of it I knew where he lived ( driving patterns, I circled in on it at the 40 minutes mark ), that he was left-handed ( the way he shifts gears. total give-away. ) and that his wife and child were in the car with him the whole time ( mass distribution, tire behaviour, and also the high-pitched screaming were good indicators ). 
 Only, I did n't stop. 
 And I did n't get caught. 
 When I'm operating at quantum-levels of computing power I just never get arrested. It's impossible. Who is smart enough to catch the raging IQ-monster? 
 No-one. 
 Knowing this, I tried to quit. I tried quitting alcohol, I tried quitting relationships ( try that one some time: you try to quit, it starts an argument, then you fight, and before you know it I have another ex-girlfriend in the psych ward ). 
 I tried quitting life. 
 But that's the worst of it: When I'm drunk I'm angry. When I'm angry I'm smart. I ca n't hit rock bottom, because before the point where you realise that you are bottoming out, there is a brief moment where you go in denial. And, briefly, you get angry. This passes for normal people and they either dispair and quit or they kill themselves. Either way: They stop. 
 This is not the case with me. My powers make me think myself out of everything, and by the time I come to all my problems are solved. 
 I'm in a new city, I have a ton of cash, nice new car, new identity - the works. 
 Queue vicious cicle, rinse and repeat. 
 But not any more. I think my dumbfounded, alcohol-soaked, simple, stupid self has finaly thought of something. Something interesting. 
 I can not kill the IQ-monster. But maybe I can direct it. 
 I'm sitting here, in front of my computer, and for the first time in a long time I am angry again. 
 I quit the mood stabilisers ( maybe they will work THIS TIME around? ha, good one! ). 
 The pharmaceuticals went down the toilet and I down the stairs, to sit on my couch. 
 My laptop is, well, on my lap. On it, a website is open. It's Fox `` News''. 
 And I am very, very pissed off.

Bonar's inclusion at blindside flanker means Jemma Forsyth moves to number 8. The injured Jade Konkel drops out of the starting line-up.
With Bonar promoted from the bench, Rachael Cook is named among the replacements, as is Abi Evans.
Shade Munro's side beat Wales 15-14 last month.
The win was Scotland's first in the tournament since 2010.
England top the championship with three wins out of three so far and a superior points difference to Ireland.
"The win against Wales gave the squad a massive boost of confidence and was reward for all the hard work they've put in," said Munro.
"The players showed great character and composure to get the one-point win. While it was a solid performance in both defence and attack, there are still plenty of aspects we need to refine.
"We are under no illusion how difficult England are going to be given they are top of the table having won all their games in this year's championship, but I have every faith our players will rise to the challenge and remain focused on improving our performance."
Scotland: Chloe Rollie, Megan Gaffney, Lisa Thomson, Lisa Martin (capt), Rhona Lloyd, Helen Nelson, Sarah Law; Tracy Balmer, Lana Skeldon, Lindsey Smith, Emma Wassell, Deborah McCormack, Sarah Bonar, Louise McMillan, Jemma Forsyth.
Replacements: Lucy Park, Heather Lockhart, Katie Dougan, Rachael Cook, Lyndsay O'Donnell, Jenny Maxwell, Eilidh Sinclair, Abi Evans.

human: Ever have one of those days where you are just tired.   I went shopping today, grocery shopping, and beach shopping.   All 7 of us need beach clothes.  I lucked out and got my suit at Target uesterday, clearance rack, $7.  Whoohoo.  Tommy's was only $4.  Even better.  So today I had to search for the boys.  I went to Walmart.  I know some people hate wally world, but not me.   I love them.  Especially when I can get shirts for the boys at $2 a piece.  I actually bought myself two suits , Tommy hates the color of one (my favorite of course) and I hate the style  of the other one!  (to mamawish)   So which one to keep?   Then after shopping in Wally world for 2 hours, during peak school shopping season, I hit the grocery store wide open.   Went in for frozen pizza, came out with 2 buggy fulls of food.  I shop for a month at a time.  So it was monthly shopping time.  The only problem with that, is then you have to come home and put the food up.    Then you figure in the fact the water has been messed up for 2 days, finally got to shower at my parents house today.  Thankfully, I must say, the humidity and heat do not make a good mixture with no way to shower.  Especially with 4 boys who often forget to use deodorant.   We also made a trip to the dump today.  Not my favorite place to go.  80 degree heat and the county landfill, sheeeeewwwwww.  Casey must have wallowed in the trash, when he got in the truck, I had to make him strip down to his shorts.  TJ went the rest of the way home with his head hung out the window.  I didn't have that luxury.   I rode home with my shirt pulled over my nose.  Yes, it was that bad.   Now, Tommy is in bed, I am sitting here with my wild berry wine cooler, relaxing.  The boys are either playing the XBox, or doing something constructive, and leaving me alone.  Thank you God for small miracles.

I also grabbed two suits for myself, though Tommy hates the color of one (my favorite) and I dislike the style of the other¡ªso which to keep?

After two hours in crowded Walmart during peak back-to-school season, I tackled the grocery store. I went in for frozen pizza and left with two carts full¡ªI shop for the month, which means hauling everything home and putting it all away.

To top it off, our water¡¯s been out for two days. I finally showered at my parents¡¯ house today¡ªa relief in this heat and humidity, especially with four boys who often forget deodorant. We also made a trip to the dump in 80-degree heat. Casey must have wallowed in the trash; I made him strip to his shorts before getting in the truck. TJ rode with his head out the window, while I just pulled my shirt over my nose. Yes, it was that bad.

Now, Tommy¡¯s in bed, I¡¯m relaxing with a wild berry wine cooler, and the boys are either on the Xbox or doing something constructive¡ªand leaving me alone. Thank you, God, for small miracles.

I also picked up two suits for myself, though Tommy isn¡¯t a fan of the color on my favorite one, and I¡¯m not sold on the style of the other. Decisions, decisions!

After two hours navigating a packed Walmart during peak back-to-school season, I moved on to the grocery store. The disgust he felt told him he was in the right path. He was so sure that Laura should die digging into her vagina with a disassembled coat hanger. Even after his editor strongly advised him to scrap the scene, he did n't care if his audience might find this unrelatable. After mulling over a lightyear, he has always felt that this scene as plausible and necessary in setting the whole tone of the book. 
 
 `` Earth is not just a world where humans are farmed inside a woman's torso,'' he reasoned. `` People need to look beyond and see what it represents.'' 
 
 Against all odds, he self-published his book called Earth. And for sure, his popularity plummeted. People found the premise of humans not laying eggs into communal nests unrealistic. He was expecting this backlash, but he was disappointed that the audience were not able to understand that Laura needed to pursue her passion in the arts. She was already starving and will not endure to see the baby go through same fate. This was for her freedom, and also in a way, the baby's freedom.

His disgust confirmed he was on the right path. He was certain Laura should die, probing her vagina with a disassembled coat hanger. Even when his editor urged him to scrap the scene, he didn¡¯t care if readers found it unrelatable. After long reflection, he still saw it as plausible and necessary¡ªit set the whole tone of the book.

¡°Earth isn¡¯t just a world where humans are farmed inside a woman¡¯s torso,¡± he reasoned. ¡°People must look beyond and see what it represents.¡±

Against all odds, he self-published *Earth*. His popularity plummeted. Readers found the premise¡ªthat humans don¡¯t lay eggs in communal nests¡ªunrealistic. He¡¯d expected backlash, but was disappointed they missed how Laura needed to pursue her passion for art. Already starving, she couldn¡¯t bear to see the baby suffer the same fate. LLM_2:
His revulsion was a compass needle, trembling toward true north. He knew, with a bone-deep certainty, that Laura had to die, that the scene¡ªthe cold, deliberate probe of a straightened coat hanger¡ªwas non-negotiable. Even when his editor pleaded with him to cut it, warning that readers would recoil, he held firm. Let them find it alien. After nights staring at the ceiling, tracing the contours of the story in the dark, he still believed it was not only plausible, but essential. It was the keystone; without it, the entire arch of the narrative would collapse.

¡°Earth is not merely a world where humans are cultivated within a womb,¡± he would explain, voice low and intent. ¡°It is a mirror. We must be willing to see what it reflects.¡±

Defying every piece of conventional wisdom, he released *Earth* himself. The silence that followed was deafening, then it broke into a wave of cold dismissal. His readership evaporated. Critics and readers alike fixated on the premise¡ªthe idea that humans do not lay their eggs in some shared, sacred nest¡ªand declared it absurd. He had braced for outrage, but this¡­ this was a quieter, more profound disappointment. They had missed the point entirely. They did not see Laura, starving not just for food but for a life she could taste, choosing her canvas over a cradle. They did not see that in her desperate, brutal act, she was clawing at a kind of freedom¡ªfor herself, and in a terrible, twisted way, for the child who would never know the gnawing hunger of an unlived life.

==========================================
Summary
==========================================
 
The paper proposes a new metric to measure the discriminative properties of a classification model beyond its top-k accuracy.
This metric is obtained by grouping annotated classes by different criteria, e.g. "pretending", "prepositions, "final state", etc., and reporting the mean score over groups.

In addition, an new version of the Something-Something dataset (Goyal et al,ICCV'17) is released including the group-level annotations.


----------------
Novelty
----------------

This paper proposes a new metric and a Something-Something dataset (Goyal et al,ICCV'17)

----------------
Clarity
----------------

The paper is clear and its content is easy to follow.

----------------
Significance
----------------

Beyond the proposed metric, the additionl group-related labels could be useful in other work that explores the internal properties of trained models or towards model interpretation.

----------------
Quality
----------------

Observations made through the presentated experiments are barely discussed which hinders the significance of the work. Beyond some presented results, it is hard to asses why the proposed metric indeed encondes discriminative properties of the model.

In addition, is not clear to me the purpose of the captioning problem mentioned in the paper since there is no experiment or result reported related to that problem.

==========================================
PROs:
- Clear and easy to follow.
- Potential to foster model interpretation research.


CONS:
- Findings/observations made through are barely discussed.
- No provided evidence that the proposed metric achieves its goal of measuring discriminative properties of a model
==========================================

Additionally, a new version of the Something?Something dataset (Goyal et al., ICCV¡¯17) is released with group?level annotations.

**Novelty**  
The work proposes a novel metric and an extended Something?Something dataset.

**Clarity**  
The paper is clearly written and easy to follow.

**Significance**  
Beyond the metric itself, the added group?related labels could support research on model internals and interpretation.

**Quality**  
The experimental observations are insufficiently discussed, limiting the work¡¯s impact. It remains unclear why the proposed metric effectively captures discriminative properties. The mention of a captioning problem is also unexplained, as no related experiments or results are provided.

**PROs**  
- Clear and accessible.  
- Could advance model interpretation research.

**CONs**  
- Inadequate discussion of findings.  
- Lacks evidence that the metric achieves its intended goal.

Beyond the metric itself, the inclusion of group?related annotations in the dataset could facilitate further research into model interpretability and internal representations.

**Quality**  
While the paper presents a promising direction, the experimental observations are not sufficiently discussed, which limits the overall impact of the work. It remains unclear why the proposed metric effectively captures discriminative properties, and the mention of a captioning problem is not substantiated with related experiments or results.

**Strengths**

- The extended dataset has the potential to advance research in model interpretation.

**Weaknesses**  
- Inadequate discussion of experimental findings.

human: The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship the expression of cytokeratins (CK10 and CK13) and the cell proliferation index determined by Ki-67 of lip squamous cell carcinoma and actinic cheilitis with different degrees of dysplasia.Forty-five paraffin-embedded actinic cheilitis with and without dysplasia and 20 lip squamous cell carcinoma were analyzed by immunohistochemistry using anti-human anti-CK10, anti-CK13, and anti-Ki-67 antibodies.The majority of actinic cheilitis showed immunopositivity for CK10 and CK13 with decrease or loss of expression in dysplastic areas. In lip squamous cell carcinoma of the lip, heterogeneous expression of CK13 and immunonegativity for CK10 were observed. There was a statistically significant difference between CK10 expression in lip squamous cell carcinoma and in actinic cheilitis with or without dysplasia (p?<?0.001). The cell proliferation index was higher in actinic cheilitis with dysplasia and lip squamous cell carcinoma than in actinic cheilitis without epithelial dysplasia. A significant correlation was found between the intensity of the epithelial dysplasia and the cell proliferation index (p?<?0.001).
LLM_1: This study examined cytokeratin (CK10 and CK13) expression and Ki-67 proliferation index in lip squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and actinic cheilitis with varying dysplasia. Immunohistochemical analysis of 45 actinic cheilitis specimens (with and without dysplasia) and 20 lip SCCs revealed that most actinic cheilitis cases expressed CK10 and CK13, with reduced or absent expression in dysplastic regions. Lip SCC showed heterogeneous CK13 expression and was CK10-negative. CK10 expression differed significantly between lip SCC and actinic cheilitis, regardless of dysplasia (p?<?0.001). Proliferation index was higher in dysplastic actinic cheilitis and lip SCC than in non-dysplastic actinic cheilitis, with a significant correlation between dysplasia severity and proliferation index (p?<?0.001).
LLM_2: This study investigated the expression of cytokeratins (CK10 and CK13) and the Ki?67 proliferation index in lip squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and actinic cheilitis with varying degrees of dysplasia. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed on 45 actinic cheilitis specimens (with and without dysplasia) and 20 lip SCCs. Results indicated that most actinic cheilitis cases expressed both CK10 and CK13, with reduced or absent expression observed in dysplastic areas. In contrast, lip SCC exhibited heterogeneous CK13 expression and was consistently CK10?negative. CK10 expression differed significantly between lip SCC and actinic cheilitis, irrespective of dysplasia status (p?<?0.001). The proliferation index was elevated in dysplastic actinic cheilitis and lip SCC compared to non?dysplastic actinic cheilitis, and a significant correlation was found between the severity of dysplasia and the proliferation index (p?<?0.001).

human: Beyond the well-defined role of the Eph (erythropoietin-producing hepatocellular) receptor tyrosine kinases in developmental processes, cell motility, cell trafficking/adhesion, and cancer, nothing is known about their involvement in liver pathologies. During blood-stage rodent malaria infection we have found that EphB2 transcripts and proteins were up-regulated in the liver, a result likely driven by elevated surface expression on immune cells including macrophages. This was significant for malaria pathogenesis because EphB2(-/-) mice were protected from malaria-induced liver fibrosis despite having a similar liver parasite burden compared with littermate control mice. This protection was correlated with a defect in the inflammatory potential of hepatocytes from EphB2(-/-) mice resulting in a reduction in adhesion molecules, chemokine/chemokine receptor RNA levels, and infiltration of leukocytes including macrophages/Kupffer cells, which mediate liver fibrosis during rodent malaria infections. These observations are recapitulated in the well-established carbon tetrachloride model of liver fibrosis in which EphB2(-/-) carbon tetrachloride-treated mice showed a significant reduction of liver fibrosis compared to carbon tetrachloride-treated littermate mice. Depletion of macrophages by clodronate-liposomes abrogates liver EphB2 messenger RNA and protein up-regulation and fibrosis in malaria-infected mice.
LLM_1: While Eph receptor tyrosine kinases are known to regulate development, motility, adhesion, and cancer, their role in liver disease remains unexplored. In rodent malaria, liver EphB2 expression increases, likely due to elevated surface expression on immune cells such as macrophages. EphB2(-/-) mice are protected from malaria-induced liver fibrosis despite comparable parasite loads, linked to reduced hepatocyte inflammatory potential, lower adhesion molecule and chemokine receptor expression, and decreased leukocyte infiltration. Similar protection occurs in the carbon tetrachloride liver fibrosis model. Macrophage depletion abolishes both EphB2 upregulation and fibrosis in malaria-infected mice.
LLM_2: While Eph receptor tyrosine kinases are well-established regulators of development, cell motility, adhesion, and cancer progression, their function in liver pathology remains largely uncharacterized. In rodent models of malaria, hepatic EphB2 expression is significantly upregulated, an effect attributed primarily to increased surface expression on immune cells, particularly macrophages. EphB2-deficient (EphB2?/?) mice exhibit protection from malaria-induced liver fibrosis, despite sustaining parasite burdens comparable to wild-type controls. This protective phenotype is associated with diminished inflammatory potential in hepatocytes, reduced expression of adhesion molecules and chemokine receptors, and attenuated leukocyte infiltration into the liver. A similar antifibrotic effect is observed in EphB2?/? mice subjected to carbon tetrachloride-induced liver fibrosis. Notably, macrophage depletion in malaria-infected mice abrogates both EphB2 upregulation and the development of fibrosis. These findings identify EphB2 as a critical mediator of liver fibrosis in response to inflammatory injury and highlight its potential as a therapeutic target in fibrotic liver diseases.
