He stated that his resignation was intended to ¡°limit and help repair¡± damage to the institution¡¯s reputation.

**Police Investigation Underway**

The Metropolitan Police confirmed it is investigating ¡°allegations of drug-related offences involving a member of the House of Lords¡± following a search of a property in central London. Authorities have not named the individual under investigation.

**Political Reactions and Calls for Reform**

Prime Minister David Cameron, speaking during an official visit to Singapore, said he welcomed Lord Sewel¡¯s decision to ¡°absent himself¡± from the Lords. However, he resisted broader calls for reform of the unelected chamber, citing past unsuccessful attempts at overhaul.

Baroness Stowell, the Conservative leader of the Lords, expressed disappointment that Lord Sewel had not stepped down sooner. She emphasized that all members must uphold high standards to maintain public trust and noted the chamber now has ¡°powerful sanctions,¡± including expulsion, for misconduct.

**Debate Over Size and Function of the Lords**

The controversy has reignited debate over the size and role of the House of Lords, which has 783 members. Critics argue it is too large, with many peers rarely participating in proceedings. Former Lords leader Lord Hill acknowledged that some members had ¡°tarred its reputation,¡± but defended the chamber as effective in revising legislation and holding the government to account.

Opposition parties have called for cross-party talks on reform, with the Scottish National Party advocating for the Lords to be abolished and replaced with an elected chamber.

**Status and Financial Arrangements**

Lord Sewel, who was appointed to the peerage by former Prime Minister Tony Blair in 1996, retains his title despite resigning from his ¡ê84,500-a-year role as deputy speaker and chairman of the conduct committee. As one of the few salaried peers, he remains eligible for a parliamentary pension, though it is unclear whether he will claim it.

*This report has been updated to include the latest statements from involved parties and authorities.*

¡° I ¡¯ m sure we ¡¯ ll see each other again soon ¡± she says. 
 
 Jocelyn ¡¯ s fingers absently caress the microfiber of the couch, her eyes flitting around the room ¨C tasteful art, bamboo plants with lazy leaves thirsting for a bit more water, the worn green carpet that somehow conveys *community counseling center* more easily than the bold, serif signage hanging from the front eave. 
 
 ¡° How do you mean? ¡± Marq sits slightly askew in his low, wide chair. His short, plump legs are crossed in spite of the limitations of his build. His eyes ¨C grey, probing, gentle ¨C suspended under the prominent folds of his lids and jutting brow, rest on Jocelyn. His attention unconsciously attunes to the sporadic movement of her gaze, the aimless wandering of her hands. Her hair, an unkempt tangle of greying curls, falls in greasy columns to her shoulders. Her clothes are garish, an unholy smattering of colors and patterns, the repulsion they invoke outweighed only by their endearment. 
 
 ¡° What do you mean ¡® how do you mean? ¡¯ ¡± Jocelyn exhales lazily, a smile touching the corners of her eyes. ¡° It ¡¯ s not exactly complex, is it? I ¡¯ m sure we ¡¯ ll see each other again soon, because she said we would. She wouldn ¡¯ t lie to me. ¡± 
 
 Marq has been meeting with Jocelyn for over seven months now. She has a great capacity for spontaneity and joy, frequently injecting the energy of their conversations with a color that rivals the effervescence of her wardrobe. She is also deeply sad, sometimes drowning in the swirling tide of her grief. 
 
 Her mother died when Jocelyn was a younger woman, in her mid-twenties. As she reports it, her mom ¨C a lifelong government functionary ¨C departed for a routine trip to Prague. Two weeks later Jocelyn received word from an unknown State Department employee informing her of her mother ¡¯ s ¡° untimely passing ¡±. The exact nature of her death was never made clear to Jocelyn, under the premise of National Security. ¡° I ¡¯ m sure she ¡¯ s in a better place ¡±, she was told. 
 
 Marq uncrosses his legs, shifts his weight, scooting his right ankle under his ample posterior. He laces his fingers and slides his hands over the dome of his left knee. The gentle thocking of raindrops assaults the skylight of his small office. 
 
 Clinically speaking, Jocelyn is diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder; she presents with psychotic features ¨C hallucinations and delusions ¨C in addition to the presence of a persistent mood disorder, major depression. For months Jocelyn and Marq have explored her experiences: the voices she hears; the dark, smoky, translucent figures that visit her when she is alone, relentlessly attacking her sense of wellbeing and safety; her ¡° prophetic ¡± dreams; the belief that her mother is alive and that ¡° we ¡¯ ll see each other again soon ¡±. 
 
 ¡° When did she tell you this? ¡± Marq asks. ¡° Can you recall the feelings, the emotions that you felt at the time? ¡± 
 
 ¡° Always so serious, so skeptical, ¡± Jocelyn ¡¯ s laugh is a spark, a burst of light momentarily disturbing the stillness that pools so easily during a therapy session. ¡° Probing so deep, ¡± she says indifferently. Her head bobs and sways slightly, her eyes affixed to Marq ¨C a bohemian owl trying to take his measure. 
 
 ¡° I saw her in my dreams again last night. She was happy this time, more herself, ¡± a full smile comes crashing through the previously stolid features of Jocelyn ¡¯ s lined face. Her already wide and bulbous nose broadens, dough being gently stretched. ¡° She told me, exactly: ¡® We ¡¯ ll see each other again. Soon. ¡¯ See if we don ¡¯ t. ¡± She has the air of sibling keeping a great secret, a grand present spied in Mom and Dad ¡¯ s closet ¨C *it ¡¯ s better than you ¡¯ ll ever guess*. 
 
 Marq breathes calmly through his nose, sending a faint whistle through the space between them. There is an opening here, he can feel it ¨C some opportunity to move more deeply with Jocelyn, shine a light in a dark and long-forgotten corner of her narrative. Thoughts careen through his mind, groping ¨C *the art of asking a question*. 
 
 A creak reverberates from just outside the door, tearing Marq from his search. Support staff? Sessions are rarely disrupted, only in the case of emergencies, really. And they usually use the intercom to call in and request a moment to speak. A subtle wrap sounds through the door, its ill-fit causing it to shake gently in the frame. *What the fuck*, Marq thinks. 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ m sorry, room ¡¯ s occupied, ¡± he says. Maybe it ¡¯ s a new intern who isn ¡¯ t quite familiar with the agency procedures. 
 
 ¡° Jocelyn? ¡± The voice is a woman ¡¯ s: the embodiment of fine paper ¨C a beguiling blend of creaminess and subtle grit. 
 
 Marq feels a rope of tension reveal itself under his left trap, its coursing up the back of his neck and lodging itself somewhere behind his forehead. He looks at Jocelyn as if seeing her for the first time. Her smile reveals itself once more, shifting the planes of her face. Her eyes shine brightly in her deep-set sockets, sunstones glimmering in the dimly lit room. 
 
 ¡° You ¡¯ re going to love her, I ¡¯ m sure of it ¡± she says.

human: Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) is a tissue-sparing technique for the removal of cutaneous malignancies. There is no standardized procedure for determining tumor extent before taking the initial margins during the first stage of Mohs.To compare visual inspection, curettage, and dermoscopy in determining tumor extent before initial margins are taken for MMS.Fifty-four patients were randomized into three groups (visual inspection, curettage, or dermoscopy) before MMS for basal cell carcinomas on the nose. One of these three methods was used to delineate the biopsy site or residual tumor. The final number of stages and postoperative defect sizes were recorded.There was no statistically significant differences for the final number of stages (p=.20) or the final defect sizes (p=.47) between the three arms.
LLM_1: Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) is a tissue-sparing technique for cutaneous malignancy removal. No standardized procedure exists for determining tumor extent before initial MMS margins. This study compared visual inspection, curettage, and dermoscopy in delineating tumor extent prior to initial MMS margins. Fifty-four patients with nasal basal cell carcinomas were randomized into three groups (visual inspection, curettage, or dermoscopy) to mark the biopsy site or residual tumor before MMS. Final stages and postoperative defect sizes were recorded. No statistically significant differences were found in final stages (p=.20) or defect sizes (p=.47) among the three methods.
LLM_2: Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) represents a tissue-conserving surgical approach for the excision of cutaneous malignancies. Currently, no standardized preoperative method exists for delineating tumor boundaries prior to the initial stage of MMS. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of three preoperative assessment techniques¡ªvisual inspection, curettage, and dermoscopy¡ªin outlining tumor extent before the first surgical margin. A cohort of 54 patients with nasal basal cell carcinomas was prospectively randomized into three groups, each assigned one of the three assessment methods to demarcate either the biopsy site or residual tumor preoperatively. Outcomes measured included the final number of MMS stages required and postoperative surgical defect dimensions. Statistical analysis revealed no significant differences among the three techniques in terms of final stages (p = 0.20) or defect sizes (p = 0.47). These findings suggest that visual inspection, curettage, and dermoscopy yield comparable results in preoperative tumor mapping for MMS in this clinical context.

human: We have reported previously that the sympathetic nervous system is activated in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), and that this is only partly explained by a decrease in arterial oxygenation. Possible causes for increased muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) in patients with PAH include right atrial distension and decreased cardiac output. Both may be improved by atrial septostomy, but this intervention also further decreases arterial oxygenation. In the present study, we wanted to investigate the effect of atrial septostomy on MSNA in patients with PAH.We recorded BP, heart rate (HR), arterial O2 saturation (SaO2), and MSNA before and after atrial septostomy in PAH patients (mean [+/- SE] age, 48 +/- 5 years) and in closely matched control subjects. Measurements were also performed after septostomy, while SaO2 was brought to the preprocedure level by supplemental O2 therapy.Compared to the control subjects (n = 10), the PAH patients (n = 11) had a lower mean BP (75 +/- 2 vs 96 +/- 3 mm Hg, respectively; p < 0.001), lower mean SaO2 (92 +/- 1% vs 97 +/- 0%, respectively; p < 0.001), increased mean HR (84 +/- 4 vs 68 +/- 3 beats/min; p < 0.01), and markedly increased mean MSNA (76 +/- 5 vs 29 +/- 2 bursts per minute; p < 0.001). Atrial septostomy decreased mean SaO2 (to 85 +/- 2%; p < 0.001) and mean MSNA (to 69 +/- 4 bursts per minute; p < 0.01), but did not affect HR or BP. Therapy with supplemental O2 did not affect MSNA, BP, or HR. The decrease in MSNA was correlated to the decrease in right atrial pressure (r = 0.62; p < 0.05).
LLM_1: Atrial septostomy may ameliorate these factors but further lowers oxygenation. This study assessed the effect of atrial septostomy on muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) in PAH patients. We measured blood pressure, heart rate, arterial oxygen saturation (SaO?), and MSNA before and after septostomy in PAH patients and matched controls, and repeated measurements after restoring SaO? to pre-procedure levels with supplemental oxygen. Compared to controls, PAH patients had lower blood pressure and SaO?, higher heart rate, and markedly elevated MSNA. Septostomy reduced SaO? and MSNA but did not alter heart rate or blood pressure. Supplemental oxygen did not affect MSNA, blood pressure, or heart rate. The reduction in MSNA correlated with decreased right atrial pressure.
LLM_2: Atrial septostomy, while potentially mitigating certain pathophysiological factors in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), concurrently reduces systemic oxygenation. This investigation evaluated the impact of atrial septostomy on muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) in patients with PAH. Hemodynamic and neural parameters¡ªincluding blood pressure, heart rate, arterial oxygen saturation (SaO?), and MSNA¡ªwere assessed in PAH patients and matched controls before and after septostomy. Measurements were repeated following restoration of SaO? to baseline levels via supplemental oxygen. Relative to controls, PAH patients exhibited reduced blood pressure and SaO?, elevated heart rate, and significantly increased MSNA. Septostomy lowered both SaO? and MSNA, without affecting heart rate or blood pressure. Administration of supplemental oxygen did not alter MSNA, blood pressure, or heart rate. The observed decrease in MSNA was correlated with a reduction in right atrial pressure.

human:
The notion that breaking the data processing inequality is a useful property is odd. If the measure doesn't conform to the DPI then that means it's approximation to the mutual information becomes increasingly poor. The fact that neural networks have layers of features which progressively improve prediction performance is an issue with the large space the initial data ends up in, and the fact that the mutual information requires exponential quantities of compute and data to estimate high dimensional informations. The neural net isn't finding a more informative representation, it's finding one with a more easily understood manifold. I agree that the sliced projection is also likely to force things to have more understandable manifolds, and that this might be a desirable quality, but it's not because it doesn't obey the DPI. The information isn't created by computation, it's made more accesible (or inaccessible) by computation.

I don't think that pairwise independence is sufficient for property 5 in Proposition 1 to hold. Pairwise independence doesn't preclude larger interactions between sets of variables, only that each pair has no measurable interaction. As with the regular mutual information, the presence of additional variables can cause previously independent variables to become dependent (e.g.  spouse nodes in a Bayesian Network become dependent when conditioning on the shared child node). Presumably it requires mutual independence?

In section 3.1 the SMI estimator is claimed to be free from the curse of dimensionality. The error bound for it given in corollary 2 has a constant term which depends on the dimensions of both of the inputs and is unspecified.  This would seem to reintroduce the curse of dimensionality into the estimation.

In section 3.2 the term linear seems overloaded. I think it's used to mean the features are linear projections, but the interaction between the two projections could be non-linear and it might be useful to clarify this point.

Also in section 3.2, the variable Z appears in line 218, but has not previously been defined. I would assume it means X_1 as it's the partition of X into X_2 (i.e. Y) and some other variable, but this should be made clear. The text just before proposition 4 states that the most informative feature in X is X_1, even though Y is a copy of X_2 and so X_2 is maximally informative about Y.

Update:

Thanks for the response. I think that the clarifications around the DPI are necessary so as not to confuse the reader, and the responses to the reviews wrt the curse of dimensionality also are necessary updates, but overall I think this paper is a useful contribution.
LLM_1:
The idea that violating the data processing inequality (DPI) is beneficial is unusual. If a measure fails to satisfy DPI, its approximation to mutual information deteriorates. The improvement in prediction performance across neural network layers stems from the high-dimensional space of initial data and the exponential computational and data requirements for estimating mutual information in such settings¡ªnot from discovering a more informative representation, but from finding one with a more interpretable manifold. While sliced projections may also promote interpretable manifolds, this is not due to DPI non-compliance. Information is not generated by computation; it is rendered more or less accessible.

Regarding Proposition 1, pairwise independence may not suffice for property 5, as it does not rule out higher-order interactions among variables. Additional variables can induce dependencies, similar to mutual information (e.g., spouse nodes in a Bayesian network becoming dependent when conditioning on a child). Mutual independence is likely required.

In Section 3.1, the claim that the SMI estimator avoids the curse of dimensionality is questionable. Corollary 2¡¯s error bound includes an unspecified constant depending on input dimensions, which could reintroduce dimensionality challenges.

In Section 3.2, the term ¡°linear¡± is ambiguous¡ªit seems to refer to linear feature projections, but interactions between them could be nonlinear, warranting clarification. Additionally, variable Z (line 218) is undefined; it presumably denotes X?, but this should be stated explicitly. The text before Proposition 4 notes that X? is the most informative feature about Y, even though Y is a copy of X?, making X? maximally informative.

The authors should clarify the DPI discussion to avoid reader confusion and address the dimensionality concerns raised in reviews. Overall, the paper remains a valuable contribution.
LLM_2:
***

**Overall Assessment:** The paper presents a valuable contribution. However, several key arguments require clarification and strengthening to ensure conceptual rigor and avoid potential misinterpretation by readers.

**Major Comments:**

1.  **On the Framing of Data Processing Inequality (DPI):** The central premise that violating DPI can be beneficial is unconventional and risks misleading readers. A more precise framing is that apparent "violations" in practical settings often stem from estimation challenges, not fundamental informational gains. Specifically:
    *   When an estimator fails to satisfy DPI, it typically indicates a deterioration in its approximation quality for mutual information, not the discovery of a more informative representation.
    *   The observed improvement in prediction performance across neural network layers is more parsimoniously explained by the high-dimensional nature of the data and the exponential cost of accurate mutual information estimation in such spaces. The network may be finding representations with more *interpretable* or *usable* manifolds, not generating new information. Computation renders existing information more or less accessible; it does not create it.
    *   While techniques like sliced projections may also promote interpretable manifolds, this should not be conflated with or attributed to DPI non-compliance. This distinction is crucial and should be clarified to prevent confusion.

2.  **On Proposition 1 (Independence):** The reliance on **pairwise independence** for Property 5 appears insufficient. Pairwise independence does not preclude higher-order interactions among variables, where introducing additional variables can create complex dependencies (analogous to explaining away in Bayesian networks, where parent nodes become dependent when conditioned on a child). To robustly satisfy the intended property, **mutual (joint) independence** is likely required.

3.  **On Section 3.1 ¨C Curse of Dimensionality:** The claim that the proposed Sliced Mutual Information (SMI) estimator "avoids the curse of dimensionality" is overstated and requires qualification. While the slicing operation reduces the dimension of the estimation problem, Corollary 2's error bound includes an unspecified constant \(C\) that is dependent on the input dimensions \(d_x\) and \(d_y\). This dependence could implicitly reintroduce dimensionality challenges, and the text should acknowledge this nuance.

**Minor Comments / Requests for Clarification:**

*   **Section 3.2, "Linear" Features:** The term "linear" is ambiguous in this context. It appears to refer to *linear feature projections*, but the interactions or relationships *between* these projected features could be nonlinear. Please clarify the intended meaning.
*   **Undefined Variable (Line 218):** The variable \(Z\) is used but not defined. From context, it seems to denote \(X_1\), but this should be stated explicitly for clarity.
*   **Proposition 4 Context:** In the text preceding Proposition 4, it is noted that \(X_1\) is the most informative feature about \(Y\). However, given that \(Y\) is defined as a copy of \(X_2\), it follows logically that \(X_2\) itself is maximally informative about \(Y\). This point could be made more directly to avoid a moment of confusion for the reader.

**Summary:** The manuscript is promising. Addressing the points above¡ªparticularly the clarification around DPI and the independence/dimensionality assumptions¡ªwill significantly strengthen its theoretical foundation and presentation.

**Buddhist Path Described as Interwoven "Mandala" of Eight Factors, Not Linear Steps**

The Buddhist path to enlightenment is often envisioned not as a step-by-step ladder, but as an integrated, living system¡ªa perspective recently articulated by the respected monk Ajahn Sucitto. He describes the Noble Eightfold Path as a kind of ¡°mandala of interconnected factors,¡± where each element supports and balances the others.

Rather than progressing through sequential stages, practitioners develop these eight dimensions simultaneously. They encompass mental, verbal, and physical aspects of conduct, together forming what Sucitto calls ¡°a complete way of living.¡± This holistic approach emphasizes how right view, intention, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration interact dynamically, shaping a person¡¯s ethical and spiritual development in unison.

human: Intestinal barrier failure during acute pancreatitis (AP) is associated with translocation of luminal bacteria, resulting in infectious complications. We examined the effects of multispecies probiotics on the intestinal barrier impairment in a murine model of AP.Mice were injected with cerulein to induce AP and were sacrificed 11 (early AP) or 72 hours (late AP) after start of induction. AP and associated systemic effects were confirmed by histology of pancreas and lung. Animals received daily probiotics starting 2 days prior to AP induction (pretreatment) or at the moment of AP induction (treatment). Mucosal barrier function of the distal ileum was assessed in Ussing chambers by measurement of the epithelial electrical resistance and the permeability to Na-fluorescein.Histological analysis revealed pancreatic injury in both phases of AP, and lung damage in the early phase. Epithelial resistance of the ileum was reduced and permeability increased in both phases of AP, indicating impairment of the intestinal barrier. Pretreatment had no effect on resistance or permeability in the early phase of AP. In the late phase of AP, pretreatment but not treatment abolished the AP induced resistance decrease and permeability increase. Administration of probiotics as such (ie, without induction of AP) had no effect on intestinal barrier function.

Pancreatic and lung histology confirmed AP and systemic effects. Probiotics were administered daily, starting either 2 days before AP induction (pretreatment) or at induction (treatment). Ileal mucosal barrier function was assessed in Ussing chambers via epithelial electrical resistance and Na-fluorescein permeability. Histology showed pancreatic injury in both AP phases and lung damage in early AP. Ileal epithelial resistance decreased and permeability increased in both phases, indicating barrier impairment. Pretreatment did not affect resistance or permeability in early AP. In late AP, pretreatment¡ªbut not treatment¡ªprevented the AP-induced resistance decrease and permeability increase. Probiotics alone, without AP induction, had no effect on barrier function.

Probiotics were administered daily, beginning either two days prior to AP induction (pretreatment) or at the time of induction (treatment). Intestinal barrier integrity was evaluated in ileal mucosa using Ussing chamber measurements of transepithelial electrical resistance and Na-fluorescein permeability. Results demonstrated reduced epithelial resistance and increased permeability in both early and late AP, indicating significant barrier disruption. Pretreatment with probiotics did not mitigate barrier dysfunction in early AP. However, in late AP, pretreatment¡ªbut not treatment initiated at induction¡ªprevented the AP-induced decline in epithelial resistance and rise in permeability. Probiotic administration in the absence of AP induction had no observable effect on baseline barrier function. These findings suggest that prophylactic probiotic intervention may preserve intestinal barrier integrity in the later phases of acute pancreatitis.

human: Since 1958 many, but not all studies have demonstrated that paternal age is a risk factor for schizophrenia. There may be many different explanations for differences between studies, including study design, sample size, collection criteria, heterogeneity and the confounding effects of environmental factors that can for example perturb epigenetic programming and lead to an increase in disease risk. The small number of children in Western families makes risk comparisons between siblings born at different paternal ages difficult. In contrast, more Eastern families have children both at early and later periods of life. In the present study, a cross-sectional population study in an Iranian population was performed to compare frequency of schizophrenia in younger offspring (that is, older paternal age) versus older offspring.A total of 220 patients with the diagnosis of schizophrenia (cases) from both psychiatric hospitals and private clinics and 220 individuals from other hospital wards (controls), matched for sex and age were recruited for this study. Patients with neurological problem, substance abuse, mental retardation and mood disorder were excluded from both groups.Birth rank comparisons revealed that 35% vs 24% of the cases vs the controls were in the third or upper birth rank (P = 0.01). Also, the mean age of fathers at birth in case group (30 ¡À 6.26 years) was significantly more than the control group (26.45 ¡À 5.64 years; P = 0.0001). The age of 76 fathers at birth in case group was over 32 versus 33 fathers in control group. Individuals whose fathers' age was more than 32 (at birth) were at higher risk (2.77 times) for schizophrenia versus others (P < 0.0001, 95% CI 1.80 to 4.27). The maternal age at parturition of the case versus controls groups was 26.1 ¡À 5.41 vs 25.07 ¡À 4.47 (P = 0.02). Logistic regression analysis suggests that maternal age is less likely to be involved in the higher risk of schizophrenia than advanced parental age.
LLM_1:
While many studies since 1958 have linked paternal age to schizophrenia risk, findings vary due to differences in study design, sample size, and confounding environmental factors. Western family structures often limit sibling comparisons across paternal ages, whereas Eastern populations more frequently include offspring born at both early and later paternal ages. This cross-sectional study in an Iranian population compared schizophrenia frequency in younger offspring (reflecting older paternal age) versus older offspring. The study included 220 schizophrenia patients and 220 age- and sex-matched controls, excluding those with neurological conditions, substance abuse, intellectual disability, or mood disorders.

Results showed a higher proportion of cases (35%) than controls (24%) were of third or higher birth rank (P=0.01). Mean paternal age at birth was significantly higher in cases (30¡À6.26 years) than controls (26.45¡À5.64 years; P=0.0001). Paternal age over 32 years was associated with a 2.77-fold increased schizophrenia risk (P<0.0001, 95% CI 1.80¨C4.27). Maternal age also differed between groups (cases: 26.1¡À5.41; controls: 25.07¡À4.47; P=0.02), but logistic regression indicated maternal age is less likely than advanced paternal age to contribute to elevated risk.
LLM_2:
Research examining the association between paternal age and schizophrenia risk has yielded inconsistent findings since 1958, largely attributable to methodological variations, sample size disparities, and confounding environmental influences. Comparative studies within Western family structures are often constrained by limited sibling representation across paternal age ranges, whereas Eastern populations more commonly include offspring born to fathers at both younger and more advanced ages. This cross-sectional investigation, conducted within an Iranian population, compared the prevalence of schizophrenia among younger offspring (reflecting older paternal age at birth) with that among their older siblings. The study comprised 220 individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia and 220 age- and sex-matched controls, excluding participants with neurological disorders, substance use disorders, intellectual disability, or mood disorders.

Analyses revealed a significantly higher proportion of cases (35%) relative to controls (24%) were of third or higher birth order (*P* = 0.01). Mean paternal age at birth was significantly elevated in cases (30.0 ¡À 6.26 years) compared to controls (26.45 ¡À 5.64 years; *P* = 0.0001). Paternal age exceeding 32 years was associated with a 2.77-fold increase in schizophrenia risk (*P* < 0.0001; 95% CI 1.80¨C4.27). Although maternal age also differed between groups (cases: 26.1 ¡À 5.41 years; controls: 25.07 ¡À 4.47 years; *P* = 0.02), logistic regression indicated that advanced paternal age is a more salient predictor of elevated schizophrenia risk than maternal age.

human: Pre-sectarian Buddhism is the earliest phase of Buddhism, recognized by nearly all scholars. Its main scriptures are the Vinaya Pitaka and the four principal Nikayas or Agamas. Certain basic teachings appear in many places throughout the early texts, so most scholars conclude that Gautama Buddha must have taught something similar to the Three marks of existence, the Five Aggregates, dependent origination, karma and rebirth, the Four Noble Truths, the Noble Eightfold Path, and nirvana. Some scholars disagree, and have proposed many other theories.
LLM_1: Pre-sectarian Buddhism, widely accepted by scholars as the earliest phase of Buddhism, is primarily based on the Vinaya Pitaka and the four main Nikayas or Agamas. Core teachings recurrent in these early texts¡ªsuch as the Three Marks of Existence, the Five Aggregates, dependent origination, karma and rebirth, the Four Noble Truths, the Noble Eightfold Path, and nirvana¡ªare generally attributed to Gautama Buddha. A minority of scholars dissent, offering alternative theories.
LLM_2:
Scholars broadly recognize pre-sectarian Buddhism as the original form of the tradition, drawing principally from early scriptural collections¡ªthe Vinaya Pitaka and the four primary Nikayas or Agamas. Central doctrines consistently appearing in these texts are widely ascribed to Gautama Buddha himself.

These foundational teachings include the Three Marks of Existence, the Five Aggregates, the principle of dependent origination, the concepts of karma and rebirth, the Four Noble Truths, the Noble Eightfold Path, and the ultimate goal of nirvana. While this view commands general academic acceptance, a minority of researchers propose differing interpretations.

human:
The initial plan is for a new line from London to Birmingham, with later extensions to Manchester and Leeds.
The Stop HS2 campaign group had called on Mr Grayling to urgently review the project on cost grounds, and the effect on towns and cities near the route.
But Mr Grayling told BBC Radio 4's The World This Weekend: "I have no plans to back away from the HS2 project."
After Mr Grayling's remarks, Stop HS2 campaign manager Joe Rukin told the BBC the transport secretary's comments were "hardly a ringing endorsement" of the project.
The new transport secretary also said he wanted to reach a quick decision on where a new runway should be built to meet growing demand for air travel to and from London.
On rail, Mr Grayling told the BBC: "The thing that's important for people to understand is that HS2 is not simply a speed project, it's a capacity project.
"We have lines at the moment which have seen huge increases in the number of passengers, the amount of freight in recent years."
He said the West Coast main line was becoming "really congested" and was limiting the capacity of services to places such as Northampton and Milton Keynes.
Mr Grayling added: "Of course it makes sense if we're going to build a new railway line for it to be a fast railway line, to increase travel times or reduce travel times from north to south - that's logical.
"But actually we need a better transport system for the 21st century and HS2 is part of increasing the capacity of our transport system."
On flight capacity for the South East, the Airports Commission published a report last year that said a new runway was needed by 2030, and recommending that Heathrow's plan for a third runway should go ahead.
An alternative option would be to build a second runway at Gatwick - an idea supported by London's mayor, Sadiq Khan.  Another suggestion has been doubling an existing runway at Heathrow.
Mr Grayling said: "I am very clear that I want to move rapidly with a decision on what happens on airport capacity. It is a decision that will be taken collectively by the government.
"We have a quasi-judicial role so I'm not going to say today whether I prefer Gatwick or Heathrow, there's two options at Heathrow. I'm going to look at this very carefully in the coming weeks."
MPs are due to vote on the first phase of the HS2 project later this year. Their approval of the bill should allow construction to start on the London to Birmingham section.
The company building the line, HS2 Ltd, is also set to hand out ?¡ê11bn worth of contracts in the coming months.
Last week Stop HS2 called on the government of new Prime Minister Theresa May to undertake a fresh review of the rail project, saying a failure to do so would be "irresponsible".
Mr Rukin, the pressure group's campaign manager, said the project had failed a recent Department for Transport review, on the issues of both costs and the scheduling of work.
That was one reason why HS2 should not be allowed to commence with its tendering processes, he argued.
LLM_1:
The initial HS2 plan involves a new London-Birmingham line, with later extensions to Manchester and Leeds. While the Stop HS2 campaign urged Transport Secretary Chris Grayling to review the project on cost and local impact grounds, he stated he has ¡°no plans to back away from it.¡± Campaign manager Joe Rukin called Grayling¡¯s comments ¡°hardly a ringing endorsement.¡±

Grayling emphasized that HS2 is primarily a capacity project, not just about speed, noting congestion on the West Coast main line is limiting services to places like Northampton and Milton Keynes. He argued a new fast rail line would logically reduce travel times while increasing overall transport capacity for the 21st century.

On airport expansion, Grayling said he aims to reach a quick decision on a new runway for London, considering both Heathrow and Gatwick options, but declined to state a preference due to the government¡¯s quasi-judicial role.

MPs are due to vote on HS2¡¯s first phase later this year, which would allow construction to begin on the London-Birmingham section. HS2 Ltd is also set to award ¡ê11bn in contracts soon.

Stop HS2 recently called on Prime Minister Theresa May¡¯s government to review the project again, calling it ¡°irresponsible¡± not to do so. Rukin claimed HS2 failed a recent Department for Transport review on cost and scheduling, and should not proceed with tendering.
LLM_2:
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling has reaffirmed the government¡¯s commitment to the High Speed 2 (HS2) rail project, despite renewed pressure from campaigners to reconsider the scheme on grounds of cost and local disruption.

The initial phase of HS2 will connect London and Birmingham, with later extensions planned toward Manchester and Leeds. While the campaign group Stop HS2 has urged a review, Mr Grayling stated he has ¡°no plans to back away from it.¡± In response, campaign manager Joe Rukin described the minister¡¯s remarks as ¡°hardly a ringing endorsement.¡±

Mr Grayling emphasised that HS2 is not solely a high-speed initiative, but a crucial capacity upgrade for Britain¡¯s rail network. He pointed to congestion on the West Coast main line, which he said is limiting services to towns such as Northampton and Milton Keynes. A new dedicated line, he argued, would not only cut journey times but also provide essential extra capacity for 21st-century travel demands.

Separately, on the issue of airport expansion in London, the Transport Secretary said he intends to reach a swift decision on a new runway, with both Heathrow and Gatwick under consideration. He declined to express a personal preference, citing the government¡¯s quasi-judicial role in the process.

MPs are expected to vote on the first phase of HS2 later this year, which would enable construction to begin on the London¨CBirmingham section. HS2 Ltd is also preparing to award contracts worth around ¡ê11 billion in the near future.

The Stop HS2 campaign recently called on Prime Minister Theresa May¡¯s government to conduct another review, labelling it ¡°irresponsible¡± to proceed without one. Mr Rukin claimed the project had failed a recent Department for Transport assessment on cost and scheduling grounds, and should not advance to the tendering stage.

Barnaby built a an underground bunker, knowing that one day, zombies, aliens, robots, or a combination thereof would attempt to enslave and/or eat humanity. 
 
 And he was right. 
 
 On September 25, 2014, the whole world woke up to hear the Undead-Extraterrestrial-Robot Coalition knocking on their door. 
 
 ¡° Who is it? ¡± Barnaby said. 
 
 ¡° Rrlgrrbrrgl, ¡± the local representative of the Undead-Extraterrestrial-Robot Coalition said. 
 
 Barnaby peered through the peephole. 
 
 ¡° Sweet baby Moses in the rushes, ¡± he said. A three-foot tall zombie with alien tentacles and a robotic head stood on the doorstep. Tapping its foot. It wore a utility belt with a spoon for eating brains, a transponder for teleporting back to the mothership, and a sauntering iron for repairing blown circuits. 
 
 ¡° I was right! ¡± he shouted back up the stairs, ¡° Hey honey, I was right. ¡± 
 
 ¡° Whaaat? ¡± Lyndon called back. She was in the shower. 
 
 ¡° Get the kids honey, ¡± Barnaby yelled, ¡° We ¡¯ re going to the bunker. ¡± 
 
 Lyndon said nothing. Barnaby bounced on the balls of his feet with excitement. He wiped his sweaty palms onto his pajama pants. 
 
 ¡° Honey, ¡± Barnaby yelled, his voice straining. 
 
 ¡° Whaaat? ¡± Lyndon called back. 
 
 Barnaby trotted up the stairs, two at a time. He spun around the corner on his tiptoe. 
 
 ¡° Honey, ¡± he shouted, standing outside the bathroom door. ¡° The aliens are here. ¡± 
 
 The shower ¡¯ s patter went silent.

 ¡° No, ¡± Barnaby said, ¡° No, no, I promised you I ¡¯ d never do that again. ¡±

 Barnaby checked his breath. Minty fresh. ¡° No honey, ¡± he said, ¡° Hey we need to go now. ¡± 
 
 The door swung open. His beautiful wife, clad in a purple towel strode out. She brushed passed him. His eyes widened. 
 
 ¡° Hey honey, ¡± he said, ¡° Why aren ¡¯ t you listening to me? We need to get Peter and Melissa and get into the bunker. ¡± 
 
 ¡° Stop Barnaby, ¡± Lyndon said, ¡° Just stop. ¡± 
 
 Barnaby grabbed her arm. ¡° Come with me! ¡± he said, ¡° I ¡¯ m saving you! ¡± 
 
 She snatched her arm away from him. ¡° That ¡¯ s it, ¡± she said, ¡° We need to get a divorce. I can ¡¯ t believe we ¡¯ ve lasted this long, to be honest. You ¡¯ re just¡ªYou have shenanigans. What kind of husband has shenanigans? When we got married, I thought that you were going to be a real¡ª ¡± 
 
 Barnaby glared at her. She was so unfair. He turned around and ran down the stairs to the kids ¡¯ rooms. 
 
 ¡° Hey! ¡± Lyndon shouted, ¡° You come back here! I ¡¯ m talking to you! ¡± 
 
 Barnaby ignored her. 
 
 ¡° Melissa! ¡± he shouted, ¡° Peter! ¡± He knocked on their doors. No response. He peered inside. There was a lump in Peter ¡¯ s bed. Barnaby tore the cover off the bed. It was a basketball and some pillows positioned to look like a person. Ridiculous. Of all the nights to sneak out, Peter had chosen the eve of the apocalypse. So irresponsible. 
 
 He barged into Melissa ¡¯ s room. Empty. Where was she? Maybe she was already in the bunker. She was a smart kid. Responsible. 
 
 Barnaby crept towards the back door. The coast was clear. He grabbed the keyring from the hook next to the door. He dashed outside towards the bunker. He fiddled with the keyring and shoved it into the bunker ¡¯ s steel door. The deadbolt tumbled. He swung the door open. In the corner of his eye, he saw a three-foot-tall zombie-alien-robot sprinting towards him from the neighbor ¡¯ s yard. 
 
 ¡° Nooo, ¡± Barnaby cried, diving into the bunker and swinging the door shut. THUNK. THUNK. THUNK. The door bolted automatically in three places. 
 
 ¡° Melissa? ¡± he said. 
 
 There was no answer. He stared at the racks of canned food. The board games set up on the table. The rows of cots. There was a figure on one of the cots, underneath a blanket. He approached slowly. 
 
 ¡° Melissa, ¡± he called again, ¡° It ¡¯ s Dad. Are you okay? ¡± 
 
 No response. 
 
 He peaked under the blanket. A basketball and pillows. He looked at them in horror. What was going on here? 
 
 Just then, he heard his wife ¡¯ s shriek. He fumbled with the key ring. He had to go save her. No matter how much of a naggy old meanypants she was, he loved her. He would save her. 
 
 He looked down at the key ring. He had a long brass key in his hand. But that was the key for the entrance. There was a separate key for the exit. What had happened to the other key? Why wasn ¡¯ t it on the key ring? 
 
 The lights went out. 
 
 ¡° ¡° Rrlgrrbrrgl, ¡± came a low growl next to him. 
 
 Barnaby screamed.

human:
He went to sulk somewhere in Australia, I think. 
 
 I mean, if you could choose to live anywhere on earth, why would you choose Australia? Sure, it gets nice and hot there, beaches to chill on, ( chill? OK, maybe not ), but basically everything wants to kill you there. But maybe that was the point. 
 
 That was a few months ago. I lost track of exactly how many. I did try, at the beginning I thought it was important to cling onto the human construct of time, but then the days merged into each other, weeks, months.... 
 
 I'd moved to what was formerly Florida, it was somewhere I'd always wanted to go. Nice and warm, all year round, without getting too ridiculously hot. OK, so there was a rainy season, but I'd cross that bridge when I got there. And I could always move again - the world was my oyster, right? Or at least half of it. And at least it was n't grey and rainy every single day of the year. I'd never been so tanned in my life. Not that there was anyone around to appreciate it, but you ca n't win them all, eh? 
 
 I mean, really, Australia. It was such an extreme reaction. Maybe he'll get over it, once he gets tired of all the snakes, and the sharks, and the spiders...
LLM_1:
He went to sulk in Australia, I think. If you could live anywhere, why choose a place where everything wants to kill you? But maybe that was the point.

Months have blurred since then. I tried to keep track of time at first, but days melted into weeks, then months.

I moved to what was once Florida¡ªsomewhere I¡¯d always wanted to be. Warm year-round, without extreme heat. There¡¯s a rainy season, but I¡¯d deal with that later. I could always move again; the world was my oyster, or at least half of it. At least it wasn¡¯t endlessly grey. I¡¯ve never been so tanned, though there¡¯s no one around to notice. You can¡¯t win them all.

Really, Australia¡ªsuch an extreme reaction. Maybe he¡¯ll get over it once he tires of the snakes, sharks, and spiders.
LLM_2:
He vanished to brood in Australia, I suppose. If you could pick anywhere on the map, why choose a land where every creature seems to have teeth, venom, or claws? Then again¡ªmaybe that was precisely why.

Time has smudged since he left. I counted the days at first, watching them bleed into weeks, then dissolve into months without edges.

I drifted south to what used to be Florida¡ªa place I¡¯d always imagined in sun-bleached daydreams. Warmth wraps the year here, a gentle kind, without the scorching breath of a furnace. There¡¯s a season of rain, they say, but I¡¯ll face that when it comes. I could always wander on; the world felt wide open, or at least my half of it did. At least the sky wasn¡¯t a perpetual sheet of grey. My skin has taken on the shade of old honey¡ªnot that there¡¯s anyone to see it. Some victories are quiet ones.

Still¡ªAustralia. Such a dramatic exit. Maybe he¡¯ll wear himself out dodging serpents and spiders and tides that bite, and come back when the drama feels thin.

human: Over the course of the past few months I have been burning a whole lot of midnight oil. Many nights I spend sitting idly in front of the computer screen searching for blogger's and Xanga's that resonate with my own heart. I spent a little time before I sat down to surf the net and considered why I do this. I refuse to go over the externals as to why I spend too much time surfing the net, I will go straight to the heart of the matter. I am looking for acceptance in the online world... looking for someone to validate my thoughts and Ideas. Someone to encourage, rebuke, agree, or deny me. All of this fruitless searching in order to supplement my time with the Lord. I also have some great freinds. My freinds Willy, Russ, Milo, Pete, Renee, and Becky are ssome I spend time talking about who God is, who Jesus Christ is, who we are in Christ and how that relates to the World. I have decided that I will not allow myself to surf the net or hang out with my freinds until I have spent time in the word and spent time with the Lord in prayer. Jesus Christ alone can fill the void in my heart... all other relationships, to include best freinds, or even spouses will not fill the emptiness in the heart of man so much as God.       Holy Father, Lord of my life and Savior of my soul, I consecrate my life to you today. I pour out my life as a drink offering to you my King. The blood of your Son draws me nigh Lord and keeps me so. I do not know where to go, but I am ready, Lord send me. How to adress the pain, how to be a light in a dark place? I do not know... Lord I ask, your will be done and you be glorified.
LLM_1:
Over the past few months, I¡¯ve been burning the midnight oil, often sitting at my computer searching for blogs and Xanga pages that resonate with me. I¡¯ve reflected on why I do this¡ªnot the surface reasons, but the real heart of it: I¡¯m looking for acceptance online, for someone to validate my thoughts, to encourage or challenge me. Yet all this searching can¡¯t replace time with the Lord.

I¡¯m blessed with close friends¡ªWilly, Russ, Milo, Pete, Renee, and Becky¡ªwith whom I discuss faith, Christ, and our place in the world. Still, I¡¯ve decided not to surf the web or meet with friends until I¡¯ve first spent time in Scripture and prayer. Only Jesus can fill the emptiness in my heart; no other relationship, however dear, can satisfy like God.

Holy Father, Lord of my life, I consecrate myself to you today. I pour out my life as an offering. Your Son¡¯s blood draws me near and keeps me close. I don¡¯t know where to go, but I¡¯m ready¡ªsend me. I don¡¯t know how to address the pain or be light in darkness, but I pray: Your will be done, and you be glorified.
LLM_2:
Over the last few months, I¡¯ve spent countless late nights scrolling through blogs and old Xanga pages, looking for something that felt like it spoke to me. I¡¯ve asked myself why¡ªnot just the easy answers, but the real, quiet truth underneath: I¡¯m searching for a kind of acceptance online, for someone to see my thoughts and say, ¡°Me too,¡± or maybe even, ¡°Have you considered this?¡± But no amount of scrolling can fill the space meant for time with God.

I¡¯m deeply thankful for friends like Willy, Russ, Milo, Pete, Renee, and Becky¡ªpeople I can talk with about faith, about Jesus, about where we fit in this world. Even so, I¡¯ve made a commitment: no internet browsing, no meet-ups, until I¡¯ve first opened my Bible and prayed. Because at the end of the day, only Christ can truly satisfy this heart of mine. No other connection, as meaningful as it is, reaches the places He can.

Holy Father¡ªYou who hold my life in Your hands¡ªtoday I choose to set myself apart for You. I offer my days, my questions, my quiet hours. In anesthetized Wistar-Kyoto rats, cardiac microdialysis was applied to the left ventricle to examine the effect of ¦Á?-adrenergic stimulation via medetomidine on myocardial interstitial acetylcholine (ACh) levels, both without and with SAS from the left stellate ganglion. The effect of electrical vagal efferent stimulation on ACh release was also assessed under the same conditions. Intravenous medetomidine significantly increased myocardial interstitial ACh levels without SAS, but not in the presence of SAS. In contrast, electrical vagal nerve stimulation increased ACh levels similarly regardless of SAS.

Using anesthetized Wistar-Kyoto rats, cardiac microdialysis was performed in the left ventricle to measure myocardial interstitial acetylcholine (ACh) levels following ¦Á?-adrenergic stimulation with medetomidine, both in the absence and presence of SAS applied via the left stellate ganglion. Additionally, the influence of SAS on ACh release during direct electrical vagal efferent stimulation was evaluated under identical experimental conditions. Results indicate that intravenous administration of medetomidine significantly elevated myocardial interstitial ACh levels in the absence of SAS, an effect that was abolished when SAS was concurrently applied. In contrast, direct electrical stimulation of the vagus nerve increased ACh release to a similar extent irrespective of SAS presence. These findings suggest that SAS selectively inhibits centrally mediated vagal activation triggered by ¦Á?-adrenergic stimulation, without affecting peripherally evoked vagal responses.

human:
This paper proposed a deep learning framework with three components: an obfuscator, a classifier, and a reconstructor, for privacy-preserving image classification. To protect the privacy of the image data, this paper proposed an adversarial training process to optimize the obfuscator such that it achieves high classification accuracy while the "best" reconstructor is not able to accurately reconstruct the sensitive input image from the output features. Experiment results showed relatively high accuracy with no sign that an input image can be reconstructed by state-of-the-art reconstruction models.

The presentation of the paper is pretty good. The problem of learning without leaking sensitive information in data is an important issue, and the paper proposed an interesting framework for it. However, I think some technical aspects need to be more addressed:
It seems that the obfuscator+classifier models are obtained by dividing an existing deep CNN architecture, but the paper did not justify the choice of the model or the choice of the layer as the dividing point. These seem to be important decisions in the framework, so I think more intuitions, or some heuristics for choosing them need to be provided.
It is not clear to me how reconstruction accuracy (measured by human¡¯s perception) and data privacy are related. I think in general high reconstruction error does not automatically imply that the sensitive information is removed. It is still possible for a machine learning model to extract sensitive information from images that are not readable for human. So I think justifications for this choice of privacy metric need to be provided.

A few things about presentation:
1. The first sentence of Section 4: "the our proposed framework" --> "the proposed framework of"
2. Figure 3: all lines are overlapping. I suggest explaining why and color-code the lines for better visibility.
LLM_1:
This paper introduces a deep learning framework for privacy-preserving image classification, consisting of an obfuscator, a classifier, and a reconstructor. An adversarial training process optimizes the obfuscator to maintain high classification accuracy while preventing accurate reconstruction of sensitive input images from the output features. Experiments show relatively high accuracy with no evidence that state-of-the-art reconstruction models can recover input images.

The paper is well-presented and addresses an important problem. However, some technical aspects require further clarification:
- The obfuscator and classifier appear to be derived by splitting an existing CNN, but the choice of model and division point lacks justification. More intuition or heuristics for these design decisions should be provided.
- The relationship between reconstruction accuracy (based on human perception) and data privacy is unclear. High reconstruction error does not necessarily guarantee removal of sensitive information, as machine learning models might still extract such information from images unreadable to humans. Justification for this privacy metric is needed.

Presentation notes:
1. Section 4, first sentence: "the our proposed framework" should be "the proposed framework of".
2. Figure 3: lines overlap; consider explaining this and using color coding for better visibility.
LLM_2:
This paper proposes a deep learning framework for privacy-preserving image classification, comprising an obfuscator, a classifier, and a reconstructor. Through adversarial training, the obfuscator is optimized to preserve classification accuracy while preventing accurate reconstruction of sensitive input images from intermediate features. Experimental results demonstrate competitive classification performance, with no evidence that state-of-the-art reconstruction models can successfully recover the original inputs.

**Overall Assessment**  
The paper is clearly written and tackles a meaningful problem at the intersection of privacy and computer vision. The framework is conceptually interesting, and the experimental setup appears sound. However, several technical aspects would benefit from further elaboration to strengthen the methodological grounding and clarify the privacy claims.

**Major Comments**  
1. **Architectural Design Choices**  
   The obfuscator and classifier seem to be derived from a partitioned CNN, but the rationale for selecting the base model and the specific splitting point is not adequately justified. Providing intuition or heuristic guidelines for these design decisions¡ªsuch as how the split affects privacy-utility trade-offs¡ªwould improve reproducibility and methodological transparency.

2. **Privacy Metric and Its Interpretation**  
   The paper uses reconstruction accuracy (judged by human perception) as a proxy for privacy. However, high reconstruction error does not necessarily guarantee the removal of sensitive information, as machine learning models might still extract such information from visually distorted or unreadable images. The authors should justify this metric more thoroughly, perhaps by discussing its limitations or relating it to established privacy definitions (e.g., mutual information, differential privacy).

**Minor Comments**  
- **Section 4, first sentence**: ¡°the our proposed framework¡± should be revised to ¡°the proposed framework¡± or ¡°our proposed framework.¡±  
- **Figure 3**: Some lines appear to overlap; consider adjusting the layout or using distinct colors to improve readability.

**Recommendation**  
With the above clarifications addressed, this paper could make a stronger contribution to the literature on privacy-preserving visual computing.

LLM_2:
In Mahayana Buddhist tradition, the *arahant*¡ªa figure revered for spiritual attainment¡ªis understood to reach a state of nirvana, yet remains partially bound by subtle delusion. By contrast, the *bodhisattva* pursues a path of complete liberation, ultimately overcoming all delusion to achieve *bodhi*, or full awakening, thereby becoming a buddha.

Meanwhile, in Theravada Buddhism¡ªthe school often regarded as preserving the earliest teachings¡ªthe terms *bodhi* and *nirvana* maintain their classical definitions. Here, both signify freedom from the three core afflictions: greed, hatred, and delusion. This interpretation underscores a more unified view of enlightenment, distinct from the graduated stages emphasized in Mahayana thought.

The question is pertinent and timely, given that Standard Chartered, a UK bank, was accused this week of violating US law.
Not, that is, as a result of the bank's relatively limited activities in America.
Rather, the bank stands accused of hiding transactions for "Iranian financial institutions" that were subject to US economic sanctions. The bank denies the allegations.
The case is just the latest example of how the US has been extending its so-called extraterritorial powers in recent years - where the US has been flexing its legal muscle outside its own territory.
"The issue boils down to the following concept," says Jacob Frenkel, chair of securities enforcement, white-collar crime and government investigations practice with the law firm Shulman, Rogers, Gandal, Pordy & Ecker.
"Any sovereign, whether a country, province, state or municipality, has a right to expect that a company or person doing business in that territory is subject to the laws of that territory.
"Just as a party doing business enjoys the protection of the laws, so too must a party comply with the laws."
That definition raises two further questions. First, how should "doing business in that territory" be defined? In other words, when is an individual or firm deemed to be doing business in the US?
It does not take much, according to David Pitofsky, a member of law firm Goodwin Procter's litigation department, who is currently involved in client work connected to the Libor scandal, and is representing the administrator of the Gulf Coast Claims Facility, which deals with claims from victims of the Deep Water Horizon oil spill.
"As long as dollars are involved, they will eventually touch a US institution," he says, referring to how almost all banking transactions, particularly in US dollars, will at some point in the process flow through the Federal Reserve Bank in New York.
The courts have made clear over the years that such flows of funds through New York is sufficient for asserting jurisdiction.
"Even if a transaction is done, say, in Japanese yen, if a blip in the system turns these into dollars - however briefly - that in theory could mean it falls under US law," says Mr Pitofsky.
American patent lawyers are also eagerly eyeing activities abroad.
"Through both judicial and legislative efforts, [US patent law] has evolved from a strict territorial based set of laws asserting jurisdiction only over those infringements taking place on American soil," according to University of Alberta professors Moin Yahya and Cameron Hutchison.
US patent law, they say, has expanded into "a more expansive set of rules asserting jurisdiction over any event that may harm patent holders in the United States regardless of where the infringement is taking place".
"This, we argue, is contrary to the original purpose of patent law and inconsistent with American obligations under the International Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property," they write in a paper.
Another example of how the US legal system is extending its tentacles abroad is the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, a controversial piece of legislation that provides for extraterritorial jurisdiction for US courts over actions brought where US investors or markets are harmed by actions outside the United States.
Dodd-Frank, with its numerous registration and clearing requirements and its ongoing revisions, has caused considerable legislative uncertainty in a number of financial markets.
The act has resulted in particular concern among players in the so-called over-the-counter derivatives markets, which include interest-rate, currency or commodity swaps that are used by companies in a wide range of sectors to reduce investment, currency and trading risk.
"We have a rule that's being extended beyond its original scope, and that's concerning," says Don Thompson, managing director and associate general counsel at JP Morgan in New York.
The second question raised by Mr Frenkel's definition of what the issue relates to is should non-US individuals and companies be bound by US law even when they operate outside the US, simply because they also do some business in America?
According to US anti-corruption laws, they should.
Two examples illustrate how such laws are increasingly used to target activities that take place in other parts of the world.
The media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's US-based global media group News Corporation is co-operating with the US Department of Justice (DoJ) which is looking into possible breaches of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
The DoJ is examining allegations its now defunct UK newspaper subsidiary News of the World paid UK officials for information, something prohibited by the Act.
In 2010, industrial group Daimler, the owner of Mercedes-Benz, pleaded guilty in the US to corruption charges after admitting to paying tens of millions of dollars in bribes to government officials in at least 22 countries. The bribes were not paid in the US, yet the German company agreed to pay US authorities $185m (?¡ê118m) to settle the case.
Similarly, back in 2008 the German industrial group Siemens paid $800m to settle a US investigation into bribes paid to government officials in Argentina, Bangladesh, Iraq and Venezuela.
Individuals have also been targeted.
In 2009, Gary Kaplan, the boss of London-based gambling company BetOnSports, fell foul of a US law that bans Americans from placing bets online even on websites outside the US. He was jailed for four years.
In 2006, three British former NatWest bankers were extradited to the US to face fraud charges, in a case sparking anger in the UK business community.
At the time, the bankers said their crimes had taken place in the UK and the victim was a UK bank hence they wanted to be tried in Britain. But the US authorities said their actions had been linked to the collapse of the energy giant Enron and as such it was a US matter.
And earlier this year, retired UK businessman Christopher Tappin was extradited to the US on charges of exporting parts for Iranian missiles.
In fact, the US is tightening its sanctions against Iran, and thus the potential for legal action against anyone trading with the country - and not just those doing deals that would aid it in building a nuclear reactor.
Earlier this month, US Congress voted to impose sanctions that meant anyone who provided commercial goods, technology or financial services to Iran's energy sector could face punishment.
Critics of the international reach of US legislation do not necessarily disagree with US ambitions, which range from protecting the global financial system to curbing the nuclear or military ambitions of a number of dictatorships.
But companies, whether in the financial services sector or in industry or elsewhere, do object to the one-sided approach of US legislation, pointing to a lack of reciprocity that would allow other countries' legal systems to also cover US firms.
That, however, is "an issue for the 'affected' sovereign", according to Mr Frenkel.
"There is nothing that prevents other sovereigns from adopting laws and courts of other sovereigns from enforcing laws as sweeping and with the breadth of US enforcement programs. That becomes an issue of sovereign willpower and allocation of enforcement resources."
Non-US critics have also vented their anger in instances where they deem US rulings unfair.
And many complain about the increased complexity of doing business, both within and outside the US.
The thicket of new regulations has the potential to create an uneven playing field in international markets, according to Dan Cohen, managing director and head of government relations for the Depository Trust and Clearing Corp, a non-commercial co-operative that serves as the primary post-trade infrastructure organisation for US capital markets.
Moreover, it could impede global regulatory co-operation and undermine efforts to increase market transparency and mitigate risk in the over-the-counter derivatives market, he says.
Others point to the added complexities for companies required to deal with the vast and growing number of regulatory bodies in the US.
Not only will they have to comply with the rules of federal bodies such as the US Securities and Exchange Commission, the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, there are also state bodies, such as The New York State Department of Financial Services, which is the regulator that accused Standard Chartered.
It is 10 months old and supervises some 4,500 institutions with assets of about $6.2 trillion.
Yet many had not even heard of it until this week.
LLM_1:

Jacob Frenkel of Shulman Rogers notes that any entity doing business in a territory must comply with its laws. This raises two questions: what constitutes ¡°doing business¡± in the US, and should non-US firms be bound by US law abroad?

David Pitofsky of Goodwin Procter explains that any transaction involving US dollars typically touches the Federal Reserve in New York, giving US courts jurisdiction. Even non-dollar transactions briefly converted to dollars could fall under US law.

US patent law has also broadened, now covering infringements abroad that harm US patent holders¡ªa shift some scholars argue conflicts with international agreements.

The Dodd-Frank Act extends US court jurisdiction over overseas actions harming US investors, creating uncertainty in financial markets, especially for over-the-counter derivatives.

US anti-corruption laws are increasingly applied globally. News Corporation is under DoJ scrutiny for alleged UK bribes, while Daimler and Siemens paid large settlements for foreign bribery. Individuals, like BetOnSports¡¯ Gary Kaplan and former NatWest bankers, have faced US prosecution for overseas actions.

The US is tightening Iran sanctions, threatening penalties for anyone aiding Iran¡¯s energy sector. Critics acknowledge US goals like protecting financial systems or curbing nuclear threats but object to the one-sided approach, noting a lack of reciprocity.

Dan Cohen of DTCC warns that complex US regulations risk uneven global markets and hinder regulatory cooperation. Companies must navigate numerous federal and state bodies, including New York¡¯s Department of Financial Services¡ªthe new regulator that accused Standard Chartered.
LLM_2:

The case underscores the increasingly expansive extraterritorial application of American regulations.

Legal experts point to a growing trend in which US authorities assert jurisdiction over international business activities. According to Jacob Frenkel, a specialist at Shulman Rogers, any organization operating within a jurisdiction is subject to its legal framework. This development prompts two pressing questions: how is ¡°doing business¡± in the United States defined, and should foreign companies be held accountable to US law outside American borders?

David Pitofsky of Goodwin Procter clarifies that nearly any transaction conducted in US dollars typically involves clearance through the Federal Reserve in New York, thereby granting US courts potential authority. Even non-dollar transactions momentarily converted into dollars may fall under US legal scrutiny.

Beyond banking, US patent law has also widened in scope, now addressing infringements abroad that adversely affect American patent holders¡ªa move some legal scholars contend may clash with international agreements.

The 2010 Dodd-Frank Act further extends US judicial reach to overseas activities that harm domestic investors, generating uncertainty within global financial markets, particularly regarding over-the-counter derivatives.

Individuals, including BetOnSports founder Gary Kaplan and former NatWest bankers, have faced US prosecution for conduct occurring abroad.

Concurrently, the US is intensifying sanctions against Iran, warning of severe consequences for entities supporting Iran¡¯s energy sector. While critics recognize objectives such as safeguarding financial systems or countering nuclear proliferation, many challenge what they see as a unilateral approach, highlighting an absence of reciprocal enforcement by other nations.

Dan Cohen of the Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation cautions that the complexity of US regulations risks fragmenting global markets and complicating international regulatory collaboration. Firms must now contend with a multitude of federal and state agencies, including New York¡¯s Department of Financial Services¡ªthe newly empowered regulator that brought the allegations against Standard Chartered.

Philip Spriggs, 51, from Oxford, was found guilty of a total of 20 charges including 11 counts of rape, sexual assault and making indecent photos.
Oxford Crown Court was told the offences took place in Headington over seven years between 2007 and 2014.
Thames Valley Police praised his victims for being "brave" and "speaking out".
Spriggs was given an additional seven years on licence and placed on the sex offenders' register for life.
Det Sgt Tracey Shepherd said: "The victims in this case have been very brave at speaking out against their abuser.
"They can now begin to rebuild their lives knowing they do not have to suffer further abuse."
Spriggs, who was arrested and charged last October, was found guilty of 20 charges following a trial in April.
The charges were 11 counts of rape, two counts of assault of a child under 13, one charge of attempted rape, two charges of sexual assault of a child under 13, two counts of causing a child under 13 to engage in sexual activity, one charge of assault by penetration, and one count of making indecent photos.

human: We studied the effects of ketamine in the isolated rat lung under conditions of increased pulmonary arterial pressure using the thromboxane A2 mimic, U46619, and in response to ventilatory hypoxia. Ketamine caused dose-dependent vasodilation, and possible mechanisms were evaluated using verapamil, meclofenamate, N(omega)-L-nitro-L-arginine benzyl ester (an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase), and U-38883A (an ATP-sensitive potassium channel antagonist) in the isolated blood-perfused rat lung. Under increased tone conditions, N(omega)-L-nitro-L-arginine benzyl ester, meclofenamate, and U-38883A had no significant effect in attenuating ketamine-induced vasodilator responses. In a final series of experiments, verapamil significantly attenuated ketamine-induced vasodilator responses. These data suggest that ketamine has significant vasodilator activity in the pulmonary vascular bed of the rat, which seems to be mediated by an L-type calcium channel-sensitive pathway. These responses are not mediated or modulated by the release of nitric oxide, the activation of K+ ATP channels, or the release of vasodilator cyclooxygenase products.
LLM_1: This study examined ketamine's effects on isolated, blood-perfused rat lungs under elevated pulmonary arterial pressure induced by U46619 or ventilatory hypoxia. Ketamine produced dose-dependent vasodilation. Pharmacological evaluation using inhibitors of nitric oxide synthase (N?¦Ø?-L-nitro-L-arginine benzyl ester), cyclooxygenase (meclofenamate), and ATP-sensitive potassium channels (U-38883A) showed no significant attenuation of ketamine-induced vasodilation. However, verapamil, an L-type calcium channel blocker, significantly reduced these responses. The findings indicate that ketamine's vasodilator activity in the rat pulmonary vascular bed is mediated primarily through an L-type calcium channel-sensitive pathway, independent of nitric oxide release, K? ATP channel activation, or cyclooxygenase-derived vasodilator products.
LLM_2: This investigation assessed the vasoactive properties of ketamine in an isolated, blood-perfused rat lung model under conditions of elevated pulmonary arterial pressure, induced either pharmacologically (via U46619) or physiologically (through ventilatory hypoxia). Ketamine elicited a dose-dependent vasodilatory response. Pharmacological blockade of nitric oxide synthase (using N?¦Ø?-L-nitro-L-arginine benzyl ester), cyclooxygenase (via meclofenamate), and ATP-sensitive potassium channels (with U-38883A) did not significantly attenuate ketamine-induced vasodilation. In contrast, administration of verapamil, an L-type calcium channel antagonist, markedly suppressed these vasodilatory effects. The results demonstrate that ketamine¡¯s vasodilator action in the rat pulmonary vascular bed is mediated principally via a pathway sensitive to L-type calcium channel inhibition, and operates independently of nitric oxide release, activation of ATP-sensitive potassium channels, or cyclooxygenase-derived vasodilator metabolites.

human: The present study compares the accuracy of a new continuous venous oxygenation monitoring system (PediaSat Oximetry Catheter) with laboratory blood oximetry in paediatric surgical patients.Children and adolescents undergoing cardiac, orthopaedic or craniofacial surgery with major blood loss were included. A 4.5 Fr two-lumen or 5.5 Fr three-lumen central venous oximetry catheter (SPediaSatcvO2) was inserted preoperatively into the superior vena cava. After in-vivo calibration of the PediaSat system, repeated blood samples were obtained from the distal port of the venous catheter and oximetrically analysed for haemoglobin and central venous oxygen saturation (SCO-OXcvO2). Central venous oxygen saturation values measured by the PediaSat (SPediaSatcvO2) were compared with co-oximetry (SCO-OXcvO2) values from the simultaneously taken blood samples by Bland-Altman and simple regression analyses.Overall, 142 data pairs from 27 patients, aged from 0.6 to 19.0 years (median 5.3 years) were analysed. SPediaSatcvO2 and SCO-OXcvO2 values ranged from 57 to 98% and from 57.1 to 95.8%, respectively. Correlation between SPediaSatcvO2 and SCO-OXcvO2 was poor with r equal to 0.28 (P < 0.0001). SPediaSatcvO2 overestimated SCO-OXcvO2 (mean bias +2.6%), but limits of agreement (+/-2 SD of bias) were unacceptably high (-14.4/+19.6%). Sensitivity and specificity of SPediaSatcvO2 to indicate a fall or rise of SCO-OXcvO2 between two subsequent measurements were only 0.42 and 0.24, respectively.

After in-vivo calibration, repeated blood samples were drawn from the catheter for co-oximetric analysis of hemoglobin and central venous oxygen saturation (SCO-OXcvO?). PediaSat measurements (SPediaSatcvO?) were compared with SCO-OXcvO? using Bland-Altman and regression analyses. In 27 patients (age 0.6¨C19 years, median 5.3 years), 142 data pairs showed SPediaSatcvO? values from 57% to 98% and SCO-OXcvO? from 57.1% to 95.8%. Correlation was poor (r=0.28, P<0.0001), with a mean bias of +2.6% and wide limits of agreement (-14.4% to +19.6%). Paulina Vega had come under pressure to quit after her country's condemnation of the pageant owner, Donald Trump.
Mr Trump caused a furore last month after he said Mexican immigrants who came to the US brought drugs and crime.
Ms Vega called Mr Trump's comments "unjust and hurtful", but said she would continue as Miss Universe.
"The fact that I am not giving up my crown doesn't mean I am changing my stance about everything I said," Ms Vega told local radio on Monday, adding that the Miss Universe organisation did meaningful social work.
"I have kept doing my job as Miss Universe all these days. The work continues as always despite all this craziness going on," she added.
Mr Trump had attacked Ms Vega for keeping her crown, saying: "Miss Universe, Paulina Vega, criticised me for telling the truth about illegal immigration, but then said she would keep the crown - hypocrite."
While announcing his candidacy for the US presidency last month, Mr Trump had accused Mexico of sending rapists and other criminals to the United States.
He also pledged to build a "great wall" on the US border with Mexico and insisted it would be paid for by Mexicans.
He later insisted he was criticising US lawmakers, not Mexican people.
Following Mr Trump's remarks, several TV networks across the Americas said they would no longer air Miss Universe, including the Spanish language network, Univision and NBC.
Mexico also announced that it would not send a contestant to the pageant.
