The 66-year-old Australian, who replaced Steve McNamara earlier this month, has a contract to lead England through to the 2017 World Cup.
Bennett, who is yet to announce his backroom team, told BBC Sport: "I am not going to stay as English coach for 20 years - that is not going to happen.
"I want to leave it with people who have a similar philosophy to me."
Bennett, who will combine the role with leading Brisbane Broncos in the National Rugby League, is not planning wholesale changes to the England set-up.
"I'm very conscious of the English game and England. I am not coming here to teach anyone how to suck eggs," he added.
"I want as much English involvement as I can. I am bringing two staff with me - one of them is an Englishman - and the other is involved in the tactical side. Everyone else will be English."
Former St Helens full-back Paul Wellens, who has taken up a player performance coaching role with Saints, was one of McNamara's backroom staff.
Bennett has remained a stony-faced touchline presence in Australia's NRL during a top-level career that has spanned 27 years, three different clubs and a record seven Grand Final victories.
He says his persona reflects one of the demands he will make of England's players.
"I might be smiling on the inside, I might be pretty twisted on the inside, but I am not there to please anyone else but myself," he said.
"I taught myself a long time ago to be extremely disciplined with my behaviour in the public spotlight and I expect my players to be the same."
Bennett said he would not shirk from the difficult decisions and disagreements that are inevitable when running a top team.
"I don't want them to dislike me, but you are dealing with people and there will always be issues because people take positions on things," he said.
"The bottom line is that if I have to make a hard decision for the benefit of the team and it upsets people, I'm fine with that."
Bennett's appointment means - with Eddie Jones in rugby union and Trevor Bayliss in cricket - Australians are in charge of three of England's major national teams.
Bennett believes work ethic and a willingness to share ideas across sport are one of the strengths of Australian coaching culture.
"There is one common denominator: we are a pretty committed bunch and to coach you have to be committed," he said.
"We share a lot of ideas between sports back home, it is not something we hold back on."
BBC Sport's Simon Stone:
Wayne Bennett's seven Grand Final wins make him the most decorated Australian coach ever. And his determination to succeed is not confined to the rugby field.
"My daughter has barred me from playing with my grandchildren," he said. "They want to win and so do I, so we get into fights. I can't help it. It is just who I am."
Bennett has no intention of reigning himself in.
"I don't want to stop myself," he said. "I want to do my best and I want to win, whether it is cards or whatever it is. I have been like that all my life.
"In fact I make people stay until I win at cards."

Labour lost its majority on Newcastle-under-Lyme Borough Council in February when two councillors stood down after not being reselected to stand in May.
A recount in the remaining Ravenscliffe ward earlier saw Labour's Sarah Pickup gain the seat from independent councillor Gill Burnett.
It means Labour retains 29 seats out of the 60, not enough for a majority.
The Conservatives increased their number of seats by five to 20 in the administration, which elects a third of its councillors each year.
Gill Burnett and Paul Waring stood down from Labour in February after they were not reselected.

The Conservatives gained five seats, bringing their total to 20 in the council, which elects a third of its members annually. Elsewhere in local elections, Labour lost overall control in Stoke-on-Trent, while the Conservatives took control of Staffordshire Moorlands District Council and retained Cheshire East and Stafford Borough Council.

The Conservatives made significant gains in the authority, adding five seats to reach a total of 20. Newcastle-under-Lyme Council elects one-third of its members each year under a system of partial renewal.

The results in Newcastle-under-Lyme formed part of a broader set of local election outcomes across the region. Labour also lost overall control of Stoke-on-Trent City Council, while the Conservatives took command of Staffordshire Moorlands District Council and maintained control of both Cheshire East and Stafford Borough Councils.

Those who today received large sums of money for doing very little but doing it well have inspired me to do something.  I will do it, and do it well.  Cap'n calls me today after I confront Teddy about his absence from the task at hand.  Only after concern of my anger will he call.  Too late, I am on my own.  I need to be free. I¡¯ve watched people around me build lives doing things that look effortless, not because they¡¯re easy, but because they do them exceptionally well. That¡¯s the kind of path I want: not just to work, but to work with purpose and skill.  

Funny how the boss only reaches out after I finally speak up¡ªafter I call out Teddy for ghosting shifts, and only because he¡¯s worried about my frustration. But by then, it¡¯s already too late. My mind is made up. I¡¯m stepping out on my own.  

I need this freedom¡ªnot as an escape, but as a foundation. Soon enough, I¡¯ll be working again, earning again, but next time it¡¯ll be on my own terms. And that¡¯s when I¡¯ll really be free.

human: The short stature homeobox-containing gene, SHOX, located on the distal ends of the X and Y chromosomes, encodes a homeodomain transcription factor responsible for a significant proportion of long-bone growth. Patients with mutations or deletions of SHOX, including those with Turner syndrome (TS) who are haplo-insufficient for SHOX, have variable degrees of growth impairment, with or without a spectrum of skeletal anomalies consistent with dyschondrosteosis.Our objective was to determine the efficacy of GH in treating short stature associated with short stature homeobox-containing gene deficiency (SHOX-D).Fifty-two prepubertal subjects (24 male, 28 female; age, 3.0-12.3 yr) with a molecularly proven SHOX gene defect and height below the third percentile for age and gender (or height below the 10th percentile and height velocity below the 25th percentile) were randomized to either a GH-treatment group (n = 27) or an untreated control group (n = 25) for 2 yr. To compare the GH treatment effect between subjects with SHOX-D and those with TS, a third study group, 26 patients with TS aged 4.5-11.8 yr, also received GH. Between-group comparisons of first-year and second-year height velocity, height sd score, and height gain (cm) were performed using analysis of covariance accounting for diagnosis, sex, and baseline age.The GH-treated SHOX-D group had a significantly greater first-year height velocity than the untreated control group (mean +/- se, 8.7 +/- 0.3 vs. 5.2 +/- 0.2 cm/yr; P < 0.001) and similar first-year height velocity to GH-treated subjects with TS (8.9 +/- 0.4 cm/yr; P = 0.592). GH-treated subjects also had significantly greater second-year height velocity (7.3 +/- 0.2 vs. 5.4 +/- 0.2 cm/yr; P < 0.001), second-year height sd score (-2.1 +/- 0.2 vs.-3.0 +/- 0.2; P < 0.001) and second-year height gain (16.4 +/- 0.4 vs. 10.5 +/- 0.4 cm; P < 0.001) than untreated subjects.
LLM_1: The SHOX gene, located on the distal ends of the X and Y chromosomes, encodes a transcription factor essential for long-bone growth. Mutations or deletions in SHOX¡ªincluding in Turner syndrome (TS) with SHOX haploinsufficiency¡ªlead to growth impairment and skeletal anomalies. This study assessed GH efficacy in treating short stature due to SHOX deficiency (SHOX-D). Fifty-two prepubertal subjects with molecularly confirmed SHOX-D were randomized to GH treatment (n=27) or an untreated control (n=25) for two years; a third group of 26 TS patients also received GH. Compared to controls, the GH-treated SHOX-D group showed significantly greater first-year height velocity (8.7¡À0.3 vs. 5.2¡À0.2 cm/yr; P<0.001), similar to GH-treated TS subjects (8.9¡À0.4 cm/yr; P=0.592). After two years, GH treatment also yielded significantly greater height velocity, height SD score, and height gain versus controls (all P<0.001).
LLM_2: The SHOX gene, situated at the distal regions of the X and Y chromosomes, encodes a transcription factor critical for longitudinal bone development. Genetic alterations in SHOX¡ªsuch as deletions or mutations, including the haploinsufficiency observed in Turner syndrome (TS)¡ªresult in growth retardation and skeletal abnormalities. This investigation evaluated the effectiveness of growth hormone (GH) therapy in addressing short stature associated with SHOX deficiency (SHOX-D). A cohort of 52 prepubertal participants with genetically confirmed SHOX-D was randomly assigned to either a GH treatment group (n=27) or an untreated control group (n=25) over a two-year period; an additional group of 26 TS patients also received GH therapy. Relative to controls, the GH-treated SHOX-D group demonstrated a significantly increased height velocity during the first year (8.7¡À0.3 vs. 5.2¡À0.2 cm/year; P<0.001), a response comparable to that observed in GH-treated TS subjects (8.9¡À0.4 cm/year; P=0.592). After two years, GH administration was associated with significantly greater improvements in height velocity, height standard deviation score, and total height gain compared to the control group (all P<0.001).

human:
Useful thermal imaging dataset that can enable deployment of long-term solutions robust to concept drift

- Introduces and makes available a long-term thermal dataset for investigating gradual concept drift. The dataset also includes additional metadata (timestamp and weather) that may be useful for a variety of associated tasks.
- Analysis of the causal relationship and correlations between the environment and performance.
- Performance of recent methods has been studied (Sec. 4.3) and analysis of performance compared with environmental variables (Sec. 5) is also analyzed.

Strengths:
- Makes a long-term public thermal dataset accessible for the community. Thermal imaging datasets enable personal data to be protected without requiring extensive post-processing, unlike RGB datasets. Hence, this dataset can comply with GDPR.
- Large dataset almost twice the size of the other available thermal datasets (Table 1).
- Metadata analysis is well-motivated in light of the application niche of the dataset.
- Recent deep methods have been used for the baseline experiments and the experiments are appropriately motivated.
- The drift analysis of the performance of methods compared with environmental factors is sufficient.

Weaknesses:
- Description of prior art seems to deliberately exclude Domain Adaptation works. DA, especially for applications in autonomous driving deal with season shifts and relevant 'concept' shifts such as time-of-day and day-to-night and widely different scenario shifts and methods, have performed well for detection and pixel-level labeling tasks. They also use real-world data such as [1] and [2]. Authors should address why and how these datasets are/are not relevant to the seasonal shifts discussed.
- Similarly, [1] and [3] also include additional metadata such as geographic location and scenes of the same location captured at various time/seasonal intervals. This enables datasets to be balanced, whereas capturing long-term videos with concept shifts at very few time intervals may lead to imbalanced datasets that may not generalize well to different geographical locations. These are relevant to be discussed here especially in light of why and what metadata is useful for concept shift identification.

References:  
[1] Sakaridis, C., Dai, D. and Van Gool, L., 2021. ACDC: The Adverse Conditions Dataset with Correspondences for Semantic Driving Scene Understanding. arXiv preprint arXiv:2104.13395.  

[2] Yu, F., Chen, H., Wang, X., Xian, W., Chen, Y., Liu, F., Madhavan, V. and Darrell, T., 2020. Bdd100k: A diverse driving dataset for heterogeneous multitask learning. In Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF conference on computer vision and pattern recognition (pp. 2636-2645).  

[3] Sakaridis, C., Dai, D. and Gool, L.V., 2019. Guided curriculum model adaptation and uncertainty-aware evaluation for semantic nighttime image segmentation. In Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision (pp. 7374-7383).

Correctness: Yes, the submission is a dataset constructed in a manner useful for the machine learning community. The evaluation methods and experiments are appropriate. The dataset and the code to reproduce the experiments were shared.
Clarity: Yes, the paper is clear and well written.
Relation to prior work: Please refer to the Weaknesses section. Relation to prior work could include more discussions on datasets and methods that deal with similar niche outcomes albeit for a different use case (DA methods for example).
Documentation: There is sufficient detail on the dataset and how the dataset was collected. The paper includes documentation and intended uses cases for the dataset. The dataset is uploaded on Kaggle.
Ethics: There seem to be no ethical concerns that warrant further discussions. However, the wordings in L:106-108 are generic and may need further review. The highlighted words in: "However, thermal imagining **generally makes it easier** for personal data to be protected and **reduces the requirement** for additional post-processing to ensure person anonymity, which is a crucial requirement for complying with the European general data protection regulations (GDPR)." The explanation in Checklist 1(d) is seemingly enough.
Additional feedback: L:106 imagining -> imaging
LLM_1:
This work introduces a valuable long-term thermal imaging dataset for studying gradual concept drift, accompanied by timestamp and weather metadata. It analyzes causal relationships and correlations between environmental conditions and model performance, evaluating recent methods (Sec. 4.3) and comparing performance with environmental variables (Sec. 5).

Strengths:
- Provides a public long-term thermal dataset that supports GDPR compliance by protecting personal data without extensive post-processing.
- The dataset is nearly twice as large as other available thermal datasets (Table 1).
- Metadata analysis is well-motivated given the dataset¡¯s application niche.
- Baseline experiments use recent deep learning methods and are appropriately motivated.
- Drift analysis relating performance to environmental factors is sufficient.

Weaknesses:
- Prior art discussion appears to deliberately exclude Domain Adaptation (DA) works. DA methods for autonomous driving address season shifts, time-of-day/day-to-night changes, and diverse scenario shifts, performing well on detection and pixel-level labeling tasks using real-world data such as [1,2]. Authors should clarify why these datasets are not considered relevant to the seasonal shifts discussed.
- Datasets like [1,3] include metadata such as geographic location and scenes captured across time/seasonal intervals, enabling balanced datasets. This paper presents a long-term thermal imaging dataset designed to study gradual concept drift, accompanied by timestamp and weather metadata. The authors analyze causal relationships and correlations between environmental conditions and model performance, evaluate recent methods (Sec. 4.3), and compare performance with environmental variables (Sec. 5).

**Strengths**  
- The dataset is publicly released and supports GDPR compliance by protecting personal data without extensive post-processing.  
- It is nearly twice as large as other available thermal datasets (Table 1).

- Baseline experiments appropriately use recent deep learning methods.  
- The drift analysis relating performance to environmental factors is sufficient.

**Weaknesses**  
- The related work section appears to deliberately exclude Domain Adaptation (DA) methods. DA approaches for autonomous driving address season shifts, time-of-day/day-to-night changes, and diverse scenario shifts, and have shown strong performance on detection and pixel-level labeling tasks using real-world data (e.g., [1,2]). The authors should clarify why these datasets and methods are not considered relevant to the seasonal shifts discussed.

In contrast, long-term video capture at sparse intervals may yield imbalanced data with limited generalization across locations. The relevance of this point should be discussed, particularly regarding which metadata aids concept shift identification.

This paper studies partially observable extensive games with perfect recall. They propose a computationally efficient model-free algorithm with $\sqrt{T}$-regret. The algorithm works by reducing the tree-structured game to a linear bandits problem and then applying some variant of EXP-IX (similar to Jin et al., 2020) to solve it.

This paper is well-written and easy to follow. The new algorithm looks computationally efficient and has regret guarantee matching the best known result. Moreover, it can also play favourably against adversarial components.

Is the conversion to online linear bandits first proposed in this work? If not, maybe it would be better to point this out explicitly in section 3.1. Besides, the algorithm designed in this paper bears much similarity to Jin et al., 2020. I feel it¡¯s worthwhile to point it out in the paper.

Could you provide a direct comparison between this paper and Lanctot et al. (2009); Farina et al. (2020) in terms of computational complexity? I believe this comparison is necessary especially when these works have the same regret.

How do you compare this work to [1]? I think it would be interesting to compare the two settings studied in this paper and [1]. Which setting is more general or practical?

Overall this is an interesting paper making reasonable contributions.

[1] A Sharp Analysis of Model-based Reinforcement Learning with Self-Play. Qinghua Liu, Tiancheng Yu, Yu Bai, Chi Jin. ICML 2021
LLM_1:
This paper studies partially observable extensive games with perfect recall, proposing a computationally efficient model-free algorithm with $\sqrt{T}$-regret. The method reduces the tree-structured game to a linear bandits problem and applies a variant of EXP-IX (similar to Jin et al., 2020). The paper is clear and well-written, and the algorithm is computationally efficient with a regret guarantee matching the best known result, while also handling adversarial components.

A few suggestions could strengthen the presentation:  
- If the conversion to online linear bandits is not novel, this should be explicitly noted in Section 3.1.  
- The similarity to Jin et al., 2020 deserves mention.  
- A direct computational complexity comparison with Lanctot et al. (2009) and Farina et al. (2020) would be valuable, given their matching regret bounds.

Overall, this is an interesting paper with reasonable contributions.
LLM_2:
This paper introduces a computationally efficient model-free algorithm for partially observable extensive-form games with perfect recall, achieving $\sqrt{T}$-regret. The approach reduces the tree-structured game to a linear bandits problem and employs a variant of EXP-IX (akin to Jin et al., 2020). The paper is clearly written, and the algorithm is computationally efficient, matching the best known regret guarantees while accommodating adversarial components.

**Strengths**  
- The algorithm is computationally efficient and achieves regret bounds consistent with state-of-the-art results.  
- The reduction to linear bandits is elegantly presented, and the handling of adversarial settings is a notable contribution.  
- The paper is well-structured and accessible.

**Suggestions for Improvement**  
1. **Clarity on novelty**: If the reduction to online linear bandits is not entirely novel, this should be explicitly acknowledged in Section 3.1.  
2. **Related work**: The similarity to Jin et al. (2020) deserves a more direct discussion, particularly regarding algorithmic adaptations.  
3. **Computational comparison**: A direct comparison of computational complexity with Lanctot et al. (2009) and Farina et al. (2020)¡ªboth of which achieve matching regret bounds¡ªwould strengthen the evaluation.  
4. **Generality and practicality**: Comparing the setting with Liu et al. (ICML 2021) in terms of generality and practical applicability would provide useful context.

**Overall Assessment**  
This is an interesting paper with solid contributions. Addressing the above points would enhance its clarity and positioning within the literature.

human:
The authors present a new method for doing reverse curriculum training for reinforcement learning tasks with deterministic dynamics, a desired goal state at which reward is received, and the ability to teleport to any state. This covers a number of important cases of interest, including all simulated domains, and a number of robotics applications. The training proceeds in phases, where in each phase the initial starting set of states is expanded. The initial set of states used is close to the desired state goal. Each phase is initiated when 80% of the states in the current phase can reach the goal. Once the initial set of start states overlaps with the desired initial set of states for the task, training can terminate. During the training in a single phase, the algorithm uses a shaping reward (the tendency) which is based on a binary classifier that predicts if it will be possible to reach the goal from this state. This reward is combined in a hybrid reward signal. The authors suggest the use of a small number of checkpoints to guide the backwards state expansion to improve the search efficiency. Results are presented on several domains: maze, Super Mario, and Mujoco domains.

The topic of doing more sample efficient training is important and interesting, and the subset of settings the authors consider is still a good set.

The paper was clearly written though some details were relegated to the appendix which would¡¯ve been useful to see in the main text.

I¡¯m not yet convinced about this method for the desired setting in terms of significance and quality.

An alternative to using tendency shaping reward would be (during phase expansion) make the new ¡°goal¡± states any of the states in the previous phase of initial states P_{i} that did reach the goal. This should greatly reduce the decision making horizon needed in each  phase. Since the domain is deterministic, as soon as one can reach one of those states, we have a path to the goal. If we care about the number of steps to reach the goal (vs finding any path), then each of the states in P_{i} for which a successful path can be achieved to the goal can also be labeled by the cost / number of time steps to reach the goal. This should decompose the problem into a series of smaller problems. Perhaps I¡¯m missing something-- could the authors please address this suggestion and/or explain why this wouldn¡¯t be beneficial?

The authors currently use checkpoints to help guide the search towards the true task desired set of initial states. If those are lacking, it seems like the generation of the new P_{i+1} could be biased towards that desired set of states. One approach could be to randomly roll out from the start state and then bias P_{i+1} towards any states close to states along such trajectories. In general one could imagine a situation in which one both does forward learning/planning from the task start state and backwards learning from the goal state to obtain a significant benefit, similar to ideas that have been used in robot motion planning.

Why learn from pixels for the robot domains considered? Here it would be nice to compare to some robotics approaches. With the action space of the robot and motion planning, it seems like this problem could be tackled using existing techniques. It is interesting to have a method that can be used with pixels, but in cases where there are other approaches, it would be useful to compare to them.

Small point
D.2 Why not compare to GAIL instead?
LLM_1:
This paper introduces a reverse curriculum training method for reinforcement learning in deterministic environments with a goal state and state teleportation, applicable to simulated and some robotics domains. Training proceeds in phases, expanding the initial state set from near the goal until it overlaps with the task¡¯s desired start states. Each phase begins once 80% of its states can reach the goal. Within a phase, a hybrid reward incorporates a shaping term ("tendency") from a classifier predicting goal reachability. Checkpoints are suggested to guide backward expansion for efficiency. Experiments are shown on maze, Super Mario, and MuJoCo domains.

The topic is important, and the chosen settings are relevant. The writing is clear, though some details in the appendix would benefit the main text. I remain uncertain about the method¡¯s significance and quality for the intended setting.

**Major comments:**

1. **Alternative to tendency shaping:** During phase expansion, making the new ¡°goal¡± states any states from the previous phase that reached the goal could shorten the decision horizon per phase. In deterministic settings, reaching one such state provides a path to the goal. If minimizing steps matters, labeling these states by cost could decompose the problem. Please address why this might not be beneficial.

2. **Checkpoints and bias:** Without checkpoints, generating the new state set could be biased toward the desired initial states¡ªe.g., by rolling out from the start state and biasing toward nearby states. Combining forward planning from the start with backward learning from the goal may offer benefits, akin to bidirectional motion planning.

3. **Pixel-based learning in robotics:** For the robot domains, why learn from pixels? Comparisons to existing robotics or motion planning approaches would be valuable to contextualize the contribution.

**Minor point:** In D.2, why not compare to GAIL?

Overall, while the method is interesting, its advantages over alternatives need clearer justification.
LLM_2:
This paper proposes a reverse curriculum training approach for reinforcement learning in deterministic environments with goal states and state teleportation, applicable to simulated and selected robotic domains. The method trains in phases, progressively expanding the initial state set from regions near the goal until it overlaps with the task¡¯s desired starting states. Each phase begins once 80% of its states can reach the goal, using a hybrid reward that includes a shaping term (¡°tendency¡±) derived from a classifier predicting goal reachability. Checkpoints are introduced to guide efficient backward expansion. Experiments are conducted in maze, Super Mario, and MuJoCo domains.

The topic is timely, and the experimental settings are well-chosen. The writing is generally clear, though certain details currently in the appendix would strengthen the main text. However, the paper¡¯s core contributions¡ªspecifically, the significance and effectiveness of the proposed method within its intended scope¡ªremain unclear and require further justification.

**Major Comments:**

1. **Alternative to tendency shaping:** During phase expansion, designating the new ¡°goal¡± states as those from the previous phase that successfully reached the goal could reduce the decision horizon per phase. In deterministic environments, reaching any such state inherently provides a path to the final goal. If minimizing step count is important, labeling these states by cost could further decompose the problem. Please discuss why this alternative may not be beneficial compared to the proposed approach.

2. **Checkpoints and potential bias:** Without checkpoints, generating the new state set may unintentionally bias sampling toward the desired initial states¡ªfor example, by rolling out trajectories from the start state and favoring nearby states. Combining forward planning from the start with backward learning from the goal could offer advantages, similar to bidirectional motion planning strategies. The authors should address whether such integration was considered and how checkpoints mitigate or interact with this bias.

3. **Pixel-based learning in robotics:** For the robotic domains, the rationale for learning directly from pixels should be clarified. Comparisons to established robotics or motion planning methods would help contextualize the contribution and demonstrate the added value of the proposed approach in these settings.

**Minor Comment:**

- In Appendix D.2, please include a comparison with Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning (GAIL) to better situate the method within related work.

**Overall Assessment:**  
While the idea is interesting, the advantages of the proposed method over existing alternatives need clearer and more compelling justification. Strengthening the comparative analysis and methodological rationale would significantly enhance the paper¡¯s contribution.

The effect of subclinical thyroid disease on very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) kinetics is not known.Our objective was to investigate whether subclinical thyroid disease is associated with alterations in hepatic VLDL metabolism. DESIGN AND OUTCOMES: We measured VLDL-TG and VLDL-apolipoprotein B-100 (apoB-100) kinetics by infusing stable isotopically labeled tracers, in conjunction with mathematical modeling.Ten women with subclinical hypothyroidism, 10 women with subclinical hyperthyroidism, and 25 euthyroid women, matched on age, body mass index, and percent body fat, were studied in the Clinical Research Unit at Washington University School of Medicine.Plasma VLDL-TG concentrations were 0.75¡À0.13, 0.51¡À0.06, and 0.37¡À0.07 mmol/liter (P=0.029), and hepatic VLDL-TG secretion rates were 6.5¡À0.7, 5.0¡À0.4, and 4.1¡À0.6 ¦Ìmol/liter¡¤min (P=0.026) in hypothyroid, euthyroid, and hyperthyroid women, respectively. The differences in VLDL-TG secretion rates were due to differences in the incorporation of systemic plasma free fatty acids into VLDL-TG (4.3¡À0.3, 3.1¡À0.3, and 2.5¡À0.3 ¦Ìmol/liter¡¤min in hypothyroid, euthyroid, and hyperthyroid women, respectively; P=0.005). Plasma VLDL-apoB-100 concentration and hepatic secretion rate did not differ among groups (P>0.400), so the molar ratios of VLDL-TG to VLDL-apoB-100 secretion rates were 21,469¡À3,477, 16,025¡À1,273, and 11,889¡À1,319 in hypothyroid, euthyroid, and hyperthyroid women, respectively (P=0.019).
LLM_1: Clinically overt thyroid dysfunction alters triglyceride (TG) metabolism, but the impact of subclinical thyroid disease on very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) kinetics is unclear. This study investigated whether subclinical thyroid dysfunction affects hepatic VLDL metabolism. Using stable isotope tracers and mathematical modeling, VLDL-TG and VLDL-apolipoprotein B-100 (apoB-100) kinetics were measured in 10 women with subclinical hypothyroidism, 10 with subclinical hyperthyroidism, and 25 euthyroid women matched for age, body mass index, and body fat percentage. Plasma VLDL-TG concentrations and hepatic secretion rates were higher in hypothyroid women (0.75¡À0.13 mmol/liter and 6.5¡À0.7 ¦Ìmol/liter¡¤min) compared to euthyroid (0.51¡À0.06 mmol/liter and 5.0¡À0.4 ¦Ìmol/liter¡¤min) and hyperthyroid women (0.37¡À0.07 mmol/liter and 4.1¡À0.6 ¦Ìmol/liter¡¤min), with significant group differences (P=0.029 and P=0.026, respectively). These differences were driven by variations in systemic free fatty acid incorporation into VLDL-TG (P=0.005). Plasma VLDL-apoB-100 concentration and secretion did not differ among groups (P>0.400), leading to higher molar ratios of VLDL-TG to VLDL-apoB-100 secretion rates in hypothyroid women (21,469¡À3,477) versus euthyroid (16,025¡À1,273) and hyperthyroid women (11,889¡À1,319; P=0.019).
LLM_2: While clinically apparent thyroid dysfunction is known to influence triglyceride (TG) metabolism, the effects of subclinical thyroid disorders on very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) kinetics remain poorly characterized. This study examined the impact of subclinical thyroid dysfunction on hepatic VLDL metabolism. Using stable isotope tracer methodology combined with mathematical modeling, VLDL-TG and VLDL-apolipoprotein B-100 (apoB-100) kinetics were assessed in 10 women with subclinical hypothyroidism, 10 with subclinical hyperthyroidism, and 25 age-, body mass index-, and body fat percentage-matched euthyroid controls. Plasma VLDL-TG concentrations and hepatic secretion rates were elevated in the hypothyroid group (0.75 ¡À 0.13 mmol/L and 6.5 ¡À 0.7 ¦Ìmol/L¡¤min) relative to both euthyroid (0.51 ¡À 0.06 mmol/L and 5.0 ¡À 0.4 ¦Ìmol/L¡¤min) and hyperthyroid participants (0.37 ¡À 0.07 mmol/L and 4.1 ¡À 0.6 ¦Ìmol/L¡¤min), with statistically significant intergroup differences (*P* = 0.029 and *P* = 0.026, respectively). These variations were primarily attributable to differences in the systemic incorporation of free fatty acids into VLDL-TG (*P* = 0.005). In contrast, plasma VLDL-apoB-100 concentration and secretion did not differ significantly across groups (*P* > 0.400). Consequently, the molar ratio of VLDL-TG to VLDL-apoB-100 secretion rates was markedly higher in hypothyroid women (21,469 ¡À 3,477) compared to euthyroid (16,025 ¡À 1,273) and hyperthyroid individuals (11,889 ¡À 1,319; *P* = 0.019). These findings indicate that subclinical hypothyroidism is associated with altered hepatic VLDL-TG metabolism, characterized by increased secretion of TG-rich VLDL particles.

Abu Khaled al-Suri was among several people who died when a base of Ahrar al-Sham, part of the Islamic Front, was targeted on Sunday, activists said.
The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIS), a jihadist rebel group, is thought to have been responsible.
Suri was reportedly sent to Syria by al-Qaeda to end the infighting between ISIS and other rebel groups.
It is said to have left more than 2,000 people dead since early January.
Abu Khalid al-Suri was killed along with six comrades from Ahrar al-Sham in Sunday's attack, according to the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.
Two rebels told the Reuters news agency that five men had entered the rival group's headquarters in Aleppo and opened fire before one blew himself up.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but a spokesman for the Islamic Front, Akram al-Halabi, said he believed ISIS was behind it.
"The first fingers of blame point to the State," he told the Associated Press. "Unfortunately this is going to make the infighting worse."
Suri, a Syrian-born militant whose real name was Muhammad Bahaiah, is believed to have been close to the late al-Qaeda leader Osama Bin Laden and his successor Ayman al-Zawahiri.
He fought against US forces in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Rebel sources said he was sent to Syria a few months ago on a mission to mediate in the conflict between ISIS and other rebel groups, including the al-Qaeda-affiliated al-Nusra Front.
An audio recording attributed to Suri was released last month in which he said ISIS had "sought to corrupt the jihad in Syria, as it did in Iraq and Afghanistan".
He called on the group to stop attacking other jihadists, adding: "Direct your car bombs at the infidels and do not busy yourself with fighting the mujahedeen and killing them."
Earlier this month, al-Qaeda's general command insisted that it had "no connection" with ISIS and was not responsible for its actions.
ISIS grew out of the former Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), a jihadist militant umbrella group that included al-Qaeda in Iraq. It is believed to have helped create the al-Nusra Front in mid-2011.
In April 2013, ISI leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi announced the merger of his group and al-Nusra - effectively a takeover - and the creation of the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIS).
But the move was rejected by al-Nusra leader Abu Mohammed al-Julani and Zawahiri, al-Qaeda's overall leader, who recognised al-Nusra as its sole Syrian offshoot.
Since then, ISIS and al-Nusra have operated as separate entities, with the latter focusing on toppling President Bashar al-Assad and maintaining better relations with other rebels. ISIS has seemed to be more concerned by territorial gains and implementing its extreme interpretation of Islamic law.
Also on Sunday, several people were reported killed by a car bomb near a field hospital in northern Syria, close to the border with Turkey.
Activists said the blast happened in the rebel-held town of Atmeh, which hosts a camp for thousands of people displaced by Syria's civil war.
It was not immediately clear who had carried out that attack.
According to UN figures, 6.5 million Syrians have been displaced by the country's civil war, and 2.5 million are registered as refugees. Lebanon has taken the highest number of refugees, followed by Jordan and Turkey.

human: A particular criticism of the Buddha was Vedic animal sacrifice.[web 18] He also mocked the Vedic "hymn of the cosmic man". However, the Buddha was not anti-Vedic, and declared that the Veda in its true form was declared by "Kashyapa" to certain rishis, who by severe penances had acquired the power to see by divine eyes. He names the Vedic rishis, and declared that the original Veda of the rishis[note 25] was altered by a few Brahmins who introduced animal sacrifices. The Buddha says that it was on this alteration of the true Veda that he refused to pay respect to the Vedas of his time. LLM_2:
# The Buddha's Critique of Vedic Rituals and the Evolution of Early Hinduism

In a striking departure from the religious norms of his time, the Buddha openly criticized the practice of animal sacrifice in Vedic tradition and dismissed the celebrated "hymn of the cosmic man" as misguided. However, scholars note that his stance was not a blanket rejection of Vedic thought. Instead, he distinguished between what he saw as a corrupted contemporary Veda and its purer origins.

According to early Buddhist teachings, the true Veda was originally revealed by the sage Kashyapa to a group of seers¡ªknown as rishis¡ªwho attained profound spiritual insight through rigorous penance. The Buddha named these Vedic sages and maintained that their teachings had later been distorted by Brahmin priests, who introduced rituals involving animal sacrifice. It was this alteration, he explained, that led him to withhold respect from the Vedas as they were practiced in his day.

Notably, the Buddha did not reject core Vedic concepts such as the union with Brahman¡ªthe ultimate reality¡ªor the idea of the individual self merging with the universal Self. His critique was directed specifically at ritual practices he viewed as degenerate, not at the underlying spiritual framework.

During this same period, what is now termed traditional Hinduism was itself undergoing significant transformation, gradually developing into the early forms of Hindu practice and philosophy that would shape the religious landscape of ancient India.

human: Mitochondrial dysfunction has been suggested as a contributing factor to the pathogenesis of sepsis-induced multiple organ failure. Also, restoration of mitochondrial function, known as mitochondrial biogenesis, has been implicated as a key factor for the recovery of organ function in patients with sepsis. Here we investigated temporal changes in platelet mitochondrial respiratory function in patients with sepsis during the first week after disease onset.Platelets were isolated from blood samples taken from 18 patients with severe sepsis or septic shock within 48 hours of their admission to the intensive care unit. Subsequent samples were taken on Day 3 to 4 and Day 6 to 7. Eighteen healthy blood donors served as controls. Platelet mitochondrial function was analyzed by high-resolution respirometry. Endogenous respiration of viable, intact platelets suspended in their own plasma or phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) glucose was determined. Further, in order to investigate the role of different dehydrogenases and respiratory complexes as well as to evaluate maximal respiratory activity of the mitochondria, platelets were permeabilized and stimulated with complex-specific substrates and inhibitors.Platelets suspended in their own septic plasma exhibited increased basal non-phosphorylating respiration (state 4) compared to controls and to platelets suspended in PBS glucose. In parallel, there was a substantial increase in respiratory capacity of the electron transfer system from Day 1 to 2 to Day 6 to 7 as well as compared to controls in both intact and permeabilized platelets oxidizing Complex I and/or II-linked substrates. No inhibition of respiratory complexes was detected in septic patients compared to controls. Non-survivors, at 90 days, had a more elevated respiratory capacity at Day 6 to 7 as compared to survivors. Cytochrome c increased over the time interval studied but no change in mitochondrial DNA was detected.
LLM_1:
Mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to sepsis-induced multiple organ failure, while mitochondrial biogenesis aids recovery. This study examined temporal changes in platelet mitochondrial respiration during the first week of sepsis. Platelets were isolated from 18 severe sepsis or septic shock patients at admission, day 3¨C4, and day 6¨C7, with 18 healthy controls. High-resolution respirometry assessed mitochondrial function in intact platelets (in septic plasma or PBS-glucose) and permeabilized platelets stimulated with complex-specific substrates and inhibitors.

Platelets in septic plasma showed elevated basal non-phosphorylating respiration versus controls and PBS-glucose suspensions. Respiratory capacity increased from day 1¨C2 to day 6¨C7 and exceeded controls in both intact and permeabilized platelets oxidizing Complex I/II-linked substrates, with no respiratory complex inhibition. Non-survivors at 90 days exhibited higher respiratory capacity at day 6¨C7 than survivors. Cytochrome c rose over time, but mitochondrial DNA remained unchanged.
LLM_2:
Mitochondrial impairment is a recognized contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple organ failure in sepsis, whereas mitochondrial biogenesis supports clinical recovery. This study investigates the longitudinal dynamics of platelet mitochondrial respiratory function during the initial week following sepsis onset. Platelets were isolated from 18 patients with severe sepsis or septic shock at three time points: hospital admission (day 1¨C2), day 3¨C4, and day 6¨C7. A cohort of 18 healthy individuals served as controls. High-resolution respirometry was employed to evaluate mitochondrial function under two conditions: in intact platelets suspended either in autologous septic plasma or in a phosphate?buffered saline?glucose solution, and in permeabilized platelets following stimulation with respiratory complex?specific substrates and inhibitors.

Platelets incubated in septic plasma demonstrated significantly elevated basal non?phosphorylating respiration compared both to healthy controls and to platelets suspended in PBS?glucose. Total respiratory capacity increased progressively from day 1¨C2 to day 6¨C7, ultimately exceeding control levels in both intact and permeabilized platelets oxidizing Complex I? and II?linked substrates, with no evidence of inhibition at the level of individual electron transport system complexes. Notably, non?survivors at 90?day follow?up exhibited higher platelet respiratory capacity at day 6¨C7 than survivors. Cytochrome c content increased over the observation period, whereas mitochondrial DNA copy number remained stable.

These findings indicate that sepsis induces a time?dependent upregulation of platelet mitochondrial respiratory capacity, which is more pronounced in non?surviving patients, suggesting a potential role of adaptive mitochondrial responses in sepsis pathophysiology and outcomes.

BBC Cymru Fyw, the Welsh-language online news service, understands the body is currently reviewing the awards, as well as a number of other aspects of their work.
Literature Wales is responsible for managing the award, on behalf of the Welsh Arts Council.
A statement is expected before the end of the week.
Responding to news of the review, Jon Gower, winner of the award in 2012 and a judge of the English language award in 2011, said: "It would be a great shame if the awards were brought to an end since opportunities for Welsh language books are limited.
"Unfortunately the status and financial value of the award has decreased substantially over the last few years.
"I feel that what Literature Wales should be doing is being more creative when it comes to marketing books that come to the fore, and doing more to highlight the awards and those on the shortlist."
He said he understood the awards were a part of Literature Wales' business plan until 2019.
Another former judge of the competition, editor and literary critic Bethan Mair, said: "I believe the award gives status and helps increase sales of Welsh language books.
"It also increases visibility - for example on S4C's Nos Galan programme a week and a half ago they looked at Caryl Lewis' work. Winning the Book of the Year award gave her that prominence.
"There is value to the award but perhaps it's time to consider asking companies to sponsor it - this already happens with companies like Costa and Whitbread for awards in England.
"The Welsh Books Council could also take responsibility for the award - they are already responsible for the Tir na n-Og award, and do so successfully."
The Book of the Year award is given annually to works of poetry, fiction, and creative non-fiction in Welsh and English.
In the past it has been judged by two panels, one of three Welsh-language judges and one of three English-language judges, who chose a shortlist of three books in each category that are announced in May.

human: Fluid resuscitation from hemorrhagic shock is intended to abolish microcirculatory disorders and to restore adequate tissue oxygenation. Diaspirin cross-linked hemoglobin (DCLHb) is a hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier (HBOC) with vasoconstrictive properties. Therefore, fluid resuscitation from severe hemorrhagic shock using DCLHb was expected to improve perfusion pressure and tissue perfusion of kidneys and pancreas.In 20 anesthetized domestic pigs with an experimentally induced coronary stenosis, shock (mean arterial pressure 45 mmHg) was induced by controlled withdrawal of blood and maintained for 60 min. Fluid resuscitation (replacement of the plasma volume withdrawn during hemorrhage) was performed with either 10% DCLHb (DCLHb group, n = 10) or 8% human serum albumin (HSA) oncotically matched to DCLHb (HSA group, n = 10). Completion of resuscitation was followed by a 60-min observation period. Regional blood flow to the kidneys and the pancreas was measured by use of the radioactive microspheres method at baseline, after shock and 60 min after fluid resuscitation.All animals (10/10) resuscitated with DCLHb survived the 60-min observation period, while 5/10 control animals died within 20 min due to persisting subendocardial ischemia. In contrast to HSA survivors, pancreas and kidneys of DCLHb-treated animals revealed lower total and regional organ perfusion and regional oxygen delivery. Renal and pancreatic blood flow heterogeneity was higher in the DCLHb group.
LLM_1: Fluid resuscitation in hemorrhagic shock aims to correct microcirculatory dysfunction and restore tissue oxygenation. Diaspirin cross-linked hemoglobin (DCLHb), a hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier with vasoconstrictive effects, was investigated for its potential to enhance perfusion pressure and tissue perfusion in kidneys and pancreas during resuscitation from severe hemorrhagic shock. In 20 anesthetized pigs with induced coronary stenosis, shock (mean arterial pressure 45 mmHg) was maintained for 60 minutes following controlled blood withdrawal. Resuscitation involved replacing the withdrawn plasma volume with either 10% DCLHb (n = 10) or 8% human serum albumin (HSA) matched oncotically to DCLHb (n = 10), followed by a 60-minute observation period. Regional blood flow to kidneys and pancreas was measured via radioactive microspheres at baseline, post-shock, and 60 minutes post-resuscitation. All DCLHb-treated animals survived the observation period, whereas 5 of 10 HSA-treated animals died within 20 minutes from persistent subendocardial ischemia. Compared to HSA survivors, DCLHb-treated animals exhibited lower total and regional organ perfusion and oxygen delivery in pancreas and kidneys, along with increased renal and pancreatic blood flow heterogeneity.
LLM_2: This study investigates the efficacy of diaspirin cross-linked hemoglobin (DCLHb), a hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier with vasoactive properties, in the resuscitation from severe hemorrhagic shock, with a focus on microcirculatory outcomes in renal and pancreatic tissues. In a porcine model involving 20 anesthetized subjects with induced coronary stenosis, hemorrhagic shock was induced and sustained for 60 minutes. Resuscitation was performed by isovolemic replacement of withdrawn plasma volume using either 10% DCLHb (n = 10) or 8% human serum albumin (HSA, n = 10), followed by a 60-minute observation phase. Regional blood flow in the kidneys and pancreas was quantified via radioactive microsphere technique at baseline, post-shock, and post-resuscitation time points. All animals in the DCLHb group survived the observation period, whereas 50% of the HSA-treated subjects succumbed within 20 minutes due to persistent subendocardial ischemia. Compared to surviving HSA controls, DCLHb administration was associated with significantly reduced total and regional organ perfusion and oxygen delivery to both the pancreas and kidneys. Furthermore, DCLHb treatment resulted in elevated heterogeneity of blood flow distribution within these organs. These findings suggest that, despite improving survival, DCLHb resuscitation may exacerbate microcirculatory impairment and perfusion heterogeneity in abdominal organs during hemorrhagic shock.

Detailed Comments: This paper introduces various Deep Recurrent Gaussian Process (DRGP) models based on the Sparse Spectrum Gaussian Process (SSGP) models and the Variational Sparse Spectrum Gaussian Process (VSSGP) models. This is a good paper and proposed models are very sound so I recommend for acceptance although as main weakness I can say that is very technical so it can be difficult to follow. Adding more intuitive ideas, motivation and maybe a figure for each step would be a solution. Apart from that it is a really good paper, congratulations.

Related to: RNN models and Sparse Nystrom approximation.

Strengths: Models are very sound, solutions are solid, the proposed methodology is correct and the empirical results and experiments are valid and properly done.

Weaknesses: It is too difficult to follow and it is written in an extreme technical way. More intuitions and a proper motivation both in the abstract and introduction may be put in order to make the paper easier to read and, hence, more used by researchers and data scientists.

Does this submission add value to the ICLR community? : Yes it does, the experiments show the efficiency of the proposed methods in some scenarios and are valid methodologies.

Quality:
Is this submission technically sound?: Yes it is.
Are claims well supported by theoretical analysis or experimental results?: Experimental results prove empirically the methods and appendixes show the analysis performed in a clear and elegant way.
Is this a complete piece of work or work in progress?: Complete piece of work.
Are the authors careful and honest about evaluating both the strengths and weaknesses of their work?: Yes, and I would enfatize that I have liked that some experiments are won by other methods such as GP-LSTM, they are very honest.

Clarity:
Is the submission clearly written?: Yes, but it is difficult for newcomers due to the reasons that I have stated before.
Is it well organized?: Yes it is.
Does it adequately inform the reader?: Yes it is.

Originality:
Are the tasks or methods new?: Yes, they are sound.
Is the work a novel combination of well-known techniques?: Yes it is.
Is it clear how this work differs from previous contributions?: Yes.
Is related work adequately cited?: Yes, being a strength of the paper.

Significance:
Are the results important?: I would argue that they are and are a clear alternative to consider in order to solve these problems.
Are others likely to use the ideas or build on them?: If the paper is written in a more friendly way, yes.
Does the submission address a difficult task in a better way than previous work?: Yes I think.
Does it advance the state of the art in a demonstrable way?: Yes, empirically.

Arguments for acceptance: Models are very sound, solutions are solid, the proposed methodology is correct and the empirical results and experiments are valid and properly done

Arguments against acceptance: Clarity of the paper.

Minor issues and typos:
-> (V)SS not defined before being used.
-> Abstract should be rewritten adding a motivation and focusing more on the problems being solved and less in the details of the solutions.
-> Recurrent indexes that go backwards (i) of Eq. 1. should be explained why are going backwards before being used like that. Newcomers may be confused.
-> Section 2 writing style lacks a bit of cohesion, relating the paragraphs may be a solution.
-> Q is not defined in section 3.1 paragraph 1.
-> A valid covariance function must produce a PSD matrix, put that in section 3.1. 
-> I do not see how U marginalizes in Eq. 7, kind of confused about that, I think that it should be p(y|X,U).
-> Section 3.4 statistics should be explained.

Reading thread and authors response rebuttal decision:
=================================================

I consider that the authors have perfomed a good rebuttal and reading the other messages and the authors response I also consider that my issue with clarity is solved. Hence, I upgrade my score to 7 and recommend the paper for publication.

human: There is increasing evidence that the T-cell reactivity to environmental allergens underlying expression of allergic disease in adulthood, develops initially during childhood. However, there is little information available on the kinetics of these early responses, or on the patterns of cytokine production during this period.The purpose of this study was twofold: to obtain further information on the reported differences between responses to food versus inhalant allergens during early childhood, and to ascertain the age-range over which T-cell responses to inhalant allergens become polarized towards the TH2 cytokine profile, in potentially atopic children.In vitro cytokine responses to house dust mite (HDM) and egg (OVA) were assessed by semiquantitative RT-PCR in panels of 2- and 5-year-old children and adults; lymphoproliferative responses to OVA were subjected to epitope analysis.At age 2 years IL-4/IL-5 responses to HDM grouped with positive atopic family history, and by age 5 years cytokine responses correlated strongly with individual SPT reactivity to HDM. In contrast, OVA responses were restricted to weak and transient IL-5 signals in the 2-year-old family history positive group. Lymphoproliferation assays performed in parallel indicate a log-scale greater postnatal expansion of T-cell reactivity to the inhalant allergen; preliminary epitope analysis of OVA responses indicate that the number of OVA epitopes recognised decrease during early childhood.
LLM_1: Evidence suggests that T-cell reactivity to environmental allergens, which underlies adult allergic disease, originates in childhood. However, the kinetics and cytokine profiles of these early responses remain poorly characterized. This study aimed to clarify differences between early responses to food versus inhalant allergens and to determine when T-cell responses to inhalants polarize toward a TH2 cytokine profile in potentially atopic children. Using semiquantitative RT-PCR, cytokine responses to house dust mite (HDM) and egg (OVA) were assessed in 2- and 5-year-old children and adults; lymphoproliferative responses to OVA underwent epitope analysis. At age 2, IL-4/IL-5 responses to HDM were associated with a positive atopic family history; by age 5, these responses correlated strongly with individual skin prick test reactivity to HDM. In contrast, OVA responses were limited to weak, transient IL-5 signals in 2-year-olds with a positive family history. Lymphoproliferation assays revealed a log-scale greater postnatal expansion of T-cell reactivity to inhalant allergens, and preliminary epitope analysis indicated a decrease in recognized OVA epitopes during early childhood.
LLM_2: Research indicates that T-cell reactivity to environmental allergens, a key mechanism in adult allergic disorders, is established during early childhood. Nevertheless, the developmental dynamics and cytokine patterns of these initial immune responses are not well understood. This investigation sought to delineate differences in early T-cell responses to food versus inhalant allergens and to identify the point at which responses to inhalants adopt a T-helper 2 (TH2) cytokine polarization in children with potential atopic predisposition. Cytokine responses to house dust mite (HDM) and egg ovalbumin (OVA) were evaluated using semiquantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in cohorts of children aged 2 and 5 years, alongside adults. Epitope mapping was performed on lymphoproliferative responses to OVA. At age 2, interleukin-4 (IL-4) and IL-5 responses to HDM were linked to a family history of atopy; by age 5, these responses showed a strong association with individual skin prick test reactivity to HDM. In contrast, responses to OVA were restricted to weak, transient IL-5 production in 2-year-old children with a familial atopic history. Lymphoproliferation assays demonstrated a postnatal expansion of T-cell reactivity to inhalant allergens that exceeded responses to food allergens by an order of magnitude. Preliminary epitope analysis further suggested a reduction in the number of recognized OVA epitopes over early childhood.

human: Immune suppression in the tumour microenvironment remains a major limitation to successful immunotherapy of cancer. In the current study, we analysed whether the natural killer T cell-activating glycolipid ¦Á-galactosylceramide could overcome immune suppression and improve vaccination against metastatic breast cancer.Mice with metastatic breast cancer (4T1 model) were therapeutically treated with a Listeria monocytogenes-based vaccine expressing tumour-associated antigen Mage-b followed by ¦Á-galactosylceramide as separate agents, or as a complex of ¦Á-galactosylceramide stably incorporated into Listeria-Mage-b. Effects on metastases, tumour weight, toxicity and immune responses were determined.Sequential treatments of mice with established 4T1 breast carcinomas using Listeria-Mage-b followed by ¦Á-galactosylceramide as a separate agent was highly effective at reducing metastases, but was accompanied by severe liver toxicity. In contrast, combined therapy using Listeria-Mage-b modified by incorporation of ¦Á-galactosylceramide resulted in nearly complete elimination of metastases without toxicity. This was associated with a significant increase in the percentage of natural killer T cells in the spleen, and an increase in natural killer cell activity and in T cell responses to Mage-b.
LLM_1: Immune suppression in the tumor microenvironment limits cancer immunotherapy efficacy. This study investigated whether ¦Á-galactosylceramide, a natural killer T cell-activating glycolipid, could overcome immune suppression and enhance vaccination against metastatic breast cancer. In a murine 4T1 metastatic breast cancer model, therapeutic treatment involved a *Listeria monocytogenes*-based vaccine expressing tumor antigen Mage-b followed by ¦Á-galactosylceramide as separate agents, or as a complex with ¦Á-galactosylceramide incorporated into the vaccine. Outcomes included metastasis reduction, tumor weight, toxicity, and immune responses. Sequential treatment with separate agents significantly reduced metastases but caused severe liver toxicity. In contrast, the combined Listeria-Mage-b¨C¦Á-galactosylceramide complex nearly eliminated metastases without toxicity, correlating with increased splenic natural killer T cells, enhanced natural killer cell activity, and elevated T cell responses to Mage-b.
LLM_2: Immunosuppression within the tumor microenvironment represents a significant barrier to the effectiveness of cancer immunotherapies. This study examines the potential of ¦Á-galactosylceramide (¦Á-GalCer), a glycolipid activator of natural killer T (NKT) cells, to counteract such immunosuppression and augment vaccine efficacy against metastatic breast cancer. Using a murine 4T1 metastatic breast cancer model, therapeutic strategies were evaluated: a sequential regimen of a *Listeria monocytogenes*-based vaccine expressing the tumor antigen Mage-b followed by separate administration of ¦Á-GalCer, and an integrated approach in which ¦Á-GalCer was complexed directly with the Listeria-Mage-b vaccine. Outcomes assessed included metastatic burden, primary tumor weight, treatment-related toxicity, and antitumor immune responses. While sequential administration of the separate agents markedly reduced metastases, it induced severe hepatic toxicity. In contrast, the Listeria-Mage-b¨C¦Á-GalCer complex nearly abolished metastatic dissemination without observable toxicity. This enhanced therapeutic effect was associated with an expansion of splenic NKT cells, heightened natural killer cell cytotoxicity, and potentiated Mage-b-specific T cell responses. These findings demonstrate that co-delivery of ¦Á-GalCer within a bacterial vaccine vector can effectively overcome immune suppression, yielding robust antitumor immunity while circumventing the toxicity associated with sequential agent delivery.

human:
This paper extends the idea of invariant risk minimization (IRM) initially introduced by Arjovsky et al. (2019) to the setting of continual learning in which environments are observed sequentially rather than concurrently. This extension is implemented under a variational Bayesian and bilevel framework and the optimization is solved using a variant of the alternating direction method of multiplier (ADMM). The authors demonstrate the superiority of the proposed methods on variants of Colored MNIST. 

Pros:
+ The proposed method is a natural and practical extension of IRM and IRMG, which I believe is more applicable to many real-world scenarios. 
+ The resulting bilevel problem can be efficiently addressed using the alternating direction method of multipliers.

Concerns:
- My main concern is about the generalization theory in this continual setting. In both IRM and IRMG, the authors provide the conditions under which the OOD generalization can be guaranteed, as stated in Assumption 8 and Theorem 9 of Arjovsky et al. (2019) and in Assumption 2 and Theorem 2 of Ahuja et al. (2020). I did not see any similar theoretical guarantees in this paper. Without them, it is hard to judge whether or not the proposed method really generalizes out-of-distribution in a sequential manner. 
- I do not think the contents in Definition 1&2 are just definitions. Instead, they should be treated as propositions, or lemma or so on, because they should be supported by proofs which seem not to be provided yet. 
- The section of Continual IRM by Approximate Bayesian Inference is not friendly with readers unfamiliar with ADMM, which makes that part hard to go through. 
- No section index
LLM_1:
This paper extends invariant risk minimization (IRM) to continual learning, where environments are observed sequentially rather than concurrently. The approach is implemented within a variational Bayesian and bilevel framework, optimized via a variant of ADMM. Experiments on Colored MNIST variants demonstrate the method¡¯s superiority.

Pros:
+ A natural and practical extension of IRM/IRMG, likely more applicable to real-world scenarios.
+ The bilevel problem can be efficiently solved using ADMM.

Concerns:
- No generalization theory is provided for the continual setting, unlike the theoretical guarantees in prior IRM works. Without such analysis, it is unclear whether the method truly ensures sequential out-of-distribution generalization.
- Definitions 1 and 2 should be presented as propositions or lemmas, as they require proofs not currently given.
- The section on Continual IRM via Approximate Bayesian Inference is difficult to follow for readers unfamiliar with ADMM.
- The paper lacks section numbering.
LLM_2:
This paper proposes an extension of invariant risk minimization (IRM) to continual learning, where environments are observed sequentially rather than concurrently. The method is implemented within a variational Bayesian and bilevel framework, optimized via a variant of ADMM. Experiments on Colored MNIST variants demonstrate the method¡¯s superiority over baseline approaches.

**Strengths**  
- The extension of IRM/IRMG to continual learning is natural and practical, with potential applicability to real-world scenarios.  
- The bilevel optimization problem is efficiently solved using ADMM, which is a well-suited algorithmic choice.

**Weaknesses and Suggestions for Improvement**  
1. **Theoretical grounding**: Prior IRM works provide theoretical guarantees for out-of-distribution generalization. In contrast, this paper lacks a generalization theory for the continual setting. Without such analysis, it remains unclear whether the proposed method truly ensures sequential out-of-distribution generalization. Providing theoretical analysis or at least a discussion of this aspect would strengthen the paper significantly.  

2. **Clarity of definitions**: Definitions 1 and 2 are presented as definitions but involve non-trivial claims that require proof. It would be more appropriate to present them as propositions or lemmas, accompanied by proofs or at least proof sketches.  

3. **Accessibility of technical content**: The section on *Continual IRM via Approximate Bayesian Inference* assumes familiarity with ADMM and may be difficult to follow for readers less versed in optimization. Expanding the explanation or adding a brief intuitive overview would improve readability.  

4. **Structural clarity**: The paper currently lacks section numbering, which makes navigation and referencing less straightforward. Adding section numbers would improve the organization and readability of the manuscript.

**Overall Recommendation**  
The paper presents a promising and well-motivated extension of IRM to continual learning, with a sensible algorithmic approach and encouraging empirical results. However, the lack of theoretical analysis and certain presentational issues detract from its current impact. Addressing the concerns above¡ªparticularly regarding theoretical grounding and clarity¡ªwould make the paper more complete and accessible to the broader machine learning community.

`` Sir, we have found a planet so toxic and in hospitable, I could not even imagine a place so hostile. However, it still appears to have sentient life. They call themselves'humans,' and seem entirely unaffected!'' 
 
 That was the infamous last message we received from FTL-179 before it disappeared. They say that from the equipment transmissions, FTL-179 descended into the planets atmosphere, never to be seen again. 
 
 `` Captain, why do you think the 179 tried to land on'Earth' despite all the warning indicators? Do you think it was brought down forcefully?'' Asked our co-pilot. 
 
 `` I do n't know. The thrust logs seem to show they descended according to standard protocol. In other words, they went down by their own will alone.'' 
 
 `` Do you think we'll ever find a hospitable place to colonize?'' 
 
 `` Maybe. You'd think planets with liquid water would be common,'' I said. 
 
 The truth is that our species has been floating in space for over twenty years now. We all lived on the mothership after our planet ran out of resources. Most of us live there anyway. I'm a full time planetary scout. I would that captaining this FTL was a decision by choice, but I ca n't live on the mothership. It's too sad. Most of our people turned to drugs and other mind altering activities. Those who did n't either had extreme mental fortitude or had already committed suicide. 
 
 On the FTL-10, there was some peace and quiet, and the occasional ray of hope that we could save our species. That rush of hope was a drug of its own, but coming down getting more and more painful. 
 
 `` Why do n't we check this'Earth' out. It's only fifty odd light years from where we are now,'' said my cartographer. 
 
 There were three crew members for each FTL in the fleet. The pilot, the co-pilot, and the cartographer, who made sure we did n't get lost in space. 
 
 `` Sure, why not.'' I said. 
 
 In a rush of light, we activated our faster than light boosters and warped into range of Earth's atmosphere. 
 
 The planet matched almost perfectly with the images that FTL-179 sent back. The planet covered in mainly yellow, and there were violent storms undulating slowly across the sky. Occasionally, a crack of lightning would even be visible to the naked eye. 
 
 The sensors indicated that the main liquid on the planet was sulfuric acid. The oceans consisted of almost purely acid and the planet only had around ten percent landmass. The atmosphere was mainly of methane and sulfur dioxide, a combination which no known life form could survive in. Except humans, of course. 
 
 Earth was mainly so valuable because it possessed lots of rare metals that the mothership needed for repair. 
 
 `` What if we went down?'' 
 
 My cartographer and my co-pilot shot me a look of bewilderment. 
 
 I qualified my statement. `` Look, our ship can handle the atmosphere perfectly fine. What if we did a flyover to get a closer look?'' 
 
 `` Do you have a death wish?'' The cartographer asked. 
 
 `` No, but the way I see it, we're all dead anyway in five years when the mothership breaks down for good. Also, the humans ca n't be a very advanced society, considering the elements they have to weather on a daily basis.'' 
 
 `` This is probably exactly what the crew of FTL-179 thought before disappearing,'' my co-pilot reasoned. 
 
 `` That was seven years ago. Things are getting desperate now. Just a flyover, it'll take under ten minutes.'' 
 
 
 My co-pilot sighed and nodded. The cartographer went to ready the ship's ammunition, which had n't been used in the better part of a year. You can never be too prepared. 
 
 We activated our thrusters and prepared to dive into the atmosphere for a flyover. 
 
 The air around us began turning red. This was standard anytime you enter the atmosphere of a planet. We could feel a slight temperature increase from our seats, just from the heat radiating through the windshield. 
 
 `` Activate brakes and stabilize in three, two, one!'' 
 
 Our ship pulled back into a stable position, flying parallel to the surface of the planet. We were 35,000 feet in the air. We looked down. 
 
 It was paradise. 
 
 There was liquid water as far as the eye could see. There was no yellow ocean. No violent storms hurling corrosive acid around in the air. Just over the horizon looked to be a huge city, littered with skyscrapers. There were a few boats coasting in the water underneath. 
 
 We did n't say anything for a few minutes. 
 
 Finally I broke the silence. 
 
 `` This is beautiful.'' 
 
 `` We should relay this back to headquarters,'' our cartographer said. 
 
 `` Great idea.'' 
 
 Just as I picked up the broadcaster, our ship was rocked by a huge blunt force from our right. 
 
 `` Thruster down! Thruster down! Warm up the FTL booster now!'' 
 
 Before we could even say another word, we were hit by another blow from the left. No thrusters left. Our FTL booster was destroyed. The windshield shattered and my co-pilot was bleeding from his shoulder profusely as he laid unconscious in his seat. 
 
 About ten seconds later, we hit the water. 
 
 -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - 
 
 `` It's been seven years since this last happened.'' 
 
 I woke up in a dimly lit room. I sat across from two humans, dressed in a black garment. They had a voice box clipped near their throat to translate their language into one I could understand. They looked serious. 
 
 `` We'll let you live if you promise to cooperate.'' 
 
 I nodded. 
 
 `` Fifty years ago, we developed technology to fool alien sensors about the state of our planet. We did n't want to get involved in some inter-planetary war. Most aliens steer clear of us. But sometimes a ship will get too curious and fly too close. That's when we have to shoot them down. You have two options. You can run, or you can live peacefully here on Earth and teach us what you know. Just a tip: the former will get you killed.'' 
 
 In one hand was the chance to save my species, and in the other was paradise. The paradise that eluded me for twenty years. 
 
 I might go to hell for my choice. But I was weary and exhausted. I just wanted to lie down on a real bed, eat a real meal, and feel the smooth embrace of being immersed in water again. Imagine swimming in that ocean. Sweet, sweet water. 
 
 `` Good choice,'' the lieutenant said. `` Marco here will show you the way to your living quarters.'' 
 
 
 Note: Typed on a phone, so apologies for any weird grammar errors or misspellings!

LLM_2:
¡°Sir, we¡¯ve found a world so hostile it shouldn¡¯t exist¡ªand yet, it¡¯s alive. They call themselves ¡®humans.¡¯ They breathe poison like it¡¯s air.¡±

That was the last whisper from the *FTL?179* before it dissolved into silence. The logs show it descended, willingly, into the toxic shroud of the planet below.

¡°Captain, why would they land? Were they forced down?¡± my co?pilot¡¯s voice was thin with dread.

¡°No. The thrusters tell a story of choice.¡±

¡°Will we ever find a home?¡±

¡°Maybe. The universe is wet in places,¡± I said, though I no longer believed it.

We are wanderers, ghosts living in the metal belly of a dying mothership. Twenty years adrift since our world turned to dust. I took this post not for glory, but for silence. Aboard the mothership, hope is a currency spent on narcotics or the void. Here, in the *FTL?10*, there is only the hum of engines and the cruel, flickering dream of salvation.

¡°What about this ¡®Earth¡¯?¡± our cartographer cut in. ¡°It¡¯s close. Fifty light?years¡ªa heartbeat in the dark.¡±

A crew of three: pilot, co?pilot, cartographer. I looked at their tired faces. ¡°Why not,¡± I said.

A blink, a wrench of space, and there it hung¡ªa mottled amber orb veined with storms. Sensors screamed: acid seas, choking air, death in every breath. And yet, life. Human life.

¡°They mine rare metals here,¡± the cartographer noted. ¡°Enough to patch the mothership for another decade.¡±

¡°What if we went down?¡± I heard myself say.

They stared.

¡°A flyby. Just to look.¡±

¡°You want to die?¡± the cartographer asked flatly.

¡°We¡¯re dying anyway. And look at this place¡ªhow advanced could they be?¡±

¡°That¡¯s what the *179* thought,¡± the co?pilot murmured.

¡°That was seven years ago. We¡¯re emptier now. Ten minutes. That¡¯s all.¡±

A slow nod from the co?pilot. The cartographer powered up the guns¡ªcold and unused for a year. Better armed than sorry.

We fell into the atmosphere.

The world reddened. Heat brushed the hull. ¡°Brakes now. Level off in three¡­ two¡­¡±

And then we saw.

Not acid, but water¡ªendless, gentle, blue. Not storms, but soft clouds. A city of light rose in the distance, ships tracing peaceful lines below.

We were speechless.

¡°It¡¯s¡­ beautiful,¡± I breathed.

¡°We have to tell the fleet,¡± the cartographer urged, fingers already moving toward the transmitter.

Then¡ªimpact. A shudder through the ship. Another hit. Alerts blared: thrusters gone, FTL drive dead. The viewport cracked; the co?pilot slumped, bleeding.

Ten seconds of falling.

Then the sea took us.

---

¡°Seven years since the last one.¡±

I woke in a low?lit room. Two humans in black stood before me, their words shaped by translators on their collars. Their eyes were hard.

¡°Cooperate, and you live.¡±

I nodded.

¡°Fifty years ago,¡± one began, ¡°we learned to cloak our world. To make hell look like hell, and heaven invisible. Most species stay away. The curious ones¡­ we discourage.¡± He leaned closer. ¡°You have a choice: run, and die. Or stay, and share what you know. But know this¡ªif you run, we will find you.¡±

In one hand, the fate of my species. In the other, a paradise I had only dreamed of¡ªsoft beds, real food, water that didn¡¯t kill.

I am so tired.

I thought of the ocean below, sweet and deep.

¡°Good choice,¡± the lieutenant said. ¡°Marco will show you to your room.¡±

And just like that, I traded the stars for a cage of sky.
