human: Chromosome instability manifests as an abnormal chromosome complement and is a pathogenic event in cancer. Although a correlation between abnormal chromosome numbers and cancer exist, the underlying mechanisms that cause chromosome instability are poorly understood. Recent data suggests that aberrant sister chromatid cohesion causes chromosome instability and thus contributes to the development of cancer. Cohesion normally functions by tethering nascently synthesized chromatids together to prevent premature segregation and thus chromosome instability. Although the prevalence of aberrant cohesion has been reported for some solid tumors, its prevalence within liquid tumors is unknown. Consequently, the current study was undertaken to evaluate aberrant cohesion within Hodgkin lymphoma, a lymphoid malignancy that frequently exhibits chromosome instability.Using established cytogenetic techniques, the prevalence of chromosome instability and aberrant cohesion was examined within mitotic spreads generated from five commonly employed Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines (L-1236, KM-H2, L-428, L-540 and HDLM-2) and a lymphocyte control. Indirect immunofluorescence and Western blot analyses were performed to evaluate the localization and expression of six critical proteins involved in the regulation of sister chromatid cohesion.We first confirmed that all five Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines exhibited chromosome instability relative to the lymphocyte control. We then determined that each Hodgkin lymphoma cell line exhibited cohesion defects that were subsequently classified into mild, moderate or severe categories. Surprisingly, ~50% of the mitotic spreads generated from L-540 and HDLM-2 harbored cohesion defects. To gain mechanistic insight into the underlying cause of the aberrant cohesion we examined the localization and expression of six critical proteins involved in cohesion. Although all proteins produced the expected nuclear localization pattern, striking differences in RAD21 expression was observed: RAD21 expression was lowest in L-540 and highest within HDLM-2.
LLM_1: Chromosome instability, characterized by an abnormal chromosome complement, is a significant pathogenic event in cancer. While a correlation exists between abnormal chromosome numbers and cancer, the mechanisms underlying chromosome instability remain poorly understood. Recent findings indicate that aberrant sister chromatid cohesion contributes to chromosome instability and cancer development. Cohesion normally functions to tether nascent chromatids, preventing premature segregation and instability. Although aberrant cohesion has been documented in some solid tumors, its prevalence in liquid tumors is not well established. This study aimed to investigate aberrant cohesion in Hodgkin lymphoma, a lymphoid malignancy frequently displaying chromosome instability. Using established cytogenetic techniques, we examined chromosome instability and cohesion defects in mitotic spreads from five Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines (L-1236, KM-H2, L-428, L-540, and HDLM-2) compared to a lymphocyte control. Indirect immunofluorescence and Western blot analyses assessed the localization and expression of six critical proteins involved in sister chromatid cohesion. All five Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines demonstrated chromosome instability relative to the lymphocyte control, with cohesion defects categorized as mild, moderate, or severe. Notably, approximately 50% of mitotic spreads from L-540 and HDLM-2 exhibited cohesion defects. To explore the mechanisms behind aberrant cohesion, we analyzed the localization and expression of the six proteins. Although all proteins exhibited expected nuclear localization, significant differences in RAD21 expression were observed, with the lowest levels in L-540 and the highest in HDLM-2.
LLM_2: Chromosome instability, characterized by an abnormal chromosomal complement, is a critical pathogenic event in cancer progression. Although a correlation exists between abnormal chromosome numbers and cancer, the mechanisms underlying chromosome instability remain inadequately elucidated. Recent findings suggest that aberrant sister chromatid cohesion plays a significant role in promoting both chromosome instability and cancer development. Cohesion typically functions to tether nascent chromatids, thereby preventing premature segregation and subsequent instability. While aberrant cohesion has been documented in various solid tumors, its prevalence in hematological malignancies, particularly liquid tumors, is not well established. This study aimed to investigate the presence of aberrant cohesion in Hodgkin lymphoma, a lymphoid malignancy commonly associated with chromosome instability. Utilizing established cytogenetic techniques, we assessed chromosome instability and cohesion defects in mitotic spreads from five Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines (L-1236, KM-H2, L-428, L-540, and HDLM-2) in comparison to a lymphocyte control. Indirect immunofluorescence and Western blot analyses were employed to evaluate the localization and expression of six critical proteins involved in sister chromatid cohesion. All five Hodgkin lymphoma cell lines exhibited chromosome instability relative to the lymphocyte control, with cohesion defects categorized as mild, moderate, or severe. Notably, approximately 50% of mitotic spreads from the L-540 and HDLM-2 cell lines displayed cohesion defects. To elucidate the mechanisms underlying aberrant cohesion, we analyzed the localization and expression of the six proteins. While all proteins demonstrated expected nuclear localization, significant differences in RAD21 expression were noted, with the lowest levels observed in L-540 and the highest in HDLM-2.

human: We have previously found a 28% reduction in common cold incidence with 50 mg/day vitamin E supplementation in a subgroup of the Alpha-Tocopherol Beta-Carotene Cancer Prevention (ATBC) Study cohort: older city-dwelling men (> or =65 years) who smoked only 5-14 cigarettes/day.To carry out more detailed analyses to explore the modification of vitamin E effect by age, smoking, and residential neighborhood.We examined the effect of vitamin E on common cold risk in subjects consisting of the placebo and vitamin E arms (n = 14,573) of the ATBC Study, which recruited males aged 50-69 years who smoked > or =5 cigarettes/day at the baseline. The ATBC Study was conducted in southwestern Finland in 1985-1993; the active follow-up lasted for 4.7 years (mean). We modeled common cold risk as a function of age-at-follow-up in the vitamin E arm compared with the placebo arm using linear splines in Poisson regression.In participants of 72 years or older at follow-up, the effect of vitamin E diverged. Among those smoking 5-14 cigarettes per day at baseline and living in cities, vitamin E reduced common cold risk (RR = 0.54; 95% CI 0.37-0.80), whereas among those smoking more and living away from cities, vitamin E increased common cold risk (RR = 1.58; 1.23-2.01).
LLM_1: In a previous study, we observed a 28% reduction in common cold incidence with 50 mg/day vitamin E supplementation among older city-dwelling male smokers (¡Ý65 years, 5-14 cigarettes/day) from the Alpha-Tocopherol Beta-Carotene Cancer Prevention (ATBC) Study. This analysis aimed to investigate how age, smoking habits, and residential area modify the effect of vitamin E on cold risk. We analyzed data from the placebo and vitamin E groups (n=14,573) of the ATBC Study, which included men aged 50-69 years who smoked ¡Ý5 cigarettes/day at baseline. Conducted in southwestern Finland from 1985 to 1993, the study had an average follow-up of 4.7 years. Using Poisson regression with linear splines, we modeled common cold risk as a function of age-at-follow-up in the vitamin E arm versus the placebo arm. Among participants aged 72 and older, the vitamin E effect varied: it reduced cold risk in those smoking 5-14 cigarettes/day and residing in cities (RR = 0.54; 95% CI 0.37-0.80), while it increased risk in heavier smokers living outside urban areas (RR = 1.58; 95% CI 1.23-2.01).
LLM_2: Previous research indicated a 28% reduction in the incidence of the common cold associated with 50 mg/day of vitamin E supplementation among older male smokers (¡Ý65 years, 5-14 cigarettes/day) participating in the Alpha-Tocopherol Beta-Carotene Cancer Prevention (ATBC) Study. This analysis aims to elucidate how factors such as age, smoking habits, and residential area influence the efficacy of vitamin E in mitigating cold risk. We examined data from both the placebo and vitamin E groups (n=14,573) of the ATBC Study, which encompassed men aged 50-69 years who smoked a minimum of 5 cigarettes per day at baseline. Conducted in southwestern Finland from 1985 to 1993, the study featured an average follow-up period of 4.7 years. Employing Poisson regression with linear splines, we assessed the risk of common cold as a function of age-at-follow-up, comparing the vitamin E arm to the placebo arm. Among participants aged 72 years and older, the effect of vitamin E varied significantly: it diminished cold risk for those smoking 5-14 cigarettes/day and residing in urban areas (Relative Risk [RR] = 0.54; 95% Confidence Interval [CI] 0.37-0.80), whereas it increased risk for heavier smokers living in non-urban areas (RR = 1.58; 95% CI 1.23-2.01).

human:
The ease with which the gunman boarded a packed international train with an arsenal of weapons in his backpack is prompting re-examination of what many experts see as a weak link in the fight against terrorism.
Apart from the cross-Channel Eurostars and the Spanish high-speed network, there are no systematic identity or baggage controls anywhere on the European railway system.
With the Schengen border-free arrangements in place in 26 countries, it means criminals or terrorists can use trains to move around the continent more or less undetected.
They can also transport drugs or arms. And if they choose to use those arms, as on Friday, then hundreds of people are potential victims.
New counter-terror approach needed - by Claude Moniquet
Allegations of drugs and jihad - profile of suspect Ayoub El-Khazzani
What we know
Of the several avenues being looked into for tightening security, the least feasible is the most obvious: turning railway stations into airports.
Requiring rail passengers to present identity papers, and to submit to a body and bag search, would lower the terrorist risk to practically nil.
But the costs of implementing such a policy make it utterly impractical.
"There are 20 times more train passengers in France than there are air passengers. So whatever security there is now at airports, you would have to multiply it by 20 in stations. It is not a realistic proposition," says Guillaume Pepy, president of France's state rail company SNCF.
Five million people use the trains every day in France, at some 3,000 stations - 230 of them linked to the TGV high-speed network. For most of these passengers, the train is an essential part of their working life, with the huge advantage over planes that you can board them up to the moment before departure.
Requiring people to arrive half an hour early in order to get through security would strip rail travel of one of its essential assets.
"There is also the financial cost," says Marc Ivaldi, transport economist at Toulouse School of Economics.
"Not just all the equipment. But reconstructing railway stations to create adequate spaces. Most railway stations are old buildings, and totally unsuited for modern security."
However, Mr Ivaldi says that Eurostar-style checks on international trains like the Thalys - and on parts of France's own TGV network - may now be inevitable.
"It will be purely symbolic, because wherever there are checks the terrorist can go elsewhere.  But not doing it may prove untenable."
If universal Eurostar-style controls are impossible, what other options are there?
One possibility under serious consideration is random checks. But this is where political sensitivities have kicked in.
Speaking on French radio on Monday, the Socialist Transport Minister Alain Vidalies brought down the wrath of the left when he said the risk of racial discrimination that might follow "random" checks was something he could live with.
"Every time we talk about random checks, there is always someone who retorts, 'Yes, but you know it could be discriminatory.' Well you know something: I would rather discriminate and be effective, than just sit back and let it all happen." the minister said.
The worry of opponents of random checks is that they would not be random at all. Police would inevitably gravitate towards young males of North African looks, especially ones with beards and wearing a djellaba (full-length hooded robe).
Writing in left-wing daily Liberation, journalist Rachid Laireche said Mr Vidalies' words "sent a shiver down my spine". "By legitimising discriminatory controls... you will not only be ineffective, you will also reinforce the stigmatisation of a whole section of society."
That in turn prompted a storm of indignation from the right, which said the transport minister was talking plain good sense, and that the real scandal was how the suspect, Ayoub el-Khazzani, was able to travel freely around Europe despite having been identified as a potential danger.
In general, though, it seems likely that some sort of random baggage check will be authorised by the government later this week - with a strong insistence that it be applied with a close eye to the passenger's appearance.
Other ideas under consideration are an increase in training for the SNCF's 150,000 staff, so they are better equipped to respond to terrorist emergencies; clearer and more prominent warnings about terrorism on trains and in stations; and the deployment of more police and soldiers.
However, police unions have warned that the service is now at its limits.
"After the January attacks we have been operating at 100% capacity, reinforced by 10,000 soldiers. There is no more reserve," says Nicolas Comte of SGP Police FO.
With the limitations of traditional security improvements all too evident, some are calling for a changed mentality in society as a whole to cope with the now permanent threat.
"I do not doubt the vigilance of the security forces, but what we need now is for the whole nation to be in a state of vigilance," said former centre-right interior minister Claude Gueant.
He cited the example of the state of Israel, which "has lived for years under the constant threat of attacksa| and yet people live ordinary lives, because they take elementary precautions".
Urging an Israeli-style security mindset will not endear Mr Gueant to many people in France. But it is a sign of the times that he has not been immediately denounced for making the comparison.
LLM_1:

Outside of the Eurostar and Spanish high-speed networks, there are no systematic identity or baggage checks across the European railway system. The Schengen Zone allows criminals and terrorists to travel undetected, posing risks not only for passengers but also for the transport of drugs and arms.

Experts suggest that while stringent security measures, akin to airport protocols, could significantly reduce risks, the practicality of implementing such systems is questionable. Guillaume Pepy, president of France's state rail company SNCF, notes that with train ridership in France being 20 times greater than air travel, the logistics and costs of heightened security would be overwhelming. Daily, 5 million passengers use France's approximately 3,000 train stations, which are often more convenient than flying, as they allow last-minute boarding.

Economist Marc Ivaldi highlights the financial burden of updating aging railway infrastructure to accommodate modern security needs. Despite these challenges, he believes that Eurostar-style checks on international trains may become necessary, even if they serve more as a symbolic gesture than a complete solution.

Random security checks are under consideration, but they raise concerns about potential racial discrimination. French Transport Minister Alain Vidalies sparked debate by stating that he would prioritize effectiveness over concerns of discrimination. Critics fear that such checks would disproportionately target young North African men, exacerbating social stigmas. 

On the right, some support the minister's stance, arguing that the real issue is how the suspect, Ayoub el-Khazzani, was able to travel freely despite being flagged as a potential threat. Random baggage checks may be authorized soon, accompanied by a commitment to avoid bias in their application.

Other proposals include enhanced training for SNCF staff, clearer terrorism warnings at stations, and increased police and military presence, though police unions have warned of existing strains on resources.

Once there were 4 houses, Griffandor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw and Slytherin. 
 In the years after the last Wizerding War, the Minister of Magic, the chosen one himself, began to meddle in the affairs of the Wizerding world. 
 Some said it was old age. One woman who claimed to know him well, said it was an effect of a Horcrux, but she was silenced soon after. Suspicion of using magic on muggles. 
 
 In order to prevent more Dark Wizards from emerging, Hogwarts was brought under the direct supervision of a Special Inquister. While the last scion of freedom, the Malfoy family, had gone into hiding, suspicion of being former Death Eaters. 
 I remember my father telling me all about how Merlin was a Slytherin when he heard the news. A whole House gone from Hogwarts... how absurd it could seem. Yet, as he said, the Cult of Potter would allow just that. I remember what he told me when I got my letter, `` Gregory, I love you my son. I know you ca n't be a Slytherin like I was, or my father, but whatever you be I will love you.'' 
 
 Headmaster Longbottom, gave a boring speech, announcing the 3 Houses and their virtues. Duty, Honor, Bravery. He sat down and the sorting began. My distant cousin was first, he was a Ravenclaw, my neighbor a Hufflepuff. Then it came to me. 
 I quivered in fear as I stepped forward and sat down, the old hat on my head. 
 I could hear it whispering, 
 `` Something new here, for years I have not sensed this, for years it has been too long. I dub thee Slytherin!'' 
 
 The whole room gasped. The Special Inquister, a portly older woman yelled in a shrieking high voice, `` Do it again!'' 
 Professor Slughorn, interjected, `` The sorting hat is final! We have a Slytherin.'' 
 All eyes were one me, the Headmaster let out a deep sigh, `` Well, Gregory Goyle Jr. you are a Slytherin.'' 
 And so my journey at Hogwarts began.

Once, four houses¡ªGryffindor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, and Slytherin¡ªstood proudly at Hogwarts, each a pillar of tradition and legacy. In the wake of the last Wizarding War, however, the Minister of Magic, the so-called Chosen One, began to meddle in the affairs of the Wizarding world. Some attributed his peculiar behavior to the toll of age, while a woman who claimed to know him hinted at the lingering influence of a Horcrux; her voice was swiftly silenced amid rising suspicions of magic being used on Muggles.

To combat the resurgence of Dark Wizards, Hogwarts found itself under the scrutiny of a Special Inquisitor. The Malfoy family, once the last bastion of freedom, had disappeared, their past as former Death Eaters casting a long shadow over their legacy. I still remember my father¡¯s disbelief when he learned that Merlin had been a Slytherin. The very notion of an entire house missing from Hogwarts seemed preposterous, yet he cautioned me about the insidious reach of the Cult of Potter¡¯s influence. When my acceptance letter arrived, he took my hands in his and said, ¡°Gregory, I love you, my son. You may not be a Slytherin like I was, nor like my father before me, but my love for you knows no bounds.¡±

Headmaster Longbottom delivered a lackluster speech extolling the virtues of the three remaining houses: Duty, Honor, Bravery. Then came the sorting. My distant cousin was placed in Ravenclaw, my neighbor in Hufflepuff. When my turn arrived, trepidation coursed through me as I approached the stool, feeling the weight of the ancient hat as it settled upon my head.

It whispered with an eerie familiarity, ¡°Something new here; it has been too long. I dub thee Slytherin!¡±

A gasp rippled through the Great Hall. The Special Inquisitor, a portly woman with an air of authority, shrieked, ¡°Do it again!¡±

Professor Slughorn quickly interjected, ¡°The Sorting Hat¡¯s decision is final! We have a Slytherin.¡±

All eyes turned toward me as the Headmaster sighed, ¡°Well, Gregory Goyle Jr., you are indeed a Slytherin.¡±

And thus began my journey at Hogwarts.

human: Human respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is associated with airway remodeling and subsequent asthma development. Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF) plays a crucial role in asthma development. The mechanism regulating TGF gene expression during RSV infection is not known. Kruppel-like factor family of transcription factors are critical regulators of cellular/tissue homeostasis. Previous studies have shown that Kruppel-like factor 6 (KLF6) could function as a trans-activator of TGF gene; however, whether KLF members play a role during infection is unknown. In the current study we have evaluated the role of KLF6 during TGF expression in RSV infected cells.Silencing KLF6 expression by shRNA led to drastic inhibition in TGF production during RSV infection, as assessed by ELISA analysis of medium supernatants. RT-PCR analysis revealed loss of TGF expression in KLF6 silenced cells. Chromatin-immunoprecipitation assay conducted with RSV infected cells showed binding of KLF6 protein to the TGF promoter during RSV infection. We further observed reduced RSV infectivity in KLF6 silenced cells and in cells incubated with TGF neutralizing antibody. In contrast, enhanced RSV infection was noted in cells incubated with purified TGF.
LLM_1: Human respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is linked to airway remodeling and asthma development, with transforming growth factor-beta (TGF) playing a vital role in this process. The regulatory mechanisms controlling TGF gene expression during RSV infection remain unclear. Kruppel-like factor 6 (KLF6), a member of the Kruppel-like factor family of transcription factors essential for cellular homeostasis, has been identified as a potential trans-activator of TGF. However, the involvement of KLF factors during RSV infection is not well understood. In this study, we explored the role of KLF6 in TGF expression in RSV-infected cells. Silencing KLF6 using shRNA significantly inhibited TGF production during RSV infection, as demonstrated by ELISA of culture supernatants. RT-PCR analysis confirmed the reduction of TGF expression in KLF6-silenced cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation assays indicated KLF6 binding to the TGF promoter in RSV-infected cells. Additionally, decreased RSV infectivity was observed in KLF6-silenced cells and those treated with a TGF neutralizing antibody, while enhanced RSV infection occurred in cells treated with purified TGF.
LLM_2: Human respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is associated with airway remodeling and the development of asthma, with transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-¦Â) playing a crucial role in these processes. However, the regulatory mechanisms governing TGF-¦Â gene expression during RSV infection remain poorly understood. This study investigates the role of Kruppel-like factor 6 (KLF6), a member of the Kruppel-like factor family of transcription factors that are essential for cellular homeostasis, as a potential trans-activator of TGF-¦Â. We demonstrate that silencing KLF6 using short hairpin RNA (shRNA) significantly inhibits TGF-¦Â production in RSV-infected cells, as evidenced by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) of culture supernatants. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis further confirmed the reduced expression of TGF-¦Â in KLF6-silenced cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation assays revealed that KLF6 binds to the TGF-¦Â promoter in the context of RSV infection. Additionally, we observed decreased RSV infectivity in KLF6-silenced cells and in cells treated with a TGF-¦Â neutralizing antibody, whereas enhanced RSV infection was noted in cells treated with purified TGF-¦Â. These findings elucidate the role of KLF6 in modulating TGF-¦Â expression during RSV infection and highlight its potential as a therapeutic target.

In this paper, the authors proposed an approach to fit locally constant functions using deep neural networks (DNNs).
The idea is based on the fact that DNN consisting of only linear transformations and ReLU activations is piecewise linear.
Thus, the derivative of such a network with respect to the input is locally constant.

In the paper, the authors focused on connecting the locally constant network with oblique decision trees.
Specifically, they proved that these two models are in some sense equivalent, and one can transform one model to another.
This connection enables us to train the oblique decision trees by training the locally constant network instead.
Because the locally constant network can be trained using the gradient-based methods, it would be much easier to train than the oblique decision trees.

I think the paper is well-written and the idea is clear.
Connecting the locally constant network with oblique decision trees looks interesting.

I have one concern, however.
The authors mention that the training of oblique decision trees is difficult, and the use of the locally constant network is helpful.
If I understand correctly, oblique decision tree is one specific instance of the hierarchical mixtures of experts.
And, [Ref1] pointed out that the hierarchical mixtures of experts can be trained using EM algorithm, which is another type of the gradient-based training.
The current paper misses such a prior study.
I am interested in to see if the use of locally constant network is truly effective for training oblique decision trees over the algorithms considered in the literatures of hierarchical mixtures of experts.

[Ref1] Hierarchical mixtures of experts and the EM algorithm


### Updated after author response ###
The authors have successfully demonstrated that the proposed approach is better than the EM-like classical approaches. I therefore keep my score.
LLM_1:
The authors propose a method for fitting locally constant functions using deep neural networks (DNNs). Their approach is grounded in the understanding that a DNN consisting solely of linear transformations and ReLU activations is piecewise linear, resulting in a locally constant derivative concerning the input.

The paper establishes a connection between locally constant networks and oblique decision trees, demonstrating their equivalence and the feasibility of transforming one model into the other. This relationship allows for training oblique decision trees by employing gradient-based methods on locally constant networks, simplifying the training process.

The paper is well-written, and the idea is clearly articulated. The connection between locally constant networks and oblique decision trees is intriguing.

However, I have a concern. The authors state that training oblique decision trees is challenging and that locally constant networks provide a solution. I believe oblique decision trees are a specific instance of hierarchical mixtures of experts, which can be trained using the EM algorithm, another gradient-based method, as noted in [Ref1]. The paper does not reference this prior work. I am interested in understanding whether the locally constant network is indeed more effective for training oblique decision trees compared to the algorithms discussed in the literature on hierarchical mixtures of experts.

[Ref1] Hierarchical mixtures of experts and the EM algorithm

### Updated after author response ###
The authors have successfully demonstrated that the proposed approach is better than the EM-like classical approaches. I therefore keep my score.
LLM_2:
The authors propose a novel method for fitting locally constant functions utilizing deep neural networks (DNNs). Their approach is based on the premise that a DNN composed exclusively of linear transformations and ReLU activations exhibits piecewise linearity, leading to a locally constant derivative with respect to the input.

The paper effectively establishes a connection between locally constant networks and oblique decision trees, demonstrating their equivalence and the potential for transforming one model into the other. This relationship facilitates the training of oblique decision trees by leveraging gradient-based methods on locally constant networks, thereby streamlining the training process.

Overall, the manuscript is well-written, and the central idea is articulated with clarity. The exploration of the relationship between locally constant networks and oblique decision trees is particularly intriguing.

Nonetheless, I do have a concern. The authors assert that training oblique decision trees poses significant challenges and that locally constant networks offer a viable solution. However, it is important to note that oblique decision trees can be viewed as a specific instance of hierarchical mixtures of experts, which may be trained using the EM algorithm¡ªanother gradient-based method, as highlighted in [Ref1]. The paper does not reference this relevant prior work. I would appreciate clarification on whether the locally constant network demonstrates superior efficacy in training oblique decision trees compared to the algorithms discussed in the existing literature on hierarchical mixtures of experts.

[Ref1] Hierarchical mixtures of experts and the EM algorithm

### Updated after author response ###
The authors have convincingly demonstrated that their proposed approach outperforms traditional EM-like methods. Consequently, I maintain my original score.

Professors Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano and Shuji Nakamura made the first blue LEDs in the early 1990s.
This enabled a new generation of bright, energy-efficient white lamps, as well as colour LED screens.
The winners will share prize money of eight million kronor (?¡ê0.7m).
They were named at a press conference in Sweden, and join a prestigious list of 196 other Physics laureates recognised since 1901.
Prof Nakamura, who was woken up in Japan to receive the news, told the press conference, "It's unbelievable."
Making the announcement, the Nobel jury emphasised the usefulness of the invention, adding that the Nobel Prizes were established to recognise developments that delivered "the greatest benefit to mankind".
"These uses are what would make Alfred Nobel very happy," said Prof Olle Inganas, a member of the prize committee from Linkoping University.
The committee chair, Prof Per Delsing, from Chalmers University of Technology in Gothenburg, emphasised the winners' dedication.
"What's fascinating is that a lot of big companies really tried to do this and they failed," he said. "But these guys persisted and they tried and tried again - and eventually they actually succeeded."
Although red and green LEDs had been around for many years, blue LEDs were a long-standing challenge for scientists in both academia and industry.
Without them, the three colours could not be mixed to produce the white light we now see in LED-based computer and TV screens. Furthermore, the high-energy blue light could be used to excite phosphorus and directly produce white light - the basis of the next generation of light bulb.
Today, blue LEDs are found in people's pockets around the world, inside the lights and screens of smartphones.
White LED lamps, meanwhile, deliver light to many offices and households. They use much less energy than both incandescent and fluorescent lamps.
That improvement arises because LEDs convert electricity directly into photons of light, instead of the wasteful mixture of heat and light generated inside traditional, incandescent bulbs. Those bulbs use current to heat a wire filament until it glows, while the gas discharge inside fluorescent lamps also produces both heat and light.
Inside an LED, current is applied to a sandwich of semiconductor materials, which emit a particular wavelength of light depending on the chemical make-up of those materials.
Gallium nitride was the key ingredient used by the Nobel laureates in their ground-breaking blue LEDs. Growing big enough crystals of this compound was the stumbling block that stopped many other researchers - but Profs Akasaki and Amano, working at Nagoya University in Japan, managed to grow them in 1986 on a specially-designed scaffold made partly from sapphire.
Four years later Prof Nakamura made a similar breakthrough, while he was working at the chemical company Nichia. Instead of a special substrate, he used a clever manipulation of temperature to boost the growth of the all-important crystals.
2013 - Francois Englert and Peter Higgs shared the prize for formulating the theory of the Higgs boson particle.
2012 - Serge Haroche and David J Wineland were awarded the prize for their work with light and matter.
2011 - The discovery that the expansion of the Universe was accelerating earned Saul Perlmutter, Brian P Schmidt and Adam Riess the physics prize.
2010 - Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov were awarded the prize for their discovery of the "wonder material" graphene.
2009 - Charles Kuen Kao won the physics Nobel for helping to develop fibre optic cables.
In its award citation, the Nobel committee declared: "Incandescent light bulbs lit the 20th Century; the 21st Century will be lit by LED lamps."
Commenting on the news, the president of the Institute of Physics, Dr Frances Saunders, emphasised that energy-efficient lamps form an important part of the effort to help slow carbon dioxide emissions worldwide.
"With 20% of the world's electricity used for lighting, it's been calculated that optimal use of LED lighting could reduce this to 4%," she said.
"Akasaki, Amano and Nakamura's research has made this possible. This is physics research that is having a direct impact on the grandest of scales, helping protect our environment, as well as turning up in our everyday electronic gadgets."
LED lamps have the potential to help more than 1.5 billion people around the world who do not have access to electricity grids - because they are efficient enough to run on cheap, local solar power.
At the University of Cambridge in the UK, Professor Sir Colin Humphreys also works on gallium nitride technology, including efforts to produce the crystals more cheaply and reduce the cost of LED lamps. He told BBC News he was thrilled by the Nobel announcement.
"It pleases me greatly, because this is good science but it's also useful science. It's making a huge difference to energy savings. And I think some of the Nobel Prizes we have had recently - it will be years, if ever, before that science is usefully applied."
Professor Ian Walmsley, a physicist at Oxford University, said the jury had made a "fantastic choice".
"The ideas derive from some very important underpinning science developed over many years," he said, adding that the technology "makes new devices possible that are having, and will have, a huge impact on society, especially in displays and imaging".
Follow Jonathan on Twitter

### Nobel Prize in Physics Awarded for Breakthrough in Blue LED Technology

Professors Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, and Shuji Nakamura have been awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for their pioneering work in the development of blue light-emitting diodes (LEDs) in the early 1990s. This groundbreaking innovation has paved the way for bright, energy-efficient white lighting and vibrant color LED screens. The three laureates will share a prize of eight million kronor (approximately ¡ê0.7 million) and join the ranks of 196 other Nobel laureates recognized since the award's inception in 1901. 

At a press conference held in Sweden, Professor Nakamura, who received the news while in Japan, expressed his astonishment, stating, "It's unbelievable." The Nobel committee underscored the invention's profound impact on humanity, with committee member Professor Olle Inganas remarking, "These uses are what would make Alfred Nobel very happy." Committee chair Professor Per Delsing commended the winners for their perseverance, highlighting that many companies had attempted this innovation without success.

While red and green LEDs were already in existence, the creation of blue LEDs proved to be a significant challenge for scientists. The advent of blue LEDs was instrumental in mixing colors to produce white light in LED screens. Additionally, blue LEDs facilitated the direct creation of white light, forming the foundation for next-generation light bulbs. Today, they are vital components in smartphones and energy-efficient white LED lamps found in homes and offices, consuming considerably less energy than traditional incandescent and fluorescent bulbs.

Unlike conventional bulbs that waste energy as heat, LEDs convert electricity directly into light. The laureates utilized gallium nitride, a crucial material that enabled them to overcome the challenge of growing large crystals. Profs. Akasaki and Amano accomplished this feat in 1986 at Nagoya University, while Prof. Nakamura achieved a similar breakthrough in 1990 at Nichia through temperature manipulation.

The Nobel committee remarked, "Incandescent light bulbs lit the 20th Century; the 21st Century will be lit by LED lamps." Dr. Frances Saunders, president of the Institute of Physics, emphasized the importance of energy-efficient lamps in reducing global carbon dioxide emissions, noting that optimal use of LEDs could lower lighting's electricity consumption from 20% to just 4%.

LED technology holds the potential to benefit over 1.5 billion people worldwide who lack access to electricity grids, as it can operate on inexpensive local solar power. Professor Sir Colin Humphreys from the University of Cambridge expressed his enthusiasm for the Nobel announcement, highlighting the tangible impact of the research on energy savings. Meanwhile, Professor Ian Walmsley from Oxford University praised the Nobel jury's decision, emphasizing the significant societal implications of this technology in displays and imaging.

This paper connects knowledge distillation and label smoothing regularization. With two sets of well designed experiments, train large network with small teacher or poorly trained teacher, the authors claim knowledge distillation has a strong regularization effect. The authors then show that both knowledge distillation and label smoothing loss can be written as linear combination of supervised learning loss and KL divergence loss. Finally, two 'teacher free' methods are proposed, use the same network as student and teacher, and a variant of label smoothing. 

I am generally on the fence for this paper. I think it makes sense to view knowledge distillation as a regularizer. It is not a surprising finding but I have not seen it in previous papers. On the other hand, there are multiple ways to interpret knowledge distillation, including categorical relationship, loss smoothing, and regularizer. It is hard to convince me regularization is the main drive because in original KD, even without the supervised part H(q, p), it still works reasonably well. It looks to me this paper is more about label smoothing/regularization than knowledge distillation. But since label smoothing has been shown to be an effective regularizer in previous works, it is difficult to say how much practical value is there. 

About the two proposed teacher free methods, the first one looks like Born Again Network, the second looks like can be achieved by tuning the label smoothing parameter \alpha. 

A relatively minor issue is how the hyper-parameters (\alpha and there should be a temperature parameter T) are decided for knowledge distillation.
LLM_1:
This paper explores the relationship between knowledge distillation and label smoothing regularization. Through two well-designed experiments involving training large networks with either a small or poorly trained teacher, the authors claim that knowledge distillation serves as a strong regularization method. They demonstrate that both knowledge distillation and label smoothing can be expressed as linear combinations of supervised learning loss and KL divergence loss. Additionally, they propose two 'teacher-free' methods that utilize the same network as both student and teacher, along with a variant of label smoothing.

I am ambivalent about this paper. While it is reasonable to view knowledge distillation as a regularizer¡ªalbeit not a surprising conclusion¡ªit has not been extensively discussed in previous literature. However, knowledge distillation can be interpreted in various ways, including categorical relationships, loss smoothing, and regularization. I find it challenging to accept that regularization is the primary driving force, as the original knowledge distillation framework functions reasonably well even without the supervised component H(q, p). It appears that this paper emphasizes label smoothing more than knowledge distillation, and since label smoothing has been recognized as an effective regularizer in prior studies, its practical value remains uncertain.

Regarding the two proposed teacher-free methods, the first resembles the Born Again Network, while the second seems achievable by adjusting the label smoothing parameter ¦Á.

A relatively minor concern is the determination of hyperparameters (¦Á and potentially a temperature parameter T) for knowledge distillation.
LLM_2:
This paper investigates the relationship between knowledge distillation and label smoothing regularization. Through two meticulously designed experiments that involve training large networks with either a small or poorly trained teacher, the authors assert that knowledge distillation functions as a robust regularization method. They illustrate that both knowledge distillation and label smoothing can be represented as linear combinations of supervised learning loss and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence loss. Furthermore, the authors introduce two 'teacher-free' methodologies that leverage the same network as both student and teacher, accompanied by a variant of label smoothing.

I find myself ambivalent regarding this paper. While it is reasonable to conceptualize knowledge distillation as a form of regularization¡ªalbeit this is not an unexpected conclusion¡ªit has not been thoroughly explored in the existing literature. Nonetheless, knowledge distillation can be interpreted in multiple ways, including categorical relationships, loss smoothing, and regularization. I struggle to accept the notion that regularization serves as the primary motivating factor, since the original framework for knowledge distillation continues to perform adequately even in the absence of the supervised component \( H(q, p) \). It appears that this paper places greater emphasis on label smoothing than on knowledge distillation; given that label smoothing has been identified as an effective regularizer in prior research, its practical significance in this context remains ambiguous.

With respect to the two proposed teacher-free methods, the first bears resemblance to the Born Again Network, while the second appears to be attainable through an adjustment of the label smoothing parameter \( \alpha \).

A relatively minor concern pertains to the determination of hyperparameters \( \alpha \) and, potentially, a temperature parameter \( T \) for knowledge distillation.

human:
This paper presents an analysis that with simple energy minimization and training on fractal terrain can lead to different gaits at different target speeds. 

Strengths and Weaknesses:

Pro:

1. Demonstrate that a simple reward (compared to other work that use similar control structure) is able to generate natural gaits that can work well on the real robots.

2. Froude number analysis with number compared with real animals.

Con:

No major flaw. See more comments below.

Originality: Good: Some advance.

Technical Quality: Very Good: Convincing.

Clarity of Presentation: Very Good: Well organized and clear.

Impact: 3: The work is incremental and unlikely to have much impact, even though it may be technically correct and well executed.

Recommendation: Weak Accept: I recommend accepting the paper, but will not argue for my recommendation if the majority of other reviewers have a different opinion.

Summary of Recommendation: The idea in the paper is straightforward and the paper is well written. The analysis of gait, especially compared to those of animals' using Froude number is interesting.

However, similar result (gait emergence with simple energy minimization) is also demonstrated in Learning Symmetric and Low-Energy Locomotion, by Yu, et al. Although they did not give the throughout analysis of different gait patterns as provided by this paper.

Another impressive part of the paper is the robustness of the controller, although that mainly benefits from the approach in prior work, i.e., Learning quadrupedal locomotion over challenging terrain by Lee et al, and Rma: Rapid motor adaptation for legged robots, by Kumar et al, and is not a contribution of this paper.

Overall, this paper presents a simple approach to train policies for different locomotion gaits for the A1 robot and can be valuable to the community, although the contribution is a bit incremental.

Questions/Concerns:

1. The claim "Show that minimizing energy consumption is sufficient for the emergence of natural locomotion patterns" is not true, as mentioned in the paper, fractal terrain during training is also necessary.

2. How repeatable are the experiments? e.g., if I train with 10 different random seeds, will all seeds give us the same gait for the same speed?

3. Can we see what the gaits trained on flat ground looks like in the video? I can't get any information from Figure 8 alone.

4. It will be interesting to see the transition between different speeds.

5. Will the authors open source the code? Open source implementation will greatly benefit the community, especially given the affordable price of the robots.

Reviewer Expertise: Very good: Comprehensive knowledge of the area

Strengths and Weaknesses:

Pro:

1. The paper demonstrates that a straightforward reward mechanism can generate natural gaits that perform effectively on real robots, differing from similar studies.

2. It includes Froude number analysis, comparing results with those observed in real animals.

Con:

No significant flaws noted. Further comments are below.

Originality: Good: Some advancement.

Technical Quality: Very Good: Convincing.

Clarity of Presentation: Very Good: Well-organized and clear.

Impact: 3: The work is incremental and may not significantly influence the field, despite being technically sound and well-executed.

Recommendation: Weak Accept: I suggest accepting the paper, though I will not advocate for this if other reviewers disagree.

Summary of Recommendation: The concepts presented are straightforward, and the paper is well-written. The analysis of gait, particularly through Froude number comparisons to animal locomotion, is intriguing.

However, similar results regarding gait emergence from simple energy minimization have been observed in "Learning Symmetric and Low-Energy Locomotion" by Yu et al., although they did not provide as thorough an analysis of various gait patterns.

Another notable aspect is the controller's robustness, which primarily benefits from approaches in prior works, such as "Learning Quadrupedal Locomotion Over Challenging Terrain" by Lee et al. and "RMA: Rapid Motor Adaptation for Legged Robots" by Kumar et al., rather than being a unique contribution of this paper.

Overall, this work offers a straightforward method for training policies for different locomotion gaits for the A1 robot, which could be beneficial to the community, albeit with somewhat incremental contributions.

Questions/Concerns:

1. The claim that minimizing energy consumption alone leads to natural locomotion patterns is misleading; as noted, fractal terrain during training is also essential.

2. How repeatable are the experiments? For instance, if I train with 10 different random seeds, will all yield the same gait for the same speed?

3. Could we see the gaits trained on flat ground in the video? Figure 8 does not provide sufficient information.

4. It would be interesting to observe transitions between different speeds.

5. Will the authors open-source the code? An open-source implementation would greatly benefit the community, particularly given the affordable price of the robots.

Reviewer Expertise: Very good: Comprehensive knowledge of the area.
LLM_2:
This paper analyzes how simple energy minimization and training on fractal terrain can produce varied gaits at different target speeds.

### Strengths and Weaknesses:

**Strengths:**

1. The paper effectively demonstrates that a straightforward reward mechanism can generate natural gaits that perform well on real robots, distinguishing it from similar studies in the field.

2. The inclusion of Froude number analysis, which compares the results with those observed in real animals, adds significant value to the findings.

**Weaknesses:**

- No significant flaws were noted. Additional comments are provided below.

### Assessment Criteria:

- **Originality:** Good - The work presents some advancements in the field.
  
- **Technical Quality:** Very Good - The methodologies and results are convincing and well-supported.
  
- **Clarity of Presentation:** Very Good - The paper is well-organized and articulates its points clearly.
  
- **Impact:** 3 - While the work is technically sound and well-executed, it is rather incremental and may not have a significant influence on the field.

### Recommendation: Weak Accept  
I recommend accepting the paper, although I will not advocate for this position if other reviewers express differing opinions.

### Summary of Recommendation:  
The concepts presented in this manuscript are straightforward, and the writing is clear and coherent. The analysis of gait, particularly through the Froude number comparisons to animal locomotion, is intriguing.

However, it is important to note that similar results regarding gait emergence from simple energy minimization have been documented in "Learning Symmetric and Low-Energy Locomotion" by Yu et al., although that study did not provide as comprehensive an analysis of various gait patterns.

Additionally, the robustness of the controller seems to primarily benefit from approaches discussed in prior works, such as "Learning Quadrupedal Locomotion Over Challenging Terrain" by Lee et al. and "RMA: Rapid Motor Adaptation for Legged Robots" by Kumar et al., rather than offering a unique contribution.

Overall, this work presents a straightforward method for training policies for different locomotion gaits for the A1 robot, which could be beneficial to the community, albeit with somewhat incremental contributions.

### Questions/Concerns:

1. The assertion that minimizing energy consumption alone leads to natural locomotion patterns may be misleading; it is also essential to consider the role of fractal terrain during training.

2. What is the repeatability of the experiments? Specifically, if 10 different random seeds are utilized, will all yield the same gait for a given speed?

3. Can we observe the gaits trained on flat ground in the accompanying video? The information provided in Figure 8 is insufficient.

4. It would be valuable to observe the transitions between different speeds during locomotion.

5. Will the authors consider open-sourcing the code? An open-source implementation would significantly benefit the community, especially given the affordability of the robots.

### Reviewer Expertise:  
Very Good - The reviewer possesses comprehensive knowledge of the area.

He missed. He was soaring through the air shooting massive blasts of energy ( which I do n't understand the origin nor mechanics of ) at a balding man in a robotic suit who was scaling a skyscraper. About 30 seconds ago, the flying, suited man blasted a blue sphere of energy that landed about 200 feet away from his intended target and directly onto an apartment complex. My apartment complex. Where I lived with my daughter, two cats, and goldfish. 
 
 When the fiasco started, I had gotten out of my car which was stuck in the heavy traffic of people fleeing for their lives, and was running towards the complex while trying to get on the line with the babysitter. No answer. The ground was quaking every few minutes and the dust made it difficult to breathe. Then I traced the blue light streaking through the sky right to the very place I was sprinting towards. I came to a halt and watched as everything I knew collapsed to the ground. A numbness spread over me immediately, starting from my fingertips and quickly spread to my heart and my brain. I vaguely recall a similar sensation occurring when I had opened the door to a uniformed man carrying a triangle flag. I stood there for another three explosions and then I turned around and walked away.

`` But Jack, I will always love you!'' The TV speakers whisper into your ears as you sit up alone at seven in the evening, watching yet another terrible chick flick. You're kind of lounging in the chair, and your legs are on a foot rest in front of you. This is basically all you do at home now. 
 
 `` I know you do baby, but I ca n't be with another wom-'' Bam, your door is knocked down. Before you can even get up on your feet rough brown fabric is covering your eyes and ears, and your arms have been bound behind your back. `` I'm afraid you're going to have to come with us Mr. Martin'' 
 
 Within seconds, you're being hauled into the back of some sort of vehicle, it's hard to tell with a burlap sack over your head, but you definitely feel movement, and the bumps of the ground and the holes in the unrefined Arizona backroad they're taking you through. You can only smell two things, cigarette smoke, and the vegetable fibers used to make the sack covering your head. You can hear even less, just the sound of the cars cracking and whirring. 
 
 `` It's time to move *Mr. Martin*, you feel someone grab the rope keeping your hands tied to each other. You're thrown out of whatever contraption they used to bring you hear, and brought to the ground. `` *Here, let me help you up*'' You question whether your mystery man is actually very interested in helping. Before you can even begin to finish your though you are pulled up to your feet, and brought into an unknown building. 
 
 You feel the rough fabric and hear the soft scratching sound as it's ripped off your head. You look around in amazement at the sleek metal walls, and somehow futuristic architecture of the extremely modern building. No mistake about it, you've caught the attention of the exact *wrong* people. 
 
 `` You may be wondering why you've been brought here *Mr. Martin*, or you may not be, either way, we know you have the Covenated Key, hand it over, or you're never leaving here. 
 
 `` What are you talking about, who's Mr. Martin?'' At the conception of your question you can see the nascent recognition of confusion and shock at what you've just asked. 
 
 `` You, you are Mr. Martin, right?'' 
 
 `` No, I'm Jeffrey Adams! What do you want from me?'' Terror truly resonates with your voice, and it seems the people around you have recognized the error of their ways. 
 
 `` Oh, I'm afraid we're going to have to let you go then''. 
 
 You wake up in the middle of town with no trace of your short lived memories of government organizations and advanced alien keys. Confused and dazed, you begin walking home.

Willow Rosenberg was a bookish girl. Her long red hair rested on her shoulders in braids. She had a bit of a reputation for being the Teacher's Pet. Even still, she enjoyed minor indulgences. For example, on this particular morning she had skipped homeroom to sneak into the library. Whilst perusing the stacks, she heard a loud crash. She turned to see a young blonde student fighting with an older woman. The older woman, blonde and slender, effortlessly overpowered the student. 
 
 Willow screamed. The blonde woman looked up. Her face had shifted into a monstrous form. Yellow eyes and sharp teeth smiled as they walked toward her. The monstrous woman said coyly, 
 
 `` You look delicious.'' 
 
 In the minutes that followed, Willow screamed as she was dragged into the tunnels under the school. The blonde woman laughed as Willow kicked and screamed. The woman came to a stop in the remains of an old church that had long since fallen into the into the caverns below the school. Willow could n't help but scream as a monster with grey skin and pointy ears smiled a devilish grin and said, 
 
 `` Oh Darla, you always were my favorite child. Is this Ms. Summers?'' 
 
 Darla tossed the limp and unconscious body of the young blonde student to the gray-skinned man. The walls shook as he feasted upon her. Willow watched as he pushed through a translucent field of energy and emerged on the other side. Darla tightened her grip on Willow's wrist, causing her to let out a hoarse whimper and a cough. The blonde monster said, 
 
 `` I was able to bring a snack as well.'' 
 
 The gray-skinned man placed his hand on Willow's face. She could n't help but cry has he pulled her up toward his eyes. They were mesmerizing. He whispered into her ear, 
 
 `` I see a spark in you. Welcome to the Order of Aurelius.'' 
 
 The grey-skin man prick his finger on his tooth and shoved it into Willow's mouth. It tasted foul and metallic. No sooner that she could think to spit, he bit into her neck. It was all over in moments. He drained her to the last drop and tossed her to the side. 
 
 Darla smiled and said, 
 
 `` Oh Master, I've always wanted a little sister.'' 
 
 The Master and Darla moved with the other creatures that had gathered below the school. Night would be upon them soon. With the night would come the slaughter. No one in the world above would be ready for the carnage or the terror. Over the events of that dreadful evening, none were more monstrous than the young Willow. When the last of the students at the homecoming game were cowering in fear, young Willow walked up to a cheerleader that had tormented her for years. 
 
 The cheerleader, a young brunette woman by the name of Cordelia, turned to Willow and said, 
 
 `` Dammit Rosenberg, I always knew you were a freak.'' 
 
 Willow slashed her throat and danced in the fountain of blood. As the cheerleader gurgled incoherent insults and grabbed at the hole in her neck, Willow turned to the bodies laid before her and said, 
 
 `` Bored now.''

The older woman, slender and blonde, easily overpowered the student.

Willow screamed as the woman looked at her, transforming into a monstrous figure with yellow eyes and sharp teeth. "You look delicious," she said coyly.

In the chaos that followed, Willow was dragged into the tunnels beneath the school, kicking and screaming. The woman brought her to the ruins of an old church deep in the caverns. Cordelia turned, sneering, "Dammit Rosenberg, I always knew you were a freak."

human: The inflammatory response has been implicated in the pathogenesis of left ventricular (LV) remodeling after myocardial infarction (MI). An anthraquinone compound with anti-inflammatory properties, diacerein inhibits the synthesis and activity of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor and interleukins 1 and 6. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of diacerein on ventricular remodeling in vivo.Ligation of the left anterior descending artery was used to induce MI in an experimental rat model. Rats were divided into two groups: a control group that received saline solution (n = 16) and a group that received diacerein (80 mg/kg) daily (n = 10). After 4 weeks, the LV volume, cellular signaling, caspase 3 activity, and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-¦ÊB) transcription were compared between the two groups. After 4 weeks, end-diastolic and end-systolic LV volumes were reduced in the treatment group compared to the control group (p < .01 and p < .01, respectively). Compared to control rats, diacerein-treated rats exhibited less fibrosis in the LV (14.65%¡À 7.27% vs. 22.57%¡À 8.94%; p < .01), lower levels of caspase-3 activity, and lower levels of NF-¦ÊB p65 transcription.

The family went missing from their home in Waltham Forest, east London, last week and were thought to have left via London City Airport, the Met said.
The mother is being held by Turkish Police. The children, aged from four to 12, were said to be safe and well.
The Met said it was liaising with Turkish authorities.
The BBC's special correspondent Lucy Manning said the 33-year-old mother was thought to be trying to join her sister and brother-in-law who travelled to Syria last year.
The brother-in-law is understood to have been a follower of the radical preacher Anjem Choudary, she added.
Richard Walton, of the Met's counter-terrorism command, thanked the public and the media for helping to find the family.
He said: "We had very real concerns that she may have been planning to travel with her children to Syria and she has now been detained with the children in Turkey."
Police officers first appealed for information about the family after the woman's husband contacted them on Wednesday to report them missing.
It was thought they had flown from London to Amsterdam last Tuesday.
Detectives later found the family had been pictured on security cameras at London City Airport before their flight.
Several cases have been reported recently in which women and children from the UK are thought to have travelled to parts of Syria, under the control of militant group the Islamic State.
More than 40 women and girls travelled to Syria from Britain in the last year, the Met Police has said.

Police believe Judith Ducker, 64, was injured during a raid at Wellgate News, Rotherham, on 1 September. She died in hospital on Thursday.
Paul Blueitt, 36, from Rotherham, has been charged with attempted murder and robbery.
Police are trying to locate the man and woman captured on CCTV at the time of the raid.
Officers said the couple were captured on film between 11:00 BST and 11:25 BST and they may have entered the shop and been the last people to have seen Mrs Ducker.
South Yorkshire Police said the witnesses were "crucial" to the investigation.
The force added it was waiting for further tests after a post-mortem examination failed to establish a cause of death for Mrs Ducker.
She is believed to have had underlying health conditions.
Mr Blueitt was remanded in custody at Sheffield Crown Court on 3 October.

human: To investigate whether effects on food intake are seen in obese subjects receiving exogenous administration of ghrelin.Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study of intravenous ghrelin at doses 1 pmol/kg/min and 5 pmol/kg/min.In all, 12 healthy lean subjects (mean body mass index (BMI) 20.5+/-0.17 kg/m(2)) and 12 healthy overweight and obese subjects (mean BMI 31.9+/-1.02 kg/m(2)).Food intake, appetite and palatability of food, ghrelin and other obesity-related hormones, growth hormone.Low-dose infusion of ghrelin increased ad libitum energy intake at a buffet meal in the obese group only (mean increase 36.6+/-9.4%, P<0.01.) High-dose ghrelin infusion increased energy intake in both groups (mean increase 20.1+/-10.6% in the lean and 70.1+/-15.5% in the obese, P<0.01 in both cases.) Ghrelin infusion increased palatability of food in the obese group.
LLM_1: This study investigates the effects of exogenous ghrelin on food intake in obese subjects through a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Twelve healthy lean subjects (mean BMI 20.5 ¡À 0.17 kg/m2) and twelve overweight/obese subjects (mean BMI 31.9 ¡À 1.02 kg/m2) received intravenous ghrelin at doses of 1 pmol/kg/min and 5 pmol/kg/min. Measurements included food intake, appetite, food palatability, ghrelin levels, and other obesity-related hormones. Low-dose ghrelin significantly increased ad libitum energy intake at a buffet meal in the obese group (mean increase 36.6 ¡À 9.4%, P < 0.01). High-dose ghrelin infusion raised energy intake in both groups (mean increase 20.1 ¡À 10.6% in lean and 70.1 ¡À 15.5% in obese, P < 0.01). Additionally, ghrelin infusion enhanced food palatability in the obese group.

human:
The Official Chart with Greg James will kick off the weekend at 16:00 BST every Friday on BBC Radio 1, as part of his drivetime show.
The move coincides with the music industry's launch of New Music Fridays in more than 45 countries.
All albums and singles will now be released globally at 00:01 on a Friday.
Currently albums and singles are released on different days around the world - for example, albums such as Madonna's Rebel Heart were released on Monday in the UK, Tuesday in the US and on Friday in Germany and Australia.
As well as the charts, record companies, artists, distributors and retailers have been working together to align with the new international release day.
According to research for the BPI (British Phonographic Industry), which represents the British music industry, 60% of consumers who buy or stream new music (who expressed a preference), prefer it to come out on a Saturday or Friday.
The most popular reasons include it being "the weekend" (36%), when they have "time to listen to new music" (26%) or time to go shopping or look online.
"In a business that is increasingly digital and global, the logic for a global release day is compelling," said Geoff Taylor, chief executive of BPI.
"Fans don't understand why they have to wait to legally access music that has already been released in other countries."
Official Charts Company chief executive, Martin Talbot, said the move to Fridays "ushers in a new era" for the chart, which has been going out on Sunday afternoon since it moved from Tuesdays in October 1987.
"Every Friday night will be party night for all the artists and their UK fans celebrating their latest chart position. It is going to be a fantastic new beginning," said Talbot.
As well as Radio 1, MTV UK will also move its TV coverage of the charts to a Friday, while the complete albums and singles top 100 will be published on the Official Charts website at 18:00 BST every Friday.
The first Friday chart, on 10 July, will be a five-day chart, following on from the final Sunday afternoon chart on 5 July.
The current Sunday chart show attracts around 1.2 million listeners, while Greg James' show attracts more than five million across the week.
The Official Chart Show with Clara Amfo will continue every Sunday until 5 July, from 16:00-19:00 BST on BBC Radio 1. The Official Chart with Greg James takes over at 16:00 BST every Friday from 10 July.
LLM_1:
The Official Chart with Greg James will launch on Fridays at 16:00 BST on BBC Radio 1, coinciding with the music industry's global initiative, New Music Fridays, which will see all albums and singles released worldwide at 00:01 on Fridays. Previously, releases varied by country, with albums like Madonna's *Rebel Heart* debuting on different days in the UK, US, and Germany.

Record companies, artists, and retailers are collaborating to align with the new release schedule. Research from the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) indicates that 60% of consumers favor Friday or Saturday releases, citing reasons such as having time to listen (26%) or shop (36%).

Geoff Taylor, BPI's chief executive, emphasized the need for a global release day, stating that fans are frustrated by delays in accessing music available in other countries. Martin Talbot, chief executive of the Official Charts Company, noted that this shift marks a "new era" for the chart, which has aired on Sundays since October 1987. 

MTV UK will also adjust its chart coverage to Fridays, and the complete top 100 albums and singles will be available on the Official Charts website at 18:00 BST. The first Friday chart on July 10 will be a five-day tally, following the final Sunday chart on July 5. The current Sunday show draws about 1.2 million listeners, while Greg James' show averages over five million weekly. The Official Chart Show with Clara Amfo will continue on Sundays until July 5, transitioning to Greg James' Friday slot from July 10.
LLM_2:
The Official Chart with Greg James is set to debut on Fridays at 16:00 BST on BBC Radio 1, aligning with the music industry's global initiative, New Music Fridays. This initiative will see all albums and singles released worldwide at 00:01 on Fridays, a significant shift from the previous practice where release days varied by country. Notable examples include Madonna's album *Rebel Heart*, which debuted on different days across the UK, US, and Germany.

In a bid to synchronize with the new release schedule, record companies, artists, and retailers are joining forces. Research from the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) reveals that 60% of consumers prefer Friday or Saturday releases, with 26% citing the opportunity to listen and 36% noting increased shopping time as key reasons.

Geoff Taylor, BPI's chief executive, highlighted the necessity for a global release day, addressing fan frustrations over delays in accessing music that is available in other countries. Martin Talbot, chief executive of the Official Charts Company, described this transition as marking a "new era" for the chart, which has traditionally aired on Sundays since its inception in October 1987.

Additionally, MTV UK will also shift its chart coverage to Fridays. The complete top 100 albums and singles will be accessible on the Official Charts website at 18:00 BST. The inaugural Friday chart on July 10 will be a five-day tally, following the final Sunday chart on July 5. Currently, the Sunday show attracts approximately 1.2 million listeners, while Greg James' show boasts an average of over five million weekly. The Official Chart Show with Clara Amfo will continue on Sundays until July 5, before transitioning to Greg James' Friday slot starting July 10.

human: In 1996 Brewster Kahle, with Bruce Gilliat, developed software to crawl and download all publicly accessible World Wide Web pages, the Gopher hierarchy, the Netnews (Usenet) bulletin board system, and downloadable software. The information collected by these "crawlers" does not include all the information available on the Internet, since much of the data is restricted by the publisher or stored in databases that are not accessible. These "crawlers" also respect the robots exclusion standard for websites whose owners opt for them not to appear in search results or be cached. To overcome inconsistencies in partially cached web sites, Archive-It.org was developed in 2005 by the Internet Archive as a means of allowing institutions and content creators to voluntarily harvest and preserve collections of digital content, and create digital archives.
LLM_1: In 1996, Brewster Kahle and Bruce Gilliat developed software to crawl and download publicly accessible World Wide Web pages, the Gopher hierarchy, the Netnews (Usenet) bulletin board system, and downloadable software. The data collected by these "crawlers" does not encompass all online information, as much is restricted by publishers or stored in inaccessible databases. These crawlers also adhere to the robots exclusion standard for websites whose owners wish to prevent their appearance in search results or caching. To address inconsistencies in partially cached websites, the Internet Archive launched Archive-It.org in 2005, enabling institutions and content creators to voluntarily harvest, preserve, and create digital archives of their collections.
LLM_2: In 1996, Brewster Kahle and Bruce Gilliat developed software designed to crawl and download publicly accessible World Wide Web pages, the Gopher hierarchy, Usenet (Netnews) bulletin board systems, and downloadable software. The data collected by these "crawlers" does not encompass all online information, as much of it is restricted by publishers or stored in inaccessible databases. These crawlers also comply with the Robots Exclusion Protocol, which allows website owners to prevent their content from appearing in search results or being cached. To address inconsistencies in partially cached websites, the Internet Archive launched Archive-It.org in 2005. This platform enables institutions and content creators to voluntarily harvest, preserve, and create digital archives of their collections.

The snow swirled in the doors of the emergency room as paramedics filed quickly and quietly out. The lights of the ambulance still strobing on the walls of the small county hospital, and then they were gone. 
 
 A young man emerges from the hospital corridor shortly after, rounds the corner to waiting area, and sits heavily in the chair across from his wife's elderly parents. Their are eyes still focussed on the hallway from which he had just emerged. The young man looked up and said quietly, `` We'll name the baby Jacob. She's had that name picked out for months.'' 
 
 `` And Jill? How is Jill?'' asked her mother. 
 
 The young man looked away, then down at his hands, and then began to sob.

 Sentences 10 
 Paragraphs 4 
 Reading Level 11-12th Grade

"And Jill? How is Jill?" her mother asked.

The young man looked away, down at his hands, and began to sob.
