He sank into a chair opposite his wife's elderly parents, their eyes fixed intently on the hallway, as if willing their daughter to return. He took a deep breath and said softly, ¡°We¡¯ll name the baby Jacob. She¡¯s had that name picked out for months.¡±

¡°And Jill? How is Jill?¡± her mother inquired, her voice trembling with concern.

The young man¡¯s gaze fell to his hands, and a wave of grief washed over him as he began to sob, the weight of his sorrow palpable in the stark silence of the room.

human:
What people do n't understand is there is no warzone in space. On planets, sure. Terra Prime has it worst. Got nuked so many times back in the Old Times. And even now half the planet is inhospitable. 
 
 Planetary wars are kind of a taboo now. Interstellar conflict that words and treaties ca n't solve? Settle it outside. In space. Where there are n't civilians. And there have been so many space combats over the terracycles. I've been involved in a few of them, too. I was part of the Intess: elite, fighter pilots. Had been on a couple of missions aboard state-of-art, versatile, quick and hard-hitting bombers. 
 
 After I was discharged I was sent back to the surface. 
 
 Now, everyone who's been in space long enough ca n't just suddenly go back to the planetary confines of.. the planet. Sure, you can planet hop and all that, but there are not many jobs that involve one-manned piloting of a spacecraft. You ironically miss the artificial gravity aboard vast battle vessels. 
 
 What was I saying? 
 
 Right. There are no warzones in space. This is because the debris from exploded ships just get carried away by their own momentum. Never really slowing down. Just drifting through space. Expensive, rare parts. Just floating endlessly away in whichever direction they had been launched from explosions or whatever. 
 
 And that's where I come in. I'm a scavenger. Kind of a sad deal for someone of my stature. But hey, when you do n't have any loved ones back on the surface to go back to. When you do n't really have much of a life-you know what, I just like being out in space. 
 
 So yeah, I navigate through the galaxy aboard a medium ship. A medium ship is a fairly small ship that can house up to eight crew members ( fifteen on a short haul ), and has two cargo bays to store all yours' and the crews' things. And whatever cargo you have to pick up. It, due to some compatibility management done by my engineer, can also do ftl jumps. Ftl jumps are a pretty fun concept. 
 
 Basically, you fire and latch on to these things called'metagods'. They are essentially some kind of space virus that can influence another plane of existence which they used to travel. And in this plane, a few feet can be pretty much a few light-years on the normal plane. 
 
 Now, you can buy canisters of metagods ( provided your ship is ftl capable and you have a metagod bay ) and keep replenishing them when you run out. This is only worth it if you rarely do ftl jumps. Because meta God canisters are really expensive and you'll have to keep buying them. 
 
 Another option is using metagnets. They are nets that catch metagods whenever they're near, and keep them stored up. This is what we have. 
 
 So we pick coordinates, face the coordinates, then we fire the metagods towards the direction we want to go, and boom, they try to use the other plane to escape, and we use them like reigned horses and jump off once we reach our place. And then the metagnets catch some more. 
 
 I know what you're thinking. Why are n't we farming metagods? Well, it's true there are more metagods the further you are from a star. So you just got ta get to where is n't much sunlight to find them. It's also true that they are the most sought after life forms in the galaxy. But come on. Metagnets are pretty sufficient. And we usually have excess metagods which we sell on the black anyway. Metagnets are really really expensive and hard as fuck to maintain. Expensive, too. But my engineer knows her stuff. 
 
 
 Ok, back to space warzones, or the lack of them. We essentially go to where there was once a battle. And then our mathematician calculates space storms and gravity waves and all that juicy stuff to find out where most of the debris might be drifting. And then we just follow his guts and calculations and collect the parts. 
 
 We sell these parts back to the manufacturers, or whoever paid a lot. And people pay a lot for spacecraft parts. 
 
 My medium ship is called Sirhowy by the way. And my crew included me, the captain. Suzy, the engineer. Tom, the mathematician. Ryushewa, the doctor. And finally my cyborg pal, J428C. We call him Jay. My name is Barry. 
 
 So that's pretty much what we do. Or did. 
 
 We were captured, you see. The Northern Outer Rim Territories ( NORTh ) were a sad bunch. They occupied, as their title suggests, the Northern outer rim of the galaxy. They were miners and farmers. Commercial metagods exist because of them. And everyone knows the top-of-the-line ships are made from tyrrinium. The lightest, hardest and strongest metal known to man. And the metal can only be found in the NORTh. 
 
 But the NORTh are pretty much laughed at. The situation is this: the closest your system is to the center of the galaxy, the more important you are. Which is kinda stupid and hypocritical to what the Republic Galactic Systems stands for. But anyway, NORTh justifiably hated how they were treated. They pretty much controlled most of the monopoly on ftl travel. And tyrrinium can only be found there. But does the RSG keep them up to date and reward them? No. So war! 
 
 And we accidentally got caught in the middle of it. 
 
 Okay, it's my fault, mostly. We knew there had been small battles around the NORTh, so we decided to go to one of the spots afterwards. You know, so the scent of the debris is fresh, so to speak. And word was the NORTh were using some new kind of ships. Single fighter ships that have massive firepower and fuel efficiency. And since it's a NORTh design, it's obviously going to be full tyrrinium. 
 
 We had to get our hands on some of that. I wanted it most, though. I missed one-manned ships. The GRS did not issue them anymore. So unless you were part of a convoy with large vessels, good luck getting your hands on one. 
 
 Here's a gist of what happened. We entered the aftermath of the battle, and actually saw some debris along the way. And lo and behold, an almost fully intact NORTh one-manner. We caught it in our tractor beam and were going to do a ftl jump back, when suddenly a large vessel jumped in front of us and caught *us* on their tractor beam. 
 
 It was n't a trap. It was more of us not cloaking well enough. The one-manner had a man inside, too. Still alive. The Northerners retrieved him and held us in custody for trying to steal their ship designs. Like what? There were GRS sympathisers up in the NORTh who would do that for us anyway eventually. 
 
 But whatever, we were taken as prisoners and it was all my fault. 
 
 *part 2 soon if I'm not lazy*
LLM_1:
What people often overlook is that there are no warzones in space. On planets, yes¡ªTerra Prime suffers the most, having endured countless nuclear strikes in the Old Times, leaving half its surface inhospitable.

Planetary wars are now taboo. When treaties fail, conflicts are settled in the void of space, devoid of civilians. I've witnessed my share of these battles, serving as a fighter pilot with the elite Intess. I flew state-of-the-art bombers on several missions before my discharge sent me back to the surface.

For those of us who¡¯ve spent significant time in space, returning to a planet feels restrictive. Sure, you can hop between worlds, but jobs for solo spacecraft pilots are scarce. Ironically, you miss the artificial gravity of vast battle vessels.

So, back to the point¡ªspace lacks warzones. Debris from destroyed ships drifts endlessly, propelled by momentum, valuable parts lost to the cosmos.

That¡¯s where I come in¡ªas a scavenger. It may seem like a sad fate for someone like me, but without loved ones waiting on the surface and little else to cling to, I find solace in the vastness of space.

I navigate the galaxy on my medium ship, Sirhowy. It accommodates up to eight crew members, with two cargo bays for our belongings and whatever salvage we collect. My ship, thanks to some clever engineering, is FTL-capable¡ªallowing for fun jumps through space.

We harness entities called "metagods" for FTL travel. These space viruses manipulate another plane of existence, enabling us to cover vast distances in mere feet. We can purchase metagod canisters or use metagnets to capture them, which is our preferred method.

We choose coordinates, fire the metagods, and let them guide us through the alternate plane. Once we arrive, we catch more metagods with our nets.

You might wonder why we don¡¯t farm metagods. True, they are more abundant away from stars, but farming is impractical. Plus, metagnets are sufficient for our needs, and we often sell excess metagods on the black market. Maintaining metagnets is costly, but my engineer excels at it.

Returning to the topic of space warzones, we venture to sites of past battles. Our mathematician predicts the drift of debris using complex calculations, and we follow his lead to collect valuable parts. We then resell these parts to manufacturers or the highest bidder.

My crew consists of myself, the captain; Suzy, the engineer; Tom, the mathematician; Ryushewa, the doctor; and my cyborg friend, J428C, whom we call Jay. 

However, our scavenging days came to an abrupt halt. We were captured in the Northern Outer Rim Territories (NORTh), home to miners and farmers who supply the galaxy with metagods and the prized tyrrinium metal, the strongest known. The NORTh, despite controlling a monopoly on FTL travel, feels neglected by the Republic Galactic Systems, igniting their resentment and leading to conflict.

We, unfortunately, found ourselves caught in the fray. My fault, really. Aware of skirmishes in the area, we decided to scavenge immediately after a battle, hoping to find fresh debris. Rumors suggested the NORTh were deploying new, powerful single-fighter ships made of tyrrinium.

Upon entering the battlefield¡¯s aftermath, we spotted a nearly intact NORTh fighter and ensnared it with our tractor beam, ready to make our escape via FTL jump. Suddenly, a larger vessel appeared, capturing us in its own tractor beam.

It wasn¡¯t a trap; we simply failed to cloak sufficiently. The fighter contained a living pilot, and the Northerners took him and us captive for attempting to steal their designs. Yet, there are GRS sympathizers in the NORTh who would have aided us eventually.

Now, here we are, imprisoned¡ªmy fault entirely.

human:
Complacency. That is why I was rejected from the program when I was younger, they would come at night, the greys. I had the average reaction so terrified by the natural state of these beings and their abduction technique that I was paralyzed like most. Even if you found the mental capacity to quantify what was happening and somehow process it they had alternate means of subduing you in the forums they call it psychic probing. They can create a visual representation of any scenario and blind you from the reality of time, but to be frank as someone who has experienced it multiple times it's basically mind rape. 
 
 They stopped coming when I was about thirteen, because I was able to break the trances and somewhat fight back, this bothered them and while restrained I could tell they would discuss it in'their' way no words but the mental shouting was evidently displayed by hand movements and finger pointing. The Program I speak of, I later found out to be a form of colonization through alien hybridization of human and the greys. I found this out by accepting a job in mid level government and making it my life's work to find answers. 
 
 I was not the only one they took, and they will pay dearly for what they have done, through regression hypnosis I have detailed memories of the things they did to the others. Cutting them up, splaying their live bodies out like frogs on a high school lab table, I suppose I was lucky in that aspect they never went beyond mind raping me. 
 
 With the help of some long trusted friends I broke into a facility and found three names of interest in the databanks which I siphoned to a hard drive. My name was in the nonviable column... complacency was always key, those that can resist are a threat to their colonization. Not even our government who works side by side with some of them know what their numbers are. My story is one of shadows and deep throats with whispers that cost the ones who speak them their lives. 
 
 I used the database to infiltrate one of their recon ships by taking the place of a man they had been abducting for thirty years. He was thankful and bordering on suicide by the time I met him, I slept in his bed for three days and waited assuming the role hoping that the recon team of greys would not recognize that I was not him before they got me on their ship. It worked. 
 
 There is a base ganglia in the pituitary that can make you immune to their psychic probing by severing it. Through conditioning you can even probe their minds but I have only seen one little boy capable of this feat and it was long ago. 
 
 The three greys assumed the routine, levitating me onto their ship. They led me down a long corridor into one of many rooms and strapped me to the table and I appeared complacent, a few gadgets were produced by the larger of the three greys who dragged a large familiar machine like a dentist's lamp to the opposite side of the table. The gadget's would certainly reveal through some sort of identification tech that I was not the man they were supposed to abduct. 
 
 I moved fast like I had trained on the test dummies the gunmen had created, using my feet to hit the restraint release button the bigger of the three tried to pin me and lock my gaze for mind raping. 
 
 `` You probably do n't remember me.'' I said producing the weapon hidden in my silk pajama pants head butting him as he got closer with a hollow thud. 
 
 I shoved him back being careful not to puncture his skin with it, their blood when mixed with oxygen creates a nitrous gas poisonous to humans. The biggest grey fell on his back and I took the opportunity to shove the ice pick right into the back of his neck, it instantly killed him as the poison began to slowly leak. The other two were shocked by this display and hesitated allowing me to grab one before the other darted off to warn the rest of the crew. 
 
 He put up little fight and I finally saw the same fear reflected back as when I was a child in it's cold stoney black eyes and it's thoughts were revealed to me as I held it's tiny neck in my hand. My God, there were millions of them warships lined as far as the eye could see in the vastness of space. History lessons this thing has learned about his own race, millenias of colonizing smaller planets for resources and DNA to sustain their own failing life force. Everything I wanted to know revealed in the blink of an eye. Including where to find her, they kept test subjects for breeding the hybrids, if she were alive she would be there. 
 
 This one did not know how to fly the ship, a safety protocol for just such scenarios, I would need to find one of the pilots to get to where she was at. A roving facility on the moon that served as a base for their recon ships, how strange a thing to think. I icepicked the one I now held in my hands and closed the room door, soon the room would fill with nitrous gas as their bodies rapidly decayed. I will place the rest of any corpses in these rooms I mentally noted. [ End of Part1 ]

Complacency. That¡¯s why I was rejected from the program in my youth. The greys would come at night, and I was paralyzed with fear at their abduction techniques, just like most. Even if I could grasp what was happening, they had other ways to subdue me¡ªwhat they call psychic probing. They can create vivid illusions, distorting the perception of time. Frankly, it felt like mind rape.

They ceased their visits when I was thirteen, as I learned to break their trances and fight back. This seemed to disturb them; while restrained, I could sense their silent communication through frantic hand gestures. The program I later discovered aimed at colonization through the hybridization of humans and greys. My quest for answers began when I took a mid-level government job.

I was not the only one they abducted, and I intend to make them pay for their atrocities. Through regression hypnosis, I uncovered horrific memories of what they did to others¡ªmutilating them, laying their bodies out like specimens. I suppose I was fortunate; they never went beyond mental violation with me.

With trusted friends, I infiltrated a facility and extracted three names from their databanks, finding my name listed as nonviable. Complacency had always been key¡ªthose who resist threaten their colonization efforts. Not even our government, which collaborates with them, knows their true numbers. My story is one of shadows and dangerous whispers that can cost lives.

Using the database, I assumed the identity of a man they had abducted for thirty years. He was near suicide when we met. I slept in his bed for three days, hoping the greys wouldn¡¯t recognize me before I boarded their ship. It worked.

There¡¯s a ganglia in the pituitary that can render one immune to their psychic probing by severing it. Conditioning might allow one to probe their minds, but I¡¯ve only seen one boy capable of this long ago.

The three greys levitated me onto their ship and led me into a room, strapping me to a table. I feigned compliance as one of them produced a device that would likely reveal I wasn¡¯t the man they intended to abduct.

I moved quickly, using my feet to hit the restraint release button. The largest grey tried to pin me and lock my gaze for probing.

¡°You probably don¡¯t remember me,¡± I said, revealing a concealed weapon and headbutting him as he approached.

I shoved him back, careful not to puncture his skin¡ªtheir blood mixes with oxygen to create a toxic gas. The largest grey fell, and I seized the moment to plunge the ice pick into the back of his neck, killing him instantly as the poison leaked. The other two hesitated in shock, allowing me to grab one before the other fled to alert the crew.

He put up little resistance, and I saw the same fear in his cold, stony eyes that I had known as a child. His thoughts flooded into my mind; there were millions of them, warships stretching across the vastness of space. I learned of their history¡ªmillennia of colonizing smaller planets for resources and DNA to prolong their failing lives. Everything I sought to know came in an instant, including her whereabouts. They kept test subjects for breeding hybrids, and if she was alive, she would be there.

This grey didn¡¯t know how to fly the ship¡ªsafety protocols prevented it. I needed to find a pilot to reach her, located in a roving facility on the moon. How strange to think. I killed the one in my grasp and closed the room door; soon, the space would fill with toxic gas as their bodies decayed. I mentally noted to dispose of the remaining corpses in these rooms.

Damn this floor is cold, whoever did this could have at least given me a pair of socks... I look up and see a timer, and I realize that the time is winding down. I look back at the two red buttons, then at the timer once more, then at the buttons, then I think about the buttons on my favorite shirt, I recently lost a button on my favorite shirt. I close my eyes, ( even though I know I'm about to press the one on the left ) bring my hand down to rest atop of the button and gently press it down. I quickly slam my hand down on the other button and the gas quickly vanishes from the room, 35 minutes left on the timer. The Algerian Football Federation announced his departure on its official website, saying that it had "ended his contract amicably at his request."
According to local reports, the Frenchman had told his bosses of his wish to leave on Thursday, on the plane back from their Africa Cup of Nations match in Ethiopia.
The former France international was appointed in 2014 and speculation surrounding his position had been growing for some time.
The Algerian Football Federation confirmed that Nabil Neghiz - the team's assistant national coach - would take interim charge of the Desert Foxes.
After three wins and a draw, Algeria are top of their qualifying group for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.
They need just one win from their remaining games, at Seychelles on 3 June and at home to Lesotho on 2 September, to guarantee qualification.
Algeria are also into the final group stage of 2018 World Cup qualifying.
The draw takes place in Cairo on 24 June 2016, with the final round starting in October.

human: This study was intended to delineate the association between digestive tract malignancies and bacteraemia due to Streptococcus gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus.We reviewed the medical records and microbiological results of patients with bacteraemia due to Streptococcus bovis during the period 2000-2012. Species and subspecies identification of isolates originally classified as S. bovis was confirmed by 16S rRNA sequencing and PCR restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) assays. Minimum inhibitory concentrations of antimicrobial agents were determined by the broth microdilution method.Of the 172 S. bovis complex isolates obtained from 172 patients (age range, <1-94 years, median age, 66) with bacteraemia, 31 isolates were identified to be S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus, 126 were S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus, and 15 were shown to be Streptococcus infantarius. The majority (n = 104, 60%) of patients were male and had underlying malignancies (n = 87, 51%). Bacteraemia due to S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus was significantly associated with endocarditis while S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus was more likely to be associated with malignancies of the digestive tract, including gastric, pancreatic, hepatobiliary and colorectal cancers. Septic shock at presentation was the only factor associated with mortality among patients with bacteraemia due to either subspecies of S. bovis. Isolates of S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus had higher rates of resistance to macrolides and clindamycin than isolates of S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus.
LLM_1: This study aimed to explore the relationship between digestive tract cancers and bacteraemia caused by Streptococcus gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus. We reviewed medical records and microbiological data from patients with S. bovis bacteraemia between 2000 and 2012. Identification of isolates initially classified as S. bovis was confirmed through 16S rRNA sequencing and PCR restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) assays. Minimum inhibitory concentrations of antimicrobial agents were measured using the broth microdilution method. Among 172 S. bovis complex isolates from patients aged <1 to 94 years (median age 66), 31 were identified as S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus, 126 as S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus, and 15 as Streptococcus infantarius. Most patients (n = 104, 60%) were male, with 51% (n = 87) having underlying malignancies. Bacteraemia caused by S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus was significantly linked to endocarditis, whereas S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus was more frequently associated with digestive tract malignancies, including gastric, pancreatic, hepatobiliary, and colorectal cancers. Septic shock at presentation was the sole factor correlated with mortality among patients with either subspecies. Isolates of S. gallolyticus subspecies pasteurianus exhibited higher resistance rates to macrolides and clindamycin compared to those of S. gallolyticus subspecies gallolyticus.
LLM_2: This study investigates the association between digestive tract cancers and bacteraemia induced by *Streptococcus gallolyticus* subspecies *pasteurianus*. We conducted a comprehensive review of medical records and microbiological data for patients diagnosed with *S. bovis* bacteraemia from 2000 to 2012. The identification of isolates initially classified as *S. bovis* was validated through 16S rRNA sequencing and polymerase chain reaction restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) assays. Minimum inhibitory concentrations of various antimicrobial agents were determined using the broth microdilution method. Among the 172 *S. bovis* complex isolates from patients ranging in age from less than one year to 94 years (median age 66), 31 were identified as *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *gallolyticus*, 126 as *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *pasteurianus*, and 15 as *Streptococcus infantarius*. The majority of patients (n = 104, 60%) were male, and 51% (n = 87) had underlying malignancies. Bacteraemia caused by *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *gallolyticus* was significantly associated with endocarditis, whereas *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *pasteurianus* showed a higher frequency of association with digestive tract malignancies, including gastric, pancreatic, hepatobiliary, and colorectal cancers. Septic shock at presentation was identified as the sole factor correlated with mortality in patients with either subspecies. Notably, isolates of *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *pasteurianus* displayed elevated resistance rates to macrolides and clindamycin compared to those of *S. gallolyticus* subspecies *gallolyticus*.

This paper studies the problem of PAC learning an axis-aligned rectangle in d-dimensions under the constraint of differential privacy (DP). The class of d-dimensional axis-aligned rectangles can be viewed as a generalization of threshold functions. Previous work have shown that the problem of privately learning thresholds is equivalent (up to constants) to the problem of privately selecting the interior point of a set of totally ordered points. A naive approach to extend this result to high-dimensional rectangles is to compute the threshold in each dimension separately and then use advanced composition. Unfortunately the dependence of the samples complexity of this approach on the dimension is $d^{1.5}$ (rather than $d$). Therefore, this problem captures one of the main technical challenges of designing DP methods, namely handling high-dimensional data. 

The authors introduce a carefully constructed algorithm that applies the private interior point algorithm on each dimension, but at each step prunes some points in the dataset so that they are not used in future steps. Intuitively, this approach allows them to overcome the expensive advanced composition since not too many points will be reused. [and as a consequence, the resulting method has only linear dependence on $d$].

This is an important and fundamental result in private PAC learning. The proof technique that the authors develop is interesting and will be of interest to the general DP community. The authors do a good job in explaining why extended existing solutions for the 1-dimensional case to d-dimensions introduces looseness in the sample complexity bounds. The introduction of the paper is well written. Beyond the introduction, the writing seems to be a bit rushed and that there is a lot of room for improvement in the presentation. Some places where the paper can use some improvement/clarification are highlighted in below (SUBMISSION refers to the line number in the main file, while SUPPLEMENT refers to the line number in the supplementary material)

Line 260-262 (SUBMISSION): In definition 2.3, I believe it would be helpful to explicitly say that ¡°it holds for any $n \geq m$ that:¡± instead of ¡°it holds that:¡± since the variable $n$ used in the probability statement at the end of the definition has not been introduced.

Line 286-289 (SUBMISSION): It will be helpful to explain what $\Delta$ is in the statement. The authors can perhaps modify the statement to say something like ¡°Let IP be an algorithm for solving the interior point problem with sample complexity $\Delta$.¡± Also, in this theorem and in many other Lemma statements, the bounds on some parameters like $\alpha,\beta, \varepsilon$ etc are not explicitly stated.

Comments regarding proof of privacy (Lemma 3.4):

Line 310-313 (SUBMISSION): The authors claim that the first part of the algorithm in the inner loop right before the interior point algorithm is used satisfies $(\varepsilon,0)$-DP, and claim that the inner loop ¡°can be seen as a composition of a Laplace mechanism (represented by the addition of Laplace noise) and the given mechanism $\mathcal{A}$.¡± It is not immediately clear why this can be viewed as a Laplace mechanism and furthermore, it is not clear how the choice of the scale parameter for the Laplace noise guarantees $(\varepsilon,0)$-DP. The authors should clarify this, as it is key to the correctness of the proof.

Line 359-361 (SUPPLEMENT): Going from the inequality on line 359 to the inequality on line 361 is not immediately obvious to me, even after plugging in the value for z and trying to get the same upper bound as in the equation on line 361.

Line 333 (SUPPLEMENT): (minor question) the authors prove the bound $Pr\left[\ln\left(\frac{\mathcal{RM}(S)=p}{\mathcal{RM}(S¡¯)=p}\right)\cdot \mathbb{I}_{p\in G} \geq \widetilde{\varepsilon}\right] \leq 2\delta$, however I think the upper bound can be $\delta$ without the factor of 2?

Comments regarding proof of accuracy (Lemma 3.5):

1. This proof is relatively straightforward to follow, however I have a few concerns. I don¡¯t see anywhere (neither in the proofs nor in the pseudocode) that explicitly states that the inputs to the algorithm are the positive points in the dataset. I assumed that this is the case since this is what makes the proof make sense to me and this was mentioned very briefly (and informally) in the introduction where the authors stated on Line 91-92 (SUBMISSION): ¡°For simplicity, we assume that $S$ contains ¡°enough¡± positive elements, as otherwise we could simply return the all-zero hypothesis.¡±. This statement was not made formal in the paper and I think it is important to explain why it is OK to make this assumption.
2. When analyzing the probability that the empirical error is large, the authors used a union bound on each dimension. So, shouldn¡¯t the term $6d\Delta\log(1/\beta)\log(1/\delta)$ be $6d\Delta\log(2d/\beta)\log(1/\delta)$ to ensure the empirical error is low with probability at least $1-\beta/2$ ?
3. Why did the authors choose $\mu = 4\Delta\log^2(1/\delta)$ instead of $\mu = 4\Delta\log(1/\delta)\log(1/\beta)$?
LLM_1:
This paper investigates the PAC learning of axis-aligned rectangles in d-dimensions under differential privacy (DP). The class of d-dimensional axis-aligned rectangles generalizes threshold functions. Previous studies have shown that privately learning thresholds is equivalent (up to constants) to privately selecting an interior point from a totally ordered set. A naive extension of this result to high-dimensional rectangles involves computing thresholds separately for each dimension and applying advanced composition. However, this method leads to a sample complexity dependence of $d^{1.5}$, rather than $d$, highlighting a significant challenge in developing DP methods for high-dimensional data.

The authors propose a well-structured algorithm that applies the private interior point algorithm across dimensions while pruning points from the dataset at each step. This strategy effectively mitigates the costly effects of advanced composition by limiting point reuse, resulting in a method with only linear dependence on $d$.

This fundamental result contributes significantly to private PAC learning, and the authors¡¯ proof technique is noteworthy for the broader DP community. They clearly articulate the shortcomings of extending existing solutions from the 1-dimensional case to d-dimensions, which introduces looseness in sample complexity bounds. The introduction is well-written, but the overall presentation could benefit from refinement. Specific areas for improvement are highlighted below (SUBMISSION refers to line numbers in the main file, and SUPPLEMENT refers to line numbers in the supplementary material).

Line 260-262 (SUBMISSION): In Definition 2.3, it would be clearer to state, ¡°it holds for any $n \geq m$ that:¡± instead of ¡°it holds that:¡± since the variable $n$ in the probability statement is not previously introduced.

Line 286-289 (SUBMISSION): It would be helpful to clarify what $\Delta$ represents. The authors could revise the statement to say, ¡°Let IP be an algorithm for solving the interior point problem with sample complexity $\Delta$.¡± Additionally, in this theorem and other Lemmas, the bounds on parameters like $\alpha, \beta, \varepsilon$, etc., should be explicitly stated.

Comments regarding the proof of privacy (Lemma 3.4):

Line 310-313 (SUBMISSION): The authors assert that the initial part of the algorithm in the inner loop before the interior point algorithm satisfies $(\varepsilon,0)$-DP, describing it as a composition of a Laplace mechanism (via the addition of Laplace noise) and the mechanism $\mathcal{A}$. However, it is unclear why this qualifies as a Laplace mechanism, and how the scale parameter for the Laplace noise ensures $(\varepsilon,0)$-DP. This clarification is crucial for the proof's validity.

Line 359-361 (SUPPLEMENT): The transition from the inequality on line 359 to that on line 361 is not immediately clear, even after substituting the value for $z$ to attempt matching the upper bound in line 361.

Line 333 (SUPPLEMENT): (minor question) The authors prove the bound $Pr\left[\ln\left(\frac{\mathcal{RM}(S)=p}{\mathcal{RM}(S¡¯)=p} ight)\cdot \mathbb{I}_{p\in G} \geq \widetilde{\varepsilon} ight] \leq 2\delta$, but I believe the upper bound could be $\delta$ without the factor of 2.

Comments regarding the proof of accuracy (Lemma 3.5):

1. While the proof is generally straightforward, I have concerns. There is no explicit statement in the proofs or pseudocode indicating that the algorithm's inputs are the positive points in the dataset. I inferred this from a brief mention in the introduction (Line 91-92, SUBMISSION): ¡°For simplicity, we assume that $S$ contains ¡®enough¡¯ positive elements, as otherwise we could simply return the all-zero hypothesis.¡± This assumption needs formal clarification.

2. In analyzing the probability of large empirical error, the authors utilize a union bound across dimensions. Shouldn¡¯t the term $6d\Delta\log(1/\beta)\log(1/\delta)$ be adjusted to $6d\Delta\log(2d/\beta)\log(1/\delta)$ to ensure the empirical error remains low with probability at least $1-\beta/2$?

3. Why did the authors select $\mu = 4\Delta\log^2(1/\delta)$ instead of $\mu = 4\Delta\log(1/\delta)\log(1/\beta)$?

human:
Jaywick, near Clacton, was found to be the country's most deprived area, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) has reported.
It found the Middlesbrough council area had the highest proportion of deprived neighbourhoods, while Birmingham had the largest number.
Officials judged 32,844 neighbourhoods across England for the study.
The department's Indices of Deprivation scored neighbourhoods according to seven key areas including crime, health and employment.
It found almost half of Middlesbrough's 42 neighbourhoods were among the most deprived 10% nationally, while it classed 162 of Birmingham's 253 neighbourhoods as highly-deprived.
Report author Baljit Gill said: "There are concentrations of deprivation in large urban conurbations, areas that have historically had large heavy industry, manufacturing and or mining sectors, coastal towns, and large parts of east London.
"There are also pockets of deprivation surrounded by less deprived places in every region of England."
Jaywick was also named the most deprived neighbourhood following the 2010 report.
Gill Elkins, of the Jaywick and Tudor Residents Association, said she was disappointed but not surprised by Jaywick retaining its ranking.
She also said the latest findings, based on figures from 2012-13, will fail to take into account recent investment in improving roads and homes.
Ms Elkins said: "A lot of our infrastructure still needs improving but things are happening here.
32,844
Neighbourhoods surveyed
3,284 considered "highly-deprived" in 2015
83% also featured among 2010's most deprived
61% proportion of council districts containing at least one of England's most deprived neighbourhoods
"There is still a lot of community spirit here, everyone knows each other and is willing to help each other out, things like that don't seem to be considered as part of the deprivation figures."
Clacton MP Douglas Carswell said government investment was needed to stop the Jaywick area from "spiralling" further.
The UKIP politician said a minimum housing standard is needed to stop the government "subsidising squalor".
Leader of the Labour-run Blackpool Council Simon Blackburn said he was not surprised at the data.
"Every day we see the struggles that Blackpool families face. That is why every morning every primary school child in Blackpool can receive a free breakfast," he said.
"If we don't provide it there will be children who don't have anything to eat until lunchtime - that is the harsh reality."
A DCLG spokesman said: "We will ensure that every part of Britain benefits from a growing economy and that everyone who works hard gets the opportunities they need to succeed."
Elsewhere, South Tyneside's overall deprivation score rose by just over 10% since 2010 - the largest percentage increase for a single area.
Hackney in London saw the the largest improvement in its score since 2010, with nearly 25%.
But the report warned the figures represent relative deprivation, and do not represent changes in actual deprivation over time.
"Differences between areas in their actual levels of deprivation may be very small," it said.
LLM_1:
Jaywick, near Clacton, has been identified as the most deprived area in England, according to a report from the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG). The study assessed 32,844 neighbourhoods, finding Middlesbrough had the highest proportion of deprived areas, while Birmingham had the most in total.

The Indices of Deprivation evaluated neighbourhoods based on seven criteria, including crime, health, and employment. Nearly half of Middlesbrough's 42 neighbourhoods ranked in the most deprived 10% nationally, with 162 of Birmingham's 253 also classified as highly deprived. Report author Baljit Gill noted that deprivation is concentrated in urban areas, regions with heavy industry, coastal towns, and parts of east London, often surrounded by less deprived locales.

Jaywick has maintained its ranking as the most deprived neighbourhood since the 2010 report. Gill Elkins from the Jaywick and Tudor Residents Association expressed disappointment but noted that recent investments in infrastructure have not been reflected in the figures. She highlighted community spirit as a positive aspect often overlooked in deprivation metrics.

Clacton MP Douglas Carswell emphasized the need for government investment to prevent further decline in Jaywick, advocating for a minimum housing standard to combat poor living conditions. Simon Blackburn, leader of Blackpool Council, acknowledged the struggles faced by local families, highlighting the provision of free breakfasts for primary school children to address food insecurity.

A DCLG spokesperson assured that efforts would be made to ensure all regions benefit from economic growth. South Tyneside saw the largest increase in deprivation since 2010 at over 10%, while Hackney experienced the most significant improvement with a nearly 25% reduction in its score. However, the report cautioned that the figures reflect relative deprivation and not changes in actual living conditions over time, as differences in deprivation levels can be minimal between areas.

Sanity. I remember sanity. I remember innocence. 
 
 For me, it all started fifteen years ago, though that day often feels a lifetime away. It started out as a good day, a great one even. I remember the loud engine of the ship's crane, a deafening groan I'd somehow become accustomed to. I remember the thick steel cable rising from the seemingly bottomless abyss that is the Mariana trench. I remember the moment when its cargo finally broke through the water, and my eyes shone. 
 
 For most people, it probably looked utterly unimpressive. Old rubble. Old, *dirty* rubble. 
 
 But it was so much more than that. It was a mystery, an unanswered question. It was evidence of a completely unknown, unrecorded civilization. How it had ended at the bottom of the trench was just one of the many riddles ahead. 
 
 Then the chopper came. I only heard it when we turned off the crane engine, and by then it was already above us. I tried to signal that no, our small ship did not have any room for them, but I had no idea what I was doing, and there was no way to communicate. It did n't matter, the helicopter never tried to land. 
 
 It just needed to deliver a tactical team armed to the teeth, dressed in dark clothes that covered every part of their bodies, their faces hidden behind gas masks. They slid down black ropes with equally black harnesses, their weapon's flashlights blinding all of us as they pointed around the ship. 
 
 They said no word as they surrounded us and our newest acquisition, but they would n't hesitate to aim at anyone who'd try to move even one step. The message was clear enough. 
 
 Then one of them removed her mask. Her face was pale, too pale. Her lips were black. Her eyes were haunted. She pointed at me and gestured to approach her. I did not need to be asked twice. 
 
 She took a small device from a pouch. I thought it was some kind of taser, but she took it to her own throat. 
 
'You... must... put it... back' The voice came hoarse and metallic, and she looked like she was having trouble breathing.'Now.' 
 
 If the situation felt strange before, it was bizarre now. I stood there, trying to understand what was happening, but they were in no mood to wait. 
 
'NOW.' She repeated, taking a handgun to my head. 
 
 I complied. I did not have much of a choice. I gave the order, and soon enough the crane engine was roaring again as it lifted its precious cargo and prepared to return it to the bottom of the ocean. 
 
 A small fragment fell from it and rolled all the way to my feet. I picked it up. 
 
'Dont!' The woman said as all guns turned to me.'Drop... it.' 
 
 I looked at the rock in my hand. There was nothing special about it. Just a brick with a few cracks. I looked back at the woman, about to ask why, when I caught something out of my corner of my eye. Something in one of the cracks. As if someone was looking back at me. 
 
 I looked at the brick again, and I saw it. It can not be described with words, but I will try my best. It was as if there was an entire universe inside that crack, and that universe was nothing but howling chaos. It was as if the natural laws had found a small point where they had no hold, and that point had become an entire world of endless despair. It was as if I was looking through a gateway into the mind of God, and God was a madman, and there was no longer any question about the insignificance of our planet, a small oasis about to be ravaged by forces beyond our understanding. 
 
 It was a moment of clarity, and it was my last moment of sanity. What happened next was too fast, too confusing for my broken mind, but with the years I've managed to put some of it together from broken memories and the testimony of others who were there. 
 
 The brick in my hand ceased to be, it was turned inside out by the cracks in it, and *they* came pouring out, invisible to the ship's crew, but not to me or the tactical team. The guns hit the floor as their wielders knew they were useless against their grotesque, unnatural enemies. They fought instead with sheer force of will, the only weapon that could work against the embodiment of dread. 
 
 The battle was short but brutal. Many died, including the woman who'd talked to me. I was probably only spared because I had gone into a catatonic state and was on my knees, too numb to fear, to fight. 
 
 I woke up, or... returned, from wherever my mind had gone, weeks later, in a hospital room. 
 
 I tried to call for help, but could n't. My voice was gone. I stood up from my bed, but my body was weak and I stumbled and fell. I looked at my hands, holding on to the floor as if it could crumbled beneath them at any moment, shaking as if I was out in a frozen wasteland. They were completely white. 
 
 I took a deep breath to calm myself. I found the strength to stand up. 
 
 I stretched my arms before me and looked at my shaking hands. 
 
 Then a thought came to me, a thought that made them go completely still. 
 
 They were out there. 
 
 They were coming for us. 
 
 And I was going to stop them.
LLM_1:
Sanity. I remember sanity. I remember innocence.

It all began fifteen years ago, though that day feels like a lifetime away. It started as a great day. I recall the loud engine of the ship's crane, a deafening groan I had grown used to. I remember the thick steel cable rising from the seemingly bottomless Mariana Trench. My eyes sparkled when its cargo broke the surface.

To most, it must have seemed unimpressive¡ªold, dirty rubble. 

But it was far more. It was a mystery, evidence of an unrecorded civilization. How it ended up in the trench was just one of many riddles.

Then the chopper arrived. I noticed only when we turned off the crane engine, and by then it hovered above us. I signaled that our small ship had no room for them, but my gestures went unnoticed. The helicopter never attempted to land.

Instead, it delivered a tactical team, armed and cloaked in dark gear, their faces obscured by gas masks. They slid down black ropes, their weapon flashlights blinding us as they swept the ship.

They surrounded us without a word, weapons ready to aim at anyone who dared to move. The message was clear.

One of them removed her mask. Her face was too pale, lips black, eyes haunted. She pointed at me, gesturing to approach. I didn¡¯t hesitate.

From a pouch, she pulled a small device, which I assumed was a taser. Instead, she pressed it to her throat.

"You... must... put it... back," her voice was hoarse and metallic, labored. "Now."

If the situation felt strange before, it was bizarre now. I stood frozen, confusion paralyzing me, but they had no patience.

"NOW." She pressed a handgun to my head.

I complied. With little choice, I ordered the crane engine to roar back to life, lifting its precious cargo toward the ocean's depths.

A fragment fell, rolling to my feet. I picked it up.

"Don't!" the woman shouted as all guns swung toward me. "Drop... it."

I examined the rock¡ªnothing special, just a cracked brick. I looked back at her, about to ask why, when something caught my eye in one of the cracks, as if someone was looking back.

Upon closer inspection, I saw it. It defies description, but I¡¯ll try. Inside that crack was an entire universe of howling chaos, a small point where natural laws lost their hold, an endless world of despair. It felt like peering into the mind of a mad God, revealing our planet's insignificance, a fragile oasis threatened by incomprehensible forces.

It was clarity, my last moment of sanity. What followed was a blur, too fast and confusing for my fractured mind. Yet, over the years, I pieced together fragments from my memories and others who were there.

The brick in my hand ceased to exist, turned inside out by the cracks, and *they* poured forth¡ªvisible only to me and the tactical team. The crew dropped their weapons, knowing they were useless against grotesque, unnatural foes. They fought with sheer will, the only weapon effective against such dread.

The battle was brief but brutal. Many died, including the woman who had spoken to me. I survived, likely because I slipped into a catatonic state, too numb to fear or fight.

I awoke weeks later in a hospital room.

I tried to call for help, but my voice was gone. I stood from my bed, weak and unsteady, falling to the floor. My hands trembled as if I were in a frozen wasteland, completely white.

Taking a deep breath, I found the strength to stand. 

I stretched my arms before me, staring at my shaking hands.

Then a thought struck me, freezing them completely.

They were out there.

They were coming for us.

And I was going to stop them.

The experimental results on two dataset shows the results for disease progression prediction. Some comments and suggestions are listed as follows:

for the proposed method by using the cross-validation.  But, I think it is a bad choice. The dataset in your experiments on the ADNI dataset just separate the ADNI dataset into training and validation sets. The choice in the validation sets may produce bad results on the real test data.
4.In Line 237-245: Author should give more rigorous experiments to demonstrate the generalization of the proposed methods.

LLM_1:
This paper proposes a novel method for learning metrics from data and includes proofs of the proposed techniques. However, it requires more detailed descriptions of the experimental settings and explanations of the figures to enhance clarity. The experimental results on two datasets demonstrate disease progression prediction. Below are some comments and suggestions:

1. Line 97 contains typographical errors.
2. In Figure 2, the authors should provide a more detailed explanation.
3. Lines 224-225: The method for selecting ¦Ò is unclear. It appears that the authors used cross-validation to determine the optimal value, but this may lead to poor performance on real test data, as the ADNI dataset was only split into training and validation sets.
4. Lines 237-245: More rigorous experiments are needed to demonstrate the generalization of the proposed methods.
5. Lines 260-361: The ADNI1, ADNI GO, ADNI2, and ADNI3 datasets contain overlapping subjects. Is there a risk of data leakage? Are only AD data being utilized?
6. The paper should compare the proposed method with existing state-of-the-art approaches for metric learning and disease progression prediction.
7. While interpretability is claimed as a contribution, the paper lacks sufficient descriptions of both model interpretability and result interpretability.
8. An analysis of the time and space complexity of the proposed method should be included.

This paper presents a novel method for learning metrics from data and includes formal proofs of the proposed techniques. However, the manuscript would benefit from more comprehensive descriptions of the experimental settings and clearer explanations of the figures to enhance overall clarity. The experimental results on two datasets demonstrate the potential for predicting disease progression. Below are some comments and suggestions for improvement:

1. **Typographical Errors**: Line 97 contains several typographical errors that need correction.
   
2. **Figure Explanation**: In Figure 2, the authors should provide a more detailed explanation to facilitate reader understanding.

3. **Selection of ¦Ò**: The method for selecting ¦Ò (Lines 224-225) remains unclear. It appears that the authors utilized cross-validation to determine the optimal value; however, this approach may result in suboptimal performance on real test data, given that the ADNI dataset was only divided into training and validation sets.

4. **Generalization of Methods**: More rigorous experiments are required to convincingly demonstrate the generalization capabilities of the proposed methods (Lines 237-245).

5. **Data Overlap and Leakage**: The ADNI1, ADNI GO, ADNI2, and ADNI3 datasets contain overlapping subjects. This raises concerns regarding potential data leakage. Additionally, it is unclear whether only AD data is being utilized.

6. **Comparison with Existing Approaches**: The paper should include a comparative analysis of the proposed method against existing state-of-the-art approaches for metric learning and disease progression prediction.

7. **Interpretability Contributions**: While the authors claim interpretability as a significant contribution, the paper lacks sufficient descriptions regarding both model interpretability and result interpretability.

8. **Complexity Analysis**: An analysis of the time and space complexity of the proposed method should be incorporated to provide a complete understanding of its efficiency.

`` Hurry up,'' the man said sharply, angrily. `` You're stalling.'' He was young and nervous. He tried not to be, but his eyes betrayed him. 
 
 `` This is n't the first time someone has extorted a spell from me,'' Andar said, putting down his quill, letting it rest on the parchment on his large oak desk. `` I understand, you know. These spells-'' 
 
 `` Shut up! Get back to writing, or I'll-'' the young man hissed, keeping his voice down. He brandished his knife in a steady hand, but Andar was n't fooled. He was afraid of alerting the guards, Andar thought, all the way up in the Tower of the Magi, during the mid-autumn recess, when no other Magi were around. 
 
 `` -are very expensive,'' Andar continued, apparently unphased by the threat. `` And destructive magicks are illegal without consent from the Archon. There are better ways. Take a loan, become a student in good standing, become a Magi yourself.'' 
 
 `` Shut up, I said!'' the man jabbed the knife at Andar, and the tip of the blade went into his bony, wrinkled shoulder. He jolted at the sharp pain, but the young man seemed as surprised as he was. 
 
 Andar looked back up at him sternly as a tiny spot of blood began to well up on his thin white cloak. `` Very well,'' Andar said, and turned back to his desk. 
 
 He scribbled for another ten minutes, drawing large diagrams with geometric shapes, mathematic equations, sounding out words in his own voice. This was his greatest gift, of course: he had a profound understanding of the arcane arts, but with no latent ability to cast the magicks he studied, he was at no risk of accidentally releasing a dangerous spell via experimentation. 
 
 He stood slowly, and the young man jumped to his feet, his knife at the ready. `` Are you finished, old man?'' 
 
 `` Nearly,'' Andar said, pulling out a large canvas drop-cloth. He spread the cloth out, and the young man stood to the side, watching intently, nervously, but with bewildered greed showing in his eyes and in his half-crazed grin. 
 
 Andar pulled out a large charcoal stick attached to a short pole, and began to draw a large, intricate Arcanist's Circle, with the deft hands of an experienced Magi. He finished quickly, then wrote the words, in the ancient tongue, that would release the spell from the young man's internal well of power. 
 
 `` Do you speak the old tongue?'' Andar asked, looking up from the cloth as he finished the final flourish of the final character. 
 
 `` Of course I do,'' the young man said with vitriol, `` I'd be a full Magi in a couple years if your gods-damned school would ever have taken me.'' 
 
 `` They would,'' Andar said. `` But there is a price for everything. You have power in you, I'm sure. Give the Council a chance.'' 
 
 `` Fuck the Council,'' he said. `` I'll not be limited by a bunch of crotchety old men. Now teach me the spell, or it's the end of you.'' 
 
 Andar sighed. `` Draw your wand, then.'' 
 
 The young man did as he was bidden, holding a rickety old hand-me-down wand he likely picked up at a pawn shop in the Low Town in one outstretched arm. With the other, he pointed the knife warningly at Andar, who pushed a wooden training dummy across the cloth from the man. 
 
 `` When you finish the spell, you'll fire a bolt of flame directly into the dummy. The spell is designed that the dummy will burn internally, and the flames will extinguish when exposed to air, so we do n't burn down the Tower.'' 
 
 The young man nodded. 
 
 `` Now read the script,'' Andar said. `` At the third set, perform a right-left flourish. At the fourth, a right-right flourish. Are you capable?'' 
 
 The young man spat at Andar's feet. Andar glanced down at the sticky wad, frowning. `` Very well.'' 
 
 The young man began reading the text. 
 
 `` Fioran-danale-anja,'' he said, chewing on each word deliberately, carefully. *Another one lost. He does have some talent, but he lacks any manner of patience. * 
 
 `` Adwa-mala-najar,'' he continued, slower still. *Damn shame. * 
 
 `` Sindar-terana-magari,'' he said, and suddenly struck his hand out in an elegant flourish, from right to left across his body. *Quite good with the wand, too. He's likely spent quite a few hours practicing parlor magicks in his mirror. * 
 
 The young man's eyes went wide as he began the final set, his voice louder, a wicked smile creeping across his lips. 
 
 `` Alta-majia-EANTUS!'' as he finished the spell, he reeled around, pointing the want squarely at Andar. The young man's eyes were wild, his teeth white pillars of madness before his gaping mouth. 
 
 Nothing happened. 
 
 `` You... you tricked me! This is no spell!'' the young man said angrily, and raised the knife above Andar's head, preparing to strike down into his chest. 
 
 `` You're right, but only about one thing,'' Andar said calmly, which seemed to unnerve the young man, who's eyes began to descend into shocked realization. 
 
 Andar glanced down at the man's hand, which still clutched the wand. A couple flakes of ice had begun to form on the end of the dirty oak rod. The young man tried to move his arm down, but the muscles refused to move, his joints giving only slightly. 
 
 `` It most certainly was a spell.'' 
 
 The man's skin turned ice blue, and flakes of white, fluffy ice formed on his lips, his eyelids, around his ears. His mouth suddenly became a tuft of white snow, and he stood, his eyes still open in that shocked realization, snap-frozen solid. 
 
 He fell stiffly to the ground, shattering into a hundred pieces on the drop-cloth. 
 
 Andar sighed, pulling the corners of the cloth up to gather the bits that was formerly a man, too young of years, before tying the lot into a sort of makeshift bag. 
 
 `` Pity,'' Andar said longingly. `` At least this one landed on the damned cloth.''

He spat at Andar¡¯s feet. Andar frowned, then the young man began reading.

"Adwa-mala-najar," he continued, even slower. *A shame.*

Nothing happened.

human: So, I think I mentioned a while back that I've pondering the future of this blog.  My posting has dwindled a lot lately, for a variety of reasons.  Just busy for one.  Also, I'm frankly not interested in posting somewhere where I'm just going to get harrassed by some troll who got here from some fat hate site.  Like, say, NAAFA.  Primarily, though, I'm concerned about pleasing my audience.  I know somethings interest people more than others.  Lately, I've been very interested in politics and have posted about it a lot, but a lot less than I wanted.  Sometimes, I want to post about baseball or the football playoffs, but I know you guys don't care about that.  This also keeps me from promoting this site.  I have a link at the fat related sites I post, but not other ones, because I'm too concerned about the inconsistant focus.  I mean, I'd like readers, but I know I'll just turn off a sports fan with a lengthy post about John Edwards.  And as to political sites I visit, are they necessarily going to give a damn about non-political fat issues as an introduction?  So, what do I do?  Decide to focus on one subject?  That'd make sense, but I've never been good at concentrating on one goal.  I always want them all.  So, I'm thinking I might just start several new blogs to post on my interested subjects.  I figure I'd have 4.  One for fat issues, one for politics, one for sports, and one for pop-cult stuff.  I'm thinking about keeping this blog as a kind of clearinghouse for all posts, and obviously some stuff would be cross posted.  My pimping for Romeo Void's appearance on Bands Reunited is both fat related and pop-cult focused, for instance.  I'm thinking this might actually get me posting more, because I'll be less concerned about turning off my audience and could actually bother to, you know, GET an audience beyond a couple friends.  Just a thought for now.  Actually, that was my original idea for a site before I started my blog.  I wanted a site to post my writing with defined sections for various topics.  Of course, I'm the king of unfufilled projects.  Already setting myself up for one as I've started writing a graphic novel I know I'll probably do nothing with, even though I've already bothered to come up with a three-year story arc.  Mid-to-late 20's angst, I guess.  You know, the feeling that I want to persue all my hopes and dreams, and the nagging feeling that I dropped the ball by not doing more to persue them when I was 20.  All sorts of missed opportunites due to spreading myself to thin.  (which, of course, is what I'm proposing now, but lets not confuse this discussion with logic)  Wishing I was more dedicated to singing or acting in high school.  Contradicting that wish by wishing I was quicker to give up on performing and concentrating on developing myself as a writing.  Wishing I was Communications major in college.  Wishing I bothered to learn how to really draw instead of learning how to do some really good sketches but missing some key skills.  Wishing I tried to developing my comic side so I could have been a comedy writer.  Wishing I knew how I could start persuing any of this now.  Wishing I knew what I want to do with my life.  Lots of wishing.  I'm actually optimistic about that graphic novel, but I always get like that and never follow through.  But, maybe I'm wrong.  I've got this weird thing where I'm a pessimistic optimist.  Ah, well.
LLM_1:
I've been thinking about the future of this blog, especially since my posting frequency has declined for various reasons. Life has been busy, and I¡¯m reluctant to engage with trolls from hate sites like NAAFA. My main concern is pleasing my audience; I know some topics interest you more than others. Recently, I¡¯ve been passionate about politics and have written about it, but I often feel limited. Sometimes I want to discuss baseball or football playoffs, but I know those topics might not resonate with you. This uncertainty also impacts my ability to promote the site. I have links on fat-related sites, but I'm hesitant to branch out due to my inconsistent focus.

I¡¯ve considered narrowing my topics, but I struggle to stick to one subject. Instead, I¡¯m thinking about starting several new blogs¡ªone for fat issues, one for politics, one for sports, and one for pop culture. This blog could serve as a central hub for all my posts, allowing for some cross-posting. For example, my promotion of Romeo Void's appearance on Bands Reunited fits both fat and pop culture themes. I believe this approach might encourage me to post more frequently, as I wouldn't worry about alienating my audience and could attract a broader readership.

Originally, I envisioned a site organized by distinct sections for various topics before starting this blog. I tend to leave projects unfinished, like my graphic novel, which I¡¯m excited about despite knowing I might not follow through. I often feel a mix of mid-to-late 20s angst, wanting to pursue all my dreams while regretting missed opportunities from when I was younger. I wish I had dedicated myself more to singing or acting in high school, or focused on developing my writing skills instead. I also regret not majoring in Communications or learning to draw properly. There¡¯s a lot of wishing involved, and while I¡¯m optimistic about the graphic novel, I typically don¡¯t follow through. Perhaps this time will be different, as I navigate my way through being a pessimistic optimist.
LLM_2:
Lately, I¡¯ve been pondering the future of this blog, especially as my posting frequency has dipped for various reasons. Life has been hectic, and to be honest, I¡¯m hesitant to engage with trolls from hate sites like NAAFA. My primary concern is to keep my audience happy; I know some topics resonate with you more than others. 

Recently, I¡¯ve found myself deeply passionate about politics and have shared my thoughts on the subject. However, I often feel restricted in this focus. There are times when I want to dive into discussions about baseball or the latest football playoffs, but I worry those topics might not connect with you. This uncertainty also affects my ability to promote the site. While I have links on fat-related websites, I hesitate to branch out because of my inconsistent focus.

I¡¯ve contemplated narrowing my topics, but I struggle to commit to just one. Instead, I¡¯m considering launching several new blogs¡ªone dedicated to fat issues, another for politics, one for sports, and a fourth for pop culture. This blog could serve as a central hub for all my posts, allowing for some cross-pollination of ideas. For instance, my promotion of Romeo Void's appearance on *Bands Reunited* fits beautifully within both the fat and pop culture realms. I believe this approach might motivate me to post more frequently, alleviating the fear of alienating my audience while attracting a wider readership.

When I first envisioned this site, I imagined it organized into distinct sections for various topics. However, I have a tendency to leave projects unfinished¡ªlike my graphic novel, which I¡¯m excited about even though I know I might not see it through. There¡¯s a constant tug-of-war in my mid-to-late 20s between pursuing my dreams and regretting the opportunities I missed when I was younger. I often find myself wishing I had dedicated more time to singing or acting in high school or focused on honing my writing skills. I also regret not majoring in Communications or learning to draw properly. 

Amidst all this wishing, I remain cautiously optimistic about the graphic novel. Perhaps this time will be different as I navigate the journey of being a pessimistic optimist.

But the chairman, European Council President Donald Tusk, will keep the two discussions separate - despite concern that some jihadists are slipping into the EU posing as migrants and exploiting the freedom of movement provided by the Schengen zone.
At least two of the killers involved in the Paris attacks got in among the crowds of migrants arriving daily on the Greek islands near Turkey.
But EU leaders are anxious to avoid sounding like the nationalists who argue that the removal of border controls in the EU left Europeans more at risk from terrorists. That is the rallying cry of the French National Front (FN) and some other populist parties.
Migration and terrorism are also treated as separate issues because - as pointed out by EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker - many asylum-seekers are themselves fleeing from the terror inflicted by Islamic State (IS), the Taliban and other extremist groups.
The dilemma for the EU is that Schengen - the passport-free area embracing 26 countries - greatly eases the flow of people and goods across the EU, but also requires more information-sharing, to prevent cross-border criminality.
About 1.7 million EU citizens cross borders daily in the Schengen zone to go to work, the Bruegel think-tank reports.
And opinion polls indicate that many Europeans value Schengen more than any other change brought about by the EU.
But temporary border controls have been reimposed - by France, Germany, Austria and Hungary.
So the stakes are high at this summit.
"Our goal is clear: we must regain control over our external borders to stem migratory flows and to preserve Schengen," said Mr Tusk in his summit invitation letter.
Mr Juncker said Europeans now have "one border" and "a shared responsibility to protect it".
"We want to defend everything Schengen represents, and let me tell you that Schengen is here to stay," he told the European Parliament.
Saving Schengen means beefing up the surveillance of all people entering or leaving the Schengen area.
So in future EU citizens, as well as those from outside the bloc, will have their passports checked against police databases.
There is much work to do, however, to link up and improve those databases.
More than a million refugees and other migrants have surged into the EU this year, most of them desperate to reach Germany or other northern countries where job prospects are better, or where relatives can help them settle.
The Syrian war has pushed irregular migration to the EU to a record high.
There are fears that the international campaign to smash IS, and the Russian bombing in support of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's forces, will drive even more Syrians to flee abroad.
So the 28 leaders in Brussels will look again at the EU's help for Greece and Turkey. The migrant registration process is still slow and patchy.
Turkey, struggling with more than two million Syrian refugees, now has much bargaining power. Critics say the EU risks compromising its human rights standards as it leans on Turkey to curb the migrant flow.
Greek coastguards and the EU's Frontex border agency only manage to intercept 20% of the migrants who reach Greek islands after life-threatening voyages, according to Frontex.
This week the Commission unveiled an ambitious plan for a new EU Border and Coast Guard to tackle problems on the EU's external borders.
The force - stronger than Frontex - would have 1,000 permanent staff and 1,500 reserves, who could be deployed rapidly to a trouble spot, within three days.
That could happen even without the host country requesting it - if the rest of the EU decides to take action.
Such force majeure might be the exception - but Poland has already raised objections on sovereignty grounds.
Once again, the migrant crisis is threatening to divide, more than unite, Europe.

*The loop's pretty good*, I thought. I watched the black-and-white cat spun on the playground merry-go-around, its alarmed face in stark contrast to the delighted expression on the kids' faces. One little girl and two boys, maybe 5 or 6 years old, gave the roundabout a single push and squealed with laughter at the cat's protests. The end of the gif seamlessly looped back to the first push. Or maybe the push came at the end? It was hard to tell. 
 
 `` Heh, dumb cat,'' I murmured and prepared to close the tab.But something about the gif mesmerized me. I could n't stop looking. 
 
 And then, there it was. Just a flicker. 
 
 I blinked deliberately. Did I really just see...? A little apprehensively, I watched the gif again, from beginning to end ( or end to beginning, whichever it was ). I let out a little sigh of relief as it finished - nothing weird. Just my imagination. 
 
 But... was the merry-go-around suddenly red? Was n't it blue just a few loops ago? I frowned and refreshed the page. Nope, still red. Guess I'm just confused... wait. The little girl's wearing a dress now. I could swear she had jeans and a little shirt on... 
 
 I shook my head roughly and moved to X out of the window. Clearly I was losing my mind. And yet, something transfixed me about the gif. I guess I was waiting for more weird changes? *Someone probably edited the gif so that it loops a bunch of times but then photoshopped little changes in it. Just to mess with people*, I thought. After several more loops, I began to feel kind of stupid. *This is dumb*. I moved my cursor. 
 
 `` Oh, FUCK!'' I yelped, jerking my hand away. I slammed my laptop closed, heart racing. It had happened again, and this time long enough for me to really see it. The whole gif had turned scales of grey, and the everything - I mean *everything* - in the gif had changed, momentarily. for the worse: the reddish house in the background had suddenly looked dilapidated and falling apart, the merry-go-around itself had rusted, the cat had been replaced by a emaciated husk of animal. But the worst part was the children. They had done something completely new, something that giif had not looped: they turned their heads and looked directly at me, and when I saw their faces, their unsmiling mouths, those *hollow eye sockets*... 
 
 I started laughing shakily. The asshole who had edited the gif had done a really good job. Scared me shitless for a second there! But I had a sudden thought that sent a wave of chills down my spine. The reddish house in the background... oh God, no. That could n't be fucking possible. With dread, I reached over to the blinds on my right and slowly pushed them aside. I peered through the window and felt my blood turn to ice. 
 
 The reddish house, which had stood across from my own for years, now lay in a burned, disheveled pile of wood surrounded by yellow caution tape. The grass on the lawn had browned completely, which was impossible; it had been vibrant green just yesterday. Unable to tear my eyes away, I directed my gaze to the merry-go-round, which I had never before seen in my whole life. It was barely turning, almost falling apart where it stood. And the cat was no longer on it; just a small, dusty-looking skeleton. Everything was even worse than it had appeared in the gif. 
 
 With horror, I realized the children were there, too. They looked perfectly fine, actually; they laughed and pointed to the rusted merry-go-around with its bony occupant. *Look away, dumbass*, I tried telling myself. But I could n't. I was transfixed. 
 
 And when the children turned their... their *faces* toward me, I began to scream. 
 
 ____________________________

human: In Europe the Wayback Machine could be interpreted as violating copyright laws. Only the content creator can decide where their content is published or duplicated, so the Archive would have to delete pages from its system upon request of the creator. The exclusion policies for the Wayback Machine may be found in the FAQ section of the site. The Wayback Machine also retroactively respects robots.txt files, i.e., pages that currently are blocked to robots on the live web temporarily will be made unavailable from the archives as well.
LLM_1: In Europe, the Wayback Machine may be seen as violating copyright laws, as only content creators can determine the publication or duplication of their work. Consequently, the Archive must delete pages from its system upon the creator's request. Exclusion policies for the Wayback Machine are detailed in the site's FAQ section. Additionally, the Wayback Machine retroactively honors robots.txt files, making currently blocked pages unavailable from the archives.
LLM_2: In Europe, the Wayback Machine has been viewed as potentially violating copyright laws, as only content creators have the authority to determine the publication or duplication of their work. William Ball, 37, had been working at Derby Market Hall with a colleague before falling at about 04:20 GMT on Wednesday, Derbyshire Police said.
Mr Ball, from Sandiacre, was taken to hospital but was pronounced dead.
The Derby City Council-owned market hall remains closed and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has been informed.
More on this story and other news in Derbyshire
Well-wishers have been leaving floral tributes outside the hall's entrance.
One read: "Gone far too young. Always be in our memories."
Another said: "You will never be forgotten and sadly missed."
The council has not said what type of work Mr Ball was doing, and said it does not know when the market hall will reopen.

William Ball, 37, was working at Derby Market Hall with a colleague when he fell around 04:20 GMT on Wednesday, according to Derbyshire Police. He was taken to the hospital but was pronounced dead. The market hall, owned by Derby City Council, is currently closed, and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has been notified. 

Floral tributes have been placed at the entrance, with messages expressing sorrow and remembrance. The council has not disclosed the nature of Mr. Ball's work or when the market hall will reopen.

The market hall, which is owned by Derby City Council, is currently closed as authorities investigate the circumstances surrounding the incident. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has been notified and is expected to look into the matter.

In the wake of this tragedy, floral tributes have been placed at the entrance of the market hall, with heartfelt messages of sorrow and remembrance from the community. As of now, the council has not released details regarding the nature of Mr. Ball's work or a timeline for the market hall's reopening.

The Wales fly-half has not passed return to play protocols so Wales team-mate Sam Davies will start at 10.
Bradley Davies starts in the second row for the first time since November.
The Blues make four changes from the 24-24 draw with Ulster, with Sam Warburton, George Earle and Blaine Scully all injured.
Nick Williams, Macauley Cook and Matthew Morgan all start for the Cardiff region, while hooker Kristian Dacey returns from a groin strain.
Sam Underhill is also missing for Ospreys after also receiving a blow to the head against Leinster.
A heavily bandaged Biggar complained of being "dazed" after missing a last-kick-of the-game penalty which would have seen Ospreys beat Leinster. As it was the Swansea-based region lost 20-18.
After the game coach Steve Tandy explained the player had passed a pitchside head injury assessment following a clash of heads before being allowed back on to the pitch.
Second row Davies was a second-half replacement for the Ospreys in that match - his first appearance since playing for Wales against Australia on 5 November 2016.
Blues produced some scintillating back play in the draw at Ravenhill, but paid a heavy injury price with Lions captaincy candidate Warburton chief among the casualties.
They are eighth in the Pro12 table, 25 points behind third-placed Ospreys who have lost their last two league outings.
Ospreys coach Steve Tandy: "It's very much about us in the run-in, if we put together three winning performances then there's nothing anyone else can do to stop us reaching the play-offs.
"Things haven't gone as planned the last few ... Ulster and the Scarlets are breathing down our neck and will both be desperate to put one over us in the final two rounds."
Blues scrum-half Lloyd Williams: "Sam (Warburton) has been in training all week and he's been influential in the way we've been preparing.
"We will miss him and another key forward, George Earle, as well, but it is a chance for Macauley Cook and Nick Williams. We have strong players coming back in for them who can fill their shoes."
