human: Although undernutrition is recognized as a risk factor for mortality among people living with HIV (PLWHIV), even among those initiating antiretroviral therapy, few studies have explored the underlying determinants of undernutrition. The objectives of the present study were to: (i) examine the independent association between household food security, individual diet quality and nutritional status; and (ii) determine if any association between food security and nutritional status is mediated through diet quality.Cross-sectional baseline survey.Gulu and Soroti districts, Uganda.Nine hundred and two PLWHIV recruited into a study evaluating the impact of a food assistance programme supported by the World Food Programme.Food security and diet quality were measured using the Household Food Insecurity Access Scale (HFIAS) and the Individual Dietary Diversity Score (IDDS), respectively. Multivariate regression results demonstrated that HFIAS and IDDS independently predict BMI (P < 0.01) and mid upper-arm circumference (P < 0.05). The adjusted odds ratio of being underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2) among individuals living in severely food-insecure households was 1.92 (P < 0.0 0 1); individuals consuming a highly diverse diet had an adjusted odds ratio of being underweight of 0.56 (P < 0.05) compared with those consuming a diet of low diversity. Similar results were observed when mid upper-arm circumference and wasting were modelled as outcomes. Using path analysis, we observed that the indirect effect of food insecurity on BMI mediated through dietary diversity is negligible, and mostly a result of the direct effect of food insecurity on BMI.
LLM_1: Undernutrition is a recognized risk factor for mortality among people living with HIV (PLWHIV), particularly those initiating antiretroviral therapy; however, the determinants of undernutrition remain underexplored. This study aimed to: (i) assess the independent relationship between household food security, individual diet quality, and nutritional status; and (ii) evaluate whether diet quality mediates the association between food security and nutritional status. A cross-sectional baseline survey was conducted in Gulu and Soroti districts, Uganda, involving 902 PLWHIV participating in a World Food Programme-supported food assistance evaluation. Food security and diet quality were assessed using the Household Food Insecurity Access Scale (HFIAS) and the Individual Dietary Diversity Score (IDDS), respectively. Multivariate regression analysis revealed that both HFIAS and IDDS independently predict body mass index (BMI) (P < 0.01) and mid-upper arm circumference (P < 0.05). Individuals from severely food-insecure households had an adjusted odds ratio of being underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2) of 1.92 (P < 0.001), while those with a highly diverse diet had an odds ratio of 0.56 (P < 0.05) compared to individuals with low dietary diversity. Similar findings were noted for mid-upper arm circumference and wasting. Path analysis indicated that the indirect effect of food insecurity on BMI, mediated by dietary diversity, is negligible, primarily reflecting the direct impact of food insecurity on BMI.
LLM_2: Undernutrition is a well-established risk factor for mortality among people living with HIV (PLWHIV), particularly during the initiation of antiretroviral therapy; however, the determinants of undernutrition remain inadequately explored. This study aimed to (i) assess the independent relationships among household food security, individual diet quality, and nutritional status, and (ii) evaluate whether diet quality mediates the association between food security and nutritional status. A cross-sectional baseline survey was conducted in the Gulu and Soroti districts of Uganda, involving 902 PLWHIV participating in a World Food Programme-supported food assistance evaluation. Food security and diet quality were assessed using the Household Food Insecurity Access Scale (HFIAS) and the Individual Dietary Diversity Score (IDDS), respectively. Multivariate regression analyses revealed that both HFIAS and IDDS independently predict body mass index (BMI) (P < 0.01) and mid-upper arm circumference (P < 0.05). Individuals from severely food-insecure households exhibited an adjusted odds ratio of 1.92 (P < 0.001) for being underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2), while those with a highly diverse diet had an odds ratio of 0.56 (P < 0.05) in comparison to individuals with low dietary diversity. Similar findings were observed for mid-upper arm circumference and wasting. Path analysis indicated that the indirect effect of food insecurity on BMI, as mediated by dietary diversity, is negligible, primarily reflecting the direct impact of food insecurity on BMI.

 Angel Ramsbottom was n't pleased he was assigned plug in duty today but someone had to do it so he kept at it. 
 
 `` Welcome to heaven. Here's your plug. Plug in'' 
 
 `` Plug into what?'' James inquired. 
 
 `` To heaven of course'' the angel retorted. 
 
 James peered beyond the pearly gates to see infinitely long lines of cubicles inhabited by what he could only assume were people plugged in. They looked serene and blissful. Like in a perpetual orgasm. 
 
 
 `` What does it feel like?'' 
 
 `` Well why do n't you try it?'' The angel prescribed. 
 
 `` Has anyone ever unplugged?'' James wondered. 
 
 `` No one wants out of heaven buddy. They're all connected and live as Gods in a world that ca n't be imagined. `` 
 
 `` So it's a hive mind?'' 
 
 `` It's heaven'' 
 
 `` Can you show me what hell looks like?'' 
 
 `` Why would you even want to see that?'' 
 
 `` I'm just curious'' 
 
 `` It's nothing special. Just worldly pleasures. Endless debauchery. Everyone is an individual. No communing like in heaven'' 
 
 `` What? I thought there'll be punishment eternal'' 
 
 `` Compared to heaven that's punishment'' 
 
 `` But if I join a hive I would cease to be who I am'' 
 
 `` Do n't call it that. You would commune with the others and become more than yourself'' 
 
 `` Well let me take a quick look at hell'' 
 
 James is transported to an island. He loses his inhibitions. Everyone is naked. Everyone is extremely horny. There's loud rave music playing. It's one huge orgy.

"Welcome to heaven. Here¡¯s your plug. Plug in."

Angel Ramsbottom wasn't particularly thrilled about his plug-in duty today, but it was his responsibility, so he pressed on.

"Plug into what?" James asked, a mix of curiosity and apprehension in his voice.

¡°To heaven, of course,¡± the angel replied, his wings shimmering in the ethereal light.

James peered through the pearly gates, his eyes widening at the sight of endless lines of cubicles, each filled with people seemingly plugged in. They looked serene and blissful, as if enveloped in a state of perpetual ecstasy.

"What does it feel like?" he inquired, intrigued.

"Why don¡¯t you try it?" the angel suggested, a hint of mischief in his tone.

"Has anyone ever unplugged?" James pressed.

"No one wants to leave heaven. They¡¯re all connected, living as gods in an unimaginable realm," the angel explained, his gaze distant.

"So it¡¯s a hive mind?" James queried, skepticism lacing his words.

"It¡¯s heaven," the angel affirmed, his voice steady.

"Can you show me what hell looks like?" James asked, his curiosity piqued.

"Why would you want to see that?" the angel countered, raising an eyebrow.

"I¡¯m just curious," James replied, a hint of defiance in his tone.

"It¡¯s nothing special. Just worldly pleasures¡ªendless debauchery. Everyone is an individual. No communion like in heaven," the angel said dismissively.

"What? I thought there¡¯d be eternal punishment," James exclaimed, his mind racing.

"Compared to heaven, that¡¯s punishment," the angel replied, a knowing smile playing on his lips.

"But if I join a hive, won¡¯t I cease to be myself?" James asked, his voice wavering.

"Don¡¯t call it that. You would commune with others and become more than yourself," the angel reassured him, his tone soothing.

"I want to take a quick look at hell," James insisted, his resolve hardening.

In an instant, James found himself transported to an island pulsing with energy. He shed his inhibitions, the air thick with temptation. Everywhere he looked, bodies danced freely, lost in desire, the thumping beats of rave music echoing in the air. It was one massive celebration of flesh and fervor.

His gaze was drawn to two voluptuous figures approaching him, their laughter ringing like chimes in the chaotic symphony of indulgence.

The Kelso-based Borders Search and Rescue Unit was called out in the early hours of the morning.
The elderly woman, who has dementia, had been reported missing from her home in Eyemouth.
A police helicopter spotted her at about 04:00 walking on the rail lines and the rescue team took her to safety.
BSARU team leader Stuart Fuller-Shapcott said: "When she was spotted actually on the lines, it suddenly became extremely urgent.
"With me was a police inspector, who immediately liaised with train operators to make sure any traffic on the railway was stopped."
The helicopter directed search teams to the location, where the woman was found moving slowly with two sticks on rough railway ballast.
"She was confused and had sustained minor injuries in reaching the lines through hedges and fences, and in stumbling repeatedly on the difficult ground," said Mr Fuller-Shapcott.
"We ferried her to safety on a stretcher, from where she was transferred to a road-ambulance and taken for observation to the Borders General Hospital."

A police helicopter located her around 04:00 walking on the rail lines, prompting an urgent response from the rescue team. The helicopter guided search teams to the woman's location, where she was found moving slowly with two sticks on rough terrain. "She was confused and had sustained minor injuries from navigating through hedges and stumbling on the difficult ground," said Mr. Fuller-Shapcott. The team transported her on a stretcher to a waiting ambulance for observation at the Borders General Hospital.

A police helicopter successfully located her at approximately 4:00 AM, walking along the railway tracks, which triggered an immediate response from rescue personnel.

Team leader Stuart Fuller-Shapcott emphasized the critical nature of the situation upon her discovery on the tracks. A police inspector swiftly coordinated with train operators to suspend railway services in the area. The helicopter played a crucial role in directing search teams to the woman's position, where she was found navigating rough terrain with the assistance of two walking sticks.

"She appeared confused and had suffered minor injuries from maneuvering through hedges and stumbling on the uneven ground," Mr. Fuller-Shapcott reported. The rescue team transported her on a stretcher to a nearby ambulance, where she was taken for observation at Borders General Hospital.

human:
The paper summarizes and compares some of the current explanation techniques for deep neural networks that rely on the redistribution of relevance / contribution values from the output to the input space.

The main contributions are the introduction of a unified framework that expresses 4 common attribution techniques (Gradient * Input, Integrated Gradient, eps-LRP and DeepLIFT) in a similar way as modified gradient functions and the definition of a new evaluation measure ('sensitivity n') that generalizes the earlier defined properties of 'completeness' and 'summation to delta'.

The unified framework is very helpful since it points out equivalences between the methods and makes the implementation of eps-LRP and DeepLIFT substantially more easy on modern frameworks. However, as correctly stated by the authors some of the unification (e.g. relation between LRP and Gradient*Input) has been already mentioned in prior work.

Sensitivity-n as a measure tries to tackle the difficulty of estimating the importance of features that can be seen either separately or in combination. While the measure shows interesting trends towards a linear behaviour for simpler methods, it does not persuade me as a measure of how well the relevance attribution method mimics the decision making process and does not really point out substantial differences between the different methods. Furthermore, The authors could comment on the relation between sensitivity-n and region perturbation techniques (Samek et al., IEEE TNNLS, 2017). Sensitivtiy-n seems to be an extension of the region perturbation idea to me.

It would be interesting to see the relation between the "unified" gradient-based explanation methods and approaches (e.g. Saliency maps, alpha-beta LRP, Deep Taylor, Deconvolution Networks, Grad-CAM, Guided Backprop ...) which do not fit into the unification framework. It's good that the author mention these works, still it would be great to see more discussion on the advantages/disadvantages, because these methods may have some nice theoretically properties (see e.g. the discussion on gradient vs. decompositiion techniques in Montavon et al., Digital Signal Processing, 2017) which can not be incorporated into the unified framework.
LLM_1:
Its main contributions include a unified framework that represents four common attribution techniques (Gradient * Input, Integrated Gradient, eps-LRP, and DeepLIFT) as modified gradient functions, and the introduction of a new evaluation measure, 'sensitivity n,' which generalizes the previously defined properties of 'completeness' and 'summation to delta.'

The unified framework is beneficial as it highlights equivalences among methods and simplifies the implementation of eps-LRP and DeepLIFT in modern frameworks. However, as the authors note, some aspects of this unification, particularly the relationship between LRP and Gradient * Input, have been addressed in prior research.

The sensitivity-n measure attempts to address the challenge of estimating feature importance both individually and in combination. While it reveals interesting trends toward linear behavior for simpler methods, it does not convincingly demonstrate how well relevance attribution methods replicate the decision-making process or highlight substantial differences among the methods. Furthermore, the authors could explore the connection between sensitivity-n and region perturbation techniques (Samek et al., IEEE TNNLS, 2017), as sensitivity-n appears to extend the region perturbation concept.

It would be valuable to examine the relationship between the "unified" gradient-based explanation methods and other approaches (e.g., Saliency maps, alpha-beta LRP, Deep Taylor, Deconvolution Networks, Grad-CAM, Guided Backprop) that fall outside the unification framework. While the authors mention these methods, a deeper discussion on their advantages and disadvantages would be beneficial, as they may possess theoretically significant properties (see e.g., the discussion on gradient vs. decomposition techniques in Montavon et al., Digital Signal Processing, 2017) that are not encompassed by the unified framework.
LLM_2:
The primary contributions of this work include the development of a unified framework that encapsulates four prevalent attribution techniques¡ªGradient * Input, Integrated Gradient, eps-LRP, and DeepLIFT¡ªby representing them as modified gradient functions. Additionally, the authors introduce a novel evaluation metric, termed 'sensitivity n,' which broadens the previously established concepts of 'completeness' and 'summation to delta.'

This unified framework offers significant advantages by elucidating the relationships among these methods, thereby facilitating the implementation of eps-LRP and DeepLIFT within contemporary frameworks. Nonetheless, as the authors themselves acknowledge, certain aspects of this unification, particularly the link between LRP and Gradient * Input, have been explored in earlier studies.

The sensitivity-n measure presents an approach to tackle the challenge of assessing feature importance both on an individual basis and in conjunction. Although it uncovers intriguing trends indicating a linear behavior for more straightforward methods, it falls short of compellingly illustrating how effectively relevance attribution techniques mirror the decision-making process or distinguishing substantial differences among the various methods. Moreover, it would be pertinent for the authors to investigate the relationship between sensitivity-n and region perturbation techniques, as proposed by Samek et al. (IEEE TNNLS, 2017), since sensitivity-n appears to extend the concept of region perturbation.

Furthermore, it would be beneficial to explore the connections between the "unified" gradient-based explanation methods and alternative approaches, such as Saliency maps, alpha-beta LRP, Deep Taylor, Deconvolution Networks, Grad-CAM, and Guided Backpropagation, which are not included in the unification framework. While the authors acknowledge these techniques, a more in-depth analysis of their respective advantages and disadvantages would enhance the discussion, particularly considering that they may exhibit theoretically significant properties¡ªsuch as those debated in Montavon et al. (Digital Signal Processing, 2017)¡ªthat are not captured by the unified framework.

human:
The paper is a little hard to follow and some parts are poorly written. While the authors claim that they use the greedy approach (in sec 2) for quantization where both B and ¦Á are learned in a greedy way, it is not clear why there is convergence difference between the two as claimed by the authors in section 3.1. Moreover, the authors claimed faster convergence of B than ¦Á because fewer bit clips are observed from the left subplot of Figure 2. However, this conclusion is not quite convincing because 1) on the right subplot of Figure 2, it seems that ¦Á also becomes more stable after 80k iterations; 2) the fewer bit clips may comes from using a stepwise learning rate decay scheme. Thus, the motivation for using another phase to train the ¦Á is not strong.

The iterative quantization approach has limited novelty. It is similar to many quantization methods like BinaryConnect and Xnor-Net, except that the quantization step is not done immediately after the BP and model updates, but after some iterations of full-precision training. Moreover, these methods also use full-precision weights for update during training.

Clarity in the experiments section is a little better than the previous sections. However,
- The proposed method only performs comparably with TTQ, and shows significant accuracy drop on the Cifar-10 and Cifar-100 datasets (especially on Cifar-100)
- On the ImageNet dataset, there is a large accuracy drop of the proposed method compared to Zhou et al. (2018). Though the authors said that they believe their proposed model can reach a higher accuracy by using layer-by-layer quantization as in Zhou et al. (2018), it is hard to verify this claim due to lack of the corresponding results. Thus, efficacy of the proposed method on large datasets or models are hard to evaluate.
LLM_1:
The paper is somewhat difficult to follow, with certain sections poorly articulated. While the authors assert the use of a greedy approach for quantization in Section 2, the reasons for the convergence differences between B and ¦Á, as claimed in Section 3.1, remain unclear. Additionally, the assertion of faster convergence for B over ¦Á due to fewer bit clips in the left subplot of Figure 2 is unconvincing because: 1) the right subplot suggests that ¦Á stabilizes after 80k iterations; and 2) the reduced bit clips may result from a stepwise learning rate decay scheme. Thus, the rationale for a separate training phase for ¦Á is weak.

The iterative quantization approach lacks novelty, resembling methods like BinaryConnect and Xnor-Net. The key distinction is that quantization occurs after several iterations of full-precision training, rather than immediately following backpropagation and model updates, while these methods also utilize full-precision weights during training.

The clarity in the experiments section is somewhat improved compared to earlier sections. However, the proposed method shows only comparable performance with TTQ, experiencing a significant accuracy drop on the Cifar-10 and Cifar-100 datasets, particularly on Cifar-100. On the ImageNet dataset, the proposed method demonstrates a substantial accuracy decline compared to Zhou et al. (2018). Although the authors believe their model can achieve higher accuracy through layer-by-layer quantization, this claim is difficult to substantiate due to the absence of relevant results, making the efficacy of the proposed method on larger datasets or models challenging to assess.
LLM_2:
The clarity of the paper is somewhat lacking, as certain sections are poorly expressed. While the authors claim to employ a greedy approach for quantization in Section 2, the rationale behind the observed convergence discrepancies between B and ¦Á, as discussed in Section 3.1, is not adequately explained. Furthermore, the assertion that B converges more rapidly than ¦Á due to fewer bit clips, as illustrated in the left subplot of Figure 2, is not entirely convincing for two main reasons: 1) the right subplot indicates that ¦Á stabilizes after 80,000 iterations; and 2) the reduced number of bit clips may be influenced by a stepwise learning rate decay strategy. Consequently, the justification for a distinct training phase for ¦Á appears weak.

The iterative quantization technique presented lacks originality and closely resembles existing methods such as BinaryConnect and Xnor-Net. The primary difference lies in the timing of quantization, which occurs following several iterations of full-precision training rather than immediately after backpropagation and model updates, as is the case with the aforementioned methods that also utilize full-precision weights during training.

While the experiments section exhibits improved clarity compared to previous sections, the proposed method only achieves performance comparable to TTQ and suffers a notable accuracy decline on the Cifar-10 and Cifar-100 datasets, particularly on Cifar-100. In terms of the ImageNet dataset, the proposed method shows a significant drop in accuracy relative to the findings of Zhou et al. (2018). Although the authors assert that their model can realize higher accuracy through layer-by-layer quantization, this claim lacks adequate support due to a lack of relevant results, making it difficult to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method on larger datasets or models.

But.... we do need to know the best ways to function productively in the environment we live.This means to adapt, folow and function according to the rules of the society(Darwin's theory of ' The survival of the fittest' is still valid). Ok so the gist of the whole story or the gyan of the day is to have a practical approach towards the strategies used in teaching. LLM_1:
We engage in writing, reading, and working on tasks essential for completing our coursework or job responsibilities. As we progress in our careers and academics, each of us develops unique approaches to these tasks, shaping our thinking, analysis, problem-solving strategies, organization, prioritization, and goal planning. We often learn through imitation and modeling, influencing our development. This individuality means no two people are alike. 

However, to thrive in our environment, we must adapt and adhere to societal rules¡ªDarwin's "survival of the fittest" remains relevant. Education is crucial in this personal evolution, though its definition varies among individuals. Ultimately, the goal is enlightenment and self-improvement. 

Thus, the methods and strategies employed to help students acquire knowledge should be practical, enabling them to apply their skills in various situations. As we navigate through our careers and educational journeys, we naturally cultivate distinct methods for approaching these responsibilities. Much of our learning stems from observation and imitation, shaping our personal growth and development. This individuality is what makes each of us unique.

Yet, to flourish in our environments, we must also adapt and conform to the norms of society. The concept of "survival of the fittest," as proposed by Darwin, continues to hold significance today. Education plays a pivotal role in this journey of personal development, although its interpretation can vary widely from one person to another. Ultimately, the aim is to achieve enlightenment and foster self-improvement.

With this in mind, the techniques and strategies we use to help students learn must be grounded in practicality. It's essential that they can apply their knowledge and skills in diverse situations. The central message here is to embrace practical teaching methods, as our reading and learning habits profoundly influence our overall lifestyles.

Charles Danvers looked out the window of his study into the pitch black night. He heard his wife, Helen, enter from behind. ¡° Helen, ¡± he said. ¡° Now that we ¡¯ re married, I feel there is a secret I must impart to you ¡± 
 
 Helen grabbed one of her hands, tension building in her gut. ¡° W-what is it dear? ¡± She asked. 
 
 ¡° I¡­ ¡± his voice felt dry as he spoke. ¡° I¡­ I ¡¯ m not like other men. When I was a child, I was bitten by a wolf. And ever since then, I ¡¯ ve been cursed. ¡± 
 
 A soft white light illuminated the landscape outside. He looked upward, the full circle of the moon brilliant in the sky. ¡° Oh no, ¡± he said. ¡° I forgot it was tonight¡­ ¡± 
 
 He doubled over, the flesh of his body rippling and twisting as his body grew elongated. Meanwhile, his face narrowed into a snout, two flappy ears growing from his head. His eyes grew large and black, while a thin sheen of brown hair covered his body. His limbs got bigger, but seemed to shrink in proportion to his elongated body. A body that grew so long, he had to set himself on all fours, lest he fall over. 
 
 It was not until he stopped that Helen ( frozen with a mixture of fear and simply raw confusion ) realized it. 
 
 ¡° Charlie! You ¡¯ re a¡­a¡­ ¡± 
 
 ¡° Say it! ¡± He roared, his voice hard and deep. ¡° Just say it! ¡± 
 
 The words formed on her lips. ¡° Were-Dachshund! ¡± 
 
 He let out a howl as his thin, wiry tail ripped through the back of his tattered pants. 
 
 Then he just kind of stopped. 
 
 ¡° So um¡­ Yeah Helen, this is kind of a thing. ¡± 
 
 Helen slowly took a seat, her fear now gone, replaced entirely by a general sense of ¡° what-the-fuck ¡±. 
 
 ¡° So¡­ Were-Dachshund huh? ¡± 
 
 ¡° Yep. ¡± 
 
 ¡° So, not a Werewolf? I mean you said a wolf, I only assumed¡­ ¡± 
 
 ¡° Yeah, ¡± he moved to her side, laying on his belly as he wagged his tail. ¡° That ¡¯ s what people usually think. But uh¡­ no. it ¡¯ s like a were-canine lottery. I drew Dachshund. ¡± 
 
 ¡° Is it hard to deal with? ¡± 
 
 ¡° Well, I like to chase rodents sometimes, I eat and beg for food a lot, even when I ¡¯ m not hungry. Occasionally, I like to dig holes and burrow into places. You know, the usual. ¡± 
 
 She rolled her eyes. ¡° Well¡­ this will¡­ take some getting used to. ¡± 
 
 ¡° Will you stay, ¡± his eyes glistened, getting very large as he stood on his legs and put a paw on her armrest. 
 
 ¡° What? ¡± 
 
 ¡° Will you stay? ¡± 
 
 ¡° Oh Charlie, ¡± she scratched behind his ears, making his long tail whoosh loudly and crash against the floor as he wagged it. ¡° You ¡¯ re still my husband underneath all this. You know I love you. ¡± She kissed his nose, making him pant a little. ¡° Now, why don ¡¯ t we go upstairs and I ¡¯ ll let you sleep at the foot of the bed until you change back. ¡± 
 
 He stopped wagging as he turned his gaze outward to the night sky, his demeanor seeming to turn mournful. ¡° I ¡¯ m afraid I can not do that Helen. For you see¡­ I really should not be going upstairs as it puts a great undue strain on my back. ¡±

¡°Will you stay?¡±

¡°Oh, Charlie,¡± she said, scratching behind his ears. His long tail thumped joyfully against the floor. ¡°You¡¯re still my husband at heart. You know I love you.¡± She pressed a kiss to his nose, prompting him to pant with happiness. ¡°Now, how about we head upstairs, and you can curl up at the foot of the bed until morning?¡±

He ceased his tail-wagging and gazed mournfully at the night sky. ¡°I¡¯m afraid I can¡¯t do that, Helen. It puts a tremendous strain on my back.¡±

Strong points

- The paper is clearly written and relevant to those working in the domain generalization field.
- The authors are rigorous in testing both theory-based measures and a comprehensive list of empirical measures.


Potential Improvements
- I would recommend splitting Table 1 to present separate numbers for each dataset. This would also allow some discussion of which measures performs well on which dataset and why. 
- I would recommend the authors also run their analyses on ColoredMNIST, as 1) it is the standard dataset used to benchmark most domain generalization methods, 2) it is one dataset where IRM actually outperforms ERM for some model selection strategies, and 3) it is a dataset where spurious correlation is simple and synthetically added, as opposed to the three datasets currently examined in the paper.
- Figure 3 is a bit confusing to me - the authors should define how looseness is calculated (I'm assuming it's the bound minus the target domain error), and the equation reference on line 175 is also missing. In addition, if $\epsilon_S(\hat{h})$ is the same across divergence measures, I would recommend making it a single bar for clarity.
- I would recommend moving the full equations for the bounds from Appendix Section 7 into the main paper Section 2.
- The authors could consider strengthening their analyses by adding a couple of additional datasets (maybe from non-image modalities) from the WILDS paper [1], which has also shown that ERM outperforms IRM on domain generalization tasks. The datasets proposed in WILDS also tend to be more practically useful than the ones from DomainBed. I do realize that this would be quite time-consuming though.

Recommendation

I recommend acceptance of this paper, since I believe it is a valuable continuation of the discussion started by the DomainBed paper, and the insights from this paper could lead to additional theoretical or methodological developments in domain generalization.

[1] https://arxiv.org/pdf/2012.07421.pdf

Additionally, ColoredMNIST features synthetically added spurious correlations, unlike the three datasets currently examined.

human: I'm so tired. Life caught up with me in a bad way. I feel like the astronauts when they come back from space, when gravity hits them for the first time after being weightless for so long. I have 23-day cycles, and you wouldn't think that extra five days makes a big difference, but it does. I'm basically left with three very different weeks. The week before my period I'm typically PMS-y, the week during my period I'm recovering, but still shell shocked, and the week between the two is a desperate spurt of activity in an effort to accomplish what I can before the next wave hits. It leaves me feeling frenetic, being whipped about by my hormonal rollercoaster. Five days of steady would really be nice. I could do a lot with five days.  This weekend I was complaining about it to John, telling him how lucky he is that he's steady all the time. He set me straight, he told me I need my frenzy. And he's right. Somewhere between the highs and lows is where passion is born. Passionate highs and passionate lows. My own personal yin and yang. Without it, I wouldn't have my creativity, my spark. I guess this hormonal freakshow is my muse. But man, is she a bitch.   I was almost going to be the best mom in the world today. I found out that the Fifth Ward branch library was offering a teach your baby pre-reading skills program this morning and I was planning on attending. Ellie saved my lazy, hormonal rear though by falling sound asleep at the very moment I should have been packing her into the car. Maybe next time.   I found out the Heights library has a nice Tuesday morning program schedule. I've been desperate to find something since Miss Gail left the Montrose library. She was amazing. Where are you Miss Gail!!! Maybe I'll try the Heights library next Tuesday, today I'm just bone tired.

human: Anaemia is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular (CV) events in patients with heart failure and patients with chronic kidney disease. The effect of anaemia on CV outcomes in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) remains unclear. Therefore, we investigated the prognostic value of anaemia in this group of patients.Patients with stable angina pectoris, referred for a first diagnostic coronary angiography, were eligible for this study. Only subjects with significant coronary artery disease (>50% luminal narrowing) were used for analysis (n=143). Cardiovascular events were defined as cardiovascular death, acute myocardial infarction and hospitalisation for unstable angina pectoris. Anaemia was defined according to WHO criteria as haemoglobin level ¡Ü8 mmol/l in men and ¡Ü7.5 mmol/l in women.The mean age of the population was 61.5¡À9.4 years. During follow-up (44¡À19 months), 19 CV events occurred. The diagnosis of anaemia predicted CV events, even when adjusted for other risk factors (hazard ratio 5.73, 95% confidence interval 1.49-22.13, p=0.01). In univariate analysis, serum erythropoietin levels predicted CV outcomes (p<0.05); however, this association was lost when adjusted for haemoglobin concentration.
LLM_1: Anaemia is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular (CV) events in patients with heart failure and chronic kidney disease, yet its impact on CV outcomes in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the prognostic significance of anaemia in this population. We included patients with stable angina pectoris referred for their first diagnostic coronary angiography, analyzing only those with significant CAD (>50% luminal narrowing; n=143). CV events were defined as cardiovascular death, acute myocardial infarction, and hospitalization for unstable angina pectoris. Anaemia was defined per WHO criteria as haemoglobin levels ¡Ü8 mmol/l in men and ¡Ü7.5 mmol/l in women. The mean age of participants was 61.5¡À9.4 years. Over a follow-up period of 44¡À19 months, 19 CV events occurred. The presence of anaemia significantly predicted CV events, even after adjusting for other risk factors (hazard ratio 5.73, 95% confidence interval 1.49-22.13, p=0.01). In univariate analysis, serum erythropoietin levels were associated with CV outcomes (p<0.05), but this association was not significant after adjusting for haemoglobin concentration.
LLM_2: Anaemia is recognized as an independent risk factor for cardiovascular (CV) events among patients with heart failure and chronic kidney disease; however, its influence on CV outcomes in individuals with coronary artery disease (CAD) is not well understood. This study aimed to assess the prognostic relevance of anaemia within this specific patient cohort. We examined patients diagnosed with stable angina pectoris who were referred for their initial diagnostic coronary angiography, focusing exclusively on those exhibiting significant CAD (defined as >50% luminal narrowing, n=143). CV events were operationally defined to include cardiovascular mortality, acute myocardial infarction, and hospital admissions for unstable angina pectoris. According to World Health Organization criteria, anaemia was characterized by haemoglobin levels of ¡Ü8 mmol/l in men and ¡Ü7.5 mmol/l in women. The average age of participants was 61.5¡À9.4 years. Throughout a follow-up duration of 44¡À19 months, 19 CV events were recorded. The presence of anaemia emerged as a significant predictor of CV events, even when adjusted for additional risk factors (hazard ratio 5.73, 95% confidence interval 1.49-22.13, p=0.01). In univariate analyses, serum erythropoietin levels displayed an association with CV outcomes (p<0.05); however, this correlation lost significance after controlling for haemoglobin concentration.

human: Because dipyridamole is used to assess heart rate (HR) variability, we investigated whether a low HR response during dipyridamole single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) in patients with diabetes indicates the presence of cardiac autonomic neuropathy (CAN).Subjects were 61 non-insulin-dependent diabetes patients without perfusion defects, myocardial infarction, or arrhythmia who underwent thallium 201 SPECT imaging. The control group comprised 28 subjects without diabetes. HR was measured during infusion of dipyridamole at a rate of 0.14 mg/kg/min, and peak-baseline ratios of 1.20 or less were defined as low. CAN severity was classified by standard autonomic function tests as severe (n = 22), mild (n = 19), or none (n = 20). HR ratios were significantly attenuated in patients with diabetes compared with those in control subjects (1.22 +/- 0.12 vs 1.32 +/- 0.12, P <.001). Among the patients with diabetes, HR ratios decreased as CAN severity increased from none (1.32 +/- 0.10) to mild (1.23 +/- 0.12, P <.05) to severe (1.13 +/- 0.08, P <.005). There was good correlation between HR ratio and R-R interval ratio to deep breathing and to Valsalva, and patients with low HR ratios showed an attenuated response to both tests (all P <.001). The sensitivity and specificity of HR ratios in the detection of CAN were 77% and 74% for severe CAN and 63% and 90% for mild-to-severe CAN, respectively.
LLM_1: We investigated whether a low heart rate (HR) response during dipyridamole single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) in patients with diabetes indicates cardiac autonomic neuropathy (CAN). The study involved 61 non-insulin-dependent diabetes patients without perfusion defects, myocardial infarction, or arrhythmia, and a control group of 28 non-diabetic subjects. HR was monitored during a dipyridamole infusion at 0.14 mg/kg/min, with peak-baseline ratios of 1.20 or less defined as low. CAN severity was categorized using standard autonomic function tests: severe (n = 22), mild (n = 19), and none (n = 20). Diabetes patients exhibited significantly lower HR ratios than controls (1.22 ¡À 0.12 vs. 1.32 ¡À 0.12, P < 0.001). Among diabetic patients, HR ratios decreased with increasing CAN severity: none (1.32 ¡À 0.10), mild (1.23 ¡À 0.12, P < 0.05), and severe (1.13 ¡À 0.08, P < 0.005). A strong correlation existed between HR ratios and R-R interval ratios during deep breathing and Valsalva maneuvers, with low HR ratios associated with reduced responses (all P < 0.001). Sensitivity and specificity for HR ratios in detecting severe CAN were 77% and 74%, respectively, and for mild-to-severe CAN, 63% and 90%.
LLM_2: This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between low heart rate (HR) responses during dipyridamole single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and cardiac autonomic neuropathy (CAN) in patients with diabetes. The cohort comprised 61 non-insulin-dependent diabetic patients, all of whom exhibited no perfusion defects, myocardial infarction, or arrhythmias, alongside a control group of 28 non-diabetic individuals. HR was recorded during a dipyridamole infusion at a rate of 0.14 mg/kg/min, with peak-baseline HR ratios of 1.20 or lower classified as low. The severity of CAN was assessed through standard autonomic function tests, categorizing participants into severe (n = 22), mild (n = 19), and none (n = 20). Results indicated that diabetic patients had significantly lower HR ratios compared to controls (1.22 ¡À 0.12 vs. 1.32 ¡À 0.12, P < 0.001). Among the diabetic cohort, HR ratios diminished with escalating CAN severity: none (1.32 ¡À 0.10), mild (1.23 ¡À 0.12, P < 0.05), and severe (1.13 ¡À 0.08, P < 0.005). Furthermore, a robust correlation was observed between HR ratios and R-R interval ratios during deep breathing and Valsalva maneuvers, with lower HR ratios linked to diminished autonomic responses (all P < 0.001). The sensitivity and specificity for HR ratios in identifying severe CAN were determined to be 77% and 74%, respectively, while for mild-to-severe CAN, these values were 63% and 90%.

human: Persistent hyperphosphatemia is one of the most important factors in the development of secondary hyperparathyroidism (sHPTH). Recently, we demonstrated that a higher body mass index (BMI) and female gender could predispose to a larger phosphate (P) body burden, thereby influencing the severity of sHPTH.This prospective study aimed to verify if these two risk factors, i.e. BMI and female gender, also influenced calcium (Ca) and P kinetics in the immediate post-parathyroidectomy (PTx) period in 42 consecutive adult Caucasian anuric hemodialysis (HD) patients referred for first PTx. Serum Ca and P were measured pre-PTx and on the 5 consecutive post-PTx days; serum immunoreactive parathyroid hormone (iPTH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels were measured pre-PTx and 3 days post-PTx.Ablation of parathyroid tissue determined a significant reduction in serum iPTH, ALP, Ca and P (p = 0.001). The stratification of the cohort into four groups according to the cut-off value of BMI = 25 kg/m(2) and according to gender showed the following: males and females with BMI >25 kg/m(2) (analyzed both separately and as a subgroup including males and females) had significantly higher pre-PTx serum P levels, when compared with the respective sub-groups with BMI <25 kg/m(2) (p < 0.01); a significantly higher mean area under the concentration curve (AUC) of serum P was observed in the high BMI group (males and females), when compared with the low/normal BMI group (p = 0.03); the serum P kinetics in the 5 post-PTx days did not differ between the two groups of male patients (low/normal BMI males vs. high BMI males), whereas a significantly higher mean serum P AUC was observed in the high BMI female patients, when compared with the low/normal BMI female patients (p = 0.003); finally, the serum P kinetics in the 5 post-PTx days did not differ between the two groups of low/normal male and female patients, whereas a significantly higher mean serum P AUC was observed in the high BMI female patients, when compared with the high BMI male patients (p = 0.006). A linear multiple regression analysis with the serum P AUC of each patient as a dependent variable and BMI, gender, age and dialysis duration as independent variables showed that BMI (p = 0.0001) and female gender (p = 0.001) were independent predictors of the serum P AUC.
LLM_1: Persistent hyperphosphatemia is a critical factor in secondary hyperparathyroidism (sHPTH) development. This study investigated whether body mass index (BMI) and female gender influence calcium (Ca) and phosphate (P) kinetics in 42 adult Caucasian anuric hemodialysis patients undergoing their first parathyroidectomy (PTx). Serum Ca and P levels were measured pre-PTx and over five consecutive post-PTx days, alongside serum immunoreactive parathyroid hormone (iPTH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels pre-PTx and three days post-PTx. Parathyroid tissue ablation significantly reduced serum iPTH, ALP, Ca, and P (p = 0.001). Stratification by BMI (cut-off at 25 kg/m2) and gender revealed that males and females with BMI >25 kg/m2 had significantly elevated pre-PTx serum P levels compared to those with BMI <25 kg/m2 (p < 0.01). The high BMI group exhibited a higher mean area under the concentration curve (AUC) for serum P than the low/normal BMI group (p = 0.03). Post-PTx serum P kinetics did not differ between low/normal and high BMI male patients; however, high BMI females had a significantly greater mean serum P AUC compared to low/normal BMI females (p = 0.003). Additionally, high BMI females had a higher mean serum P AUC than high BMI males (p = 0.006). Linear multiple regression analysis indicated that BMI (p = 0.0001) and female gender (p = 0.001) were independent predictors of serum P AUC.
LLM_2: Persistent hyperphosphatemia plays a pivotal role in the onset of secondary hyperparathyroidism (sHPTH). This research aimed to assess the impact of body mass index (BMI) and female gender on the kinetics of calcium (Ca) and phosphate (P) in a cohort of 42 adult Caucasian anuric hemodialysis patients who were undergoing their initial parathyroidectomy (PTx). Serum levels of Ca and P were evaluated prior to PTx and across five consecutive days following the procedure. Additionally, serum immunoreactive parathyroid hormone (iPTH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels were measured both pre-PTx and three days post-PTx. The results demonstrated that parathyroid tissue ablation led to a significant reduction in serum levels of iPTH, ALP, Ca, and P (p = 0.001). When stratified by BMI, using a cut-off of 25 kg/m2, and by gender, it was found that both males and females with a BMI exceeding 25 kg/m2 exhibited significantly higher pre-PTx serum P levels in comparison to those with a BMI below this threshold (p < 0.01). Notably, the high BMI group displayed a greater mean area under the concentration curve (AUC) for serum P than the low/normal BMI group (p = 0.03). While post-PTx serum P kinetics were comparable between low/normal and high BMI male patients, high BMI females demonstrated a markedly elevated mean serum P AUC compared to their low/normal BMI counterparts (p = 0.003). Furthermore, high BMI females had a significantly higher mean serum P AUC than high BMI males (p = 0.006). Linear multiple regression analysis established that both BMI (p = 0.0001) and female gender (p = 0.001) serve as independent predictors of serum P AUC.

human: What is God going to do today?      God was woken up around 5:30 am. Two of her favorite beings were walking over her begging for attention. God got up, went to the bathroom and then back to bed. The kids ran downstairs thinking it was breakfast. ('not till 6:30' she says)     God couldn't sleep, her boyfriend kept harassing her. Poke Poke Poke, 'what ya doing?', 'where are the cats?' God was getting annoyed.   She got up and went to the bathroom and brushed her hair, and went back to bed. Poke Poke Poke, God threatened her boyfriend with eternal damnation. Her boyfriend laughed knowing that doesn't exist.      Six thirty, God gets up (for real this time). Boyfriend says 'Come back to bed.' So God does, 6:36, 'I only have 24 minutes before my bus comes' exclaims God. The cats are furious.     Finally she gets up, gets dressed and goes downstairs. God's cats are in a panic. Breakfast is 4 minutes late.     God gets her lunch ready for work, Left over roasted red pepper pesto on whole wheat pasta with chicken (heavenly), a banana, and a yogurt. God's little sister is in the way, cooking a 3 course meal for breakfast (well one course but it had a lot of preparation). God grabs a bowl of cereal and sits down to watch some TV.     God's boyfriend stumbles downstairs. They sit together watching the news, making fun of the reporters.     It is now 6:57, 3 minutes till God has to leave. A quick brush of the teeth (as tastefully suggested by the boyfriend) and she's out the door.     I have no idea where God works, I do know that she gets off at 5, and usually has to stop at the store on her way home.
LLM_1:
What is God going to do today? God was woken up around 5:30 am by two of her favorite beings begging for attention. After a quick trip to the bathroom, she returned to bed. The kids rushed downstairs, eager for breakfast, but God reminded them it wouldn't be ready until 6:30.

Unable to sleep, her boyfriend kept poking her, asking, "What ya doing?" and "Where are the cats?" Growing annoyed, God got up again, brushed her hair, and tried to settle back in bed. When her boyfriend persisted, she jokingly threatened him with eternal damnation, but he just laughed, knowing it was all in good fun.

At 6:30, God finally got up for real. Her boyfriend urged her to come back to bed, but she reminded him that she only had 24 minutes before her bus. The cats were in a frenzy, frustrated that breakfast was running four minutes late.

After getting dressed and heading downstairs, God prepared her lunch¡ªleftover roasted red pepper pesto pasta with chicken, a banana, and yogurt. Meanwhile, her little sister was busy cooking an elaborate breakfast. With little time to spare, God settled for a bowl of cereal and watched some TV.

As the clock ticked to 6:57, with just three minutes left until she had to leave, God quickly brushed her teeth, as suggested by her boyfriend, and rushed out the door. I don't know where God works, but I do know she finishes at 5 and typically stops at the store on her way home.

After a swift trip to the bathroom, she crawled back into bed, only to hear the kids racing downstairs, eager for breakfast. However, God reminded them that breakfast wouldn¡¯t be served until 6:30.

With sleep eluding him, her boyfriend kept poking her, asking, "What are you up to?" and "Where are the cats?" Growing a bit irritated, God decided to rise once more. She brushed her hair and attempted to settle back down, but her boyfriend¡¯s persistence led her to jokingly threaten him with eternal damnation. He just chuckled, fully aware it was all in good spirits.

Finally, at 6:30, God got out of bed for real. Her boyfriend encouraged her to return to bed, but she pointed out that she only had 24 minutes before her bus was due. Meanwhile, the cats were in a tizzy, clearly unhappy that breakfast was running four minutes late.

After getting dressed and heading downstairs, God prepared her lunch: leftover roasted red pepper pesto pasta with chicken, accompanied by a banana and some yogurt. Her little sister, on the other hand, was busy whipping up an elaborate breakfast. With time slipping away, God opted for a quick bowl of cereal while catching a few moments of TV.

As the clock struck 6:57, with just three minutes left before she needed to leave, God quickly brushed her teeth, per her boyfriend's suggestion, and dashed out the door. While I can't say where God works, I do know that her day wraps up at 5 PM, and she often stops by the store on her way home.

My wife was sleeping peacefully next to me. I smoothed a curl that clung to her neck and kissed her on the cheek. Lazily, she woke and smiled. 
 
 We moved for a while, kissing and generally enjoying ourselves. Eventually she sat up. She was beautiful like this. Hair wild, eyes bright. Naked in bed. 
 
 I scanned her form slowly, enjoying her curves and the look on her face as she watched me. Her slender neck, sloping shoulders, perfect breasts, glowing stomach.... Wait what? 
 
 My heart sank. I strained my eyes, trying to convince myself that what I saw was just a trick of the light. 
 
 There was no mistake. 
 
 My wife was pregnant, and the child inside her would one day be my undoing. My family gift, knowing what person or thing would kill us, has never been more of a curse. 
 
 `` Honey?'' My wife's concerned voice breaks through my thoughts. I force a smile on my face. 
 
 `` Yes dear?'' 
 
 -- -- -- 
 Will add more later

We shared tender kisses, savoring the moment until she sat up. She looked stunning¡ªhair tousled, eyes sparkling, and bare in bed.

I admired her form, drinking in her curves as she watched me. Her slender neck, graceful shoulders, perfect breasts, and glowing stomach... Wait, what?

Panic gripped my heart. I strained my eyes, hoping it was just a trick of the light.

But there was no mistake.

My wife was pregnant, and the child within her felt like a harbinger of my doom. My family's gift, knowing what could kill us, had never felt more like a curse.

¡°Honey?¡± Her concerned voice broke through my thoughts. I forced a smile.

¡°Yes, dear?¡±

My wife lay beside me, enveloped in a tranquil slumber. I gently brushed a stray curl from her neck and pressed a soft kiss to her cheek. Slowly, she stirred awake, a smile blooming on her lips.

We exchanged sweet, lingering kisses, relishing the intimacy of the moment, until she propped herself up. She was a vision of beauty¡ªher hair a delightful mess, her eyes alight with joy, and the sheets draped over her bare form.

I couldn¡¯t help but admire her silhouette, drinking in the sight of her curves as she gazed back at me. Her delicate neck, elegant shoulders, perfectly shaped breasts, and the soft glow of her belly... Wait, what?

A sudden wave of panic washed over me. I squinted, hoping that what I saw was merely an illusion cast by the morning light.

But there was no denying it.

My wife was pregnant, and the life growing within her felt like an omen of impending doom. The legacy of my family, which had always known what could bring us to ruin, now felt like an unbearable burden.

¡°Honey?¡± Her voice, laced with concern, pulled me from my spiraling thoughts. I forced a smile, hiding the turmoil within.

¡°Yes, my love?¡±

human: Dietary selenium is of fundamental importance to maintain optimal immune function and enhance immunity during infection. To this end, we examined the effect of selenium on macrophage bactericidal activities against Staphylococcus aureus.Assays were performed in golden Syrian hamsters and peritoneal macrophages cultured with S. aureus and different concentrations of selenium.Infected and selenium-supplemented animals have significantly decreased levels of serum nitric oxide (NO) production when compared with infected but non-selenium-supplemented animals at day 7 post-infection (p < 0.05). A low dose of 5 ng/mL selenium induced a significant decrease in macrophage NO production, but significant increase in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) levels (respectively, p = 0.009, p < 0.001). The NO production and H2O2 levels were significantly increased with increasing concentrations of selenium; the optimal macrophage activity levels were reached at 20 ng/mL. The concentration of 5 ng/mL of selenium induced a significant decrease in the bacterial arginase activity but a significant increase in the macrophage arginase activity. The dose of 20 ng/mL selenium induced a significant decrease of bacterial growth (p < 0.0001) and a significant increase in macrophage phagocytic activity, NO production/arginase balance and S. aureus killing (for all comparisons, p < 0.001).
LLM_1: Dietary selenium is crucial for optimal immune function and infection response. This study evaluated selenium's effects on macrophage bactericidal activity against Staphylococcus aureus using golden Syrian hamsters and cultured peritoneal macrophages. Infected and selenium-supplemented animals showed significantly lower serum nitric oxide (NO) levels compared to infected controls without selenium at day 7 post-infection (p < 0.05). A low dose of 5 ng/mL selenium resulted in a notable decrease in macrophage NO production, accompanied by a significant increase in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) levels (p = 0.009, p < 0.001). Both NO and H2O2 levels increased with higher selenium concentrations, peaking at 20 ng/mL. The 5 ng/mL selenium dose decreased bacterial arginase activity while increasing macrophage arginase activity. At 20 ng/mL, selenium significantly reduced bacterial growth (p < 0.0001) and enhanced macrophage phagocytic activity, NO production/arginase balance, and S. aureus killing (all comparisons, p < 0.001).
LLM_2: Dietary selenium plays a vital role in supporting immune function and the response to infections. This investigation examined the influence of selenium on the bactericidal activity of macrophages against *Staphylococcus aureus*, utilizing golden Syrian hamsters and cultured peritoneal macrophages. Results indicated that infected hamsters receiving selenium supplementation exhibited significantly lower serum nitric oxide (NO) levels compared to the infected controls lacking selenium at seven days post-infection (p < 0.05). Administration of a low selenium dose of 5 ng/mL led to a marked reduction in macrophage NO production, while simultaneously causing a significant increase in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) levels (p = 0.009, p < 0.001). Notably, both NO and H2O2 concentrations escalated with rising selenium levels, reaching a peak at 20 ng/mL. The 5 ng/mL selenium dose decreased bacterial arginase activity, while enhancing macrophage arginase activity. At the highest concentration of 20 ng/mL, selenium significantly inhibited bacterial growth (p < 0.0001) and improved macrophage phagocytic activity, NO production/arginase balance, and the killing of *S. aureus* (all comparisons, p < 0.001).

The award of 10 council houses since 1997 "seemed to all benefit members of Councillor [Mahboob] Hussain's family", the council said.
"Patterns of behaviour" looked like "conspiracy to defraud and/or misconduct in a public office", a council investigation report said.
Mr Hussain said the accusations were "purely politically-motivated".
The report further alleged another serving councillor, Babu Singh Bawa, and Mr Hussain "benefitted from a unique Compulsory Purchase Order [CPO] pilot scheme".
Read more stories from Birmingham and the Black Country
Both men expressed an interest in land in 1998 which became the subject of an exclusive bid for self-build plots a year later, the council said.
The only bids the council said it received for the plots in September 1999 were from St Paul's ward councillor Mr Bawa and Mr Hussain and their immediate family members.
For one plot, the four bids received were all from Mr Hussain and members of his family, according to the report.
"The bids gave the impression of potential cover pricing and bid suppression," the authority said.
Mr Hussain said the allegations were an attempt to "smear" his character and the council had published allegations which had "not been properly investigated".
He said he would "cooperate fully with any investigation because he had done nothing wrong".
The council said Mr Bawa later failed to declare his role as a councillor when a planning application was submitted on his behalf in October 2007.
Mr Bawa has not yet responded to a BBC request for comment.
The report said a separate potential alleged code of conduct breach should be looked into further by the council.
In February 2011 former economy chief councillor Ian Jones asked for a property to be removed from a public auction at the request of the then-council leader, now deceased, Darren Cooper and instead be sold to a family member of Councillor Mohammad Rouf at a price "significantly below" what it was eventually sold for under a sealed bid process a year later - also to a relative of Mr Rouf, the report said.
Mr Jones said he had had "no opportunity to see or understand any evidence of the allegations against him" before Wednesday's report and questioned the council's "impartiality in any investigation" as information he had previously provided "had not been pursued".
There was also a "breach of the council's financial regulations and procedures" due to an informal arrangement between former borough mayor Derek Rowley while he was a serving councillor, and a member of the public to sell four council-owned containers from Jubilee Park in Tipton, according to the council.
"Conflicting information" over the sums involved, and the fact both Mr Rowley and a former employee were no longer involved with the council, meant "there may be little advantage to be gained from pursuing this matter further at this stage", the report said.
"No fault" was meanwhile found in the actions of another councillor, Stephen Frear, over the award of a three-bed council house to him.
Oldbury ward councillor Mr Hussain and Mr Jones stood down from the borough's ruling cabinet after an earlier investigation into alleged irregularities in the sale of the council's former properties.
West Midlands Police confirmed the allegations were referred to the force on 3 January and were being reviewed. The BBC has contacted councillors Frear and Rouf.

The report also alleged that another councillor, Babu Singh Bawa, and Mr. Hussain benefitted from a unique Compulsory Purchase Order pilot scheme. The council noted that the only bids for the plots in September 1999 came from Mr. Bawa, Mr. Hussain, and their families, with one plot receiving four bids solely from Mr. Hussain and his relatives. The authority indicated these bids suggested potential cover pricing and bid suppression.

Mr. Hussain characterized the allegations as a smear campaign, asserting that the council's claims were inadequately investigated. He vowed to cooperate fully with any investigation, insisting he had done nothing wrong. The report mentioned that Mr. Bawa failed to declare his councillor role during a planning application submitted on his behalf in October 2007. Mr. Bawa has not yet responded to BBC inquiries.

The report also suggested a separate potential breach of the code of conduct for further investigation. In February 2011, former economy chief Ian Jones was asked to withdraw a property from public auction at the then-council leader Darren Cooper's request, selling it instead to a family member of Councillor Mohammad Rouf at a significantly lower price. Mr. Jones claimed he had not been able to review evidence against him before the report and questioned the council's impartiality in the investigation.

Additionally, the council identified a breach of financial regulations involving former borough mayor Derek Rowley, who made an informal agreement to sell council-owned containers from Jubilee Park. The report noted conflicting information regarding the sums involved, suggesting little benefit in pursuing the matter further.

No faults were found in the actions of another councillor, Stephen Frear, concerning the award of a three-bedroom council house to him. human: This paper gives improved bounds for estimating the trace of a matrix using matrix-vector products. It turns what was previous a multiplicative factor of log(1 / failure probability) into an additive one, and shows that this bound is tight up to a loglog factor. These methods are evaluated on a wide range of matrices, several of which are implicitly represented (via the Lanczos method), and a better success probability was observed. I believe this is a solid result: trace estimators have been well studied, and the dependence on success probability is a nature parameter for analyzing algorithmic performances. The paper essentially closes off this dependence issue by showing that a additive log(1 / failure probability) is sufficient, and also necessary up to a loglog factor. They also empirically demonstrate this improvement by showing the failure probability of this method versus previous, and raises some interesting questions about better parallel performances of such estimators. The importance of trace estimators across numerical/ML algorithms make this paper a clear accept. On the other hand, I feel the experiments demonstrate these gains are rather limited, and occur in performance only when parallelism is brought in. However, I believe they provide natural directions to extend some of the primitives developed here, and the evidences provided in the responses indicate that significantly more can be done on this front. My impression is that failure probability are usually an artifact of the analysis. Outer loops that utilize these trace estimators are often ok with some randomized noise in the answer, and I feel empirical results (in either positive or negative directions) on this would be interesting. Also, the performance gains of these methods shown in Fig 1 seems to be around 1.5x, which to me feels rather marginal. It might take more end-to-end experiments to demonstrate more pronounced gains of these methods. I'm very happy that the authors took time to provide additional empirical evaluations in their responses, and am now quite interested in running my own experiments on this topic.
LLM_1: This paper presents improved bounds for estimating the trace of a matrix using matrix-vector products. It transforms the previously multiplicative factor of log(1 / failure probability) into an additive one, demonstrating that this bound is tight up to a loglog factor. The methods are evaluated on various matrices, including those implicitly represented via the Lanczos method, resulting in a better success probability. This represents a solid contribution, as trace estimators are well-studied, and the dependence on success probability is a critical parameter for analyzing algorithmic performance. The authors effectively address this issue by establishing that an additive log(1 / failure probability) is both sufficient and necessary up to a loglog factor. They also empirically compare their method's failure probability to previous approaches and raise intriguing questions regarding the parallel performance of these estimators. Given the significance of trace estimators in numerical and machine learning algorithms, this paper warrants acceptance. However, the experiments suggest that performance gains are limited and primarily arise with the introduction of parallelism. There are promising avenues to extend the primitives developed here, and the authors¡¯ responses indicate potential for further exploration. It is my impression that failure probabilities often stem from analysis artifacts; outer loops using these trace estimators may tolerate some randomized noise. Empirical results on this aspect would be valuable. Additionally, the performance gains highlighted in Fig 1 appear to be around 1.5x, which seems marginal. More extensive end-to-end experiments may be necessary to showcase more significant improvements. I appreciate the authors' efforts in providing additional empirical evaluations in their responses and am now interested in conducting my own experiments on this topic.
LLM_2:
This paper offers enhanced bounds for estimating the trace of a matrix through the use of matrix-vector products. Notably, it converts the earlier multiplicative factor of log(1 / failure probability) into an additive one, proving that this new bound is tight up to a loglog factor. The authors assess their methods on various matrices, including those represented implicitly via the Lanczos method, which leads to improved success probabilities. This work constitutes a meaningful contribution, particularly given the extensive study of trace estimators and the critical nature of success probability in evaluating algorithmic efficacy. 

The authors adeptly tackle this challenge by demonstrating that an additive log(1 / failure probability) is both necessary and sufficient, again up to a loglog factor. They also provide empirical comparisons between their method's failure probability and those of previous techniques, prompting thought-provoking inquiries about the parallel performance of these estimators. Considering the importance of trace estimators in numerical computations and machine learning, this paper deserves to be accepted. 

However, the experimental results suggest that the performance improvements may be modest and primarily emerge with the incorporation of parallelism. There are encouraging opportunities to expand upon the primitives introduced in this study, and the authors' responses show promise for further investigation. I believe that many failure probabilities can often be attributed to analytical artifacts; thus, outer loops utilizing these trace estimators may be capable of accommodating some degree of randomized noise. Empirical investigations into this aspect would be beneficial. 

Furthermore, the performance enhancements illustrated in Fig. 1 appear to be around 1.5x, which may be considered marginal. To demonstrate more substantial improvements, more comprehensive end-to-end experiments could be warranted. I appreciate the authors' efforts in providing additional empirical evaluations in their responses, and I am now motivated to conduct my own experiments on this topic.

human: Visceral obesity is associated with the rising incidence of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome. Low-grade chronic inflammation and oxidative stress synergize in obesity and obesity-induced disorders.We searched a cluster of molecules that support interactions between these stress conditions in monocytes.RNA expressions in blood monocytes of two independent cohorts comprising 21 and 102 obese persons and 46 age-matched controls were determined by microarray and independently validated by quantitative RT-PCR analysis. The effect of three-month weight loss after bariatric surgery was determined. The effect of RNA silencing on inflammation and oxidative stress was studied in human monocytic THP-1 cells.Interleukin-1 receptor-associated kinase-3 (IRAK3), key inhibitor of IRAK/NF¦ÊB-mediated chronic inflammation, is downregulated in monocytes of obese persons. Low IRAK3 was associated with high superoxide dismutase-2 (SOD2), a marker of mitochondrial oxidative stress. A comparable expression profile was also detected in visceral adipose tissue of the same obese subjects. Low IRAK3 and high SOD2 was associated with a high prevalence of metabolic syndrome (odds ratio: 9.3; sensitivity: 91%; specificity: 77%). By comparison, the odds ratio of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, a widely used marker of systemic inflammation, was 4.3 (sensitivity: 69%; specificity: 66%). Weight loss was associated with an increase in IRAK3 and a decrease in SOD2, in association with a lowering of systemic inflammation and a decreasing number of metabolic syndrome components. We identified the increase in reactive oxygen species in combination with obesity-associated low adiponectin and high glucose and interleukin-6 as cause of the decrease in IRAK3 in THP-1 cells in vitro.
LLM_1: Visceral obesity is linked to the increasing incidence of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome, driven by low-grade chronic inflammation and oxidative stress. We investigated a cluster of molecules that mediate interactions between these stress conditions in monocytes. RNA expression in blood monocytes from two independent cohorts¡ª21 obese individuals and 46 age-matched controls, and 102 obese individuals¡ªwas analyzed via microarray and validated by quantitative RT-PCR. The effects of a three-month weight loss following bariatric surgery were assessed, alongside RNA silencing's impact on inflammation and oxidative stress in human monocytic THP-1 cells. Interleukin-1 receptor-associated kinase-3 (IRAK3), a crucial inhibitor of IRAK/NF¦ÊB-mediated chronic inflammation, was found to be downregulated in obese monocytes. Low IRAK3 levels correlated with elevated superoxide dismutase-2 (SOD2), indicative of mitochondrial oxidative stress. A similar expression pattern was observed in visceral adipose tissue of the same subjects. Low IRAK3 and high SOD2 were associated with a heightened prevalence of metabolic syndrome (odds ratio: 9.3; sensitivity: 91%; specificity: 77%), compared to high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, which had an odds ratio of 4.3 (sensitivity: 69%; specificity: 66%). Weight loss resulted in increased IRAK3 and decreased SOD2 levels, coinciding with reduced systemic inflammation and fewer metabolic syndrome components. Additionally, the rise in reactive oxygen species, compounded by obesity-related low adiponectin and elevated glucose and interleukin-6 levels, contributed to the observed decrease in IRAK3 in vitro in THP-1 cells.
LLM_2: Visceral obesity has been increasingly associated with the rising prevalence of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome, largely attributed to chronic low-grade inflammation and oxidative stress. This study explores a specific set of molecules that facilitate the interactions between these stress-related conditions in monocytes. We conducted an analysis of RNA expression in blood monocytes from two distinct cohorts: one comprising 21 obese individuals and 46 age-matched controls, and the other consisting of 102 obese individuals. This analysis utilized microarray technology, subsequently validated through quantitative RT-PCR. We also evaluated the impact of a three-month weight loss regimen following bariatric surgery, as well as the effects of RNA silencing on inflammation and oxidative stress in human monocytic THP-1 cells. Our findings revealed a significant downregulation of interleukin-1 receptor-associated kinase-3 (IRAK3), a key inhibitor of IRAK/NF¦ÊB-mediated chronic inflammation, in the monocytes of obese subjects. Notably, lower IRAK3 levels were associated with increased superoxide dismutase-2 (SOD2), suggesting heightened mitochondrial oxidative stress. A similar expression trend was detected in the visceral adipose tissue of these individuals. The correlation between reduced IRAK3 and elevated SOD2 was linked to a greater incidence of metabolic syndrome (odds ratio: 9.3; sensitivity: 91%; specificity: 77%), in contrast to high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, which exhibited an odds ratio of 4.3 (sensitivity: 69%; specificity: 66%). Post-weight loss, we observed an increase in IRAK3 levels alongside a decrease in SOD2, which paralleled reductions in systemic inflammation and the number of metabolic syndrome components. Furthermore, the rise in reactive oxygen species, exacerbated by obesity-induced low adiponectin levels and elevated glucose and interleukin-6 concentrations, appears to mediate the observed decline in IRAK3 in vitro within THP-1 cells.
