But his zest for life and inspiring charity work, which has now seen him raise more than ¡ê1m, continues to drive him on.
And a unique rehabilitation centre treating people with catastrophic injuries which is under construction and set to be opened in September means many more will benefit in the years to come.
The Get Busy Living Centre near Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire will see Hampson's long-term dream become a reality.
Hampson, now 32, told BBC East Midlands Today: "To see something tangible for the Foundation and for our beneficiaries to come along to, and to be able to offer them a place for home, a purpose, is so, so important.
"We'd spoken about it on numerous occasions, how we wanted to build a centre and things have moved on so quickly. Now it's actually a physical building it's pretty impressive."
Former Leicester Tigers and England youth international Hampson was injured when a scrum collapsed while training with the England Under-21 squad in 2005 and he can only breathe with the help of a ventilator.
But he set up the Matt Hampson Foundation when he came out of hospital which has already helped hundreds of people in similar situations. The Get Busy Living Centre is the next step.
"When I left hospital I got stuck in a rut and didn't really have a purpose and didn't know what to do with the rest of my life," Hampson explained.
"I was very lucky to have a foundation to channel my energy in, to to do something purposeful, but a lot of people haven't got that purpose and that light at the end of the tunnel. This building will offer that help and purpose."
The ¡ê1m total has been reached since the Foundation was given charitable status in 2011.
Now the Foundation is laying foundations of a different kind at a derelict old aircraft hanger at Burrough on the Hill.
The site is being transformed into a state-of-the-art facility where beneficiaries will be able to receive physical rehabilitation, spend time with their families and share experiences.
The project has been made possible thanks to a number of local firms and construction companies, many of whom have offered their time services and expertise for free.
And Hampson has an impressive list of stars who have lent their support in all sorts of ways, including ex-England rugby union stars Martin Johnson, Johnny Wilkinson, Mike Tindall and Austin Healey, Leicester centre Manu Tuilagi and England cricketer Stuart Broad.
Former England captain and 2003 World Cup winner Tindall, who is patron of the Matt Hampson Foundation, said the new facility will provide a complete service and that Hampson's journey and charitable work remains a huge inspiration.
"I'm in awe of him in terms of how he's coped with the cards he's been dealt and how he's spurred others on," Tindall said. "He doesn't let anything stop him.
"I don't think there's many places out there that are able to provide not just the physio side, the exercise side, maximising that, but also the community side.
"That's one of the main goals of the centre, to pull families in, because I think people forget about that, how hard it becomes for them. It's not just the beneficiaries. Families get confused, they don't understand where's the best place to go to help, what should they be doing?
"Everyone talks about mental health nowadays, bottling things up, being able to have that outlet. Here you are going to naturally create that and I think that will benefit everyone."
Roy Jackson, chairman of the Trustees at the Matt Hampson Foundation, added: "It's always been Matt's dream since his accident to do things for other people. This Get Busy Living centre is going to supply that need.
"It's been nothing but a building site since October, and now to go up there and see the steel up, to walk in, you can actually feel what's going to happen in that building.
"It will be a fantastic place for Matt to continue to inspire people, and realise there is life after a spinal injury.
"I know we've helped over 100 beneficiaries and we've donated more than a million pounds and that will increase when the centre opens. But it's not just the cash. We do more than that. It's the inspiration Matt gives to people. More than just buying wheelchairs or that sort of thing."
Natalie Jackson, BBC East Midlands Today sports editor, first interviewed Hampson in hospital 12 years ago, just months after his injury.
"When the accident first happened he couldn't move or speak and only communicate with his eyes," she said.
"Matt spent 17 months in hospital and I spent his last week filming with him before he came home. What stood out even in the months after the accident was his awe-inspiring positivity and love for life.
"He was the life and soul in the Spinal Injuries National Centre at Stoke Manderville. Some people had got their injury while tripping or slipping in the shower. Matt said he was lucky that he got the injury doing something he loved and felt the injury would make him a better person.
"He explained being a sports person you need to be very selfish. He said now he sits and listens to people and has more time for them and felt that he now had an opportunity to help others and change lives. He has lived that sentiment every day since and never ceases to amaze me with his incredible attitude and determination to inspire others."
LLM_1:
Matt Hampson's passion for life and charitable work has raised over ¡ê1 million and continues to inspire others. His long-held dream of establishing the Get Busy Living Centre, a rehabilitation facility for those with catastrophic injuries, is set to open in September near Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire.

At 32, Hampson expressed his enthusiasm to BBC East Midlands Today, saying, "To see something tangible for the Foundation and for our beneficiaries is so important. Now that it's a physical building, it's impressive." 

Hampson, a former Leicester Tigers and England youth international, sustained severe injuries in a training accident in 2005, requiring a ventilator to breathe. After leaving the hospital, he founded the Matt Hampson Foundation, which has supported hundreds facing similar challenges.

Reflecting on his journey, Hampson noted, "I got stuck in a rut without a purpose. The Foundation gave me a channel for my energy, but many lack that direction. This building will provide help and purpose."

Since gaining charitable status in 2011, the Foundation has reached its ¡ê1 million fundraising goal and is transforming a derelict aircraft hangar in Burrough on the Hill into a state-of-the-art rehabilitation facility for beneficiaries and their families. Local businesses have generously contributed their services to the project.

The paper at question tackles the well-known problem of differentially private (DP) deep learning: already for moderate privacy guarantees, the model performance suffers greatly.

The paper proposes a particular SDE based method for obtaining privacy for ResNets. DP and stochastic differential equations have been considered in conjunction before e.g. in

Wang, Y.X., Fienberg, S. and Smola, A., 2015, June. Privacy for free: Posterior sampling and stochastic gradient monte carlo. In International Conference on Machine Learning (pp. 2493-2502).

Li, B., Chen, C., Liu, H. and Carin, L., 2019, April. On connecting stochastic gradient MCMC and differential privacy. In The 22nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics (pp. 557-566). PMLR.

(you might consider adding these references).

Although providing an interesting approach by combining DP deep learning and SDEs, I think the paper has some major deficits.
One of them is certain sloppiness with the presentation. I do not understand how the forward and backward Euler discretisations correspond to backward and forward propagation of ResNet layers. The main results are regarding the DP-privacy guarantees of the method (Thm. 1 and Thm. 2).
However these DP-guarantees are not used anywhere in the experiments, and it remains a mystery to me what is actually DP protected.
Another criticism is regarding the experiments: when comparing to DP-SGD, there are no eps,delta-values given, it remains mystery how private the method is and how private is DP-SGD for the choice of hyperparameters listed.

The paper would require a major revision and therefore I cannot recommend it for publication in ICLR.

EDIT: The authors have answered my questions and it clarified a lot. Thus I raise my score by one. However, I am still suspicious about the value of the DP result: for example, it is not discussed why would the residual mapping have an L2-sensitivity G (as stated in the assumptions of the theorem). Also, the reported privacy values in the end of the revised version of the paper (epsilon > 1000) are not meaningful. As far as I see, the experiments give an example where this given membership inference attack works better for DP-SGD protected model than for this residual perturbed version. However the paper does not give any privacy guarantees for the residual perturbation method. Whether the L2-sensitivity can be obtained with e.g. batch normalisation remains unclear to me. I think that the paper would require a careful rewriting.
LLM_1:
The paper addresses the challenge of differentially private (DP) deep learning, noting that even moderate privacy guarantees significantly impair model performance. It introduces a specific stochastic differential equation (SDE) method to enhance privacy in ResNets. Previous works have explored the intersection of DP and SDEs, such as Wang et al. (2015) and Li et al. (2019), which could be beneficial to reference.

While the paper presents an intriguing approach by merging DP deep learning with SDEs, it exhibits notable weaknesses. One major issue is a lack of clarity in the presentation; the relationship between forward and backward Euler discretizations and ResNet layer propagation is unclear. The main contributions focus on the DP-privacy guarantees (Theorems 1 and 2), yet these guarantees are not utilized in the experimental section, leaving the actual DP protection ambiguous.

Additionally, the experimental comparisons to DP-SGD lack specified epsilon and delta values, obscuring the privacy levels of both the proposed method and DP-SGD based on the listed hyperparameters. 

The paper requires substantial revision, and I cannot recommend it for publication in ICLR.

EDIT: Following the authors' responses to my questions, my score has increased by one due to improved clarity. However, I remain skeptical about the DP results. For instance, the assumption regarding the residual mapping's L2-sensitivity G is not justified. Furthermore, the reported privacy values (epsilon > 1000) are not meaningful. Experiments suggested that membership inference attacks perform better on DP-SGD models than on the residual perturbed version, yet no privacy guarantees are provided for the latter. The potential impact of batch normalization on L2-sensitivity also remains unclear. The paper requires careful rewriting.
LLM_2:
The manuscript tackles the issue of differentially private (DP) deep learning, emphasizing that even modest privacy guarantees can severely hinder model performance. It proposes a novel stochastic differential equation (SDE) approach aimed at enhancing privacy within ResNet architectures. Notably, prior studies, such as those by Wang et al. (2015) and Li et al. (2019), have investigated the intersection of DP and SDEs, and referencing these works could strengthen the paper.

While the integration of DP deep learning with SDEs is a compelling concept, the paper suffers from several significant shortcomings. A primary concern is the lack of clarity in the exposition; specifically, the connection between the forward and backward Euler discretizations and the propagation of ResNet layers is not well articulated. Although the main contributions are centered on the DP-privacy guarantees outlined in Theorems 1 and 2, these guarantees are not applied within the experimental framework, which leaves the actual level of DP protection unclear.

Moreover, in the experimental comparisons with DP-SGD, the absence of clearly defined epsilon and delta values obscures the privacy levels associated with both the proposed method and the DP-SGD, particularly in relation to the hyperparameters provided.

Overall, the manuscript requires comprehensive revisions, and I cannot endorse it for publication in ICLR at this time.

**EDIT:** After considering the authors' responses to my inquiries, I have increased my score by one due to enhanced clarity. However, I still harbor doubts regarding the DP results. For instance, the assumption concerning the L2-sensitivity of the residual mapping, denoted as G, lacks sufficient justification. Additionally, the reported privacy values (epsilon > 1000) do not hold practical significance. The experiments indicate that membership inference attacks perform better against DP-SGD models than the residual perturbed version, yet no privacy guarantees are provided for the latter. Furthermore, the influence of batch normalization on L2-sensitivity remains ambiguous. The manuscript necessitates thorough rewriting.

`` God dammit! Would you shut the hell up woman!'' said Michael as he slapped his wife for the third time this day. 
 
 `` You're drunk again. Why do you always do this. I love you honey.'' wept Rachel as she lay there on the floor. `` I wanted to surprise you with this news... I'm pregnant'' 
 
 Michael face turns beet red as he smashes the furniture in the house. Going on a rampage screaming about how he does n't want a child and that they can not afford to raise one. He storms out of the house saying he will not be there to support her and raise the child. As he leaves the sound of Rachel crying echos through the empty house. 
 
 9 Months later... 
 
 Rachel is the maternity ward on her due day about to be induced. The doctor checks her cervix. 
 
 `` Ok Rachel, your 8cm dilated. You will have your baby any moment so just relax and let your body do its thing naturally.'' As Rachel watches him leave her eyes fixate on a man she has n't seen in months. 
 
 `` Michael, what are you doing here?'' 
 
 `` I came to apologize'' he said. `` Ever since I left the house all those months ago I have been kicking myself for not being there and supporting you in your time of need. I have been going to AA meetings and have been sober ever since. I want to be here with you now more than ever.'' 
 
 As he finished saying his words Rachel goes into labor. The doctor rushes in and starts the procedure. 30 minutes later Rachel screams in agony as the final push brings forth a beautiful baby boy. The doctor cleans him up and hands her to his mother. As both Michael and Rachel stare deep into the boy's beautiful eyes, Michael hold Rachel's hand. 
 
 `` I love you'' he says. 
 
 `` And I you'' she replies. 
 
 As they exchanged these sentimental expression the baby coos and laughs looks at his parents and slowly closes his eyes...

human:
This paper does a good job of raising awareness of adversarial attacks in lifelong learning research with deep neural networks. This is the first time I have considered this problem, but not sure whether any prior work exists in the specific subfield.

At the conceptual level, many issues can arise when a lifelong learner is attacked, since systematic negative bias could be introduced in the training process and may be very difficult to remove, given the tendency to 'remember everything' which dominates current approaches.

The paper isolates one lifelong learning approach (A-GEM) which is characteristic of one (of many) different approaches to lifelong learning, and investigates its robustness to standard adversarial attacks and a novel attack developed within this paper, which is stronger, but specific to episodic memory approaches.

I cannot recommend acceptance at this point for the following reasons:
1) I am not sure what I can generalize away from this paper to the immediate subfield and beyond. The paper claims that the investigated method is SOTA, but it's not clear this is the case, even in restricted class of similar episodic memory based models, see [1] for an independent evaluation of many such approaches. Is there any reasons why conclusions about this particular method are indeed representative of its class?
2) While the paper does not explicitly make this claim, the title suggests that 'gradient reversion' attacks apply to lifelong learning models in general. Why is this class of approaches particularly informative such that conclusions may hold in general? Are other methods in this class more susceptible to these attacks and can the proposed attack be applied to the whole class, or even other types of approaches? This should be clarified!


References
[1] Matthias De Lange, Rahaf Aljundi, Marc Masana, Sarah Parisot, Xu Jia, Ales Leonardis, Gregory Slabaugh, Tinne Tuytelaars,  Continual learning: A comparative study on how to defy forgetting in classification tasks, https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08383
LLM_1:
This paper effectively highlights the issue of adversarial attacks in lifelong learning with deep neural networks. While this is my first exposure to this problem, I am uncertain if prior work in this specific subfield exists.

At a conceptual level, adversarial attacks could introduce systematic negative biases in the training process of lifelong learners, complicating the removal of such biases due to the prevalent tendency of current methods to "remember everything."

The paper focuses on one lifelong learning approach, A-GEM, which represents just one of many strategies in the field. It examines its robustness against standard adversarial attacks as well as a novel, stronger attack tailored to episodic memory methods.

I cannot recommend acceptance at this stage for the following reasons:
1) The generalizability of the findings to the broader subfield is unclear. Although the paper claims the investigated method is state-of-the-art, this assertion lacks clarity, even among similar episodic memory models. Refer to [1] for an independent assessment of various approaches. What justifies the conclusion that the results for this method are representative of its class?
2) The title implies that "gradient reversion" attacks are applicable to lifelong learning models broadly. What makes this class particularly relevant for general conclusions? Are other methods within this class more vulnerable to such attacks, and can the proposed attack be extended to other approaches? This needs clarification.

References  
[1] Matthias De Lange, Rahaf Aljundi, Marc Masana, Sarah Parisot, Xu Jia, Ales Leonardis, Gregory Slabaugh, Tinne Tuytelaars, Continual learning: A comparative study on how to defy forgetting in classification tasks, https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08383
LLM_2:
This paper effectively addresses the challenge of adversarial attacks within the context of lifelong learning using deep neural networks. As this is my first encounter with this issue, I am unsure whether prior research specifically focused on this subfield exists.

From a conceptual standpoint, adversarial attacks have the potential to introduce systematic negative biases into the training processes of lifelong learners. This complicates the elimination of such biases, particularly given the current methods' tendency to "remember everything."

The study centers on A-GEM, a specific approach to lifelong learning, which is just one of many strategies within this area. The authors investigate its resilience against standard adversarial attacks, as well as a novel and more potent attack designed specifically for episodic memory techniques.

At this stage, I cannot recommend the paper for acceptance for the following reasons:
1. The generalizability of the findings to the wider subfield remains ambiguous. Although the authors assert that the method under investigation is state-of-the-art, this claim lacks sufficient clarity, even in relation to similar episodic memory models. I suggest consulting reference [1] for an independent evaluation of various strategies. What substantiates the claim that the results obtained are representative of this method's class?
2. The title suggests that "gradient reversion" attacks are broadly applicable to lifelong learning models. What factors render this class particularly pertinent for drawing general conclusions? Are there other methods within this category that exhibit greater vulnerability to these attacks? Additionally, can the proposed attack be adapted to other approaches? This aspect requires further elucidation.

References  
[1] Matthias De Lange, Rahaf Aljundi, Marc Masana, Sarah Parisot, Xu Jia, Ales Leonardis, Gregory Slabaugh, Tinne Tuytelaars, Continual Learning: A Comparative Study on How to Defy Forgetting in Classification Tasks, https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08383

This paper investigates the problem of the attribute (sentiment, gender) controlled text generation or text style transfer. The authors formulate the problem from a principled causal perspective, which models the two tasks with a unified framework. A framework of structural causal model is introduced to ground the idea. Experiments on text generation and style transfer are conducted and the experimental results show that the proposed framework can indeed improve the control accuracy.


Strength:

- The paper is well written and easy to follow. The authors describe the technical content detailly and readers can easily understand the implementation tricks.

- The proposed framework unifies the tasks of attribute-controlled text generation and style transfer which using one model can conduct two tasks simultaneously.


Weakness:

- Although the authors present the story from a principled causal perspective which is good certainly, it is not easy to figure out the novelty and technical contribution compared with the previous methods (such as CVAE model). The basic and main idea is still a VAE-based framework with some more variables or tricks to improve the performance, therefore, from the technical derivatives and descriptions, it is hard to feel excited and benefit more.  

- It is good to see that Conditional LM is introduced as the baseline method to conduct comparisons. I am wondering what is the performance of CVAE model which GPT2 is employed as the language decoder. This comparison is more important and convincing.
LLM_1:
This paper investigates attribute-controlled text generation and style transfer, formulating the problem from a causal perspective within a unified framework. The authors introduce a structural causal model to support their approach. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed framework enhances control accuracy for both tasks.

Strengths:

- The paper is well-written and comprehensible, with detailed descriptions that facilitate understanding of the technical implementation.

- The framework effectively unifies attribute-controlled text generation and style transfer, allowing simultaneous execution of both tasks.

Weaknesses:

- While the causal perspective is commendable, the novelty and technical contributions compared to previous methods, such as the CVAE model, are not clearly articulated. The core concept remains a VAE-based framework with additional variables or techniques, making it difficult to derive excitement or significant benefits from the technical details.

- Although Conditional LM is introduced as a baseline for comparison, the performance of the CVAE model utilizing GPT-2 as the language decoder is also crucial and should be addressed for a more convincing evaluation.
LLM_2:
This paper explores the realms of attribute-controlled text generation and style transfer, framing the issue from a causal standpoint within a cohesive framework. The authors present a structural causal model to underpin their methodology. Experimental results indicate that the proposed framework significantly improves control accuracy across both tasks.

### Strengths:

- The manuscript is clearly articulated and accessible, featuring thorough explanations that aid in grasping the technical implementation.

- The framework adeptly integrates attribute-controlled text generation with style transfer, enabling the simultaneous execution of both tasks.

### Weaknesses:

- While the adoption of a causal perspective is praiseworthy, the originality and technical contributions relative to existing approaches, such as the CVAE model, are not sufficiently highlighted. The fundamental premise appears to still be a VAE-based framework supplemented with additional variables or techniques, which diminishes the potential excitement or substantial advantages derived from the technical specifics.

- Although the Conditional LM is introduced as a baseline for comparison, it is essential to also consider the performance of the CVAE model when using GPT-2 as the language decoder. Addressing this aspect would lead to a more robust evaluation.

human:
Summary: 

This paper proposes a framework of compressed communication that can be used to deal with error induced by contractive compressors and can serve as a superior alternative to the existing framework (compressed communication with error feedback (EF)). The proposed framework outperforms EF in terms of memory requirement, communication complexity, and technical assumptions. The extension to federated learning with partial participation, and the numerical experiments on real-world dataset illustrate the applicability of this framework.

Strength:

1. The paper compares two algorithms, i.e., distributed compressed SGD (DCSGD) and compressed communication with error feedback (EF), by analyzing their convergence rates. The paper provides a new theoretical analysis for DCSGD, with weaker technical assumptions and tighter bounds.

2. The induced compressor proposed in the paper can transform any biased compressor into an unbiased one, which can then be used in various existing methods designed for unbiased compressors.   

Comments: 

1. The paper concludes that the standard DCSGD algorithm is preferable to DCSGD with error feedback by comparing two algorithms' best-known convergence rates. It may not be appropriate because it is possible that the rate of standard DCSGD is theoretically tighter than that of DCSGD with error feedback (i.e., better theoretical bound). In other words, the difference in bounds of two algorithms is possibly due to the different theoretical analysis methods or different technical assumptions used in two algorithms, rather than the algorithm itself. How do those analysis methods used for finding convergence rates in two algorithms compared to each other? How can we make sure that the improvement is caused by the algorithm itself, but not the theoretical bounds?

2. Federated learning with partial participation has been studied in other works. I suggest the authors citing these papers and highlighting the differences. For example,
(1) Reisizadeh, Amirhossein, et al. "Fedpaq: A communication-efficient federated learning method with periodic averaging and quantization." International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics. 2020."
(2) Sattler, Felix, et al. "Robust and communication-efficient federated learning from non-iid data." IEEE transactions on neural networks and learning systems (2019).

3. The benefit of using a biased compressor is its low variance; this is what improves the performance. However, if a biased compressor is transformed into an unbiased one using an induced compressor, then don't we lose the benefits of using such a biased compressor? What is the benefit of transformation using an induced compressor if the variance is not low anymore? Why not use an unbiased compressor (e.g., C2) directly? Is it because of the additional unbiased "error feedback" the induced compressor can provide?

4. In experiments (Figure 3), authors compare various methods with one set of compressors (1) Rand-K; (2) Top-K + EF; (3) induced compressor with C1 = Top-K/2 and C2 = Rand-K/2; (4) Top-K, where K is a tunable parameter but is the same among all compressors. I wonder how their performances vary if the compressors use different values of K. For example, how do the compressor Rand-K/2 and the induced compressor with C1 = Top-K/2 and C2 = Rand-K/2 compare to each other (i.e., using unbiased C2 directly instead of transformation)?
LLM_1:
This paper proposes a framework for compressed communication addressing errors from contractive compressors, presenting a superior alternative to the existing framework of compressed communication with error feedback (EF). The new framework demonstrates advantages over EF in memory requirements, communication complexity, and technical assumptions. Additionally, its extension to federated learning with partial participation, alongside numerical experiments on a real-world dataset, showcases its applicability.

Strengths:

1. The paper analyzes the convergence rates of two algorithms, distributed compressed SGD (DCSGD) and compressed communication with error feedback (EF), providing a novel theoretical analysis for DCSGD with weaker assumptions and tighter bounds.

2. The proposed induced compressor effectively converts any biased compressor into an unbiased one, facilitating compatibility with existing unbiased compressor methods.

Comments:

1. The conclusion that the standard DCSGD algorithm is superior to DCSGD with error feedback may be problematic, as the tighter theoretical bounds for standard DCSGD could stem from differing analysis methods or assumptions rather than algorithmic performance. A comparison of the analysis methods used to derive the convergence rates for both algorithms is warranted to ensure that improvements are attributed to the algorithms themselves.

2. Previous research on federated learning with partial participation exists, and the authors should cite relevant works, such as Reisizadeh et al. (2020) and Sattler et al. (2019), while clarifying how their approach differs from these studies.

3. The advantage of a biased compressor lies in its low variance, which enhances performance. If an induced compressor transforms a biased compressor into an unbiased one, the benefits of low variance may be lost. The authors should clarify the advantages of this transformation and whether it justifies not using an unbiased compressor directly, such as C2, especially considering the potential loss of variance benefits.

4. In the experiments (Figure 3), the authors compare methods using a single set of compressors with a uniform tunable parameter K. It would be informative to examine performance variations with different K values for each compressor. Specifically, how do Rand-K/2 and the induced compressor with C1 = Top-K/2 and C2 = Rand-K/2 compare when using unbiased C2 directly instead of transformation?
LLM_2:
This paper introduces a framework for compressed communication that addresses the errors associated with contractive compressors, offering a more effective alternative to the existing error feedback (EF) framework in compressed communication. The proposed framework shows notable advantages over EF in terms of memory requirements, communication complexity, and technical assumptions. Furthermore, its application to federated learning with partial participation and the accompanying numerical experiments on a real-world dataset highlight its practical relevance.

### Strengths:

1. The paper provides an in-depth analysis of the convergence rates for two algorithms: distributed compressed SGD (DCSGD) and compressed communication with error feedback (EF). It presents a novel theoretical analysis for DCSGD, distinguished by weaker assumptions and tighter bounds.

2. The introduced induced compressor adeptly converts any biased compressor into an unbiased one, thereby enhancing compatibility with existing unbiased compressor techniques.

### Comments:

1. The assertion that the standard DCSGD algorithm outperforms DCSGD with error feedback could be contentious. The tighter theoretical bounds for standard DCSGD may result from differing analytical approaches or assumptions rather than an inherent advantage in algorithmic performance. It would be beneficial to compare the analytical methods used to derive the convergence rates for both algorithms to ensure that any claimed improvements are genuinely reflective of the algorithms' efficacy.

2. The literature on federated learning with partial participation includes prior research that should be acknowledged, notably works by Reisizadeh et al. (2020) and Sattler et al. (2019). The authors ought to clarify how their framework distinguishes itself from these studies.

3. A key advantage of a biased compressor is its low variance, which enhances overall performance. If an induced compressor modifies a biased compressor into an unbiased one, it raises concerns about the potential loss of the low variance benefits. The authors should elucidate the merits of this transformation and whether it provides justification for not utilizing an unbiased compressor directly, such as C2, particularly in light of the possible variance trade-offs.

4. In the experiments presented (Figure 3), the authors evaluate methods using a single set of compressors with a uniform tunable parameter K. It would be insightful to explore how performance varies with different K values for each compressor. Specifically, a comparison of Rand-K/2 and the induced compressor with C1 = Top-K/2 and C2 = Rand-K/2 versus using an unbiased C2 directly, without transformation, would yield valuable information.

We went to  urlLink this place . They've got their little microbrewery on site, and though I won't give it too much credit since it's a chain of microbreweries, I ordered the seven beer sampler (two ounces each, maybe?) along with my buffalo chicken pizza (disappointing¡ªa bit weak on the hot sauce).   I came back to my place and had a choice between going bowling with Dan and co. (my concert-going friends) or going to see  The Bourne Supremacy  with Nathan and Melissa (of the Cellular and Molecular Biology program at school) and their friends. Since I was horribly sore from the dancing (maybe that'll discourage me next time), I opted for the choice that had me sitting on my ass for a couple of hours. The movie was thoroughly mediocre. I hand enjoyed the first one¡ªthough it was nothing special, it was entertaining enough¡ªbut the second one was just not particularly interesting or exciting.   I was supposed to catch up with Dan &c. at a bar afterwards, but he couldn't hear his cell phone, so I went over to Woodrow's to hang out with Will. He'd the door man there on Fridays and Saturdays, so it's pretty dependable that he's a) there and b) bored. I know the bartenders through him, and they're kind of cute, so it's not a bad way to kill an evening.   After they closed, we went for food. The authors present a novel neural modular network for video grounding tasks, offering interpretable intermediate reasoning outcomes and demonstrating model robustness. This model achieves competitive results on the AVSD datasets and state-of-the-art performance on the TGIF-QA datasets, highlighting the effectiveness of its design.

Detailed comments are as follows:

LLM_2:
The authors introduce a novel neural modular network (NMN) aimed at video grounding tasks, showcasing interpretable intermediate reasoning outcomes and demonstrating robustness in their model. They report competitive performance on the AVSD datasets and state-of-the-art results on the TGIF-QA datasets, underscoring the design's effectiveness.

Here are some detailed comments for consideration:

- The originality of the NMN appears to be somewhat constrained, as similar concepts have been addressed in prior research. Could the authors clarify how they define the modular space? Are there established principles for designing modules like "find, summarize, when, and describe"?

- The reasoning structure presented in this paper seems overly simplistic. The modules labeled "find," "when," and "where" operate primarily as signal detectors and do not provide a robust reasoning framework for generating the final response. In the current methodology, the information detected is merely aggregated to create the final answer through a response decoder, which does not illuminate the connections between the final response and the identified visual or linguistic entities.

- [Question] How is the program generation task trained using language input? Is there a ground truth program structure annotation for supervision? Additionally, how are the hyper-parameters ¦Á and ¦Â determined?

- The writing quality of the paper requires improvement, as some expressions can be confusing. For instance, the statement "Different from..., our model is trained to fully generate the parameters of components in the text" is unclear. Here, "parameters" seems to refer to the inputs of each module, which is distinct from model parameters.

human:
Strengths -
1. The paper was overall well written, easy to understand and likely easy to reproduce.
2. The idea of "answering structured queries directly over text" is worth pursuing.

Weaknesses -
1. The paper contains little modeling novelty. It narrows down the scope of "structured queries" to one-hop "KB triple fragments" and adopts off-the-shelf neural machine comprehension (MC) models. However, the idea that "MC models can be used to answer structured KB queries" has been shown in the CoNLL paper by (Omer et. al 2017), where MC models were used for zero-shot relation extraction by completing triple pattern fragments.
2. The dataset construction largely replicates the work done by (Welbl et. al. 2018) for WikiHop, while missing several important quality control procedures. For example, (Welbl et. al. 2018) reported significant answer candidate imbalance in the initial WikiHop collection, i.e. some entities are much more likely to appear as an answer than others and a majority class baseline would be very competitive. Similar issues should be studied and controlled for the new dataset used in this paper as well. To this reviewer, a more reasonable approach is to also test the proposed system on existing KB-text benchmark datasets such as WikiHop.
3. This paper does not provide evidence to support its main claim that "using text as the database has a number of potential benefits". For a fair comparison on accuracy, the paper should conduct a head-to-head comparison of the performance of models that use only text vs. those also use a pre-extracted KB. If the ones with access to KBs demonstrate a big performance jump, it is an evidence that pre-extracted KBs are beneficial. (This experiment should be carried out on QA datasets with natural language questions so as not to give models with access to KBs an advantage.) Efficiency-wise, the paper claims that having a separate KB representations incur maintenance cost and synchronization issues. However, query execution on KBs can be highly optimized. On the other hand, text processing and NN execution can sometimes trigger extra overhead. The paper needs to benchmark the runtime efficiency of a text-only system and a system that accesses KBs in a head-to-head fashion, too.
LLM_1:
Strengths -  
1. The paper is well written, clear, and likely reproducible.  
2. The concept of "answering structured queries directly over text" is a valuable pursuit.  

Weaknesses -  
1. The paper lacks modeling novelty, limiting its scope of "structured queries" to one-hop "KB triple fragments" and relying on existing neural machine comprehension (MC) models. The use of MC models for structured KB queries has been previously demonstrated by Omer et al. (2017) in their CoNLL paper, where MC models facilitated zero-shot relation extraction through triple pattern completion.  
2. Dataset construction closely follows Welbl et al. (2018) for WikiHop but overlooks crucial quality control measures. Welbl et al. reported significant answer candidate imbalance in the initial WikiHop collection, indicating that some entities are more likely to appear as answers, making a majority class baseline competitive. Similar issues must be addressed in the new dataset. A more effective approach would involve testing the proposed system on established KB-text benchmark datasets like WikiHop.  
3. The paper fails to provide evidence supporting its claim that "using text as the database has several potential benefits." A direct comparison of models using only text versus those utilizing pre-extracted KBs is necessary for a fair accuracy assessment. If models with KB access show a significant performance increase, it suggests the advantages of pre-extracted KBs. Additionally, while the paper argues that separate KB representations entail maintenance and synchronization costs, it should benchmark the runtime efficiency of text-only systems against those accessing KBs. Query execution on KBs can be highly optimized, and text processing may introduce additional overhead.
LLM_2:
## Review Comment

### Strengths
1. The manuscript is articulately composed, demonstrating clarity and a structure that suggests it could be reproduced effectively.
2. The exploration of "answering structured queries directly over text" is a commendable initiative with significant potential.

### Weaknesses
1. The paper exhibits a lack of innovative modeling, confining its interpretation of "structured queries" to one-hop "KB triple fragments" and depending heavily on pre-existing neural machine comprehension (MC) models. Notably, the application of MC models for structured knowledge base (KB) queries has already been established by Omer et al. (2017) in their CoNLL paper, which illustrated how MC models could enable zero-shot relation extraction through triple pattern completion.
   
2. The methodology for dataset construction closely mirrors that of Welbl et al. (2018) for WikiHop, yet it neglects essential quality control protocols. Welbl et al. highlighted a significant imbalance in answer candidates within the original WikiHop dataset, indicating that certain entities are disproportionately likely to be selected as answers, thus rendering a majority class baseline competitive. Similar challenges should be addressed in the new dataset. A more effective strategy would involve evaluating the proposed system against well-established KB-text benchmark datasets such as WikiHop.

3. The manuscript does not substantiate its assertion that "using text as the database has several potential benefits." A direct comparison between models that rely solely on text and those employing pre-extracted KBs is imperative for an equitable assessment of accuracy. Should models with KB access demonstrate a notable performance advantage, this would highlight the benefits of utilizing pre-extracted KBs. Furthermore, while the paper posits that separate KB representations incur maintenance and synchronization costs, it ought to benchmark the runtime efficiency of text-only systems against those that access KBs. Query execution on KBs can often be finely optimized, and processing text may introduce additional overhead that warrants consideration.

I wipe my eyes and get away the morning rust from a long nights sleep. I sit up and turn off my alarm that was shattering my ear drums. I go to the bathroom and throw water on my face, shower, get ready for work, just like any ordinary day. 
 
 I look in the mirror as I finish looping the last loop of my tie, I stare at myself for a little more than a moment, then I decided. 
 
 Today is the day. 
 
 I tighten my tie up to my neck, so much that I almost choked myself. I know today is going to be the day I tag Benny `` The Jet''. 
 
 Years ago on the playground, a large group of friends and I used to play tag. It was so much more than tag, it was a lifestyle. Benny was the best at it though, he would dodge arm swings, ran faster, jumped higher, and agile'd agiler. He was the star, and even with the playground fame he never let it go to his head. He was so kind and pleasant to everyone, well, except me. Benny always seemed to avoid me, when playing tag, in class, anything. It hurt me more than he will ever admit that I wanted to be a part of what he had, but he did n't want me to be apart of his life. Every day we used to play and my only goal was tagging Benny; maybe then he would notice me and be my friend. However, I never was able to tag him. 
 
 I snap back to reality, realizing that I have n't seen or heard from Benny in years. That small hiccup was n't going to stop me, though. I pull the shoe strings on my best running shoes, I was determined to tag Benny, and nothing was going to stop me. 
 
 I ran to the nearest corner market and bought the first phone book I saw. My finger racing through the white pages: 
 
 Benny... Benjamin... Bernard... 
 
 I could n't find his name. My life seemed to shatter around me, was my journey over so fast? 
 
 I pulled out my phone to check twitter, Facebook, MySpace, Xanga. Anything to get me the information I needed. 
 
 Then I seen it. His location, he was recently tagged with multiple family members and a ton of friends at a single location. `` We'll miss you, Benny!'' Must've been a going away party or something. This is perfect, I'll be able to embarrass him in front of his co-workers, just like he insulted me at school. 
 `` He's going to be sorry he did n't invite me, he's going downnnnnn'' I mumbled to myself, trying not to look insane because I was still in public. 
 
 I sprinted to my car, knowing that my time has come, all the years of mental torture are coming to a close. Today is my day and nothing is going to stop me. Checking my phone for the address I can see myself getting closer, 5 miles. 4.20 miles, 3.1, 2.6, 1.8,.9, until I finally arrive. 
 
 I pull up to a dark garden with large metal gates with vines engulfing them with their grasp. I get out and start running as fast as my legs will take me. I ran through the garden as if I was a horse with blinders, straight ahead is all I was focusing on. 
 
 In the distance I see a large group of people. 
 `` Here I come, Benny!'' I think to myself, assuming that group of people is the party that had tagged him. I run faster, feeling the wind pick up around me as I cut through it like a knife. I'm getting closer I can start to see people's faces. I immediately start to scan for Benny's. Not slowing down at all I continue to speed towards the group of people. I can feel the empowerment burning in my hand, waiting to pass the title onto Benny. 
 
 I stop immediately. My body goes numb, I ca n't feel anything. 
 
 I approach the party, and finally it all hits me at once. 
 
 This is n't a garden, it's a graveyard. 
 This is n't a party, it's a service. 
 I walk up to the edge of the hole in the ground that people are lowering a casket into. Time seems to slow to a complete stop, seconds felt like minutes, minutes felt like hours, hours felt like days. 
 
 A girl Benny and I went to school with together recognizes me, and grabs my hand. 
 `` Benny talked a lot about you, even if you guys have n't talked in years. 
 He always talked about how on the playground he would always avoid you the most playing tag because he knew you were the only one that could catch him.'' 
 
 My throat swells up and I feel my breathing stop. 
 
 `` He wishes he would've been your friend, he always held that regret that he was n't friendlier to people he felt threatened by.'' She continues. 
 
 `` How?'' I asked 
 
 `` He killed himself. He did n't leave a note, no one is sure why. He was n't acting strange, did n't have any work changes, no financial changes, he was just unhappy.'' 
 
 The crowd start to dissipate, as it starts to rain. 
 
 `` Can I be alone?'' I ask under my breath. 
 
 ``... Yeah, take your time.'' She whispers. 
 
 I approach Benny's tombstone, which reads: 
 
 Here Lies Bernard `` The Jet'' 
 6-1-1991 to 5-31-2015 
 
 I walk up the tombstone, and wipe my eyes from the rain and tear concoction. I gently place my hand at the crest of the tombstone, and with my voice breaking I mutter: 
 
 `` You're it.''

human: I went to breakfast with my mom today: a rare occurence since I'm never up before noon during the summer usually.  I realized then that I won't get to do that very often soon since I won't be coming back here after college (no matter what happens).  It made me sad because I know I won't get to see my family as much.  Decatur - I can leave with no problems.  But I will miss my family and the few friends I have left here.     I've been to some of the most wonderful places in the world: New York City, London, Munich, Paris, Washington, Chicago, Atlanta, Orlando, Philadelphia, etc.  I've gone to places that are 100's if not 1000's of years old, met people from all over the world, been to 8 different countries and 25 states.  I've been on the snow-capped mountains, in huge fields of flowers, swimming in the Caribbean, places where there are waterfalls all around you, cave diving in some of the largest caves in the country, kickin it with friends in Disney World for over a week, and standing in the middle of Times Square. I've stood where monarchs, politcians, famous composers, inventors, and even ancient Romans have been.  After seeing all that, you can see why I won't miss Decatur at all.  Maybe this explains why I'm easily bored though sometimes.    But I am by no means done travelling.  One of my friends told me that this was probably the happiest they had ever seen me, when I'm travelling.  Guess its no secret that I'm not a person to stay put.  There are so many places I still want to go and see: California, Alaska, Australia, Italy, Greece, the pyramids of Egypt, New Zealand, western Mexico, Spain, the Virgin Islands.  Hopefully I'll get to see it all someday.  And I can't wait till the day I can go back to London - not only to see my family, but to actually appreciate the things I see this time.  It truly is one of my most favorite places (if not the most) to visit that I have ever been to.

Anyway, Lance Berkman had 42 HRs and 128 RBIs in 2002, but since that was before I moved here, and thus before I cared about the Astros (and read their daily beat writer summaries in the Chronicle, for lack of anything better to do when my girlfriend is studying for MCATs), I didn't know a lot about him. His performance last night, even in loss, was magical. He ripped like 6 in a row to left field at one point, making small elementary school children sprawl over trying to catch the ricochet. Still - and I know you can find a survey to prove anything (that's how I got through college) - there's countless surveys that the average time UPPER MIDDLE CLASS parents spend with their children is decreasing on an annual basis, probably down several percentage points from the early 1990s. human:
The bus collided head-on with a goods vehicle near the city of Khairpur in Sindh province, officials say.
The bus was travelling overnight from Swat, in the north-west, to the port city of Karachi.
Deadly accidents are common on Pakistan's roads - often caused by reckless driving, poorly maintained surfaces or unsuitable vehicles.
The BBC's Shahzeb Jillani in Islamabad says that most of those killed in the accident early on Tuesday morning were women and children.
At least 15 people were injured - some seriously - and are being treated in hospital.
Medical Superintendent of the Khairpur district hospital Ghulam Jaffar Soomro told Geo TV that it looked as if the bus overturned at high speed.
Police say there were 65 passengers in the bus and that a morning fog which covered the highway at the time of the collision could have played a part in the accident.

human: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a potent activator of lymphocytes, but its effectiveness as an anti-cancer agent is compromised by several adverse side effects including pulmonary edema. One explanation for the pulmonary toxicity of IL-2 is that activated lymphocytes directly induce the pulmonary vascular endothelium to become more leaky.To test this hypothesis the number of total lymphocytes, gamma delta T cells, and CD2-positive cells (alpha beta T cells and natural killer cells) in peripheral blood and lung lymph of sheep were compared before and after IL-2 infusion. Hemodynamic and lymph dynamic changes were also evaluated.IL-2 decreased mean aortic pressure, increased cardiac output, lowered systemic vascular resistance, and doubled lung lymph flow (P < or = 0.05), but had no effect on plasma or lymph oncotic pressure. The lymph protein concentration and the lymph-to-plasma protein concentration ratio were not different after IL-2 infusion. IL-2 had no effect on the number of total lymphocytes, gamma delta T cells, or CD2-positive cells in the peripheral blood. In contrast, the number of total lymphocytes, gamma delta T cells, and CD2-positive cells in lung lymph decreased significantly (P < or = 0.05).
LLM_1: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a powerful lymphocyte activator, yet its anti-cancer efficacy is limited by adverse effects such as pulmonary edema. One proposed mechanism for IL-2's pulmonary toxicity is the induction of increased permeability in the pulmonary vascular endothelium by activated lymphocytes. To investigate this, we compared the concentrations of total lymphocytes, gamma delta T cells, and CD2-positive cells (alpha beta T cells and natural killer cells) in the peripheral blood and lung lymph of sheep before and after IL-2 infusion. We also assessed hemodynamic and lymph dynamic changes. IL-2 infusion resulted in decreased mean aortic pressure, increased cardiac output, reduced systemic vascular resistance, and a doubling of lung lymph flow (P ¡Ü 0.05), with no changes in plasma or lymph oncotic pressure. The lymph protein concentration and the lymph-to-plasma protein concentration ratio remained unchanged post-infusion. IL-2 did not affect the total lymphocyte count, gamma delta T cells, or CD2-positive cells in peripheral blood; however, significant decreases were observed in lung lymph (P ¡Ü 0.05).
LLM_2: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) serves as a potent activator of lymphocytes, yet its therapeutic potential against cancer is hindered by side effects, notably pulmonary edema. A proposed mechanism underlying the pulmonary toxicity associated with IL-2 is the elevation of permeability in the pulmonary vascular endothelium, mediated by activated lymphocytes. This study aimed to examine this hypothesis by comparing the concentrations of total lymphocytes, gamma delta T cells, and CD2-positive cells (which include alpha beta T cells and natural killer cells) in the peripheral blood and lung lymph of sheep, both prior to and following IL-2 infusion. Additionally, we evaluated changes in hemodynamic and lymphatic dynamics. Following IL-2 infusion, we observed a reduction in mean aortic pressure, an increase in cardiac output, a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, and a twofold increase in lung lymph flow (P ¡Ü 0.05), with no corresponding changes in plasma or lymph oncotic pressure. The concentrations of lymph proteins and the ratio of lymph-to-plasma protein concentrations remained stable post-infusion. While IL-2 did not impact the total lymphocyte counts, gamma delta T cells, or CD2-positive cells in the peripheral blood, a significant reduction was noted in lung lymph (P ¡Ü 0.05).

Detective John Larson had never been one for playing it rough when it came to interrogations but he was to close to getting what he had been searching for and he was n't gon na let it slip away. 
 `` Where are the shipments coming from?'' Larson screamed as he smacked away the remaining french fries off of the table. 
 Across from him tied to a chair was a shacking young man dressed in jeans and a black hoodie. 
 `` I told you everything I know man! The King sends the stuff and I pick it up at the docks, that's all I know I swear!'' 
 Larson was n't convinced. It had been three years since the war on grease had started and he felt as though he had seen everything. Being the the man who took down Wendy he was known for getting results. 
 `` Look I know the war is about to begin. I've picked up three Mcdealers this week for starting brawls with the King's men. I just wan na stop this before anyone else gets hurt. Now where are the shipments coming from?'' 
 The boy sat silent for a moment, trying his best not to meet Larson's eyes. Finally he looked at him and said `` I do n't know where they came from but I know the next shipment is coming in tonight at 8 and the King is delivering it personally'' 
 The Detective's watch read 7:35. He immediately left the room and got on his cell phone and dialed the commissioner. 
 `` I'm gon na need all available units to be at the docks at 8:10, were taking the King down.'' 
 `` 8:10? But the boy said 8?'' The commissioner responded 
 `` Trust me, have your men there at 8:10, I need to catch the King in the act'' Larson commanded as he hung up his phone. 
 Larson then entered his squad car, put his key in the ignition and sped away. About a mile away from the docs Larson noticed something moving in his rear view mirror. Ignoring it he continued driving. He parked about two blocks away from the docks. Exiting the car he felt the cool breeze on his cheeks and then a very familiar smell. 
 `` Whoopers'' He muttered to himself 
 He ran and hid behind one of the many large crates in the area. He sat there for a few minutes until a van showed up and parked about 20 feet in front of him, a little close for his liking but he stayed put. 
 The back doors of the van opened and two obese men stepped out. It was n't hard to tell that they had been doing fries. Then the front door opened. It was him. The King. His long fur coat drenched from his feet all the way to his plastic smile. 
 Another car pulled and two more obese men stepped out. 
 `` You got the grease'' One of the men said 
 The King nodded and motioned to one of the creates. The men walked over to the create and opened it and the smell of beef erupted from create. 
 The men, looking satisfied threw the King a brief case. He handed it to one of his men who brought it to the van. 
 `` So we done here?'' one of the obese men asked 
 The King shook his head and pointed at Larson. He started walking toward him. The detective readied his gun knowing this might get ugly when suddenly there was a huge explosion from the van. The King looked back to see that one of his men were dead. From creates all around the docs clowns were poping up and shooting at the king as he made his way to the other car on the doc. Larson watched as the King managed to get in the car and drive away. 
 `` Ronald you son of a bitch!'' Larson screamed as a swarm of cop cars entered the docs. 
 The Detective sank to his knees and looked at his watch. 8:10 exactly. The bust was to late.
LLM_1:
Detective John Larson had always preferred a softer touch during interrogations, but now he was on the brink of a breakthrough he couldn't afford to lose. 

¡°Where are the shipments coming from?¡± he shouted, swatting away the remaining fries on the table. 

Tied to a chair across from him was a trembling young man in jeans and a black hoodie. 

¡°I told you everything! The King sends the stuff, and I pick it up at the docks¡ªthat¡¯s all I know, I swear!¡± 

Larson remained unconvinced. Three years into the war on grease, he¡¯d seen it all. Known for taking down Wendy, he was a man who got results. 

¡°Look, I know the war is about to escalate. I¡¯ve arrested three Mcdealers this week for starting fights with the King¡¯s men. I just want to stop this before anyone else gets hurt. Now, where are the shipments coming from?¡± 

The boy hesitated, avoiding Larson's gaze. Finally, he met the detective¡¯s eyes. ¡°I don¡¯t know where they come from, but the next shipment is coming tonight at 8. The King is delivering it personally.¡± 

Larson checked his watch¡ªit was 7:35. He dashed out of the room, grabbed his cell phone, and called the commissioner. 

¡°I need all available units at the docks by 8:10. We¡¯re taking the King down.¡± 

¡°8:10? But the boy said 8,¡± the commissioner replied. 

¡°Trust me. Have your men there at 8:10. I need to catch the King in the act,¡± Larson commanded, hanging up. 

He jumped into his squad car, started the engine, and sped off. About a mile from the docks, he noticed something moving in his rearview mirror but chose to ignore it. He parked two blocks away, feeling the cool breeze on his cheeks, followed by a familiar smell. 

¡°Whoopers,¡± he muttered. 

He ducked behind a large crate and waited. Minutes later, a van pulled up, parking too close for comfort. The back doors swung open, and two hefty men emerged, clearly fond of fries. Then the front door opened. It was him¡ªthe King¡ªhis long fur coat soaked from the rain, his plastic smile gleaming. 

Another car arrived, and two more hefty men stepped out. 

¡°You got the grease?¡± one of them asked. 

The King nodded and gestured to a crate. The men approached and opened it, releasing a powerful scent of beef. 

Looking satisfied, they tossed the King a briefcase, which he handed to one of his men to stow in the van. 

¡°So, we done here?¡± one of the hefty men asked. 

The King shook his head and pointed in Larson¡¯s direction. He began striding toward the detective. Larson readied his gun, anticipating trouble, when suddenly a massive explosion erupted from the van. The King turned to see one of his men fall dead. From the crates surrounding the docks, clowns emerged, shooting at the King as he rushed towards another car. Larson watched helplessly as the King climbed in and sped away. 

¡°Ronald, you son of a bitch!¡± Larson shouted as a swarm of cop cars arrived at the docks. 

The detective sank to his knees, glancing at his watch¡ª8:10 exactly. The bust had come too late.

human: ok, so the mm did not say that......it was said by phillip roth.....He published his first book, the collection of short stories Goodbye Columbus, in 1959, and it got good reviews and won several awards. But a few years later, he went to speak at a university in New York City, and the audience attacked him, shouting that he was writing anti-Semitic literature. When he tried to leave the stage, a crowd surrounded him, shouting and waving their fists, and he barely got away without being hurt. Later that night he said, 'I'll never write about Jews again.' He worked on a novel with no Jewish characters called When She Was Good (1967), but it wasn't any fun to write, and he realized that he couldn't give up on writing about his background. He figured that if everyone thought he was offensive, he might as well try to write a book that was as offensive as possible. He set out write a novel in the wild, obscene voice that he remembered from his childhood friends. He had started psychoanalysis at the time, and he got the idea of writing the book from the point of view of a patient on his psychoanalyst's couch.   That book became Portnoy's Complaint (1969), about Alexander Portnoyhis obsession with sex, and his struggles with his Jewish parents, especially his mother. It begins, 'She was so deeply imbedded in my consciousness that for the first year of school I seem to have believed that each of my teachers was my mother in disguise.' It was one of the most sexually explicit books ever published, and it became one of the best-selling books of the 1960s. Jewish critics attacked Roth for his portrayal of Jews, and others attacked him for his obscenity, but he had decided that he no longer cared if he offended his readers. He said, 'I cannot and do not live in the world of discretion, not as a writer, anyway. I would prefer to, I assure youit would make life easier. But discretion is, unfortunately, not for novelists.'  He has gone on to write many more novels, most of them narrated by a fictional writer named Nathan Zuckerman, including American Pastoral (1997), I Married a Communist (1998) and The Human Stain (2000). His most recent novel is The Dying Animal (2001). Roth said, 'The road to hell is paved with works-in-progress.'
LLM_1: Phillip Roth, who published his first book, the short story collection *Goodbye Columbus*, in 1959, faced backlash when he spoke at a New York City university. The audience accused him of writing anti-Semitic literature, surrounding him and shouting as he tried to leave. That night, he vowed never to write about Jews again. However, he soon found that writing without Jewish characters was unfulfilling. Embracing the controversy, Roth decided to write a provocative novel, inspired by his childhood experiences and his psychoanalysis sessions, from the perspective of a patient. This led to *Portnoy's Complaint* (1969), exploring Alexander Portnoy's obsession with sex and his turbulent relationship with his Jewish parents, particularly his mother. The book, one of the most sexually explicit of its time, became a best-seller despite criticism from Jewish critics and others for its obscenity. Roth expressed indifference to the offense he caused, stating, "I cannot and do not live in the world of discretion, not as a writer, anyway." He continued to write numerous novels, many featuring the fictional author Nathan Zuckerman, including *American Pastoral* (1997), *I Married a Communist* (1998), and *The Human Stain* (2000). His latest work, *The Dying Animal* (2001), reflects his belief that "the road to hell is paved with works-in-progress."
LLM_2:
Philip Roth made his literary debut in 1959 with the short story collection *Goodbye Columbus*, but his career took a dramatic turn during a speaking engagement at a New York City university. There, he encountered a hostile audience that accused him of penning anti-Semitic literature, and as he attempted to exit, they surrounded him, shouting their discontent. That evening, Roth made a solemn vow to never again write about Jewish themes. 

However, the absence of Jewish characters left him feeling unfulfilled. Rather than shy away from the controversy, Roth leaned into it, crafting a daring novel that drew from his childhood experiences and insights from his psychoanalysis sessions, all narrated through the eyes of a patient. This creative endeavor culminated in *Portnoy's Complaint* (1969), a candid exploration of Alexander Portnoy¡¯s sexual obsessions and his tumultuous relationship with his Jewish parents, particularly his mother. The novel, known for its explicit content, quickly became a bestseller, even as it drew sharp criticism from Jewish critics and others who deemed it obscene. Roth remained unfazed by the backlash, famously declaring, "I cannot and do not live in the world of discretion, not as a writer, anyway."

Roth continued to produce a remarkable body of work, often featuring the semi-autobiographical character Nathan Zuckerman. His notable novels include *American Pastoral* (1997), *I Married a Communist* (1998), and *The Human Stain* (2000). In his later work, *The Dying Animal* (2001), he succinctly encapsulates his perspective on creativity, stating, "the road to hell is paved with works-in-progress." Through his fearless storytelling and willingness to confront difficult themes, Roth left an indelible mark on American literature.

No agreement has been reached and, as things stand, Wright is planning to play O'Halloran in next weekend's League Cup semi-final with Hibernian.
O'Halloran set up a goal as Saints lost 3-1 to Premiership leaders Celtic, who went six points clear at the top.
"The latest is that there has been no change," said Wright.
O'Halloran started on the right flank before moving up front in the second half. He did not play last week, after news of Rangers' interest broke, because Wright felt he was not in the right frame of mind.
There was enough about his game to create an equaliser at Celtic Park, though, for Steven MacLean.
"Michael's our player and we can't stop clubs asking a question about him," Wright told BBC Scotland. "He played because all week he's been excellent in training.
"When it emerged and really hit the press last week, it did have an effect on him. But he's in a good frame of mind.
Media playback is not supported on this device
"The chairman came down on the bus today and unless something's happened, Michael's still our player, so that's the only update I can give.
"I'm confident that he'll be our player in the morning. He's contracted to us for another 18 months.
"We do know that Rangers are seriously interested. There's a valuation and if that's met then he'll no longer be our player. I'll be preparing, come Monday, for him to be in the team for next week."
Wright was happy with O'Halloran's performance, and aspects of the team's display as a whole, despite the defeat.
"We put a lot into game," he said. "First goal, they get a little break with the deflection. But we should see it out to half-time when we get the equaliser.
"We conceded the second goal at a bad time. At the start of the second half we looked okay, we put Michael up top, but the third goal kills us.
"I thought it was a foul on Brian Easton, [Gary] Mackay-Steven's foot was high and I was disappointed the ref didn't give it.
"You need those situations to go for you, then to compound it [Craig] Gordon makes a great save from Liam Craig moments later.
"I'm pleased with how we played, but there are still things we could do better; retention of the ball. But you have to work so hard here to get the ball [that] at times you don't keep is as much as you would like.
"The attitude, organisation and desire was good, I just thought at times we won the ball back then gave it away too cheaply."
Celtic manager Ronny Deila was pleased with the way his side "controlled" the game and the number of chances they created.
Mackay-Steven scored twice, Stuart Armstrong also found the net and Deila believes his team will be hard to catch if they maintain the same level of performance.
"We play much more forward now and we're hard to beat because we have a lot of quick players in the team," the Celtic manager said.
"[Mackay-Steven] was very good. Stuart and him were very good, the full-backs were vey good coming forward, so there was a lot to build on there.
"We're going to be very hard to beat when we are playing so direct and with pressure, everybody working so hard and then we win the ball in good situations."
LLM_1:
No agreement has been reached, and Wright plans to play O'Halloran in next weekend's League Cup semi-final against Hibernian. O'Halloran contributed to a goal during Saints' 3-1 loss to Premiership leaders Celtic, who now lead by six points. 

"The latest is that there has been no change," said Wright. O'Halloran started on the right flank before moving to the front in the second half. He missed last week¡¯s game due to concerns about his mindset following Rangers' interest. However, he showed enough quality to assist Steven MacLean in creating an equalizer at Celtic Park.

The President of the United States of America was making a speech, a speech about how we should live our last years in dignity. Resources were considered irrelevant, Economists were trying to work out the best way to deal with the situation. Researchers studied. Philosophers debated. Many spent their time spending all of their money since, hey, no point saving for retirement now. They knew, or they thought they knew, that they would die in February 2017. On one day in February, the earth would burn up. 
 
 Unfortunately, the results were n't properly vetted. As Newton said, *'' If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.'' *. As Kelvin should upon Celsius and Celsius should on Fahrenheit. Scientific scales for temperature were changed, at some later date, it is assumed we would find a better scale than the boiling and melting points of water. Perhaps we would find a maximum temperature, clearly defined, Planck temperature, an Absolute Hot to match the Absolute Zero. 
 
 Such a scale would be invented in 2017. A scale without boiling or melting points, but one that simply divides temperature into 1 unit, a Blane. Named after an upcoming scientist. The common unit being something like Nano-blanes or Pico-blanes. In short, you can not exceed 1 Blane. 
 
 It turns out the website making predictions must have relied on such a fact and been using Pico-blanes instead of Celsius. Due to a change in scale the temperature would probably be no different. 1000 Pico-blanes may equal 23 Celsius. 
 
 At first, the Scientists were relieved. They thought this mistake would mean that there was nothing wrong. A big mistake had been made, it may cost some of them their jobs. But at least the earth will not boil. 
 
 The scale had to be invented for a reason, maybe there was an underlying problem. Maybe temperature was rapidly decreasing and they wanted to find out why, why the temperature was decreasing everywhere, and not just earth. 
 
 Oh no, the Earth will not burn. 
 
 Earth will freeze.

The President of the United States delivered a speech about living our final years with dignity. Resources seemed irrelevant as economists sought solutions, researchers studied, and philosophers debated. Many chose to spend their money, believing there was no point in saving for retirement, convinced they would die in February 2017 when the earth would burn.

Unfortunately, the predictions were flawed. As Newton noted, *"If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants."* Scientific temperature scales have evolved, and it was assumed a more effective measure than the boiling and melting points of water would emerge. Perhaps a maximum temperature would be established, akin to Planck temperature, to complement Absolute Zero.

In 2017, a new scale was proposed, the Blane, named after an emerging scientist. This scale eliminated boiling and melting points, defining temperature in units like Nano-blanes or Pico-blanes, with 1 Blane as the maximum.

It appears the prediction website miscalculated, using Pico-blanes instead of Celsius. As a result, 1000 Pico-blanes could equate to 23 Celsius.

Initially, scientists felt relieved, believing this error indicated no imminent danger, though it might jeopardize some jobs. At least the earth wouldn¡¯t boil.

Yet, the creation of the scale hinted at a deeper issue. Perhaps temperatures were plummeting globally, and they sought to uncover the reason behind this chilling trend.

Oh no, the Earth will not burn.

The Earth will freeze.

In the midst of this discourse, traditional resources seemed trivial; economists scrambled for solutions, researchers engaged in their studies, and philosophers sparked debates. Yet, the forecasts proved to be misguided. As Newton wisely observed, *"If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants."* The scientific community has refined temperature scales over time, anticipating the emergence of a more sophisticated measurement that would transcend the boiling and melting points of water. It was conceivable that a maximum temperature, reminiscent of Planck temperature, would be introduced to complement Absolute Zero.

In 2017, a novel scale emerged ¡ª the Blane, named in honor of a promising young scientist. This innovative scale did away with the conventional boiling and melting points, instead defining temperature in unique units such as Nano-blanes and Pico-blanes, establishing 1 Blane as the upper limit.

However, the introduction of the Blane scale hinted at a more profound concern. Could it be that temperatures were actually plummeting across the globe? Scientists were compelled to investigate the cause behind this alarming trend.

The Earth will freeze.
