human: The aim of this observational prospective study was to evaluate the safety of outpatient therapeutic endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) in a very elderly cohort.A total of 600 patients were included in the study between June 2006 and June 2009. All underwent first therapeutic ERCP and were scheduled to be discharged on the same day following a postprocedure observation period of 6 hours. Of the 600 patients, 123 patients (group A) were re-admitted due to postprocedure complications that presented during the observation period, and 477 patients (group B) were discharged on the same day. Concomitant diseases, details of ERCP procedures, complications, and outcomes were all evaluated. The accuracy of the 6-hour postprocedure observation period, clinical criteria in predicting those patients aged 80 years and older in whom all therapeutic ERCP can be performed on an outpatient basis, and costs saved were all assessed.There was a statistical difference in incidence of concomitant diseases between groups A and B (group A 84.5 % vs. group B 74.6 %; P = 0.020). However, there was no difference between the groups with regard to indication for ERCP and type of intervention. There was no difference in postprocedure complication rate between very elderly patients and younger patients (< 80 years), except for prolonged sedation or hypotension, which occurred more frequently in older (¡Ý 80 years) than in younger (< 80 years) patients (7.6 % vs. 3.2 %; P = 0.037). In group B, complications necessitating re-admission after the 6-hour observation period occurred in 10 patients (2.09 %) (patients ¡Ý 80 years 0.8 % and patients < 80 years 2.5 %). The costs saved by performing the procedure on an outpatient basis was calculated as 150  per patient.
LLM_1: This observational prospective study aimed to evaluate the safety of outpatient therapeutic endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) in a very elderly cohort. A total of 600 patients, treated between June 2006 and June 2009, underwent their first therapeutic ERCP with a planned same-day discharge following a 6-hour post-procedure observation. Among these, 123 patients (group A) were re-admitted due to complications arising during the observation period, while 477 patients (group B) were discharged without incident. The study assessed concomitant diseases, ERCP procedure details, complications, and outcomes. Notably, the incidence of concomitant diseases was significantly higher in group A (84.5%) than in group B (74.6%; P = 0.020), although no differences were observed regarding indications for ERCP or type of intervention. The post-procedure complication rate was similar between very elderly patients and those younger than 80 years, except for prolonged sedation or hypotension, which occurred more frequently in patients aged 80 years and older (7.6% vs. 3.2%; P = 0.037). In group B, complications that required re-admission post-observation occurred in 10 patients (2.09%), with rates of 0.8% for patients ¡Ý 80 years and 2.5% for those < 80 years. The estimated cost savings from outpatient procedures were calculated at 150 per patient.
LLM_2:
This observational prospective study sought to assess the safety of outpatient therapeutic endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) in a cohort of very elderly patients. A total of 600 individuals who underwent their first therapeutic ERCP between June 2006 and June 2009 were included, all of whom were scheduled for same-day discharge after a 6-hour post-procedure observation period. Among these, 123 patients (group A) required re-admission due to complications that arose during the observation phase, whereas 477 patients (group B) were discharged without any incidents. The study examined various factors, including comorbidities, specifics of the ERCP procedures, complications encountered, and overall outcomes. 

A noteworthy finding was that the prevalence of concomitant diseases was significantly elevated in group A (84.5%) compared to group B (74.6%; P = 0.020). However, there were no significant differences between the groups regarding the indications for ERCP or the types of interventions performed. The rate of post-procedural complications was comparable between the very elderly patients and those under 80 years of age, with the exception of prolonged sedation or hypotension, which was more prevalent in the cohort aged 80 years and older (7.6% vs. 3.2%; P = 0.037). In group B, complications necessitating re-admission following the observation period were recorded in 10 patients (2.09%), with a re-admission rate of 0.8% for patients aged 80 and above, and 2.5% for those under 80 years. Furthermore, the estimated cost savings associated with outpatient procedures were quantified at 150 per patient.

*Thought I'd try my hand at writing, please go easy on me: > Not overly happy with the end, but snappy comebacks are hard >. < * 
 
 The last day of fighting. It was pitiful, really. What was a race of philanthropists and diplomats to do against the might of the Jun'recsh, the greatest empire the galaxy had ever known? 
 
 It would have been over if they'd just dropped a nuke on the city and be done with it, but Accord High Command wanted to use this for propaganda. Nukes make for bad propaganda, apparently. 
 
 Commander Har'schlach did n't care in the slightest. He wanted blood. He'd had great fun earlier in the millennium, wiping out the humans. Such fragile little things they were, fully-grown individuals barely reaching to his mid-chest, which was at an average height for a Jun'recsh, though most of their women were pretty, if tiny, and they made acceptable slaves even if they did n't last all that long. 
 
 ¡° Warriors of Hal'chran! ¡± A voice boomed through his headset. Glorious blood is about to be spilled today. 
 
 ¡° Today we fight to exterminate the pitiful Lunria. To crush them beneath our heels, to obliterate their hopes and dreams at the end of the barrels of our guns! ¡± A maniacal grin appeared on his face. Perhaps he would take one of the Lunria, female of course, home with him? They were pretty enough and generally lasted longer in bed than any Jun'recsh, as shameful as it was to admit that Jun'recsh were second-best at anything. 
 
 ¡° Today we prove once again that the Jun'rec-what the fuck is tha -- ¡± he tore his headset off, his ear ringing from the crackle of a malfunctioning microphone at the other end. The resounding boom of explosions was heard by all, and all raised their eyes to the sky, their gazes resting on the lines of bright orange-yellow streaking from high-orbit to the soil. 
 
 In the time it took to utter four and three-quarter word, an enemy fleet had jumped into system and wiped out the Jun'recsh fleet, numbering more than 50 vessels for this single pathetic planet. 
 
 As their eyes were still raised toward the sky, they bore witness to the pods falling. The Lunria would later call the event'Divine Vengeance'. 
 
 He was knocked off-balance by the shockwave of a pod landing none too gently near him. Instinct kicking in, he planted his feet firmly on the ground, fell to one knee to present a smaller target, and raised his rifle to shoulder-height. He trained his rifle on the pod as the pod hissed and the hydraulics governing the pod's latch started work. 
 
 The pod was small, he absently noted. Less than 180 cm in height, barely to his mid-chest. The pod opened fully in less than ten seconds, allowing him to see the mass of armour inside. A memory from a while ago flashed, causing him to blurt out, ¡° human? ¡± 
 
 In response, the human in thick armour raised his gatling gun, the barrels started rotation, gradually increasing to maximum velocity. 
 
 The human's voice filled the air between him and the six Jun'recsh. 
 
 ¡° Payback's a bitch, innit? ¡± 
 
 The gun spat out rapid-fire lasers, and Har'schlach knew no more.

human:
This paper tackles the problem of learning joint embeddings for OCT and fundus images in the context of missing data at test time. The model is composed of two neural networks, each processing one of the modalities, with the goal of exploiting complementary information among modalities to improve classification performance. Modality networks are trained to classify normal vs abnormal images, while avoiding to distinguish between modality-specific representations by means of an adversarial loss.

pros:
+ important problem of designing models that can cope with missing modalities
+ simple method

cons
- presentation and writing clarity could be significantly improved
- experimental analysis and evaluation are not compelling

My main concerns are the presentation of the paper and the weak experimental pipeline. 

*The paper largely exceeds the recommended page length, without any need. Information appears duplicated, some plots presented in the paper do not convey much additional information and tables are way too big (see page 10). 
*The method is explained in a somehow convoluted way. For the first few pages, I was under the impression that a gradient reversal method was used to learn modality-agnostic features. However, it seems that instead, a regular adversarial loss is used to enforce features from both modalities to be indistinguishable. ?
*Notation introduced in the figures does not always match the notation in the text. ?
*Authors should also consider changing the title to something more meaningful.?
*Some tables do not report the metric that they use to compare approaches.?
*Some figures do not have a figure number nor a caption.?
*Although using adversarial losses to learn domain-agnostic features is a valid approach, there is a vast literature that should be reviewed in the paper. 
*Some figures are referenced and do not appear in the paper.
*Citations of Theano and Lasagne should appear in the paper, since those are the frameworks used.
*Section 5.2 paragraph 1 is the same as Section 5.3 paragraphs 1.

*I wonder how an end-to-end model, that would learn to co-register modalities and extract thickness maps would work.
*In the experimental setup, why not train the proposed model with 2 labels (instead of 4) directly? A similar experiment is performed in Section 5.3.2 but with an architecture that fuses labels, and has more capacity (instead of preserving the initial architecture and training with 2 possible outputs instead of 4). Surprisingly, in all the tables a single number is reported.
*Although the method can be tested on single modality datasets, it still requires a very curated and paired dataset to perform the training, which might not always be readily available. 
*Is the local dataset private? Calling the second dataset "private dataset" makes it confusing.
*How many experts annotated the dataset?
*It would be beneficial to provide results on publicly available datasets as well, for the sake of comparison with other related methods.
*Most of the results are reported per patch, whereas it seems much more interesting to report the results per image.
*How is the dataset split after data augmentation? Are images belonging to different patients properly separated?
*How are the class predictions computed from the output of the networks? From the text "the obtained probabilities are converted to class labels by applying sigmoid activation function". It is not clear why one would apply a sigmoid non-linearity after the probabilities, one would expect to have argmax over the probabilities to obtain the class labels (given 4 classes).
*It is not clear what Figure 6 shows, according to the text "Train & Test" are shown, but there is only one plot per model. Please note that, in any case, it would be better to show validation plots instead of test plots. Additionally, it seems natural that the "proposed model" learns faster, since it starts from pre-trained OCT and fundus networks.
*In the cross modal training and testing (page 8), how is the feature concatenation performed when one of the modalities is not available? Authors claim that performance is deteriorated, but it is not clear how this was tested.
*Table 3 should present per image results instead of per patch results. Moreover, it is not clear which metric is used to compare different models.
*Plots in Figure 9: Given that the Dm network takes as input features from layers C4, C6 and C8, it would be interesting to show the role of each one of those layers separately (and incrementally combining them).
*It would be beneficial to show some qualitative results.
LLM_1:
This paper addresses the challenge of learning joint embeddings for OCT and fundus images in the presence of missing data at test time. It employs two neural networks, each dedicated to one modality, aiming to leverage complementary information for enhanced classification performance. The modality networks classify normal versus abnormal images while using an adversarial loss to prevent the differentiation of modality-specific representations.

**Pros:**
- Tackles the significant issue of models dealing with missing modalities.
- Utilizes a straightforward method.

**Cons:**
- Clarity of presentation and writing requires substantial improvement.
- The experimental analysis and evaluation lack robustness.

My primary concerns relate to the paper's presentation and its inadequate experimental framework.

The paper exceeds the recommended page limit unnecessarily, with duplicated information, uninformative plots, and overly large tables (e.g., page 10). The methodology is convoluted; initially, it appears that a gradient reversal method is employed to learn modality-agnostic features, but it turns out that a standard adversarial loss is used instead. Additionally, the notation in figures does not consistently align with that in the text. A more meaningful title should be considered. Some tables fail to specify the metrics employed for comparison, and certain figures lack both numbers and captions. Although using adversarial losses for learning domain-agnostic features is valid, the literature review is insufficient. Some referenced figures are missing from the paper, and citations for Theano and Lasagne, the frameworks used, are absent. Furthermore, Section 5.2 paragraph 1 is identical to Section 5.3 paragraph 1.

I am curious about the potential of an end-to-end model that could learn to co-register modalities and extract thickness maps. In the experimental setup, why not train the proposed model with two labels instead of four? A similar experiment in Section 5.3.2 employs a label-fusing architecture with greater capacity, rather than maintaining the original architecture while training with two outputs. Notably, only single numbers are reported in all tables. While the method can be applied to single-modality datasets, it demands a carefully curated paired dataset for training, which may not always be available. The term "private dataset" is ambiguous; clarification on whether the local dataset is private is needed. It is also unclear how many experts annotated the dataset, and including results from publicly available datasets would enhance comparisons with related methods. Most results are reported per patch, yet presenting them per image would be more informative. The dataset splitting method post-augmentation raises questions about the separation of images from different patients. Additionally, the process for computing class predictions from network outputs is unclear; the text states that "the obtained probabilities are converted to class labels by applying a sigmoid activation function," which is puzzling since one would expect to apply argmax over probabilities given four classes. The significance of Figure 6 is unclear, as only one plot per model is shown despite the mention of "Train & Test"; validation plots would be preferable. In the cross-modal training and testing (page 8), the method of concatenating features when one modality is absent needs clarification, especially since performance reportedly deteriorates. Table 3 should display results per image rather than per patch, and the comparison metric used across models is not identified. For plots in Figure 9, it would be insightful to separately and incrementally showcase the contributions of the features from layers C4, C6, and C8 as inputs to the Dm network. Finally, including some qualitative results would be advantageous.
LLM_2:
This paper confronts the challenge of learning joint embeddings for Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) and fundus images when faced with missing data during testing. It employs two distinct neural networks, each tailored to one modality, with the goal of harnessing complementary information to improve classification performance. These modality-specific networks differentiate between normal and abnormal images while utilizing adversarial loss to mitigate the distinction between modality-specific representations.

**Pros:**
- Addresses the critical issue of models managing missing modalities.
- Implements a straightforward approach.

**Cons:**
- The clarity and quality of the presentation need significant enhancement.
- The experimental analysis and evaluation are not sufficiently robust.

My primary concerns are centered around the paper's presentation and its limited experimental framework.

The manuscript exceeds the recommended page limit, containing redundant information, unclear plots, and excessively large tables (for example, on page 10). The methodology appears convoluted; while it initially seems to employ a gradient reversal method to learn modality-agnostic features, it ultimately relies on a standard adversarial loss. Additionally, there is inconsistent notation between the figures and the text. A more descriptive title would be beneficial. Some tables do not clarify the metrics used for comparison, and certain figures lack numerical data and captions. Although employing adversarial losses for learning domain-agnostic features is a valid approach, the literature review is lacking. There are also missing figures that are referenced, and citations for the frameworks used, Theano and Lasagne, are absent. Furthermore, the first paragraph of Section 5.2 is identical to that of Section 5.3.

I am interested in the potential of an end-to-end model capable of co-registering modalities and extracting thickness maps. In the experimental design, why not train the proposed model with two labels instead of four? A related experiment in Section 5.3.2 utilizes a label-fusion architecture with increased capacity, instead of retaining the original architecture while training with two outputs. It is noteworthy that all tables present only single numerical values. While the method can be adapted for single-modality datasets, it requires a well-curated paired dataset for training, which may not always be accessible. The term "private dataset" is vague; clarification is needed regarding whether the local dataset is indeed private. It is also unclear how many experts annotated the dataset, and including results from publicly available datasets would facilitate more effective comparisons with related methods. Most results are reported per patch; however, it would be more informative to present them on a per-image basis. The dataset splitting method after augmentation raises concerns about the separation of images from different patients. Additionally, the process for deriving class predictions from network outputs remains ambiguous; the text mentions that "the obtained probabilities are converted to class labels by applying a sigmoid activation function," which is confusing, as one would typically expect to use argmax over the probabilities, given four classes. The significance of Figure 6 is unclear, showing only one plot per model, despite the mention of "Train & Test"; validation plots would be more appropriate. In the cross-modal training and testing section (page 8), the method for concatenating features when one modality is missing requires clarification, particularly as performance reportedly declines. Table 3 should present results per image rather than per patch, and the comparison metric utilized across models is not specified. For the plots in Figure 9, it would be beneficial to incrementally showcase the contributions of features from layers C4, C6, and C8 as inputs to the Dm network. Lastly, the inclusion of qualitative results would enhance the overall presentation.

human:
The contribution of the paper is in proposing a quantitative measure of memorization based on the assumption that the activations at the deeper layers of a *generalizing* deep network should be invariant to intra-class variations. The measure corresponds to how well can the activation matrix of a batch be approximated by a low-rank decomposition. The paper proposes to use approximate non-negative matrix factorization and compares it to PCA. As for ¡°wellness¡± it uses the final accuracy of the network after the activation is approximated in some layer(s).

The composition of the paper and its writing makes it an easy read. The work is novel in the way it proposes to measure memorization to the best of the reviewer¡¯s knowledge. However, the novel insights and/or the practical usefulness of the proposed method seem very limited. Also, there are many questions that comes to my mind that I would appreciate the authors to address:

Specific questions:
The experimental setup is unclear:
Is the linearization-batch taken from the training set or the test set?
If it is taken from the training set, for the case that p>0 (noisy labels), is the batch of a single class obtained from noisy labels or non-noisy labels? 
For the experiments, is there only one fixed batch used? How is this batch selected? How sensitive the evaluation is to the selection of the batch members and its size?
Do the batches cover the whole set?

- Figure 2.a and 2.b: How come all networks with different label noise levels end up with the same (100%?) accuracy? Are the fixed samples different for each p? (class labels change for each p).

- Figure 2.c: Why should the performance drop more when linearizing the middle layers (3_2:4_2) than the earlier layers. This seems to be in violation of the assumption about class invariance in deeper layers.

- When k=1 for NMF and PCA, the difference of the activations for different samples becomes a matter of scale. In this case, shouldn¡¯t all classifications become the same for all samples? How does this affect the accuracy? Does it make the evaluation very sensitive to the sampling of the batch? It would be interesting to study the property of the basis obtained in this border case. The same questions can be studied as one gradually increases k.
Section 4.2: It starts with the sentence ¡°In this section we show our technique is useful for predicting good generalization in a more realistic setting¡°. Indeed, the high correlation of the test performance and the proposed memorization measure in this section is very interesting. However, as for usefulness, it does not seem to provide a better criterion for early stopping or other practicalities of ReLU networks. 

- An experiment describing how well are the approximations (i.e. activation matrix reconstruction error) and how that correlate with memorization is missing.

Some general questions that come to my mind:

- the paper assumes (e.g. in page 4) that ¡°When single-class batches are not approximately linear, even in deep layers, we take this as evidence of memorization¡±. I have a concern here. Apart from the last layer, this form of simplicity of the support for the intermediate layers of a good classifier does not seem to be *necessarily*. That is, it seems to me that as long as the activation matrix of each class is linearly separable from the activation matrices of the others, there is no need for it to become simpler (by reducing the intra-class variations at the deep layers) for the classification loss to be minimized. Does this mean the paper¡¯s assumption for memorization is not necessarily valid?

- The paper relates the memorization to the extent of local linearity of a deep ReLU network. ReLU networks represent piece-wise linear functions. Thus, in order for this relation to be drawn, probably different linear regions (polytopes in the input space) should be considered for the linearization of the activation matrix. In that regard, how can this empirical measurement be translated into a more formal linearity of the global function?

- The rc number as well as the rank k of a good approximation directly depend on the number of samples in the batch. How can one obtain a measure that is independent of the number of samples in the batch?


Summary judgment:

The paper puts forward an interesting observation using a novel approach. However there are questions about the experiments, discussions around the experiments and the usefulness of the observation for training better models and/or giving additional insights to what we know. Considering that, I think the paper would make a very good workshop paper but needs more work to address the bar of an ICLR conference paper. But I am open to discussion with the authors and other reviewers.
LLM_1:
The paper contributes a quantitative measure of memorization based on the premise that the activations in the deeper layers of a generalizing deep network should remain invariant to intra-class variations. This measure assesses how well the activation matrix of a batch can be approximated by a low-rank decomposition, utilizing approximate non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) in comparison to principal component analysis (PCA). The concept of "wellness" is defined by the final accuracy of the network following the approximation of activations in specific layers.

The paper is well-structured and presents its content clearly, making it accessible for readers. To my knowledge, the approach to measuring memorization is novel. However, the insights and practical applicability of the proposed method appear limited. Several questions arise that I would like the authors to address:

Specific questions:
The experimental setup lacks clarity:
- Is the linearization batch sourced from the training set or the test set?
- If from the training set and with p>0 (noisy labels), is the batch for a single class derived from noisy or non-noisy labels?
- Is a single fixed batch used for experiments? How is this batch selected, and how sensitive is the evaluation to the selection and size of the batch?
- Do the batches encompass the entire dataset?

- For Figures 2.a and 2.b, why do all networks, despite varying label noise levels, achieve the same (100%?) accuracy? Are the fixed samples distinct for each p?

- In Figure 2.c, why does the performance decline more when linearizing middle layers (3_2:4_2) compared to earlier layers? This seems contradictory to the assumption of class invariance in deeper layers.

- When k=1 for NMF and PCA, the differences in activations across samples become scale-dependent. Shouldn¡¯t this result in uniform classifications across samples? What implications does this have for accuracy, and does it introduce sensitivity to batch sampling? It would be insightful to explore the properties of the basis obtained in this scenario and to pose similar questions while gradually increasing k.

- Section 4.2 states, ¡°In this section we show our technique is useful for predicting good generalization in a more realistic setting.¡± While the high correlation between test performance and the proposed memorization measure is indeed intriguing, the section does not demonstrate improved criteria for early stopping or other practical applications of ReLU networks.

- An experiment assessing the accuracy of approximations (i.e., activation matrix reconstruction error) and their correlation with memorization is absent.

General questions:
- The paper posits (e.g., on page 4) that ¡°When single-class batches are not approximately linear, even in deep layers, we take this as evidence of memorization.¡± This raises a concern: aside from the last layer, the simplicity of intermediate layer supports in a good classifier does not seem necessary. As long as the activation matrix for each class is linearly separable from others, simplification of intra-class variations in deep layers may not be required to minimize classification loss. Does this imply that the paper¡¯s assumption regarding memorization might not be valid?

- The paper connects memorization to the degree of local linearity in deep ReLU networks, which represent piece-wise linear functions. For this relationship to hold, it seems essential to consider different linear regions (polytopes in the input space) in the linearization of the activation matrix. How can this empirical measurement be related to a more formal characterization of the global function's linearity?

- The rank k of a good approximation and the rc number are directly influenced by the batch size. How can one derive a measure that is independent of the number of samples in the batch?

Summary judgment:
The paper presents an intriguing observation through a novel methodology. However, concerns regarding the experimental design, discussions related to the experiments, and the practical utility of the findings for enhancing model training and providing additional insights must be addressed. Given these considerations, the paper would be suitable for a workshop but requires further refinement to meet the standards of an ICLR conference. I remain open to discussions with the authors and other reviewers.
LLM_2:
The paper introduces a quantitative metric for memorization, based on the premise that the activations in the deeper layers of a generalizing deep network should be invariant to variations within the same class. This metric evaluates the extent to which the activation matrix of a batch can be approximated using a low-rank decomposition, employing approximate non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) and comparing it to principal component analysis (PCA). The notion of "wellness" is characterized by the final accuracy of the network after approximating activations in designated layers.

The structure of the paper is commendable, and it effectively communicates its findings, making it accessible to its intended audience. To the best of my knowledge, the method for quantifying memorization is innovative. However, the depth of insights and the practical applicability of the proposed approach seem somewhat restricted. I have several questions that I would like the authors to address:

### Specific Questions:
- **Experimental Setup:** The clarity of the experimental setup is lacking. 
  - Is the batch used for linearization drawn from the training set or the test set?
  - If it originates from the training set with p>0 (indicating noisy labels), are the batches for each individual class derived from noisy or clean labels?
  - Is a fixed batch utilized throughout the experiments? What criteria govern the selection of this batch, and how sensitive is the evaluation to both the selection and size of the batch?
  - Do the batches represent the entirety of the dataset?

- **Figures 2.a and 2.b:** Why do all networks achieve the same (100%?) accuracy, despite differing levels of label noise? Are the samples fixed for each value of p?

- **Figure 2.c:** The performance appears to decline more significantly when linearizing the middle layers (3_2:4_2) compared to the initial layers. This seems to contradict the assumption of class invariance in deeper layers.

- **NMF and PCA Analysis:** When k=1 for NMF and PCA, the differences in activations across samples become scale-dependent. Shouldn't this lead to uniform classifications across samples? What are the implications for accuracy, and does this introduce sensitivity to batch sampling? It would be beneficial to examine the properties of the basis acquired in this context and to raise similar inquiries while progressively increasing k.

- **Section 4.2:** The statement, ¡°In this section we show our technique is useful for predicting good generalization in a more realistic setting,¡± lacks substantiation. While the high correlation between test performance and the proposed memorization measure is intriguing, the section fails to demonstrate improved criteria for early stopping or other practical applications concerning ReLU networks.

- **Absence of Experimentation:** There is no experiment assessing the accuracy of approximations (i.e., activation matrix reconstruction error) and their relationship with memorization.

### General Questions:
- The assertion (e.g., on page 4) that ¡°When single-class batches are not approximately linear, even in deep layers, we take this as evidence of memorization¡± raises a critical concern. Beyond the last layer, the simplicity of intermediate layer supports in a competent classifier does not seem obligatory. Provided that the activation matrix for each class is linearly separable from others, the simplification of intra-class variations in deeper layers may not be necessary for minimizing classification loss. Does this cast doubt on the validity of the paper¡¯s assumption regarding memorization?

- The paper links memorization to the degree of local linearity in deep ReLU networks, which are defined by piece-wise linear functions. For this connection to hold, it seems crucial to account for the different linear regions (polytopes in the input space) in the linearization of the activation matrix. How can this empirical measurement be tied to a more formal characterization of the global function's linearity?

- The rank k of a sound approximation and the rc number are directly affected by batch size. How can a measure be developed that is independent of the number of samples in the batch?

### Summary Judgment:
This paper presents a compelling observation through a novel methodology. However, it must address concerns regarding the experimental design, the discussions surrounding the experiments, and the practical implications of the findings for improving model training and offering deeper insights. Given these points, while the paper may be suitable for a workshop, it requires further refinement to align with the standards expected at an ICLR conference. I am open to engaging in discussions with the authors and fellow reviewers.

They are taking action on behalf of investors, including hedge funds and pension funds, who accuse banks of conspiring to manipulate rates.
The banks include HSBC, Barclays, BNP Paribas, Bank of America, JP Morgan, Citibank, Goldman Sachs, RBS and UBS.
Lawyer Michael Hausfeld said this was just the start.
Seven other banks are also being pursued and Mr Hausfeld added that the firm was also considering "concerted" action in London and Asia.
"While the recoveries here are tremendous, they are just the beginning," he said.
"Investors around the world should take note of the significant recoveries secured in the United States and recognize that these settlements cover a fraction of the world's largest financial market."
Traders used their banks' closed chat rooms, instant messaging systems and emails to manipulate prices.
Using the kind of colourful language typical in the spate of market rigging cases involving the banks, traders assumed names such as "The Cartel," "The Bandits' Club," and "The Mafia" to communicate and place confidential orders.
Many of the world's leading banks have paid hefty fines for fixing rates in the ?¡ê5.5 trillion a day currency trading markets.
In May, US and UK regulators ordered $6 billion in fines on six major banks for rigging the foreign exchange market and Libor interest rates.
The agreements, which have not been broken down into the amounts individual banks will pay, are preliminary and need to be agreed by the district judge.

human:
This paper proposes a hierarchical RL method where the high level controller produces a series of sub-goals in an open-loop fashion which the low-level controller attempts to reach sequentially with the aim of maximising task rewards. The agent is trained using an extension of Hindsight Actor-Critic (HAC) algorithm. The algorithm also leverages a model-free flat policy trained on task rewards as an expert. The approach is evaluated on two tasks: Mountain Car and Lunar Lander.

The related work section lacks a thorough analysis of existing literature in this domain. Additionally, the lack of baselines is quite concerning, I would have liked to see a comparison with closed loop hierarchical agents, or model based hierarchical agents.

1. While the motivation of the work is interesting, the paper lacks novelty and fails to provide any comparisons with existing HRL methods that could also directly fit in the category of explainable RL methods. There have been several papers attempting sub-goal discovery in HRL which are not discussed in this work. Hence, it is hard to assess the novelty and how it stands in comparison to existing methods. Some recent work in this direction: ([Jurgenson et. al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.05329), [Parascandolo et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.11410), [Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453))

2. To my understanding, the method only works if the low-level controller has near optimal performance as otherwise setting open-loop goals would not be plausible. For example, the agent might diverge significantly from the path expected by the high level-controller while reaching one of the subgoals and hence the rest of the plan is not relevant anymore. This limits the usefulness of this method significantly, making it only plausible in deterministic settings and it is unlikely that it would generalise outside of the distribution of data seen during training. Could you comment on how this could be addressed?

3. Connected to that, other work on model-based HRL also seems directly relevant in this context where there is no need to assume necessarily that the low-level controller is perfect as the high level transition model is learned and leveraged during planning to find a most rewarding series of subgoals. This has an additional benefit of not assuming the low-level policy is perfect and rely on a learned transition model of behaviour for the agent. It also does not rely on having access to an expert low-level controller to provide demonstrations. It would be nice to better motivate the reasoning behind assuming a perfect low-level controller and discuss its failure cases. Relevant works in this direction include  an ([Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453 ), [Pierrot et al, 2020](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.13363))

4. It is not clear to me how many goals are queried from the high level controller at the start of an episode, the paper states ¡°...,this process repeats until the desired amount of goals has been collected.¡± It would be good to discuss this in the main text.

In summary, while the motivation seems sound and important, the problem the paper is addressing is not particularly novel. At the same time, the assumptions made seem quite restrictive to me, the experiments are not particularly convincing and rigorous comparisons to baselines are missing.

Hence unfortunately, I don¡¯t believe this paper, in its current form, is appropriate for publication. But I encourage the authors to improve their related work section, discuss and compare their method with existing approaches to subgoals discovery and model-based HRL to better motivate the novelty and significance of this work.
LLM_1:
This paper presents a hierarchical RL method where a high-level controller generates sub-goals in an open-loop manner for a low-level controller to achieve sequentially, aiming to maximize task rewards. The agent is trained using an extension of the Hindsight Actor-Critic (HAC) algorithm and incorporates a model-free flat policy trained on task rewards as an expert. The approach is evaluated on the Mountain Car and Lunar Lander tasks.

The related work section lacks a comprehensive analysis of existing literature in this area. Additionally, the absence of baselines is concerning; comparisons with closed-loop hierarchical agents or model-based hierarchical agents would be beneficial.

1. While the motivation is intriguing, the paper lacks novelty and does not compare the proposed method with existing HRL approaches that could qualify as explainable RL methods. Several relevant works on sub-goal discovery in HRL are not addressed, making it difficult to evaluate the novelty and competitive standing of this approach. Notable references include ([Jurgenson et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.05329), [Parascandolo et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.11410), [Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453)).

2. The method appears viable only if the low-level controller performs nearly optimally; otherwise, setting open-loop goals may become impractical. For instance, significant divergence from the expected path while reaching a sub-goal could render subsequent plans irrelevant. This limitation restricts the method's applicability, particularly in non-deterministic settings, and raises concerns about its generalization beyond the training data distribution. A discussion on addressing this issue would be valuable.

3. Other research on model-based HRL is directly pertinent, as it does not require a perfect low-level controller; instead, it learns a high-level transition model to guide planning for optimal sub-goal sequences. This approach alleviates reliance on an expert low-level controller for demonstrations and offers advantages in cases where the low-level policy is imperfect. It would be helpful to clarify the rationale for assuming a perfect low-level controller and to discuss potential failure cases. Relevant works include ([Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453), [Pierrot et al., 2020](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.13363)).

4. The paper does not specify the number of goals generated by the high-level controller at the start of an episode, stating only that ¡°this process repeats until the desired amount of goals has been collected.¡± Clarification on this point in the main text would enhance understanding.

In summary, while the motivation is sound, the addressed problem lacks novelty, and the assumptions made are quite restrictive. The experiments are not particularly convincing, and rigorous comparisons to baselines are missing.

Therefore, I do not believe this paper is suitable for publication in its current form. I encourage the authors to enhance the related work section and engage in discussions and comparisons with existing approaches to sub-goal discovery and model-based HRL to better substantiate the novelty and significance of their work.
LLM_2:
This paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning (RL) approach in which a high-level controller formulates sub-goals for a low-level controller to pursue sequentially, with the objective of maximizing task rewards. The agent is trained using an adaptation of the Hindsight Actor-Critic (HAC) algorithm and employs a model-free flat policy, guided by task rewards, as an expert. The evaluation is conducted on the Mountain Car and Lunar Lander tasks.

However, the related work section falls short of providing an in-depth analysis of the existing literature in this field. Furthermore, the lack of baseline comparisons is troubling; it would be advantageous to include comparisons with closed-loop hierarchical agents or model-based hierarchical agents.

1. Although the motivation behind this research is compelling, the paper lacks novelty and fails to compare the proposed method with established hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) approaches that could be classified as explainable RL methods. Several pertinent studies on sub-goal discovery in HRL are not referenced, making it challenging to assess the originality and competitive positioning of this method. Important references that should be included are ([Jurgenson et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.05329), [Parascandolo et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.11410), [Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453)).

2. The viability of the proposed method hinges on the low-level controller operating at near-optimal performance; otherwise, the use of open-loop goals may become impractical. For example, if the controller significantly deviates from the expected trajectory while attempting to achieve a sub-goal, subsequent plans could become irrelevant. This limitation restricts the applicability of the method, particularly in non-deterministic environments, and raises questions about its ability to generalize beyond the training data distribution. A discussion on how to address this challenge would be beneficial.

3. Research on model-based HRL is particularly relevant here, as it does not necessitate a perfect low-level controller. Instead, it develops a high-level transition model to facilitate planning for optimal sequences of sub-goals. This strategy mitigates the dependence on an expert low-level controller for demonstrations and proves advantageous when the low-level policy is less than ideal. It would be helpful for the authors to clarify their rationale for assuming an ideal low-level controller and to examine potential failure scenarios. Relevant works include ([Nasiriany et al., 2019](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08453), [Pierrot et al., 2020](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.13363)).

4. The paper does not clarify how many goals the high-level controller generates at the beginning of an episode, stating only that ¡°this process repeats until the desired amount of goals has been collected.¡± Providing more detail on this aspect in the main text would enhance clarity.

In conclusion, while the motivation is valid, the addressed problem lacks originality and the assumptions are rather restrictive. The experimental results are not particularly persuasive, and there is a notable absence of rigorous comparisons to baseline methods.

Consequently, I do not believe this paper is fit for publication in its current form. I encourage the authors to strengthen the related work section and engage in discussions and comparisons with existing sub-goal discovery and model-based HRL approaches to better establish the novelty and significance of their contributions.

Jonah threw the first punch, but he had no idea what he was in for. 
 
 It became instantly clear when the suited man caught Jonah ¡¯ s fist, twisted and threw him over his shoulder. The man walked away while Jonah lay there, dazed. Despite the show of surprising strength, Jonah got up and came at the man again, this time trying to rush him from behind. The man turned around and shoved, and Jonah was back on the floor. 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ ve been augmented, ¡± he said, looking down at Jonah. ¡° There ¡¯ s no point. You ¡¯ re only hurting yourself. ¡± 
 
 Jonah tried to kick out at the man, but he agilely stepped back out of the way. Somewhere, behind his fury, Jonah knew he looked idiotic. He also knew he had to land a blow, whatever it took. 
 
 Two of the bouncers had arrived, and they lifted Jonah off the ground to escort him out of the bar. He struggled, but they were far too strong for him. 
 
 ¡° Come fight, you coward, ¡± he shouted as they dragged him away. ¡° I don ¡¯ t care if you ¡¯ re augmented, I ¡¯ ll smash your face in. I ¡¯ ll smash your mother ¡¯ s face in. I ¡¯ ll smash your grandmother. I ¡¯ ll find your children and kick in their teeth. Come fight! Are you afraid? Come fight me you bastard! ¡± 
 
 Then he was out on the street. It was cold, but he was still burning in rage. Steam was coming off him in the freezing night air. He paced furiously back and forth in front of the door, while the bouncers scowled at him. 
 
 ¡° Shove off, or we ¡¯ ll call the police, ¡± said the bigger of the two. 
 
 Jonah laughed. ¡° I am the police! ¡± He whipped his badge out of his coat pocket. The bouncers eyed it dubiously. Then suddenly Jonah ¡¯ s adversary was striding through the door towards him, and the badge was stuffed back. Only one thing was on his mind now. 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ m not afraid of you, ¡± said the man calmly. ¡° And if I have to prove it by kicking the shit out of you, I will. ¡± 
 
 This time the man punched first, and Jonah barely ducked in time. He attempted to return the hit, but the man swatted the blow away with ease, punching Jonah hard in the face. Blood splashed into Jonah ¡¯ s sight, but he wasn ¡¯ t stopping. He lunged, and received another ringing clout, then another, then another, and then ¨C he was down. He tried to get up, but not even adrenaline could help him now. His eyesight was hazy, and his head was throbbing with agony. 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ m faster than you, I ¡¯ m stronger than you, I ¡¯ m smarter than you, ¡± said the man. ¡° Give up. ¡± 
 
 Jonah laughed bitterly, spluttering blood. ¡° You Martians. You ¡¯ re all money and geneering. Think the Earth is your playground. ¡± 
 
 ¡° I ¡¯ m afraid you ¡¯ re probably right, ¡± he replied. ¡° But there ¡¯ s no point taking it out on a stranger. ¡± 
 
 ¡° You ¡¯ re no stranger, ¡± Jonah said. ¡° I know who you are. You ¡¯ re the rich asshole who started it all. ¡± 
 
 The man looked at him in surprise. ¡° You think I ¡¯ m Tanner Johnsgard? ¡± Then he started to laugh. ¡° You think the Tanner Johnsgard would be slumming in an Earth bar? ¡± 
 
 ¡° You are Tanner! It ¡¯ s been years, but I remember. You can stay young; everyone knows that Martians don ¡¯ t age. I saw you when I was a child, and I never forget a face. ¡± 
 
 ¡° I guess you ¡¯ re a little right, ¡± said the suited man. ¡° I ¡¯ m not Tanner Johnsgard, though I am one of his clones. There are hundreds of us, but I ¡¯ m a third generation. Funny you should pick me out to fight. ¡± 
 
 The anger went out of Jonah, and he became a broken old man. ¡° He killed my mother. Right in front of me. Or had her killed rather. I swear I would kill the bastard with my two bare hands if I ever saw him. ¡± 
 
 ¡° What a sad story, ¡± the clone remarked apathetically, turning and walking back into the bar.

human:
This work presents a method, named SnAp, that takes Real-time Recurrent Learning derivations and proposes to approximate its computations with sparse approximations to make them more computational tractable. The method is an alternative to overcome the truncation in backpropagation through time (BPTT) over long term temporal structure. The method assumes a sparsity pattern on the parameters of the network that leads to the relationship on how the gradients could be updated. Finally, the method is evaluated against BPTT, UORO and RTRL on character-level language modeling and a copy task.   

=================

The method is simple and a complexity analysis has been included. The experimental section seems limited in only showing a performance comparison with other methods. A better analysis in aspects of the method (like capacity for learning long-term temporal patterns) is lacking.

==================

When does the Snap/RTRL is not applicable? Are there cases where BPTT is applicable and Snap/RTRL is not? It would be nice to clarify such cases so readers can understand when Snap, RTRL, or BPTT are the right or better solutions. 

The motivation behind the method is to overcome the limitation of the truncation behind BPTT for learning long term temporal structure. However this seems to be evaluated with very short sequences overall (128 for language modeling and maybe less than that for the copy task, the length is not present). How well the Snap method would work when training for sequences of thousands of elements, where BPTT is well known to struggle?

The relationship between neurons can vary every time the parameters are updated. Is it assumed to be fixed over the entire training? What would happen if the pattern is updated every few gradient updates? Also, complexities for Snap in table 1 don¡¯t seem to consider the computational time of computing the sparsity pattern (even for a random pattern).

When n is big, the experimental results show a better and competitive performance to BPTT. However, in such cases (like Snap-3) the computational cost becomes very expensive compared to BPTT by at least 2 orders of magnitude, and the matrices become more dense. What are the results of TBPTT when stateful training is applied and how do they compare in such case? Also, the copy task has been solved with fewer neurons in previous works. 

The Copy task details are unclear for someone that doesn¡¯t know the work from Mujika et al., 2018. Please describe all the details. What is the length L used in the experiments? What is the length of the overall sequence? What does ¡°data time¡± mean in the plots of Figure 4?

==================

My concerns behind the limited practicality of the method, and the limited experimental results given the hypothesis that the method can learn long-term temporal patterns. These are my considerations not to accept this paper.

==================

Minor issues:

-Use bigger fonts in the plots, and diagrams.

-In 5.1, do you use SGD or Adam?

-Figure 3: leave space between caption and figures

-Table 1 caption: ¡°Below¡± -> ¡°Above¡±

-It would be nice to mention the relationship between |\theta| and k, for each recurrent cell case.
LLM_1:
This paper introduces SnAp, a method based on sparse approximations of Real-time Recurrent Learning (RTRL) to improve computational tractability while avoiding the truncation issues inherent in backpropagation through time (BPTT). The approach leverages a sparsity pattern in network parameters to approximate gradient updates and is evaluated on character-level language modeling and a copy task against BPTT, UORO, and RTRL.

The method is conceptually simple and includes a complexity analysis. However, the experimental evaluation is limited in scope, focusing primarily on performance comparisons without deeper investigation into the model¡¯s ability to capture long-term temporal dependencies¡ªits primary motivation. A more thorough analysis of this capacity is needed.

Key questions remain regarding the applicability of SnAp and RTRL compared to BPTT. Clarification is required on scenarios where BPTT remains viable but SnAp or RTRL may not be applicable. Furthermore, the evaluation uses relatively short sequences (e.g., 128 for language modeling; sequence length not specified for the copy task), which undermines claims about handling long-term structure. Performance on much longer sequences¡ªwhere BPTT is known to fail¡ªshould be assessed to better validate the method's advantages.

It is unclear whether the assumed sparsity pattern is fixed throughout training or updated periodically. If the latter, how often should it change, and what impact does this have on learning? Additionally, the computational cost of generating the sparsity pattern¡ªeven randomly¡ªis not accounted for in the complexity analysis in Table 1, potentially underestimating actual runtime costs.

While SnAp shows competitive performance with large n (e.g., Snap-3), its computational cost exceeds BPTT by at least two orders of magnitude, and the resulting matrices become denser. How do these variants compare with truncated BPTT (TBPTT) under stateful training, which can mitigate some limitations of truncation? Moreover, prior work has solved the copy task with fewer neurons; thus, the current setup should be justified.

The description of the copy task lacks sufficient detail, especially for readers unfamiliar with Mujika et al. (2018). The sequence length L, total sequence duration, and the meaning of ¡°data time¡± in Figure 4 must be explicitly defined.

Overall, concerns about the method¡¯s practicality and the insufficient experimental validation¡ªparticularly with respect to long-term dependency learning¡ªundermine confidence in the contribution. These limitations lead to reservations about acceptance.

Minor points:  
- Increase font sizes in plots and diagrams.  
- Specify optimizer (SGD or Adam) used in Section 5.1.  
- Add vertical space between Figure 3 and its caption.  
- In Table 1 caption, correct ¡°Below¡± to ¡°Above¡±.  
- Clarify the relationship between |¦È| and k for each recurrent cell type.
LLM_2:
This paper presents SnAp, a method based on sparse approximations of Real-Time Recurrent Learning (RTRL), designed to improve computational tractability while circumventing the truncation biases inherent in Backpropagation Through Time (BPTT). By exploiting structured sparsity in network parameters, SnAp approximates gradient updates in an online fashion and is evaluated on character-level language modeling and a synthetic copy task, with comparisons to BPTT, UORO, and full RTRL.

The approach is conceptually straightforward and accompanied by a theoretical complexity analysis, which contributes to its interpretability. However, the experimental evaluation is limited in scope and depth. While performance metrics are reported, there is insufficient investigation into the model¡¯s core claimed strength: the ability to capture long-term temporal dependencies. A more rigorous analysis¡ªparticularly one that isolates and measures this capacity¡ªis necessary to substantiate the methodological contribution.

Several key questions regarding the practical applicability of SnAp (and RTRL-based methods more broadly) remain unaddressed. Specifically, the conditions under which BPTT remains viable while SnAp or RTRL may not be suitable require clarification. Moreover, the current experiments employ relatively short sequences (e.g., length 128 in language modeling; sequence duration unspecified for the copy task), which weakens claims about efficacy in modeling long-range dependencies. To properly validate the advantages of SnAp, evaluation on significantly longer sequences¡ªwhere BPTT is known to fail due to vanishing gradients or memory constraints¡ªis essential.

The treatment of the sparsity pattern in SnAp raises additional concerns. It is unclear whether this pattern is fixed throughout training or dynamically updated. If the latter, the frequency and mechanism of update¡ªand their impact on learning dynamics and convergence¡ªmust be specified and analyzed. Furthermore, the computational overhead associated with generating or modifying the sparsity structure (even if random) is omitted from the complexity analysis in Table 1. This omission risks underestimating the true runtime cost and undermines the validity of efficiency claims.

Although certain variants of SnAp (e.g., SnAp-3 with large *n*) achieve competitive performance, their computational cost exceeds that of BPTT by at least two orders of magnitude, and the resulting gradient matrices become increasingly dense. A comparison with truncated BPTT (TBPTT) under stateful training¡ªa standard practice that mitigates some limitations of truncation¡ªwould provide more meaningful context for assessing trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency.

Additionally, prior work has demonstrated successful solutions to the copy task using fewer neurons and simpler architectures (e.g., Mujika et al., 2018). The use of a larger model in the current setup should therefore be justified, both in terms of necessity and fairness in comparative evaluation.

The description of the copy task lacks sufficient detail, especially for readers unfamiliar with the referenced literature. Key aspects such as the sequence length *L*, total temporal extent of the input, and the meaning of ¡°data time¡± in Figure 4 must be explicitly defined to ensure reproducibility and clarity.

In sum, concerns about the method¡¯s scalability, computational feasibility, and the adequacy of the empirical validation¡ªparticularly with respect to long-term dependency learning¡ªundermine confidence in the significance of the contribution. These limitations give rise to reservations about the paper¡¯s suitability for acceptance in its current form.

**Minor revisions recommended:**  
- Increase font sizes in all figures and diagrams to ensure readability.  
- Specify the optimizer used (e.g., SGD, Adam) in Section 5.1, including hyperparameters where applicable.  
- Add vertical spacing between Figure 3 and its caption for improved presentation.  
- In the caption of Table 1, correct ¡°Below¡± to ¡°Above¡± to accurately reflect the layout.  
- Clarify the relationship between the total number of parameters |¦È| and the sparsity-induced dimension *k* for each recurrent cell type, preferably via formal definition or example.

human:
The Arkansas Parole Board has recommended mercy in the case of Jason McGehee, who was convicted of torturing and killing a teenager.
It will now be up to Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson to decide whether the 40-year-old escapes lethal injection.
The unprecedented series of executions within a 10-day period starting on 17 April is due to a drug expiring.
The state's supply of midazolam, a sedative used in its three-drug lethal injection cocktail, will be useless after this month.
Lawyers for the prisoners say the "assembly-line" of four double lethal injections is unconstitutional.
The lawyer for McGehee, John Williams, said his client was only 20 at the time of the offence and "his near-perfect record in prison has impressed many people".
Two of his co-defendants received lesser sentences despite being equally or more culpable, said Mr Williams, who asked the governor to commute the sentence to life without parole.
Johnny Melbourne, whose 15-year-old son of the same name was beaten to death by McGehee, had asked the board to reject clemency.
"John didn't have this. Even though he was begging for his life and was hurting. He didn't have this and he begged for his life too. He didn't have y'all."
The parole board has already turned down clemency requests from four of the other men scheduled to die in the 10-day period later this month.
No US state has put eight inmates to death in such an accelerated way since the US Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty in 1976.
Like many US states, Arkansas has struggled to find the drugs it needs to carry out executions. Its last was in 2005.
Bruce Ward - Strangled teenage shop clerk Rebecca Doss
Don Davis - Condemned for the execution-style killing of Jane Daniel as he burgled her home
Stacey Johnson - Murdered Carol Heath, who was beaten, strangled and had her throat slit
Ledell Lee - Bludgeoned Debra Reese to death with a tyre iron her husband had given her for protection
Jack Jones - Condemned for the rape and murder of accounts clerk Mary Phillips, and the nearly fatal beating of her 11-year-old daughter
Marcel Williams - Raped and murdered Stacey Erickson, after kidnapping her from a convenience store
Kenneth Williams - Murdered farmer Cecil Boren during an escape from prison where Williams had been incarcerated for murdering cheerleader Dominique Hurd
Jason McGehee - Jailed for the death of 15-year-old John Melbourne, who had been his friend
LLM_1:
The Arkansas Parole Board has recommended clemency for Jason McGehee, convicted of torturing and killing 15-year-old John Melbourne, a friend of his. The decision now rests with Governor Asa Hutchinson, who must determine whether McGehee, now 40, will face lethal injection or receive a commuted sentence of life without parole.

McGehee¡¯s legal team argues he was only 20 at the time of the crime and has maintained a nearly flawless prison record. His attorney, John Williams, noted that two co-defendants received lighter sentences despite comparable or greater culpability. The accelerated execution schedule¡ªfour double executions in 10 days beginning April 17¡ªis tied to the impending expiration of the state¡¯s midazolam supply, a sedative used in the lethal injection protocol. After this month, the drug will no longer be viable.

Critics, including defense attorneys, have condemned the pace as an unconstitutional ¡°assembly-line¡± approach. No U.S. state has executed eight inmates in such a compressed timeframe since the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty in 1976. Arkansas has not carried out an execution since 2005, largely due to difficulties obtaining execution drugs.

Johnny Melbourne, father of the victim, opposed clemency, stating emotionally, ¡°John didn¡¯t have this¡­ He begged for his life and was hurting. He didn¡¯t have y¡¯all.¡±

The board has already denied clemency to four other men set to be executed during the same period. Those inmates include:

- Bruce Ward, convicted of strangling teenage clerk Rebecca Doss  
- Don Davis, sentenced for the execution-style murder of Jane Daniel during a home burglary  
- Stacey Johnson, who killed Carol Heath by beating, strangling, and slitting her throat  
- Ledell Lee, who bludgeoned Debra Reese to death with a tire iron  
- Jack Jones, convicted of raping and murdering accounts clerk Mary Phillips and severely beating her 11-year-old daughter  
- Marcel Williams, who kidnapped, raped, and murdered Stacey Erickson from a convenience store  
- Kenneth Williams, who killed farmer Cecil Boren during a prison escape; he was already serving time for the murder of cheerleader Dominique Hurd

- **Stacey Johnson**, who beat, strangled, and slit the throat of Carol Heath in 1995  
- **Ledell Lee**, who bludgeoned Debra Reese to death with a tire iron  
- **Jack Jones**, convicted of raping and murdering 36-year-old accounts clerk Mary Phillips and severely beating her 11-year-old daughter  
- **Marcel Williams**, who kidnapped, raped, and murdered 22-year-old Stacey Erickson from a Little Rock convenience store in 1996  
- **Kenneth Williams**, who killed farmer Cecil Boren during a 1999 prison escape; he was already serving a sentence for the 1998 murder of college student and cheerleader Dominique Hurd

As the execution dates draw near, the cases have sparked intense debate over sentencing disparities, the ethics of capital punishment, and the use of expiring pharmaceuticals in state-sanctioned executions.

human: In this study, we compared the success of sinus lifting and alternative treatment methods in applying dental implants in cases lacking adequate bone due to pneumatization of the maxillary sinus.In a computer environment, 3D models were created using computerized tomography data from a patient. Additionally, implants and abutments were scanned at the macroscopic level, and the resulting images were transferred to the 3D models. Five different models were examined: a control model, lateral sinus lifting (LSL), short dental implant placement (SIP), tilted implant placement (TIP) and distal prosthetic cantilever (DC) use. Vertical and oblique forces were applied in each model. The compression, tension and von Mises stresses in each model were analyzed by implementing a finite element analysis method.In our study, the LSL method was observed to be the closest to the control model. The TIP model showed high stress values under conditions of oblique forces but showed successful results under conditions of vertical forces, and the opposite results were observed in the SIP model. The DC model provided the least successful results among all models.
LLM_1: This study evaluated the biomechanical performance of sinus lift and alternative implant placement techniques in maxillary sinus pneumatization using finite element analysis. Three-dimensional models were constructed from patient-specific computed tomography data, incorporating scanned implants and abutments. Five models were analyzed: control, lateral sinus lift (LSL), short implant placement (SIP), tilted implant placement (TIP), and distal cantilever prostheses (DC). Vertical and oblique loading conditions were applied to assess von Mises, compressive, and tensile stresses. LSL exhibited stress distributions closest to the control model. TIP demonstrated higher stress under oblique loads but favorable performance under vertical loading, whereas SIP showed the converse pattern. DC yielded the least favorable stress distribution among all models.
LLM_2: This study evaluated the biomechanical performance of sinus lift and alternative implant placement techniques in the context of maxillary sinus pneumatization using finite element analysis. Three-dimensional models were developed based on patient-specific computed tomography data, incorporating scanned dental implants and abutments. Five distinct configurations were analyzed: a control model (conventional implant placement), lateral sinus lift (LSL), short implant placement (SIP), tilted implant placement (TIP), and distal cantilever prostheses (DC). Mechanical loading simulations¡ªcomprising vertical and oblique forces¡ªwere applied to assess stress distribution patterns, with particular focus on von Mises, compressive, and tensile stresses. The LSL model exhibited stress distributions most similar to those of the control, indicating favorable biomechanical behavior. TIP demonstrated higher stress concentrations under oblique loading, yet performed well under vertical loading conditions; in contrast, SIP showed lower stress during oblique loading but less optimal performance under vertical loads. The DC configuration resulted in the least favorable stress distribution among all models, suggesting potential biomechanical limitations. These findings provide insights into the relative merits and trade-offs of different implant strategies in compromised posterior maxillary regions.

human: According to consensus documents, sweat testing remains the standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. We studied a novel method of sweat analysis on two chemistry platforms: Dimension Vista (Siemens Healthcare Diagnostics) and Aeroset (Abbott).Sweat collected from healthy individuals and aqueous samples in the critical range for sweat analysis were measured using the Orion 290 plus (Thermo Electron Corporation), Chiron 925 chloride analyser (Sherwood Scientific Ltd), flame photometry, sweat-chek analyser and indirect ion-selective electrodes (ISE) of Vista and Aeroset. For measurement on ISE, an addition protocol was designed.Within-run and between-run variation coefficients of Aeroset and Vista remained <5% as prescribed by UK guidelines. The correlation between the chloride analyser and chloride concentrations analysed on Vista or Aeroset was, respectively, y = 0.96x + 7.61 (r(2) 0.990) and y = 0.97x + 1.10 (r(2) 0.930) and between sweat-chek (conductivity) and sodium concentrations analysed on Vista or Aeroset was, respectively, y = 1.08x - 4.0 (r(2) 0.967) and y = 1.13x - 1.00 (r(2) 0.939). When classified according to medical decision rules (30 mmol/L and 60 mmol/L chloride, combined with sodium concentration), the same classification was found with the ISE-module and conventional methods for all samples.
LLM_1: Sweat testing is the established method for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. This study evaluated a novel sweat analysis approach using two chemistry platforms¡ªDimension Vista (Siemens) and Aeroset (Abbott)¡ªcomparing them with conventional methods including the Orion 290 plus, Chiron 925 chloride analyser, flame photometry, sweat-chek analyser, and indirect ion-selective electrodes (ISE). Sweat samples from healthy individuals and aqueous solutions in the critical analytical range were assessed. An optimized addition protocol was implemented for ISE measurements. Both platforms met UK guidelines, with within-run and between-run coefficients of variation below 5%. Strong correlations were observed between the Chiron 925 and Vista (y = 0.96x + 7.61, r2 = 0.990) or Aeroset (y = 0.97x + 1.10, r2 = 0.930) for chloride, and between sweat-chek conductivity and sodium on Vista (y = 1.08x ? 4.0, r2 = 0.967) or Aeroset (y = 1.13x ? 1.00, r2 = 0.939). When applying clinical decision thresholds (chloride at 30 and 60 mmol/L, combined with sodium), classification agreement between ISE-based platforms and conventional methods was complete across all samples.
LLM_2: Sweat testing remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. This study evaluated a novel approach to sweat analysis using two automated chemistry platforms¡ªDimension Vista (Siemens) and Aeroset (Abbott)¡ªin comparison with established methods: the Orion 290+, Chiron 925 chloride analyzer, flame photometry, Sweat-Chek analyzer, and indirect ion-selective electrode (ISE) techniques. Sweat samples from healthy individuals and aqueous solutions within the clinically relevant analytical range were analyzed. An optimized sample addition protocol was implemented to enhance ISE measurement accuracy. Both the Dimension Vista and Aeroset platforms demonstrated high analytical precision, with within-run and between-run coefficients of variation below 5%, meeting current UK performance guidelines. Strong linear correlations were observed between chloride measurements obtained by the Chiron 925 and the Vista (y = 0.96x + 7.61, r2 = 0.990) and Aeroset (y = 0.97x + 1.10, r2 = 0.930). Similarly, conductivity measurements from the Sweat-Chek correlated well with sodium concentrations measured on the Vista (y = 1.08x ? 4.0, r2 = 0.967) and Aeroset (y = 1.13x ? 1.00, r2 = 0.939). When applying established clinical decision thresholds (chloride at 30 and 60 mmol/L, in conjunction with sodium), complete agreement in patient classification was achieved between the ISE-based platforms and conventional reference methods across all samples.
