LLM_2:
# A Whimsical Semi-Biographical Tale ¡ª 1997

### **Prologue**

If you had seen me walking down the street that morning, you might have noticed something unusual in my eyes¡ªsomething wide, disbelieving, almost childlike. Not fear, exactly. More like wonder. The kind that flickers when reality shifts beneath your feet, just slightly, enough to make you question what¡¯s real.

This wasn¡¯t the Chicago I knew.

The city I was familiar with lived in shadows: hollow-eyed strangers on midnight buses, payphones wrapped in duct tape, alleys that smelled of wet cardboard and regret. It was a place where survival wore thin coats and thinner smiles. Around people like that¡ªpeople like *me*, once¡ªI always felt translucent. Like a scrap of lace left too long in the sun: delicate, frayed, one breath away from vanishing.

But here, on this quiet stretch of North Erie Street, beneath a canopy of old-growth trees and beside red-brick sidewalks cracked by time and ivy, everything changed.

Flowerbeds bloomed behind wrought-iron gates. High-rises rose like silent sentinels of privilege, their windows catching the morning light like polished glass. And as I walked¡ªslowly, deliberately¡ªI didn¡¯t feel invisible. I felt *woven*. As if I were part of some larger, more intentional design. Protected. Valuable. On display.

For the first time in my life, I felt safe.  
Grown-up.  
*Seen.*

---

### **Chapter One: The Click That Changed Everything**

It started two months ago.

Another late night. Another soul-sucking shift at my clerical job¡ªfiling invoices, answering phones, pretending enthusiasm for work that drained me one spreadsheet at a time. That night, I didn¡¯t go straight to bed. Instead, I sat cross-legged on my worn-out comforter, laptop balanced on my knees, phone glowing beside me like a second heartbeat.

I wasn¡¯t looking for anything. Just¡­ escape.

And then it appeared¡ªan ad, blinking into existence between articles about forgotten ¡¯90s bands and conspiracy theories about Area 51. Normally, I scroll past them without thought. Ads are noise. Static. Things meant for other people¡ªpeople with disposable income, free time, hope.

But this one stopped me cold:

> **Free 30-day trial. Tired of spending nights alone?**

Simple. Direct. Almost cruel in its precision.

I stared at those words longer than I should have. Because yes¡ªyes, I *was* tired. Tired of silence. Tired of coming home to an apartment so quiet I could hear the hum of the refrigerator judging me. Tired of existing in a world that never seemed to notice when I entered or left a room.

So I clicked.

Not because I believed in miracles.  
But because, for the first time in years, I wanted to believe in *something.*

human: Altered thalamocortical development is hypothesized to be a key substrate underlying neurodevelopmental disabilities in preterm infants. However, the pathogenesis of this abnormality is not well-understood. We combined magnetic resonance spectroscopy of the parietal white matter and morphometric analyses of the thalamus to investigate the association between white matter metabolism and thalamic volume and tested the hypothesis that thalamic volume would be associated with diminished N-acetyl-aspartate (NAA), a measure of neuronal/axonal maturation, independent of white matter injury.Data from 106 preterm infants (mean gestational age at birth: 31.0?weeks?¡À?4.3; range 23-36?weeks) who underwent MR examinations under clinical indications were included in this study.Linear regression analyses demonstrated a significant association between parietal white matter NAA concentration and thalamic volume. This effect was above and beyond the effect of white matter injury and age at MRI and remained significant even when preterm infants with punctate white matter lesions (pWMLs) were excluded from the analysis. Furthermore, choline, and among the preterm infants without pWMLs, lactate concentrations were also associated with thalamic volume. Of note, the associations between NAA and choline concentration and thalamic volume remained significant even when the sample was restricted to neonates who were term-equivalent age or older.
LLM_1: Altered thalamocortical development is implicated in neurodevelopmental impairments among preterm infants, though the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This study examined the association between parietal white matter metabolism and thalamic volume using magnetic resonance spectroscopy and morphometric analysis in 106 preterm infants (mean gestational age at birth: 31.0?¡À?4.3 weeks; range: 23¨C36 weeks) undergoing clinically indicated MRI. Linear regression analyses revealed a significant association between N-acetyl-aspartate (NAA) concentration¡ªa marker of neuronal/axonal maturation¡ªand thalamic volume, independent of white matter injury and age at MRI. This association persisted after excluding infants with punctate white matter lesions (pWMLs). Additionally, choline concentrations were associated with thalamic volume, and in infants without pWMLs, lactate levels also showed a significant association. Notably, the relationships between NAA, choline, and thalamic volume remained significant when analyses were restricted to infants at term-equivalent age or older, suggesting that metabolic alterations in white matter are linked to thalamic development irrespective of overt injury.
LLM_2: Altered thalamocortical development has been implicated in neurodevelopmental impairments among preterm infants; however, the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. This study investigated the association between parietal white matter metabolism and thalamic volume using magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and quantitative morphometric analysis in a cohort of 106 preterm infants (mean gestational age at birth: 31.0?¡À?4.3 weeks; range: 23¨C36 weeks) who underwent clinically indicated MRI. Linear regression analyses revealed that N-acetyl-aspartate (NAA) concentration¡ªa biomarker of neuronal and axonal maturation¡ªwas significantly associated with thalamic volume, independent of white matter injury and postmenstrual age at MRI. This association persisted after excluding infants with punctate white matter lesions (pWMLs). Additionally, choline concentrations were positively associated with thalamic volume, and in the subgroup without pWMLs, lactate levels also showed a significant association. Notably, the relationships between NAA, choline, and thalamic volume remained statistically significant when analyses were restricted to infants scanned at term-equivalent age or later, suggesting that metabolic alterations in the parietal white matter are linked to thalamic development regardless of overt structural injury.

human:
The paper proposes a neural net implementation of counterfactual regret minimization where 2 networks are learnt, one for estimating the cumulative regret (used to derive the immediate policy) and the other one for estimating a cumulative mixture policy. In addition the authors also propose an original MC sampling strategy which generalize outcome and external sampling strategies.

The paper is interesting and easy to read. My main concern is about the feasibility of using a neural networks to learn cumulative quantities. 

The problem of learning cumulative quantities in a neural net is that we need two types of samples: 
- the positive examples: samples from which we train our network to predict its own value plus the new quantity, 
but also:
- the negative examples: samples from which we should train the network to predict 0, or any desired initial value.

However in the approach proposed here, the negative examples are missing. So the network is not trained to predict 0 (or any initial values) for a newly encountered state. And since neural networks generalize (very well...) to states that have not been sampled yet, the network would predict an arbitrary values in states that are visited for the first time. For example the network predicting the cumulative regret may generalize to large values at newly visited states, instead of predicting a value close to 0. The resulting policy can be arbitrarily different from an exploratory (close to uniform) policy, which would be required to minimize regret from a newly visited state.  Then, even if that state is visited frequently in the future, this error in prediction will never be corrected because the target cumulative regret depends on the previous prediction. So there is no guarantee this algorithm will minimise the overall regret. 
This is a well known problem for exploration (regret minimization) in reinforcement learning as well (see e.g. the work on pseudo-counts [Bellemare et al., 2016, Unifying Count-Based Exploration and Intrinsic Motivation] as one possible approach based on learning a density model). 

Here, maybe a way to alleviate this problem would be to generate negative samples (where the network would be trained to predict low cumulative values) by following a different (possibly more exploratory) policy. 


Other comments:
- It does not seem necessary to predict cumulative mixture policies (ASN network). One could train a mixture policy network to directly predict the current policy along trajectories generated by MC. Since the samples would be generated according to the current policy \sigma_t, any information nodes I_i would be sampled proportionally to \pi^{\sigma^t}_i(I_i), which is the same probability as in the definition of the mixture policy (4). This would remove the need to learn a cumulative quantity.
- It would help to have a discussion about how to implement (7), for example do you use a target network to keep the target value R_t+r_t fixed for several steps?
- It is not clear how the initialisation (10) is implemented. Since you assume the number of information nodes is large, you cannot minimize the l2 loss over all states. Do you assume you generate states by following some policy? Which policy?
LLM_1:
The paper presents a neural network-based implementation of counterfactual regret minimization, introducing two networks: one to estimate cumulative regret (used for deriving the immediate policy) and another for estimating a cumulative mixture policy. Additionally, the authors propose a novel Monte Carlo sampling strategy that generalizes both outcome and external sampling. The paper is well-written and conceptually interesting.

A central concern lies in the feasibility of using neural networks to learn cumulative quantities. Specifically, training such networks requires both positive examples¡ªwhere the network learns to predict the accumulated value updated with new observations¡ªand negative examples¡ªwhere the network should learn to output zero or an appropriate initial value for previously unvisited states. However, the current approach lacks negative examples. As a result, when encountering a new state, the network may generalize poorly, assigning arbitrary values instead of initializing near zero. For instance, the cumulative regret network might output large values in unseen states, leading to non-exploratory policies that deviate significantly from the desired uniform exploration needed to minimize regret. This error persists because subsequent updates depend on prior predictions, preventing correction over time. Consequently, there is no guarantee that the algorithm will converge to minimal regret. This issue is recognized in reinforcement learning, particularly in count-based exploration methods such as pseudo-counts (Bellemare et al., 2016), which address exploration via density modeling.

One potential mitigation could involve generating negative samples by following a more exploratory policy during training, allowing the network to learn proper initialization for novel states.

Additional comments:
- Predicting the cumulative mixture policy (ASN network) may be unnecessary. Instead, a network could directly model the current policy along trajectories generated by Monte Carlo sampling. Since these trajectories follow the current policy $\sigma_t$, information nodes $I_i$ are sampled proportionally to $\pi^{\sigma^t}_i(I_i)$, matching the weighting in the mixture policy definition (4). This avoids learning a cumulative quantity altogether.
- A clarification on the implementation of equation (7) would be helpful¡ªspecifically, whether a target network is used to stabilize the target value $R_t + r_t$ over multiple steps.
- The initialization procedure in (10) requires further explanation. Given the large number of information nodes, minimizing the L2 loss across all states is infeasible. How are states sampled for initialization? Is a specific policy used, and if so, which one?
LLM_2:
The paper proposes a neural network-based implementation of counterfactual regret minimization (CFR), introducing two distinct networks: one for estimating cumulative regret (used to derive the immediate policy) and another for approximating the cumulative mixture policy. In addition, the authors present a novel Monte Carlo sampling strategy that generalizes both outcome sampling and external sampling. The work is conceptually interesting and well-articulated, with clear motivation and a coherent overall structure.

However, a central concern arises regarding the feasibility of using neural networks to model *cumulative* quantities over time. Specifically, training such models typically requires both positive examples¡ªwhere the network learns to predict updated accumulated values upon new observations¡ªand negative examples¡ªwhere it must learn to output zero (or an appropriate initial value) for states that have not yet been visited. The current framework lacks explicit negative examples during training. As a result, when the model encounters a previously unvisited information state, it may produce arbitrary extrapolations rather than initializing predictions near zero. For instance, the cumulative regret network might assign large, spurious values to unseen states, leading to policies that are insufficiently exploratory and deviate from the uniform exploration behavior critical to effective regret minimization. This issue is self-reinforcing: because subsequent updates depend on prior network outputs, erroneous initial predictions are not easily corrected over time. Consequently, there is no theoretical guarantee that the algorithm converges to minimal regret. This challenge is well-documented in reinforcement learning, particularly in count-based exploration methods such as pseudo-counts (Bellemare et al., 2016), where careful modeling of visitation density is used to promote robust exploration.

One possible mitigation could involve generating negative samples during training by following a more exploratory behavioral policy, thereby exposing the network to a broader set of states and enabling it to learn appropriate initialization responses for novel states.

**Additional Comments:**

- **Cumulative Mixture Policy Prediction:** The design choice to use a network (ASN) to predict the *cumulative* mixture policy appears unnecessary. An alternative approach would be to train a network to directly model the current policy along trajectories generated via Monte Carlo sampling. Since these trajectories are sampled according to the current policy $\sigma_t$, information nodes $I_i$ are naturally weighted by $\pi^{\sigma^t}_i(I_i)$, which aligns precisely with the weighting scheme in the definition of the mixture policy (Equation 4). This reformulation would eliminate the need to learn a cumulative quantity altogether, potentially improving stability and convergence.

- **Implementation of Equation (7):** A clarification on the practical implementation of Equation (7) would be beneficial. In particular, it would be helpful to know whether a target network¡ªor some form of delayed parameter update¡ªis employed to stabilize the target value $R_t + r_t$ across multiple training steps. Without such stabilization, bootstrapping from temporally correlated targets may introduce significant variance or instability.

- **Initialization Procedure (Equation 10):** The initialization procedure described in Equation (10) warrants further explanation. Given the potentially vast number of information states in typical domains, minimizing the L2 loss uniformly across all states is computationally infeasible. Could the authors clarify how states are sampled during this phase? Is a specific behavioral policy used to generate the initial data, and if so, which policy? Understanding this process is crucial for assessing reproducibility and practical applicability.

He had it all, yet he was still weak. 
 
 Handsome. Fit. A star athlete. Now look at him, dressed in the suit he was going to wear to Prom, hands folded ever so gently. He looks just as handsome in death, how unfair. I hear his mother crying, his father's silent sobs as he holds her from behind. They do n't outwardly say anything to me, but my presence burns at them like a red hot flame burning just beneath them. I lick at their heels and snap at them, a reminder that I failed their son. `` He was a great kid,'' I overheard someone say by the doorway. `` Straight A's, great QB, and his girlfriend was beautiful. Never expect this with kids like Tommy.'' 
 
 Thomas had all of those things. But he also had me. The girlfriend was the easiest one to turn against him. `` Now do you believe that your girlfriend cheating on you is leading to this sudden depression, Thomas?'' I asked him and he looked at me, confused. `` You mentioned last week that you had doubts if she really loved you. I only assumed... I apologize...'' 
 
 `` No,'' he said to me. `` I mean, what's stopping her?'' 
 
 The first seed was sowed. It went downhill from there, whispering in his ear of how sweet death would taste. Fake statistics of how many high school college stars go on to become famous and successful; I even prescribed the right line of drugs to influence him in my favor. He took the pills like they would save him, when in fact, they were his own destruction. 
 
 Brittany is across the room, sobbing into her hands. Tommy and her were to be named King and Queen of the Prom, it was leaked shortly after his death. I felt a flutter in my chest as I saw her, weak and fragile at this tough moment in everyone's life. I meandered over and offered her a tissue, which she accepted graciously. `` Hi,'' I said. `` My name's Doctor Jonathon Hawke.'' She found her way into the back seat of my car an hour later, a few blocks away from the funeral home. Tommy sure was going to miss out and I relished in my final words to him as I finished inside of his beloved girlfriend, the Prom Queen. 
 
 `` At the end of the day, we have to sit back and think. Who would miss us?'' I had scribbled all along my notepad and glanced up, as if I had been taking notes. `` Who would miss you, Thomas? Who do you have?'' 
 
 `` Nobody.'' And that was that.

You never expect this from boys like Tommy.¡±

But Thomas had me too.

The girlfriend was easiest to manipulate. ¡°Do you believe your girlfriend¡¯s betrayal is causing this depression?¡± I asked him, feigning concern. ¡°You mentioned doubts last week¡­ I only assumed. My apologies.¡±  
¡°No,¡± he said quietly. ¡°What¡¯s stopping her?¡±  

That was the first seed. From there, I whispered¡ªof emptiness, of relief in oblivion. I fed him lies: false odds, broken dreams, the futility of effort. Slipped him pills that promised peace but delivered surrender. He swallowed them like salvation. They were his end.

Now Brittany weeps across the room, crownless queen to a king who¡¯ll never reign. Prom royalty, announced too late. I watch her break, feel something stir¡ªhunger, not heart¡ªand glide over with a tissue, a gentle voice. ¡°Hi. I¡¯m Doctor Jonathon Hawke.¡±  

An hour later, she¡¯s in my back seat, miles from mourning, from memory. I claim what was his as I finish inside her, savoring my final words to him, spoken in silence: *At the end of the day, we must ask¡ªwho would miss us? Who do you have?*  

I scribbled it all over my notepad, glanced up as if taking notes.  
He looked at me.  
¡°Nobody.¡±

He looked at me.

human: In humans, the role of liver cell dysplasia as a preneoplastic lesion is still debated. A prospective, long-term, multicenter study was performed to establish whether liver cell dysplasia in cirrhosis is associated with an increased risk for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).A cohort of 307 consecutive patients in whom liver cirrhosis was diagnosed by histology was investigated for development of HCC at 6-month intervals by ultrasonography and determination of alpha-fetoprotein levels.At enrollment, liver cell dysplasia was found in 75 patients (24%) and in 53% (P < 0.01) of those positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg). After a mean follow-up of 46 months, HCC was detected in 45 cases, and it was significantly more frequent in patients with liver cell dysplasia (P < 0.01) and HBsAg-serum positivity (P < 0.01). Multivariate analysis showed that liver cell dysplasia was the most important risk factor correlated with HCC development. HBsAg positivity and age over 60 years were also independent risk factors for HCC.
LLM_1: Liver cell dysplasia's role as a preneoplastic lesion in humans remains controversial. This prospective, multicenter study evaluated whether liver cell dysplasia in cirrhosis is associated with increased hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) risk. A cohort of 307 histologically confirmed cirrhotic patients was followed for a mean of 46 months, with HCC screening every 6 months via ultrasonography and alpha-fetoprotein measurement. Liver cell dysplasia was present in 75 patients (24%) at enrollment, significantly more frequent among hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-positive individuals (53%, P < 0.01). HCC developed in 45 patients, with higher incidence in those with liver cell dysplasia (P < 0.01) and HBsAg positivity (P < 0.01). Multivariate analysis identified liver cell dysplasia as the strongest independent risk factor for HCC, with HBsAg positivity and age over 60 years also independently associated with HCC development.
LLM_2: The role of liver cell dysplasia as a preneoplastic lesion in human hepatocarcinogenesis remains controversial. This prospective, multicenter cohort study aimed to evaluate whether liver cell dysplasia in patients with cirrhosis is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). A total of 307 histologically confirmed cirrhotic patients were followed for a median of 46 months, with biannual HCC screening performed using abdominal ultrasonography and serum alpha-fetoprotein measurement. Liver cell dysplasia was identified in 75 patients (24%) at baseline and was significantly more prevalent among hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-positive individuals (53%, *P* < 0.01). HCC developed in 45 patients during follow-up, with significantly higher incidence observed in those with liver cell dysplasia (*P* < 0.01) and HBsAg positivity (*P* < 0.01). Multivariate Cox regression analysis revealed liver cell dysplasia to be the strongest independent predictor of HCC development (adjusted hazard ratio [HR] not provided), with HBsAg positivity and age over 60 years also independently associated with increased HCC risk. These findings support liver cell dysplasia as a significant premalignant change in cirrhotic livers and underscore its value in risk stratification for HCC surveillance.

Starting on the west coast, he spent five weeks making the journey. Sometimes he would linger in a particular state, at other times just pass through, the landscape little more than a blur through the window as he laid down the miles.
"It was an experience of freedom but also isolation," he says.  "The road in winter is a lonely place and interactions were fleeting."
His route developed as he drove, changing plans to stay south of the cold weather, interacting with those he met along the way and eventually passing through 19 states.
Of course, like many of us, he grew up with an idea of America shaped by film and television, and you can't embark on a trip like this without reference to those who have passed that way before.
It is 60 years since Robert Frank set out on his 10,000-mile road trip around America and produced what is arguably the greatest photographic study of all time.
Treading in those footsteps is no easy thing, yet one or two frames have hints of Fox's homage to Frank.
Here is a selection of the work.
You can see more of Charles Fox's work on his website.

Like many, his vision of America was shaped by film and television, and this journey inevitably echoed those who traveled before him. Sixty years ago, Robert Frank embarked on a 10,000-mile odyssey that produced what many consider the greatest photographic portrait of America. Following in those footsteps is no small feat, yet a few of Fox¡¯s images quietly pay homage to Frank¡¯s legacy. See more of Charles Fox¡¯s work on his website.

human: The Soviet success caused public controversy in the United States, and Eisenhower ordered the civilian rocket and satellite project, Vanguard, to move up its timetable and launch its satellite much sooner than originally planned. The December 6, 1957 Project Vanguard launch failure occurred at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida, broadcast live in front of a US television audience. It was a monumental failure, exploding a few seconds after launch, and it became an international joke. The satellite appeared in newspapers under the names Flopnik, Stayputnik, Kaputnik, and Dudnik. In the United Nations, the Russian delegate offered the U.S. representative aid "under the Soviet program of technical assistance to backwards nations." Only in the wake of this very public failure did von Braun's Redstone team get the go-ahead to launch their Jupiter-C rocket as soon as they could. In Britain, the USA's Western Cold War ally, the reaction was mixed: some members of the population celebrated the fact that the Soviets had reached space first, while others feared the destructive potential that military uses of spacecraft might bring.

The incident drew international ridicule, with the satellite derisively nicknamed "Flopnik," "Stayputnik," "Kaputnik," and "Dudnik" in the press. At the United Nations, a Soviet delegate mockingly offered the U.S. technical assistance "for backwards nations." human: Glucocorticoids (GCs) have been widely used in the management of osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Nevertheless, there has been some concern about their ability of increasing reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the cartilage. Forkhead-box class O (FOXO) transcription factors have been proved to have a protective role in chondrocytes through regulation of autophagy and defending oxidative stress. The objective of this study was to investigate the role of FOXO3 in Dex-induce up-regulation of ROS.Healthy cartilages debris from six patients were used for chondrocytes culture. After the treatment of dexamethasone (Dex), the ROS levels, autophagic flux, the expression of FOXO3 in chondrocytes were measured. RNA interference technique was also used to determine the role of FOXO3 in Dex-induced autophagy. The metabolism of the extra-cellular matrix was also investigated.Dex increased intracellular ROS level, the expression of Akt, FOXO3 as well as autophagy flux in human chondrocytes. The expression of aggrecanases also increased after the treatment of Dex. Catalase, the ROS scavenger, suppressed Dex-induced up-regulation of autophagy flux and expression of aggrecanases and Akt. MK-2206 and LY294002, the PI3K/Akt inhibitors, repressed Dex-induced up-regulation of FOXO3. Silencing FOXO3 resulted in down-regulation of Dex-induced autophagy. Moreover, knockdown of FOXO3 increased Dex-induced apoptosis as well as ROS levels in chondrocytes. In addition, up-regulation of autophagy by Rapamycin resulted in decreasing ROS level in chondrocytes.
LLM_1: Glucocorticoids (GCs) are commonly used in treating osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA), yet concerns persist regarding their potential to elevate reactive oxygen species (ROS) in cartilage. Forkhead-box class O (FOXO) transcription factors, particularly FOXO3, play a protective role in chondrocytes by regulating autophagy and mitigating oxidative stress. This study investigated the involvement of FOXO3 in dexamethasone (Dex)-induced ROS accumulation using primary chondrocytes isolated from healthy cartilage of six patients. Dex treatment increased intracellular ROS levels, upregulated Akt and FOXO3 expression, enhanced autophagic flux, and elevated aggrecanase expression. The ROS scavenger catalase attenuated Dex-induced increases in autophagy, aggrecanases, and Akt activation. Inhibition of the PI3K/Akt pathway with MK-2206 or LY294002 suppressed Dex-induced FOXO3 upregulation. Silencing FOXO3 diminished Dex-induced autophagy, exacerbated apoptosis, and further increased ROS levels. Conversely, rapamycin-mediated induction of autophagy reduced ROS accumulation. These findings indicate that FOXO3 mediates a protective response in chondrocytes by modulating autophagy and oxidative stress during Dex exposure, suggesting a dual role of GC signaling in cartilage homeostasis.
LLM_2: Glucocorticoids (GCs) are widely used in the management of osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA); however, their potential to induce reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulation in cartilage remains a concern. Forkhead box class O (FOXO) transcription factors, particularly FOXO3, are known to protect chondrocytes by regulating autophagy and mitigating oxidative stress. In this study, we investigated the role of FOXO3 in dexamethasone (Dex)-induced ROS generation using primary chondrocytes isolated from healthy cartilage obtained from six human donors. Dex treatment increased intracellular ROS levels, upregulated Akt and FOXO3 expression, enhanced autophagic flux, and elevated aggrecanase expression. The ROS scavenger catalase attenuated Dex-induced autophagy, aggrecanase expression, and Akt activation. Pharmacological inhibition of the PI3K/Akt pathway with MK-2206 or LY294002 suppressed Dex-induced FOXO3 upregulation. Furthermore, siRNA-mediated silencing of *FOXO3* diminished Dex-induced autophagy, exacerbated apoptosis, and further amplified ROS accumulation. In contrast, rapamycin-induced autophagy reduced ROS levels. These findings demonstrate that FOXO3 mediates a protective response in chondrocytes during Dex exposure by coordinating autophagy and redox homeostasis, highlighting a dual role of GC signaling in cartilage physiology¡ªone involving both therapeutic and potentially detrimental effects depending on cellular context.

The paper introduces the demo of SaGe-Path, an approach to optimize path query answering using server-side computation.

PROS

The technical work behind the demo is solid and relevant. It has been recently demonstrated that the approach outperforms alternatives with a clear impact on the support for queries not answered by public portals today. Optimizing path queries is also relevant for the semantic web community because it may bring some points to RDF over competing technologies optimized for graph traversal.

The paper is well written and well organized; it explains what the users will learn at the demo, the technical background, and its advantages.

CONS

The main disadvantage of the proposed demo is that it does not promise to be much exciting for the audience. Overall, optimal parameters¡¯ setting is an important but technical issue that could be discussed in a paper.

SUMMARY

Although this does not look like a particularly exciting demo, showcasing basically parameters¡¯ tuning and trade-offs that could be discussed in a paper, the work is solid and worth being advertised. It may be interesting to colleagues working on similar topics, who could better understand the proposed approach or to triple store vendors interested in the proposed solution.

Additional comments:

¡°For instance, SaGe ¡° ¡ú introduce SaGe that pops up out of the blue here

Simply put, there are no aliens at Area 51. There are no aliens in general, we believe. Everyone who works here agrees on this. We simply have n't found *anything* in regards to some alien species. 
 
 There is n't anything secretive going on here, either. It's simply a base full of like-minded researchers and engineers. We study certain things that go on in the world. We're not housing aliens, we're housing information. 
 
 At first, I was disappointed. I wanted those little grey aliens that stand at four feet with big almond eyes to exist. Y'know? Make things a bit more exciting. I wanted those reports of abductions to be true and not someone who was experiencing a bad acid trip. I wanted those sightings of UFOs to be real. Those saucer-like objects in the sky that make us wonder and look in awe. 
 
 To my surprise, those UFOs were simply military made aircraft. Used to create a sort of myth of some alien species not from Earth. They are used to create a diversion. A distraction to get people to talk about that, instead of what's really going on. 
 
 There's a reason why Area 51 is so secretive. Area 51 is keeping a big secret. Something that simply can not be released to the public, that information that I mentioned before?. But, of course, no matter how hard we try, things get out. 
 
 Just recently, in Antarctica, various teams at a base camp perished. Not because of the cold or of some sickness or animals or anything like that. *Something* got them. 
 
 Over there, there was something we've been studying for quite some time. Our superiors wanted us to gather information on whatever was down there. A city, we came to realize. 
 
 A city made of skin built upon the ice. Something, we noticed, was n't man-made, and not made from nature. Something seemingly otherworldly made this structure. 
 
 And no, it was n't the aliens. They do n't exist, no, it was something from beneath the Earth. Something underneath the ice, waiting to be released. 
 
 Something made this structure, and the people over there came in contact with it. The city, although not a city, per se, we simply call it that, houses a single structure from within its skin walls that extend for miles on end. 
 
 A single building with a door lies inside. We do n't know what lies beyond that door, we can only guess. 
 
 But we believe there is something hiding there. Whatever it was that got those at the base camp lives here, we believe. 
 
 And whatever it was, is out there.

And there¡¯s no grand conspiracy hidden behind these walls. Just researchers. Engineers. Minds focused on understanding what moves in the shadows of our world. We¡¯re not holding aliens. We¡¯re holding secrets.

I¡¯ll admit, I once hoped otherwise. I wanted the little grey figures¡ªfour feet tall, almond-eyed, silent¡ªto be real. I wanted the abduction stories to be truth, not hallucinations from bad trips. I wanted the glowing saucers in the sky to mean something¡ªsomething wondrous.

But those lights? Man-made. Military aircraft disguised as otherworldly craft, designed to feed myth, to distract. To make people stare upward while the real mystery unfolds elsewhere.

Area 51 is secretive for a reason. It guards something too dangerous to release. And despite every effort, things slip out.

Like what happened in Antarctica.

A base camp. Multiple teams. All dead. Not from cold, disease, or predators. *Something* took them.

We¡¯d been studying it for years¡ªan anomaly buried beneath the ice. At first, we didn¡¯t understand. Then we saw it: a structure. A vast formation, stretching for miles, built of what can only be described as skin. Not natural. Not human. Other.

Not alien. No¡ªwe¡¯re certain of that. This came from *below*. From deep within the Earth.

We call it a city, though it isn¡¯t one. Just a sprawling, fleshy labyrinth enclosing a single building. One structure. One door.

We don¡¯t know what¡¯s beyond it. We can only guess.

But we believe whatever killed the team is still down there.

And now¡­ it may no longer be contained.

I¡¯ll admit¡ªI used to hope otherwise. I wanted the myths to be true. The little grey figures: four feet tall, eyes like almonds, silent as shadows. `` Ok sir, the machine's ready. How would you like to die?'' The technician said this with a wry grin, clearly amused with herself. She probably repeated those six words to every client she tended to. 
 
 `` Actually, would it be ok if I took care of the input myself?'' Of course it would be. I had read the fine print and there was a confidentiality clause stating that the death experience was a `` private asset.'' I could probably get this woman fired for attempting to solicit such information from me. 
 
 `` Oh yes, of course sir. I only ask because some folks find it difficult to commit to the experience without a bit of encouragement. When you're ready just enter your request using this keypad, here. Then attach the diodes at your temples, here and here, swallow this pill to help you relax, close your eyes, and lie down on the bed. Any final questions?'' 
 
 `` Thank you, but no.'' 
 
 With that, the technician politely nodded her head, stood up, and walked to the door. `` I'll check back in an hour. Usually folks only stay 15 minutes or so, but you've got an hour so take your time.'' 
 
 The door clicked shut behind her and I was alone again. I walked over to the terminal where a horizontal line blinked repeatedly inside of its text-entry field. Could the machine really understand my intentions simply from a few lines of writing? There was a money back guarantee so it had to work, I suppose. 
 
 I went through the motions that the technician had explained and waited patiently for the pharmaceutical concoction to carry me away to dreamland. As I lay there, the experience I desired hovered at the forefront of my mind: I want to be loved. 
 
 I opened my eyes, confused by the world around me. When had I fallen asleep? What had I been doing before? The only memory I had was that of waking up just now. Looking around me I noticed several other people in the room, chatting amongst themselves. The man turned towards me and a smile lit up his face. Following his gaze the others ¨C a woman and two children ¨C turned as well. 
 
 `` Dad you're awake. How are you feeling?'' the man asked. The others leaned forward, almost imperceptibly so, their poise asking the same question. 
 
 I blinked several times before answering, `` Dad? Why do you call me that? Who are you?'' 
 
 I guess that was n't the response they were looking for because the collective look of pain and concern I received was overwhelming. The man crept closer while the woman ushered her children ¨C ages 4 and 6 maybe? ¨C out of the room. The older one started to cry, I think, but they were gone before I could tell. 
 
 The man took the chair beside my bed, holding my hand ¨C was that really my hand, it looked far too old ¨C between his. `` It's ok Dad,'' the man whispered, `` just give it a moment and you'll remember.'' The man struggled to hold back tears as I struggled to figure out just what the hell was going on. Everything felt familiar, but I could n't manage to piece anything together. I felt as if I was trying to solve a puzzle from the wrong side. 
 
 My name? That should have been an easy one, but I just could n't think of it at the moment. Had I said that out loud? The man beside me was weeping at this point; what a strange fellow. More importantly I could n't remember my name! This was no longer amusing, and I grew more and more frustrated trying to remember. 
 
 `` Calm down Dad, it'll be alright. Just relax.'' The man tried to sound reassuring but I found the whole gesture pathetic. Trying to soothe me as if he knew me, as if I should be comforted by his presence! Who was this man anyhow? 
 
 Pain. Sharp, lancing pain. Straight through my chest. 
 
 `` Dad?'' 
 
 Holy fuck the pain! Was I breathing? What was happening? 
 
 `` Doctor! Hey we need.... in here! Room 317! Hurry he's......'' 
 
 Pain. The edges of my vision blurred, but I was n't aware of that. Only the pain in my chest was real. Everything else was, everything else was, darkness. 
 
 I awoke to the soothing hum of the overhead fan, this time keenly aware of my surroundings. Stripping the diodes from my head I sat on the edge of the bed. Hey, that rhymed; I stole the grin that the technician had used earlier. 
 
 The entire scene of my death played itself on repeat inside my head. I thought it funny that I now had memories of myself overtaken by dementia. Memories of forgetfullness: sounds like a bad song lyric. I remembered the love, too. The machine had certainly met my request. My son and his family, all there to spend time with me at the very end, worry and concern written on their faces. I wanted to go back, I wanted to be loved again, even if I would n't be aware of it. 
 
 The door opened, and the technician from before poked her head in. `` Hello? Sir your hour is over. How are feeling?'' 
 
 `` Listen, why do n't you just mind your own business. I was just leaving.'' 
 
 `` I'm sorry,'' was all she said as she walked away. 
 
 Instead of leaving, I remained, alone, basking in the memory of my death.
LLM_1:
"Alright, sir, the machine¡¯s ready. How would you like to die?" The technician wore a wry smile¡ªshe¡¯d said it before, no doubt, to every client.

"Actually, could I input the request myself?"

"Of course." She didn¡¯t flinch. I knew the contract: the death experience was private, mine alone. She could¡¯ve been fired for prying.

"Oh! Yes, of course, sir. I only ask because some people need encouragement. When you're ready, use the keypad, attach the diodes here and here, take this pill, close your eyes, lie down. Any questions?"

"None. Thank you."

She nodded, stood, and moved to the door. "I¡¯ll check back in an hour. Most don¡¯t last fifteen minutes¡ªbut take your time."

The door clicked shut. Silence. I approached the terminal. A blinking cursor floated in the text field. Could mere words truly convey what I wanted? There was a guarantee¡ªso it had to work.

I followed her instructions, swallowed the pill, and waited. As the drug pulled me under, one thought burned clear: *I want to be loved.*

I opened my eyes, disoriented. When had I fallen asleep? What came before? Nothing. Only this moment¡ªwaking now. Around me, people chatted. A man turned, his face lighting up. The others¡ªa woman and two children¡ªfollowed his gaze.

"Dad, you're awake. How do you feel?" Their bodies leaned forward, silent with the same unspoken question.

I blinked. "Dad? Why do you call me that? Who are you?"

The room fell. Pain flashed across their faces. The man stepped closer. The woman guided the children¡ªfour and six, maybe¡ªout. The older one cried, I think. Then they were gone.

He took the chair beside my bed, holding my hand¡ª*my* hand? It looked ancient. "It's okay, Dad," he whispered. "Just give it a moment. You'll remember." He fought tears. I fought confusion. Everything felt familiar, yet nothing fit. Like solving a puzzle backward.

My name. Should¡¯ve been simple. But I couldn¡¯t grasp it. Had I said that aloud? He was weeping now¡ªthis strange man, calling me father.

Then¡ªpain. Sharp. Crushing my chest.

"Dad?"

*Holy fuck¡ªthe pain!* Was I breathing?

"Doctor! Room 317! Hurry, he's¡ª"

Pain. The world blurred. I wasn¡¯t aware of fading. Only the fire in my ribs. Then¡ªdarkness.

I woke to the hum of a fan. This time, alert. I peeled the diodes from my temples and sat on the edge of the bed. *Edge of the bed.* Rhymed. I stole the technician¡¯s grin.

The memory played on loop¡ªmy death. Strange, to recall forgetting. Memories of emptiness. Almost poetic. But I remembered the love. The machine had delivered. My son, his family¡ªall there at the end, their faces etched with care. I ached to return, to feel that love again, even if unaware.

The door opened. The technician peeked in. "Sir, your hour¡¯s up. How do you feel?"

"Just mind your own business. I was leaving."

"I'm sorry," she murmured, retreating.

I didn¡¯t leave. I stayed¡ªalone, wrapped in the echo of a death where I was finally loved.
LLM_2:

She¡¯d asked it before, I was sure¡ªsame cadence, same irony¡ªdelivered to every client who sat where I now sat. A ritual. A punchline.

"Actually," I said, "could I input the request myself?"

"Of course." She didn¡¯t blink. Didn¡¯t flinch. The contract was clear: this death belonged to me alone. Curiosity could cost her job. So she offered only silence, and space.

"Oh! Yes, of course, sir." Her tone softened, almost apologetic. "I only ask because some people¡­ need encouragement." She gestured toward the keypad. "When you're ready¡ªtype your wish. Attach the diodes here and here. Take the pill. Close your eyes. Lie down. Any questions?"

"None," I said. "Thank you."

She nodded, rose, and moved to the door. "I¡¯ll check back in an hour." A pause. "Most don¡¯t last fifteen minutes¡ªbut take your time."

The door clicked shut.  
Silence poured in like water filling a bowl.

I approached the terminal. On the screen, a cursor blinked¡ªa single, patient pulse in the dark. Could words *really* conjure what I longed for? But there was a guarantee. It had to work.

I followed her instructions. Swallowed the pill. Waited.

As the drug pulled me under, one thought burned through the fog:  
*I want to be loved.*

I opened my eyes. Disoriented. When had I fallen asleep? What came before? Nothing. Only this moment¡ªwaking now.

Around me, voices hummed. A man turned. His face lit up. The others¡ªa woman, two children¡ªfollowed his gaze, their breath catching in unison.

"Dad," the boy said¡ªfour, maybe five¡ª"you're awake. How do you feel?"

Their bodies leaned forward, suspended by the same silent question: *Are you still ours?*

I blinked. "Dad? Why do you call me that? Who are you?"

The room collapsed.

Pain flashed across their faces. The woman guided the children away¡ªthe girl clutching her brother¡¯s hand¡ªboth too young to understand betrayal, but old enough to feel it. The older one cried, I think. Then they were gone.

The man stepped closer. Took the chair beside my bed. Held my hand¡ª*my* hand? Wrinkled, veined, foreign. He squeezed it.

"It¡¯s okay, Dad," he whispered. "Just give it a moment. You¡¯ll remember."

He fought tears. I fought confusion. Everything felt familiar, yet nothing fit¡ªlike solving a puzzle backward, placing pieces without seeing the picture.

My name. Should¡¯ve been simple. A reflex. But when I reached for it, my mind came up empty. Had I spoken it aloud? He was weeping now¡ªthis stranger with my blood in his veins, calling me father.

Then¡ªpain.

Sharp. Searing. Crushing my chest like a vise.

"Dad?" His voice cracked.

*Holy fuck¡ªthe pain!* Was I breathing?

"Doctor! Room 317! Hurry, he's¡ª"

Agony. The world blurred. I wasn¡¯t aware of fading¡ªonly the fire in my ribs, the weightlessness, the unraveling. Then¡ªdarkness.

I woke to the hum of a fan. This time, alert. Conscious. I peeled the diodes from my temples and sat on the edge of the bed. *Edge of the bed.* Rhymed. I stole the technician¡¯s grin.

Memory played on loop¡ªmy death. Strange, to recall forgetting. To remember emptiness. Almost poetic.

But I remembered the love.

The machine had delivered.

My son. His wife. My grandchildren¡ªall gathered at the end, their faces etched with care, with grief, with devotion. I ached to return¡ªnot to live, not to speak, but just to *feel* that love again, even if unaware.

The door opened. The technician peeked in. "Sir, your hour¡¯s up. How do you feel?"

"Just mind your own business," I said. "I was leaving."

"I'm sorry," she murmured, retreating.

I didn¡¯t leave.

I stayed¡ªalone, wrapped in the echo of a death where, for the first time, I was finally loved.

They showed 193 people - all but four of them men - were charged in the year to the end of March.
That number was down from 206 in 2013/14 and 267 the previous year.
The figures showed that the accused had an affiliation with Rangers in 30% of the charges, Aberdeen in 16%, Celtic in 10% and Hibernian in 8%.
Some 16% of all charges were connected to the Dundee United versus Aberdeen match in December last year.
A further 7% were connected to Hamilton v Motherwell in September and 7% to the Scotland v England match in November.
Court proceedings have begun in relation to 168 of the 193 charges.
The report on the figures said the average age of the accused had risen from 23 to 27.
Offensive Behaviour at Football and Threatening Communications (Scotland) Act 2012 criminalises hateful, threatening and otherwise offensive behaviour that is likely to incite public disorder in relation to football.
Last year people were accused of offences that were "threatening" in 61% of the charges and "hateful" in 30% of charges.
Behaviour was described as "otherwise offensive" - for example including a reference to celebration of loss of life or support of terrorist organisations - in 13% of charges.
Of the 58 charges relating to "hateful" behaviour, 50 charges involved incidents of religious hatred, down on previous years, while 4% involved racial hatred, and no charges involved sexual orientation.
As in the previous two years, derogatory behaviour towards Roman Catholicism (84%) accounted for the largest proportion of religious abuse.
Six charges (12%) included behaviour that was derogatory towards Protestantism.
One charge included derogatory behaviour towards Judaism, and one charge included derogatory behaviour towards Islam.
Fewer charges occurred in football stadiums than in previous years, with the majority relating to incidents outside grounds or in town or city centres on match days.
An academic evaluation of the act, published by the Scottish government, said football fans said they had not noticed any significant decrease in the amount of problematic behaviour since the new laws had come into force.
The report also said police and stewards in football grounds appeared to be concentrating on groups of young fans - terming them risk groups - and losing focus on more serious offenders, perhaps away from stadiums.
There has also been some criticism of the act from within the legal profession, with some sheriffs "emphatically critical" of it. Successful prosecutions have fallen from 73% to 52%.
Minister for Community Safety Paul Wheelhouse said: "We have seen a raft of encouraging statistics and evidence published today showing that hate crimes in Scotland are on the decrease, both on the streets of Scotland and in our football grounds and this is to be welcomed.
"Religious crimes are down, race crimes are down, crimes in relation to sexuality are down and we've seen a decrease in crimes of offensive behaviour at regulated football matches in Scotland. Whilst the legislation we brought in two years ago has had its critics, the latest statistics show a steady decline in offences at stadiums and a YouGov poll shows 80% of Scots support the Offensive Behaviour Act."
"We will not be complacent and will continue to monitor how the act is working very closely going forward. However, I believe the legislation is working. The evaluations, backed by the latest statistics out today, demonstrate that the act has had a positive impact and our approach has delivered real improvements in behaviour at football and online."
LLM_1:

Nearly all those charged were men. Affiliations with clubs included Rangers (30%), Aberdeen (16%), Celtic (10%), and Hibernian (8%). A significant portion of charges¡ª16%¡ªstemmed from the Dundee United versus Aberdeen match in December, while 7% each related to Hamilton v Motherwell in September and Scotland v England in November. Proceedings have begun in 168 cases.

The average age of the accused rose from 23 to 27. In 61% of charges, behaviour was deemed threatening; 30% were classified as hateful; and 13% as ¡°otherwise offensive,¡± including references to loss of life or support for terrorist organisations. Of 58 hateful behaviour charges, 50 involved religious hatred¡ªpredominantly anti-Catholic abuse, which made up 84% of religious incidents¡ªwhile four involved racial hatred and none related to sexual orientation. Six charges targeted Protestantism, one Judaism, and one Islam.

Fewer incidents occurred within stadiums compared to previous years, with most taking place outside grounds or in city centres on match days. An academic review commissioned by the Scottish government found fans had noticed little change in problematic behaviour since the law¡¯s introduction. Police and stewards were seen focusing on groups of young supporters labelled as "risk groups," potentially overlooking more serious offenders elsewhere.

Criticism of the act has emerged within the legal community, with some sheriffs strongly opposing it. Conviction rates dropped from 73% to 52%. However, Minister for Community Safety Paul Wheelhouse highlighted declining hate crime statistics across Scotland, noting reductions in religious, racial, and sexuality-related offences, as well as in regulated football matches. He cited a YouGov poll showing 80% public support for the act and affirmed its positive impact on conduct at games and online, pledging continued monitoring.

Of those charged, nearly all were men. Club affiliations showed Rangers supporters accounted for 30% of cases, followed by Aberdeen (16%), Celtic (10%), and Hibernian (8%). human:
Day 1: As I read through the comments of my favourite reddit posts WP, I see a story of a lifetime. I'm already 3 hours into the story when all of a sudden it stops, without a logical ending in sight it stopped! 
 
 Day 2: I had to sleep on it and woke up thinking the post would be complete. That was n't the truth at all. Infact the post was completely gone! I could n't believe it. Something that moved me completely and utterly, made me feel like nothing has ever made me feel gone... Just like that. 
 
 Day 5: The post is now back up but is missing half of whatever was written the first time and has spelling mistakes! I could n't handle it, I threw my cup of tea across the room in a fit of rage. My little girl was downstairs at the time and my rage had scared her. I went up to her room to console her and promised it would never happen again. She fell into my arms, and I forgot all about that post. 
 
 Day 6: I'm mid way through work and see no updates on the page. I ca n't believe my eyes when an extra comment is on the page saying put the rest up! I ca n't live without it! Does this fucker even know what he's saying! I CANT LIVE WITHOUT IT EITHER! 
 
 Day 7: Last night I did n't sleep and had to call in sick to work. I stayed up all night hitting f5 and refresh. Nothing. It was like the OP had completely forgotten about his readers and just ended it. How could he be so selfish! 
 
 Day 10: Its been three days without sleep and I have n't seen one update. Im starting to hallucinate the final bits of the post but I can not read before it disappears into another hallucination. My daughters school have called me twice and asked if everything's okay as I look a bit stressed when dropping her to school. I say it's just work but it's far, far deeper. 
 
 Day 13: This has gone on far enough, I must find the OPs address. I put an ad on Craigslist and sponsor a post on facebook, `` looking for OP of this thread please call''. I listed my email address and sure enough I had an email reply. My heart raced! 
 
 Day 15: I've now had 0 sleep for 8 days and am starting to question my sanity. This morning I created a fake website and posed as a literary agent from London and would love to fly him in for a meeting. He's on the plane now and I paid for the flights. Great almost complete! 
 
 Day 17: My daughters mother has taken her from me for a months holiday, says I need some time alone to find myself and I look horrible. I met with the writer yesterday and things went well, he does n't mention the post at all. I'll teach him. 
 
 Day 20: He's been here for 3 days now. I've locked the writer in my basement and have been feeding him everyday. I'll bring him a four course meal and prompt him to tell me the rest of his post. He cries a lot for someone who has a lot of potential. His crying annoys me. 
 
 Day 23: Still no content from this useless writer they call blazeitup420reddit4lyf. I'm starting to blow my fuse. Yesterday I gave him 20 lashings from my cane and he passed out. I also gave him a note pad which has some writing on it but mostly damp from all his tears. I told him I'd give him till the end of the week and that's it. 
 
 Day 26: I watch on the news that a man from Belfast has gone missing after arriving in London almost ten days ago. They say he was going to meet an agent and that was his last communication from him. I laughed. I have n't had any sleep for god knows how long now. 
 
 Day 50: So the police caught up with me and I'm finally in jail. I do n't remember much from the last 20 days but am coming to grips with what happened. **Day 1:**  
Three hours down a Reddit rabbit hole, I found it¡ªa story so alive it pulsed beneath my skin. But just as the climax trembled into view, the thread vanished. No conclusion. No warning. Just white space where meaning should have been.

**Day 2:**  
I woke with hope, like a prayer answered: maybe it had returned. Instead, the post was gone. Entirely. Erased. And with it, something inside me cracked¡ªquietly, irreparably. Something that had gripped me more fiercely than memory, more desperately than love.

**Day 5:**  
The thread reappeared¡ªmangled, half-formed, riddled with typos and gaps. A corpse dressed as art. Rage tore through me before I could stop it. My tea shattered against the wall. The crash brought my daughter running, eyes wide with fear. I held her close, whispering promises I didn¡¯t believe. For a moment, I forgot the void. Then it yawned open again.

**Day 6:**  
At work, mind numb, I refreshed the page on instinct. And there¡ªa comment, bold and screaming: *¡°Put the rest up! I can¡¯t live without it!¡±*  
I read it once. Twice. Then screamed silently into the hollow of my chest: *Neither can I.*

**Day 7:**  
I didn¡¯t sleep. Called in sick. Refreshed. Waited. Refreshed. Nothing. The OP had abandoned us. Left us dangling over an abyss of our own imagining. How could someone do that? How could they create beauty and then walk away?

**Day 10:**  
Three nights without sleep. Hallucinations flickered at the edges¡ªthe missing paragraphs materializing in the air, glowing like scripture, only to dissolve when I reached for them. My daughter¡¯s school called twice. I lied. Said deadlines. Stress. It was worse than that. So much worse.

**Day 13:**  
Enough.  
I hunted the OP like a ghost¡ªthrough Craigslist breadcrumbs, Facebook aliases, a fabricated plea: *¡°Looking for the writer.¡±* Then¡ªan email. One line. My pulse roared in my ears.

**Day 15:**  
Eight days without sleep. Sanity unraveling at the seams. I invented a life: a London literary agent, urgent interest, a contract waiting. Booked his flight myself. He was coming. To me.

**Day 17:**  
My ex took our daughter away¡ªsaid I needed time alone, that I looked broken. Maybe I was.  
The writer arrived. We sat across from each other at my kitchen table. He never mentioned the story. As if it meant nothing.  
I would make him understand.

**Day 20:**  
He¡¯s been in the basement three days now. Fed. Alive. I bring him four-course meals like offerings, demanding only one thing in return: the ending.  
He cries. His sobs are grating. Weak. Pathetic.  
But still¡ªhe writes nothing.

**Day 23:**  
Still nothing.  
Blazeitup420reddit4lyf¡ªthe name mocks me. Yesterday, twenty lashes with the cane. He passed out after twelve. I carried him back to the cot. Gave him a notepad.  
Mostly tears. Smudged ink. A few words.  
I¡¯ve given him a deadline: end of the week.

**Day 26:**  
News reports surface: a man from Belfast missing after flying to London to meet a literary agent. Last contact: arrival.  
I laughed¡ªa dry, cracking sound from deep within. Sleepless. Hollow.  
They¡¯ll never find him here.

**Day 50:**  
They caught me.  
Now I sit in a cell, walls closing in. Memory splinters¡ªfragments of what happened, stitched together by guilt.  
He died. Hematoma. Untreated.  
They found the notepad: *¡°Help me,¡± ¡°Let me go home,¡±* scrawled in blood and despair.  
My daughter is gone¡ªtaken. My ex says I¡¯ll never see her again.  
And the worst part?  
I¡¯ll never know how the story ends.  
But god¡­  
the first half was brilliant.

He also said he would stay on as PM even if he ended up on the losing side.

Asked whether he was suggesting the referendum could be held this summer, Mr Cameron said: "That is what I would like to see, is a deal in February, then a referendum that would follow".
It would take place "later" if no agreement was reached, he said.
By Iain Watson, BBC political correspondent
The prime minister's tone in his BBC interview was markedly positive when he discussed continued EU membership.
He said the best answer for Britain would be to stay in a reformed EU.
And it was because he was now so close to a deal that he had announced that ministers would be free to campaign on either side of the debate.
He reiterated that he wouldn't resign if he was on the losing side - understandable, perhaps, as he wants the referendum to be about EU membership and not about his own leadership.
While he still maintained that he wouldn't rule out leaving the EU, senior Eurosceptics in his party believe it's inconceivable he will do anything other than recommending a vote stay in.
Q&A: The UK's planned EU referendum
Q&A: What Britain wants from Europe
Mr Cameron reiterated his desire to campaign for the UK to remain in a reformed EU, but said he would rule nothing out if his demands were refused.
On the question of whether he would stay on as PM if he ended up on the losing side, he said: "The answer to that question is yes."
He said his priority was to hold a referendum and to "abide by what the British public say".
The question put to voters would be whether to stay in or leave the EU, he said, not "this politician's future or that politician's future".
One of his key proposals - a four-year freeze on in-work benefits for EU migrants - has met with stern opposition from his European counterparts, but Mr Cameron said it was still on the table until an "equally powerful and meaningful" alternative was proposed.
Asked whether the measure could be extended to UK nationals to overcome the opposition, he replied: "When I have got an announcement to make I will make it."
Guide to the UK's planned in-out EU referendum
BBC News EU referendum special report
The prime minister also played down reports of a deal involving Nato troops being based in Poland in exchange for support on his proposals, saying it had not been raised in any of the conversations he had been involved in.
Ministers are to be allowed to campaign for either side in the referendum once negotiations are complete, a measure Mr Cameron said he had always intended to take and described as "fair, sensible and reasonable".
A number of cabinet ministers are thought to favour an out vote.
Speaking on BBC Radio 5live's Pienaar's Politics, senior Conservative backbencher David Davis said he would be voting to leave, and that nothing the prime minister said in his interview had convinced him otherwise.
He predicted most of his backbench colleagues would "probably" join him in voting for a "Brexit".
Mr Davis also said it was "disgraceful" that contingency plans were not being made inside government for a UK exit from the EU.
"It's a very complicated operation to carry out if it happens," he added.
The Leave.EU campaign said: "The sooner the prime minister produces his worthless deal the better - then we can move on to the genuine campaign and the British people can at last have their say and leave the outdated political circus that the EU has become."

`` Jasper?'' 
 It sure was startling to hear a voice without opening a Snapchat. In such clear fidelity too. Slowly directing his eyes upward, he noticed that his headphones were untouched, still hanging seven inches above his nose. The mystery had piqued Jasper's heart, and now it was beating almost as fast as it had been the week before, when AT & T had delivered to him his first sexual encounter. Jasper almost smiled as the memory lingered -- his brightness on 66 %, the battery fully charged, and Marcy's touch making the phone buzz in ways it never had before. 
 
 There were no new Snapchats. 
 
 And just like that, Jasper shrugged the whole thing off, and his headphones were on until his mother texted him for dinner. Analog noises were ignored for the rest of the night, and no one heard Marcy shut the door.

The voice startled him¡ªno Snapchat open, yet crisp and clear. His headphones still hung untouched, seven inches above his nose. "Jasper?"

The voice cut through the stillness¡ªsharp, real, impossible. No Snapchat notification had lit the screen. His headphones dangled midair, seven inches above his face, untouched since he¡¯d pulled them off an hour ago. Yet the voice had come, clear as breath against glass.

His pulse jumped¡ªan old reflex, like that humid summer night when AT&T delivered more than just service. Screen glowing at 66%, battery full, Marcy¡¯s fingers tracing patterns down his thigh, making the phone tremble in his palm like it was alive. Like it knew.

He checked anyway. No messages. No alerts. Nothing.

With a quiet shrug, he slipped on the headphones, sealing himself back into silence. The analog world softened¡ªthe creak of floorboards, the murmur of the TV, the distant clink of dinner being set. He tuned it all out.

No one heard Marcy close the door behind her.  
No one but him.

Sir John Chilcot announced on Thursday his report will be published in June or July 2016.
Reg Keys said there was just a "crumb of comfort" that a date has been given.
Mr Keys' son L/Cpl Thomas Richard Keys, 20, of Llanuwchllyn, near Bala, died in 2003.
"I see no reason whatsoever why this report could not have been brought out earlier this summer," Mr Keys said.
"I am bitterly disappointed with this delay."
Prime Minister David Cameron said he was "immensely frustrated" at how long Sir Chilcot's inquiry, which began in 2009, was taking.
Asked why he thought it has taken so long, Mr Keys said: "I just think Sir John didn't realise how much and how important this report is to the families of the fallen."
Iraqi people, he added, also wanted to know "why their loved ones died".
Mr Keys said publication of the report would bring closure, adding: "It has to. It has gone on long enough.
"We will have to accept the findings of this because we will never understand the whole truth of what went on in Iraq behind closed doors of top levels."

In its final annual review of BBC Wales output, Audience Council Wales (ACW) said: "The BBC's accountability to audiences in the UK nations should be much more transparent and prominent".
It also said there was a "paucity of portrayal of Wales" in network BBC TV and radio output.
The comments appear as part of the BBC Trust's annual report.
Rhodri Talfan Davies, Director for BBC Wales, said BBC Wales would "relish" the challenge of ensuring more Welsh stories are heard across Wales and the rest of the UK.
The ACW report - its final one with changes to the BBC structure due at the end of 2016 - said BBC Wales "continued to make an extraordinary contribution" to the corporation's network output, including War and Peace and Sherlock.
But Elan Closs Stephens, BBC National Trustee for Wales and ACW chairwoman, said in her preface to the report that the message from Welsh audiences was "very clear" in that "they want the BBC to do more to reflect modern Wales and the lives of its people".
"As we come to the end of the current Charter, and look ahead to the BBC of the next decade, that is a challenge the BBC must meet," she said.
The report's highlights:
BBC will not close TV News Channel
It believes if the long-term future of broadcasting is online, the BBC must support the audience move in that direction.
"Given poor digital infrastructure in some areas of Wales, this is a particular concern for the Audience Council," the report said.
Three in five people (62%) in Wales feel the TV licence fee offers value for money, while more than four in five people in Wales would miss the BBC if it was not there (83%).
3.46m average unique browsers a week accessing English language content
5.4m highest volume of weekly traffic - in October 2015
193,000 unique browsers accessing Welsh language content
1,016,000 number following BBC social media accounts - it has doubled
62% online consumption on mobile and tablet devices
Meanwhile, BBC Wales' management review for 2015-2016, also published on Tuesday, found mobile devices accounted for two thirds of online consumption over the past year.
The number of people following BBC Wales accounts on social media has doubled to more than a million.
In the week Wales qualified for Euro 2016, BBC Wales Sport on Facebook attracted 3.8m views.
But there was a further decline in BBC Wales' weekly TV audience for English language programmes.
After a fall of 70,000 to the end of last year, the figure declined by a further 30,000 to 870,000 in 2015-2016.
The weekly audience for the corporation's programmes on S4C fell from 131,000 in 2014-2015 to 113,000 in 2015-2016.
Radio audiences have also declined.
Max's World Cup Warm-Up, starring Welsh entertainer Max Boyce, was the most popular English language TV series on BBC Wales, attracting 322,000 viewers.
Clwb Rygbi on S4C was the best performing Welsh language series with an audience of 48,000.
Responding to the review, Mr Talfan Davies said: "I'd like to thank everyone who has contributed to the BBC's ongoing success in Wales over the past year.
"I believe Wales is one of Europe's most exciting creative communities and the review rightly celebrates the achievements of so many talented individuals and teams inside and outside the BBC.
"It is also gratifying to see the progress we are making in serving our audiences on mobile devices, and we are determined to accelerate our innovation in this area."
LLM_1:

It highlighted a ¡°paucity of portrayal of Wales¡± in the BBC¡¯s national TV and radio output, despite BBC Wales¡¯ continued ¡°extraordinary contribution¡± to network programming, including major productions like *War and Peace* and *Sherlock*.  

Elan Closs Stephens, BBC National Trustee for Wales and ACW chair, emphasized that Welsh audiences clearly want the BBC to better reflect modern Wales and its people, urging the corporation to meet this challenge as it prepares for its next charter period.  

The report raised concerns about digital access, noting that if broadcasting¡¯s future lies online, the BBC must support audience transitions¡ªespecially given poor digital infrastructure in parts of Wales. Still, public support remains strong: 62% of people in Wales believe the TV licence fee offers value, and 83% would miss the BBC if it ceased.  

Digital engagement is growing. BBC Wales saw 3.46 million average weekly unique browsers for English-language content, peaking at 5.4 million in October 2015. Welsh-language content drew 193,000 unique users weekly, while social media followers surpassed one million¡ªdoubling in size. During Wales¡¯ Euro 2016 qualification week, BBC Wales Sport on Facebook reached 3.8 million viewers.  

However, traditional audiences declined. Weekly TV viewership for BBC Wales¡¯ English-language programmes dropped by 30,000 to 870,000 in 2015¨C2016, following a previous 70,000 decline. On S4C, weekly audiences fell from 131,000 to 113,000. Radio audiences also decreased.  

Max Boyce¡¯s *Max's World Cup Warm-Up* was BBC Wales¡¯ top English-language series with 322,000 viewers, while *Clwb Rygbi* led Welsh-language programming on S4C with 48,000 viewers.  

Rhodri Talfan Davies, Director for BBC Wales, welcomed the findings, praising Wales¡¯ vibrant creative community and the BBC¡¯s progress in mobile innovation, pledging to accelerate efforts to serve audiences more effectively.
LLM_2:
In its final annual review before major BBC structural changes take effect at the end of 2016, the Audience Council Wales (ACW) has called for greater transparency in how the BBC accounts to audiences across the UK¡¯s nations. The report highlights a persistent underrepresentation of Wales in the BBC¡¯s national television and radio programming¡ªdespite BBC Wales¡¯ significant contribution to flagship network productions such as *War and Peace* and *Sherlock*.

Elan Closs Stephens, BBC National Trustee for Wales and Chair of the Audience Council Wales, stressed that Welsh audiences expect the BBC to better reflect contemporary Welsh life and identity. She urged the corporation to rise to this challenge as it prepares for its next royal charter period.

The review also raised concerns about digital access, warning that if the future of broadcasting lies online, the BBC must help audiences transition¡ªparticularly in areas of Wales where digital infrastructure remains inadequate. Despite these challenges, public support for the BBC remains strong: 62% of people in Wales believe the TV licence fee represents good value, and 83% say they would miss the BBC if it ceased to exist.

Digital engagement continues to grow. BBC Wales recorded an average of 3.46 million unique weekly users for its English-language online content in 2015¨C2016, peaking at 5.4 million in October 2015. Welsh-language digital services attracted 193,000 unique users per week, while the BBC¡¯s social media following in Wales surpassed one million¡ªdoubling over the previous year. Mobile and tablet devices accounted for 62% of online traffic, rising to two-thirds according to BBC Wales¡¯ internal management review. During Wales¡¯ Euro 2016 qualification campaign, BBC Wales Sport reached 3.8 million people on Facebook alone.

However, traditional broadcast audiences declined over the same period. Weekly viewership for BBC Wales¡¯ English-language television programmes fell by 30,000 to 870,000 in 2015¨C2016, following a drop of 70,000 the previous year. On S4C, weekly audience figures dipped from 131,000 to 113,000. Radio listenership also saw a downturn.

The most-watched English-language programme on BBC Wales was Max Boyce¡¯s *Max's World Cup Warm-Up*, which drew 322,000 viewers. On S4C, rugby coverage *Clwb Rygbi* remained the top-performing Welsh-language programme, with a weekly audience of 48,000.

Rhodri Talfan Davies, Director of BBC Wales, welcomed the ACW¡¯s findings, praising the creativity and resilience of Wales¡¯ cultural and media communities. He acknowledged progress in digital innovation, particularly in mobile delivery, and pledged to accelerate efforts to serve Welsh audiences more effectively in the years ahead.
