human:
The most creative deaths were the biggest draws for our town. The people who really took suicide to the next level. The folks who used props, devised schemes, and even utilized living people in their death plans. They were the reason our tiny town suddenly had a spot on the map. They had made us famous for disturbing and gruesome deaths. 
 
 About a year ago, our small town legalized suicide. Suicide, a sad and lonely way to die, became... popular. The more creative you were, the more legendary you became. Janelle, she was the initial `` shock-death'' as we called them. Janelle loved her cat more than life itself, and when her cat passed, she could n't bare to live without her. She cut off the cat's tail and attempted to swallow it. The fur and the length, well, you can imagine what happened. The news and the media loved it. `` A True Tail of Terror! ``, `` No Nine-Feline Lives for Local Woman'' headlines read. It was disgusting they way they made her famous for her death. 
 
 Then there was Ben. Ben the basketball coach at the local high school who seemed like a normal enough guy. Lived at home with his parents at the age of 30, had n't had a girlfriend in years, but no one knew the evil inside him. Ben upped the ante by planning how people would find him, dead. He knew his basketball team would arrive at 2:45pm in the locker room to change for practice. He knew they would all open their lockers at some point. He cut off his fingers and toes and planted them all over the locker room like a sick scavenger hunt. A finger here, a toe there... the young boys eventually opened their lockers to discover bits and pieces of their coach inside. They ran to his office and discovered he was n't there. They flooded onto the basketball court, and there he was... still swinging from the basketball hoop. Finger-less, toe-less, tied up by the laces from his Jordan's. No one was really sure how he managed to get himself up there, or how he tied the knots on the noose for that matter, but there he was. Ben was all about shock value, and he quickly became the next `` shock-death''. 
 
 The deaths spread like wildfire; `` woman kills herself by swallowing 200 needles'', `` Man slashes open own stomach and let birds eat intestines''. The worst part, these deaths became tourist attractions. People were paying good money to see where these deaths had occurred, and to hear people speak about them. Townspeople who knew `` Cat-tail Janelle'' or `` Basketball Ben'' were treated like local celebrities. I ca n't say I was n't intrigued by some of the odd ways people choose to die, but I sure as hell was n't going to pay money to see it or hear people speak about it. Those people in my mind were absolutely pathetic. 
 
 Unfortunately for me, I'm a 20 year old kid without a summer job, so here I am, giving the damn tours that I think are despicable and hate so much. Another day, another dollar as the saying goes though, right? 
 
 I'm finally at the end of my day, almost one year after suicide became `` legal''. I always like to end my tours at Cat-Tail Janelle's house. The tour company bought her house after she passed because she was the original shock-death and thus the most famous. I start to tell her story and some facts about her not-so-interesting life, when I realize it's time. Before I can think twice I grab the police sized can of pepper-spray Janelle had laying around the house. I spray the entire tour, 18 people falling to their knees screaming and crying, pawing at their eyes. 
 
 I know there is no need to move quickly as the spray will likely last about an hour or so. I do n't intend to hurt these people, I just want to shock them... Give the people what they want! About 45 minutes or so later, after the crying has subsided and everyone is starting to regain their vision, I ask them to look up at me as I stand there, holding a gun. 
 
 I chastise them for their behavior and sick obsessions over how people kill themselves. I berate them for their lack of tact and wanting to see gruesome things. Once more I ask them to look at me. I turn around, my back to their faces, and pull the trigger. 
 
 Straight through my brain the bullet flies without hesitation, exploding my skull and brains everywhere. All over their faces, their hands, along Janelle's wall. I think I may have heard a scream as a chunk of my brain landed near a woman on the floor. `` This is what they wanted!'' I remember thinking. The crowd finally received their own version of a `` shock death'', my death. And God, those people are pathetic.
LLM_1:
Our town became infamous not for its charm or history, but for the artistry of suicide. Death, once a quiet tragedy, turned into spectacle¡ªelaborate, grotesque, and celebrated. The more inventive the method, the greater the fame. Props, planning, even accomplices¡ªthese weren¡¯t mere suicides; they were performances.

A year ago, we legalized it. What began as sorrow morphed into competition. Creativity became currency in death.

Janelle was first¡ªthe original ¡°shock-death.¡± She adored her cat beyond reason. When it died, she couldn¡¯t bear the silence of living without it. So she cut off its tail and tried to swallow it whole. The fur, the length¡ªit choked her, slowly and horribly. The media feasted: *¡°A True Tail of Terror!¡±* *¡°No Nine-Feline Lives for Local Woman.¡±* They turned grief into punchlines.

Then came Ben, the high school basketball coach. Thirty, living with his parents, unremarkable¡ªuntil he wasn¡¯t. He knew his team would arrive at 2:45 p.m., that lockers would open. So he severed his fingers and toes, planted them like gruesome Easter eggs across the room. A toe here, a finger there. When the boys found their coach hanging from the hoop¡ªbarely recognizable, laced up by his own Jordans¡ªthey¡¯d already seen pieces of him scattered in their belongings. No one knew how he tied the noose, limbless and alone. But he did. And we remembered.

After that, madness spread. A woman swallowed two hundred needles. A man slit his stomach open and let birds devour his insides. Each death more shocking than the last¡ªand each one turning our town into a macabre tourist trap. People paid to stand where the dead had fallen, to hear stories from those who¡¯d known them. Locals became celebrities just for proximity.

I hated it. I called the tourists pathetic¡ªfeeding on pain like vultures. Yet here I was, twenty years old, jobless, leading the very tours I despised.

On the anniversary of legalization, I ended my shift where it all began¡ªat Janelle¡¯s house. The company owned it now, preserved it like a shrine. I recited her story, the dull facts of a life overshadowed by its end¡ªthen stopped.

I grabbed the can of pepper spray left behind in her home and doused the crowd. Eighteen people collapsed, writhing, blinded, screaming. I didn¡¯t run. They¡¯d be helpless for nearly an hour.

Forty-five minutes passed. Their sobs faded. Vision returned. I told them to look at me.

They did.

I condemned them¡ªcalled them out for their obsession, their lack of decency, their hunger for horror. Then I asked again: *Look at me.*

I turned my back and fired.

The bullet tore through my skull, spraying brain matter across their faces, their hands, the walls. A chunk landed near a woman on the floor¡ªmaybe I heard her scream.

*This is what you wanted,* I thought.

At last, they got their shock-death.

And God, they were pathetic.
LLM_2:
Our town didn¡¯t earn its fame through charm or history.  
No. We became infamous for the *art* of suicide.

Death, once a private sorrow, had been reimagined¡ªrefined into spectacle. Elaborate. Grotesque. Celebrated.  
The more inventive the method, the greater the renown. Props. Choreography. Accomplices. These weren¡¯t mere suicides¡ªthey were performances. And we, the audience, leaned in closer with every act.

A year ago, we made it legal.  
Grief curdled into competition. Creativity became currency. In death, we found our economy¡ªand our identity.

Janelle was first. The original ¡°shock-death.¡±  
She loved her cat like a prayer¡ªfierce, silent, absolute. When it died, the silence that followed was unbearable. So she cut off its tail and tried to swallow it whole.  
The fur caught in her throat. The length choked her, inch by inch, breath by suffocating breath.  
She died slowly. Horribly.  
And the world laughed:  
*¡°A True Tail of Terror!¡±*  
*¡°No Nine-Feline Lives for Local Woman.¡±*  
They turned mourning into punchlines. Grief into gossip.  
We let them.

Then came Ben¡ªthe high school basketball coach. Thirty years old. Lived with his parents. Unremarkable in life.  
Until he wasn¡¯t.  

He knew the team would arrive at 2:45 p.m. Lockers would open. Shoes would be swapped. Laughter would echo.  
So he severed his fingers. His toes. Planted them like grisly Easter eggs across the locker room floor¡ªa toe tucked into a sneaker, a finger curled inside a gym sock.  
When they found him hanging from the rim¡ªswaying gently, laced into his Jordans by what remained of his feet¡ªthey¡¯d already held pieces of him in their hands.  
No one knows how he tied the noose, limbless and alone.  
But he did.  
And we remembered.

After that, the madness bloomed.  
A woman swallowed two hundred needles¡ªher final act was to lie on a bed of white sheets, waiting for the slow bloom of blood beneath her skin.  
A man slit open his stomach and invited birds to feast. Crows pecked at his entrails as he watched, smiling.  
Each death more audacious than the last. Each corpse another landmark.  

Our town became a macabre tourist trap.  
People paid to stand where the dead had fallen. To touch the walls still stained with memory. To hear stories whispered by those who¡¯d known them¡ªnot as people, but as legends.  
Locals became celebrities just for proximity. For surviving near the edge.

I hated it.  
Called the tourists vultures¡ªfeeding on pain, drunk on horror.  
Yet here I was¡ªtwenty years old, jobless, voice hoarse from repetition¡ªleading the very tours I despised.  
Reciting tragedies like scripture.

On the anniversary of legalization, I ended my shift where it all began:  
Janelle¡¯s house.  

The company owned it now. Preserved it like a shrine. A museum of mourning.  
I stood on the porch and recited her story¡ªthe flat facts of a life reduced to its final, violent footnote. Then I stopped.

I reached into the shadows. Found the can of pepper spray left behind, forgotten, sacred.  
And I doused them.  

Eighteen people collapsed¡ªwrithing, blinded, screaming into the dirt.  
I didn¡¯t run.  
They¡¯d be helpless for nearly an hour.

Forty-five minutes passed.  
Their sobs softened. Tears cleared. Sight returned.  
I told them to look at me.

They did.

I condemned them¡ªvoice sharp as broken glass. Called them out for their obsession, their hunger for suffering dressed as curiosity. Their lack of decency. Their endless, ravenous need for spectacle.  
Then I said it again:  
*Look at me.*

I turned my back.  
And fired.

The bullet tore through my skull like thunder through silence.  
Brain matter sprayed¡ªacross their faces, their trembling hands, the peeling paint of Janelle¡¯s front wall.  
A chunk landed near a woman on the floor.  
Maybe I heard her scream.  
Or maybe I was already gone.

*This is what you wanted,* I thought.  
Not grief. Not remembrance.  
*Shock.*

At last, they got their shock-death.

And God¡ª  
they were pathetic.

human: The American Lunar Module was finally ready for a successful piloted test flight in low Earth orbit on Apollo 9 in March 1969. The next mission, Apollo 10, conducted a "dress rehearsal" for the first landing in May 1969, flying the LM in lunar orbit as close as 47,400 feet (14.4 km) above the surface, the point where the powered descent to the surface would begin. With the LM proven to work well, the next step was to attempt the actual landing.
LLM_1: The American Lunar Module successfully completed its first piloted test flight in low Earth orbit during Apollo 9 in March 1969. Apollo 10 then conducted a full dress rehearsal for the lunar landing in May 1969, flying the LM in lunar orbit to within 47,400 feet (14.4 km) of the Moon's surface¡ªthe point at which powered descent would begin. With the LM proven operational, the next mission was cleared for an actual landing attempt.
LLM_2: The American Lunar Module (LM) successfully completed its first crewed test flight in low Earth orbit during the Apollo 9 mission in March 1969. This was followed by Apollo 10 in May 1969, which conducted a comprehensive dress rehearsal for the lunar landing. During this mission, the LM flew in lunar orbit and descended to within 47,400 feet (14.4 km) of the Moon's surface¡ªthe altitude at which the powered descent phase would commence in an actual landing. Having demonstrated the LM's operational readiness, NASA approved the next mission, Apollo 11, for a full lunar landing attempt.

The main novelty of this paper is to use GPD to model the density ratio, which reveals important properties of different variational inference methods in the f-divergence family, which includes the inclusive KL and exclusive KL approaches. This provides a practical tool for people to use for variational inference diagnosis. One particular conclusion from this analysis is that, for moderate-to-high-dimensional posteriors, exclusive KL divergence is a better choice than inclusive KL divergence. These conclusion can be very helpful for people to choose the right variational inference method in different scenarios. Here are some more detailed commons of the paper:

1. The three predictions (P1, P2, P3) are reasonable and are verified by some experiments. However, more rigorous proofs or justifications are needed to generalize the conclusions to other applications scenarios. For example, the authors mentioned that application to neural networks is not covered theoretically or empirically. 

2. It would be better to provide a table to summarize the conclusions in the paper, for low dimensional and high dimensional problems. Properties and behaviors of different variational inference method could be included in the table, together with the recommended inference method in the f-divergence family.

3. A minor technical issue, in line 103, for the normalized importance weight, there should be a 1/S term in the denominator.

4. A problem in notation: D is used for divergence, but also used for dimension.
LLM_1:
The paper's main contribution is the use of the Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD) to model the density ratio, revealing key properties of variational inference methods within the f-divergence family¡ªincluding inclusive and exclusive KL divergences¡ªand providing a practical tool for diagnosing variational approximations. A central finding is that exclusive KL divergence tends to outperform inclusive KL divergence for moderate-to-high-dimensional posteriors, offering valuable guidance for method selection in practice.

Detailed comments:

1. The three predictions (P1¨CP3) are plausible and supported by empirical validation, but their generalization requires stronger theoretical justification. Notably, the analysis does not extend to neural network models, either theoretically or experimentally, limiting broader applicability.

2. A summary table comparing low- and high-dimensional settings would enhance clarity, outlining properties of different f-divergence-based methods, their behavior, and recommended use cases.

3. A minor technical correction: in line 103, the normalized importance weight should include a $1/S$ term in the denominator.

4. Notation conflict: the symbol $D$ is used both for divergence and dimension; distinct symbols should be employed to avoid confusion.
LLM_2:
The paper¡¯s primary contribution lies in the application of the Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD) to model the density ratio, thereby uncovering fundamental properties of variational inference methods within the $f$-divergence family¡ªspecifically, inclusive and exclusive Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergences¡ªand offering a practical diagnostic tool for assessing the quality of variational approximations. A key insight is that, in moderate-to-high-dimensional posterior settings, the exclusive KL divergence tends to outperform its inclusive counterpart, providing actionable guidance for practitioners in selecting appropriate inference strategies.

**Detailed Comments:**

1. While the three theoretical predictions (P1¨CP3) are intuitively plausible and supported by empirical evidence, their broader generalization would benefit from more rigorous theoretical justification. In particular, the current analysis does not extend to models with neural network architectures, either through theoretical treatment or experimental validation. This omission limits the scope of applicability to modern, high-capacity models commonly used in contemporary Bayesian deep learning.

2. To improve interpretability and accessibility, the authors are encouraged to include a summary table contrasting low- and high-dimensional regimes. Such a table could systematically compare different $f$-divergence-based methods in terms of their asymptotic behavior, sensitivity to dimensionality, tail approximation properties, and recommended use cases. This would significantly enhance the paper¡¯s utility as a reference for method selection.

3. A minor technical correction is required: in Line 103, the expression for the normalized importance weight appears to be missing a $1/S$ factor in the denominator. The correct form should account for sample averaging, and this clarification should be made explicit to avoid misinterpretation.

4. There is a notational conflict in the use of the symbol $D$, which is employed both for divergence measures (e.g., $D_{ ext{KL}}$) and for data dimensionality. To prevent ambiguity, distinct symbols¡ªsuch as $d$ or $p$ for dimensionality¡ªare recommended, in accordance with standard conventions in the literature.

My review will be quite short, as this is a very good paper. The idea proposed is conceptually very simple, but requires significant theoretical work to derive useful bounds. The paper is well written, and the authors do a great job at outlining their mathematical demonstrations. The experimental validation is thorough, with extensive further experiments in the supplementary. Accordingly, this is a **clear accept (8)**. I only have two small points below on the style & clarity of the tables, and on the lack of a discussion around limitations & future work (especially in regard of Figure G.2 of the supplementary). 

### Originality
This paper is well placed in the relevant literature, and the authors do a good job in section 2 at outlining how their work improves on the state-of-the-art. Although the algorithm proposed may look simple, all the complexity lies in providing useful bounds. Previous literature with buffering set of arbitrary size had only succeeded in providing bounds that are meaningful for very large batches.  

### Quality
The theoretical part of this work is very solid, with a well-structured and excellent analysis. The experimental validation is equally good, comparing to a large number of methods on diverse datasets. 

However, on light of Figure G.2 of the supplementary, I do have a (small) point of criticism.
**Q.1**: This work is very complete and leaves no question "hanging", but the authors could still make an effort to discuss potential limitations. It would be interesting to at least mention that methods such as SPAUC, designed for very specific losses and problems, can still be competitive (as seen in Figure G.2, and as sparsely discussed on l775 of the supplementary). 

### Clarity
This paper is well written, and the theoretical analysis is easy to follow from the outline provided. 

One small point I have to make is regarding the design used for the tables presenting results (Table 1, and in Section G of the supplementary). 
**C.1**: The tables do not follow the style guidelines provided in the NeurIPS template. They use vertical rules, and too many horizontal rules. Given their density, this makes them hard to parse. Moreover, in each column, highlighting the best result in bold would make them more readable at a glance. 

### Significance
This work clearly builds upon the state-of-the-art, and provides new useful bounds that are a clear improvement over previous work. This is a very interesting result, that answers a question previously left open. The techniques used by the authors to achieve this result may also be of interest to others in the field.
LLM_1:
The writing is clear and the mathematical exposition is well-structured, leading to a **clear accept (8)**. Two minor points are noted for improvement.

**Originality**: The work is well-grounded in the relevant literature, and Section 2 effectively positions the contribution relative to prior art. While the proposed algorithm appears simple, the theoretical derivation of meaningful bounds¡ªparticularly in contrast to earlier methods that only yield useful guarantees for large batches¡ªis a significant advance.

**Quality**: The theoretical analysis is solid and carefully developed, and the experiments are comprehensive, involving comparisons across multiple datasets and baselines. One small point remains:  
**Q.1**: Despite the paper¡¯s completeness, a brief discussion of limitations and future directions would strengthen the manuscript. For instance, methods like SPAUC, though specialized, remain competitive in certain regimes, as suggested by Figure G.2 and briefly mentioned on line 775. Acknowledging such cases would provide valuable context.

**Clarity**: The paper is clearly written and the theoretical development is accessible. However, the presentation of results can be improved:  
**C.1**: The tables (including Table 1 and those in Section G) deviate from NeurIPS formatting guidelines by using excessive vertical and horizontal rules, which hinders readability given their density. Removing these rules and bolding the best result in each column would enhance clarity.

**Significance**: The work advances the state of the art by resolving an open problem and providing tighter, practically relevant bounds. The techniques may inspire further developments in the field, underscoring the paper¡¯s impact.
LLM_2:
The manuscript is well-written, with a clear and logically structured mathematical exposition, supporting a **strong accept (8)**. The work makes a meaningful contribution to the field, and the presentation is largely effective. Two minor points are highlighted for potential improvement.

**Originality**: The paper is firmly grounded in the relevant literature, and Section 2 successfully situates the proposed approach within the context of prior work. While the algorithmic design appears conceptually simple, the derivation of non-trivial theoretical bounds¡ªespecially in contrast to earlier methods that provide meaningful guarantees only in the large-batch regime¡ªrepresents a notable advancement. This refinement of theoretical understanding addresses an open problem and enhances the practical applicability of existing frameworks.

**Quality**: The theoretical analysis is rigorous and carefully articulated, and the empirical evaluation is thorough, encompassing multiple datasets and a diverse set of baseline methods. One point could be expanded to further strengthen the manuscript:  
**Q.1**: Although the paper is technically complete, a brief discussion of limitations and potential avenues for future work would enhance its scholarly depth. For example, specialized methods such as SPAUC remain competitive in certain settings, as indicated by Figure G.2 and briefly noted on line 775. These contributions not only enhance current understanding but also open new directions for algorithmic development in stochastic optimization and related areas. The methodological insights are likely to influence subsequent research, underscoring the broader impact of this work.

`` Listen, I know my background check is n't gon na come up clean. But I *need* this gun. You have no idea what it's like living next to my neighbor.'' 
 
 Holy shit. This guy was trying to purchase a murder weapon from me. I started to reach for the panic button under the front desk, tried to look cool, tried to keep him going. 
 
 `` Oh yeah?'' I asked. `` Well... you might be able to convince me.'' 
 
 `` The guy's a mad scientist. I know it sounds crazy but it's true. He brought a dinosaur back to life and he lets it loose in his yard. I'm afraid it's gon na attack poor Monty, my beagle, and if it does I want to be able to stop it.'' 
 
 A *dinosaur*? What the hell? This guy did n't want to kill his neighbor, well maybe he did, but now I was pretty sure he was just plain crazy rather than homicidal. My finger froze beneath the desk. My interest was piqued. 
 
 `` Please. I know how it sounds. No one believes me. The 911 operator laughed at me. Please. I just want to be able to protect my Monty.'' 
 
 The guy's eyes were shimmering. His story was nuts, off the wall, but I could n't help feeling bad for the guy. 
 
 `` Hey, guy, what was your felony, anyway?'' 
 
 His eyes darted around nervously. 
 
 `` Felony drug posession, but I swear it was a long time ago, it was n't mine --'' 
 
 I cut him off with a laugh. 
 
 `` That's it? Listen buddy, I feel your pain. Got caught with some Girl Scout Cookies when I was younger, cop passed me in the next lane and the smell drifted out my window, was n't even smokin'. I was lucky to get off with a misdemeanor. 
 
 `` I'll tell ya what, your story's way out there, but I think you seem harmless. So I'm just gon na sell you the revolver you want, you know how to use it?'' 
 
 He nodded. 
 
 I went on. 
 
 `` Here it is, then, and some free ammo to boot. Just do n't go using it unless that... dinosaur, was it, unless the dinosaur actually comes after you or your dog.'' 
 
 I chuckled and he smiled. We shook hands and went about our days. 
 
 *** 
 
 That night I got home and grabbed myself a beer. I turned on the local news on my kitchen television. 
 
 Immediately I dropped the bottle on the floor. It smashed into pieces, cold beer splattering over the linoleum. 
 
 I did n't look down. My eyes were fixed on the television screen, which bore the face of my customer from earlier. Beneath him was a legend: 
 
 `` Man high on PCP shoots neighbor's pet iguana.''
LLM_1:
"Listen, my background check won¡¯t come clean. But I *need* this gun. You don¡¯t know what it¡¯s like living next to that man."  

I froze¡ªthis guy was buying a murder weapon. My hand crept toward the panic button under the desk. I kept my voice steady. "Oh yeah? Maybe you can convince me."  

"He¡¯s a mad scientist. Sounds insane, I know¡ªbut he brought a dinosaur back to life. Lets it roam his yard. I¡¯m scared it¡¯ll attack Monty, my beagle. I just want to protect him."  

A *dinosaur*? Either he was delusional or high. My finger stilled. Yet something in his voice tugged at me.  

"Please. I know how it sounds. No one believes me. The 911 operator laughed. I only want to keep my dog safe."  

His eyes glistened. The story was absurd, but his fear felt real.  

"Hey, what was your felony?"  

He flinched. "Drug possession. Years ago. Wasn¡¯t even mine¡ª"  

I cut in with a laugh. "That¡¯s it? Got busted with Girl Scout Cookies once¡ªcop caught the scent through his window. Lucky it was just a misdemeanor."

He nodded. We shook. He left.  

That night, beer in hand, I flipped on the kitchen TV.

LLM_2:
"Listen," he said, voice low and urgent, "my background check won¡¯t come clean. But I *need* this gun. You don¡¯t know what it¡¯s like¡ªliving next to *that man*."

I froze.

My fingers hovered beneath the desk, brushing the cold metal of the panic button. My pulse thudded in my throat, but I kept my voice level, smooth. "Oh yeah? Try me."

"He¡¯s a mad scientist," he said. "Sounds insane¡ªI know. But he brought a dinosaur back to life. Keeps it loose in his yard. Roams around at night. I¡¯m terrified it¡¯ll go after Monty. My beagle. I just want to protect him."

A *dinosaur*?

For a heartbeat, I stared. Either he was high or losing his mind. My finger stilled on the alarm. And yet¡ªsomething in the tremor of his hands, the raw edge in his voice¡ªpulled at me. Not performance. Not quite.

"Please," he whispered. "I know how it sounds. No one believes me. Called 911 last week¡ªthe operator *laughed*. All I want is to keep my dog safe."

His eyes glistened under the fluorescent hum of the shop lights. The story was absurd. Impossible. But the fear¡ªthat was real. Thick. Human.

I leaned forward. "So. What¡¯d you do?"

He flinched. "Drug possession. Years ago. Wasn¡¯t even mine¡ªjust¡­ dumb luck and dumber friends."

I barked a laugh. "That¡¯s it? I once got busted with Girl Scout Cookies¡ªcop swore he smelled Thin Mints through his window. Lucky for me, it was just a misdemeanor."

I reached under the counter and pulled out the revolver. Checked the chamber. Slid it across the glass display.

"Your story¡¯s wild," I said. "But you? You seem harmless. Take it. And here¡ª" I added two speed loaders. "Just promise me one thing. Don¡¯t pull that trigger unless that *dinosaur*¡ªor whatever the hell it is¡ªcomes charging at you or your dog."

He nodded, solemn as a vow. We shook. His palm was damp. Then he was gone.

That night, I cracked open a beer, kicked off my boots, and flipped on the kitchen TV.

The bottle slipped from my hand¡ªhit the floor, shattered, foam spilling like blood across the linoleum.

There he was.

On screen.

The man from the shop.

Below him, the headline burned in stark white letters:

**"MAN HIGH ON PCP SHOOTS NEIGHBOR'S PET IGUANA."**

Silence.

Then the anchor¡¯s voice, calm, detached: *"Police report the suspect claimed the animal was a 'rampaging prehistoric beast'..."*

I stood there, staring.

And somewhere, miles away, I wondered if Monty was okay.

The paper investigates different machine learning approaches to model and
predict the return on property investments, in particular with respect to eager
and lazy learning techniques. The authors evaluate those different techniques on
a dataset of properties in Virginia. They conclude that lazy techniques provide
better performance than eager ones.

The paper is a purely empirical study that does not introduce any novel
machine learning or evaluation techniques. The authors use the off-the-shelf
WEKA toolbox. The results are not clear, given that only a single data set was
used to evaluate the different approaches, and general recommendations cannot be
made.

The paper is not well written and the descriptions do not convey what the
authors have done very well. An example of this is Figure 3, which purports to
show the average rent (or rent distribution?) for different housing types. There
are multiple categories in there that are not valid housing types ("Make Me
Move") and the rents shown are incorrect (e.g. more than a million for a town
house). It is also unclear why the average rent for a single family house is
approximately 4 times as much as for a town house.

The problems with Figure 3 are exemplary of the paper; the other issues are too
numerous to list.

In summary, this paper should be rejected.
LLM_1:
The paper empirically compares eager and lazy machine learning techniques for predicting property investment returns using a Virginia real estate dataset, concluding that lazy methods perform better. However, the study introduces no novel methodology and relies entirely on the WEKA toolbox for analysis. Given the evaluation is based on a single dataset, the results lack generalizability, and broad conclusions about method superiority cannot be reliably drawn.

Furthermore, the paper suffers from significant presentation and clarity issues. For instance, Figure 3, intended to show average rent or rent distribution across housing types, contains invalid categories (e.g., "Make Me Move") and implausible values (e.g., over a million dollars for a townhouse), while failing to explain large discrepancies such as the single-family home rent being four times that of a townhouse. These flaws are representative of broader problems throughout the manuscript, which collectively undermine its credibility and readability.

Due to limited empirical scope and pervasive issues in exposition and data interpretation, the paper is not suitable for acceptance.
LLM_2:
The paper presents an empirical comparison of eager and lazy machine learning techniques in the context of predicting property investment returns, utilizing a real estate dataset from Virginia. The authors conclude that lazy learning methods exhibit superior predictive performance. While this finding may be of interest, the study does not introduce any novel methodology and relies entirely on off-the-shelf tools provided by the WEKA machine learning toolbox. As such, the contribution is primarily application-driven rather than methodological.

A key limitation lies in the generalizability of the results. Given that the evaluation is based on a single, geographically confined dataset, the empirical scope is narrow, and the observed performance differences cannot support broad claims regarding the inherent superiority of lazy over eager methods. Conclusions drawn from a single dataset risk overfitting to domain-specific characteristics and should be interpreted with caution.

Moreover, the manuscript exhibits significant issues in presentation, clarity, and data interpretation. For example, Figure 3¡ªintended to illustrate average rent or rent distribution across housing types¡ªcontains anomalous categories (e.g., "Make Me Move") and implausible values (e.g., rental estimates exceeding one million dollars for townhouses). Additionally, the figure fails to account for substantial discrepancies in reported averages, such as why single-family homes would command rents four times higher than those of townhouses, even without accompanying explanatory analysis. These issues are not isolated but reflect broader deficiencies in data validation, visualization practices, and interpretive rigor throughout the paper.

Collectively, these limitations¡ªrestricted empirical breadth, lack of methodological innovation, and pervasive weaknesses in exposition and analytical transparency¡ªundermine the paper¡¯s credibility and scholarly impact. As currently constituted, the manuscript does not meet the threshold for acceptance in its present form.

human: lt was the purpose of this study to investigate how bone morphogenetic protein 2 (BMP-2) influences remodelling and the biomechanics of solvent-dehydrated bone in the long run. Furthermore, the early influence of this growth factor on the substitute was investigated.Using a weight-bearing animal model, solvent-dehydrated bone was implanted in the tibial head of merino sheep ( n=12) after being loaded with BMP-2 (100 microg/100 microl). At 4 weeks ( n=6) and 9 months ( n=6) after surgery, histomorphological, histomorphometrical and biomechanical investigations were performed.At 9 months after implantation of BMP-2-loaded specimens, the bone per tissue volume was high, with levels above those of physiological cancellous bone. The amount of remaining solvent-dehydrated bone was markedly decreased, and in contrast, the amount of newly formed bone was extremely high. The specimen degradation had already occurred within the first 4 weeks after implantation, showing no further impact throughout the 9-month period. Biomechanical investigations at 9 months after implantation demonstrated a yield strength which achieved levels at least equivalent to physiological cancellous bone. BMP-2 showed no significant impact on the biomechanical properties after 4 weeks, compared to specimens prior to implantation.
LLM_1: This study investigated the long-term effects of bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) on the remodeling and biomechanics of solvent-dehydrated bone, as well as its early influence on the graft material. Solvent-dehydrated bone loaded with BMP-2 (100?¦Ìg/100?¦ÌL) was implanted into the tibial head of Merino sheep (n=12) using a weight-bearing model. Histomorphological, histomorphometrical, and biomechanical analyses were conducted at 4 weeks (n=6) and 9 months (n=6) post-surgery. At 9 months, BMP-2-loaded grafts exhibited bone volume per tissue volume exceeding that of physiological cancellous bone, with markedly reduced residual graft material and extensive new bone formation. Graft degradation occurred primarily within the first 4 weeks, with no further changes observed thereafter. Biomechanical testing at 9 months revealed yield strength comparable to native cancellous bone. No significant effect of BMP-2 on mechanical properties was detected at 4 weeks compared to pre-implantation levels.
LLM_2: This study evaluated the long-term effects of bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) on the remodeling and biomechanical properties of solvent-dehydrated bone grafts, as well as its early influence on graft integration. BMP-2 (100?¦Ìg/100?¦ÌL) was loaded onto solvent-dehydrated bone grafts and implanted into the tibial head of Merino sheep (n = 12) using a weight-bearing model. Histomorphological, histomorphometric, and biomechanical analyses were performed at 4 weeks (n = 6) and 9 months (n = 6) post-implantation. At 9 months, BMP-2-loaded grafts demonstrated a bone volume per tissue volume exceeding that of physiological cancellous bone, with extensive new bone formation, significantly reduced residual graft material, and complete structural remodeling. Graft degradation occurred predominantly within the initial 4 weeks, with no further resorption observed thereafter. Biomechanical testing at 9 months revealed yield strength comparable to that of native cancellous bone. No significant alteration in mechanical properties was detected at 4 weeks relative to pre-implantation values. These findings suggest that BMP-2 enhances osteoconductive remodeling of solvent-dehydrated bone grafts, leading to favorable structural and functional integration in load-bearing sites over time.

The ?¡ê28m "managed realignment" at Medmerry in West Sussex has seen the building of 7km (four miles) of new sea walls up to 2km inland.
By letting the waters in, the Environment Agency says the risk of flooding for hundreds of homes will be reduced.
The surrendered land will become a wetland habitat for many species.
The sea has long been a threatening presence on the flat land of the Manhood Peninsula that juts into the English channel on the coast between Portsmouth and Worthing.
Caravan parks in Selsey and Bracklesham Bay have been flooded a number of times in recent years, as the shingle defences have yielded to the surging seas.
Since 2011, the Environment Agency have been working on a plan that they believe curbs that threat.
The project is billed as the country's largest ever coastal flood realignment scheme, but it has required the destruction of the existing sea wall at Medmerry and giving back to the sea some of the land nearest to the coast.
"We have made a hole in the sea wall," the Environment Agency's flood and coastal risk manager, Andrew Gilham, told BBC News on a visit to the site.
"But before doing that we've actually built 7km of new defences further inland from the coast. What we've been able to create here is an area that can absorb the energy of the waves and reduce the flood risk to people."
Although the new walls are much closer to local communities, the Agency says homes are much better protected as a result, with the development able to withstand a once in a thousand year flood.
The change is partly being forced on the Agency because of EU legislation that requires compensation for the loss of wildlife habitat through development. The Medmerry scheme makes up for the loss of similar conservation areas in and around the Solent.
"It is not politically driven," said Mr Gilham.
"But the benefit of creating the habitat here is not only to reduce flood risk in this area but also to reduce flood risk to communities in Portsmouth and Southampton.
Abbotts Hall Farm is owned by the Essex Wildlife Trust and managed retreat was pioneered there in 2002.
Located on the Blackwater estuary, a wall keeping out the waters was breached to create 80 hectares of wetlands and intertidal habitats.
According to Karen Thomas from the Environment Agency it has been a huge success, particularly in mitigating the flood risk further up the river in populated areas.
"It's a really great site to take the pressure out of the tide. On big surge tides it is not going up and overtopping other defences," she said.
The new marshland is an important breeding ground for birds and for 10 different fish species.
"What we are trying to do here is create sites of sustainable wildlife so that people and animals have this in the future as a legacy," said Ms Thomas.
"If we weren't able create habitat here we wouldn't be be able to do those defences."
The scale of the ?¡ê28m development is enormous. Between the new earthen walls and the sea stand 183 hectares of land that the Agency says will rapidly become a saltwater marsh, with potentially huge benefits for wildlife in the area. It will be managed by the RSPB.
"Even in construction, we're seeing lots of migratory birds using this area," said Andrew Gilham.
"It is already starting to be used by the wildlife. It's a massive nature reserve and a massive opportunity on the south coast."
Local people are hoping that letting the sea in will not only protect their homes but boost the local economy as well.
Alan Chamberlain is the estate manager of the newly renamed Medmerry Park holiday village. His business, located next door to the new habitat, is actually below sea level.
"In the past we have been very close to flooding, and now we've got a one-in-one-thousand-year protection, one of the best in the country actually," he told BBC News.
"For us it's a win win, it will encourage visitors to the site, birdwatchers and those interested in nature."
The new development is facing its first big test on the day it opens as it will see one of the highest tides of the year. But the Environment Agency are fully confident it will pass with flying colours.
Medmerry is one of a number of managed realignment projects that the Environment Agency are involved in. Andrew Gilham says it's part of a new approach.
"Rather than fighting it, we are working with nature," he explained.
"It's an important change in approach, you can only keep building bigger and bigger defences for so long. We have to ask if we can make better use of public money.
"Certainly the habitat we are creating here is important to the broader ecosystem and the broader economy of the country by encouraging people to visit remote areas."
Follow Matt on Twitter.
LLM_1:
A ¡ê28 million "managed realignment" project at Medmerry in West Sussex has created 7km of new sea defences up to 2km inland, allowing the sea to reclaim low-lying coastal land and form a 183-hectare saltwater marsh. The Environment Agency says the scheme¡ªthe UK¡¯s largest coastal flood realignment project¡ªwill significantly reduce flood risk for hundreds of homes on the vulnerable Manhood Peninsula, which has faced repeated flooding in Selsey and Bracklesham Bay as natural shingle barriers erode.

By breaching the old sea wall and constructing stronger defences further inland, the new system can absorb wave energy and withstand a one-in-a-thousand-year flood event. The site, now managed by the RSPB, is already attracting migratory birds and provides breeding grounds for 10 fish species and diverse wildlife. It also fulfils EU requirements for habitat compensation lost elsewhere in the Solent region.

Andrew Gilham, the Environment Agency¡¯s flood and coastal risk manager, said the approach marks a strategic shift: ¡°Rather than fighting nature, we¡¯re working with it. We can¡¯t keep building higher walls forever¡ªwe must use public funds more effectively.¡± The wetland will also support tourism, benefiting nearby businesses like Medmerry Park holiday village, whose estate manager Alan Chamberlain noted the improved protection has made the below-sea-level site safer and more attractive to visitors, including birdwatchers.

The project follows earlier success at Essex¡¯s Abbotts Hall Farm, where managed retreat since 2002 created 80 hectares of intertidal habitat and reduced flood pressure upstream. Officials say Medmerry offers long-term environmental, economic, and community benefits, combining robust flood defence with sustainable conservation. The scheme faces its first major test during high tides coinciding with its opening, but the Agency is confident in its resilience.

The initiative, led by the Environment Agency, is designed to significantly reduce flood risk for hundreds of homes on the vulnerable Manhood Peninsula. The area, including Selsey and Bracklesham Bay, has faced repeated flooding as natural shingle barriers erode due to coastal change.

human: An interesting and so far unexplained feature of chronic pain in autoimmune disease is the frequent disconnect between pain and inflammation. This is illustrated well in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) where pain in joints (arthralgia) may precede joint inflammation and persist even after successful anti-inflammatory treatment. In the present study, we have addressed the possibility that autoantibodies against citrullinated proteins (ACPA), present in RA, may be directly responsible for the induction of pain, independent of inflammation.Antibodies purified from human patients with RA, healthy donors and murinised monoclonal ACPA were injected into mice. Pain-like behaviour was monitored for up to 28?days, and tissues were analysed for signs of pathology. Mouse osteoclasts were cultured and stimulated with antibodies, and supernatants analysed for release of factors. Mice were treated with CXCR1/2 (interleukin (IL) 8 receptor) antagonist reparixin.Mice injected with either human or murinised ACPA developed long-lasting pronounced pain-like behaviour in the absence of inflammation, while non-ACPA IgG from patients with RA or control monoclonal IgG were without pronociceptive effect. This effect was coupled to ACPA-mediated activation of osteoclasts and release of the nociceptive chemokine CXCL1 (analogue to human IL-8). ACPA-induced pain-like behaviour was reversed with reparixin.
LLM_1: An unexplained feature of chronic pain in autoimmune diseases is its frequent dissociation from inflammation, exemplified in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by persistent arthralgia despite controlled joint inflammation. This study investigates whether autoantibodies against citrullinated proteins (ACPA), hallmark RA antibodies, directly induce pain independent of inflammatory processes. Human and murinised ACPA, but not non-ACPA IgG or control monoclonal IgG, elicited prolonged pain-like behaviour in mice without inducing inflammation. This effect was linked to ACPA activation of osteoclasts and subsequent release of the nociceptive chemokine CXCL1 (murine analogue of human IL-8). Notably, ACPA-induced pain was reversed by treatment with reparixin, a CXCR1/2 antagonist. These findings demonstrate that ACPA can directly drive pain through osteoclast-mediated chemokine signaling, independent of inflammatory pathology.
LLM_2: A notable yet poorly understood feature of chronic pain in autoimmune diseases is its frequent dissociation from inflammatory activity¡ªexemplified in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by the persistence of arthralgia despite controlled joint inflammation. This study investigates whether anti¨Ccitrullinated protein antibodies (ACPA), serological hallmarks of RA, directly contribute to pain generation independent of inflammatory processes. We demonstrate that both human-derived and murinized ACPA, but not non-ACPA IgG or control monoclonal IgG, induce prolonged pain-like behaviors in mice without eliciting detectable inflammation. This nociceptive effect is mediated by ACPA-induced activation of osteoclasts and the subsequent release of the pro-nociceptive chemokine CXCL1 (the murine functional analogue of human IL-8). Importantly, ACPA-driven pain-like behavior is reversed by reparixin, a selective CXCR1/2 antagonist. These findings reveal a novel pathway by which ACPA can directly modulate pain signaling through osteoclast-dependent chemokine release, independent of classical inflammatory pathology. This mechanism may underlie persistent pain in RA and offers potential therapeutic targets for inflammation-independent pain management.

human:
Summary: 
This paper shows the feedforward network (with ReLU activation functions in the hidden layers, softmax at the output, and cross entropy-loss) exhibits a low-rank derivative structure, which is able to use second-order information without approximating Hessian. For numerical experiments, the author(s) implemented Cubic Regularization on this network structure with SGD (on MNIST and CIFAR10) and Adagrad and Adadelta (on MNIST). 

Comments: 
The idea of showing low rank structure which makes it possible to use second-order information without approximations is interesting. This feedforward network with ReLU activation, output softmax and cross-entropy-loss is well-known structure for neural networks. 

I have some comments and questions as follows. 

Have you tried to apply this to another architecture of neural networks? Do you think whether your approach is able to apply to convolutional neural networks, which are widely used? 

There is no gain on using CR with Adam as you mention in Discussion part of the paper. Do you think that CR with SGD (or with Adagrad and Adadelta) can be better than Adam? If not, why do people should consider this approach, which is more complicated, since Adam is widely used? 

The author(s) should do more experiments to various dataset to be more convincing. 

I do like the idea of the paper, but at the current state, it is hard to evaluate the effective of this paper. I hope the author(s) could provide more experiments on different datasets. I would suggest to also try SVHN or CIFAR100. And if possible, please also consider CNN even if you are not able to provide any theory.
LLM_1:
The authors implement Cubic Regularization within this framework using SGD (on MNIST and CIFAR-10) and Adagrad/Adadelta (on MNIST).

The observation of a low-rank structure facilitating second-order optimization is interesting. Given that the considered network architecture is standard, it is natural to ask whether this approach extends to other architectures¡ªparticularly convolutional neural networks, which are widely used in practice.

The paper notes no improvement when combining CR with Adam. Since Adam is dominant in practice, it is important to clarify whether CR with SGD, Adagrad, or Adadelta can outperform Adam. If not, the motivation for adopting a more complex method needs stronger justification.

Additional experiments on more diverse datasets are necessary to better assess the method¡¯s effectiveness. Experiments on SVHN or CIFAR-100 would strengthen the evaluation. While theoretical analysis for CNNs may be challenging, empirical validation on such architectures¡ªeven without theory¡ªwould significantly enhance the paper's impact.
LLM_2:
The authors incorporate Cubic Regularization (CR) within the proposed framework, employing SGD on MNIST and CIFAR-10, and Adagrad/Adadelta on MNIST. The observation that a low-rank structure can facilitate second-order optimization is intriguing. Given the use of a standard network architecture, it is natural to inquire whether this approach generalizes to other, more widely adopted architectures¡ªparticularly convolutional neural networks (CNNs), which are prevalent in practical applications.

The paper reports no performance improvement when combining CR with Adam. Since Adam remains one of the most widely used optimizers in practice, it is essential to clarify whether CR¡ªwhen paired with SGD, Adagrad, or Adadelta¡ªcan outperform Adam under comparable conditions. In the absence of such gains, the rationale for adopting a more complex optimization scheme would require stronger empirical or theoretical justification.

Furthermore, additional experiments on a broader range of datasets are warranted to more comprehensively evaluate the method¡¯s effectiveness. Testing on datasets such as SVHN or CIFAR-100 would enhance the empirical validation. While a theoretical analysis for CNNs may present challenges, even purely empirical evaluation on such architectures would significantly strengthen the paper's impact and practical relevance.

It was 1954¡ªthe year of the great turnip winter.  

The cold came down like a hammer, relentless, starving the earth of everything but those hardy yellow turnips¡ªnone of the rosy ones you see in markets today. I remember my father¡ªyour great-grandfather¡ªsending me out one gray morning to Great Uncle Steven¡¯s shop. Three eggs, two pints of beer, a loaf of crusty brown bread¡ªeight pence, no more.  

Steven ran that little store before he married Thelma. *Thelma.* Don¡¯t let her charm fool you. A so-called tramp, that one. And the moment they tied the knot, prices climbed. Coincidence? I think not.  

Though¡­ wait¡ªwas it ¡¯59 when he married her? No, no¡ª¡¯54 rings truer. That was the year your great-great-aunt Shelly wed. William¡¯s sister¡ªno, not William, bless him, he still had both eyes. It was Steven who lost his. Or¡­ was it? Memory plays tricks when the fire burns low.  

Anyway¡­ is dinner ready?

The UK's departure from the EU is the new prism through which politics, policy and business decisions are viewed.
Trade between the countries is worth a billion pounds every week.
Irish exporters are already having difficult times due to the weak pound.
On his mushroom farm near Athlone in County Westmeath, Gerry Reilly recounted how his business lost 20% of revenue in one night as sterling slumped.
The UK is the key market for mushroom producers in Ireland - each day 50 lorry-loads of the crop travel east across the Irish Sea.
Gerry Reilly said 52% of the mushrooms bought in the UK come from Ireland.
He is hoping that Brexit won't deal another blow to his industry, through the imposition of trade barriers.
"Ireland and England have had a great relationship on food," he said.
"It would be a terrible pity if anything would happen to make it more difficult or more costly."
His workers pluck tens of thousands of mushrooms from compost beds which stretch for 50 metres - and the produce will be on plates in Britain the following day.
Like many companies in the agri-food sector, margins are tight - and the UK export market crucial.
The ultimate effect of Brexit on exporters will be a major factor in how Ireland copes with the departure of its nearest neighbour from the European Union.
The Irish economy has been growing fast recently, having come through a disastrous financial crisis several years ago.
Professor Alan Barrett, director of the Economic and Social Research Institute in Dublin, said: "One of the great frustrations about Brexit is that it could interrupt what is otherwise a very strong recovery from the difficult times of recent years."
Researchers at the ESRI have modelled the various different forms which Brexit might take, and assessed the potential impact on Ireland.
A "soft" Brexit would result in Irish economic output being around 2% smaller than it otherwise would be.
If there is a "hard" Brexit, the figure is 4%.
The Irish government has said it wants to protect firms who trade into the UK market and it believes Brexit may present opportunities.
IDA Ireland - the agency which promotes the country as an investment destination - has launched an advertisement campaign which flags up Ireland's 12.5% corporate tax rate, coupled with "100% commitment to the EU."
Dublin is not being shy about what it sees as its post-Brexit credentials for investors.
Eoghan Murphy, a minister in the department of finance, said Ireland can offer a solution to firms located in the UK who want access to the European single market.
"We're an English-speaking country, we're incredibly well connected to the UK, and we have the youngest population in Europe," he said.
He highlighted financial services as being one sector which could be particularly attracted to Ireland.
When speaking about Ireland's role in the Brexit negotiations, Mr Murphy emphasised Ireland will be in the "EU 27" - the group states across the talks table from Britain.
He said he hoped 2017 will start with "less noise and hard rhetoric" compared to 2016, so that the negotiations can start "in a positive frame of mind".
Mr Murphy said Ireland's "strong and positive" relationship with the UK will continue - and he wanted trade to go on without excessive costs or burdens.
The terms of Britain's exit from the EU will probably affect Ireland's economy more than that of any other state.

human: The drunkenness and lawlessness created by gin was seen to lead to ruination and degradation of the working classes. The distinction[clarification needed] was illustrated by William Hogarth in his engravings Beer Street and Gin Lane. The Gin Act 1736 imposed high taxes on retailers and led to riots in the streets. The prohibitive duty was gradually reduced and finally abolished in 1742. The Gin Act 1751 however was more successful. It forced distillers to sell only to licensed retailers and brought gin shops under the jurisdiction of local magistrates.
LLM_1: The perceived social decay caused by gin consumption, particularly among the working classes, was depicted by William Hogarth in his engravings *Beer Street* and *Gin Lane*. The Gin Act of 1736 imposed heavy taxes on retailers, sparking public unrest, but the high duties were gradually lowered and repealed by 1742. A more effective measure, the Gin Act of 1751, required distillers to sell only to licensed retailers and placed gin shops under the oversight of local magistrates.
LLM_2:
Amid growing concerns over social disorder linked to rampant gin consumption¡ªespecially in working-class communities¡ªartist William Hogarth captured the moral panic of the era in his starkly contrasting engravings *Beer Street* and *Gin Lane*. The images, widely circulated in the 1750s, portrayed gin as a destructive force eroding public health and order. In response, the British government enacted the Gin Act of 1736, imposing steep taxes on retailers in an effort to curb sales. The move backfired, triggering widespread protests and evasion, leading authorities to gradually reduce the duties before repealing them entirely by 1742.

A more targeted approach followed with the passage of the Gin Act of 1751. This revised legislation curbed production and distribution by requiring distillers to sell exclusively to licensed vendors, while placing gin shops under the regulatory authority of local magistrates. The new rules marked a shift from punitive taxation to structured oversight, laying the groundwork for more effective control of the spirit trade.

They say children used to splash around in the puddles. I can see 
 why. Those little pools of light sit on the ground and reflect the heavens, 
 taunting us behind our windows. I've always wanted to put my foot into one. To destroy its face. I watch them now, my nose bent against the glass of the window. I can see the water congealing to form those tiny mirrors as it falls from the sky. I unlatch the window frame and slide it up. Immediately the smell hits me. That terrible, deathly smell of wet earth and humidity. The hairs on my arms raise, I can never control the fear that accompanies that smell. I look through the rain to the puddles. They seem so close, just past our front yard. I wonder again what it would be like to be out there with them. To feel the water that falls from the sky. It's like magic. I reach my hand out towards them. Just once I want to be out there. Further and further I inch my hand to the edge of the window frame. I begin to wonder if it would actually hurt me. Closer, closer... 
 
 ¡° WHAT are you doing!? ¡± Her voiced ripped through my thoughts. She grabs me from behind and all but throws me back into the room, slamming the window shut and latching it. Whipping around she looks at me, angry. She grabs my ear and starts shouting. 
 
 ¡° Eric, have you lost your mind! I ca n't trust you when it rains like this. You could have lost a finger! Or even a whole hand! This is the third time I've caught you like this, I just do n't know what to do anymore. Do I need to tie you down? ¡± I can see the tears welling up in my mothers eyes. She does n't understand. All she sees is pain and death in the rain. Her whole life has been spent learning to fear the dark clouds and thunderclaps. She ca n't understand that all I want is one touch, one second out there among the puddles. But I know I ca n't. I remember the day Mr. Frederickson could n't stand it anymore. The screams as he melted away. I know my mother is just afraid of me being next. 
 
 When she lets me go I escape to my room. I go right to the window to catch the end of the storm. Things are brightening up now, and soon we will be allowed back outside. But I wont want to then. Yes, they say children used to splash around in puddles. But not anymore.
LLM_1:
They say children once splashed in puddles. I understand why. Those small pools catch the sky, turning rain into mirrors that mock us from beyond the glass. I¡¯ve always wanted to step into one¡ªto break its surface. Pressed against the window, I watch droplets gather, forming fleeting reflections as they fall. I unlatch the frame and push it open. The scent hits instantly¡ªdamp earth, thick and lifeless. My skin prickles. That smell brings a fear I can¡¯t control. Through the downpour, the puddles shimmer, just past our yard. What would it feel like to stand among them? To touch the water falling from the heavens? It seems magical. I stretch my hand toward them. Just once, I want to be out there. Slowly, I inch closer to the edge. Could it even hurt me? Closer¡­

¡°WHAT are you doing!?¡± Her voice tears through me. She yanks me back, slamming the window shut, latching it tight. Spinning me around, she grips my ear, shouting. ¡°Eric, have you lost your mind? I can¡¯t trust you in the rain! You could¡¯ve lost a finger¡ªyour whole hand! This is the third time! Do I have to tie you down?¡± Tears brim in her eyes. She doesn¡¯t understand. To her, rain means pain, death. Her life has been ruled by fear of thunder, of clouds. She can¡¯t see that all I crave is a single moment outside, just one touch of the world beyond. But I know I can¡¯t. I remember Mr. Frederickson¡ªthe screams as he dissolved. She¡¯s not angry. She¡¯s terrified I¡¯ll be next.

When she releases me, I flee to my room. Back at the window, I watch the storm fade. Light returns. Soon, we¡¯ll be allowed outside again. But by then, I won¡¯t want to go. They say children used to splash in puddles. Not anymore.
LLM_2:
They say children once danced in rain-soaked hollows, laughing as they shattered reflections of the sky. I think I understand now¡ªnot just the urge, but the hunger behind it. Puddles are not just water; they¡¯re stolen pieces of heaven pooled on cracked earth, mirrors that hold the clouds and dare you to step through. I¡¯ve stood at the window for hours, breath fogging the glass, watching droplets fall like slow-motion stars, each one bursting into ripples that vanish too soon. The sky weeps outside, and something in me answers.

I unlatch the window¡ªsoftly, as if silence could shield me¡ªand push it open. The air rushes in, thick with the scent of wet soil and something older, deeper: decay wrapped in renewal. My skin tightens. That smell¡ªit coils in my chest, not quite memory, not quite warning. But still, I lean forward. Beyond our fence, the puddles shimmer under a bruised sky, trembling with every new drop. What would it feel like? To stand barefoot in that liquid light? To let the rain strike my face, not through glass, but raw and real? It feels less like danger and more like revelation.

My fingers stretch toward the storm, reaching for a world I¡¯ve only seen blurred by condensation and fear. Just once. Just once, I want to know what it means to be *out there*.

Then¡ªher voice. A blade in the hush.

**¡°WHAT are you doing!?¡±**

She¡¯s on me before I can blink¡ªyanking me back like I¡¯ve already fallen off a cliff. The window slams shut, the latch clicking like a gunlock. She spins me, her hand biting into my ear, her face wild with fury¡ªor is it terror? Her eyes glisten, not with anger, but with tears she refuses to shed.

¡°Eric,¡± she hisses, ¡°have you lost your mind? You can¡¯t go out in the rain! Not again! Do you want to lose a finger? Your whole arm? Is that what you want?¡± Her voice cracks. ¡°This is the third time! Should I chain you to the bed?¡±

But I don¡¯t answer. Because I see it¡ªthe truth beneath the rage. She¡¯s not mad. She¡¯s afraid. Afraid I¡¯ll dissolve like Mr. Frederickson did, screaming as his skin sloughed away beneath the downpour, his body unraveling like paper in a flood. She carries that scream in her bones. To her, rain isn¡¯t life¡ªit¡¯s execution. Thunder is judgment. Clouds are coffins.

And yet¡­ all I want is to touch the sky.

When she finally lets go, I run. Not in defiance, but in silence. Upstairs, back to my room, back to the window. The storm is breaking. Gray bleeds into gold. The world will dry. Soon, they¡¯ll unlock the doors, lift the warnings, and we¡¯ll all file outside like obedient ghosts.

But by then, the wanting will have cooled. The courage will have leaked away with the last drops. I¡¯ll step onto clean grass, safe and dry, and pretend I never dreamed of drowning in daylight.

They say children once splashed in puddles.

Not anymore.

And maybe, never again.

human: Unusual hypervascularity is a hallmark of human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Although microRNA-214 (miR-214) is upregulated in other human cancers, it is downregulated in HCC. We elucidated the biological and clinical significance of miR-214 downregulation in HCC.MicroRNAs deregulated in HCC were identified using array-based microRNA profiling. A luciferase reporter assay confirmed target association between miR-214 and the hepatoma-derived growth factor (HDGF). Tube formation and in vivo angiogenesis assays validated the roles of miR-214/HDGF in angiogenesis.miR-214 downregulation was associated with higher tumor recurrence and worse clinical outcomes. Ectopic expression of miR-214 suppressed xenograft tumor growth and microvascularity of the tumors and their surrounding tissues. The genes downregulated by ectopic expression of miR-214 were involved in the regulation of apoptosis, cell cycle, and angiogenesis. Integrated analysis disclosed HDGF as a downstream target of miR-214. Conditioned medium of HCC cells contained bioactivity to stimulate tube formation of human umbilical vein endothelial cells, which was abolished by pretreatment of the conditioned media with HDGF antibodies, suppression of HDGF expression or ectopic expression of miR-214 in the donor HCC cells. The angiogenic activity of the conditioned media, lost by ectopic expression of miR-214 in the donor cells, was restored by supplementation with recombinant HDGF. human: Reduced heart rate variability (HRV) reflects autonomic dysfunction and can triage patients better than routine trauma criteria or vital signs. However, there is questionable specificity and no consensus measurement technique. The purpose of this study was to analyze whether factors that alter autonomic function affect the specificity of HRV for assessing traumatic injury.We evaluated 216 hemodynamically stable adults (3:1 M:F; 97:3 blunt:penetrating; age 49 years ¡À 1 year, mean ¡À standard error) undergoing computed axial tomography (CT) scan to rule out traumatic brain injury (TBI). All were prospectively instrumented with a Mars Holter system (GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI). HRV was determined offline using time domain (standard deviation of normal-normal intervals, root-mean-square successive difference) and frequency domain (very low frequency [VLF], LF, wideband frequency, high frequency [HF], low to HF index ratio) calculations from 15-minute electrocardiogram and correlated with routine vital signs, mortality, TBI, morbidity, length of stay (LOS), and comorbidities. Significance (p ¡Ü 0.05) was determined using nonparametric analysis, Student's t test, analysis of variance, or multiple logistic regression.VLF alone predicted survival, severity of TBI, intensive care unit LOS, and hospital LOS (all p < 0.05). Beta-blockers or diabetes had no effect, whereas age, sedation, mechanical ventilation, spinal cord injury, and intoxication influenced one or more of the variables with age being the most powerful confounder (all p < 0.05). Except for the Glasgow Coma Scale, no other routine trauma or hemodynamic criteria correlated with any of these outcomes.

This study examined whether factors influencing autonomic function affect HRV's specificity in assessing traumatic injury. All patients were monitored via Mars Holter system (GE Healthcare); HRV was assessed using time-domain (SDNN, RMSSD) and frequency-domain (VLF, LF, wideband, HF, LF/HF ratio) metrics derived from 15-minute electrocardiograms. HRV outcomes were correlated with vital signs, mortality, TBI severity, morbidity, length of stay (LOS), and comorbidities, with significance set at *p* ¡Ü 0.05 using nonparametric tests, t-tests, ANOVA, or multiple logistic regression. VLF independently predicted survival, TBI severity, ICU LOS, and hospital LOS (*p* < 0.05 for all). Beta-blocker use and diabetes did not influence HRV outcomes, whereas age, sedation, mechanical ventilation, spinal cord injury, and intoxication each affected one or more variables, with age being the strongest confounder (*p* < 0.05). No conventional trauma or hemodynamic parameter¡ªexcept Glasgow Coma Scale¡ªcorrelated significantly with these outcomes.
LLM_2: This study investigated the influence of autonomic and clinical confounding factors on the specificity of heart rate variability (HRV) as a biomarker for traumatic injury assessment in hemodynamically stable adults. Reduced HRV, a marker of autonomic dysfunction, has potential utility in enhancing patient triage beyond conventional trauma criteria; however, its specificity is limited by the absence of standardized measurement protocols. A prospective cohort of 216 adult patients (mean age 49 ¡À 1 years, 75% male, 97% blunt trauma) undergoing computed tomography for suspected traumatic brain injury (TBI) was enrolled. HRV was assessed using the Mars Holter system (GE Healthcare), with time-domain (SDNN, RMSSD) and frequency-domain (VLF, LF, wideband, HF, LF/HF ratio) parameters derived from 15-minute electrocardiographic recordings. Associations between HRV metrics and clinical outcomes¡ªincluding vital signs, mortality, TBI severity, morbidity, length of stay (LOS), and comorbidities¡ªwere evaluated using nonparametric tests, t-tests, ANOVA, and multiple logistic regression, with statistical significance set at *p* ¡Ü 0.05. Very low-frequency power (VLF) emerged as an independent predictor of survival, TBI severity, intensive care unit LOS, and total hospital LOS (*p* < 0.05 for all). While beta-blocker use and diabetes did not significantly affect HRV measures, age, sedation, mechanical ventilation, spinal cord injury, and intoxication were identified as significant covariates, with age exhibiting the strongest confounding effect (*p* < 0.05). Notably, no conventional trauma or hemodynamic parameter¡ªexcept the Glasgow Coma Scale¡ªdemonstrated a significant association with HRV outcomes. These findings underscore the importance of accounting for specific physiological and clinical variables when interpreting HRV in trauma populations, particularly in research settings aiming to refine risk stratification models.

human: Dark room, quiet shadows, going through motions. I remember my life, remember what it looked like as all my memories flashed before my eyes in a bright moment of vivid color, and then it dawns on me. It was n't my life. I remember it was a game, I remember I had been in the afterlife for years, and I remember that this was an event to remind everyone of life so no one goes crazy. They happen once a year. I look at my watch and tap a couple times to see my score: 96 %. I smile and then bounce between conversations, talking about scores until I trip over my shoe lace. I turn over and look up to see another pitch black angel looking down at me. Slightly dazed, I look back and ask, `` Score?'' I hear a high, childlike laugh, and then wake up in an alleyway. I brush myself off and scamper away, hoping not to see the Seniors that beat me up. That wo n't be a dream I forget in a hurry.

I¡¯ve been in the afterlife for years; this annual simulation replays life to keep us grounded, sane. I check my wrist, tap twice¡ª96%. A grin spreads as I leap into chatter about scores¡ªthen stumble, tripping on a shoelace. I roll over, dazed, and see another pitch-black angel looming above. ¡°Score?¡± I ask. A childlike laugh rings out¡ªsharp, bright¡ªand then I¡¯m jolted awake in an alley. I scramble up, brush off the grime, and dart away, desperate to avoid the Seniors who beat me. That nightmare won¡¯t fade anytime soon.
LLM_2:
Darkness. A breath held too long. The world, muffled and motionless¡ªuntil, without warning, it ignites.

Color floods in¡ªcrimson sunsets behind my eyelids, the scent of rain on hot pavement, laughter echoing from a childhood I can¡¯t quite place. My pulse hammers like a drum in the hollow of my throat. For one delirious second, I¡¯m alive again¡ª*truly* alive¡ªracing down streets that remember my name. Then the thread snaps. The vision shatters.

It wasn¡¯t real. Of course it wasn¡¯t.

It was the Game.

I¡¯ve been dead for years. Not that it feels like it. Time stretches thin here, a slow loop between silence and simulation. Every cycle, they plug us back in¡ªjust for a moment¡ªletting us relive fragments of who we were. A mercy, they say. A tether to keep our ghosts from unraveling completely.

I glance at my wrist. Two taps. The number glows: **96%**. High enough to boast. High enough to matter. A grin tugs at my lips as I open my mouth to shout my score into the void¡ªsome phantom audience always listening¡ªwhen my foot catches. A shoelace, loose. I pitch forward, tumbling into the dark like I used to fall through dreams.

I roll onto my back, dazed, stars pricking the edges of my vision. And then I see *it*¡ªa silhouette cut from deeper night, wings folded like shadows given shape. Another angel, or whatever we are now. Featureless. Familiar.

¡°Score?¡± I croak.

A laugh answers me¡ªlight, crystalline, absurdly young. It rings once, bright as shattered glass, and then¡ª

I wake up choking on alley air.

Concrete bites my palms. I scramble to my feet, slapping grime from my clothes, heart still galloping from the echo of wings. The city hums above me, indifferent. Somewhere out there, the Seniors patrol¡ªthose who rule the dead with fists and fire¡ªand I am not ready to face them. Not today. Not after *that*.

The dream clings like smoke. Even now, I can feel the pulse of false life in my veins.  

And worst of all?  

I think¡­ I don¡¯t want it to go away.

This program studied several different types of one-man space vehicles, settling on a ballistic re-entry capsule launched on a derivative Atlas missile, and selecting a group of nine candidate pilots. After NASA's creation, the program was transferred over to the civilian agency and renamed Project Mercury on November 26, 1958. NASA selected a new group of astronaut (from the Greek for "star sailor") candidates from Navy, Air Force and Marine test pilots, and narrowed this down to a group of seven for the program. Capsule design and astronaut training began immediately, working toward preliminary suborbital flights on the Redstone missile, followed by orbital flights on the Atlas. Each flight series would first start unmanned, then carry a primate, then finally men.

After NASA's establishment, the program was transferred to the civilian agency and renamed Project Mercury on November 26, 1958. NASA then selected astronaut candidates¡ªderived from the Greek for "star sailor"¡ªfrom Navy, Air Force, and Marine test pilots, narrowing them to seven. In the early days of the Cold War space race, the U.S. Air Force launched an ambitious initiative known as ¡°Man in Space Soonest,¡± aiming to propel the first American astronaut into space. The program explored multiple designs for single-person spacecraft and ultimately settled on a compact, ballistic re-entry capsule based on the technology of the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile. Nine military test pilots were tapped as initial candidates for the high-stakes mission.

But just months after the project began, the landscape of American space exploration shifted. With the creation of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in 1958, control of the effort was transferred from the military to the newly formed civilian agency. On November 26 of that year, the program was officially renamed **Project Mercury**, marking the dawn of America¡¯s human spaceflight era.

NASA refined the astronaut selection process, seeking elite test pilots from the Navy, Air Force, and Marine Corps. From a pool of top candidates, seven were chosen¡ªdubbed ¡°astronauts,¡± a term rooted in the Greek words for ¡°star¡± and ¡°sailor.¡± These pioneers would become national icons, tasked with mastering cutting-edge spacecraft systems and enduring grueling physical and psychological training.

Development moved swiftly. Engineers began building and testing Mercury capsules while planning a step-by-step flight campaign: first unmanned suborbital launches using the Redstone rocket, followed by flights with primate passengers to test life support systems. Those milestones paved the way for crewed suborbital missions, with the ultimate goal of achieving Earth orbit¡ªmade possible by upgrading to the more powerful Atlas launch vehicle.

Project Mercury laid the foundation for America¡¯s presence in space, setting the stage for the Gemini and Apollo programs¡ªand turning science fiction into reality.
