The Grade II listed Newbridge Memorial Hall, known as the 'Memo', will be restored for use by the community with the Heritage Lottery Funding award.
"It is the culmination of seven years of campaigning to save these magnificent buildings," said Howard Stone, the hall's chairman.
The 'Memo' narrowly lost in the 2004 UK final of the BBC's Restoration show.
Newbridge Institute and Memorial Hall was built by miners in 1925 to commemorate members of the local community who lost their lives in the World War I.
Its supporters say it is one of the UK's finest surviving early 20th century Art Deco cinema theatres, and claim it houses the largest ballroom in the south Wales valleys.
Entertainers such as Joe Loss, Clara Novello, Tom Jones, the Stranglers and Manic Street Preachers are said to have played there.
In 2006 Prince Charles made a special request to visit the building and threw his weight behind the restoration project which last year won ¡ê129,600 in HLF funding.
Campaigners said this year's ¡ê2.9m award would go towards extensive repair and restoration of the building's dilapidated interior and exterior, and a new link building would be built to improve access.
A learning and outreach officer would be employed and up to 25 local people trained to help run the centre as visitor numbers increased.
A 'Newbridge Hall of Fame' would also be set up to explore the social history of the area, celebrating local heroes such as photographer Angus McBean and singer James Dean Bradfield.
HLF chair Dan Clayton Jones explained the reasoning behind the award, saying: "It will bring a nationally important building back into use by a community who have worked hard to show how much they value it. "
He paid tribute to those who had campaigned to save the building: "Without the skill and dedication of the Memo team, this building would be facing a very uncertain future.
Heritage Minister, Alun Ffred Jones, said the award was "great news" for the local community and for visitors to the area.
"The dedication and commitment of the community has to be applauded," he said.
Howard Stone, chair of the Newbridge Institute & Memorial Hall, said the decision was "a huge boost" for Newbridge and the wider community of south east Wales.
"It is a testimony to the determination of all our volunteers, who have never lost the will to fight for what they believed in," said Mr Stone.
"It shows that communities can make a difference, it takes hard work and tenacity and the dedication to go on even through the tough times."

human:
The paper extends the prototypical networks of Snell et al, NIPS 2017 for one shot learning. Snell et al use a soft kNN classification rule, typically used in standard metric learning work (e.g. NCA, MCML), over learned instance projections, i.e. distances are computed over the learned projections. Each class is represented by a class prototype which is given by the average of the projections of the class instances. Classification is done with soft k-NN on the class prototypes. The distance that is used is the Euclidean distance over the learned representations, i.e. (z-c)^T(z-c), where z is the projection of the x instance to be classified and c is a class prototype, computed as the average of the projections of the support instances of a given class.

The present paper extends the above work to include the learning of a Mahalanobis matrix, S, for each instance, in addition to learning its projection. Thus now the classification is based on the Mahalanobis distance: (z-c)^T S_c (z-c). On a conceptual level since S_c should be a PSD matrix it can be written as the square of some matrix, i.e. S_c = A_c^TA_c, then the Mahanalobis distance becomes (A_c z - A_c c)^T ( A_c z-A_c c), i.e. in addition to learning a projection as it is done in Snell et al, the authors now learn also a linear transformation matrix which is a function of the support points (i.e. the ones which give rise to the class prototypes). The interesting part here is that the linear projection is a function of the support points. I wonder though if such a transformation could not be learned by the vanilla prototypical networks simply by learning now a projection matrix A_z as a function of the query point z. I am not sure I see any reason why the vanilla prototypical networks cannot learn to project x directly to A_z z and why one would need to do this indirectly through the use of the Mahalanobis distance as proposed in this paper.

On a more technical level the properties of the learned Mahalanobis matrix, i.e. the fact that it should be PSD, are not really discussed neither how this can be enforced especially in the case where S is a full matrix (even though the authors state that this method was not further explored). If S is diagonal then the S generation methods a) b) c) in the end of section 3.1 will make sure that S is PSD, I do not think that this is the case with d) though.

In the definition of the prototypes the component wise weigthing (eq. 5) works when the Mahalanobis matrix is diagonal (even though the weighting should be done by the \\sqrt of it), how would it work if it was a full matrix is not clear.

On the experiments side the authors could have also experimented with miniImageNet and not only omniglot as is the standard practice in one shot learning papers. 

I am not sure I understand figure 3 in which the authors try to see what happens if instead of learning the Mahalanobis matrix one would learn a projection that would have as many additional dimensions as free elements in the Mahalanobis matrix. I would expect to see a comparison of the vanilla prototypical nets against their method for each one of the different scenarios of the free parameters of the S matrix, something like a ratio of accuracies of the two methods in order to establish whether learning the Mahalanobis matrix brings an improvement over the prototypical nets with an equal number of output parameters.
LLM_1:
The paper extends Snell et al. (NIPS 2017) prototypical networks for few-shot learning by introducing a class-specific Mahalanobis distance metric, defined as $(z - c)^T S_c (z - c)$, where $S_c$ is a learned positive semi-definite (PSD) matrix per class. While Snell et al. use Euclidean distance over learned embeddings with class prototypes computed as mean embeddings of support instances, this work augments the model by learning a transformation matrix $A_c$ such that $S_c = A_c^T A_c$, effectively applying a linear transformation dependent on the support set before computing distances. This allows the metric to adapt based on class context.

However, it is unclear whether such adaptive projections cannot be equivalently captured by standard prototypical networks through direct learning of instance-specific projection matrices $A_z$ as functions of the query $z$. If so, the added complexity of modeling Mahalanobis metrics may not be necessary. human: The management of gallbladder polyps/masses in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) (i.e., cholecystectomy vs observation) remains problematic. Given the risk of biliary tract cancer in PSC in the face of the benign nature of most gallbladder polyps in the general population, our aim was to determine the prevalence of gallbladder cancer in PSC patients with a gallbladder mass who had undergone cholecystectomy.The case records of all patients with PSC undergoing a cholecystectomy at the Mayo Clinic between 1977-1999 were reviewed.Of the 102 patients with PSC who underwent a cholecystectomy, 14 of 102 (13.7%) had a gallbladder mass. In the subset of patients with gallbladder masses, eight of 14 (57%) had adenocarcinomas (seven primary adenocarcinomas and one metastatic cholangiocarcinoma); the other six had benign masses (five adenomas and one cholesterol polyp). In those patients with benign masses, 33% had associated epithelial cell dysplasia; in patients with primary gallbladder cancers, 57% had associated dysplasia. The patients with primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma had a favorable outcome after cholecystectomy, with a 36-month survival of 66%.
LLM_1: The management of gallbladder polyps or masses in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is challenging due to the elevated risk of biliary tract malignancy despite the typically benign nature of such lesions in the general population. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of gallbladder cancer among PSC patients undergoing cholecystectomy for gallbladder masses. A retrospective review was conducted of all PSC patients who underwent cholecystectomy at the Mayo Clinic between 1977 and 1999. Of 102 PSC patients who had cholecystectomy, 14 (13.7%) had gallbladder masses. Among these, 8 (57%) were diagnosed with adenocarcinoma¡ªseven with primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma and one with metastatic cholangiocarcinoma¡ªwhile six had benign lesions (five adenomas and one cholesterol polyp). Epithelial dysplasia was present in 33% of benign cases and in 57% of primary cancer cases. Patients with primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma showed favorable post-cholecystectomy survival, with a 36-month survival rate of 66%.
LLM_2: This study investigates the prevalence and clinical implications of gallbladder malignancy in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) undergoing cholecystectomy for gallbladder polyps or masses. Given the increased risk of biliary tract neoplasia in PSC, the management of such lesions remains clinically complex despite their typically benign appearance. A retrospective analysis was conducted on PSC patients who underwent cholecystectomy at the Mayo Clinic between 1977 and 1999. Among 102 PSC patients who received cholecystectomy, 14 (13.7%) were identified with gallbladder masses. Histopathological evaluation revealed malignant disease in 8 patients (57%), including seven cases of primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma and one case of metastatic cholangiocarcinoma. The remaining six patients exhibited benign pathology, consisting of five adenomas and one cholesterol polyp. Dysplastic epithelial changes were observed in 33% of benign lesions and 57% of primary cancer specimens. Notably, patients with primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma demonstrated a favorable prognosis post-cholecystectomy, with a 36-month survival rate of 66%. These findings underscore the heightened oncogenic potential of gallbladder masses in PSC and support early surgical intervention in selected cases to mitigate malignancy risk.

human: One day I was about to eat my afternoon meal. I was excited; I had spent most of the day preparing my favorite thing to eat. Wraps are especially delicious. As I was about to dig in I heard the most horrifying sound. It was a high-pitched horrifying scream. I decided it must be serious and I rushed towards the sound to see what was the matter. As I make my way onto the white tiles of the bathroom floor my heart jumped into my mouth as a giant slammed his enormous boot only inches from my face. I scurried away as fast as I could but the giants are relentless. On his second try I wasn ¡¯ t as lucky. Every bone in my exoskeleton cracked as I felt the life squish out of me. I struggled and held on with every last bit of strength I could muster, but all I could do was twitch. I knew it was over, and all I wanted to do was help. My only regret was that I had delicious wrap waiting at home, never to be eaten.

The bathroom tiles flashed white beneath me as I skidded in, heart hammering. Then came the thunderous impact: a colossal boot slammed down inches from my face, wielded by a giant towering above. I scrambled back, but giants don¡¯t hesitate. On his second strike, he found his mark. Every joint in my exoskeleton splintered; I felt my body collapse inward, life oozing out in an instant. I twitched, clinging to consciousness with what little will remained. In those final breaths, all I wanted was to help¡ªbut fate had other plans. My deepest regret? That no one would eat the delicious wrap waiting for me at home.

I was on the verge of tasting perfection¡ªmy hands still humming from the careful choreography of crafting that afternoon¡¯s masterpiece: a wrap layered with precision, seasoned with patience, every ingredient chosen like a note in a favorite song. It wasn¡¯t just lunch. It was ritual. And I had saved the first bite for last, savoring the anticipation like sunlight pooling on the kitchen floor.

Then¡ªsound became violence.

A scream tore through the house, raw and ragged, the kind that doesn¡¯t ask for attention¡ªit *claims* it. No thought. No pause. My body moved before my mind caught up, feet slapping against the tile in pursuit.

The bathroom door yawned open. Light glared off the floor, sterile and blinding. And there he stood¡ªa colossus carved from shadow and fury, one massive boot planted like a warhammer driven into stone, missing my face by a breath. Time fractured. I recoiled, limbs betraying me, but giants don¡¯t negotiate. They *execute*.

The second blow landed true.

It wasn¡¯t pain¡ªat first. It was collapse. A symphony of cracks spiraling through my exoskeleton, each joint surrendering like ancient timber under avalanche. I folded inward, a map crumpling at the edges. Life seeped out in quiet pulses, not gushing, but whispering goodbye. I trembled, clinging to the world by a thread of instinct, my thoughts dimming like lamps at dawn.

In those final flickers, clarity came¡ªnot of fear, not of rage¡ªbut of longing. A wish so small it ached: *Let someone eat the wrap.* Let that labor of love not go cold in vain. Let flavor survive me.

But silence answered. And the kitchen waited, unaware.

Greg Dyke, chairman of the English Football Association, said the reforms were ¡°more significant than the election itself,¡± underscoring their long-term importance for institutional change.

Reactions to Infantino¡¯s election were broadly positive. Gary Lineker, a longtime critic of FIFA¡¯s leadership, described him as ¡°a decent chap¡± but warned of the immense challenges ahead, quipping that Infantino might be ¡°Blatter in disguise.¡± Former Ballon d'Or winner Luis Figo hailed the result as ¡°the arrival of change.¡± Russian Sports Minister Vitaly Mutko praised Infantino as a ¡°pragmatist¡± suited to navigate the sport through turbulent times. Rainer Koch, interim president of the German Football Federation, welcomed the outcome, noting it preserved European influence in FIFA¡¯s leadership.

UEFA executive Karen Espelund called Infantino a ¡°clean winner¡± and a credible leader for a reformed FIFA. International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach expressed readiness to collaborate ¡°for the sake of sport,¡± while U.S. Soccer President Sunil Gulati congratulated the new president and affirmed American support for ongoing reform efforts.

Despite his defeat, Sheikh Salman pledged cooperation from the Asian Football Confederation, stating that ¡°football¡¯s credibility must be restored globally.¡± 

Blatter, 79, who served as FIFA president from 1998 until resigning under pressure last year, issued a formal statement congratulating Infantino. He commended the new leader¡¯s experience, strategic vision, and diplomatic acumen, saying he is ¡°well-equipped to stabilize FIFA once again.¡±

Infantino now inherits an organization still reeling from one of the worst corruption scandals in sports history. Ongoing investigations by U.S. and Swiss authorities have resulted in dozens of indictments, including against high-ranking FIFA officials. Questions also persist over the controversial awarding of the 2018 World Cup to Russia and the 2022 tournament to Qatar. Swiss prosecutors are currently reviewing more than 150 suspicious financial transactions linked to those bids and have shared internal documents with U.S. investigators.

BBC sports editor Dan Roan described the election as a critical juncture: ¡°FIFA came into today on the brink. Had it failed to elect a credible leader or pass essential reforms, calls to dissolve the organization altogether would have become impossible to ignore.¡±

While many in the football world may view the outcome as a relief, Roan cautioned that Infantino remains part of the existing power structure, having worked closely with the suspended Platini. ¡°He¡¯s seen as a fresh face, but he¡¯s no outsider,¡± Roan noted.

As FIFA embarks on this new era, all eyes will be on Infantino to deliver not just promises¡ªbut tangible change.

Thirty-five years have passed since that historic day¡ªone so vividly remembered by so many. What once sparked wonder and fulfilled a collective dream now often feels like distant history. When President Bush recently voiced hopes for a return to the Moon, the public response was largely indifferent. LLM_2:
**35 Years On: Remembering Humanity¡¯s First Steps on the Moon**

*¡°That¡¯s one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind.¡±*  
¡ª Neil Armstrong, July 20, 1969

In the quiet vastness of space, those words crackled through radios around the world, etching a moment into history that would echo for generations. It wasn¡¯t just an American achievement¡ªit was a human one.

As President Richard Nixon put it that day, ¡°For one priceless moment in the whole history of man, all the people on this Earth are truly one.¡± And indeed, in that instant, borders faded. Millions stood together, eyes turned skyward, united by awe and possibility.

Now, 35 years later, we look back at that summer day with a mix of reverence and nostalgia. The Apollo 11 landing¡ªa triumph of courage, science, and vision¡ªonce lit up our collective imagination like a beacon. Today, it risks becoming a footnote in textbooks, its magnitude dulled by time and familiarity.

When President Bush recently proposed returning to the Moon, the reaction was notably muted. No surge of excitement, no wave of public urgency. Why? Maybe because space no longer feels mysterious. Or perhaps Saturn¡¯s rings and Mars¡¯ red dunes seem more thrilling than revisiting our pale gray neighbor. After all, we¡¯ve seen the Moon before¡ªfrozen in grainy black-and-white footage, replayed across documentaries and school assemblies.

But let¡¯s not forget: July 20, 1969, changed everything.

It was the day Earthlings became spacefarers.  
The day a species took its first deliberate step beyond the cradle of our planet.  
The day the impossible became real.

That single footprint in the lunar dust opened the door to the cosmos¡ªnot just for astronauts, but for dreamers, scientists, and storytellers alike. It proved that with enough will and ingenuity, we could reach beyond the horizon.

So as we mark this anniversary, let¡¯s not just remember the mission. Let¡¯s rekindle the wonder. Because the story of the Moon isn¡¯t just about where we¡¯ve been¡ªit¡¯s about where we¡¯re bold enough to go next.

The proposed paper introduces a novel approach for amodal segmentation of objects that is an extension of Context-Aware Compositional Networks. In particular, the paper discusses the following extensions: (1) spatial priors are introduced to explicitly encode prior knowledge of object poses and shape, (2) the implementation of partial classification is discussed, (3) amodal completion from partial bounding boxes is explored, and (4) the implementation of amodal segmentation is explored by classifying visible and invisible regions.

Overall, I have the impression that this is an interesting paper that already has a few things going for it. The proposed extensions to CompositionalNets seem reasonable and are technically sound, the method is evaluated against two other methods, and the results are promising. Furthermore, the paper is mostly well-written and easy to follow. However, I have the following objections and therefore I am not in strong support of this work. In fact, it seems this work would benefit from a thorough revision prior to accepting it for publication: 

- Although well-written, the introduction seems convoluted as there is a disconnect between what is discussed in the paragraphs of the introduction and the list of contributions. When reading the list of contributions it felt like these were never mentioned before. 

- The contribution of the paper is mostly in exploring a few new strategies for improving upon CompositionalNet. This seems to be successful, but compared to existing work, the technical contributions are somewhat incremental. 

- The method does not discuss any limitations. As is, it is not clear in which situations the method fails or what cases the method cannot handle well. 

- The method was only evaluated to work on car object instances. So, it is not clear if the method will also work for other object categories; e.g. slender structures, like poles. Testing the method on more complex data would strengthen the paper.


Additional comments: 

- The first sentence in the introduction seems somewhat off: what is meant by 'our human visual system can localize and segment the visible part of objects'? This should be rephrased. 

- Intro (P3): the discussion on CompositionalNets is not clear. First the text states that CompositionalNets 'can robustly classify and detect objects under partial occlusions' and then it states that 'for obvious reasons, they are not sufficient'. This should be clarified. 

- Related Work: To provide a more thorough overview of related work, it may be useful to also discuss top-down (region proposal based) vs bottom-up (per-pixel embedding) instance segmentation approaches. 

-  RW (P2): the first sentence states: 'Observed in biological vision, pixel-level annotations are not necessary to accomplish object segmentation ...' What does that mean? 

- In Section 3 it is not clear what the contributions of the proposed paper are and what was introduced in previous work (Kortylewsk et al. 2020, Wang et al. 2020). To avoid this, an illustration of the network setup would help that clearly shows which components where introduced by other method and what is new. 

- For Figure 1 (b) it is not clear what an iteration is. 

- No details on the size of the dataset are provided. 

- It would be interesting to see more results (e.g. provided as supplementary material). 

- There are a few typos and missing spaces throughout the text (e.g. in front of 3) in the conclusion.
LLM_1:
The paper presents an extension of Context-Aware Compositional Networks for amodal segmentation, introducing four key components: (1) spatial priors to encode object pose and shape knowledge, (2) partial classification, (3) amodal completion from partial bounding boxes, and (4) classification of visible and invisible regions for segmentation. The approach is technically sound, well-motivated, and evaluated against two baselines with promising results. The manuscript is generally clear and well-structured. However, several concerns limit my support for acceptance in its current form.

First, the introduction lacks coherence between its narrative and the stated contributions¡ªkey innovations appear disconnected from earlier discussion and are not adequately foreshadowed. Second, while the proposed extensions improve upon CompositionalNets, their technical novelty is incremental relative to existing work. Third, the paper omits any discussion of method limitations, leaving unclear under what conditions performance may degrade or fail. Fourth, evaluation is limited to car instances, raising questions about generalization to other object categories, particularly slender or articulated structures such as poles; testing on a broader dataset would strengthen the claims.

Additional issues include: the opening sentence¡¯s reference to human vision localizing visible parts is imprecise and should be rephrased. In the introduction (p. 3), the claim that CompositionalNets handle occlusions robustly conflicts with the subsequent assertion that they are insufficient ¡°for obvious reasons¡±¡ªthis contradiction requires clarification. The related work section could be expanded to include a discussion of top-down versus bottom-up instance segmentation paradigms. The statement on biological vision implying pixel-level annotations are unnecessary (p. 2) is ambiguous and needs refinement. Section 3 fails to clearly distinguish prior work (Kortylewski et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2020) from new contributions¡ªan architectural diagram delineating novel components would help. Figure 1(b) lacks definition of ¡°iteration,¡± hindering interpretability. Dataset scale is unreported, limiting reproducibility. Including additional results, possibly in supplementary material, would enhance empirical support. Finally, minor typographical errors and missing spaces (e.g., before ¡°3¡± in the conclusion) should be corrected.
LLM_2:
The paper proposes an extension of Context-Aware Compositional Networks for amodal instance segmentation, introducing four main components: (1) spatial priors to model object pose and shape, (2) partial classification, (3) amodal completion from partial bounding boxes, and (4) joint classification of visible and invisible regions to improve segmentation. The method is well-motivated, technically sound, and demonstrates promising performance compared to two baseline approaches. The manuscript is generally clear in presentation and logically structured. Nevertheless, several substantive concerns prevent me from supporting acceptance in its current form.

First, the introduction does not effectively align the narrative flow with the stated contributions¡ªkey innovations are introduced without sufficient motivation or integration into the broader context, weakening the overall coherence. Second, while the proposed approach improves upon CompositionalNets, the technical advances appear incremental in relation to prior work; a more thorough discussion of how these extensions differ meaningfully from existing methods would strengthen the contribution. Third, the paper lacks a dedicated analysis of limitations, making it difficult to assess the robustness of the method under challenging conditions or failure modes. Fourth, evaluation is currently restricted to car instances, which raises valid concerns about generalization¡ªparticularly to elongated or articulated objects such as poles or animals. Extending experiments to additional categories, ideally on a more diverse dataset, would bolster the generality of the claims.

Several other issues merit attention. The opening sentence makes a vague reference to human vision localizing visible parts; this should be clarified or rephrased for precision. On page 3, there is an apparent contradiction between the claim that CompositionalNets handle occlusions robustly and the later assertion that they are insufficient ¡°for obvious reasons¡±¡ªthis discrepancy needs resolution. The related work section would benefit from a broader discussion, particularly contrasting top-down and bottom-up paradigms in instance segmentation. The statement suggesting that biological vision implies pixel-level annotations are unnecessary (page 2) is ambiguous and should be refined to avoid misinterpretation. Section 3 does not clearly delineate prior components from novel contributions¡ªincorporating an architectural diagram that highlights new modules would significantly improve clarity. In Figure 1(b), the term ¡°iteration¡± is used without definition, impairing interpretability. The scale of the dataset used is not reported, which hinders reproducibility. Including additional experimental results¡ªpotentially in supplementary material¡ªcould further strengthen the empirical validation. Finally, minor typographical issues, including missing spaces (e.g., before ¡°3¡± in the conclusion), should be corrected in the final version.

The authors propose an approach for calibrated predictions under domain shift scenarios. The approach, that leverages (unlabeled) test samples allows for unsupervised post-processing calibration, even for off-the-shelf models for which the training data is not available. Experiments compare the proposed approach with existing calibration methods in shifted domains.

Equation (5) is confusing. If I understand correctly, the authors are simply making the point that q(x,y=k) can be written in terms of q(x,y\neq k) by weighting by the ratio of conditionals, which are available.

Sensitivity to noisy labels. The experiment is reasonable and the results are convincing, however, the authors do not justify why accurate (manual) labels on the target set are not feasible in many applications. The authors could point to a few examples for context.

The authors assume that q_s(y) = q_t(y), which seems restrictive in practice. Though it does not impact my opinion of the proposed approach, it seems narrow to think of a practical situation where the space of covariates is changing but the class composition remains unchanged. This is vaguely addressed in Section 6. Perhaps it can be elaborated further.

I enjoyed reading the paper, the proposed reinterpretation of NLL in terms of a weighted average and its approximation based on weights that do not depend on the labels but the (assumed known) labels marginal is interesting and seems to yield good results.
LLM_1:
The authors propose a method for calibrated predictions under domain shift, leveraging unlabeled test samples to enable unsupervised post-hoc calibration¡ªeven for pre-trained models without access to training data. Experiments demonstrate performance improvements over existing calibration techniques in distribution-shifted settings.

Equation (5) is unclear as written. If correctly interpreted, the authors intend to express $ q(x, y=k) $ in terms of $ q(x, y  eq k) $ using the ratio of conditional probabilities, which are assumed available. Clarification would improve readability.

While the experiment on sensitivity to noisy labels is sound and results are compelling, the authors should justify why manual labeling in the target domain is often impractical. Providing concrete examples would strengthen the motivation.

The assumption $ q_s(y) = q_t(y) $¡ªequal class marginals across source and target domains¡ªis limiting in real-world scenarios where covariate shift often co-occurs with changes in class distribution. Although briefly discussed in Section 6, this restriction warrants further discussion and potential relaxation.

The reinterpretation of NLL as a weighted average, and its approximation using weights based on the (assumed known) marginal label distribution, is insightful and well-executed. This perspective is both theoretically interesting and empirically effective, contributing to the paper¡¯s impact.
LLM_2:
The authors present a novel method for achieving calibrated predictions under domain shift, leveraging unlabeled test data to perform unsupervised, post-hoc calibration¡ªeven applicable to pre-trained models without access to training data. Experimental results show consistent improvements over existing calibration approaches in settings involving distributional shift, demonstrating the practical value of the proposed approach.

Equation (5) requires clarification. As currently written, it is difficult to interpret the intended relationship between $ q(x, y=k) $ and $ q(x, y  eq k) $. If the authors' intent is to express one in terms of the other using the ratio of conditional class probabilities¡ªwhich are assumed to be available¡ªthen a more precise formulation or accompanying explanation would significantly enhance readability and understanding.

The evaluation of robustness to noisy labels is well-designed and yields compelling results. However, the motivation would benefit from further elaboration: the authors should more explicitly justify why manual labeling in the target domain is often infeasible in practice. Concrete real-world examples would strengthen this argument and better situate the problem¡¯s relevance.

The assumption that $ q_s(y) = q_t(y) $, i.e., that class marginals remain invariant across source and target domains, may be overly restrictive in many practical applications. In real-world scenarios, covariate shift frequently coincides with shifts in label distributions. While this limitation is briefly acknowledged in Section 6, it deserves deeper discussion¡ªincluding potential strategies for relaxing the assumption or extending the method to handle such cases.

A key strength of the paper lies in its insightful reinterpretation of the negative log-likelihood (NLL) as a weighted average of per-class losses, with weights derived from the (assumed known) marginal label distribution. This perspective is both theoretically sound and empirically effective, providing a principled foundation for the proposed calibration framework. The clarity and utility of this formulation represent a significant contribution to the work¡¯s overall impact.

human: This study was designed to test the hypothesis that ischemic mitral regurgitation (IMR) results from, but does not influence, the progression of left ventricular (LV) remodeling after posterolateral infarction.Surgical correction of chronic IMR is being increasingly recommended.Three groups of sheep had coronary snares placed around the second and third obtuse marginal coronary arteries. Occlusion of these vessels in the control group resulted in progressive IMR over eight weeks. In a second group, Merseline mesh was fitted to cover the exposed LV before infarction. In a third group, a ring annuloplasty was placed before infarction to prevent IMR. Remodeling and degree of IMR were assessed with echocardiography at baseline and at 30 min and two, five, and eight weeks after infarction.Eight weeks after infarction, mean IMR grade was significantly higher in control animals than mesh and annuloplasty animals. At eight weeks, LV end-systolic volume and end-systolic muscle-to-cavity-area ratio (ESMCAR) were significantly better in mesh-treated sheep than in control sheep; also, at eight weeks, ESMCAR and akinetic segment length were significantly better in mesh-treated sheep than in annuloplasty sheep. Ejection fraction was significantly higher in the mesh than the annuloplasty group. There was no significant difference in any measure of remodeling between the annuloplasty and control groups.
LLM_1: This study tested the hypothesis that ischemic mitral regurgitation (IMR) is a consequence rather than a contributor to left ventricular (LV) remodeling following posterolateral infarction. Three groups of sheep underwent placement of coronary snares around the second and third obtuse marginal arteries; infarction was induced in the control group, while the other groups received either Mersiline mesh covering the LV or ring annuloplasty prior to infarction to prevent IMR. Echocardiography assessed remodeling and IMR at baseline and at 30 minutes, 2, 5, and 8 weeks post-infarction. At 8 weeks, IMR grade was significantly lower in mesh and annuloplasty groups compared to controls. Mesh-treated animals showed significantly better LV end-systolic volume and end-systolic muscle-to-cavity-area ratio (ESMCAR) than controls, and superior ESMCAR and shorter akinetic segment length compared to annuloplasty animals. Ejection fraction was significantly higher in the mesh group than in the annuloplasty group. No significant differences in remodeling parameters were observed between the annuloplasty and control groups, indicating that preventing IMR alone does not attenuate LV remodeling, whereas mechanical constraint with mesh reduces both IMR and adverse remodeling.
LLM_2: This study investigated whether ischemic mitular regurgitation (IMR) is a consequence rather than a primary driver of left ventricular (LV) remodeling following posterolateral myocardial infarction. Using a sheep model, three groups were subjected to coronary snare placement around the second and third obtuse marginal arteries, with infarction induced in all groups. Prior to infarction, prophylactic interventions¡ªleft ventricular reinforcement with Mersiline mesh or ring annuloplasty¡ªwere applied in two experimental groups to prevent IMR development, while the control group received no intervention. Serial echocardiographic assessments were conducted at baseline and at 30 minutes, 2, 5, and 8 weeks post-infarction to evaluate LV remodeling dynamics and IMR severity. At 8 weeks, both mesh and annuloplasty groups exhibited significantly lower grades of IMR compared to controls. Notably, animals treated with mesh demonstrated superior preservation of LV geometry, as evidenced by reduced end-systolic volume, improved end-systolic muscle-to-cavity area ratio (ESMCAR), shorter akinetic segment length, and higher ejection fraction relative to both control and annuloplasty groups. In contrast, no significant differences in structural remodeling parameters were observed between the annuloplasty and control groups. These findings suggest that while surgical prevention of IMR alone does not mitigate adverse LV remodeling, mechanical restraint via epicardial mesh limits both IMR development and progressive ventricular dilation, supporting the hypothesis that IMR is predominantly a secondary phenomenon in the context of infarction-induced LV dysfunction.

human:
Summary: 
The paper investigates using the transformer architecture for neural network-based lossless compression of text. The resulting model, obtained through a thorough investigation of the architecture hyper-parameters are on par with standard SOTA compression. The paper is well-written. In particular the authors have done a great job reviewing existing compression literature and positioning their method within the space of prior work.

Recommendation: Weak Reject
While the paper considers an interesting application of the Transformer architecture, and is well-written, it is of limited novelty. Specifically, the bulk of the paper is concerned with describing experimental results of a thorough (but standard) hyper-parameter search - considering things like Transformer context size, learning rate (schedule), number of layers and key, value, query dimensionality; and does not offer any new architectural modifications / insights.

Furthermore, only a single dataset - enwik8 - is considered in the experimental validation and little attention is given to the description of the dataset split and any distribution differences between splits. Taken together, the existing experimental setup potentially creates an unfair advantage for the neural network-based methods - while the standard methods can be expected to perform similarly across a wide range of datasets / texts, the neural-network based methods have been trained and tested on very similar data and could be expected to perform well on these data, but not in case of a distributional shift (e.g. compressing legal texts instead of Wikipedia). The paper does not answer the question of whether or not this is true.

Furthermore, similar to autoregressive models, transformers are known to be slow at inference time. I expect this to lead to very slow decoding. Therefore, methods in table 1 should be compared in compression/decompression time to give a better overview of the practical impact of this work. 

Taken together, in its current form the paper may be better suited for a workshop publication rather than a full conference paper.

Major comments:
1. For reasons mentioned above, the paper should include additional experimental evaluation. In particular, it should consider the effect of training the model on one dataset, but evaluating it on another dataset; and discuss how differences in performance (if any) compare to standard methods.
2. Compression/decompression times of the proposed method should be compared against the other compression methods in table 1. I expect the proposed transformer to be slow at decompressing.
3. The paper does not contain the loss that the transformer model was used to optimize. I assume that it is the softmax cross entropy, but this is worth mentioning explicitly. It would also be worthwhile to explain the training procedure - for how many epochs was the model trained (see also next question), what was the dataset size? 
4. Description of the ¡°training with revisits¡± is not very clear. My understanding is that it resembles a pass through the data, where some of it is considered again at specific intervals. My first assessment is that this should not be necessary - the data should already be considered multiple times during the training process.
a) The authors should provide a more detailed description of the training-with-revisits procedure, contrasting it specifically with a procedure where revisits are not done (i.e. normal training).
b) If the goal of the revisits training is to observe some training examples more than once, then it would be very interesting if simply training for a longer time (several epochs == passes through the data) has a similar effect.
c) Is there any motivation for the choice of the revisits hyper-parameters F and M? Was a different batch size used during the revisits training? Is the learning rate evolved during the revisits training phase or is it still decayed?

Minor comments:
1. There is some prior work on using Neural Networks for lossless image compression (e.g. [1], [2]. [3] that achieves SOTA compression ratios compared to standard methods. It may be interesting for the readers to mention these results. In particular the authors¡¯ statement that ¡°[...] purely neural network based models are still far from state of the art [...]¡± may give the wrong impression to the readers.
2. The authors mention that they ¡°[...] propose several improvements to its (the Transformer) architecture and training to accelerate and stabilize [...] training¡±. In my view, the experiments described in the paper resemble a hyper-parameter search more than architectural improvements. The authors may want to clarify in the text which specific improvements they refer to.
3. Page 1, last paragraph: ¡°[...] of all the important component [...]¡± -> ¡°[...] of all the important components [...]¡±
4. Page 3: ¡°[...] attention span size across all layers as it suggested [...]¡± -> ¡°[...] attention span size across all layers as was suggested [...]¡±
5. Page 3: Missing references.
6. Page 3: Use of small n and capital N when talking about n-grams. Should be made consistent.
7. Page 8 (Conclusion): ¡°wihtout¡± -> ¡°without¡±


[1] F. H. Kingma, P. Abbeel, and J. Ho. Bit-Swap: recursive bits-back coding for lossless compression with hierarchical latent variables. In International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), 2019.
[2] Emiel Hoogeboom, Jorn W. T. Peters, Rianne van den Berg, and Max Welling. Integer Discrete Flows and Lossless Compression. arXiv e-prints, 2019.
[3] Jonathan Ho, Evan Lohn, and Pieter Abbeel. Compression with Flows via Local Bits-Back Coding. arXiv e-prints, 2019.
LLM_1:
Summary:  
This paper explores the use of transformer architectures for neural network-based lossless text compression. Through a comprehensive hyper-parameter analysis, the authors achieve performance competitive with standard state-of-the-art methods. The manuscript is well-written and includes a thorough review of prior work, effectively situating the approach within existing literature.

Recommendation: Weak Reject  
While the application of transformers to lossless compression is interesting and the presentation is clear, the work lacks sufficient novelty for a full conference publication. The core contribution consists largely of a systematic hyper-parameter search¡ªcovering context size, learning rate schedules, number of layers, and key/query/value dimensions¡ªwithout introducing new architectural innovations or conceptual insights.

The experimental evaluation is limited to a single dataset, enwik8, with insufficient detail on data splits and potential distributional overlap between training and test sets. This setup may favor neural models that exploit dataset-specific patterns, raising concerns about generalization¡ªparticularly under distribution shift (e.g., when compressing legal or technical texts). The paper does not assess whether performance degrades in such scenarios, nor does it compare against standard compressors under diverse domains.

Additionally, given the autoregressive nature of the model, inference is expected to be slow. Yet, no decompression time measurements are reported. A practical assessment must include compression and decompression speeds relative to baseline methods (Table 1), as speed is critical for real-world applicability.

For these reasons, the current version is more appropriate for a workshop than a top-tier conference.

Major Comments:  
1. Expand evaluation to include cross-dataset testing: train on one domain (e.g., Wikipedia) and evaluate on others (e.g., legal, code, or biomedical text). Compare how performance shifts relative to classical compressors to assess robustness and generalization.
2. Report compression and decompression times for the proposed model and baselines in Table 1. This is essential for evaluating practical utility.
3. Clarify the training objective and procedure: explicitly state the loss function (e.g., softmax cross-entropy), number of training epochs, total dataset size, and batch configuration. These details are currently missing.
4. The ¡°training with revisits¡± strategy requires clarification:
   a) Provide a precise description and contrast it with standard multi-epoch training without revisits.
   b) Investigate whether similar gains can be achieved by simply increasing the number of epochs, which would question the necessity of the revisit mechanism.
   c) Justify the choice of hyper-parameters F and M; specify whether batch size or learning rate scheduling differs during revisit phases.

Minor Comments:  
1. Cite recent work on neural lossless image compression (e.g., [1], [2], [3]), where purely neural methods achieve state-of-the-art results. This contextualizes the claim that ¡°purely neural network based models are still far from state of the art,¡± which may mislead readers given advances in other modalities.
2. Revise the statement about ¡°architectural improvements¡± to accurately reflect that the experiments primarily involve hyper-parameter tuning rather than structural modifications.
3. Page 1, last paragraph: change ¡°component¡± to ¡°components.¡±
4. Page 3: correct ¡°as it suggested¡± to ¡°as was suggested.¡±
5. Page 3: Add missing references.
6. Page 3: Standardize notation for n-grams using consistent capitalization (preferably lowercase *n*).
7. Page 8 (Conclusion): correct ¡°wihtout¡± to ¡°without.¡±

[1] D. P. Kingma, P. Abbeel, and J. Ho. Bit-Swap: recursive bits-back coding for lossless compression with hierarchical latent variables. In *International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML)*, 2019.  
[2] E. Hoogeboom, J. W. T. Peters, R. van den Berg, and M. Welling. Integer Discrete Flows and Lossless Compression. *arXiv preprint arXiv:1905.07376*, 2019.  
[3] J. Ho, E. Lohn, and P. Abbeel. Compression with Flows via Local Bits-Back Coding. *arXiv preprint arXiv:1905.08054*, 2019.
LLM_2:
**  
This paper investigates the application of transformer architectures to neural lossless text compression, conducting an extensive hyper-parameter analysis to achieve performance on par with current state-of-the-art methods. The manuscript is clearly written and provides a solid overview of related work, effectively positioning the approach within the broader context of neural compression research.

**Recommendation: Weak Reject**  
While the topic is timely and the presentation is coherent, the work falls short in terms of conceptual novelty required for acceptance at a top-tier conference. The primary contribution centers on a systematic exploration of hyper-parameters¡ªsuch as context length, learning rate schedules, layer depth, and attention dimensionality¡ªrather than introducing new architectural designs or algorithmic advances. Although such empirical studies are valuable, they do not constitute sufficient innovation for a full oral presentation unless accompanied by deeper insights or generalizable principles.

The evaluation is also narrow in scope, focusing exclusively on the enwik8 dataset without detailed clarification of train/validation/test splits. This lack of transparency raises concerns about potential data leakage or overfitting to idiosyncratic patterns in the data. Given that neural models can exploit statistical regularities specific to Wikipedia-derived text, the absence of cross-domain evaluation undermines claims of broad effectiveness. There is no assessment of performance on out-of-distribution domains such as legal, scientific, or source code texts, nor any comparison with classical compressors (e.g., LZMA, BSC) in these settings.

Furthermore, due to the autoregressive nature of the model, inference is inherently sequential and likely slow. However, the authors omit measurements of decompression speed¡ªa critical metric for real-world deployment. A complete benchmark should report both compression and decompression times alongside compression ratios (e.g., in Table 1), enabling meaningful trade-off analysis against established baselines.

Given these limitations, the current submission would be better suited for a workshop venue focused on empirical deep learning or data compression, where methodological rigor and reproducibility are emphasized even in the absence of major theoretical breakthroughs.

---

**Major Comments:**  

1. **Expand evaluation to include cross-domain generalization.**  
   To assess robustness, conduct experiments where the model is trained on one domain (e.g., Wikipedia) and evaluated on others (e.g., legal documents, source code, biomedical literature). Compare how performance degrades relative to traditional compressors across these domains. This will clarify whether the gains are attributable to modeling general linguistic structure or merely memorizing domain-specific artifacts.

2. **Report compression and decompression latency.**  
   Include timing metrics¡ªparticularly decompression speed¡ªfor both the proposed model and baseline methods in Table 1. Speed is a key determinant of practical utility, especially for streaming or interactive applications. Without this information, it is impossible to evaluate the model¡¯s viability beyond raw compression ratio.

3. **Clarify training protocol and objective function.**  
   Explicitly state the loss function used (e.g., softmax cross-entropy over vocabulary), total number of training epochs, overall dataset size, and batch configuration (e.g., batch size per GPU, gradient accumulation steps). These details are currently missing but essential for reproducibility.

4. **Provide a rigorous analysis of the ¡°training with revisits¡± strategy:**  
   a) Formally define the revisit mechanism and contrast it with standard multi-epoch training. Explain how sequences are resampled or reordered during revisit phases.  
   b) Conduct ablation studies to determine whether comparable improvements can be achieved by simply increasing the number of epochs, which would challenge the necessity of the revisit design.  
   c) Justify the selection of hyper-parameters $ F $ (frequency) and $ M $ (multiplier): were they tuned? If so, over what range? Additionally, clarify whether optimization settings (e.g., batch size, learning rate schedule) differ between initial and revisit phases.

---

**Minor Comments:**  

1. Update the discussion on neural compression to reflect recent progress in other modalities. Specifically, cite recent works on neural *image* compression (e.g., [1], [2], [3]), where purely learned models have already surpassed conventional codecs. This nuance is important when claiming that ¡°purely neural network based models are still far from state of the art,¡± as that statement does not hold uniformly across domains.

2. Revise the phrasing around ¡°architectural improvements¡± to accurately reflect that the study primarily involves hyper-parameter optimization rather than structural modifications to the transformer. A more precise description would strengthen the paper¡¯s credibility.

3. Page 1, last paragraph: change ¡°component¡± to ¡°components¡± for grammatical agreement.

4. Page 3: correct ¡°as it suggested¡± to ¡°as was suggested.¡±

5. Page 3: Add missing citations referenced in the text (e.g., for prior work on n-gram models and entropy coding).

6. Page 3: Standardize notation for *n*-grams using italicized lowercase (*n*) throughout the manuscript for consistency.

7. Page 8 (Conclusion): correct typo ¡°wihtout¡± ¡ú ¡°without.¡±

---

**References**  
[1] D. P. Kingma, P. Abbeel, and J. Ho. Bit-Swap: recursive bits-back coding for lossless compression with hierarchical latent variables. In *International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML)*, 2019.  
[2] E. Hoogeboom, J. W. T. Peters, R. van den Berg, and M. Welling. Integer Discrete Flows and Lossless Compression. *arXiv preprint arXiv:1905.07376*, 2019.  
[3] J. Ho, E. Lohn, and P. Abbeel. Compression with Flows via Local Bits-Back Coding. *arXiv preprint arXiv:1905.08054*, 2019.

It must've been when I was eight years old that I realized something was different about me. We were on a school field trip to the local zoo, and things were going normal. We saw strange types of fish, birds that did n't interest me much, reptiles that looked a little bigger than they should've been, and lemurs that stared with large eyes. We saw flamingos sleeping with their heads upside down, snakes that hardly moved, and a lazy bear wacking a plant. 
 
 It was n't until we got to the lions that I noticed something was off. I always liked seeing the lions because of the way they looked at you. They stared at you with such an intensity that if they ran up convinced that they would eat you, you'd probably believe it, despite the thick glass between you and it. But that was the thing, I did n't run away when it came up. The other kids and I stared in awe at the female lion, admiring her intimidating eyes. She stared back at us, and eventually creeped over towards the glass. She moved slowly, as moving slower made it harder for us to see her. When she got close enough to the glass, she leaped, her whole body smacking up against the glass. 
 
 It was at that moment that I realized something was different about me. Because all the other kids screamed and ran away, and I just stood there, not thinking anything of it. I did n't flinch. My heart did n't go one beat faster. I was n't scared at all, and I knew I should have been. 
 
 -- -- 
 
 At nineteen I was the same in that way, just twice as old. It was time for me to go in the cave, the cave that every nineteen year old dreaded but still had to enter. It was designed to help you face your deepest fear and get over it. `` It's necessary for adulthood,'' our instructor told us as we hiked up the path towards it. 
 
 The guy in front of me puked, probably out of anxiety. Yet I felt nothing. I wished that I felt something; I wished that I could be nervous like the others. Of course, I'd gotten good at acting afraid. Over the years, I observed what other people my age found scary, and pretended to get spooked over the same stuff. It was difficult, and kind of left me empty, but it worked. 
 
 We reached the cave, breathing a bit harder than normal from the steep walk. Our instructor turned around with her clipboard and read off of paper. `` I will now call your names in order alphabetically. You will show me your drivers license and birth certificate, and then place your belonging in the second to the left of me.'' She pointed to a box on the ground made out of red spray paint, and then continued. `` First up, Adam Terrell?'' 
 
 That was me. I put my best scared-but-trying-to-act-brave face on and moved to the front. I always found that face a bit humorous. Upon showing her my required identifications and placing my stuff in the marked off spot, I faced the cave. 
 
 When I entered, I was n't surprised to find it empty. I waited for a few minutes, bored yet a little curious, and still nothing came. It was just me and the darkness. I sighed and sat down on the ground. Figuring I would have to come out looking a little troubled, I made fake tears come onto my cheeks and messed up my hair a little bit. The thought crossed my mind to give out some screams, but I decided not too. It would've been too awkward. 
 
 After what felt like ten minutes, I got up and left the cave, feeling like I stayed in for a decent amount of time. With dried tears and a determined look on my face, I came out to the other people, and they gave me a brief clap. 
 
 We had to stay until the other people were done, and it did n't take as long as I figured it would. I hung towards the back of the group so that I would n't have to share a fake experience with anyone. Unfortunately, another girl hung back too. 
 
 `` Was it hard, getting those fake tears to come out?'' She asked me. `` Or have you gotten used to doing it?'' 
 
 `` What do you --'' I started, but she interrupted. 
 
 `` You saw nothing in that cave. I know you did.'' 
 
 I tried to deny it, but it was no use. 
 
 `` It's okay,'' she told me, `` I did n't see anything either.''

But it was the lions that revealed the truth.

I¡¯d always been drawn to them¡ªtheir gaze had weight, a primal intensity that made you believe, just for a second, they could break through the glass and take you. ¡ª

When I emerged, eyes red-washed and expression resolute, the group offered a quiet clap.

We lingered until the others finished. I kept to the back, avoiding conversation¡ªuntil a girl stayed behind too.

¡°What do you¡ª¡± I began.

LLM_2:
It must have been the summer I turned eight when I first felt the quiet rift between myself and the rest of the world.

We were on a school trip to the city zoo¡ªdusty pavement underfoot, the air thick with heat and the sour-sweet smell of animal feed. We shuffled past tanks of glassy-eyed fish, birds that preened without interest, reptiles coiled like ancient secrets too big for their enclosures. Lemurs stared with round, unblinking eyes, as if they knew something we didn¡¯t. Flamingos slept upside down, limbs tangled in impossible angles. A bear pawed listlessly at the leaves, its movements slow with boredom or despair.

But then came the lions.

I had always been drawn to them¡ªnot just their power, but the stillness beneath it, the way their gaze seemed to hold centuries inside it. One look, and you could believe they weren¡¯t caged. That *we* were the ones outside the glass.

That day, the female stirred.

She moved like smoke¡ªlow, silent, deliberate. Then, without warning, she lunged. Her body struck the barrier with a crack that echoed through the walkway. Children shrieked. Some fell back. Others bolted, hands over mouths, eyes wide with real fear.

I stood perfectly still.

No tremor in my hands. No hitch in my breath. My heart beat steady, calm, indifferent. I waited for the surge¡ªthe jolt of terror that should have followed¡ªbut it never came. I watched her golden eyes, fierce and knowing, and wondered if she saw me too. Not just my face pressed against the glass, but the hollow beneath my ribs where fear was supposed to live.

And for the first time, I understood: it wasn¡¯t there.

¡ª

By nineteen, I had become an expert in disguise.

The cave awaited us all¡ªa rite carved into stone and silence, a ritual meant to strip away childhood and leave behind someone whole, tested, *real*. ¡°It¡¯s necessary,¡± our instructor repeated, voice echoing off the cliffside as we climbed the narrow path. The wind carried the scent of damp earth and pine, and the boy ahead of me retched into the bushes, his body shaking.

I envied him.

Not for the sickness, but for the feeling¡ªany feeling¡ªthat could rise so violently, so honestly, from within. I would have given anything to feel it too. But my chest remained smooth, untouched, like water undisturbed by rain.

Over the years, I¡¯d learned to wear fear like a borrowed coat. I studied flinches, memorized gasps, rehearsed the slight tremble of a lip. I mimicked panic with precision, performed courage with practiced ease. It fooled everyone. And still, each performance left me emptier than before.

At the mouth of the cave, she called names in order. ¡°Adam Terrell?¡±

I stepped forward.

Face composed. Shoulders tense in just the right way. Eyes wide with the careful balance of dread and determination. I handed over my ID. Placed my things in the box. Turned toward the dark.

Inside¡ªnothing.

No visions. No voices. No monsters rising from shadow. Just silence, deep and total, pressing in like a held breath. I waited. Listened. Felt¡­ nothing at all.

After a while, I sat. Leaned against the wall. Watched the darkness as if it might finally yield something. When no revelation came, I staged my return.

I tousled my hair. Smudged dirt across my temple. Let fake tears gather at the corners of my eyes¡ªjust enough to catch the light, not so much as to seem theatrical. I almost screamed at the end, for effect, but decided against it. Too loud. Too false.

When I emerged, pale and shaken, the group offered soft applause¡ªsympathetic, proud. I nodded, wiped my cheek, played the part of the survivor.

We waited as the others went in and came out transformed. I stayed at the edge, arms crossed, saying little¡ªuntil one girl lingered beside me.

¡°Were the tears hard?¡± she asked, voice low. ¡°Or did you stop noticing a long time ago?¡±

I opened my mouth to lie.

¡°You saw nothing,¡± she said. ¡°I know you didn¡¯t.¡±

My pulse didn¡¯t quicken. Not even then. But something deeper shifted¡ªsomething long buried stirred.

¡°I don¡¯t know what you mean,¡± I whispered.

She smiled, faint and sad. ¡°Yes, you do.¡±

A pause. The wind brushed past, carrying the scent of stone and distance.

¡°It¡¯s okay,¡± she said. ¡°I didn¡¯t either.¡±

And in that moment, for the first time, I didn¡¯t feel alone. Not because we were broken the same way, but because we had both walked through the dark¡ªand found, not terror, but ourselves.

**U.S. and Soviet Spacecraft Prepare for Historic Rendezvous in 1975 Apollo-Soyuz Mission**

In a landmark step toward Cold War cooperation, the United States and the Soviet Union are preparing to carry out the first international docking of manned spacecraft under the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project (ASTP). The mission, set for 1975, will bring together the final flight of America¡¯s Apollo program and a Soviet Soyuz capsule in a symbolic handshake in orbit.

To make the link-up possible, NASA developed a specially designed docking module that serves a dual purpose: it acts as both an adapter and an airlock. This was critical due to fundamental differences in cabin atmospheres¡ªthe Apollo operated on pure oxygen at low pressure, while the Soyuz used an Earth-like nitrogen-oxygen mix. Without this bridge, direct crew transfer would be impossible.

The docking module also marks a technological alignment between two spacefaring nations long divided by ideology and engineering standards. Notably, the device is compatible with the Soviet probe-and-drogue docking system¡ªa design already proven across their fleet and used for missions linking Soyuz craft with Salyut space stations.

Ahead of the joint flight, the Soviet Union successfully tested key systems during the Soyuz 16 mission in December 1974. That uncrewed rehearsal validated environmental controls, docking mechanisms, and other critical components essential for the upcoming encounter in space.

When the two spacecraft meet, the mission will not only demonstrate technical interoperability but also signal a new era of collaboration in human spaceflight¡ªone where former rivals work side by side beyond Earth¡¯s atmosphere.

A survey of Loe Pool, near Porthleven, has revealed images believed to be debris of a plane and a floating target used during the Second World War.
Exeter University's Camborne School of Mines used sonar technology to produce images of the bottom of the lake.
Project leader Neill Wood spoke of a "huge amount of interesting debris from many thousand years of history".
Loe Pool is Cornwall's largest natural lake and is on the National Trust's Penrose Estate stretching across 50 acres.
Mr Wood said: "There's a lot of debris which looks to originate from World War II, ranging from pieces of barbed wire through to what may be a floating target for the development of anti-U-boat rockets.
"There's very large pieces of debris in an area where it's believed an aircraft went down in or just after World War II, so that's really quite exciting.
"In a way it's like looking at a crime scene, but now we have to piece together what's actually happening here".
Mike Hardy, of the National Trust, said the survey was "really helping to build our understanding of the pool, the history, how it works and helping us to plan our conservation work".
Mr Hardy has heard stories of people seeing a plane coming across the bar and crashing into the pool around the time of the war.
He said: "To make that link potentially between that incident and one person's life and their research is amazing and fascinating."

A groundbreaking sonar survey of Loe Pool¡ªthe largest natural lake in Cornwall¡ªhas revealed what researchers believe to be the submerged wreckage of a World War II-era aircraft, along with remnants of a floating target used in the development of anti-submarine rockets.

The underwater scan, carried out by experts from the Camborne School of Mines at the University of Exeter, identified extensive debris scattered across the 50-acre site, which is managed by the National Trust on the historic Penrose Estate. Among the findings were barbed wire, large unidentifiable metallic objects, and structural fragments consistent with wartime military activity.

Project lead Dr. Neill Wood described the site as a complex archaeological puzzle. ¡°We¡¯ve found a huge amount of interesting debris spanning thousands of years,¡± he said, ¡°but the most striking elements are clearly linked to the Second World War.¡± One area of particular focus is where local legend has long suggested a plane crashed during or shortly after the war. ¡°It¡¯s like looking at a crime scene,¡± Wood explained. ¡°We can see the evidence, but now we need to reconstruct the story¡ªwhat exactly happened here, when, and under what circumstances.¡±

The discovery adds significant new detail to the wartime history of the region. The floating target structure likely played a role in testing rocket systems designed to combat German U-boats¡ªa crucial component of Britain¡¯s coastal defense strategy during the war.

Mike Hardy, representing the National Trust, emphasized the importance of the findings for both historical understanding and environmental stewardship. ¡°This survey not only deepens our knowledge of Loe Pool¡¯s layered past but also informs how we manage and conserve this unique ecosystem,¡± he said. He noted that oral histories from local residents have long referenced a wartime crash into the lake, making the potential confirmation through scientific investigation ¡°both amazing and deeply fascinating.¡±

Further analysis is underway to confirm the identity of the aircraft and assess the full extent of the submerged material. The results could lead to formal recognition of the site as a protected historical location, blending heritage preservation with ongoing conservation efforts.

I've never been more scared or lonely in my life. Everyone is out to kill me. 
 
 I have no friends. 
 
 It was n't like this yesterday. 
 
 Had I known what the experiment would result in, had I known it was irreversible I would never have gone through with it. 
 
 Admittedly, I was the most logical choice. 
 
 Pity I'm the only one who will ever know the full results. 
 
 Those on the other side will only ever know that removing your reflection from a mirror does, in fact, allow you to walk through. 
 
 They will be able to surmise that it's a one way trip. 
 
 They'll never know what truly awaits. 
 
 These will be my last words. 
 
 I do n't often walk through mirrors, but when I do, I regret it.
LLM_1:
I¡¯ve never known fear or loneliness like this. Everyone wants me dead, and I have no one to turn to.  

It wasn¡¯t like this yesterday.  

If I¡¯d known the experiment was irreversible, I¡¯d have refused¡ªno hesitation.  

Still, I was the logical choice. The only one who could go through with it.  

And now, I¡¯m the only one who¡¯ll ever know what lies beyond.  

They¡¯ll discover soon enough that removing your reflection lets you walk through the glass. They¡¯ll deduce it¡¯s a one-way journey.  

But they¡¯ll never learn what waits on the other side.  

These are my final words.  

I don¡¯t often step through mirrors¡ªbut when I do, I regret it instantly.
LLM_2:
I have never known a terror so hollow, a solitude so complete. The world has turned its face against me¡ªevery hand raised in pursuit, every voice chanting for my end¡ªand there is no ear that listens, no shoulder to bear the weight of what I¡¯ve become.

Yesterday, the sun rose like any other.  

Had I understood the cost¡ªthe permanence¡ªI would have said no without pause. Without breath.  

But they needed a volunteer, and logic has no heart. I was the only one willing to step into the unknown. The only one who could endure it.  

And now, I am also the only one who will carry the truth back¡­ or rather, the only one who cannot return to speak of it.

They¡¯ll figure out soon enough what happens when you pull your reflection from the glass. They¡¯ll trace the equations, run the simulations, and finally grasp that yes¡ªyou can pass through. But they¡¯ll also learn, coldly and irrevocably, that once you cross, there¡¯s no coming home.

What they won¡¯t know¡ªwhat *no one* will ever know¡ªis what waits in that silent, mirrored world beyond. The stillness. The shapes that move just outside sight. The whispers that sound like echoes of yourself, but aren¡¯t.

These words are my last anchor to this side.  

I don¡¯t make a habit of walking through mirrors.  
But each time I do, I realize too late: the reflection wasn¡¯t mine to take.

### Positives

**(Mostly) well-motivated approach to detecting distribution shift**:  This paper adapts the well-founded techniques of Bayesian hypothesis testing to deep generative models.  As detecting distribution shift with DGMs, ideally, requires fast, per-point evaluation, this method seems to provide just that.  Although, see my question / critique regarding identifiability below.

**Tuning computational overhead**:  As Figure 2 demonstrates, the method seems to work well¡ªor even a bit better¡ªwhen using a low-rank approximation to the Hessian matrix.  This allows the user to tune the method's computational overhead to fit the application.  This is important as detecting distribution shift often must be done in real time.  

### Critiques / Questions

**Local approximation and its validity for overparameterized models**:  While the motivating Bayesian hypothesis testing framework is undoubtedly motivated for well-identified models, it seems like identifiability could be an issue for deep generative models.  In neural networks, we know that there are often directions in parameter space around local minima that can leave the resulting model unchanged [[Maddox et al.; 2020]](https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.02139).  Thus, are parameterization issues such as this a worry when applying this test to deep generative models?  How do we know the local perturbation method won't detect these directions, thinking there is indeed distribution shift, while the model is actually invariant?  

**Why is the AUROC best at around 30 eigenvalues?:**  I was surprised to see that the test's performance doesn't improve monotonically with the rank of the approximation.  Do you have any idea why this is?  You mention that the Hessian is sparse, explaining the good performance at low rank, but I don't think this would explain why performance degrades a bit as rank increases.  Could this possibly be due to the "spurious" directions in parameter space I mention above?

**Remainder term in Proposition 1**:  Prop 1, how is the remainder term resolved?  Equation 12 is stated as an approximation, and I see how the 1/n term implies a good approximation when the data set is large.  But how do we know that the remainder term also can go to zero?  It seems like the paper is concerned about the convergence of the first and second order terms without discussing when they dominate the remainder?

**Discussion of score matching and [Sharma et al. (UAI 2021)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.12567)**: The paper is light in its discussion of previous work on OOD detection for deep generative models, and there is no Related Work section.  I think previous work on score matching and the Fisher information approach of Sharma et al. [UAI 2021] should be discussed as I see these as related methods, using perturbations of the log density function to test for OOD-ness.
LLM_1:
### Positives

**Well-motivated method for distribution shift detection**: The paper effectively adapts Bayesian hypothesis testing¡ªgrounded in statistical theory¡ªto deep generative models (DGMs), enabling fast, per-instance evaluation crucial for real-time OOD detection. This approach is both theoretically sound and practically relevant.

**Controllable computational cost via low-rank Hessian approximation**: As shown in Figure 2, the method performs well even with a low-rank approximation of the Hessian, allowing users to balance accuracy and computational efficiency. This flexibility is particularly valuable in latency-sensitive applications.

### Critiques / Questions

**Validity of local approximation in overparameterized regimes**: The Bayesian framework assumes well-identified models, but deep networks often exhibit parameter space degeneracies¡ªdirections around minima that leave model outputs unchanged [Maddox et al., 2020]. Could such non-identifiability lead the test to falsely attribute invariance directions to distribution shift? How does the method ensure that detected perturbations reflect true shifts rather than parameterization artifacts?

**Non-monotonic AUROC with increasing eigenvalue count**: The observation that performance peaks around 30 eigenvalues and slightly declines thereafter is unexpected. While sparsity of the Hessian explains strong low-rank performance, it does not account for degradation at higher ranks. Could this be due to sensitivity to spurious, non-informative directions in parameter space, possibly linked to overparameterization?

**Convergence of the remainder term in Proposition 1**: Although Equation 12 approximates the log-likelihood ratio using first- and second-order terms, with $1/n$ scaling suggesting asymptotic validity, the behavior of the remainder term is not analyzed. Under what conditions does this remainder vanish asymptotically? Does the paper provide justification that the leading terms dominate uniformly?

**Insufficient discussion of related work on score-based methods**: The paper lacks a dedicated Related Work section and overlooks key prior approaches. In particular, score matching and the Fisher information-based OOD detection method of Sharma et al. [UAI 2021] are closely related, as they also leverage perturbations of the log-density. A comparative discussion would strengthen the paper¡¯s positioning within the existing literature.
LLM_2:
### Strengths

**Strong theoretical foundation with practical applicability for distribution shift detection**: The paper presents a well-justified adaptation of Bayesian hypothesis testing¡ªrooted in classical statistical theory¡ªto the setting of deep generative models (DGMs). This enables efficient, instance-level out-of-distribution (OOD) detection, which is critical for real-world deployment. The integration of formal statistical methodology into a deep learning context is both novel and impactful, offering a principled alternative to heuristic baselines.

**Flexible computational trade-off via low-rank Hessian approximation**: As demonstrated empirically in Figure 2, the method maintains strong performance even under aggressive low-rank approximations of the Hessian. This allows practitioners to tune the computational budget according to application constraints¡ªparticularly beneficial in latency-critical environments¡ªwithout sacrificing robustness. The ability to control cost while preserving effectiveness enhances the method¡¯s practical utility.

---

### Critiques and Questions

**Concerns about the validity of local approximations in overparameterized models**: The proposed framework relies on a local Bayesian approximation that assumes identifiable model parameters and regularity around the optimum. However, in deep networks, parameter space often contains flat or degenerate directions where changes in weights do not affect outputs¡ªa phenomenon documented in works such as Maddox et al. (2020). Such non-identifiability may lead the test statistic to conflate structural redundancies in the parameterization with actual distributional shifts. Could this result in false positives? The authors are encouraged to discuss how the method distinguishes between true OOD signals and artifacts arising from model overparameterization.

**Non-monotonic behavior of AUROC with increasing Hessian rank**: The experimental results show that detection performance peaks at approximately 30 retained eigenvalues and then slightly deteriorates¡ªan observation that is not fully explained. While the success of low-rank approximations can be attributed to inherent sparsity in the Hessian spectrum, the subsequent decline at higher ranks suggests potential sensitivity to noisy or non-informative directions. Are these higher-order modes capturing overfitting effects or numerical instabilities? A deeper analysis could help clarify whether this reflects a fundamental limitation or an implementation-specific artifact.

**Asymptotic justification of the log-likelihood ratio approximation**: Proposition 1 provides an expansion of the log-likelihood ratio using first- and second-order terms, with a remainder term scaled by $1/n$. While the leading terms are motivated by asymptotic arguments, the convergence properties of the remainder are not rigorously analyzed. Under what regularity conditions does this residual vanish uniformly as $n  o \infty$? Furthermore, is there empirical or theoretical support for the dominance of the quadratic approximation in finite-sample regimes typical of deep learning?

**Limited engagement with relevant prior work on score-based OOD methods**: The paper would benefit from a more comprehensive discussion of related approaches, particularly those based on score functions and Fisher information. For example, Sharma et al. (UAI 2021) propose an OOD detection method using perturbations of the log-density, closely aligning with the conceptual framework used here. By omitting a dedicated Related Work section and failing to contrast with such methods, the paper misses an opportunity to clearly position its contributions within the broader landscape. A comparative analysis would strengthen the narrative and highlight the unique advantages of the proposed approach.
