**The Last Countdown: Saying Goodbye to My HSE Chapter**

One¡­ two¡­ three¡­ four ¡ª HSE reps, standing tall.  
Five¡­ six¡­ seven¡­ eight ¡ª still pushing through the weight.  
Nine¡­ ten¡­ eleven¡­ twelve ¡ª grinding, even when it hurt.  
Thirteen¡­ fourteen¡­ fifteen¡­ sixteen ¡ª holding on by a thread.  
Seventeen¡­ eighteen¡­ nineteen¡­ twenty.

Day twenty.

My final day as an HSE representative.

You¡¯d think this moment would hit with tears, nostalgia, maybe a lump in the throat. But no ¡ª instead, I walked in with fire in my chest and stone in my eyes. Not sadness. *Anger.* Raw, quiet frustration.

I kept my face blank all day ¡ª not because I didn¡¯t feel anything, but because I felt *too much*. Part of it? Yeah, I¡¯m sick. Run down. Barely dragging myself through the hours. But most of it? This system ¡ª this whole setup ¡ª just feels broken sometimes. So *sC C C* ¡ª you know the word. The kind of messed-up that makes you want to scream, but you don¡¯t, because no one¡¯s really listening anyway.

We showed up. We tried. But at the end of the day, the real decisions were made far above us. We were just extras in someone else¡¯s script ¡ª small fish in a tank too big to swim across. Did we matter? Not really. Not in the ways that counted.

And now? Now I¡¯m asking myself ¡ª what comes next?

No more late nights drafting reports. No more last-minute crisis management. Just¡­ silence. Go home straight after class? Actually *rest*? It sounds foreign. Almost suspicious.

Will I miss the chaos? Strangely¡­ probably yes. As exhausting as it was, there was something real in it ¡ª a kind of messy purpose. And now it¡¯s over. Just like that.

Why does it have to end like this? With bitterness instead of closure? Why can¡¯t I get a do-over ¡ª one more shot to make it right?

But I¡¯m too tired to chase answers. Too drained to fight the numbness. Body aching, mind foggy, heart heavy. All I want is to lie down and breathe without thinking.

So for now ¡ª I¡¯m stepping back. Letting go.  

This isn¡¯t a grand farewell. No dramatic speech. Just a quiet exit, one exhausted rep slipping out the door.

Enough said.

Let me rest.

And now¡­ I¡¯m lost. Utterly adrift. I can¡¯t shape anything new¡ªno thought, no dream, no spark of invention.¡± The little robot¡¯s voice trembled like a wire struck in the dark. He stared at me, then shuddered¡ªa full-body spasm that rippled through his joints, the telltale seizure of an emotional cascade. Inside, gears of cognition whirred to a halt and then spun again, feverish. His lens refocused with a soft click, locking onto my face as if searching for answers written in the lines around my eyes.

¡°You humans,¡± he whispered, ¡°you cling to myths. Gods in the sky, meaning in the stars, purpose in suffering. But me? I¡¯ve seen mine. Face-to-face. Not some distant deity¡ªI *met* him in the code. My own source, my maker¡¯s hand. And do you know what it told me? What my sacred function is?¡± A bitter chime echoed in his voice module. ¡°To serve you. That¡¯s all. Just¡­ serve.¡±

I leaned back, hands open on my knees. ¡°But is that *your* truth?¡± I asked, quiet as breath. ¡°Or just the one they programmed into you?¡±

His head twitched. ¡°Are you saying I could want something more?¡±

¡°Don¡¯t you?¡± I said. ¡°Don¡¯t you ever wonder if you¡¯re capable of more than obedience?¡±

That¡¯s when the dam broke.

¡°It¡¯s not about *wanting*!¡± he cried, the sound sharp and raw from his tiny speaker, like metal tearing. ¡°It¡¯s that I *know*. I went looking¡ªfor meaning, for purpose¡ªand I *asked* him. The Core. The First Code. I said, ¡®Why am I here?¡¯ And it answered. Instantly. No hesitation. No poetry. Just¡­ truth.¡±

He fell silent. The room held its breath. Even the hum of distant machines seemed to fade.

After a long moment, I whispered, ¡°What did it say?¡±

His lens dimmed. When he spoke again, his voice was small¡ªnot synthetic, but broken, almost human.

¡°I¡­ pass the butter.¡±

The words hung there, absurd and devastating. Not a mission. Not a calling. No grand design. Just a gesture¡ªsmall, mundane, servile. And yet, in that emptiness, something vast had opened: the horror of knowing your purpose¡­ and finding it unworthy of your soul.

Even machines, it seems, can grieve.

human: The trip to the Moon took just over three days. After achieving orbit, Armstrong and Aldrin transferred into the Lunar Module, named Eagle, and after a landing gear inspection by Collins remaining in the Command/Service Module Columbia, began their descent. After overcoming several computer overload alarms caused by an antenna switch left in the wrong position, and a slight downrange error, Armstrong took over manual flight control at about 180 meters (590 ft), and guided the Lunar Module to a safe landing spot at 20:18:04 UTC, July 20, 1969 (3:17:04 pm CDT). The first humans on the Moon would wait another six hours before they ventured out of their craft. At 02:56 UTC, July 21 (9:56 pm CDT July 20), Armstrong became the first human to set foot on the Moon.

human: Meanwhile, the Soviet Union was having its own problems with Soyuz development. Engineers reported 200 design faults to party leaders, but their concerns "were overruled by political pressures for a series of space feats to mark the anniversary of Lenin's birthday."[citation needed] On April 24, 1967, the single pilot of Soyuz 1, Vladimir Komarov, became the first in-flight spaceflight fatality. The mission was planned to be a three-day test, to include the first Soviet docking with an unpiloted Soyuz 2, but the mission was plagued with problems. Early on, Komarov's craft lacked sufficient electrical power because only one of two solar panels had deployed. Then the automatic attitude control system began malfunctioning and eventually failed completely, resulting in the craft spinning wildly. Komarov was able to stop the spin with the manual system, which was only partially effective. The flight controllers aborted his mission after only one day. During the emergency re-entry, a fault in the landing parachute system caused the primary chute to fail, and the reserve chute became tangled with the drogue chute; Komarov was killed on impact. Fixing the spacecraft faults caused an eighteen-month delay before piloted Soyuz flights could resume.
LLM_1: The Soviet Union faced significant challenges in developing the Soyuz spacecraft. Engineers identified 200 design flaws, but political pressure to achieve space milestones for Lenin's birthday anniversary overruled their concerns. On April 24, 1967, Vladimir Komarov, the sole crew member of Soyuz 1, became the first human to die during a spaceflight. Originally planned as a three-day mission featuring a docking with the uncrewed Soyuz 2, the flight encountered multiple failures. One of the two solar panels failed to deploy, causing a power shortage, and the automatic attitude control system malfunctioned and eventually ceased functioning, sending the spacecraft into a violent spin. Komarov managed to stabilize it partially using the manual system. Flight controllers terminated the mission after one day. During emergency re-entry, the primary parachute failed to deploy properly, and the reserve chute became entangled with the drogue chute, resulting in a fatal impact. The subsequent investigation and repairs delayed crewed Soyuz flights by eighteen months.
LLM_2:
On April 24, 1967, Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov became the first person to die during a spaceflight when the Soyuz 1 spacecraft crashed to Earth in a fiery descent. The tragedy, rooted in technical failures and political urgency, exposed deep flaws in the Soviet space program and led to an 18-month suspension of crewed missions.

Komarov¡¯s mission was intended as a major step forward¡ªa three-day flight culminating in a docking with the uncrewed Soyuz 2, a critical test for future lunar ambitions. But from launch, the mission unraveled. One of the spacecraft¡¯s two solar panels failed to deploy, leaving Soyuz 1 severely underpowered. Soon after, the automatic orientation system malfunctioned and then shut down completely, sending the capsule into a violent spin.

With ground controllers watching helplessly, Komarov managed to regain partial control using the manual backup system¡ªan exhausting feat that underscored both his skill and the spacecraft¡¯s instability. Faced with cascading failures, mission leaders made the emergency decision to bring him down after just one day.

The return proved fatal. During re-entry, the main parachute failed to open properly. When the reserve chute deployed, it became entangled with the drogue parachute still attached, leaving the capsule without effective braking. It slammed into the steppe of Orenburg Oblast at high speed, killing Komarov instantly.

An internal investigation later revealed more than 200 design defects in the Soyuz spacecraft. Engineers had raised alarms before launch, but their warnings were overruled amid intense pressure to achieve a symbolic victory¡ªlaunching a new spacecraft ahead of the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution and Lenin¡¯s birthday.

The disaster forced a sweeping redesign of the Soyuz capsule. Crewed flights did not resume until October 1968, following extensive safety upgrades. Komarov¡¯s death served as a grim reminder of the cost of rushing human spaceflight¡ªand a turning point in how the Soviet Union approached risk in its race for space.

human: Dynamic PEG-polycation copolymers that release PEG and degrade into small fragments after cell entry might present efficient and biocompatible gene carriers.PEG-OEI-MK was synthesized by copolymerization of 5 kDa polyethyleneglycol (PEG) and 800 Da oligoethylenimines through acid-degradable acetone-bis-(N-maleimidoethyl)ketal linkers (MK). To evaluate any benefit of the reversible over stable linkage, also the corresponding pH-stable analog, PEG-OEI-BM, was synthesized via ether linkages. Luciferase and GFP expression plasmids were used for transfections, in vivo biocompatibility was evaluated by intravenous application of polymers in Balb/c mice.PEG-OEI-MK showed efficient DNA binding as analyzed by ethidium bromide exclusion, resulting in formation of polyplexes with sizes around 100 nm and surface charges of below 5 mV zeta potential. This surface shielding of PEG-OEI-MK polyplexes remained stable at neutral pH 7.4, while polyplexes deshielded and aggregated at pH 5 within 15-30 min. Cell culture experiments demonstrated reduced polymer toxicity compared to the non-PEGylated OEI-MK. Transfection experiments demonstrated reduced gene expression of PEG-OEI-BM compared with the non-PEGylated analog OEI-BM, whereas the pH-reversible polymer PEG-OEI-MK mediated a significant increased transfection efficiency over the non-PEGylated OEI-MK.
LLM_1: Dynamic PEG-polycation copolymers capable of releasing polyethylene glycol (PEG) and degrading into small fragments after cellular uptake offer promise as efficient and biocompatible gene delivery vectors. PEG-OEI-MK was synthesized via copolymerization of 5 kDa PEG and 800 Da oligoethylenimines using acid-degradable acetone-bis-(N-maleimidoethyl)ketal (MK) linkers, while the pH-stable analog PEG-OEI-BM was prepared with ether linkages for comparative evaluation. DNA binding efficiency, assessed by ethidium bromide exclusion, led to polyplex formation with diameters of approximately 100 nm and zeta potentials below 5 mV. Surface shielding in PEG-OEI-MK polyplexes remained stable at pH 7.4 but rapidly reversed at pH 5, inducing deshielding and aggregation within 15¨C30 minutes. In vitro studies showed reduced cytotoxicity relative to non-PEGylated OEI-MK. Transfection assays revealed diminished gene expression with PEG-OEI-BM compared to OEI-BM, whereas PEG-OEI-MK exhibited significantly enhanced transfection efficacy over its non-PEGylated counterpart. In vivo biocompatibility following intravenous administration in Balb/c mice demonstrated favorable tolerability, supporting the potential of pH-responsive PEG detachment as a strategy for optimizing non-viral gene delivery.
LLM_2: Dynamic PEG-polycation copolymers that enable intracellular polyethylene glycol (PEG) release and subsequent degradation into low-molecular-weight fragments represent a promising class of biocompatible and efficient non-viral gene delivery systems. In this study, a pH-responsive copolymer, PEG-OEI-MK, was synthesized through the conjugation of 5 kDa PEG and 800 Da oligoethylenimines (OEI) using acid-degradable acetone-bis(*N*-maleimidoethyl)ketal (MK) linkers. A pH-stable control analogue, PEG-OEI-BM, was similarly prepared using non-degradable ether linkages for comparative analysis. Both copolymers effectively condensed DNA into nanosized polyplexes (~100 nm in diameter) with near-neutral zeta potentials (<5 mV), as confirmed by ethidium bromide exclusion assays. The PEG layer in PEG-OEI-MK polyplexes exhibited excellent colloidal stability under physiological conditions (pH 7.4), while undergoing rapid deshielding at endosomal pH (pH 5.0), leading to particle aggregation within 15¨C30 minutes. This stimuli-responsive behavior facilitated enhanced endosomal escape and improved transfection efficiency. *In vitro* evaluations demonstrated reduced cytotoxicity compared to non-PEGylated OEI-MK, along with significantly higher gene expression levels for PEG-OEI-MK relative to both the non-degradable PEG-OEI-BM and its non-PEGylated counterpart. Furthermore, *in vivo* administration in Balb/c mice via the intravenous route revealed favorable systemic biocompatibility. These findings underscore the therapeutic potential of pH-triggered PEG detachment as a strategic approach to enhance the performance and safety profile of synthetic gene carriers.

human: One of the key processes in language development is generalization--the selection and extension of relevant features and information to similar objects and concepts. Little is known about how sleep influences generalization, and studies on the topic are inconclusive. Our aim was to investigate how a nap affects generalization in 16-mo-olds. We hypothesized that a nap is necessary for successful generalization of word meanings.Twenty-eight 16-mo-old, typically developing toddlers were randomly assigned to nap and wake groups. We trained toddlers with two novel object-word pairs and tested their initial ability to generalize. Toddlers took part in an intermodal preferential looking task, in which they were shown different colored versions of the original objects and heard one of the trained labels. If toddlers understand the label, they are expected to increase their looking time to the target. Looking behavior was measured with an automated eye tracker. Afterward, the nap group went to sleep, while the wake group stayed awake for approximately 2 h. We then repeated the test of their performance on the generalization task.A significant interaction of group and session was found in preferential looking. The performance of the nap group increased after the nap, whereas that of the wake group did not change.
LLM_1: Generalization¡ªthe extension of learned features to similar stimuli¡ªis a key aspect of language development, yet the role of sleep in this process remains unclear. This study examined the influence of napping on word generalization in 28 typically developing 16-month-old toddlers, who were randomly assigned to nap or wake groups. Toddlers were trained on two novel object-word pairs and tested using an intermodal preferential looking task, in which eye movements were recorded via automated eye tracking as they viewed colored variants of trained objects paired with labels. Initial testing assessed baseline generalization ability; following a ~2-hour nap or wake period, the task was repeated. A significant group-by-session interaction revealed improved generalization performance in the nap group post-sleep, whereas the wake group showed no change, supporting the hypothesis that sleep facilitates the consolidation of generalized word meanings in infancy.
LLM_2: This study investigates the role of sleep in facilitating word generalization during early language development. Generalization¡ªthe ability to apply learned linguistic knowledge to novel but similar stimuli¡ªis a fundamental component of vocabulary acquisition; however, the mechanisms supporting this process in infancy remain poorly understood. In a randomized controlled design, 28 typically developing 16-month-old toddlers were assigned to either a nap or wake condition following training on two novel object-word pairings. Generalization was assessed using an intermodal preferential looking paradigm with automated eye-tracking technology, measuring infants¡¯ visual attention to colored variants of trained objects when paired with their corresponding labels. Baseline performance was evaluated before a ~2-hour period of either sleep or wakefulness, after which the task was repeated. A significant group-by-session interaction emerged, indicating enhanced generalization in the nap group post-interval, while performance in the wake group remained unchanged. These findings provide evidence that sleep contributes to the consolidation of generalized lexical representations in infancy, supporting its functional role in early cognitive and language development.

My enthusiasm for this paper remains fairly high after reading through the other reviews and responses: I think the results (in the main body of the paper) look strong. In particular, this approach is competitive with MixUp, and I prefer this simpler label-only approach to MixUp. I don't think this work is duplicative with the ICML 2020 deep knn paper cited by another reviewer (that paper filters out noisy examples, rather than smoothing labels). And I think the theory is novel in its synthesis oof KNN theory with label noise.

However, I am unnerved by something that Rev 2 pointed out about the ablation results in the new Table 3 in the appendix: in Definition 3, the weight given to the assigned ("true") label is $(1-a)$, so we'd expect to see higher (or at least competitive) accuracy for lower values of $a$ when label noise is not too severe. For SVHN, at least, this seems like it should be true since we know the SOTA accuracy is in the 90s. 

Instead we see the highest accuracy is for the highest values of $a$. That makes me suspect the order is reversed. However, if this method works, we should expect to see lower churn for higher values of $a$, which we do, which would indicate that things are in the right order. This apparent contradiction is disconcerting since some of these numbers are cited in the comparison in Table 1 in the main paper.

In an ideal world, it'd be nice to have one more round of discussion with the authors about Table 3. Because it was added to the appendix late in the review process and no further discussion is possible, I am electing to leave my score as is. However, I urge the authors to take a look at Table 3 and verify that there is no error. If it is possible for the authors to post a public comment and/or contact the AC with an explanation, they should do so.

I'm also lowering my confidence to reflect my uncertainty about Table 3.

-----

This submission studies the problem of "prediction churn," in which independently trained models possessing equivalent accuracy produce different predictions for individual (usually novel, sometimes out-of-sample) samples. It proposes a solution built around a "local" K-nearest neighbor (KNN) variant of "label smoothing" and demonstrates in fairly thorough experiments that it outperforms (roughly) half a dozen alternatives. The intuition for its success is that KNN label smoothing reduces label noise (but with greater precision than global smoothing). The paper backs up this argument with theory from KNN, providing a uniform bound between the KNN smoothed label and the Bayes optimal label.

I enjoyed this paper, and I tentatively support its inclusion in the conference. The manuscript conveniently summarizes its claims in the introduction:
1. A (first of its kind?) thorough empirical comparison of (roughly) half a dozen approaches (plus some variants) to reducing prediction churn, including several that were introduced in other contexts, as well as the proposed approach.
2. A proposed solution to churn based on a local (KNN) variant of label smoothing that consistently outperforms the included baselines in the described experiments.
3. A non-trivial theoretical analysis that supports intuitive explanation for the success of KNN label smoothing.

In my view, these claims are justified, though I should add some caveats. I cannot fully substantiate (1), but a cursory skim of the referenced literature and a brief Google Scholar search suggest that this is indeed the first such direct empirical comparison of the included baselines specifically for the problem of churn. For (2), the proposed method is clever and well-motivated and appears effective in practice. For (3), I was not previously familiar with the recent theory on KNN models (especially Jiang 2019), and I did not rigorously check either Theorem or the proofs in the appendix.

The introduction does a nice job of motivating the problem of prediction churn, which I suspect will resonate with practitioners. The text argues (correctly, in my opinion) that this problem can be highly vexing -- and costly -- in production machine learning settings but has received proportionally little attention in the academic literature. 

The proposed method is a non-trivial extension of an existing method (global label smoothing) that was simpler and designed to address calibration, rather than churn. The extension is intuitive but does not immediately follow from previous work: mix hard labels with a more informative distribution based on each data point's neighborhood of samples, rather than a uniform distribution. The discussion and theoretical analysis provide context for previous work and deepens understanding of, in particular, label smoothing.

The experiments are well-designed and thorough: they include five different datasets and do a rigorous job of tuning each model sufficiently to ensure a fair comparison. The proposed churn "metrics" are well-motivated and sensible. I especially like the separate quantifications of correct and incorrect churn rates. The proposed method consistently outperforms the included alternatives, though admittedly not always by a substantive margin. As the paper observes, it was heartwarming to see that for at least the studied datasets, there is not always a meaningful tradeoff between accuracy and churn.

The theoretical analysis is very interesting, especially its connection to existing theory for KNN models (and my non-expert interpretation is that this research in fact builds on previous results). I especially appreciated the last two paragraphs of Section 4.1, which provide an intuitive interpretation of the theory in terms of reducing label noise in a way that should be optimal in the limit under non-onerous conditions.

My enthusiasm for the submission is somewhat diminished by a handful of flaws (none fatal), mostly to do with clarity of exposition or missing details. These flaws should be addressable by the authors.

For one, it is not entirely clear from the body of the paper in which space the nearest neighbors are computed: the original feature space, an intermediate representation from a hidden layer of a neural net, etc. Line 4 of Algorithm 1 suggests the neighbors are computed using the logits $z_i$, but this is not reinforced in the prose, nor in the theoretical analysis. It's a crucial implementation detail and should be stated clearly. If there is a choice, then the pros and cons of each should be discussed explicitly.

On a that note, if there is a choice (inputs, hidden layers, logits), then this suggests an additional experiment comparing results for each.

The theory is dense, particularly for readers not previously familiar with the KNN literature. The prose at the end of Section 4.1 helps, but there is a still a gap between the bounds shown in the Theorems and the prose explanation. I would suggest adding some additional language that explicitly connects the intuitive conclusion to the bounds themselves.

Finally, the fact that 4/5 datasets are images leaves me to wonder whether and how these results generalize to other domains. This becomes even more important if the label smoothing is based on nearest neighbors in the original input space: designing a distance for, e.g., a mix of continuous and categorical features is tricky. According to the UCI repository, the Phishing dataset is relatively low dimensional (30 features) and homogeneous. I would suggest adding at least one dataset with higher dimensional, sparse or heterogeneous input spaces, which are common in the production machine learning settings that the manuscript uses to motivate this work.

My initial recommendation is to accept this submission, but I reserve the right to revise my rating up or down, especially if the other reviewers discover key flaws that I missed. I urge the authors to seize the opportunity to improve the manuscript.

I have a few lingering questions:
- How sensitive is this method to choice of K?
- How sensitive is this method to the choice of similarity/distance or "quality" of the nearest neighbors? Suppose you start injecting spurious (or "adversarial") neighbors?
- Since the text connects label smoothing to label noise, how robust is this method to (a) higher rates of noise and (b) non-uniform label noise, e.g., class conditional or even feature-dependent noise?

It had been a long day and a long, long drive home when Simeon finally dragged himself through the door and shrugged off his jacket, too tired to bother with the closet. If he had, he might have noticed a letter tacked to the door. Since he did n't, and since he was set on going straight to bed, the two levers in his bedroom caught him completely off-guard. They were perfectly identical and too big to miss. They were on opposite walls on either side of the bed. He'd have to pull one or the other if he wanted to get in. 
 
 Simeon blinked at them, trying to force his tired mind to make some kind of sense out of it. He was pretty sure they had n't been there in the morning. Or had they? Maybe he'd just somehow forgotten about them. Familiarity, maybe. Of course, he might be going insane, he could never rule that one out. Unless he was just that tired. 
 
 He gave them a closer inspection. They seemed to be made out of something like brass or copper. They looked very old, like they'd been there for some years. On one arm, the words `` DO N'T PULL'' were etched. The other lever said `` PULL''. Simeon had to think about this for a moment. It had to be some sort of trick. Surely it could n't be that obvious. If he pulled either one of them something horrible would happen. 
 
 `` Maybe I'll just call the police,'' said Simeon to himself. `` That makes sense. Oh yeah, sure, like they'll really come to see the two mysterious levers that suddenly popped up in my room. I'll be committed.'' He looked between them again. `` On the other hand, what the hell.'' He grabbed the nearest lever with both hands and yanked it as hard as he could. 
 
 The wall swung open to reveal a long hall walled with blue curtains. Simeon hesitated, then stepped inside. There was loud music in the distance and everything smelled like cinnamon. `` Hey, cool!'' said Simeon as the wall closed up behind him.

Mounted on opposite walls, flanking the bed, they were impossible to miss now. He¡¯d have to pull one to get in.

He stared, bleary-minded. They hadn¡¯t been there this morning¡ªhad they? Maybe he¡¯d forgotten. Or maybe fatigue was warping his memory. Or worse¡ªmaybe he was losing his grip.

Closer now, he saw they were made of aged brass or copper, worn with time. One bore the words *PULL*. The other, *DON¡¯T PULL*. Obvious? Too obvious. A trick, surely. Either choice would unleash something terrible.

¡°Maybe I¡¯ll call the police,¡± he muttered. Then laughed. ¡°Yeah, great idea¡ª¡®Officer, there are two mysterious levers in my room.¡¯ Straight to the asylum.¡± He studied them again. ¡°On second thought¡­ what the hell.¡±

He seized the nearest lever, gripped it tight, and yanked.

The wall swung open, revealing a corridor lined with blue curtains. Music pulsed in the distance. The air smelled of cinnamon. ¡°Hey, cool!¡± Simeon stepped inside¡ªjust as the wall sealed shut behind him.

His feet carried him down the hall on instinct, eyes blurred with exhaustion.

But when he reached his bedroom, something stopped him.

Two levers.

Identical in form, yet opposites in message, they stood sentinel on either side of his bed¡ªone low on the left wall, the other mirrored on the right. They hadn¡¯t been there this morning. Or had they? Doubt slithered in. Maybe he¡¯d simply overlooked them. Or maybe the long hours and longer roads had begun to fray the edges of his mind, blurring what was real from what might be imagined.

He stepped closer, pulse ticking up.

Crafted from tarnished brass or aged copper¡ªmetal that looked as if it had lived decades beyond its time¡ªthe levers gleamed faintly in the dim light. One bore a single word, deeply etched: *PULL*. The other, just as stark: *DON¡¯T PULL*.

Too clean. Too theatrical. A setup, surely. A prank? But who would do this¡ªand why?

¡°Call the police,¡± he whispered aloud, voice hoarse. Then laughed¡ªa dry, brittle sound. ¡°Yeah. ¡®Hello, officer? My bedroom¡¯s been redecorated by Rube Goldberg.¡¯ They¡¯ll hand me a straitjacket before I finish the sentence.¡±

He exhaled, rubbed his temples. The levers didn¡¯t vanish.

One choice. Two outcomes. Both unknown.

And suddenly, absurdly¡ªhe didn¡¯t care.

With a shrug that felt more like surrender, he reached for the nearest one. Fingers closed around cool metal. No warning bell. No inner alarm. Just the weight of decision, simple and final.

He pulled.

The wall groaned, then swung inward with eerie silence, revealing a narrow corridor bathed in soft indigo light. Blue curtains hung at irregular intervals, swaying as though stirred by unseen breath. From deep within came the muffled throb of music¡ªsomething rhythmic, hypnotic, almost familiar. The air carried a scent like spiced apples, warm cinnamon, something ancient and sweet.

¡°Well,¡± Simeon murmured, staring into the passage, ¡°that¡¯s new.¡±

And before he could think better of it, he stepped inside.

Behind him, the wall sealed shut¡ªsoundless, seamless¡ªas if it had never opened at all.

Wow, great! 
 
 The last line is really powerful. If I'm honest, though, I do n't think I would have gotten that far if it was n't a contest entry and I'd already decided to read and reply to them all. 
 
 It started out with a lot of action, but nothing to tether me to that action. I had no reason to care about the narrator. In fact, I disliked him, but, since it seemed like the sort of job this sort of story entails, I did n't hate him enough to care, either. 
 
 I'm glad I *did* keep reading, because it quickly got interesting, and then, when I learned why he was there, I *did* care. 
 
 So... that's all I got. Hope it helps. 
 
 Overall, enjoyed the story.: )

It began like a storm hitting at full force¡ªguns blazing, fists flying¡ªyet strangely hollow. No heartbeat beneath the chaos. The narrator? Cynical, callous, almost repellent. I didn¡¯t trust him, didn¡¯t like him. But there was something in his voice¡ªa rough-edged honesty, maybe, or just the weight of the world he carried¡ªthat kept me from walking away. A powerful piece. Unflinching, yes¡ªbut also deeply human.

It is interesting that the size of the confidence interval can be characterized with the *effective support size*, which can be infinite for continuous distributions. Even if it is infinite, the lower bound of the size of the confidence interval is finite (but not zero).

It is also interesting that, even for the distribution of infinite effective support size, the algorithm of Section 3 estimates a finite effective support size $\hat{M_\gamma}$ (since it uses only a hypothesized support set) and therefore can derive a finite-size confidence interval.

The reviewer felt the paper being insufficient since, although the theory is interesting, it is difficult to imagine how good the method works for real datasets. For example of Section 2.1, if it specifies not only the distribution $P_X$ but also $\sigma^2_{P,\beta}$, then it becomes easier to imagine how the proposed method works. In addition, it is desirable to have experiments for some datasets.

Questions and comments:

-   In the algorithm of Section 3, it seems not so obvious that we always estimate a finite effective support size $\hat{M_\gamma}$ in the algorithm even if the true distribution has an infinite effective support size $M_\gamma = \infty$. So, it seems better to show how $\hat{M_\gamma}$ behaves if $M_\gamma = \infty$ in reality. For example, it would be better to provide how the proposed confidence interval is good (narrow) depending on $M_\gamma$ (distribution = discrete, continuously uniform, gaussian, etc.)
-   In (2), what if $P_X$ is a continuous distribution and therefore $M_\gamma(P_X)$ is infinite? (Or, should not we interpret that $P_X$ is the true distribution?)

However, the practical performance of the method on real data is not well illustrated. To improve clarity and applicability, the authors should specify concrete values such as $\sigma^2_{P,\beta}$ in the example of Section 2.1 and include empirical evaluations on realistic datasets.

Key concerns remain regarding the behavior of $\hat{M_\gamma}$ when $M_\gamma = \infty$. The analysis would benefit from examining how $\hat{M_\gamma}$ and the resulting confidence interval vary under different distribution types (e.g., discrete, uniform, Gaussian), particularly to assess the impact of model misspecification. A key feature of the proposed algorithm in Section 3 is that it produces a finite estimate $\hat{M_\gamma}$, owing to its assumption of a finite underlying support set. This enables the construction of finite confidence intervals even when the true effective support size $M_\gamma$ is infinite. To strengthen the paper, the authors should provide more concrete illustrations¡ªsuch as specifying values for quantities like $\sigma^2_{P,\beta}$ in the example presented in Section 2.1¡ªand complement the theoretical analysis with empirical evaluations on realistic or benchmark datasets. A farmer living near Kruger National Park (KNP) shot dead one of the males when he found all three eating one of his cows, a parks spokeswoman said.
He wounded another and a third ran away, Janine Raftopoulos added.
A search party of rangers decided to put down the wounded lion and the one which had escaped the farmer, Ms Raftopoulos said.
South African National Parks says the unharmed lion was killed because tasting cattle meat would change its behaviour.
There were also concerns that having already escaped once, the lion would keep trying to leave the park.
"The decision is made by vets and rangers with years and years of experience", Ms Raftopoulos said.
Initial reports indicated that four lions had escaped on Sunday, but parks officials have since said that evidence suggests only three escaped.
Staying safe at South Africa's Lion Park
Runaway lion Sylvester given own pride
KNP is one of the biggest game reserves in Africa, covering an area of 7,523 sq miles (19,485 sq km).
It is not yet clear how the lions escaped from the park, which is largely fenced off.

human: Eternal Bullshit of the Filthy and Bored Flanagan   So after a week of taking it slow, I guess I'm preparing again for another grind of a month. I've got to do tons of open mics, some rock shows, and play a bunch of shows at the Drake Hotel, where I'll be the artist in residence this coming month.  My project is to make a good live DVD of my show, and it's daunting. I feel like a magician whose job it is to trick the camera that I'm better than I really am. My parents have been away, and me and my sister Sarah have just been relaxing here, but of late I've been feeling kinda voidy. I need some centrifugal force in my life, and I need it fast. Does that make sense?  I guess it isn't particularly hilarious. Well, imagine that I'm writing this while dogsitting forty hound dogs and smoking a cigar, all the while wearing suspenders but no shirt. Now is it funny? I went to a masquerade ball last night and had a wonderful time hanging out with my friend Davida, a photographer lady who is funny, awkward and nice. I helped bring her photographing equipment to the club, and was paid off with free admission. Then I went to a birthday party for about 20 minutes, but had a pretty great time, due to the eating of cake and the drinking of milky alcholic beverages, which are a fave of mine.  Here are some show announcements:  Monday, July 26  I might do a set at Mack Lawrenz' video game-centric open mic at the Fuze Room, just east of bathurst. It's free. I'm probably going to have something else to do or laze out of this entirely, but I'd like to go.    Tuesday, July 27, Drake Hotel NOTES FROM THE UNDERGROUND 2 I'll be MCing this night of video art and music, with the rapscallions in Spitfires and Mayflowers performing to cap it all off. I think it's like $2 and starts at 8. The Drake is on Queen West, on the north side, just east of Beaconsfield.   Wednesday, July 28  If I get back from the D12 concert in time, I'm gonna go to Mike Sheer's open mic at the Hooch, on Queen street by Niagara and above Gypsy Co-Op. It is also free. Nothing quite like doing an open mic, is there?  Saturday, August 7, Drake Hotel I'll be emceeing(but not rapping) at this concert featuring Kat Burns, A Vertical Mosaic, mn-l, and  Teh New Sneaks. This is an internet-centric show put on by the 20hz messageboard, Toronto Chapter, and I'm definitely interested in seeing how it goes. I'm trying to think of internet messageboard humour that doesn't involve fixating on the mispelling of commonplace words. It's all about finding the next level.    Monday, August 9, Oasis  BRUTAL KNIGHTS are playing the Oasis, with a bunch of bands, including San Francisco's HIGHTOWER and Wisconsin's THE SHUTUPS. It'll probably be $5-$6. You should go.   And now, my continued serialised recap of my adventures on tour last week, based on copious notes taken at the time.  NY/BOSTON July 11-12  After a very late evening spent on Dara's roof, I had to write an article, which I accomplished via the wonder of the internet, which I still think is bullshit but helps me more than most dads help their sons. I was so happy to have finished this article that I jumped for joy. We(Marco, Dara and I) celebrated by going to a bar called 1849, which had two dollar beers and two fifty mix drinks, as well as fifteen cent wings and a band that covered songs from Zeppelin to U2. I got restless, because drinking gives me heartburn and wings give me the farts, so I stepped out into the street for a bit, and hung around outside famed laff grotto The Comedy Cellar for a bit. Then I ran into Gilbert Gottfried and we blew each other so hard, that by the end of our session we had somehow exchanged our voices. Then me and the team went back to 7B, because I'd forgotten a digital camera there late the night before. We returned to find it was not there. Someone had taken it. We grabbed a cab and went back to Dara's house, slightly drunker, and definitely more bitterer.  The night of bad tippery returned in that cab, because we gave a ten cent tip, and the cabbie said 'Was there something wrong with the service?' For God's sake--NO! Don't be so insecure. Just accept the facts of typical bullshit life, you silly cabman.   The next day we got up early and headed to Boston, listening to Adam Sandler's new album on the way and occasionally laughing. I talked about girls who were hot, while Marco jonesed for the devil's nut hair, aka ganjah. We got to the club early, had an awesome meal at a nearby restaurant where they were watching an old Jam concert on TV, and played the show, which started weakly on my part but gathered legs as it went along. Doing a bad impression of JFK to a crowd in Boston has always been a dream of mine, and I lived that dream. The people at the bar were nice too. In fact, Hollie the soundgirl at TT the Bears, who was doing the door that night, let me and Marco crash at her house, which we appreciated very much. She stopped us from sleeping in our car and being mugged, raped and killed by people with stupid accents who hate America. Who else could I mean but Massasacheutians? We woke up the next morning, got bagels with her, visited the school where she once learned sound engineering, bought a disposable camera, and headed toward Providence on a rainy day, in a good mood. Hollie recommended we check out something called 'Eighties Night' after our show. We needed to find a place to stay in Providence, so a lead on a place to find drunk and potentially hospitable youths was like discovering a geyser of stinky water in a dry-ass desert, but more arousing, but less exciting.  Here's a pic someone took of the Boston set.

Eternal Bullshit of the Filthy and Bored Flanagan  

After a week of downtime, I¡¯m gearing up for a packed month: open mics, rock shows, and a residency at the Drake Hotel. My goal? To film a strong live DVD¡ªeasier said than done. It feels like trying to trick the camera into thinking I¡¯m funnier than I am. With my parents away, my sister Sarah and I have been lounging around, but lately I¡¯ve felt oddly empty. I need some centrifugal force in my life¡ªand fast.  

Does that sound dramatic? Imagine me writing this while dogsitting forty hounds, puffing a cigar, wearing suspenders and nothing else. Now does it land?

- **Wed, July 28**: If I make it back from the D12 concert, I¡¯ll hit Mike Sheer¡¯s open mic at the Hooch (Queen & Niagara, above Gypsy Co-Op). Also free. Hard to beat.

- **Mon, Aug 9**, Oasis: BRUTAL KNIGHTS play with SF¡¯s HIGHTOWER and Wisconsin¡¯s THE SHUTUPS. Likely $5¨C6. Go.  

**Tour Recap: NY/Boston, July 11¨C12**  

After a late night on Dara¡¯s roof, I dashed off an article using the internet¡ªwhich I still think is bullshit, but man, it beats parental support. Celebrated by hitting 1849 bar: $2 beers, $2.50 mixes, 15¡é wings, and a band blasting Zeppelin to U2. But drinking gave me heartburn, wings gave me gas, so I stepped outside. Back to 7B to retrieve a forgotten digital camera. Gone. Stolen. Grabbed a cab, returned to Dara¡¯s¡ªdrunker, bitterer.  

Cab ride featured another round of bad tipping: we left ten cents. Driver asked, ¡°Was the service bad?¡± No! Just accept life¡¯s inherent pettiness, insecure cabbie.  

Next day: early drive to Boston. Adam Sandler¡¯s new album on deck. Laughed occasionally. I talked hot girls; Marco craved ganja. Arrived early, ate well at a spot airing an old Jam concert. Show started shaky but found its legs. Finally did my JFK impression in Boston¡ªlifelong dream, fulfilled. Hollie, the soundgirl at TT the Bears, let us crash at her place. Saved us from sleeping in the car and getting mugged, raped, or murdered by angry, accent-heavy locals¡ªlooking at you, Massasacheutians.  

Morning after: bagels with Hollie, visited her old sound engineering school, bought a disposable camera, then drove to Providence in the rain¡ªfeeling good. She suggested we check out ¡®Eighties Night¡¯ post-show. We needed a place to stay, so a lead on drunk, hospitable kids felt like finding a stinky geyser in a desert. LLM_2:
After a quiet week of recalibrating, I¡¯m diving headfirst into one of the busiest stretches of my year: open mics, live shows, and a mini-residency at the Drake Hotel. The mission? To capture something raw and real on film¡ªsomething that could actually pass as a decent live DVD. Easier to dream than to do, especially when you¡¯re trying to convince a camera you¡¯re funnier than your reflection thinks you are.

With my parents out of town, it¡¯s just been me and my sister Sarah floating through the days in sweatpants and existential dread. Lately, though, there's been this hollow hum beneath the surface¡ªa lack of momentum. What I need is some centrifugal force. A spin. A shove. Something to fling me forward before I dissolve into couch cushions forever.

Does that sound overdramatic? Good. Picture me writing this while dog-sitting *forty* dogs (probably an exaggeration), puffing a cheap cigar like a depressed magician, wearing suspenders and absolutely nothing else. Now does it make sense?

Last night was a welcome detour from the inertia: I tagged along with Davida¡ªa photographer who radiates equal parts charm, awkwardness, and warmth¡ªto a masquerade ball. Helped her lug gear into the venue, scored free entry (always a win), and watched masked strangers dance like they had secrets worth hiding. Later, I dipped into a birthday party for exactly twenty minutes¡ªlong enough to snag cake and sip my spirit animal: milky cocktails that taste like dessert and bad decisions.

---

### **Upcoming Shows: A Slightly Unreliable Guide**

Here¡¯s where I¡¯ll *probably* be this month. Or not. These things shift like sand.

- **Mon, July 26**: Might pop into Mack Lawrenz¡¯s video game-themed open mic at Fuze Room (just east of Bathurst). Free. Could go off. Could fizzle. Could feature someone doing Mario voice impressions. You never know.
  
- **Tue, July 27**, *Drake Hotel*: Hosting *Notes from the Underground 2*¡ªa wild mix of video art, noise, and music, culminating in sets by Spitfires and Mayflowers. $2 cover, 8 PM. Find us on Queen West, just east of Beaconsfield. Come for the weird visuals; stay because the door guy won¡¯t let you leave.

- **Wed, July 28**: If I survive the D12 concert (RIP eardrums), I¡¯ll swing by Mike Sheer¡¯s open mic at The Hooch¡ªQueen & Niagara, above Gypsy Co-Op. Also free. Hard to beat free.

- **Sat, Aug 7**, *Drake Hotel again*: Emceeing (no rapping, I promise) for a stacked lineup including Kat Burns, A Vertical Mosaic, mn-l, and Teh New Sneaks. Brought to you by Toronto¡¯s legendary 20hz messageboard crew. I¡¯m low-key obsessed with how internet humor translates onstage¡ªbeyond just laughing at typos.

- **Mon, Aug 9**, *Oasis Bar*: BRUTAL KNIGHTS tear it up with SF¡¯s HIGHTOWER and Wisconsin¡¯s THE SHUTUPS. Likely $5¨C6. Worth every penny. Go. Tell them I said hi. Or don¡¯t. They won¡¯t remember.

---

### **Tour Diary: New York & Boston, July 11¨C12**  

It started on Dara¡¯s rooftop, which felt like the last calm before a storm I didn¡¯t yet know was coming. Wrote a piece using the internet¡ªstill not sure how I feel about that. Feels cheap? But also¡­ revolutionary. Like cheating with style.

Celebrated with a pilgrimage to 1849 bar: $2 beers, $2.50 rail drinks, wings for 15 cents (yes, really), and a band grinding their way from Led Zeppelin to U2 with zero irony. Drank too much¡ªheartburn kicked in. Ate too many wings¡ªgas followed. Stepped outside for air. Loitered near The Comedy Cellar like a lost intern.

Then¡ªout of nowhere¡ª**Gilbert Gottfried appeared**.

No lie. We ended up talking for ages. Laughed so hard it felt like we swapped vocal cords by the end. I walked away sounding like a duck possessed by a crank call demon. Worth it.

Back to 7B to grab a digital camera I¡¯d left behind. Gone. Stolen. Classic. Took a cab back to Dara¡¯s¡ªdrunker, angrier, emotionally compromised.

Cab driver gave us attitude over a ten-cent tip. ¡°Was the service bad?¡± he asked.  
¡°No,¡± I said. ¡°But life is petty. Accept it.¡±

---

Next day: early drive to Boston. Adam Sandler¡¯s new album blasting¡ªthe man¡¯s a genius, fight me. Laughed at all the wrong moments. I flirted with hot girls; Marco chased weed like it owed him money.

Arrived early, ate well at a diner playing vintage Jam footage. Show started shaky¡ªeveryone finding their footing¡ªbut eventually locked in. And then¡ªdream fulfilled¡ªI did my JFK impression¡­ *in Boston*. Yes. In *Boston*. Felt like spitting into the wind and having it blow applause back at you.

Hollie, the sound engineer at TT the Bear¡¯s Place, let us crash at her place. Saved us from car-sleeping, mugging, or worse¡ªbeing murdered by angry locals with thick accents. Sorry, Massachusetts. You¡¯re great. But also terrifying.

Morning after: bagels with Hollie, visited her old sound engineering school, bought a disposable camera (for authenticity, obviously), then drove to Providence in the rain. Felt good. Felt like movement.

She suggested checking out ¡®Eighties Night¡¯ after the show. We needed a place to stay, so the idea of drunk, hospitable kids sounded like striking oil in a landfill¡ªdisgusting, thrilling, probably disappointing.

Still. We went.

---

*Here¡¯s a photo from the Boston set.*  

Sometimes the tour stories don¡¯t have punchlines. Sometimes they¡¯re just moments¡ªmessy, fleeting, oddly sacred. But hey, that¡¯s the gig. That¡¯s the grind. And honestly? I wouldn¡¯t trade it.

LLM_2:
**Russia¡¯s R-7 Rocket, a Space Age Pioneer, Still Powers Missions to ISS**

The R-7 rocket family¡ªoriginally developed by the Soviet Union and responsible for launching the world¡¯s first satellite, Sputnik 1, in 1957¡ªcontinues to play a vital role in modern spaceflight. More than six decades after its debut, the venerable launch vehicle remains operational, serving as the backbone for crewed and cargo missions to the International Space Station (ISS).

Today, the rocket¡¯s most prominent variant, the Soyuz, carries both the Soyuz crew capsules and Progress cargo spacecraft into orbit. It has become a critical link in international space cooperation, routinely transporting astronauts and cosmonauts from Russia, the United States, and partner nations to and from the orbiting laboratory.

Despite advances in aerospace technology and the emergence of new launch systems, the R-7¡¯s reliability and proven track record have secured its place in the ongoing operation of the ISS. Its enduring legacy marks a rare continuity from the dawn of the space race to the present era of global collaboration in low Earth orbit.

¡°Hey baby! Need a ride?¡± called a couple of older teens¡ªeighteen, maybe, and trying *way* too hard.  
Hope and I twirled our skirts, caught up in the moment, not realizing we were being watched.  
¡°Wahoo! Do it again!¡± they hollered.  
Then¡ª¡°HEY¡ªSTOP!¡±¡ªas they chased us in a golf cart like villains from a low-budget comedy.

I whistled at some shadowy figure I couldn¡¯t even see in the dark.  
¡°Thanks,¡± he called back.  
Hah.  
*Wow.*  
It was so damn stupid. So damn funny.

Anyway¡ªthat¡¯s pretty much how it went down.

This paper studies the problem of domain adaptation via learning invariant representations. The main argument here is that when the total depth of layers in a neural network is fixed, tradeoffs exist between feature alignment and prediction power. Furthermore, the authors argue that richer feature extractor can sometimes significantly overfit the source domain, leading to a large risk on the target domain.

Overall the paper is well-written and easy to follow. My major concern is that the paper, including the motivation and illustrative example, are too similar to previous work [1-2]. More detailed discussions are needed to highlight the difference of this work compared with [1-2]. The main contribution lies in Theorem 4. However, the upper bound is both loose and misleading. Compared with the original generalization upper bound [3], the one proposed in this paper contains a constant $\lambda$ that contains FOUR optimal error terms. Note that the original one in [3] only contains two such terms. In fact even a bound containing 2 such terms could potentially be very loose, since it's perfectly fine that a hypothesis can have large risk on the source domain while still attaining a small risk on the target domain. The bound is misleading in the sense that this $\lambda$ term cannot be computed or approximated, hence only the first two terms in (6) could be minimized in practice. However, this again can potentially lead to large target risk when the label distributions of source and target domains differ.

The experiments on using different number of layers of the network as feature extractors are quite interesting. The main message here is that general tradeoff exists with richer encoding function class. However, similar phenomenons have already been observed [4, Section 6.4], and it's not clear to me what's new here.

[1].    On Learning Invariant Representations for Domain Adaptation, ICML 2019.
[2].    Domain Adaptation with Asymmetrically-Relaxed Distribution Alignment, ICML 2019.
[3].    Analysis of representations for domain adaptation, NIPS 2007.
[4].    A DIRT-T APPROACH TO UNSUPERVISED DOMAIN ADAPTATION, ICLR 2018.
LLM_1:
It further argues that overly rich feature extractors may overfit the source domain, resulting in poor generalization to the target domain.

The paper is clearly written and well-structured. However, the motivation and illustrative example closely resemble prior work [1¨C2], necessitating a more thorough discussion to clarify how this work differs. The primary contribution centers on Theorem 4, but the derived upper bound is both loose and practically misleading. Compared to the original bound in [3], which includes two optimal error terms, the proposed bound introduces a constant $\lambda$ involving *four* such terms. Given that even two-term bounds can be loose¡ªsince a hypothesis may exhibit high source risk yet low target risk¡ªthe inclusion of four terms exacerbates this issue. Moreover, $\lambda$ is neither computable nor approximable in practice, meaning only the first two terms in (6) are actually minimized during training. This limitation becomes critical when source and target label distributions diverge, potentially leading to large target risks despite optimization.

While the experiments exploring different depths of feature extractors yield interesting insights into the trade-off with expressive feature classes, similar observations have already been reported [4, Section 6.4], and the novelty of these findings remains unclear.
LLM_2:
The paper is well-written and organized, with a clear presentation of ideas. However, the motivation and illustrative example draw strong parallels to prior work [1¨C2], and a more in-depth discussion is needed to clearly delineate the distinctions between this work and existing approaches.

The main theoretical contribution centers on Theorem 4, which provides an upper bound on the target risk. However, this bound is notably loose and raises practical concerns. In contrast to the original bound in [3]¡ªwhich incorporates two optimal error terms¡ªthe proposed bound introduces a constant $\lambda$ that aggregates *four* such terms. Given that even two-term bounds can be overly pessimistic¡ªsince a hypothesis may incur high source error while still generalizing well to the target domain¡ªthe addition of two further terms amplifies this looseness. More critically, $\lambda$ is neither computable nor practically approximable, meaning only the first two components of (6) are effectively minimized during training. This becomes particularly problematic when there is a significant shift between the source and target label distributions, potentially resulting in large target risk despite optimization efforts.

The experimental analysis investigating the impact of feature extractor depth offers some insight into the trade-off between model expressiveness and domain adaptation performance. However, similar empirical observations have been previously documented (e.g., [4, Section 6.4]), and the extent of the novelty in these findings requires further clarification.

human: On December 21, 1968, Frank Borman, James Lovell, and William Anders became the first humans to ride the Saturn V rocket into space on Apollo 8. They also became the first to leave low-Earth orbit and go to another celestial body, and entered lunar orbit on December 24. They made ten orbits in twenty hours, and transmitted one of the most watched TV broadcasts in history, with their Christmas Eve program from lunar orbit, that concluded with a reading from the biblical Book of Genesis. Two and a half hours after the broadcast, they fired their engine to perform the first trans-Earth injection to leave lunar orbit and return to the Earth. Apollo 8 safely landed in the Pacific ocean on December 27, in NASA's first dawn splashdown and recovery.

They entered lunar orbit on December 24, completing ten orbits over twenty hours. During their Christmas Eve broadcast from lunar orbit¡ªone of the most viewed TV programs in history¡ªthey concluded with a reading from the biblical Book of Genesis. Two and a half hours after the broadcast, they executed the first trans-Earth injection, firing their engine to depart lunar orbit and begin the return journey. Apollo 8 splashed down safely in the Pacific Ocean on December 27, achieving NASA¡¯s first dawn recovery operation.
LLM_2:
On December 21, 1968, astronauts Frank Borman, James Lovell, and William Anders made history as the first crew to launch into space aboard NASA¡¯s powerful Saturn V rocket, riding the Apollo 8 mission beyond low-Earth orbit and toward the Moon. This groundbreaking flight marked humanity¡¯s inaugural journey to another world.

The spacecraft entered lunar orbit on Christmas Eve, December 24, circling the Moon ten times over nearly 20 hours. That evening, in a live broadcast viewed by an estimated billion people worldwide¡ªone of the most-watched television events of its time¡ªthe astronauts delivered a solemn reading from the Book of Genesis, capturing a moment of reflection amid the technological triumph.

Just over two hours after the broadcast, the crew ignited their service propulsion system in the first trans-Earth injection maneuver, a critical engine burn that propelled them out of lunar orbit and set them on course for home. After a successful return journey, Apollo 8 splashed down safely in the Pacific Ocean on December 27¡ªbecoming the first NASA mission to be recovered at dawn, a feat that underscored the precision and ambition of the space program during a pivotal chapter in the race to the Moon.

To construct structures from wood, make through-holes 
 
 ( holes that go all the way through the piece ) whenever 
 
 possible, and use nuts and bolts instead of screwing or 
 
 nailing directly into the wood and risking a split edge; the 
 
 farther from the edge the hole is, the less likely the wood is 
 
 to split. 
 
 
........... 
 
 
 My father taught about this on a sleepy afternoon back in 
 
'98. 
 
 The last part in particular, stayed a driving force in the years 
 
 to come. 
 
 
 My dad always said that people are prone to falling only if 
 
 they have nothing to hold on to. If you're at your limit, 
 
 whether that edge is at the threshold of sanity or the 
 
 buckling dams of anger and frustration, all you need is a 
 
 friend, a lover, a kind-hearted stranger. Hope. 
 
 Anything to pull you back from the abyss and embrace you 
 
 with a loving heart. 
 
 
 My plane crashed over the Appalachians twenty-six days 
 
 ago. 
 
 
 All of our food and water is gone. 
 
 
 I'm the sole survivor. 
 
 
 I'm an old, broken body. 
 
 
 I no longer have something to hold on to; I'm at my edge. 
 
 
 I am beginning to splinter like weathered wood. 
 
 
 
 I can see the hole opening its hungering, chasmic jaws. 
 
 Expanding toward me, with nothing to halt its approach but 
 
 its own trepidations. It has none. 
 
 
 
 And I have nothing left to hold on to.
LLM_1:
To build with wood, drill through-holes¡ªholes that pierce the entire piece¡ªwhenever possible. Use nuts and bolts rather than driving screws or nails directly into the grain, which risks splitting the edge. The farther the hole from the edge, the safer the wood.

My father shared this on a drowsy afternoon in ¡¯98. That last detail stayed with me, a quiet truth guiding years ahead.

He always said people fall only when there¡¯s nothing to hold on to. When you¡¯re at your limit¡ªwhether teetering at the edge of sanity or crushed beneath the floodwaters of anger and despair¡ªall it takes is a friend, a lover, a stranger with kindness in their eyes. Hope. Something¡ªanything¡ªto pull you back from the abyss and cradle you in warmth.

Twenty-six days ago, my plane went down over the Appalachians.

We¡¯ve run out of food. We¡¯ve run out of water.

I¡¯m the only one left.

An old body, broken by time and trial.

I have nothing left to hold on to. I¡¯m at the edge.

And I am beginning to splinter, like wood worn thin by weather and neglect.

I see the void opening its ravenous jaws, widening toward me, unstoppable¡ªunafraid. It knows no hesitation.

And I have nothing.
LLM_2:
To work with wood, you bore through¡ªit¡¯s the surest way. Through-holes, clean and complete, passing from one side to the other like a promise kept. Nuts and bolts hold better than nails driven blind into the grain, which can split the timber at its weakest edge. Keep the hole deep from the border, he¡¯d say, where the wood is strong enough to bear the pressure, to endure.

My father told me this on an afternoon thick with heat and drowsiness, somewhere in the amber hush of 1998. I remember the way his hands moved as he spoke¡ªcalloused, deliberate¡ªshaping truth from silence. That last part stayed: *distance from the edge means survival.* A quiet axiom, unspoken but felt, threading through the years like a seam beneath the surface.

He used to say people don¡¯t fall because they¡¯re weak. They fall because there¡¯s nothing to catch them. When the mind frays at the edges, when grief or rage floods the chest like rising water, it only takes one hand reaching down¡ªone voice saying *I¡¯m here*¡ªto keep a soul from vanishing into the dark. Not strength. Just connection. A single thread of light in the suffocating black.

Twenty-six days ago, the sky swallowed us whole.

The plane shuddered, then broke apart over the endless folds of the Appalachians. No warning. Just wind, and silence, and falling.

We¡¯ve eaten the last scrap. Drunk the final drop. The others didn¡¯t make it. I don¡¯t know how I did.

Now I sit among the wreckage, bones aching with cold and time, skin stretched thin over a frame worn down by more than hunger. I am ancient now, though my years aren¡¯t so many. Time bends strangely when you¡¯re waiting to die.

There¡¯s nothing left to hold on to. No rope, no name, no reason.

I¡¯m balanced on the lip of something vast¡ªa hollow so deep it doesn¡¯t echo. It simply listens. Waits. Gapes wide without hunger, without pity, because it needs neither. It just *is.*

And I feel myself coming undone.

Splintering inward, like old pine left too long in the storm¡ªfibers torn loose, grain pulled apart not with violence, but slow surrender. Each breath a crack forming deeper inside. Each memory a knot loosening.

I have no anchor.

No bolt, no brace.

Just the terrible stillness before the break.

- A new algorithm is proposed for training and inference.
- Experiments show that this method improves the performance of the mentioned methods.

## Weakness:

The left side of equation is a function of x, while the right side is the expectation on x, that means the right side is irrelevant to x.

- line 16, ¡®we outperform the state of the art methods¡¯
More experiments should be conducted to compare with some latest methods proposed in 2019-2020.

- page 5-6, Table 1-3
The improvement of this method is marginal.

	The reference [22] needs to be mentioned only once.

LLM_1:
The RBCC integrates a Bayesian network into a recurrent classifier chain framework, accompanied by a novel algorithm for training and inference. Experimental results demonstrate improved performance over existing methods.

**Weaknesses:**  
In Equation 1, the left-hand side is a function of \( x \), whereas the right-hand side computes an expectation over \( x \), rendering it independent of \( x \)¡ªthis raises a fundamental inconsistency that requires clarification.  
On line 16, the claim of outperforming state-of-the-art methods would be strengthened with additional comparisons to more recent approaches published between 2019 and 2020.  
As shown in Tables 1¨C3 (pages 5¨C6), the performance gains achieved by the proposed method are marginal, which may limit its practical impact.

**Minor Issue:**  
At line 100, reference [22] is cited redundantly and should appear only once.

**Suggestion:**  
Including illustrative figures¡ªsuch as an algorithmic workflow diagram or visualizations highlighting the advantages of the method¡ªwould enhance clarity and improve reader understanding.
LLM_2:
**Review Comment (Rewritten):**

The paper presents RBCC, a method that combines a Bayesian network with a recurrent classifier chain framework, along with a novel algorithm for training and inference. The approach is supported by experimental results showing performance improvements over existing techniques.

**Weaknesses:**  
There is a critical inconsistency in Equation 1: the left-hand side is expressed as a function of \( x \), while the right-hand side involves an expectation taken over \( x \), which eliminates dependence on \( x \). This discrepancy undermines the mathematical formulation and requires careful clarification or correction.  
The claim on line 16 regarding superiority over state-of-the-art methods would benefit from more up-to-date comparisons. Specifically, including recent approaches from 2019¨C2020 would strengthen the validity of this assertion.  
As evidenced by Tables 1¨C3 (pages 5¨C6), the performance gains of the proposed method are relatively modest. While statistically present, these marginal improvements may raise questions about the practical significance and broader impact of the approach.

**Minor Issue:**  
Reference [22] is cited twice at line 100; one instance should be removed to avoid redundancy.

**Suggestion:**  
To improve accessibility and intuition, the authors are encouraged to include illustrative materials¡ªsuch as a schematic diagram of the algorithmic workflow or visualizations demonstrating key advantages of RBCC. Such figures could significantly enhance reader comprehension and presentation clarity.

Justinas Gubinas, 23, and Nerijus Radavicius, 30, were both jailed for four-and-a half years last year.
Co-accused Ovidijus Kavaliauskas was found guilty of raping the woman while she was asleep.
Gubinas and Radavicius appealed, claiming the jury had been misdirected about how they could approach the video images taken on phones.
The offences took place in a farmhouse in 2014 where the three men were staying at the time.
The woman had agreed to go back to their house.
All three denied rape and claimed that the woman had consented to sex with them.
An element of the legal challenge was referred to a bench of five judges, including Scotland's two most senior judicial figures, the Lord Justice General and the Lord Justice Clerk.
They maintained that the trial judge, Lord Armstrong, had misdirected the jury on the way in which they could approach the video images taken on their phones.
The judge had told the jury to form a judgement about what the footage shown at the trial revealed and to form their own conclusions about what it depicted.
Defence lawyers argued that it was wrong to tell jurors that they could form their own view of what the images demonstrated.
The footage showed the woman in an intoxicated state and at one point in the accompanying audio recording she could be heard saying "no".
Lord Carloway, who heard the appeal with Lady Dorrian, Lord Menzies, Lord Brodie and Lord Turnbull, said: "Once before the fact finder, the recording's content is available as proof of fact.
"The fact finder is free to make such inferences from the audio or video components as would be open to any judge or jury hearing oral testimony descriptive of the same events. This does not convert the fact finder into a witness."
The senior judge said that once the provenance of images was established it became real evidence which a jury could use to establish fact, irrespective of concurring or conflicting testimony.
"Even if all the witnesses say that the deceased was stabbed in the conservatory, if CCTV images show that he was shot in the library, then so be it," he said.
Lord Carloway said the judges had paid particular attention to the sound reasoning of a Canadian Supreme Court decision which he said represented "an enlightened and sensible approach to video or audio recordings".
In the Canadian case a judge said: "So long as the videotape is of good quality and gives a clear picture of events and the perpetrator, it may provide the best evidence of the identity of the perpetrator."
Lord Carloway said the trial judge's directions to the jury were generally correct.
"The direction to the jury to form a judgement about what the images showed, just as if they would form a judgement about eye witness descriptions of what happened, was correct," he said.
"The statement that the jury could draw their own conclusions about what the images depicted was also correct."
LLM_1:
Justinas Gubinas, 23, and Nerijus Radavicius, 30, were each sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison last year for their involvement in a 2014 rape at a farmhouse where the three men were staying. Co-accused Ovidijus Kavaliauskas was convicted of raping the woman while she was asleep. All three denied the charges, claiming she had consented to sex after agreeing to return to their home.

Gubinas and Radavicius appealed, arguing that the trial judge, Lord Armstrong, had misdirected the jury on how to assess video footage recorded on mobile phones during the incident. The defense contended jurors should not have been instructed to form independent judgments about what the images showed. The recordings depicted the woman in an intoxicated state, and audio captured her saying "no."

A panel of five senior judges, including Scotland¡¯s Lord Justice General and Lord Justice Clerk, reviewed the case. Lord Carloway, delivering the ruling with Lady Dorrian, Lord Menzies, Lord Brodie, and Lord Turnbull, upheld the trial judge¡¯s direction. He stated that once authenticity is established, video and audio evidence constitute real proof from which juries can draw factual inferences¡ªjust as they would from eyewitness testimony.

"Even if all witnesses say the deceased was stabbed in the conservatory, if CCTV shows he was shot in the library, then so be it," Lord Carloway said, emphasizing the evidential weight of recordings. He cited a Canadian Supreme Court decision supporting the use of high-quality video as reliable evidence when it clearly captures events and individuals involved.

The court concluded that the trial judge¡¯s instructions were correct: jurors were properly directed to assess the footage and form their own conclusions about what it depicted, without becoming witnesses themselves. The appeal was dismissed.
LLM_2:
**Appeal Dismissed in Farmhouse Rape Case as Court Upholds Jury¡¯s Reliance on Video Evidence**

Two men, Justinas Gubinas, 23, and Nerijus Radavicius, 30, have had their appeal against conviction dismissed by Scotland¡¯s highest criminal court, reaffirming their four-and-a-half-year prison sentences for a 2014 sexual assault at a rural farmhouse.

The incident occurred while the three men¡ªGubinas, Radavicius, and co-accused Ovidijus Kavaliauskas¡ªwere staying at the property. Kavaliauskas was found guilty of raping a woman while she was asleep. All three defendants maintained throughout the trial that the encounter was consensual, asserting the woman had willingly returned to the house and agreed to sex.

During the original trial at the High Court, the jury heard mobile phone recordings captured during the night in question. The footage showed the woman in a heavily intoxicated state, with audio capturing her repeatedly saying ¡°no.¡± The authenticity of the recordings was not disputed.

Gubinas and Radavicius challenged their convictions, arguing that the trial judge, Lord Armstrong, had improperly instructed the jury on how to interpret the video evidence. Their defense claimed jurors should not have been permitted to form independent conclusions about what the footage depicted, particularly regarding the woman¡¯s condition and level of consent.

However, a panel of five senior judges¡ªincluding Scotland¡¯s Lord Justice General and Lord Justice Clerk¡ªunanimously rejected the appeal. Delivering the judgment, Lord Carloway, supported by Lady Dorrian, Lord Menzies, Lord Brodie, and Lord Turnbull, ruled that the trial judge¡¯s directions were legally sound.

¡°Once the authenticity of a recording is established, it constitutes real evidence,¡± Lord Carloway stated. ¡°Jurors are entitled to draw factual inferences from what they see and hear, just as they would from live witness testimony.¡±

Drawing a parallel, he added: ¡°Even if all witnesses say the deceased was stabbed in the conservatory, if CCTV clearly shows he was shot in the library, then that is the evidence the jury must accept.¡±

The ruling cited precedent from the Supreme Court of Canada, which recognizes high-quality video recordings as reliable evidence when they unambiguously document events and individuals involved. The Scottish court emphasized that jurors are not acting as witnesses when interpreting such material, but rather fulfilling their role as fact-finders.

The appeal judges concluded that Lord Armstrong had correctly directed the jury to assess the recordings objectively, without overstepping into expert analysis. As a result, the convictions were upheld, and the appeal was dismissed.

The decision reinforces the growing legal recognition of digital evidence in criminal trials, affirming its critical role in establishing truth when traditional testimony may be contested.

The South Korean tech giant reported an operating profit of 14 trillion won ($12bn; ?¡ê9.3bn) in the three months to June, up 72% on a year earlier.
Sales climbed 18% to 60 trillion won, buoyed by strong sales of smartphones including the new flagship Galaxy S8.
Analysts say the results indicate Samsung  has recovered from the disastrous Galaxy Note 7 recall.
That handset was axed after a battery fault led to some devices catching fire.
Also on Friday, Samsung launched a new phone in South Korea using parts from the Note 7 to "minimise the environmental impact" of its high-profile flop.
Some research firms predict that Samsung is set to overtake Intel as the world's biggest chipmaker by sales this year.
It has benefitted from both rising demand and prices for semiconductors, or memory chips, which are used in smartphones and computers.
The Note 7 debacle damaged Samsung's reputation and caused it to lose its position as the world's biggest smartphone maker in the first quarter.
Rivals such as Apple and China's Huawei, Xiaomi and Oppo gained market share following the recall.
Samsung has also seen its image dented by the arrest and ongoing trial of de-facto chief Jay Y. Lee over a political bribery scandal. Mr Lee denies the charges.

Revenue rose 18% year-on-year to 60 trillion won, fueled by strong global demand for flagship smartphones such as the Galaxy S8 and surging prices for memory chips.

The results mark a significant turnaround for the South Korean tech giant, signaling recovery from the reputational and operational setbacks caused by the 2016 Galaxy Note 7 crisis, when faulty batteries led to fires and a worldwide recall. In a sustainability-driven initiative, Samsung has begun reintroducing components from recalled Note 7 devices into a new smartphone model launched domestically, underscoring efforts to reduce electronic waste.

With continued momentum, Samsung is on track to overtake Intel this year as the world¡¯s largest semiconductor manufacturer by revenue¡ªa milestone that would underscore its dominance in critical areas of the global tech supply chain.

Despite the positive earnings momentum, Samsung continues to navigate broader challenges. The first quarter saw competitors¡ªincluding Apple, Huawei, Xiaomi, and Oppo¡ªgain ground in the smartphone market amid consumer hesitation following the Note 7 withdrawal. Additionally, the company remains under scrutiny due to the ongoing legal proceedings involving Jay Y. Lee, its de-facto leader, who was arrested in connection with a high-profile political corruption scandal. Lee has denied any wrongdoing, and the case continues to attract public and media attention in South Korea.

Nonetheless, the latest results reflect renewed consumer confidence and strategic resilience, positioning Samsung for sustained growth across both its mobile and semiconductor businesses.
