# # # # # # [ ] ( # dropcap ) 
 
 Hilary Flint was grinning by the time the barmaid came back with their drinks, the worst of the snow finally melting from their cloaks and the feeling in their hands returning. 
 
 He and Faith sat at a small table in a corner of the tavern away from the bustle of the bar and the crowded fireplace. The latter was popular tonight, the first winter storm bringing with it a chill from the icy north. Already a foot of snow had fallen, big fat flakes which clung to the hair and eyelash and melted where it touched naked skin. They'd just made it in time, reaching the town's outskirts before night compelled the watch to shut the gates. They would've been forced to pay the sentry to allow them in if they had n't, a necessary precaution in what was considered by most to be a wild stretch of territory. Stories of bandits and monsters alike were told in the halls and courts of the Fae, tales of savage human tribes and feral beasts that prowled the dark, waiting to ambush would-be travelers. From what Faith had seen most of those stories were bunk. *Most. * It was the knowledge of the remaining portion that kept her up at night. 
 
 `` This is Gregor's Mill, or at least what's left of it,'' Flint said, half-shouting over the fiddle and drum. `` Locals say Pre-Arrival it was called Gowen, something about some dead soldier or something. After the Arrival and the Collapse the village turned back to its original purpose. Lots of good lumber and a river which flows into the Grand River gives it a lifeline with the rest of the free villages. Past through here a few years back after spending a season salvaging in the old capital. We're still a good forty or fifty miles from No-Man's Land but human settlements start getting a bit sparse; only lone homesteads or the occasional trading post from here on out.'' 
 
 Faith nodded, taking in all information given in an effort at staying afloat. Politics she'd been born in, feuds and conspiracies a part of daily life growing up. But this life, a never ending struggle to survive against the dangers of hunger and famine, of beast and exposure was something she'd never been raised to endure. The edge between life and death was slim anywhere in the world, but here that edge seemed razor thin. 
 
 She did n't wear her hood indoors, the fire was warm enough that it would have looked strange for her to remain all bundled up, but kept her hair over her telltale ears. If anyone here bothered to pay any attention to her blood they did n't show it, and for that she was at least moderately grateful. This far north Fae were a rare sight, and usually an unwelcome one to the people who called these woods and fields home. 
 
 The barmaid had to weave past a table full of boasting loggers, hard men shaped by hard work. They bore the scars and calluses of their trade, ax and saw blade and splinter all marking their bodies. The maid carried a small tray and dipped down to place their drinks down. 
 
 `` A pint of stout for the sir, and a mug of mulled wine for the miss. Can I get you anything to eat?'' 
 
 Flint nodded, taking a sip of his beer as black as night. `` What do you have?'' 
 
 `` Hot mutton stew, slaughtered fresh this morning. We also have roasted capon with potatoes and vegetables as well as smoked whitefish with the same. Bread and butter comes with them all.'' 
 
 `` I'll take the stew,'' Flint said. 
 
 `` And I the chicken if you'll be so kind,'' Faith added. 
 
 The barmaid smiled and tucked her tray under her arm. `` Very good, miss, sir. I'll have them right out shortly.'' 
 
 Despite the gray in his beard Flint still watched her hips sway as she left. Toying with the gold band strung on a chain round his neck he sighed and turned to Faith. 
 
 `` Kid,'' he said. `` Whatever you do, whatever else you might forget or think is bullshit, do n't get fucking married. I got married once and regretted ever since.'' 
 
 `` Because you did n't love her anymore?'' 
 
 `` Because I *still* love her. Love is a funny thing, Faith, and every other problem in this world is due to it. Half the fucking songs are about it, wars have been waged because of it and it makes men do foolish things like write love songs and start wars. Do n't get married.''
LLM_1:
Hilary Flint was grinning when the barmaid returned with their drinks, the worst of the snow melting from their cloaks, feeling slowly returning to their numbed hands. He and Faith had claimed a small corner table away from the crowded bar and roaring fireplace¡ªtonight¡¯s gathering place for travelers fleeing the first winter storm, its icy breath sweeping down from the north. Already a foot of heavy snow blanketed the ground, flakes clinging to lashes and hair, dissolving against warm skin. They¡¯d arrived just in time, slipping through the town gates before nightfall sealed them shut. A few minutes later, they¡¯d have had to bribe the sentry¡ªan expected toll in these wild lands, where tales of bandits and monsters haunted Fae court gossip. Most were exaggerations, Faith knew. But not all. It was the truth behind the rumors that kept her awake.

¡°This is Gregor¡¯s Mill,¡± Flint shouted over the fiddle and drum, ¡°or what¡¯s left of it. Locals say it was called Gowen before the Arrival¡ªsomething about a dead soldier. After the Collapse, it reverted to its roots: timber and trade. Good lumber here, and the river feeds into the Grand, so they stay connected to the free villages. I passed through a few years back after salvaging in the old capital. We¡¯re still forty or fifty miles from No-Man¡¯s Land, but settlements thin out ahead¡ªjust lone homesteads and the odd trading post.¡±

Faith absorbed his words, struggling to keep pace. Politics she understood; feuds and courtly schemes were her birthright. But this life¡ªthis constant fight against hunger, cold, beasts, and exposure¡ªwas foreign. Death always loomed close in the world, but here the edge felt paper-thin.

She¡¯d lowered her hood indoors; the fire made bundling unnecessary. Still, she let her hair fall forward, concealing her pointed ears. If anyone noticed her Fae blood, they gave no sign¡ªand for that, she was quietly grateful. This far north, her kind were rare, often unwelcome.

The barmaid wove past a rowdy table of loggers, men carved by labor, their arms etched with scars from ax, saw, and splinter. Balancing a tray, she bent to set down their drinks.

¡°A pint of stout for the sir, and mulled wine for the miss. Anything to eat?¡±

Flint took a sip of his pitch-black beer. ¡°What¡¯ve you got?¡±

¡°Hot mutton stew¡ªfresh-slaughtered this morning. Roasted capon with potatoes and vegetables, or smoked whitefish with the same. Bread and butter with each.¡±

¡°I¡¯ll take the stew.¡±

¡°And I¡¯ll have the chicken, please,¡± said Faith.

The maid smiled, tucking her tray under her arm. ¡°Coming right out.¡±

Despite the gray in his beard, Flint¡¯s eyes followed her as she walked away. He toyed with a gold band on a chain around his neck, then sighed and turned to Faith.

¡°Kid,¡± he said, ¡°whatever else you forget, whatever you think is bullshit¡ªdon¡¯t get married. I did once. Regretted it every day since.¡±

¡°Because you stopped loving her?¡±

¡°Because I *still* love her. Love¡¯s a strange thing, Faith. Half the songs ever sung are about it. Wars start because of it. Makes men write poetry, fight duels, do stupid shit. Don¡¯t get married.¡±
LLM_2:
Snow wept from their cloaks in slow, dripping surrender as the barmaid set down their drinks, steam curling into the thick air. Hilary Flint grinned, fingers tingling back to life¡ªpins and needles dancing like embers rekindled. Across the table, Faith watched the firelight flicker in her companion¡¯s eyes, two pools of amber caught between memory and moment.

They¡¯d claimed a sliver of space in the corner, far from the press of bodies and the hungry crackle of the hearth. The inn was full¡ªoverflowing with travelers who¡¯d outrun the storm now clawing at the world beyond the walls. Winter had come early this year, howling down from the northern wastes with teeth of ice and breath like frozen steel. Outside, snow lay thick as a shroud, swallowing roads and silencing footsteps, each flake dissolving against warm skin like whispered secrets too fragile to survive.

They¡¯d slipped through the town gates just before curfew¡ªa narrow victory over timing and fate. A few minutes later, they¡¯d have been left to bargain with the sentries, coin or charm traded for shelter. That was the way out here, where law frayed at the edges and survival wore many faces: bandit, trader, ghost. The Fae courts spun tales of these lands¡ªwild things stalking moonlit paths, creatures born of old magic and older rage. Most of it was myth, Faith knew. But myths, she also knew, were often born from truth sharpened by fear.

¡°This place,¡± Flint called over the raucous jig of fiddle and drum, ¡°used to be Gregor¡¯s Mill. Or maybe it wasn¡¯t. Locals mutter about Gowen¡ªsome soldier buried beneath the roots, name lost to rot and rain. After the Collapse, names didn¡¯t matter much. Timber did. Trade did. The river runs fat here, feeds into the Grand, keeps the villages breathing. I passed through years ago, hauling relics from the dead capital. We¡¯re still miles from No-Man¡¯s Land, but ahead? Nothing but silence. Lone cabins clinging to the hills, smoke rising like prayers. And every so often, a post where men trade salt for stories.¡±

Faith listened, her mind working to map his words onto a world she hadn¡¯t lived. Politics, she could navigate blindfolded¡ªcourtly dances of betrayal and alliance, the quiet poison behind silk smiles. But this¡ªthe raw grind of hunger, the constant war against cold and tooth and claw¡ªthis was another language entirely. Death had always been a shadow in her world, but there it wore velvet gloves. Here, it walked bare-knuckled, breathing down your neck.

She¡¯d shed her hood inside, the fire¡¯s warmth making layers unnecessary. Still, she let her hair fall forward like a curtain, veiling the delicate points of her ears. If anyone noticed the telltale sign of Fae blood, no one showed it. No narrowed eyes, no muttered curses. For now, she was just another traveler seeking warmth. And that small mercy settled deep in her bones.

The barmaid moved through the crowd like a river through stone¡ªgraceful, unbothered. Loggers, broad-shouldered and scarred from years of ax and saw, roared laughter at her passing. She balanced her tray with practiced ease, bending slightly as she placed their drinks on the worn wood.

¡°A stout for the gentleman,¡± she said, setting down the dark pint, ¡°and mulled wine for the lady. Something to eat?¡±

Flint swirled the beer once, black as tar, then took a slow sip. ¡°What¡¯s good?¡±

¡°Mutton stew¡ªfresh-killed this morning. Roast capon with spuds and greens, or smoked whitefish, same sides. Bread and butter with all.¡±

¡°Stew for me.¡±

¡°The chicken, please,¡± Faith added softly.

The woman nodded, tucking her tray beneath her arm. ¡°Coming right up.¡±

Even as she turned away, Flint¡¯s gaze lingered¡ªjust a heartbeat too long. Then he touched the chain around his neck, fingers brushing a thin gold band that hung like a secret. He exhaled, low and heavy, as if pushing up from the bottom of a deep well.

¡°Listen,¡± he said, voice roughened by time and smoke, ¡°forget half of what I¡¯ve told you. Call the rest lies if you want. But this¡ª*this*¡ªyou hold onto.¡± He leaned in, close enough that the firelight painted one side of his face in flame. ¡°Don¡¯t get married.¡±

Faith blinked. ¡°Because you stopped loving her?¡±

He laughed¡ªshort, bitter, gone too soon. ¡°No. Because I *never* stopped. That¡¯s the curse of it.¡± His thumb rubbed the ring again, a silent ritual. ¡°Love¡­ it¡¯s not just poems and roses. It¡¯s the reason kings burn kingdoms. Men carve their names into trees and fight duels over glances. It makes fools of saints and turns cowards into heroes. And when it ends? Or worse¡ªwhen it *doesn¡¯t*? That¡¯s when it breaks you.¡±

He looked at her then, really looked, as if seeing not just the woman across the table, but the girl she once was, the woman she might become.

¡°So whatever else you do,¡± he murmured, ¡°don¡¯t make it official. Marriage is love with chains on.¡±

human: The goal of this study was to determine if the haptoglobin phenotype was predictive of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in diabetic mellitus (DM).Cardiovascular disease is the most frequent, severe, and costly complication of type 2 DM. There are clear geographic and ethnic differences in the risk of CVD among diabetic patients that cannot be fully explained by differences in conventional CVD risk factors. We have demonstrated that a functional allelic polymorphism in the haptoglobin gene acts as a major determinant of susceptibility for the development of diabetic microvascular complications.We sought to determine if this paradigm concerning the haptoglobin gene could be extended to CVD in DM. We tested this hypothesis in a case-control sample from the Strong Heart study, a population-based longitudinal study of CVD in American Indians. Haptoglobin phenotype was determined by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in 206 CVD cases and 206 matched controls age 45 to 74 years. Median follow-up was six years.In multivariate analyses controlling for conventional CVD risk factors, haptoglobin phenotype was a highly statistically significant, independent predictor of CVD in DM. The odds ratio of having CVD in DM with the haptoglobin 2-2 phenotype was 5.0 times greater than in DM with the haptoglobin 1-1 phenotype (p = 0.002). An intermediate risk of CVD was associated with the haptoglobin 2-1 phenotype.
LLM_1: This study investigated whether haptoglobin phenotype predicts cardiovascular disease (CVD) in individuals with diabetes mellitus (DM), given that CVD is the most prevalent and severe complication of type 2 DM and exhibits unexplained geographic and ethnic variation. Prior evidence indicates that a functional polymorphism in the haptoglobin gene influences susceptibility to diabetic microvascular complications, prompting examination of its role in CVD. Using a case-control design within the population-based Strong Heart Study of American Indians, haptoglobin phenotypes were assessed via polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in 206 CVD cases and 206 matched controls aged 45¨C74 years, with a median follow-up of six years. Multivariate analysis adjusting for conventional CVD risk factors revealed that haptoglobin phenotype was a significant independent predictor of CVD in DM. The odds ratio for CVD was fivefold higher in individuals with the haptoglobin 2-2 phenotype compared to those with the 1-1 phenotype (p = 0.002), while the 2-1 phenotype conferred intermediate risk.
LLM_2: This study examined the association between haptoglobin phenotypes and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk among individuals with diabetes mellitus (DM), in light of the substantial burden of CVD as a complication of type 2 DM and its unexplained disparities across geographic and ethnic populations. Building on prior evidence that a functional polymorphism in the haptoglobin gene modulates susceptibility to diabetic microvascular complications, the present analysis extended this hypothesis to macrovascular outcomes. A case-control design was employed within the population-based Strong Heart Study cohort of American Indians. Haptoglobin phenotypes were determined using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in 206 DM patients with incident CVD and 206 matched controls without CVD, aged 45¨C74 years, with a median follow-up duration of six years. Multivariate logistic regression models, adjusted for established CVD risk factors, demonstrated that haptoglobin phenotype independently predicted CVD risk in this population. Individuals with the haptoglobin 2-2 phenotype exhibited a fivefold increased odds of CVD compared to those with the 1-1 phenotype (odds ratio = 5.0, *p* = 0.002), whereas the 2-1 phenotype was associated with intermediate risk. These findings suggest that haptoglobin genotype may serve as a significant biomarker for CVD risk stratification in diabetic populations, particularly among high-risk ethnic groups.

The unreleased movie follows a clown who is sent to a concentration camp and told to lead children to their deaths.
Lewis, who has died at the age of 91, gave his copy of the film to the US Library of Congress.
In 2015, the library confirmed it would be shown to scholars and members of the public - but not before June 2024.
Some, however, are not prepared to wait that long.
"RIP jerry lewis, release 'the day the clown cried' immediately," wrote one Twitter user on Sunday.
"Is it horrible that my first thought upon hearing about Jerry Lewis's death is 'now they can release The Day The Clown Cried'?" asked Paul DeBruler.
Lewis directed the 1972 film and played the leading role - a clown who is arrested in Nazi Germany for drunkenly defaming Hitler.
The character is then thrown into a concentration camp, where he is beaten and forced to lead children into gas chambers.
Lewis kept what is believed to be the only copy locked in a private vault before donating it to the Library of Congress.
US comedian Harry Shearer, one of only a handful of people known to have seen the film, said he was "stunned" by how bad it was.
In 1992, he said: "This movie is so drastically wrong, its pathos and its comedy are so wildly misplaced, that you could not, in your fantasy of what it might be like, improve on what it really is."
The film's release was initially blocked by co-writer Joan O'Brien, according to the Lewis biography King of Comedy by Shawn Levy.
Later, Lewis himself didn't want the film to be shown, at least not in his lifetime, and rarely spoke about it.
On one of the few occasions he broke his silence, he said it was "bad, bad, bad" and would "never be seen".
"I was ashamed of the work and I was grateful I had the power to contain it all and never let anyone see it," he said in 2013.
"It could have been wonderful but I slipped up - I didn't quite get it."
"It ain't finished," he said in another interview in 2009. "No one's ever gonna see it.
"After I'm gone, who knows what's going to happen? [But] I think I have the legalese necessary to keep it where it is."
Last year, images from the film featured in a BBC documentary titled The Story of The Day the Clown Cried, and clips have emerged on YouTube.
Various purported versions of the script have been circulated online, inspiring both live readings and video re-enactments.
Lewis was famous around the world for his partnership with Dean Martin, his fund-raising for muscular dystrophy and his numerous hit comedies.
For all his attempts to keep it under wraps, though, his infamous Holocaust drama remains a source of continued fascination and debate.
Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

Despite this, some are calling for its immediate release. Following Lewis¡¯s death, social media users expressed curiosity, with one writing, ¡°RIP Jerry Lewis, release ¡®The Day the Clown Cried¡¯ immediately,¡± and another asking if it was wrong to think of the film upon hearing the news.

LLM_2:
Jerry Lewis, the legendary comedian and filmmaker who died at 91, left behind one of cinema¡¯s most enigmatic legacies: *The Day the Clown Cried*, a film so troubled it has never been officially released. The only known copy remains sealed in the U.S. Library of Congress, where Lewis himself deposited it under strict conditions.

In 2015, the library confirmed that the film would eventually become accessible¡ªbut not until June 2024, more than half a century after its completion. Until then, access is restricted to scholars under limited circumstances. Yet following Lewis¡¯s death, calls have grown louder for an earlier release.

On social media, reactions blended mourning with morbid curiosity. ¡°RIP Jerry Lewis¡ªnow please release *The Day the Clown Cried*,¡± one user wrote. Another admitted, ¡°Is it terrible to immediately think of that unreleased movie when I heard the news?¡±

Few have seen the full film, but those who have offer damning assessments. Comedian Harry Shearer, best known for *The Simpsons*, viewed a cut in the 1990s and described it as ¡°stunned¡± by its failure. He later called it ¡°drastically wrong¡±¡ªa tone-deaf mix of slapstick and tragedy set against the backdrop of the Holocaust.

Co-written by Joan O¡¯Brien, the screenplay initially faced resistance from her, who opposed its release on ethical grounds. But even after she relented, Lewis remained resolute. For decades, he refused to allow public screening, repeatedly calling the work ¡°bad, bad, bad¡± and expressing deep shame over its execution. In a 2013 interview, he conceded, ¡°I slipped up¡ªI didn¡¯t quite get it,¡± maintaining that the film was artistically incomplete and legally encumbered.

Despite his efforts to suppress it, *The Day the Clown Cried* has taken on a mythic status. Last year, brief excerpts appeared in a BBC documentary about Lewis, sparking renewed debate. Unauthorized script copies have circulated widely, inspiring staged readings and fan re-enactments around the world.

The enduring fascination stands in sharp contrast to Lewis¡¯s towering legacy: a comedic pioneer whose dynamic partnership with Dean Martin defined mid-century entertainment, and whose annual telethons raised billions for muscular dystrophy research.

Now, as the June 2024 deadline approaches, anticipation builds. When the Library of Congress finally unlocks the film, the world may at last see the project Lewis called his greatest misstep¡ªa cautionary tale from a master entertainer who, for once, miscalculated the bounds of taste and tragedy.

The tanker, which is yet to be built, will be called the USNS Harvey Milk, USNI News said.
It cited a notification signed by Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus.
Milk was one of the first openly gay politicians in the US and was killed a year after winning election to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors.
He served in the US Navy in his youth as a diving officer during the Korean War before being honourably discharged.
Milk was wearing his Navy belt buckle when he was shot dead.
Speaking in 2012, Milk's nephew Stuart Milk said such a move would send "a green light to all the brave men and women who serve our nation: that honesty and authenticity are held up among the highest ideals of of nation's military".
The news delighted San Francisco politician Scott Wiener, who has called for a ship to be named after Milk, saying it was an "incredible day".
"When Harvey Milk served in the military, he couldn't tell anyone who he truly was," he wrote.
"Now our country is telling the men and women who serve, and the entire world, that we honour and support people for who they are."
The idea is not without controversy. After the suggestion was first mooted critics said Milk would have disapproved of lending his name to a Navy ship, given his opposition to the Vietnam War.
Several other civil rights champions are also set to be honoured with ships bearing their names, USNI News said, including former Supreme Court Chief Justice Earl Warren and women's rights activist Sojourner Truth.
LLM_1: The yet-to-be-built tanker will be named USNS Harvey Milk, according to a notification signed by Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus, as reported by USNI News. Milk, one of the first openly gay U.S. politicians, was elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1977 and assassinated a year later. He had served as a Navy diving officer during the Korean War and was honorably discharged. He was wearing his Navy belt buckle when he was killed. His nephew, Stuart Milk, said in 2012 that naming the ship after him would send ¡°a green light to all the brave men and women who serve our nation: that honesty and authenticity are held up among the highest ideals of our nation's military.¡± San Francisco politician Scott Wiener, who has long advocated for the honor, called it an ¡°incredible day,¡± noting that while Milk could not be open about his identity during his service, the gesture now affirms that the country honors people for who they are. The decision has drawn criticism from some who argue Milk, a Vietnam War opponent, would have objected to having his name on a Navy vessel. Other civil rights figures set to be similarly honored include former Chief Justice Earl Warren and women¡¯s rights activist Sojourner Truth.
LLM_2:
The U.S. Navy will name a future fleet replenishment oiler *USNS Harvey Milk* in honor of the pioneering civil rights leader and former naval officer, according to a Department of the Navy announcement signed by Secretary Ray Mabus and first reported by USNI News.

Harvey Milk, one of the first openly gay elected officials in U.S. history, served on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors after his 1977 election but was tragically assassinated less than a year later. Before entering politics, Milk served as a diving officer in the Navy during the Korean War, earning an honorable discharge. Notably, he was wearing his Navy belt buckle at the time of his death¡ªa detail that underscores his enduring connection to military service.

The naming of the vessel has been widely praised as a powerful symbol of inclusion. In 2012, Stuart Milk, Harvey Milk¡¯s nephew and longtime advocate for LGBTQ+ rights, said the gesture would send ¡°a green light to all the brave men and women who serve our nation: that honesty and authenticity are held up among the highest ideals of our nation's military.¡± California State Senator Scott Wiener, who has championed the effort for years, called the decision ¡°an incredible day,¡± emphasizing that while Milk could not live openly during his military service, the honor reflects how far the country has come in affirming individuals for who they are.

Still, the move has drawn some criticism. Detractors point out that Milk was a vocal opponent of the Vietnam War and question whether he would have supported having a Navy ship bear his name. Nevertheless, the Navy has proceeded with the tribute as part of a broader initiative to recognize transformative American leaders. The *Harvey Milk* will join other ships in the John Lewis-class series named for prominent civil rights figures, including former Chief Justice Earl Warren and abolitionist Sojourner Truth.

The vessel is expected to serve as a symbol of both logistical strength and moral progress, reinforcing the Navy¡¯s commitment to diversity and service across generations.

human: Clinical studies indicate that patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) frequently share comorbidity with numerous chronic pain conditions. However, the sustained effects of PTSD-like stress over time on visceral nociception and hyperalgesia have been rarely studied, and the underlying mechanisms of stress-induced modulation of visceral hyperalgesia remain elusive. The purpose of this study was to investigate the characterization of visceral nociception and hyperalgesia over time in rats exposed to PTSD-like stress, and to explore the potential role of protein kinase C gamma (PKC¦Ã) in mediating visceral hyperalgesia following exposure to PTSD-like stress.On day 1, the rats exposed to single-prolonged stress (SPS, an established animal model for PTSD) exhibited an analgesic response and its visceromotor response (VMR) to graded colorectal distention (CRD) at 40 and 60 mmHg was reduced compared with the control group (all P?<?0.05). On day 6, the VMR returned to the baseline value. However, as early as 7 days after SPS, VMR dramatically increased compared with its baseline value and that in the controls (all P?<?0.001) and this increase persisted for 28 days, with the peak on day 9. Abdominal withdrawal reflex (AWR) scores were higher in SPS rats than in controls on days 7, 9, 14, 21 and 28 (all P?<?0.001). Intrathecal administration of GF109203X (an inhibitor of PKC gamma), attenuated the SPS-induced increase in both VMR and AWR scores on days 7, 14, 21 and 28 (all P?<?0.05). PKC¦Ã protein expression determined by immunofluorescence was reduced in the spinal cord within 3 days after the exposure to SPS (P?<?0.01), which returned to normal levels between days 4 and 6, and significantly increased from day 7, and this increase was maintained on days 14, 21, and 28 (all P?<?0.001), with the peak on day 9. In addition, Western blotting showed a consistent trend in the changes of PKC¦Ã protein expression.
LLM_1: Clinical studies show a high comorbidity between post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and chronic pain conditions, yet the long-term effects of PTSD-like stress on visceral nociception and hyperalgesia, along with their underlying mechanisms, remain poorly understood. This study investigated the temporal profile of visceral hyperalgesia in rats exposed to single-prolonged stress (SPS), an established PTSD model, and examined the role of spinal protein kinase C gamma (PKC¦Ã) in this process. On day 1 post-SPS, rats exhibited analgesia, with reduced visceromotor responses (VMR) to colorectal distention at 40 and 60 mmHg compared to controls (all *P*?<?0.05). VMR normalized by day 6 but increased significantly from day 7 onward (*P*?<?0.001), peaking on day 9 and persisting through day 28. Similarly, abdominal withdrawal reflex (AWR) scores were elevated in SPS rats on days 7, 9, 14, 21, and 28 (*P*?<?0.001). Intrathecal administration of GF109203X, a PKC¦Ã inhibitor, attenuated SPS-induced increases in both VMR and AWR scores at all measured time points (*P*?<?0.05). Immunofluorescence revealed decreased spinal PKC¦Ã expression within 3 days post-SPS (*P*?<?0.01), returning to baseline by days 4¨C6, followed by a significant increase from day 7 that persisted through day 28 (*P*?<?0.001), peaking on day 9. Western blot analysis confirmed these temporal changes in PKC¦Ã protein levels. These findings demonstrate that PTSD-like stress induces a delayed-onset, sustained visceral hyperalgesia temporally associated with upregulation of spinal PKC¦Ã, which may play a critical role in mediating stress-induced nociceptive sensitization.
LLM_2: Clinical evidence indicates a significant comorbidity between post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and chronic pain; however, the long-term impact of PTSD-like stress on visceral nociception and the underlying neurobiological mechanisms remain unclear. In this study, we examined the temporal dynamics of visceral hyperalgesia in rats subjected to single-prolonged stress (SPS), a validated animal model of PTSD, and investigated the involvement of spinal protein kinase C gamma (PKC¦Ã) in this process. Following SPS exposure, rats initially exhibited analgesia on day 1, as evidenced by reduced visceromotor responses (VMR) to colorectal distension at 40 and 60 mmHg compared to control animals (all *P* < 0.05). VMR magnitudes normalized by day 6 and subsequently increased significantly from day 7 onward (*P* < 0.001), with peak hyperalgesia observed on day 9 and sustained elevation through day 28. Similarly, abdominal withdrawal reflex (AWR) scores were significantly elevated in SPS-treated rats at days 7, 9, 14, 21, and 28 (*P* < 0.001). Intrathecal administration of GF109203X, a selective PKC¦Ã inhibitor, attenuated the SPS-induced enhancement of both VMR and AWR scores across all post-stress time points (*P* < 0.05), suggesting a functional role for PKC¦Ã in mediating nociceptive sensitization. Immunofluorescence analysis revealed a transient downregulation of spinal PKC¦Ã expression within the first 3 days post-SPS (*P* < 0.01), followed by restoration to baseline levels on days 4¨C6 and a subsequent marked upregulation beginning on day 7 (*P* < 0.001), which persisted through day 28 and peaked on day 9. These temporal changes in PKC¦Ã expression were corroborated by Western blot analysis. Collectively, these results indicate that PTSD-like stress induces a delayed-onset, persistent visceral hyperalgesia that coincides temporally with the upregulation of spinal PKC¦Ã, implicating this kinase in the central sensitization processes underlying stress-associated chronic pain.

human: The world¡¯s largest passenger cruise liner QE VIII sank in the Sahara desert, possibly killing all its 20,000 crew and 50 passengers.  The freak mishap occurred soon after the liner took a diversion, on advice from a lighthouse, following a severe storm in a passenger¡¯s teacup.  Unfortunately, the cruiser encountered sinking sand in the desert.  Unconfirmed reports stated that the cruise captain deserted the ship, like a rat, minutes before it sank into the hot sand.   But the captain¡¯s mistress, in a highly emotional statement from Dubai, said she was dead sure that her lover was among the victims.  Emergency rescue teams have been flown to the site to try and ensure the crew is safely evacuated.  Ecological experts have labeled the disaster ¡®monstrous.¡¯ The mishap will create a huge crater in the desert, an expert said. ¡®The accident will leave a void which cannot be replaced.¡¯  Private investigators believe that some prisoners from a nearby jail could have been digging a huge underground escape tunnel, which led to the unfortunate incident.  Most passengers are believed to be filthy rich Arabs who had just eaten their meals and were on to the deserts.   The media in the Gulf has blacked out news of the tragedy.
LLM_1: The world¡¯s largest passenger cruise liner, QE VIII, sank in the Sahara Desert, likely claiming all 20,050 souls on board¡ª20,000 crew and 50 passengers. The disaster followed a bizarre detour prompted by a lighthouse¡¯s advice after a storm erupted in a passenger¡¯s teacup. En route, the vessel plunged into shifting desert sands. Unconfirmed reports allege the captain abandoned ship moments before it disappeared, though his mistress from Dubai insists he perished with the rest. Rescue teams have been deployed to evacuate survivors, while ecological experts warn of lasting damage, calling the event ¡°monstrous¡± and predicting an irreversible crater in the desert floor. Investigators suspect nearby prisoners may have dug an underground tunnel for escape, weakening the terrain. Most passengers were wealthy Arab travelers, reportedly finishing their meals and moving on to dessert when the incident occurred. News of the tragedy has been suppressed in Gulf media.
LLM_2:
In what can only be described as a masterpiece of surreal storytelling, news has emerged¡ªthough not from where you¡¯d expect¡ªof the world¡¯s largest passenger cruise liner, the *QE VIII*, sinking. Not in the ocean. Not even near water. But deep in the heart of the Sahara Desert.

Yes, you read that right.

According to this increasingly outlandish account, the vessel¡ªcarrying 20,050 people (a curious ratio of 50 passengers and 20,000 crew)¡ªplunged into shifting desert sands after veering wildly off course. The cause? A storm. But not a meteorological one¡ªa ¡°storm in a teacup,¡± allegedly sparked by a disgruntled passenger. Guided, of all things, by the advice of a *lighthouse*¡­ in the desert.

Let¡¯s pause for a moment.

Lighthouses typically warn ships away from rocky shores. They don¡¯t usually sit atop sand dunes giving navigation tips to cruise liners crossing Africa. And yet, in this tale, the *QE VIII* reportedly followed such guidance straight into oblivion¡ªvanishing beneath waves of sand rather than sea.

The aftermath is equally fantastical. Rescue teams have been dispatched to scour the dunes for survivors. Ecologists are warning of ¡°irreversible damage¡± to the desert floor, citing a ¡°monstrous¡± crater left behind. Investigators are probing whether escaped prisoners dug an underground tunnel that destabilized the terrain¡ªbecause apparently, when your cruise liner sinks in the desert, structural sabotage is on the table.

Then there¡¯s the captain. Rumors swirl that he abandoned ship moments before its sandy demise. His mistress from Dubai, however, insists he went down with the vessel¡ªadding a touch of soap opera to an already theatrical disaster.

Most passengers, we¡¯re told, were wealthy Arab travelers who had just finished their main courses and were tucking into dessert when the ground gave way. And while global headlines might be expected to explode with such a story, it¡¯s curiously absent from Gulf media¡ªsuppressed, perhaps, or simply too absurd to report.

Now, let¡¯s be clear: **this never happened.**

There is no *QE VIII*. Cruise ships don¡¯t sail through deserts. Lighthouses don¡¯t operate in landlocked sandscapes. And storms in teacups, while metaphorically real, don¡¯t reroute ocean liners.

But that¡¯s precisely the point.

This piece reads like satire¡ªa sharp, absurdist jab at how misinformation spreads, how narratives warp, and how easily the unbelievable can sound plausible when dressed in the language of news. It mimics the tone of legitimate reporting so well that, for a fleeting second, you might question reality. That¡¯s powerful. And dangerous.

In an age of deepfakes, echo chambers, and viral falsehoods, stories like this serve as both entertainment and warning. They test our skepticism. Challenge our instincts. Remind us to ask: *Does this make sense? Where¡¯s the source? Who benefits from me believing this?*

So while the *QE VIII* may not have met its end in the Sahara, the story itself sails on¡ªas a clever parody, a linguistic illusion, and a timely reminder: not everything that sounds like news deserves to be believed.

Welcome to the era of narrative disruption. Read carefully. Think critically. And maybe¡ªjust maybe¡ªdouble-check if lighthouses come with GPS coordinates for desert routes.

This paper studies the following problem: How to train a certifiably robust classifier with ensemble methods? The authors considered two types of ensembles: the weighted-average ensemble and large-margin ensemble. They first derived theoretically sufficient and necessary conditions for robustness under two types of ensembles, with the conclusion that large confidence margin and diversified gradients are two factors which contributes to the robustness of ensemble models. Diversity-regularized training, a method of designing loss functions for training ensemble models, is proposed motivated by their theoretical findings. They applied this methodology to randomized smoothing, performed extensive experiments and showed non-trivial improvement over single model methods.

The paper is very well-written and provided extremely detailed discussion about many different aspects of the problem, both theoretically and empirically. From the reviewer's point of view, this is the strongest part of this work. I am very impressed by the level of detail in the appendix, which covers many interesting questions like under which scenario is WE better than MME, why is ensemble before smoothing better than ensemble after smoothing, to name a few. I wish more papers in the community are written in this way.

However, my current evaluation to this paper is a weak accept - it is a bit conservative, but I think it's based on some valid concerns, detailed below. 

The experimental results, while showed non-trivial improvements over single model baselines, may not be very strong. In most cases, the improvements are like 3~4%, sometimes a little over 5% in smaller radius settings comparing to smoothadv. This improvement is much smaller than some of the earlier works like smoothadv vs gaussian. Also in certain settings, the improvement over other single model baselines becomes very small (e.g. <2% over MACER in Table 12). The performance is also overall very similar to recent ensemble baselines like Liu et al. 2020. My understanding is that this shows a limitation of ensemble-based methods in certifiable robustness.

To summarize, despite of the limitations mentioned above, I think this work is overall good enough for recommending acceptance and thank the authors for their effort.

Minor comments:
I don't quite get the point of appendix D.3, in particular, the reasoning that trying to justify the uniform distribution assumption of confidence scores. The concentration of measure in high dimensional Gaussian does not imply the uniformity of confidence scores. Although I do understand this assumption as a concrete example  trying to get more interpretable results.
LLM_1:
This paper investigates how to train certifiably robust classifiers using ensemble methods, focusing on two types: weighted-average ensembles (WE) and large-margin ensembles (MME). The authors derive sufficient and necessary conditions for robustness under both frameworks, identifying large confidence margins and diversified gradients as key factors contributing to improved robustness. Motivated by these theoretical insights, they propose diversity-regularized training¡ªa loss design strategy for ensemble models¡ªapplied within the randomized smoothing framework. Extensive experiments demonstrate non-trivial improvements over single-model baselines.

The paper is exceptionally well-written, with thorough theoretical and empirical analysis. The appendix in particular stands out, offering detailed discussions on nuanced questions such as when WE outperforms MME and why ensembling before smoothing is more effective than after. This level of rigor and transparency is commendable and sets a high standard for reproducibility and depth in machine learning research.

Despite these strengths, my assessment remains a weak accept due to certain limitations. While the reported gains over single-model baselines are consistent, they are modest¡ªtypically 3¨C4%, occasionally exceeding 5% only at smaller perturbation radii compared to SmoothAdv. These improvements are notably smaller than those seen in earlier advances (e.g., SmoothAdv vs. Gaussian smoothing). Moreover, against recent ensemble-based approaches such as Liu et al. (2020), the performance gain is marginal, and in some cases (e.g., <2% over MACER in Table 12), nearly negligible. This suggests inherent limitations in current ensemble methodologies for certifiable robustness, which the work highlights but does not fully overcome.

One minor concern lies in Appendix D.3, where the argument for assuming uniform distribution of confidence scores relies on concentration of measure in high-dimensional Gaussians. However, this reasoning does not strictly justify uniformity of confidence outputs. While the assumption may serve as a simplifying example to yield interpretable results, its validity warrants further clarification.

Overall, the work is solid, well-motivated, and thoroughly analyzed, meriting acceptance. I thank the authors for their careful and thoughtful contribution.
LLM_2:
This paper presents a comprehensive study on training certifiably robust classifiers via ensemble methods, with a focus on two paradigms: weighted-average ensembles (WE) and large-margin ensembles (MME). The authors establish sufficient and necessary conditions for certified robustness within both frameworks, identifying key factors¡ªnamely large confidence margins and diverse gradient directions¡ªas central to enhanced robustness. Guided by these theoretical insights, they propose a diversity-regularized training strategy, which modifies the loss function to encourage such properties in ensemble models, implemented within the randomized smoothing framework. Empirical evaluations demonstrate consistent, albeit modest, improvements over single-model baselines.

The paper is exceptionally clear and technically rigorous, combining deep theoretical analysis with extensive experimental validation. The supplementary material is particularly strong, offering insightful discussions on subtle but important design choices¡ªsuch as the relative merits of WE versus MME, and the advantages of ensembling before rather than after smoothing. This level of transparency not only strengthens the paper¡¯s credibility but also promotes reproducibility, setting a high bar for work in this area.

Nevertheless, I arrive at a *weak accept* due to limitations in the magnitude and competitiveness of the reported gains. While the improvements over single-model approaches are statistically non-trivial, they are quantitatively small¡ªtypically in the range of 3¨C4%, with gains exceeding 5% only at smaller perturbation radii and relative to SmoothAdv. These margins are notably smaller than those achieved in prior methodological leaps (e.g., the gap between Gaussian smoothing and SmoothAdv). More critically, when compared to recent ensemble-based methods such as Liu et al. (2020), the performance advantage is marginal¡ªin some cases, less than 2% over MACER (see Table 12)¡ªand occasionally negligible. This raises questions about the scalability and practical impact of current ensemble strategies for certified robustness, an issue the paper thoughtfully surfaces but does not fully resolve.

A minor concern arises in Appendix D.3, where the justification for assuming uniform confidence score distributions rests on concentration of measure phenomena in high-dimensional Gaussians. However, this argument does not strictly imply uniformity in the output confidences of the model. While the assumption may be useful as a simplifying approximation to enable analytical tractability, its validity and potential implications should be discussed more carefully.

In summary, the work is well-conceived, theoretically sound, and empirically thorough. It makes a valuable contribution by clarifying the mechanisms through which ensembles improve robustness and by proposing a principled training strategy accordingly. Despite limited empirical gains, the depth of analysis and clarity of exposition justify acceptance. I appreciate the authors¡¯ careful and thoughtful approach to this challenging problem.

**January 27, 1967: Apollo 1 Crew Killed in Capsule Fire During Ground Test**

On the same day the United States and the Soviet Union signed the landmark Outer Space Treaty, NASA faced one of its darkest moments: a catastrophic fire during a pre-launch test claimed the lives of three astronauts assigned to the first crewed Apollo mission.

Command Pilot Virgil "Gus" Grissom, Senior Pilot Edward H. White II, and Pilot Roger B. Chaffee died when flames erupted inside their command module during a launch rehearsal at Cape Canaveral¡¯s Launch Complex 34. The accident occurred just weeks before their planned February 21 liftoff¡ªthe first piloted flight of the Apollo program aimed at landing humans on the Moon.

The fire, believed to have started from an electrical spark, spread with explosive speed through the cabin, which was pressurized with pure oxygen¡ªan atmosphere highly conducive to combustion. Trapped inside, the crew had no way to escape as intense pressure sealed the inward-opening hatch shut. Rescue teams arrived within minutes but were unable to open the door in time.

An official investigation board later identified critical design flaws in the spacecraft, including flammable materials used in the cabin interior and poor wiring practices. The inquiry also highlighted systemic oversights in safety procedures, particularly the failure to recognize the dangers of a high-pressure, 100% oxygen environment during ground operations.

In the aftermath, NASA grounded crewed flights for 22 months while engineers overhauled the Apollo capsule¡ªredesigning the hatch for rapid egress, replacing combustible materials, and revising emergency protocols.

Grissom, a veteran of both the Mercury and Gemini programs, was widely seen as a leading candidate to command the first lunar landing. His death, along with those of White¡ªthe first American to walk in space¡ªand Chaffee, a rookie astronaut on his first flight assignment, sent shockwaves through the space community and forced a sober reassessment of the risks inherent in human spaceflight.

The tragedy underscored the perils of pushing technological boundaries and reshaped NASA¡¯s approach to safety, ultimately paving the way for the success of later Apollo missions.

`` This does n't make any sense...'' I muttered to myself as I punched in the digits on my phone. `` Sell my soul to the devil... Stupid punk kids are going to get an earful, I ca n't believe they'd go this far...'' 
 
 I was stringing together the threats I would make about calling their parents, when someone actually picked up on the other end. 
 
 `` Welcome to Comcast customer service!'' chirped an automated voice. 
 
 The phone clattered to the floor as the overwhelming reality crashed over me -- my son had promised to get me a new cable provider, but I had no idea that he would ever condemn me to Comcast. The voice droned on in the background and I fell to my knees, devoid of hope of every receiving good cable, a repairman at a reasonable time, and above all, a real human on the phone.

But before I could summon righteous fury, a voice cut through¡ªbright, artificial, and utterly cheerful.

¡°Welcome to Comcast Customer Service!¡± it sang, all synthetic sunshine and programmed politeness.

The phone slipped from my fingers, clattering against the floor like a discarded relic. The room seemed to tilt. Suddenly, it all clicked into place: my son¡¯s vague promise of ¡°a better cable deal,¡± his nervous grin, the way he¡¯d rushed me to sign *something* during halftime. I¡¯d trusted him. And now, standing in the wreckage of that trust, I realized the horrifying truth¡ªI hadn¡¯t just been duped.

I¡¯d been condemned.

The automated voice prattled on, a loop of hollow assurances, while I sank slowly to my knees. Hope drained out of me like a severed connection. No crystal-clear signal. No repairman showing up within a three-day window. No, worse than that¡ªno human voice. Not today. Not tomorrow. Maybe never again.

Just silence, broken only by the soft, soulless hum of customer service purgatory.

The paper brings local model fairness into federated learning that allows clients to set its own ¡°fairness budget¡±. The model fairness is an important problem in recent machine learning communities to avoid the model being biased by the sensitive attributes. The problem is quite interesting and practical. It is not evident to see how to combine fairness with performance consistency in federated learning. The authors gave a solution easy to follow and performs well in logistic regression problems.  The paper is well organized and the ideas are easy to follow although it makes use of the existing techniques. 

I have the following comments:
1. The main algorithm 1 in Appendix for FCFL is presented in a centralized way. It would be better to present it from both the client and the server perspectives.  It is not clear from the main paper how to parallelize the calculations of FCFL.
2. The experiments part is a little bit weak as only logistic regression problems are considered. It would be better to show the neural network performance. 
3. It seems the definition of $\triangle DP_k$ in Eq. 2 is for binary classification. Just for curiosity, what does the  $\triangle DP_k$ look like for multiple classification problems?
LLM_1:
The paper introduces local model fairness into federated learning by allowing clients to define their own "fairness budget," addressing an important and practical challenge in mitigating bias with respect to sensitive attributes. The integration of fairness with performance consistency in federated learning is non-trivial, and the proposed solution is well-structured, easy to follow, and effective¡ªparticularly in logistic regression settings. While the approach builds upon existing techniques, the presentation is clear and logically organized.

However, several improvements can be made. First, Algorithm 1 in the appendix presents FCFL in a centralized manner; a decentralized formulation detailing both client- and server-side operations would enhance clarity, particularly regarding how computations are parallelized in practice. Second, the experimental evaluation is limited to logistic regression models; including results on neural networks would strengthen the empirical validation and demonstrate broader applicability. Finally, the definition of $ riangle DP_k$ in Equation (2) appears tailored to binary classification; the authors are encouraged to discuss how this fairness metric extends to multi-class settings.
LLM_2:
The paper addresses a timely and important challenge in federated learning by introducing the concept of local model fairness through client-defined "fairness budgets." This approach offers a practical mechanism for mitigating bias with respect to sensitive attributes in decentralized settings. The integration of fairness considerations with model consistency across clients is non-trivial, and the proposed framework is well-designed, clearly articulated, and effectively demonstrated¡ªparticularly in the context of logistic regression models. The method builds upon established techniques but presents them in a coherent and accessible manner, contributing to the readability and logical flow of the work.

That said, several aspects could be strengthened to enhance the technical rigor and broader impact of the paper. First, Algorithm 1, as presented in the appendix, describes the FCFL framework in a centralized fashion. A more explicit, decentralized formulation that delineates both client-side and server-side computations would improve clarity and better reflect the distributed nature of federated learning, especially regarding how operations are parallelized in real-world deployments.

Second, the experimental evaluation is currently limited to logistic regression. While the results are promising, extending the empirical analysis to neural network models¡ªparticularly those used in more complex downstream tasks¡ªwould significantly strengthen the validation and demonstrate the method¡¯s scalability and applicability beyond linear models.

Lastly, the fairness metric $  riangle DP_k $ defined in Equation (2) appears primarily suited for binary classification scenarios. The authors are encouraged to discuss potential extensions or adaptations of this metric in multi-class settings, which would broaden its relevance and applicability across diverse fairness-sensitive applications.

Addressing these points would further solidify the paper¡¯s contribution and increase its impact on both research and practice in fair and federated machine learning.

The European Committee on Social Rights (ECSR) says the hours UK children can work are "excessive".
Some local by-laws allow UK children as young as 13 to do "light work" like delivering newspapers or shop work.
But work considered light "ceases to be so if it is performed for an excessive duration", says the report.
UK law allows children to work up to 12 hours a week during term time, with a maximum of two hours on school days and Sundays.
It stipulates children should not work more than an hour before school and should not start work before 7am or finish after 7pm - but local by-laws can sometimes be less restrictive, the report found.
The Committee monitors how individual states apply the legally binding European Social Charter.
It is part of the Council of Europe which was set up by statesmen including Sir Winston Churchill to promote human rights in Europe and is completely separate from the European Union.
The Charter requires that during the school term, the time children may work must be limited "so as not to interfere with their attendance, receptiveness and homework", the report points out.
For example "allowing children aged 15 years, still subject to compulsory education, to deliver newspapers from 6am for up to two hours per day, five days per week before school is not in conformity with the charter", it adds.
The report also expresses concern about work by children during the school holidays.
Excessive working hours for children can risk "their health, moral welfare or education", it suggests.
In the UK, 15- to 16-year-olds can work a maximum of 35 hours a week in the school holidays, with a maximum of eight hours on weekdays and Saturdays and two hours on Sundays.
For 13- to 14-year olds, school holiday working times are restricted to 25 hours a week, with a maximum of five hours on weekdays and Saturdays and two hours on Sundays.
The Charter requires children in full-time education to have a two-week break from any work during the school holidays in a calendar year.
In the report, the committee asks the UK for confirmation that children have two consecutive weeks free from work during the summer holiday in the United Kingdom.
It asks the UK for more detailed information on how it monitors possible illegal employment of children and what sanctions are imposed against employers who do not comply with restrictions under the law.
The Department for Education did not directly address the ECSR's suggestion that the hours UK children are allowed to work are "excessive" but said there were "clear rules to protect school age children".
"They limit time that teenagers can spend working - especially within the school term," said a spokesman.
LLM_1:

While local by-laws permit 13-year-olds to perform "light work" such as newspaper delivery or shop duties, the ECSR warns such tasks cease to be light if performed for too long.  

UK law allows children to work up to 12 hours weekly during term time¡ªno more than two hours on school days and Sundays¡ªand prohibits work before 7am or after 7pm, or for more than one hour before school. However, the report notes some local regulations are less strict. The ECSR emphasizes that child labor must not interfere with attendance, learning, or homework, as required by the European Social Charter. It cites concern over 15-year-olds delivering newspapers from 6am for two hours daily, five days a week, calling it incompatible with the Charter.

The committee also raised concerns about holiday work. In the UK, 15- to 16-year-olds can work up to 35 hours per week in holidays¡ªeight hours on weekdays and Saturdays, two on Sundays¡ªwhile 13- to 14-year-olds are limited to 25 hours weekly, with five hours on weekdays and Saturdays and two on Sundays. The Charter mandates that children in full-time education must have at least two consecutive weeks free from work annually, prompting the ECSR to request confirmation that UK summer holidays include such a break.

Additionally, the committee seeks detailed information on how illegal child employment is monitored and what penalties employers face for non-compliance.  

In response, the Department for Education defended existing rules, stating they provide clear protections for school-age children by limiting working hours, particularly during term time.

**UK Faces Criticism Over Child Work Hours Amid Education and Wellbeing Concerns**

The European Committee on Social Rights (ECSR) has raised serious concerns about the United Kingdom¡¯s regulations permitting extended working hours for children, warning that current policies may jeopardize their education, health, and overall development.

While UK law allows 13-year-olds to engage in so-called "light work"¡ªsuch as delivering newspapers or assisting in shops¡ªthe ECSR cautions that such tasks lose their "light" designation when carried out for excessive durations. The committee emphasized that child employment must not interfere with school attendance, academic performance, or rest, in accordance with the European Social Charter.

Under existing rules, children of school age may work up to 12 hours per week during term time¡ªlimited to two hours on school days and Sundays¡ªand are prohibited from working before 7 a.m. or after 7 p.m., or for more than one hour before school begins. Younger teens aged 13 to 14 are permitted up to 25 hours per week during holidays, with no more than five hours on weekdays and Saturdays and two on Sundays. 

Despite these limits, the ECSR has called on UK authorities to confirm whether children are guaranteed at least two consecutive weeks free from work each year, as required by the Charter to ensure adequate rest and family time.

In response, the Department for Education maintained that current regulations offer strong protections for young people, particularly through strict caps on working hours during the academic term. A spokesperson reiterated the government¡¯s commitment to balancing limited work experience opportunities with the priority of education and child welfare.

The findings come amid growing international attention on youth labor practices, with the ECSR urging the UK to align its policies more closely with European social standards.

Special Report: The Technology of Business
World Cup 2014 to be most hi-tech ever
Battery technology playing catch-up
Councils 'wasting millions' on IT
Tech promises sustainable healthcare
Mobile brightening Africa's future
Got one? Good. Congratulations. Chances are that by plucking that number out of the ether you have done a better job than Google of predicting the percentage increase in the number of flu-like illnesses that will strike Americans over the next few weeks.
That's right. You, armed only with your puny brain, can outdo a multi-billion dollar corporation that employs some of the smartest people in the world.
This example might seem trivial, but many think it matters because of the status of Google Flu Trends (GFT), once seen as the shining example of the power of so-called big data.
The data it uses to make predictions about how many will be sneezing and wheezing a week or so ahead is drawn from search terms, blog entries and messages shared via social media - so-called unstructured data.
This is very different to the structured and slow stream of information gathered from forms filled in at surgeries and hospitals that, before the rise of big data, were how predictions were made.
And the problem is, GFT turned out not to be terribly accurate.
In a run of 108 weeks, GFT wrongly predicted the number of flu cases 100 times, revealed a recent study.
Sometimes its estimate was double the number of actual flu cases recorded by US doctors. Hence the reason anyone can do better by plucking a number out of thin air.
Yet this unstructured data humans put online is exactly the type of stuff that companies want to analyse when they kick off their own big data projects.
Many corporations are keen to use those garbled knots of human sentiment to monitor how their brands are faring online, and to tweak their operations accordingly when they spot commercial opportunities or potential PR disasters.
Before now, those giant data sets had been hard to unpick. GFT seemed to suggest that with the right tools it could unlock all kinds of useful predictions.
Not only that, but those predictions could be uncovered quickly and cheaply.
Why did GFT go so wrong and what implications does this have for other big data projects?
"There's no such thing as clean and stable data," said statistician Kaiser Fung who has written extensively about the pitfalls that can dog big data projects.
What he means by "clean and stable" is that it is a mistake to think that the data Google gathered for GFT today is the same as it gathered last week, last month or last year.
Google regularly tweaks the algorithms it uses to index online life and, as a result, may be sampling very different things month to month, adding a degree of instability - spots of dirt as it were - to that dataset.
The same is true of any big data set gathered by anyone, he said.
All will be tainted in some way as they will miss out something simply because of the quirks of the underlying code used to parse and index web pages, social media messages and blog posts.
That will be particularly true if companies buy in their data from different sources and then treat it as all one corpus.
"I have never come across a complete data set," he said. "Often times the only reason why people believe their data is clean is because they have never looked at it."
Companies in possession of a huge corpus of data can assume that all the information they need is in it. Sadly, he said, this "N=all" assumption is wrong.
"It is much better to assume that the data has holes and flaws than it is to assume it is complete."
Any company starting a big data project would do better to look at the data they have gathered and clean it up before any analysis starts.
There are other good reasons for scrutinising that mass of information about customers, says Patrick James, a partner in consultancy Ernst and Young's consumer practice.
"There's a customer backlash about to happen," he says. "It's against the big part of big data."
More and more people are getting less and less happy about simply surrendering information and getting nothing in return, he maintains.
Increasingly, consumers and customers will attempt to hold back their data, limit what they share online or simply give the wrong answers when they sign up for a service or are quizzed about their life and habits, he believes.
The tens of thousands of people who filled in a form to make Google expunge their data from its index was evidence of that growing desire to disappear, says Mr James.
If this trend grows, it could mean data sets get skewed and become less useful for those big projects.
These early days of big data might prove to be its golden age.
"Data has never been cheaper than it has been today and it's only going to get more expensive," says Mr James.
So, if data is not the key to a good project, what is?
"Too many big data projects are started by the IT departments in companies that want to play with new technologies like Hadoop," says Dr Laurie Miles, head of analytics at big data specialist, SAS.
"That's led to scepticism, because in the history of IT projects a lot of them have been failures."
Instead of the technology coming first, anyone embarking on a big data project needs to know why they are doing it before they sign off on any expenditure by the IT folks, he argues.
"A big data project is not going to deliver any benefit unless you focus on a specific problem."
That focus can stop a project running away with itself and ensure it produces results that impinge on a real business issue, he says.
Spotting fraudulent credit card use requires a very different approach to analysing the performance of elite rowers - SAS is helping with both.
"We analyse credit card data at the point of sale, and you need that quickly," says Dr Miles. "With British Rowing we have a couple of weeks to to give them answers."
Knowing the response can help define the technology needed to underpin that big data project.
"Often you do not need to spin up a massive IT infrastructure to make this work," he says. "That's just as well, as real time results are really expensive."
LLM_1:
Google Flu Trends, once hailed as a breakthrough in big data, has proven less accurate than expected, mispredicting flu levels 100 times in 108 weeks¡ªsometimes doubling actual case counts. Unlike traditional clinical data, it relies on unstructured online content like searches and social media, which change unpredictably due to shifting algorithms and user behavior. Statistician Kaiser Fung warns that no data is truly "clean or stable," emphasizing that all datasets contain gaps or biases, especially when aggregated from multiple sources. Assumptions that large datasets are complete¡ª"N=all"¡ªare often flawed; scrutiny and cleaning are essential before analysis.

Patrick James of Ernst & Young highlights growing consumer resistance to data collection, with users increasingly withholding or falsifying personal information, threatening data quality. This backlash may undermine the reliability of future big data initiatives. While data remains cheap today, its cost is likely to rise, potentially marking these early years as the golden age of big data.

Dr. Laurie Miles of SAS stresses that successful big data projects must begin with clear objectives, not technological experimentation. Too many initiatives start with IT departments adopting tools like Hadoop without addressing specific business problems. Effective projects focus on defined goals¡ªsuch as detecting credit card fraud in real time versus analyzing athlete performance over weeks¡ªwhich in turn determine the necessary infrastructure. Often, extensive IT systems aren't needed, particularly since real-time processing is costly. Success lies not in volume or technology, but in purpose-driven analysis.
LLM_2:
**Google Flu Trends Falters, Highlighting Broader Challenges in Big Data Reliability**

A once-celebrated example of big data innovation, Google Flu Trends (GFT), has come under scrutiny after repeatedly overestimating flu activity¡ªfailing to accurately predict actual case levels in 100 out of 108 weeks, at times reporting double the true number of cases. The shortcomings underscore growing concerns about the reliability of data derived from unstructured digital sources such as search queries and social media.

Unlike traditional surveillance methods that rely on clinical reports and laboratory confirmations, GFT uses algorithms to infer flu trends based on online behavior. However, experts say this approach is vulnerable to fluctuations in user habits and platform algorithms, making the data inherently unstable. 

¡°Data is never truly clean or stable,¡± said statistician Kaiser Fung, who warns that all datasets¡ªespecially those aggregated from diverse digital streams¡ªcarry hidden biases and gaps. He cautions against the common misconception that massive datasets represent a complete picture, or what some call ¡°N=all.¡± In reality, rigorous validation and preprocessing remain essential before any meaningful analysis can occur.

The integrity of big data is further threatened by shifting public attitudes toward privacy. Patrick James, an analytics leader at Ernst & Young, notes a rising trend of consumer resistance: individuals are increasingly withholding personal information or providing false details when prompted for data. This growing skepticism could erode the quality and representativeness of future datasets, potentially undermining large-scale predictive models.

James also suggests that while data collection remains inexpensive today, it may not stay that way. As regulatory pressures mount and public trust wanes, the cost of acquiring reliable data is likely to rise¡ªpossibly marking the current era as the "golden age" of big data.

Meanwhile, Dr. Laurie Miles of SAS emphasizes that successful data initiatives must be driven by clear business objectives¡ªnot technological novelty. Too often, organizations begin with tools like Hadoop without first defining the problem they aim to solve. ¡°Starting with technology leads to solutions in search of a problem,¡± she said.

Instead, effective projects begin with specific goals¡ªsuch as real-time detection of credit card fraud versus long-term analysis of athletic performance¡ªwhich then inform infrastructure needs. In many cases, expensive, high-volume systems are unnecessary; real-time processing, while powerful, comes with significant costs. The key to success, experts agree, lies not in data size or computing power, but in purposeful, well-defined analysis.

As the limitations of early big data ventures become clearer, the focus is shifting from scale to strategy¡ªhighlighting the need for discipline, transparency, and accountability in an age defined by information abundance.
